BRIDGEWATER LIBRARY
bookplate

The new Jewel of Health, wherein is contained the most excellent Secrets of
Physic and Philosophy, divided into four Books. In the which are the best
approved remedies for the diseases as well inward as outward, of all the
parts of man's body: treating very amplye of all Dystillations of Waters, of
Oils, Balmes, Quintessences, with the extraction of artificial Saltes, the
use and preparation of Antimonie, and potable Gold. Gathered out of the best
and most approved Authors, by that excellent Doctor Gesnerus. Also the
Pictures, and manner to make the Vessels, Furnaces, and other Instruments
thereunto belonging. Faithfully corrected and published in English, by George
Baker, Chirurgian.

ALCHYMYA


Printed at London, by Henry Denham.

1576.

VERO NIHIL VERIVS
blazon or coat of arms

To the Right Honorable, Virtuous, and his singular good Lady, the Noble
Countess of Oxeforde. etc. your humble servant wishes long life, prosperous
health, and daily increase of Honor.
IT IS WRITTEN (RIGHT Honorable and my singular good Lady) that Philip King of
Macedonia rejoiced greatly when his son Alexander was borne, because his
Empire should not lack a governor after his death, but herein he rejoiced
much more, that his son was borne in the time of Aristotle that learned
Philosopher, by whom he was taught and instructed ten years: And in like
manner it fares now with me, as with the King of Macedonia, and no less is
my joy* than the delight of that mighty Prince. Herein I do rejoice, that
this work of Dystillation is now finished to the profit of my country,
wherein great study and long labor has been earnestly bestovved. But I
rejoice much more that it is finished in the time of you my Honorable,
virtuous, and good Lady, to whose learned view and favorable protection I
offer this Book, as a due testimony of my serviceable heart, and as some
fruits of my poor paynfull study and practice, vvishing that it were in
value counteruayle able to the condign demerites of your so Honorable
expectation, so as every line, in respect of my loyalty, might supplye a nevve
Jewel for your Nevve years gift, albeit, you have no need of Gold and
Jewels, abounding honorably in all riches: Notvvithstanding, this book may
be truly termed the nevve Jewel of health, which before this day was never
seen or published abroad by any other man. This nevve Jewel will make the
blind to see, and the lame to walk. This new Jewel will make the vveake
to become strong, and the old crooked age appear young and lustye. This nevve
Jewel will make the foul seem beautiful, and the withered faces shevve
smoothe and fair, yea, it will heal all infirmities, and cure all pains in
the whole body of man. What is it to have lands and houses, to abound in
silver and gold, to be decked with Pearls and Diamondes, yea, to possess
the whole world, and lack health the principal Jewel. Not without cause
therefore Agamemno^ the wise and famous Captain of the Greeks did highly
esteem and reward Machaon and Podalirius, by whose cunning skill in
Chirurgerie, thousands vvorthie Creekes were saved alive, and healed, which
else had dyed and perished. But why do I here name Agamemnon, or the Greeks,
when as no age can be without Physic, no person can live without
Chirurgerie, no country can mysse these noble mysteries. Wherefore I at this
time to pleasure my country and friends, have published this nevve Jewel
under your Honorable protection, that it may more easily be defended against
Sycophants and fault finders, because your wit, learning, and authority has
great force and strength in repressing the curious crakes of the envious and
bleating Babes of Momus charm.

Your honors humble and obedient servant. George Baker.


George Baker to the Reader.
GEntle Reader, although I have given the onset to publish in our own natural
tongue, this most excellent work of Distillation, for which cause, it should
not be the less esteemed, although some more curious than wise, esteem of
nothing but that which is most rare, or in hard and unknown languages.
Certainly these kind of people cannot abide that good and laudable Arts
should be common to many, fearing that their name and practice should decay,
or at the least should diminishe. The intension truly of such persons seems
much like them which gape for all, and would all have, leaving nothing to any
body, but that which they must needs forgo, not considering that we are not
borne for our selves only, as Plato says, but for the profit of our
country. Surely, if that I did not fear to be to long in this Preface, I
would prove how all Arts and sciences may be published in that tongue which
is best understood: as for example, Hippocrates, Galen, Paulus Aegineta,
Aecius, were Grecians, and wrote all in the Greek, to the perfect
understanding of their country men. Also Cornelius Celsus being a Latinist,
wrote in the Lati^e. Auicen and Albucrasis, Arabians, wrote in the Arabicke
tongue. The eternal fame of which worthy men shall never be extinguished or
drowned in oblivion, nor their noble works for ever be out of remembrance. For
what man is as yet alive that ever was able to counteruayle them, yea the best
learned in our days, do most highest esteem of them above all, without whose,
works all Physicians in the world be but blind, and not able to make any
perfect Art. Peradventure some will object and say, that if we were without
their works, there are other of later writers which should suffice. To the
which I will answer, that they have written nothing, but that their ground
was first laid by them, and further, as M. John Canape D. of Physic says, I
will give them this gift, except they first read Hippocrates and Galen, they
shall never understand what they read, nor make any perfect work. Therefore
not without good cause Guido calls Galen the lantern of light. And now in
these our days, we see how other Nations do follow their examples. For what
kind of science or knowledge ever was invented by man, which is not now in
the Italian or French* And what more prerogative have they than we English men
(of the which many learned men have made sufficient proof within th^se few
years, fully to furnish and satisfy our Nation with many goodly works.) For
our English is as meet and necessary for us, as is the Greek for the
Grecians, though in the translation we be constrained to make two or three
words sometime for one. For if it were not permitted to translate but word for
word, the^ I say, away with all translations, yt which were great loss to the
common weal, considering that out of one language into another have been turned
many most excellent works, the which the best learned have both received and
approved to the singular commodity of all men. And among all the works which
have been translated into our native tongue, I do think concerning the
matter, there was never the like to this as yet. For herein you shall learn
the manner to separate by Art the pure and true substance as well manifest as
hidden, the which in Physic is a great help to the taking away of diseases,
hard or rebellious to be cured. And moreover, that by the Chimicall Art,
those medicines which are hard and hidden, their forces and virtues are
plainly manifested and proved, and the gross juice being mingled with the
subtle and fine substance, are thereby digested and separated, as we may see
by the drawing of the oil of Gold, Iron, Copper, or Tynne. Also by
Distillation are corrected the malignitie or venomous qualities thereof, as in
oils of Quicksiluer, of oil of Vitrioll, Antemonie, artificial Saltes, and
many other purging medicines. Furthermore, we see plainly before our eyes,
that the virtues of medicines by Chimicall distillation, are made more
vailable, better, and of more efficacy than those medicines which are in use,
and accustomed. In trial of the which, we do daily prove to our great
credit, and our pacients comfort. For make trial between the one and the
other, and you shall see that the decoctions, Juices, Syrupes, or such like,
shall never come near to the dystilled waters, Oils, Balmes, artificial
Salts, and extraction of Roots, leaves, flowers, and fruits, of wood,
Barks, Gummes, Metals, and such others, so that two or three drops of the
oil of Sage does more profit in the Palsy: Three drops of the oil of
Corrall for the falling sickness: Three drops of the Quintessences of Pe^rle
for the Sincope or swounding: Three drops of the oil of Brimstone or
Turpentine for the Astmatikes: One drop of the oil of Cloves, for the cold
pain in the teeth: Three drops of the oil Ammoniacke for the diseases of
the spleen: One dram of the water of the oil or salt of Guaiacum, for the
French pox. One dram of the oil of Walwort for the gout: Three drops of
the oil of Iron for the Dysenteria, or other white fluxes: Three drops of
the oil of Crystal for the stone: Three drops of the oil of Cloves or Baye
berries for the Cholicke: Three drops of the oil of Antimonium for the
Leprosy, does more than one pound of those decoctions not dystilled. And
another thing is to be noted, that the diseased people, principally those which
are delicate, do detest all things which do not agree to their minds, and
delight not only in the pleasantness of the taste, but also the sight of the
eye, and the littleness of the quantity of the medicine, the which I think,
no man will deny. But this I will say, that through the fire there is some
hot quality in the medicine, but that quality is easy to be corrected, as
in the administering of them are plainlye taught. Peradventure some in the sight
of the furnaces, and other vessels will be loathe to meddle with so busy
matters, as the preparing of the Mettalles, and drawing of Quintessences. For
the which look what excellent medicine any stands in need of, there be in
this City which are most excellent in the preparing or drawing of any of them,
to whom if you resort, they will faithfully deal, among whom none to be
dispraysed. I do know some most excellent, as one master Kemech an English
man dwelling in Lothburie, another, master Geffray, a French man dwelling in
the Crouched friars, men of singular knowledge that way, another named John
Hester dwelling on Powles wharfe, the which is a paynfull traueyler in those
matters, as I by proof have seen, and used of their medicines to the
furtheraunce of my Pacients healthes, and also one Thomas Hill, who for his
excellent knowledge in this Art, is not to be left out, who did also take
pains in this work, but before it could be brought to perfection, God took
him to his mercy: There are yet others excellent men, which for brevity I
leave at this present. so finishing this my simple Preface, desiring God to
further the study of all those which faithfully and truly mean in the
exercise of this so noble an Art, desiring all those which shall find any
fault, that they will friendlye admonish me thereof, or else to note them in
the margent of their own books for their private use and commodity, till
such time as it shall be new printed again, and then if it shall please them
to give me their old Books so corrected, I will deliver them new for them.
And as for those find faults, which will do nothing themselves, I wey them
not, for I had rather be serviceable to my Country, than to please some
particular persons, as the Lord does know, who rules and guydes us all in the
right way. Amen. From my house in Bartholmewe lane beside the Royal exchange
in London, this xxj. day of Februarye. 1576.

Finis Tabulae.
The first Book of Dystillations, containing the most excellent secret
remedies for all diseases, with the rare forms of many Vessels and Furnaces,
serving for Dystillations, lively set forth in the same.
What Sublyming or Dystillation is, and what especially in the same ought to be
considered. The first Chapter.
THe Arabians (if we may credit the learned Physician Fumanellus) were first
author^ and inuentors of the Art of Sublyming, which some do name Drawing or
Distilling, and others (as the Chymistes) having regard and consideration to
another end, do term the same, both the Chymick and Chimistick Art: that is,
a sep^rating and drawing of iuyces, and other moystures more subtle, out of
the most kinds of things. And they not only were first inuentors (although the
worthy man Mathiolus be of a contrary opinion, that none of the ancient
Physicians left any monument of this Art) but by their search, diligence, and
long continuance of time, endeavored to increase the same with many worthy
secrets, and other matters right profitable: and those to none other intent and
end, than for the only health and benefit of man. But Dystillation, as writes
Ioannes Langius in his Epystles, is the seperating and running forth of a
subtle moisture. First, by the force of heat into a vapor, which hanging in
the head, and thickeneth after by the cold air, is so caused to fall down to
the Channel or Gutter of the head, and from thence guided to run unto the
nose, does on such wise dystill by dr^ppes, into a narrow mouthed Receyuer
standing under. An other Chemist does report, the Art of Distilling to be none
other, than only a seperating of Elements, as the Air from Water, the water
from fire, the fire from earth, and the pure from the impure, and to bring also
those matters imperfect, to a perfitenesse, through help of this Art. The
le^^ned Cardanus defines Dystillation to be a changing of bodies into a
thy^ner substaunc^, the quality yet remaining, and the commodities of
Distillation to be so great and many, that scarcely any thing can be found^
comparable to it, in that it seperateth the unlike parts, and delivers the
worthyer from corruption: and those matters which are imperfect, this by
attenuating makes perfect: also those which are divided, does this join into
one substance, both in qualities and properties, although the bodies be myxed.
Besides, this Art has invented many profitable and excellent things for man's
l^fe: yea, the same in Phi^^cke has found out rare and marvelous secrets,
and of those greatly to be esteemed, if any prepare them orderly, and according
to Art. This mann^r of doing, do some Chymistes term by another ^ame, to
sublyme, which signifies no other matter, than to separate the parts more
light and thynne, from those heauyer and thicker, and the working of this
requires so to do, that the bodies or matters whose substance is impure and
gross, be (...) pure, fair, and clear, or the earthly parts euilly (...)
and conjoined, or otherwise overmuch confused, and shed through all the
substance of the Bodies, be drawn, gathered, and better fixed together, in
such manner, that those separated by heat, each may abide a part at the bottom
of the Lymbecke.

An other Chymiste (as it should seem of more experience) does define this
manner of working to sublyme, on this wise, that the same (being a second
degree very principal unto the ch^^nging of many natural matters) serves to
separate the thynne and pure parts, from the gross and heavy substaunces, as
Distillation does: so that thro^gh this doing, is the aptest substance of the
grosser Bodies extenuated and fined, that is, the thynnest, lightest, and
purest part, from the superficial matter, being next to the grosser substance
of the Body, raised and drawn up to the head by force of the heat: next to
which, are those parts, that in pureness nyghest agree to the first
substance: so that the third and last matter being both heauyest and grossest,
and containing the earthly parts in it, requires then a mightyer force and
stronger heat of fire, through which, the same so seperateth and sends forth
wholye all the liquide matter or substance yet remaining, which thoroughly
drawn forth, there does after remain none other, than a substance wholly dry
(much like to ashes) in the bottom of the Cucurbite or Glass body: Insomuch
that out of every moist substance, or Body by distillation, there is a
certain crude or raw waterishnesse, or rather Flegmaticke matter, at the
first sent forth, next to which, by diligence, is a substance drawn forth,
rather better digested, and purer: and last, a matter of Oylynesse, drawn
forth by the stronger heat of fire: By which may evidently appear, that not
only out of massy parts, but even out of Bones, by Sublimation, may a like
matter be had and gotten: although certain moyst^ parts there are so light,
and thynne of substance, that these in a manner send up (by the heat of fire)
their whole moisture and strength at the first drawing: Such moist substances
and licours are gotten without aid of the Suns heat, the fire, or any
putrefying, as through the dropping caused by a List, or piece of Woollen
cloth, cut and fashioned into the form of a Tongue, which manner of doing (the
Chymistes name Fyltring) or otherwise by a Sponge, Strayner, Ipocras bag,
fine Searse, raw earthen Pot or Pan, through which any moist substance
may either distill or drop, as the like is thought and has been tried by an
Iuie vessel made of the wood for the only purpose, through which, wine
soketh or distilleth, like to sweating drops, leaving behind only the water
that tofore was myxt with the wine, yet such a drawing of moystures or lycours,
ought not properly to be named a Distillation, but rather the same may rightly
be termed a Distilling, when a Cucurbite or Glass Body filled with Flowers,
and set into Sand, does by the mighty heat of the Sun, yield forth a
lycour or water, by little and little, into a receyuer, fastened or luted
(after Art) to the nose of the Lymbecke, which as Mathiolus writes, sauoureth
near to the smell of the Flowers, through the gentle and easy drawing of that
heat: But if you mind to distill a moist substance or any other thing, in an
Earthen, Tynne, Glass, or Copper Body tynned within, set into a Furnace, then
prepare before fine sifted sand or ashes, for your Body to stand in half
covered (in a manner:) Or thus, let your Body be set into the Sand, that three
parts appear free and above the Sand, and the head to have a long necked
Receyuer, aptly luted or fastened to the Nose, that the same retching a good
distance from the heat of the fire, may thereby yield and send forth the
more plenty of moisture, drawn by force of heat of the fire, which raised of
the same into a vapor extenuated, and this again thickened through the
coldness of Air compassing the head, is on such wise converted into a
lycour, which from thence by drops falling into the Channel or Gutter of the
head, does so distill and run forth by the Nose into a long necked Receyuer
standing under, and this we properly name a Distillation: Or thus, Distillation
(as writes the former Fumanellus in his Book of the Composition of Medicines)
is the drawing or running forth of a thynner and purer humor by little and
little, or drop by drop, by force of the heat, out of the juice or thick
substance contained in the Cucurbite, or other vessel, for the only purpose:
through which, as by a certain Boiling, is a separation and ascension, caused
of many matters mixed together, and the drawing forth sometimes of certain
secret matters and hid properties, into one special substance gathered and
thickened into a water or other thin licour, properly in the head, which,
after distilling down into the Receyuer, serves for the commodity and use of
sundry griefs and sickenesses. Not unlike writes Johannes Mesue, where he
affirms that many matters of sundry kinds contained, and as they were
congealed into one body, in the Cucurbite or Glass body, are by force of the
heat separated, in working, according to the industry of the Chymistes, and
Distillers of Quintessence. And for troth such Ascentions, Distillations, or
Sublimations of Bodies, are not wholly a water, nor thoroughly an oily or
unctuous licour, but a certain substance sufficiently differing from the same
matter, which tofore you had put and mixed together, to be distilled. In this
place it is not to be forgotten, nor ouerpassed, that this word to Sublyme,
may be used in an other signification with the Chymistes: as when they mention
of Mercury sublymed. etc. The signification of which, shall after at large be
taught. And although yt in every Distillation, many and diverse considerations
are necessary to be learned, yet ought these two things to be specially
regarded at all times of every workman (which foreseen at the beginning of the
work, that the industrious Artificer be diligent to compass and bring to an
end the same) the one is the matter which he myndeth to deal withal, as to
find and try out of what condition the same is, and whether of his own
nature it is proper to endure, or do: The other is to such end, that the
work which is pretended, may come to a good and happy success: and then is
required to choose and make ready, seemly and apt vessels. If the Dystiller
will carefully consider and have regard unto these two points (as meet and
right it is) then needs he not to doubt, but that he shall bring his work
unto the same perfection and desired end, which he hops after: For as in the
universal or general nature of things in this world, all Bodies are not
made and formed indifferently of every sort and condition of matter, nor the
Craftesman can indifferently cut out and carue the image of Mercury, of every
wood (as by many and singular reasons the learned Physicians do persuade and
prove to us) but all things are made and formed of a certain matter, apt and
proportioned to receive a form appointed, by the means and aid of many
causes; even so in this Chymicall Art, it behooves him which will draw out
of any matter, Oil, or water, or any other like thing, that he before know the
matter, if the same be such, as he may hope to draw forth of it, a Water or
Oil, or any other like thing: after to search and choose those Instruments
or vessels for the work, which seems apte^^ for the turn, and according
to his desire: That if a man would Distill any matter, which is destitute or
lacking, the same moisture or licour that he searches and hops after: what
is it any other thing (I pray you) than to desire wool from an Asses back, or
to wring water out of a Pummyse stone, (which two, are well known) to be
matters impossible to be attained. Wherefore seeing that all mixed Bodies, be
constituted and formed of the four Elements: and that among those, the one
more partaketh of the Air, the other more of the water, some more of the fire;
others more of the earth, according to the necessity of each compounde
predominant and governing: for which cause it behooves to regard, and
diligently to consider in each Body, what Element surmounteth the other: These
well considered, it shall be an easy matter by force of the fire, to separate
and draw a water out of those substances, which are of nature waterie: as also
with like easiness it is possible to draw an Oil, by the Art of
Distillation, out of others that be of quality Aeriall or fiery: For the
heat of the fire is such, that it gathers together those things which are of
like kind and nature, and separateth such as be disagreeing. There be also
many Bodies or substances that be earthly and dry, out of which, to draw a
water or Oil, is not only hard to be done, but is altogether impossible: yet
are there some Bodies or substances, out of which, a water does easilye
distill, as all such matters which shall be moist and waterie: Others there
are, out of which, an Oil may be drawn, but no water at all, as all those
substaunces or Bodies, which be very tough and hard through dryness.

How often the virtues of certain substantial parts are lost, or changed
in the Distillations, and why that Distillation came but of later time into
use: this borrowed of the learned Ioannes Langius.

The second Chapter.
NO Person needs to doubt, that all Bodies which grow and take increasement
in the earth, are compounded of diverse, and in a manner, infinite small parts
(which ye Greeks properly name Atoms) of the Elements, and that in those rest
differing and contrary virtues: nevertheless, under one manner of form of all
the Bodies compounded: as the like appears, and is confirmed in that root of
Rubarbe, so much regarded and esteemed in all places, which does both loose the
Belly, and bind the same, yet this delivers and opens the obstructions
and stoppinges of the Liver. The same also is known to be in the juice of
Roses, which purges the bellye of Choler, where contrariwise, the distilled
water, and the dry powder of the leaves, do bind and harden the Belly: the
like to this is found in the bitterness of the nails, or white ends of the
leaves, which boiled and applied up in Glyster form (after the mind of the
learned Mathiolus) does mightily stay the flux of the Belly, and by giving it
to drink, this heals the perilous ulcers of the Lunges: The yelowe seeds
within the Rose, and the hears hanging to them, boiled in Wine, and drunk,
does stay (as he affirms) the styllings down to the Gummes, and
marvelously helps the running of the Whites in women. He also reports that
the whole heads of the Rose sodden in Wine, and drunk, helps the flux of
the Belly, and stays the spitting or casting up of blood: the seeds within
the pears of the Rose, are known (of experience) to be astringent, for which
cause, the yelowe, and all the whole Pears sodden in wine, does greatly
profit the flux of the Belly, and such abundance of the Whytes in women,
yea, marvelously stays the tedious Gonorrhea, these hitherto Mathiolus. And
is it not euidentlye seen and known, that the outward part of the Nettle
procures ytching and burning, in that part of the body, as the same touches:
where contrariwise, the juice drawn out of the inner substance, applied on the
arteries of the arms, does refresh and cool the burning of the Fever, or
feuerous burning of the heart: Besides, dried and brought into powder, and
given to a married man to eat, causes him after to love dearly his wife and
children: and the same used, fortifieth the veneriall act, and purges the
Matrix in women, by the daily eating in meat: yea, wasshyng the Body with the
decoction of it, mitigateth all pains caused of cold, and heals scabbes.
And do we not daily understand and see, that out of one ^^per Mine of the
vein under the ground purchased, there (...) ^olten and separated in the
Furnace, diverse kinds of Metals, that is, of Lead, of Silver, Copper, and
Gold, of which always the greater part is converted into Fumes. When therefore
after in the Distillation, the grosser and excrementuous parts abide in the
bottom of the Lymbecke, then do the Aereall vanysh into spirits, and the
moisture thickened through the cooling of the cover or head of the Lymbecke,
fall from the Gutter of the head, and run down drop by drop into a
Receyuer standing under. It is not to be marueyled at, if distilled waters do
not yield their proper savor, taste, and all other virtues, or but little
that they ought, of those matters, out of which they are distilled. For which
cause the learned Physician Mesue reports, that the water drawn by
distillation out of Roses, does greatly comfort and strengthen: yet does the
same nor like loose and purge the body, as the juice gotten out of the fresh
Roses, or the infusion of them done after Art, by reason that their subtle
heat vanishes with the fire. To these add, that the hid or secret
property which proceeds of the form (that the Physicians term particular)
as in the Lode stone, Colocynthis, Scamonie, and others like, equally shed
throughout the whole substance of his subject, insomuch that when the forces
and virtues be lost of the other parts of the subject, it cannot then retain
his proper strength, but that his action and working perysheth: as by a like
the water distilled by a Lymbeck of the Colocynthis, or Rubarbe, cannot then
loose or purge the Belly: where the lycour at all times, or either of them
infused for certain hours, and ministered, will easily perform the like
working. By the same manner, all herbs of a hot and dry quality, do yield
or give forth in their Distillation, the best waters of property, keeping
nevertheless their natural heat and dryness: but the herbs cold and
moist, do not reteyne so well their coldenesse and moisture, by reason they
attain or purchase a certain strange heat of the fire of the Lymbecke,
which abateth and takes away from the waters their proper nature and virtue:
so that the same water, which is distilled, does not any thing reteyne, or but
little of the nature and virtue of that simple, out of which it is distilled.
Whereof it comes to pass, that although the waters of Endyue, Lettuce, or
Nightshade, are accustomed or wont to cool: yet do these always perform
the same but a little: where otherwise, if these kept the proper qualities of
the Herbs, from which they are distilled, would then greatly cool: to the
end that the Herbs, the same which are of temperature (...), may keep their
proper qualities, they ought rather to be ^^yled with a soft fire, and their
decoctions ministered, when ^^ede requires. If at any time, the distilled
waters are more agreeable and pleasanter in taste, than the decoctions of the
Herbs: it behooves to understand, that these loose lesser of their moisture
and coldness (in that they need but a temperate fire) if they be distilled in
the Furnace, named MARI. BALNEVM
Balneum Mariae, whose form is here described to the eye, that commonly is
made long, whereby the same may contain many vessels, and has sundry doors,
that the water may heat together alyke: buylt also of small heygth, to the
end the water may be made hot with a small fire: than if they were distilled
in a dri^ Furnace, as in Sand, or Ashes: of which hereafter, shall further be
uttered, whereas we mind to entreat of the correction of Herbs. By the same
discourse each man may easily conceive and judge, that all forms cannot wholly
resist and do their workings a long time in mixed bodies, if the qualities
abide not perfect and hole. For which cause, it is no marueyle, if the waters
of Plants and Juices, especially those which are distilled, by a dry heat of
fire: do disagree, and sever from the virtues of their Simples: which for
troth more troubled, and moved rather the skillful to be abashed, than the
ignorant Physicians, and caused that a long time after it was, or they any
thing (to purpose) attempted to put in use Distilled waters: yet others, for to
recompense the default, which they knew to be in them, sought out and
practiced many ways, how and by what means these might best retain and keep
their virtues after the Distilling. But among the Arabians, the Noble Mesue
first made mention of Sublimation or Distillation of ye waters of Wormwoode and
Roses. For, says he, water of Wormewoode is distilled after the manner as is
out of Roses, and such like, which are done in vessels of Sublimation. But in
process of time, when Rhasis, Serapio, and Auicen, had taken in hand the
practice of Alchymie: then began these waters to be used in Physic.

Of the kinds and differences of Distillations. The third Chapter.
FOrasmuch as we have sufficiently uttered in the first Chapter, that the
Bodies which we desire to separate by Distillation, are not of one nature and
quality: yet it often comes to pass, that some lightly suffer, and others
resist mightilye, through the action of the causes agent, and these yield not,
but by a great force and violence: so that not without good occasion, the first
inuentors of the Art of Distilling, and their successors, which made a matter
of the said Art, devised diverse kinds of Distilling, according to the
diversity of things proper to be distilled, by the means of which, they might
the more easily come unto the intended scope which they purposed. Again,
seeing it is certain, that for the diversity of the kinds and fashions of
Distilling, there needs diverse instruments proper and commodious to each
fashion of Distilling. Good reason it is (in my opinion) that we entreat of
the kinds of Distillations, before we make mention of the Instruments.

Seeing that every Distillation is done by the resolution and separation of the
substantial parts, through the force of the outward heat: The Chymicke
Authors have purposed two ways, and the rule certain of the said
separation. For they understood and knew by reason and experience, that some
Bodies or substances, with greater pain do yield or send forth a lycour:
and others more easilye, and with lesser traueyle. For which cause they
invented one manner very easy, and another harder, and with greater pain,
according to the necessity and condition of the matter or substance to be
drawn. The one of these they would to be done in the Discending, which the
Latin Chymistes term, per Descensum: the other in the Ascending, of the
Latynes named per Ascensum: so that for each of these, they gave the same apt
names. By this reason we say in general, that every Distillation to be done
in the Descending, or in the Ascending, so that either of these two ways are
to be applied i^differently to these things that a man would distill: and
according as each person may herein be persuaded, after the capacity of his
wit, or by experience. But the oftener Distillation that is exercysed in the
Ascending, is done of the seeds of Herbs, which spread into breadth, bearing
flowers and seeds, as the Annise, the Dill, the Fennel, and such others. In
like manner of the fragrant and comfortable spices, the Tears, Gummes, Rosins,
and lycors. For those which are done in the Descending, or by Discention, are
the oils drawn out of ye woods of Juniper tree, Aloe, Guaicum, Ash,
Tamaricke, Medler tree, Pyne tree. etc. although true it is, that sundry
waters are distilled into the Descending, or by Discention, as those of Roses,
Flowers, and tender Herbs. etc.

Further, although that the Chymisticke Authors do teach and show diverse
fashions of Distilling by Ascension, yet may all these ways and fashions be
brought into three orders, according to the difference of the cause agent or
efficient, which is heat.

The first manner is, when we distill any liquide substance or flowers in the
Sun by force of his heat. The second, when the Distillation is done, by
force of the heat of fire. The third is performed by the heat, which
consists in putrified and rotten matters or substaunces, of which
particularlye, and by order, we shall after entreat.

First, the Distillation that is done in the Sun, when the vessel or
Lymbecke of Glass filled with the matter, which a man would distill, is set
fully in the hot Sun on fine sifted Sand or Ashes hot, to the nose of
which, is a receyuer hanging or fastened: But this manner of Distillyng in
England and Germany, and in cold Countries, cannot so well be performed.
Yet sundry Chymistes are wont to prepare many Oils by Sunning, that is, by
setting them in the hot Sun, which perhaps may more commodiouser be
prepared and done by decoction, to the end that the faculty and property of
the Symples may the better be drawn forth by a stronger heat.

Secondlye, there be many manners and ways of drawing forth waters and Oils
of compounde things, by the vehemency and force of the heat of fire. For
either the things to be distilled, are put up or closed simply in a Cucurbite
or Retort (which are instruments of Glass for distilling, being large at the
bottom) and set over the heat of fire: or the same substance closed up in a
Cucurbite or Glass body, set into that Furnace named Balneum Mariae, or else
bestowed in sifted Ashes, or fine Sand, a desired Lycour is drawn forth, by
force of the dry heat of fire put under. This manner of Distilling, as it is
very excellent, and every where used: even so is the same most at large set
forth, as in the instructions following, shall further be learned.

Thirdly, the form of Distilling by Ascension, is done in Distillatorie
vessels, filled with the purposed medicines or substances, deep set, or
standing covered, in a heap or little hill of new pressed Grapes with the
Kirnelles, or in the refuse of Olyues, after the Oil pressed forth, or in
Horse, or other Cattels dung. For by the rotten heat of any of these kinds,
being one and the selfsame continual for certain days. The Chymistes not
only purge and separate their Quintessences, by a small labor and cost, but
infuse in a Glass body (with a narrow neck and mouth, for a long time)
their singular Medicines and Balmes, with Oil, Aqua vitae, or other Lycoure,
with which they affirm to cure diverse desperate diseases and sickenesses. They
also affirm by the said form of Distilling, that certain waters may be
attained for the restoring of youth, and prolonging of life, and I cannot tell
what manner of Defensatiues, and worthy Drinckes (says Ioannes Langius in his
Epistles) for expelling of the Plague, and all manner of poisons, to which as
they gave the name of Gold, or termed Golden: even so they would those to be
rewarded with gifts of Gold. And these three manners of Distilling, may by
good right be named Sublimations, because these make their vapors to ascend on
high.



The other form and manner of Distilling, which the Chymistes often have in
usage, named of Albertus by Discention, is wrought or done on this wise, a
round hole and deep, must be dygged in the earth, after two Potts prepared,
glased within for the only purpose, the upper Pot, having many small hoales
in the bottom, and that filled with the matter or chyppes of the wood to be
distilled, which after set into the mouth of the nether Pot, standing in
the ground, luting diligently both Po^tes with a strong ^u^e, made with the
whytes of Eggs, after the well drying, cover the nether Pot with earth up to
the bryn^ke or edge, or higher if you will. Which done, make an easy fire at
the first round about the upper Pot with coals, or dry cloven wood, not
smoking (least with too strong a heat at the first, you dry up much of the
lycour or Oil in the Dystilling, therefore increase the fire by little and
little, until the work be ended. For as soon as the wood or thyppes in the
upper pot shall be heated, the Oil or lycour then begins to distill through
the little holes into the nether Pot. And by this manner or way, d^e many at
this day draw out or dystill Oils of the wood^ of Juniper* Guaiatum; and
other woods shaven, as writes Langius. Besides these, we may not be
^^noraunt, that there be sundry other manners or ways of Dy^tilling often in
use, as those which are wrought or done by Fylt^ing, by a Sponge, by a Press.
etc. But of all these shall here no further be mentioned, but only touched by
the way.

Of the Instruments or vessels which serve to the Dystillations. The.iiij.
Chapter.
ALthough that all manner of Dystillations, may diversely be performed, according
to the judgment and industry of the Distillatour, and according to the
pleasure and opinion of each person: yet evermore the workman and Practiser,
how ingeniouser and better aduysed he shall be, so much the more carefully and
diligently he ought to search before all things, the same which he knows to
be necessary for the guyding and perfourming of the work happily. And he
shall in like manner weye, and consider in his mind, what Instruments are for
him more commodious for Dystilling, before that he takes in hand or begins
the work of Dystilling. Now of the Instruments, some are in general, and
for the same cause* require all one manner of Distillation, which is the heat.
But the others are particular, appointed only to certain fashions of
Distilling, which are these, Infusion, Putrefaction, Fermentation, the
Furnace^, of sundry kinds, the diverse vessels of Glass, of Earth, of Tyn, or
other matter, and whatsoever there are of any other.

The manner of cutting your Glasses fit for your purpose.
Now the easy way^ of cutting the necks of diverse Glasses, when need
requires, with the apt Instruments serving to that use, shall hereafter
appear. First with that stone (which the Glasiers use) being set into some
handle, draw about the neck of the Glass, in the same place where you covet
to break it of. After the Instrument formed, having three or four edges,
according to the figure here described) and the same made glowing hot, work
about the raced place unto the time it be through hot. After by dypping your
finger in water, and letting a drop or two fall, the Glass incontinent will
crack in the said place marked: and drawing after that instrument (which we
have above demonstrated) round about, you may lightly break of the p^ece
without danger to the Glass. The like of this have I known to be wrought
with a poynted Diamonde set in a Ring: but a waxed threede was fastened about
that place, by which (the Diamonde guided) should run, for the strayghter
and euener racing of the Glass, which done in such order, and the place heated
hot round about with the flame of a wax Candle, or other Candle, if a man
will, was sodainlye cracked through the falling of a drop or two of cold
water, on the place marked. Another more easy way to cut Glass, have I
known experienced with a bygge Wire wreathed round at the one end (like to a
Ring) which heated glowing hot, and turned often round on the place marked,
caused the Glass (through his heating) by a drop or two of cold water
falling on it, to crack about the said raced place. Some use to break off
the necks of Retorts, with a double waxed threede twisted hard, and made in the
form of a Ring, which put hard on the neck, they heat the same round about
with the flame of a wax Candle, and by pouring a drop or two of water on the
place, the Glass is caused to crack.

And some use other Instruments like to those before descrybed, which heated
glowynge hot, after they draw sundry times about the place of the Glass
raced, and do the rest above taught.

If you covet to seal up or shut close the mouths of narrow necked
Glasses, that no vapors or spirits may breath forth, and that these may
appear to be whole on every part, then prepare a little Furnace (like to this
here descrybed) in whose bottom let a Grate of Iron be coutched, with a hoale
made in the side above the Grate, to thruste in the neck of the Glass, and
retching up to the top of the Furnace, set a strong pair of Tongues, and broad
at the end, which done, and the neck of the Glass made hot, wring with the
glowing Tongues the Glass together, then sweating by occasion of the heat,
which shall so be united at the top, as the same there were whole, or that it
seemed like as it were closed together in the Glass makers shop.

Of the heat being the Instrument in general, necessary to all kinds and
forms of Distilling. The fifth Chapter.
EVery Distillation is especially performed and done by two ways or means:
as the first by heat and Dryness, and the other by heat and moisture. And of
both these, there are three degrees constituted: the first is of gentle heat,
or of quality weak: the second more strong, yet with some mediocritie: the
third heat is mighty and violent. Therefore it behooves to govern the
fire, and to moderate the same, according to the nature and quality that the
skillful may have, of the thing or substance which he would distill: Herein not
neglecting how much and how little the second and third qualities are to be
moderated. Wherefore those, which are of a tender and thynne substance, as the
Lettuce, Endyue, Sorrel, Maydenheare, Hearts tongue, and such like Symples, do
not endure a heat but moderate, and which is of the first degree: those which
are thick and gross, and of a substance more firm and solid, as the
Wormewoode, Mugwoort, Egrimonie, Sothernwoode, the Aromaticke things, the
Spyces, and others like, require a heat more mighty. The Antimonie
contrarywyse, and all kinds of Metals, desire one manner of fire. By the heat
moderate, in the Distillation of Wine, and all Herbs, do the watrie parts
ascend: but by the heat more mighty and violent, do the thynner parts
only show, and the watrie tarry behind. Further conceive, that the flame it
self as well as the Coals, do not a little differ, not by reason only of the
same being greater or lesser, but by occasion of the woods rottenness, or ill
smelling, or otherwise sound and well smelling, green or dry. To these, the
greatness or smalnesse of the Furnace: the form and closing of it, has a
great force in changing or altering of the heat. The Coals also made of
smothered and half burnt wood, yield a certain ill ^auour and strange
quality in the things distilled: as the like in boiling, and otherwise
preparing of matters with them is perceived. For which cause the Coals ought
to be through kyndled, and half burnt, whereby the malignitie or ill savor of
them, may (in the doing) breath forth, before that any matter be distilled
with them, to be ministered especially into the Body, were the same outward
applied, it forces not so much. There is as great a matter to be considered in
the difference of Coals: for that the Coals made of the wood growing in the
valleys are supposed to be woorthyer and far better, than those made of the
wood on the Hlles: and the wood in the valleys is the thynner, for which
cause are the Coals the like, yet does the fire lightly and soon waste all
thynne matters. And in making the best Coals, they ought not to be done under
the Ground (as the custom of many is) but made above the Earth, for that they
burn better, and are more profitable. Also the Coals made of the Beeche,
Birche, and Fyrre tree, are accounted best, for their sweeter and sooner
burning, although Coals of the Juniper tree, do last far longer, as of
experience known: besides, the Coals made of the Oak and Ash tree, are not
in cases of necessity to be refused, especially where the store of the Beeche,
and other trees are not. Moreover, it behooves the Distillatour to have a
special regard and care about the bestowing of fire under his vessels, that
the same be not made of cleft wood half rotten, or evil smelling (as we have
above declared) nor of Coals smoothered within a deep pit or hole of the
Earth, or evil burned, or of Coals gotten out of Caves, whether those be of
Stone, or of Earth, for fear that the vessels of Distilling, and the lycours
be not taynted and infected of their vapor, filthy and stynking. A like
reason may be gathered, that if waters or Oils be distilled with any of those,
they after purchase a savor and quality disagreeing, yea, far unlike the
substances that are to be distylled, as the same may well be perceived and
tasted, by the matter boiled with any of them. Further, the Chambers, Parlours,
Stoues, Hot houses, heated with such wood or Coals, do sufficiently
witness how noyous and hurtful such a vapor and savor is, which not only
brings an intolerable pain of the head, but moves vomiting, and causes
passions of the heart, to those which be conversant and abide any time in such
places: as I the like (says the worthy Gesnerus) have experienced in my
self, to the peril of my health, at the Bathes of Oenosponte, where I abode a
certain season with the Noble Prince Palatine. Of the like occasion Galene
seemed worthilye to reprehende Erasistratus, which perceived that the
inhabitants of his Country to peryshe, through the overmuch subtilnesse or
thyckenesse of the air. He also learned and knew that these came much sooner
to their death, by reason of the exceeding deep Caves and Pyttes of Charon,
which breathed forth pestilent exhalations and vapors: or through their houses
newlye plastered, and whytened with Lyme: or for the evil savor of the
Coals, which sent forth vapors very dangerous: this out of Ioannes Langius.
It is besides reported, that many are molested by the stynking sweat of the
feet, after the shoes newly shyfted of in any close room, whether the same
be Parlour or Chamber: but affirmed to be more dangerous, where Coals burning
in any close room, breath forth a stinking savor: yet some there are of a
contrary opinion, which suppose that neither the fume, nor favor of the
Coals burning, can any thing harm nor alter the matters which a man
distilleth, when the Cucurbite (or Glass Body with his head) is well luted
and stopped round about, according unto Art: but that sooner the vapor may
be annnoyance to the Distillatour, and to those which govern the Distillation,
than to the matters which any distilleth.

Of the other Instruments particular. The sixth Chapter.
THere are other Instruments, by which the quality fierye, is increased, or
diminished in the Distillation, which is the cause that the Dystyllation is
made or done, sometimes by means of the hot vapoure of boiling water, as
Manardus in his Epystles instructs: sometimes through the ^elpe of boiling
water, when as the Glass body stands in that Bath, named Balneum Mariae:
sometimes by a dry means, as by sifted Ashes, fine Sand, small Stones finely
ground, fylings, or dross of soft metals, sometimes by these things mixed
together, as when water is mixed with the Sand. In such manner the Distillation
is not wholye wrought or done in the Bathe named Balneum Mariae, nor yet only
in Sand. There are some which wylleth a quantity of sand to be myxed with
the water of Balneum Mariae, to the intent the heat may be the greater, and
more vehement: for in such a manner of Distillation, may two waters be
obtained, as the first thynne and waterie, the other more read and thycker, as
the learned Mathiolus reports. To these it behooves to note, that the
Distillation which is done with the fine syfted powder of Bryckes or
Tylestones, is the better and more sure of all others, according to the
judgment of some skylfull persons, for that it nourishes and mayntayneth
equally the heat, and breaks not so lightly and soon the Glass bodies:
which two things are very necessary in Distillations: But of all these
varieties, we mind at large to entreat in the particular Distillations, and
to show in what, and when it is needful to use now the one, and now the
other means.

For the Distillation of matters, sometimes the infusion is necessary,
sometimes the Putrefaction, sometimes the grynding of things, and other like
preparations.

The infusions by which the dryer matters are prepared to distill, for the
more easy drawing forth the Water or Oil: are done either in simple water
labored, that is, running by pypes a long way: or in water dystilled, or in
water of Life, or Wine, or in water distilled of Herbs simply, or vinegar, or
in any other lycour: on such wise infused, let them stand and abide in the
hot Sun, or on the fire, for the space of half an hour, or more hours, a
whole night, a whole day, two days, three days, one, or many Months,
according to the nature of the medicine, and diverse intention of the Physician,
and necessity present. We wring out sometimes before the Distillation the
things infused, and distill the lycour wrynged forth, or the same we distill in
a Glass body, or other like Instrument, the infusion altogether, that is, the
same which is infused, and the lycour in which the infusion is made.

The waters and Oils which are drawn forth of pleasant Spyces, ought to be
done by infusion in simple water, not in Wine, nor in Aqua vitae, for that
these do over speedily ascend, and carry not with them the force and virtue
of the Aromaticke Spyces: but the simple water, (in a contrary manner) ascends
not, without carrying with it the Aromaticke virtue. Sometimes we put to
putrify the things to be Distilled, and after that they are putrified, we
distill them: although that sometimes the same putrefaction is a kind of
Distillation, as we have before uttered, and shall after entreat more at large
in the proper place.

The Fermentation of matters, is done after the manner of infusions, by an
outward heat increased, which works into moisture, whereby a certain
common quality with the hot spirit causing bubbles, may be myxed and
extended thorowout the whole body: and this either wrought in the Suns great
heat at the Dog days (if the Suns heat in the mean time, be not
sufficient) or on the Furnace of Balneo Mariae, carefully governed, or in hot
Horse dung. The Fermentation has need of many days, as of four or more: and
how much the better shall the Fermentation and preparation be done, so much the
greater quantity shall a man draw forth of water or Oil.

Of the Furnaces, Cucurbites, Heads of sundrie^formes, Receyuers, and other
Instruments in general. The seventh Chapter.
IT is not our determination nor purpose at this present to declare at length,
but a part of the Instruments material, which serve for Chymistes workinges to
Distill the water and Oils: seeing that many Authors have at large entreated
of all these: It shall suffice us to make mention of some more rare Instruments
in general, and to set forth duers fashions of Distilling; not known to
many, as shall after appear in this first Book.

The best and most commodious form of a Furnace, among all others, is the same
(which within) is round all about: whether the same be buylt into length and
squarenesse, with a convenient breadth, for the better containing of sundry
bodies together, or as many as you will. And after the manner of one, may you
frame sundry furnaces of like condition. For the buylding of this Furnace,
whether it be one alone, or sundry together (to serve as well for Balneo, as
Sand or sifted Ashes) it behooves to choose vnbaked Bryckes and Tyles, yet
those very well dried and hardened in the Sun, for that they are more
tractable and softer than the baked, and that a man may better cut them with
the iron Trowell or like instrument, to frame them into what form he will: the
hollow hole within (reaching to the ground) ought to be so large as the
Earthen Pan not baked, or of Copper, may stand or hang to the bryncke in
it, whose form shall be broad above and narrow beneath (after the manner of
the Iellyflower Pot with us, having a large edge) the bottom of the Pot to
stay or stand on a little bar fixed overthwart in the walls, and in each
corner a little hole for the breathing forth of the fume, as the like in all
Furnaces are made: let the thyckenesse of the walls be framed more or less,
according as you shall think necessary. For how much the thicker the compass
about, or walls shall be, so much the more heat they retain within. The
vnbaked Bryckes ought first to be laid in a moist place, as in a Celler, to
the end that those may more easily be cut and fashioned, with the edge of the
Trowell, or some other apt Instrument of iron. The Bryckes ought so to be
couched and laid one upon another, that the joints (in the lying of them)
meet not, but are unequal, as the end of one reaching to the myddle of
another: for by the same manner couched, the buylding and walls shall be the
stronger. The Bryckes and Tyles shall be joined or couched with Mortar made of
the fattest Cley, myxed with a quantity of Woollen flocks (shoren off broad
Clothes or Carsies) and new Horse dunge well stamped together, and that the
Mortar be tempered in water very saltie, when any will use and occupy of the
same. A certain Chemist teaches another manner of making common Lute for the
strong erecting of all manner of Furnaces, and the Philosophers tower, which is
on this wise. Take of Cley being clammie and tough, to which ^dde or put a
little Sand or fine Gravel, after myxe Woollen flocks and Horse dung, so
much as shall suffyce, and labor diligently the whole together, that the same
may rather be soft, than styffe or hard, and this he names a Lute common,
for all Furnaces. The lute of wisdom, with which the Chymistes dawbe their
Glass bodies, for to resist a mighty heat of fire, shall after be taught in
that Chapter, where we mind to entreat at large of all manner of Lutes for the
distilling Instruments. The form of which long Furnace, behold here under
lively descrybed to the eye.



The description of another Furnace, to be used as well for Oils, as other
Lycours, and Mynerall waters done by Sublimation, which may on such wise be
buylt, that the same^maye be removed from place to place, in any chamber, or
other room of the house: if the foundation of the vnbaked Brycke and Tyles be
cowched on a square thycke Planckeboorde with four feet, (marked with the
letter G.) and the walls (of a sufficient thycknesse) raised two foot high,
with Brickes mortered in the form above taught. After this, that the roumes
within be made, a foot distaunt one from the other. Which done, to make an
Arch door beneath, (marked with A.) where the Ashes falling from the Coals,
may be drawn or gotten forth. Above the same (a foot distant) another door
made, (noted with this letter B.) opening above the Grate, and the Grate
figured with the letter D. on which the Coals ougth to lie, and the entrance
of this door needs to be no larger, than that a man may hardlye thrust in
his hand. Above this, that two small bars of Iron (marked with E.) be fixed
a cross, or but one only, and those to serve for the stronger staying of the
Pan or Pot. Toward the top in each corner above (marked with F.) that
four ventes or breathing holes be made, and into the largest hole in the
middle (marked with H.) a Pan set (being broad above and narrow beneath)
reaching to the cross bar, and the edge about mortered strongly, that no
heat of fire pass forth, between the head of the Pan and Furnace: after
to pour into it water, if a man myndeth to distill herbs, Roots, or other
tender things. But contrariwise, Oils or other matters, yt require a myghtier
heat: then to put in fine sifted Sand or Ashes, and to begin your
Dystilling. The form of this Furnace serving for one Cucurbite or Glass body,
is here lively described.

Also if a man will build a round Furnace, it behooves him to place the vent
holes about, to rise from the bottom of the Pan, and the Cucurbite, of
Glass, Tynne, or thynne Copper well tynned within, to be set half full of
lycour into the Pan, about which two or three narrow bands of lead to be
hanged on with a cloth, that the Body start not up through the moving of the
water. This done, lay two half couers of Lead (cut just in the mids) in
such manner, that these close in the Glass body, whereby the heat of the
seething water may the commodiouser abide, and longer continue. On the body
(being either T^nne or Copper) set on a Glass head (which is accounted best)
for the sight of the lycour, and the same so close about with fine Lynnen
clothes, that no vapors at all may breath forth, and the Receyuer of pure
Glass set to it, that the water Distilling, may run into it, being like
luted to the nose of the Head. And this kind of Furnace wrought with water,
is named Balneum Mariae: but working with a dry heat (as in Ashes or Sand)
there needs no such half couers to guide or stay up the body. The
Cucurbite and head may wholly be made of Tynne, which are more commodious, in
that the Glass body is lightly broken through heat, and to much cold. In
many round Furnaces, the Grate has eight or nine overthwart bars of Iron,
that the Ashes may the co^modiouser fall through: and this Grate ought to be
made according to the proportion of the Furnace, that it may agree most aptlye
to the roundenesse and largeness of the same. The pan (wheth^r the same be of
Copper or Earth) ought to be of a like depth and breadth (although it shall be
commodious, that the depth be somewhat more than the breadth) with a Pype
standing out at the top, by which the hot water may run forth, without
harm to the Furnace. And this Copper Pan ought so to be set into the
Furnace, that it hangs well a spanne distant from the Grate underneath.

The Tower of the Philosophers, is a Furnace that hardlye can be learned by
words, nor by long writing, without full sight of the same in the buylding:
for if any happens to see the whole making of it, yet may he fail to
co^ceyue and understand the secret consisting in it, in that there are many
things in it, framed and made after such manner, that a man may hardly attain
to the knowledge of them. But to declare wholly (and to the end) how the same is
to be made, and that any conceyueth this my writing and demonstration, to his
profit be it, and he that understands not the same, to his harm be it. The
manner of erecting and framing of the said Tower, is on this wise, that the
foundation be laid four square with raw or baked Bricks, on a plain and
even ground, and three foot broad on every side, and that a hollow space
(in cross manner) be left, to the breadth of a baked Brick, and of heygth so
much, as is the heygth of the said Brick in largeness set on edge: and this
Pype or Gutter, is the same, where the fire or flame passes, and over the
mids of the said cross Pype, lay an iron Grate, and above the same build a
round Furnace of a spanne in breadth, and a yard and a half of heygth: and
this is named the Tower, and to the four holes (appearing forth) build and
frame in like manner four little Furnaces round, but lower than the hoales,
and without little Grates of iron in them: that the fire or flame may pass by
those pipes, and enter within the said small furnaces, on which, may be placed
or set Glass bodies, Retortes, or other vessels. When you will bestow Coals,
and make fire in the myddle Tower, do the same after this manner, that is, take
kindled coals, and put them in at the bottom of the Tower, and after fill up
the said Tower with dead or vnkindled coals: and shut close above with a cover
of Iron, the head of the tower, that no air breath forth: for by this dooyng,
the fire shall burn only below, so much as the pypes which extend to the
Furnaces can receive, and no more: and on such wise, in a Tower of this
greatness full of Coals, will the fire endure twelve or fourteen hours,
without putting in of any Coal. With this Tower may a man Distill, Circulate,
dry up, and Sublyme, with great facility: And this is the Philosophers Tower
above named, which serves, and is very necessary in the Art of Alchymie.

Another skillful Chemist, teaches a very ingenious manner of Distilling, by
which a man may with one only fire draw together, and all at one time, both
Water and Oil, besides the commodity of Sublyming, and Distilling by Balneo
Mariae: and this is named a Distillation in the tower, by reason of the form
of the Furnace, or rather named the Philosophers Tower, for great commodities
of the same, which is made after this manner: that is, in any plain and even
ground, let the form of a tower be buylt, either round or square, or fix
cornered, or of some other form, with vnbaked or baked Bryckes, and in heygth
about a yard and a half, or two or three, or so high and large as a man
pleases, in such condition always, that the same may receive and contain a
fire sufficient great and burning: In the said Tower, distant from the ground,
about a handbredth and a half, let be laid a Grate of iron, which may bear
up the Coals, with a wyndowe or square hole, by which the air may enter to
kyndle the Coals. After that done, let be buylt of either side, and round
about the tower, many Furnaces regarding the outward face of the tower, of
such a bygnesse as he thinks good and necessary, and of such heygth from the
ground, as answers aptly to the Grate of iron, which shall be in the mids
of the tower, and on each side of the tower, which shall be in the mids of
these Furnaces, let holes be made sufficient great, and somewhat higher than
the Grate of iron, to the end, that by those the heat of the fire might be
communicated and extended to the Furnaces. These Furnaces ought to be buylt
after the form of the Bulwarks of a warrelike Town: to each of the holes
running and extending within the Tower, before that the Furnaces are set or
joined too, ought a Plate or Register of Iron to be made, boared with three, or
six holes, or more, and those of like greatness and distance, one directly
above the other: to the end, that those may be drawn wholye forth of the
Furnace, when need shall require the same, or thrust down so deep, as the
Chemist would that the force of the fire to extend to the Furnaces without,
whether the same be by two or three, or one only hole, or by the great or
least hole: At the top of the myddle Tower, ought there to be made like to a
vaulte, by which the Furnace or the tower may be exactly closed, to the end
that the ai^e which enters by the lower part of the Tower, may not breath and
issue out by the top: and this after such manner always guyded, that those
may be drawn up, and put down again, according as he shall think needful.
The things on such wise prepared, the holl^we place of the Tower in the mids,
ought to be filled with Coals, and the top close shut or stopped with the
cover, to be strongly luted or mortered round about. At the hole or door
below shall he put in the fire, for by that means the Coals which shall be
nearer the said holes, will be consumed by the fire, and on such wise
consumed, that those which shall be at the top of the Tower, shrynking and
falling down by little and little, kyndle and burn one after the other, and
in the like manner do the others consequently burn, until all shall be
kyndled and wasted. The person which will occupy such a fashion, and the like
Furnaces to distill in, it shall suffice that he visit or look to his fire
once in the day. Such a buylding is not only ingenious and delectable to
behold, but also very commodious and necessary. I have seen sometimes (says
the Chemist) that a Balneum Mariae, has been placed on the said buylding, or
top of the Tower, and a vessel to Sublyme: besides a Furnace for
Reuerberating, and Cymenting, and a Furnace for Melting, according as a man may
learn and know, by the figure herevnder descrybed. Another Furnace I saw of
meaner cost in the building, which had a Tower in the mids, like to this
abouesayd, being four square, and very plain of workmanship, at whose
corners were four vessels placed, as at each corner one, and Registers made
for them, as to the other Furnaces before descrybed: so that little differing in
uses, saving in the form and beauty, for which cause, this Furnace is to be
ordered in all points like to the aforesaid: in governing the Registers, and
heat of the fire, that this may easier be conceived, I have joined it with the
figure before descrybed, as the same may euidentlye appear on the other side
to the eye, borrowed both out of the singular work, entitled Pirotechnia.

The said Chemist in his work of Pirotechnia, descrybeth two other Furnaces,
serving to sundry uses: the one to be built after this manner: That is, a
square Turret to be raised with Bryckes, and the same made round within, the
hole for the drawing forth of the Ashes, to be half a foot from the
foundation, above which (nygh a foot) three or four small Bars to be laid
(in the form of a Grate) well a finger breadth distant one from the other, that
the Ashes may the lightlyer fall through, for hyndring of the fire to burn and
give his heat, on this Grate all about lay Tyles in handsome manner, leaving
but a hands breadth uncovered, for the fire to burn through: after this, about
a foot higher, make your Oven open in the top, but in fashion like to the
Bakers Oven, which leave hollow downewarde to the Grate, that the Coals in the
nether Oven (having a lesser mouth than the upper) kyndled, may burn and flame
up: to the mouth of this nether Oven, must a door be set, whereby it may be
opened for the putting in and taking out of Coals, and shutting the same
again, when need shall require: but the mouth of the upper and greater, must
always be left open, for the flame to pass forth: over the inner mouth of
this greater Oven, must two Iron bars more be laid, so wide one from the
other, that a man may handsomelye set on them a melting Crucible, or other
vessel to calcyne withal, as it behooves: Over the head of this square
Turret remaining open, must so large a slate stone be laid, as may wholly cover
the same, yet may you not make fast the slate with mortar, to the head or top
of the Oven or Turret, in that when need requires, the same is to be taken
of. After all these done, the Oven must (within and without) be well playstred
with fast and strong Lyme, that the same chop not, which performed, the
Furnace is then finished. The Crucible with the matter that you would calcyne,
shall you set on the Iron Bars, and lay down the Slate close on the Ouens
head: after kyndle fire in the nether Oven, that the flame extending up, and
about the Crucible, may so pass forth of the mouth of the upper Oven, for on
such wise, it calcyneth the better, in that the flame must burn about the
matter, before it extends forth of the mouth of the Oven. The uses of these
two Ouens, are for the calcyning of Metalline Bodies, or other Mixtures, which
are like calcyned, as the Saltes, and all manner of stones. And without the like
Furnaces, may a man perform no work, where as calcination needs: for if he
shall attempt to calc^ne Bodies by another means, it will be very hard to bring
to pass: wherefore the Philosophers at the first, invented such a Furnace, for
the like intent and purpose, and named it properly the Furnace of Reuerberation
for calcyning, and cymenting.

The other Furnace made round and hollow to the bottom, differs but little
from the abouesayde, saving that this in the working, is left open and
uncovered at the top for the fumes to pass forth: near to the bottom must
a square hole be formed, and a door to the same, whereby the fire by it may
so be governed, that the same may be increased great or small, as need shall
require. Above this, a Grate of Iron for the Coals to burn upon, and vent
holes round about, for the air to come in, as well as the head remaining all
open for the large passing forth of the smoke: which otherwise would not
burn, for the lack of vent holes to let the smoke pass, that seeks issue
forth, so that nothing seems, nor is more enemy to the fire, than the smoke.
And for this reason, if Furnaces had not their ventes of breathing holes, it
were not possible that they could work or do their effect: and if these in
like manner had not their breathing forth below, the fire with great
difficulty would burn: for which cause, it behooves to have breathing holes
on either side, that the Furnace may work with more easiness. The vessel
standing on the Grate ought to be well defended with lute round about, before
the Coals be poured upon to kyndle and burn: the door of the same requires
to be opened reasonable wide for a time, to the end the fire may kyndle and
burn the freelyer, and the smoke pass forth at the top. The Furnace thus
finished, serves as well for the Distilling of waters and oils (by the help
of a Pan set on the head, and filled with Sand or water) as for Sublyming,
and the melting of Mynerals: for which cause the Aucthour thought good (by
reason of their profitable uses) to place them by the way a part, that their
forms lively descrybed to the eye, might the easier and perfiter be conceived
of all parsons.

A commended Furnace for distiling of the Oil of Vitrioll, and other Oils, is
made after this manner: First, with baked Brickes and Tyles a foundation laid
four square, on which, a wall raised a foot high, or thereabout, and a door
made below for the drawing forth of Ashes: above this (within the Furnace) a
Grate couched of the said heygth, distant from the bottom a foot and a
half, or thereabout. After this, bestow ouerthwarte the myddle of the same, a
long and sufficient strong Bar of iron, mortered with the best Lute, and
that it extends from one side unto another of the Furnace. Between the Grate
and the said Bar of Iron, frame of the one side of the Furnace, a slow
Harrie, even as the figure following demonstrateth: Which ought to be of such a
greatness, that a man may in a manner thrust in his head. The things thus
prepared ready, set forward the building of the Furnace of the Bar of Iron,
unto the heygth of a foot and a half, and leave it on such wise open, until
you have bestowed the Glass, in which the Vitrioll is contained. Here
conceive, that the side of the Furnace toward the flow Harrie, ought to be
left open from the Grate, unto the top of it, until such time as the Glass is
bestowed within the Furnace. The Furnace thus buylt and prepared in a
readynesse, set in the Glass strongly fenced with Lute, and filled with the
prepared substance, of that side of the Furnace which remains open: in such
manner place it within, that the bottom staying on the iron Bar, the neck may
be caused to bend downwarde, so much as may be, in the overthwart standing of
it in the furnace: But not so much downward, that ye substance in the Glass
may spill forth. The neck of the Retorte (if you will draw the Oil of
Vytrioll) ought to lie or extend forth, nigh half a foot, to the end that
it may after be very well luted and fastened with the Receyuer hanging
without. The things on such wise prepared, close up all that part open of the
Furnace, from the Grate unto the top of it, and conioyne with Mortar by the
same means very diligently, the Glass with the Furnace. After that (in this
closing up) you are come unto the top, make a great hole at one of the four
corners, of the greatness of an Egg, and a cover formed to it, that the same
may be set on and taken away, when need requires, at the other three corners,
make in like manner ventes or breathing holes, but those much lesser ((...) so
small) that a man can not put in his thumb at any of the^* (...) this, he must
by little and little close up the Furnace, and fashion the same (from the
holes) narrower and narrower, until he come unto the top, where he must
fashion a round hole of such a greatness, that a man may easily put in
his hand, to which hole prepare in like manner a cover, that a man may
stop and open the hole, when he lusts. After that you have thus buylt the
Furnace, and in the same bestowed the Glass, as is aaforesayde. It shall be
requisite and needful, to have another great Glass, able to receive and
hold eight or ten measures of lycour (to be as the receiving vessel) which he
shall very well fasten with the neck of the Body hanging without, after such
manner, that the neck of this be entered sufficient deep into the Receyuer:
which two on such wise ordered, lute diligently (round about) with the
strongest lute, as the common manner is. But the figure following shall show
to the eye all the said description of the Furnace, and the vessels before
mentioned. In which it behooves to note, that the slow Harrie ought not so
exactly to extend unto, and touch the Iron Grate: but sufficient it shall be,
if the same caryeth the Coals thither, or to the Grate. A. represents the
door, by which the Air enters to nourishe and maintain the fire. B. the
grate of Iron which sustayneth or bears the Coals. C. the slow Harrie, by
which the Coals are poured in. D. the place where is laid the long Bar of
Iron, which bears the Body. E. the neck of the Body lying forth, which
bends downewarde. F. represents the great vessel receiving. G. the vent or
breathing holes, situated in the.iiij. angles or corners. H. the great hole,
which is formed on the top of the Furnace. I. the cover seruinge for the
greater hoale on the top.

After that the things shall be on such wise prepared, let the Furnace be
heated with the fire of Coals, and the slow Harrie filled up with great
Coals: which done, shut or stop close with his cover the upper hole, and
like the other vent holes, except the three little ones before mentioned. At the
same time, shut or put to half the door, which is placed under the Grate,
marked with the letter A. by reason of the air, for to preserve the fire. etc.

The other vessels which commonly serve in the Art of Distilling, and be put
in use every where, as well for matters of Alchymie, as the drawing of
medicinable things, which are all manner of Waters, Oils, Baulmes, Aqua vitae,
Quintessences, and all other compounde matters, shall after be lively
demonstrated: and the manner how to order them in the distilling of things,
with the apt names for each vessel, and the forms, shall in order be
faithfully set forth.

First, this Instrument or Vessel, is named a Crooked Body or Retort: and
where always mention is made of a Retort, there is meant a Vessel of such a
form, whether the same be great or small, according as it shall seem to the
workman, that it is agreeable for the quality, and quantity of the matter,
that he would distill with such a kind of Vessel as this is: And in such a
kind of Vessel, the Chymistes distill matters that are unctuous, which not so
aptly sublyme, or ascend on high: as all the kinds of waters, that are easily
distylled with a Cucurbite and head, because these sublyme with much
easiness: wherefore the things unctuous and heavy, that cannot sublyme or
ascend, but with great difficulty, are distilled with this manner of Vessel,
in that the same has but a short and small rising, before the passing and
falling into the Receyuer, and for that cause, this is a Vessel very
commodious and necessary in such an Art, as to each person may well appear,
by working with the same.



This Vessel is named the Glass body with a long neck, and where at any time
is mentioned of a Body (which in Latin is named Cucurbita) there this Vessel
is understood and meant, whether the same be greater or less, according as
the workman shall think necessary: and this is a Vessel common, much
occupied of them which Dystill diverse matters in the Art: and this is as much
used for Physic matters, as for the working of Alchymie: So that this comes
to occupying often, as a thing most commodious, for the dooyng of all manner of
workinges in a manner, and may as well serve for a Receyuer, as for a Body to
dystill withal: Of which, it may be said, that this is a principal Vessel
in the Art of Dystilling, serving (as it does) for two Vessels, and being
commodious in so many things, so that more needs not to be spoken of it.
Wherefore we will proceed to descrybe herevnder, that Vessel, which (of the
Chymistes) is named a Head, without the which a man can not distill any
matter by the Cucurbite or Body of Glass, as after shall playner appear.



This Vessel named a Head, is well known to most persons, and in the Art of
Dystilling very necessary: Because (as I have aforesaid) it is impossible,
that a man may distill any thing without it: and of such Vessels, the workman
may choose or cause to be made with narrower and larger mouths, according to
the condition of the Body standing under, yet these require to be fashioned
all after one manner, and the like to be made with one manner of Nose: which
Nose requires to be after this manner, that is, fashioned long, and that (put
in) it may reach a good way into the Receyuer, for by entering very deep in
the Dystilling, and the spirits yssuing out of the Body, will not be so apt
to pass forth of the Receyuer: for this cause the said head will be much
better when the Nose shall be formed long: herein considering that it has the
like similitude, with the Nose of the Head, here before descrybed, and being on
such wise fashioned, it is a perfect Vessel, for the Distilling of tender and
Flegmaticke matters.

This Vesselle (the Chimystes name) ye Vrinall, which but little differs
from the Cucurbite (before described) as to the eye, may evidently be perceived:
for there is no other difference, saving that the Vrinall is formed with a
larger neck and mouth, than the Cucurbite has: and this made the like, for
that intent, whereby a man might dystill with more facility: for by this, the
vapors ascend far better on high, through the large head set upon, like to
the same before described. And into this vessel may the workman put his hand,
to draw out the matter remaining, which rests at the bottom, without losing
of the Vessel: when a man dystilleth not those things, which it behooves him
to burn, and to rest cleaving to the bottom, so that when the workman
