needs not to dystill those things, which require a drying up: in such a case
(the contrary) may he cleanse the Vrinall, and make it serve for another time,
yea, for many times. In this Vessel may a man dystill Herbs, Wine, Flowers,
Honey, Wax, and all other matters, that he thyncketh may aptly be dystilled:
for the workman may order and apply it, in a manner to all woorkyngs, that he
would attempt to do, as well in Alchymie, as in Physic matters: so that
this Vrinall Body, is a Vessel very necessary, as we have before declared.



This Instrument named the Pellicane, which is a Vessel for Circulating,
serves to none other end and purpose, than for to Circulate the Quintessence,
which by the Art of dystilling is drawn: so that this Vessel on such wise
made, is not apt for the dystilling of any matter, but only serves for the
Circulating of Aqua vitae, and other compounde lycours. Where in any place you
find written to be done in a Pellicane, the same is meant to be wrought in the
said Vessel: and in all the Art, there is no other kind of Vessels, that
are more necessary than these five, which we have before descrybed, although
many other Vessels, and of those diverse are occupied of sundry Chymistes, yet
all consist and serve to the like woorkyng, which the above named do, that is,
the Retorte, the narrow necked Body, the Head, the Vrinall, and Pellicane,
with which a man may do all manner of works that are required in the Art, as
Dystillations, Sublimations, Fixations, Circulations, and other like woorkyngs.
And for that cause I think it not needful to make a long description of so
many strange sorts, as of those long, short, round, square, and so diverse
forms, which rather are occupied to marueyle at, than for utility or profit:
But I this affirm, that these five Instruments to be the fundament of the
whole Art of Distilling, and Alchymie, as I have before declared. Therefore let
it not move you to marueyle at so many sorts of Glasses that many Chymistes
use, which for this respect, I leave to demonstrate in this place.



This is a Bag which the Chimistes make of white Woollen cloth (whether the
same be Pennystone or Karsie) shaped and sown after this manner, and name it a
Fylter. And it is a very necessary thing, in that a man can not work in a
manner, any thing without it, that consists thycke: and in any place
whereas a man finds written to dystill by Fylter, the same is meant to be in
this Instrument, which he shall like do when the matters are dissolved into
water, for to clear them from their Faecies, that they may remain neat and
purified: which manner of Purifying, he shall work and do after this order,
that is, when the matter shall be dissolved, it behooves us to pour the same
into this Bag, letting it pass and run through by it self, which passed
through (by this manner of dystilling) will be most clear and pure, and this is
named the dystillation by Fylter, that also is very necessary in the work
of Alchymie, and the Apothecaries besides do often use this manner of
Dystilling, for to separate diverse matters, as are the Iuleps, Syrupes,
Decoctions, Juices of Herbs, and other Infusions, whereby they might come
purified and neat: and in this doing, there is nothing that may hinder their
woorking: wherefore if such matters were not sufficiently purged, they would
soon fall to putrefying and corrupting: which they do not, being well
Fyltred, and cleared through the Bag: As by a like in that Syrup, which
compounded of the Juice of sour Cytrone, ought first to be dystilled by the
Bag above descrybed, or by a List put into the Lycour: for this otherwise
curdeth, when it shall be cold: and the like does the Juice of Orenges and
Lemmons, being not ordered as abouesayde.

The other Instruments necessary for dystillation, not before descrybed, shall
after be lively demonstrated, and their uses orderly taught, borrowed out of
Adamus Louicerus, of Dystillation. The Instruments (says he) whose use is
required unto Dystillation, are made of diverse matter, as of Glass, Earth, or
Metals. But the Instruments of Glass, do excel all others, and for that
cause are warily to be used: therefore for a more safegarde of the Glass, the
Chymistes will to draw over it, a hose or Cote of vnshoren clothe (which
resists by that means, the stronger heat of Balneo Mariae) and after the
Dystillation it may be drawn of, and the Vessel made clean. Such mynding to
dystill by a dry heat of fire in Ashes or Sand, ought before to fence their
Instruments with the Lute of wisdom, made of Cley, Horsedung, Salt and
Flocks: but of this Lute shall more at large be uttered, in the proper place
hereafter. The said Instruments are to be formed of the best Earth that may
be found in any Country, for these in many causes are much commended, so
that they be occupied with heads of Glass, for they be better, seeing that
through them the matter as it is in ^ystilling, may be seen, as it is before
declared. Wherefore who so is minded to make Dystillation of Arsenick,
Orepment, Cinnaber, Mercury, Sulpher, or any such like Bodies, he must
remember before to buyld a common Furnace for dystilling, round or square,
according to the will of the Dystillatour, and that two round holes of a
finger bygnesse, be made of each side the Furnace, for the venting or breathing
forth of the fire. These done, on the mouth or myddle hollow place of the
Furnace, shall you bestow a deep Earthen pan, filled with fine sifted Sand
or Ashes, for the staying vpryght of the Glass Body: under the bottom of
which Pan, let be cowched an iron Bar overthwart or cross the hole,
retching from the one side to the other, for the stronger bearyng of the weight of
the Pan: and the lyppes of the Pan so stronglye mortered with the head of
the Furnace, that the fire breath not forth, between the Earthen pan and the
Furnace. After this, put in Coals by the myddle door, and kyndle the fire,
which ought to be at the first gentle and soft, unto the time that the Furnace
waxes hot, and that the matter contained in the Body begins to dissolve
and melt. After may a man increase and fortify the heat more and more, for
so long time as that he sees not rising any more fumes, by the mouth of the
Body, otherwise named a Gourde or Cucurbite.

As touching the Copper Vessels, said in an Empericke Chemist, that there
needs no tynning of them within: because the Tynning draws somewhat to it
of the Waters and Oils, which hanging to, so consumes the more, that the
Copper Vessels simply do not.

The Cucurbites or Glass bodies ought sometimes to be very long necked, as
when we seek and covet a purer and subtiller lycour: Which sort of most long
necked Bodies (as writes Cardane) serve for the only turn and purpose of
dystilling the Quintessence, when as we would that the subtiller parts or
spirits, and not the grosser and more earthlye, to ascend from the bottom of
the Cucurbite or Glass Body.

In the time of dystilling any substance, a man must now and then cool the
Lymbecke or head of the Glass, with Lynnen clothes dypped or wette in mean
cold water, and those after the gentle wrynging forth, to lap wittily about
the Head, that the vapors and spirits (through the same doing) may the
sooner thicken and fall down into the Gutter about: But a man may avoid this
labor and traueyle, if he orders the Lymbecke or head of the Cucurbite,
after the manner which the skylfull Louicerus descrybeth in his Treatise of the
Art of Dystilling, under these words.



Choose a Vessel of Copper, having the form of an Helmet, for so it is named
of ye Germans, or of a Limbeck (which is the Cover or Head of a Distillatorie
Vessel) as the same is here marked here with the figure B. Aloft the said
Lymbeck, put another round Cover (having an hoale on the top) of the fashion
which the letter A. here demo^strateth, that it touches nothing at all the
aforesaid Cover or Lymbeck, which fill with cold water, that the compass
about of the cover C. may refresh and cool the neck and gutter of the Limbeck.
The nose of the Limbeck must retch through the neck of this Cover that
cools, as the figure C. playner shows. And if it comes to pass, that the
water contained in the Cover, which compasses the Lymbecke or Head, be hot
through the continuance of time, of the heat of the Lymbecke, draw the same
forth by the Tappe or Cock fastened to the bottom of the Cover, as the figure
D. here demonstrateth, and into it pour other cold water: this so often cool
and draw by the Cock, until the work be ended. Or you may put certain
drawing pypes into the Cover, such as you see here lively descrybed, which
within short time will draw forth all the hot water of the Cover, by putting
the shorter end into the hole of the Cover: after into it pour cold water,
doing the like (when need requires) as above taught. He further sets
forth, another manner of cooling the head of the Lymbecke, on this wise: put an
Ox bladder on the Helmet, which drawn aloft, tie hard and close with a sure
Cord, about the neck of the ^^mbecke: this done, pour cold water into it,
filling the same round about the neck and Gutter of the Lymbecke, which being
come hot by heat of the Lymbecke, empty by the Tappe fastened in the
Bladder: after fill the same again, and do the like, as above taught. Herein
remembering that the top of the Bladder, be fastened with a string, for the
better retayning of the water. Such manner of coolinge profit and avail very
much, when any draws forth by Dystillation of the Symples, pure, and tender,
which are the Flowers, Herbs, Roots, and Fruits, yea, the Aqua vitae, and
separating of the Quintessence. Some there are of a contrary opinion and
mind, which in no manner will agree to the drawing of a Cappe aloft the Helmet,
nor to any outward cooling of the Head, nor Nose of the Lymbecke, because
that such coolinges repulse and put back the Oils ascending on high, and
cause them to fall into the Cucurbite or Glass Body, from whence they
ascended and came, that afterward they can no more be elevated, nor yet
brought into a vapor, but dry and waste away in the Body.

The Beak or Nose of the head, ought not to be longer (for the more part)
than from twelve unto eyghtene inches of the Thumb, before that it touches
the water: where otherwise if the Gutter be longer, as well the Oils as the
Waters should consume somewhat the more.

The manner of Dystilling in the Sun. The.viij. Chapter.
THe singular man Adam Louicer in his treatise of the Art of Dystilling,
sets forth an easy manner of Dystilling by the heat of the Sun beams,
which also may be used (howsoever a man will) in cold Countries: if so be he
myndeth at all times to dystill Flowers, and such like matters, to the end
that those may retain their savor and other qualities. And the same is to be
wrought on this wise: take (says Louicer) a hollow burning Glass, which
directlye place toward the hot beams of the Sun, after (between the
Beams of the Sun, and the burning Glass) set the Glass Body filled with
the Flowers or other like matter (and to stand in a small Earthen pan of
sifted Sand or Ashes) in such manner, that the Beams of the hot Sun falling
into the hollow Glass, may so beat back and extend to the Glass Body
with the proper matter (as to the object standing right against) which so
causes that lighter and purer matter ascending, to Dystill forth, as more
lively appears by this figure here descrybed.

The Italians have invented another manner and way of Dystilling waters in the
Sun, which with them is often used after this manner. They take two Glass
Bodies with narrow necks and mouths, the one being empty, and the other
filled with Herbs or Flowers. This Glass so filled, they close or ^^op with a
fine Lynnen cloth (bound about) through which the lycour may aptly pass or
dystill. After that, they thrust the neck of this Glass, into the neck of
the empty Glass standing under, and then diligently ferment and stop the
passages and ways round about, with Lute or Potters Claye, or other like
matter, to the end, that no vapor nor virtue of the substance may breathe
forth: This done, set these two Glasses on such wise joined and bound
together in the beams of the Sun, after such manner, that the same Glass
which conteyneth the Herbs or Flowers, may seem to be above, and the other
which is empty, to stand under, for to receive the lycour which is heated and
decocted by the Suns force, that so dystilleth down into the Glass. And on
such wise, do the women of Bononie in Lumbardie, prepare and purchase the
water of Bremble flowers, for the benefit and singular comfort of the eyes. As
touching another manner or way of Dystilling in the Sun, read hereafter in
the proper place taught.

The manner of Dystilling by Ascension, and what especially behooves to be
observed in the said working. The.ix. Chapter.
WE have before taught, that the Dystillation, which is a separation of the
subtle parts from the grosser and heauyer, to be wrought and done especially
after two means and ways, as by the Ascending and Descending. Further, of the
same which is wrought in the Ascending, is one way done, in that named Balneum
Mariae: in another manner by Ashes or Sand, another way in Horse dung, and in
another manner, by another mean heat serving between these. This by the way
in every Dystillation ought to be observed (that how often Oils especially are
to be drawn out of substances) that the Dystillation in the mean time, be in
no manner hyndered or stayde. For if this Dystillation begun, be once let,
insomuch that the matter or substance be cooled, the work or Dystillation
after can never be performed, in that the same can no more ascend. For which
cause, it behooves that this woorking or Distillation, be diligently and
carefully followed unto the end.

The manner very commodious, for the retayning without great pain and
impediment, that the Cucurbites flote or swymme not aloft the Kettle or Pan
full of hot water, when any myndeth to Dystill in Balneo Mariae. The.x.
Chapter.
TO do the like, prepare an Earthen Vessel, or deep Pot glased within, and
the same so large, that it may well receive or contain the Cucurbite, which
it behooves you to fill with water (in a manner to the brynke) at ye bottom of
which, within let four Tyles be laid, as the one lying right against the
other, and those formed with certain rysinges boared through, to the end that
by the holes of each of th^se eminencies or rysings up, a cord or string may
pass, after this form in a manner here described: After you have thus put
through the cords in each hole, place the Cucurbite in the mydle of the Tyles,
before that you pour in the water (as before taught) and after the same manner
tie the said Cord round about the neck of the Cucurbite, to which equally
fasten the four small cords tied and retching from the four tyles lying in
the bottom of the vessel, after such manner, that these four cords may be
loosed or stiffned, and fastened shorter or longer, according as the woorkeman
will have, that the Cucurbite or Glass body to stand deeper, or higher in
the Water. And by this means may the Cucurbite be commodiouslye retained,
which otherwise would not so well be stayed under the water. But if the
Cucurbite shall be of Copper, and not of Earth, in the stead or place of that
coarde, which compasses the neck of the Cucurbyte may a man bestow and
fasten a Copper band, having four small Rings hanging equidistant, to which
each Cord retching (from the bottom of the Vessel) may easily be tied: and
on such wise, shall the Cucurbite or Bozia be stayed in the bottom of the
Vessel, as the same figure aforesaid, lively demonstrateth to the eye.

How a great yield and quantity of waters, may with a small cost, few
Instruments or Vessels, and in a very short time, be dystilled in Balneo
Mariae. The.xi. Chapter.
IF the necessity present be such, that any has to make a great quantity
of waters dystilled in Balneo Mariae, he may accomplish the same with small
charge^, little pain, few Instruments, and in short time, such a yield and
quantity as he would have by this means* in preparing a Wooden bowl or
Tubbe, of a sufficient compass and largeness over, and placed on a form or
Benche being like made of wood: in the mids of which Tubbe, erect and set
from the bottom unto the edge or bryncke of the same (or rather above it) a
great Copper Vessel, in the form of a hollow pype, sufficient large, bored
without round about, and all over with little holes. Under the bottom of the
Tubbe, make a Furnace, within which empty part or space, let a part of the
Copper Pype descend, in such sort and manner, that the water be contained
between the outward bored wall of the Pype, and the part within of the
Tubbe: But within that part of the Pype, which descends by the bottom of the
Tub, let the fire be put and kyndled, for the heating of the water, which being
in such wise handled and done, round about the Pype, and in the rest of the
space of the Tubbe which is full of Water, let many Lymbeckes with their
Helmets be placed (after such manner) that the Beakes and Noses may reach
beyond the edge of the Tubbe round about, for the easier and handsommer
setting to, and fastening of the Receiving vessels. The water within the Tubbe
must he cause so long to sees, unto the time all the matters and substances in
the Cucurbites, be wholly dystilled. The form of making the abouesayd Balneum
Mariae, is borrowed out of that skillful work named Pirotechnia, which in
Englysh is called the Art of Fiery works, or working by fire.

The figure of Balnei Mariae, invented by Alb^casis, as the learned Gesnerus
coniectureth. The.xij. Chapter.


THe Letter A. in this figure represents the Furnace where the fire appears
be made and kyndled: the Character B. expresses the Funnell or Chymney of the
Furnace: the note C. declares the Pot set and standing over the fire, in
which the water boylinge is contained: the Figure D. shows the Pype, by
which the water boiling runs forth into a Wooden Tubbe, standing nygh to the
Furnace: the letter E. expresses the Tubbe of wood, which receives the water
heated, within which is set and stands the Cucurbite or Body of Glass: the
letter F. demonstrateth the Bozia or Cucurbite with his Helmet, which
contains the matter to be dystilled: the figure G. represents the hollow
Pype, by which the water runs forth into another waste Tubbe or Pan
standing under: the letter H. shows the Glass vessel, which receives the
water dystilled. It seems undoubtedly (says the worthy Gesnerus) the same
to be the better fashion of all others, for the Dystilling in Balneo Mariae,
but much more commodious, than if the fire were put under the Dystilling
vessels, Consider and mark the other form, like in a manner to this,
hereafter among the Oils.

The Dystillation of the Quintessence, in Balneo Mariae. The.xiij. Chapter.
TAke four or five measures of the best white wine, or of simple water, or of
May dew, or of other lycour pure, according to the greatness and largeness
of the Bozia or Cucurbite, in such sort, that a third part of the Glass body
remain empty: which done, set the Lymbecke or Head on the Vessel, fast
luted about, with the whytes of Eggs Flower or Meal, and water myxed
together, and spread on a Lynnen cloth: the Body of Glass on such wise trymmed
and prepared, let be set into Balneum Mariae, after dystilling by a small or
most soft fire, day and night, until the time that the five measures be come
to the one half, the same keep, that you have thus dystilled for the
extractions: you shall have a sign or note certain of the perfect
Dystillation of the Quintessence, if you cast a hear of the Eye browe into the
same, and that it sinketh or falls to the bottom incontinent: then have you
brought the Quintessence to a perfection, commodious, and apt for other
Dystillations. The like may you bring to pass and do with water ^ymple, or
May dew: In the mean whiles it behooves, that the Bozia be very long, to
the end that the gross vapors o^ earthly spirits, ascend not on high. The
same Dystillation must be repeated five or seven times over, or so often,
until that it be perfect. And such a fashion or way seems very excellent:
for that the sa^^e infecteth nothing at all the extractions (infused in it)
with any strange quality: you shall also obtain a water with expedition, if
on any juice or lycour heated, you set a Goblet or Bowl of Glass, into which
the fume ascended, turns it self into sweating drops, and those drops
gathered together of the sweatings, are on such wise converted into water. By
the like means and way, is the Vinegar easily converted into water: even so
the vapor of Herbs boiled in Wine, is gathered round about the bottom of
Platters or Dyshes covered over: such a Quintescense is very excellent, for the
clensing of spots, and Web or Pearl of the eyes, especially if a man boil
of the Rue, or herb Grace in white Vinegar, us the worthy Physician Cardanus
affirms.

An ingenious manner of distilling by Sand. The.xiiij. Chapter.


Bestow the matter which you will distyll within a Glass body stopping the
mouth with Paste, that no air at al may breath forth, after do the like, as
follows: Set the Cucurbite into a Kettle or Copper pan full of water, and
fresh Oten straw; which cause to sees softly, until the time that the matter
or substance boyleth no more (as the same perhaps may be, at the consumption
of all the water in the Kettell) after remove the Kettle with the Cucurbite
from the fire, and as soon as the Cucurbite is through cold, put the same a
new into another vessel full of Sand, in which let it be compassed about,
and covered with Sand up unto the neck: after bestow the same in a sunnie
place, where the sun all the day shyneth very hot, and in that hot place
let this stand for forty days together, which time expired, take it forth of
the Sand, and set the Glass again on the Sand only, without a vessel, for
the space of eight days: at the time ended, let it run through a new Lynnen
cloth, and wring the substance hard, in a Press for the purpose. etc. This
manner of Dystillation ought rather to be wrought and done in the Months of
July and August.

A form very rare, of Dystilling by Dung, borrowed out of the work
Pyrotechnia. The.xv. Chapter.
THere is also another fashion and manner of distilling (says a certain
Author) much used of the Chymistes, which is wrought in Horse dung, whose heat
is to be increased by the fume or vapor of Boiling water: after this order.
Let a wooden Coffer or Chest be made, of six Flemishe Else in length, (or
not above four yardes and a half of our measure) and of such a breadth, that
the same may commodiously contain of either side the Vrinall bodies of
Glass: and that there be no more left, than a space, by which the Pype may
pass and retch between the rows of the Glasses, standing on either side.
This long Chest fill with dry dung, myxed with short chopped straw: after lift
up and set the same on a wooden Form or Benche, to the end, that it may
stand the higher and commodiouser, for the performance of the work. These
done, it behooves you orderly to bestow the Vrinall bodies, or Cucurbites of
Glass in the Dung, with their heads above it, and regarding (by their heygth)
over the edge of the Chest on either side: to the end the Noses of the
Lymbeckes, may the handsomer be luted to the receiving vessels: In the myddest
between these vessels must a Pype of Copper or Lead, or if you will, of
Wood, be extended and couched, having bored round about many small holes,
and these in order throughout, or all the length of the pype, the one end of
which to bend after such fashion, that it wholye regards toward the
Ground: to this mouth and end of the Pype, let a vessel of the best Earth,
or of Copper be raised and set, having a long neck and narrow mouth, which
must be conjoined so close to the Pype, that no vapors at all breath forth of
it: This vessel or Pot filled with water, set on a Treuet with three feet,
for to be heated by the fire made under, until the water boil: which by the
like means eleuating or sending up vapors, and those carried along the hollow
Pype (by issuing through the little hoales) do heat the dung, causing after
all the Vrinall Bodies standing in the same, to dystill in comely order, and
with a temperate heat: as the figure before placed, does liuelyer represent to
us.

Of the Dystillation to be done by the Ice. The.xvi. Chapter.
This Dystillation in very deed is marvelous, if that any matter putrified of
a Month or two, is set into Ice, and that it comes to pass (as a certain
Chemist affirms) that the flewme settled, and staying at the bottom, will be
frosen, and the part Oily swymme or flote aloft, which may be separated by the
strayning.

Of a Furnace to dystill very artificial, which the Sarrazenes have in often
usage, borrowed out of Vitruuius the Almaine, by ^ualterus Riffius. The.xvij.
Chapter.
TO prepare and build the Furnace artificial, which serves the Macedonians
and Sarrazenes, or that they most often use: In the beginning a man must couch
or lay (in handsome manner) the foundation, and build the furnace up with
Mortar or Earth very strong (like to the same of the Potters) and with glased
or well baked Bryckes, according to the form which is represented by the
letters R.S.T.V. These on such wise prepared in a readynesse, let the Base or
foot of the Furnace be of form round or square, laid with Lyme and Brickes
after the fashion of a wall, as the letter Q. demonstrateth: on the said Base
co^eh the vessels of Glass, disposed in good order, and a like together, with
fast Mortar laid, according to the form which the letter Y. declares: and to
the end that the said heat temperate be not unprofitable, all the vessels
may be disposed both within and without very well defended, being of Glass,
or earth, or Metal, as the letter Z. playner shows to the eye. The vessels
in such a fashion disposed, it behooves to apply ^arefully and with diligence
the receiving vessels* well closed with Lute round about: to the end that
they no where breath forth: as you see here by the letter V. Further, when any
will dystill water or Oil, the matter ought before to be put into the vessels:
as this letter X. insigneth ^o (...): and after, (...) each ^et the receiving
vessel be (...), as we have above declared: In the myddest of the furnace,
must ^ gentle and soft fire ^e kyndled of Coals, to the end that it may not
touch any of the vessels: and on such wise shall you perform your
Distillation, by the means of a soft and temperate heat. In this Furnace
also, shall you dystill together, and at one time fifty or sixty kinds of
waters, as the figure here placed, does playner demonstrate.

The Venetian and Neapolitane Artificers of Dystilled waters, which have
plenty of Glass Lymbeckes with them, do often use this kind of Furnace, in
which they dystill in a day and night, with a dry heat of fire, well a
hundredth kinds of waters: The Furnace is buylt round, like to that before
described, and after the fashion of the Stoues in Germany. This Furnace
contains and has placed round about the compass of it (as is to be seen)
infinite Glasses within fenced with Lute, being of the form of the greater
Vrinall body, and fastened by a careful skyll to the Furnace, with the
strongest Lute: to each of which, must receiving vessels of Glass be set,
fastened with a bygge stryng to the knobbe of the head, that they may seem
to hang, as the Figure pl^^ner demonstrateth: This Furnace then heat in the
same manner, as they do the Stoues between the Mountains toward Italy, and
whiles the fire in the beginning is vehement or very hot, the Vessels in the
mean time they leave empty, until the heat be somewhat abated, least
through the violent heat, the Plants or Flowers, might be burned: After the
close shutting of the Furnace ^oore, that no heat be lost, they bestow the
Herbs, in the Vrinall vessels, and set on the heads of Glass with the
Receyuers fastened to each: which done, they draw forth a great yield and
^uantitie of waters, which are far better than those purchased out of Leaden
Instruments, in that they bring, with them no infection of Metals. This
borrowed out of the learned Treatise of Mathiolus, De facul. simp. Medica.

Certain Instruments to Dystill, of the Invention of the worthy man Gesnerus,
which he refers to the judgment of others. The.xviij. Chapter.
IT behooves to consider, (says the learned Gesnerus) whether a man may
dystill commodiously with such an Instrument. A. the Vessel of Copper tynned
within, for to be set on the fire, in which the matters are: Now the Herbs
may be put in by themselves, or strawed on a quantity of Sand. B. the
vessel of earth which is bestowed within the Vessel A. Or by a contrary manner
and fashion, that one of the Vessels has a skirte or edge, within which the
other is received. C. the Chaplet of Glass or Earth, or of Copper tynned
within: the mouth of which set into the mouth of B. at the top of C. the
vapor ascendyng is converted into water, shall descend into his nether parts,
which regard toward the Base downewardes: and when need requires, you shall
draw or let forth the water by the Cock: as well for the taste sake when any
will, as for the emptying, when it shall be to full of water: unless he rather
desires to make a hole at the top of the head C. to the end that when it
pleases, or that he shall see needful, he may empty or draw out all
consisting in C.D. is the Vessel or Bucket placed aloft, which contains the
cold water, that serves for the cooling of the head.

An other Instrument to be carried about one, in any journey. The.xix. Chapter.


This manner of Instrumente, marked by the figure 1. may be of Copper tinned
within, to the end that a man may carye it whyther he will, for to dystill
the fountains and Springs etc. and he may empty the same by the hole on the
top. He may also make such a Lymbecke, as that Figure noted by the number 2.
does demonstrate, with a Cock, Tappe, or small beak at the top: or like to
that which the figure denotes, marked with the number 3. Moreover, this only
is the portrature or draught of a Lymbecke, which behooves to be set on an
Vrinall or Glass body, as the first Figure declares: of which the nether
part, that is, the Vrinall Glass, may be luted with the strongest Clay myxed
with Floxe, or waxed about twyce or thryce with molten wax, and on such wise
set on the fire of Coals.

A new form of a Retort. The.xx. Chapter.
LEt a Retort be made of such a fashion, as the letter A. demonstrateth, of
good Earth, that is, of broken Tyles, pieces of looking Glasses, and other
Glasses white and clear, of Potters clay, and the sylings of iron, diligently
powdered and wrought together. B. must be thrust within C. which has an edge or
border. D. the Pype sharpened at the end, made of earth, or of copper, to
the end that it may be thrust into any manner of Glass vyoll, or long necked
Glass with a narrow mouth.

For to dystill the water of Sinamon, a man must prepare such an Instrument.
First set ready a Treuet, on which bestow a vessel of Iron sufficient
hollow, filled with fine Sand or sifted Ashes: or having nothing in it, that
requires then a greater fire, and to be bored full of small holes, into which
set a Cucurbite of Glass well luted, you may include the whole with a band
of an iron plate, etc.

A figure very rare of the Alchymistes borrowed out of an ancient book of
Alchymie, in written hand. The.xxi. Chapter.
THe vessels of separation are those, by which the Quintessence, or secret
spirit, is by one only Dystillation attayn^d, and it is a way very formal,
and the like a very much abrydging of the work: which as much avails unto
Aurum po^abile, or Potable Gold, as for the Philosophers Stone.

In this little Furnace having to the right hand three flames, ought to be
filled with fine Sand and sifted, and that the fire kyndled and flaming to
have three Candles: the second Furnace which is in the mids of the two, ought
also to have Sand, and a fire temperate of two Candles, as does the flame
demonstrate in the d^^re of the Furnace: In the third Furnace to the left
hand, is a Balneum Mariae, and the fire or flame of one Candell. These
Fu^naces ought on such wise to be disposed and set in order, that they stand
nigh one the other, whereby a very small space may appear between Furnace
and Furnace, as the figure above playner shows to the eye.

For the same use, have the Alchymistes devised these Instruments following.



A. the Cucurbite which con^ayneth the substance, with his headde. B. the
head, whose Nose retcheth within the neck C. Into the glass C. does the
secret spirit of the Quintesse^ce pass. Into the receiving vessel D. does
the simple wine or Flewme of the Quintessence fall.

The manner and Instruments of Dystilling by Discention. The.xxij. Chapter.
THe manner of Dystilling by Discention, is wrought in a Bozia or Cucurbite
turned vpside down, which is conioined to ye Furnace with the best lute, that
is, of that part which the body of ye Bozia thickest fenced, touches to the
furnace: after the well drying and closing thus of the Glasse^Body to the
Furnace, that no matter fall through, the Coals then are to be laid upon all
about, and on such wise kindled, that the fire be very gentle. For a small fire
suffices in this work at the first, but when it touches and is come to the
Bozia, let the fire be after increased by little and little. Before the
Dystillation, it behooves to thrust and couch strongly together, the matter
within the Bozia, or to dry thoroughly the same, or with the white of an Egg,
or by long running to stay the matter in the Bozia turned vpside down, to the
end that it shed not forth: During the time of the Dystillation, the matter
cleaves to the neck of the Bozia. etc. This manner of Dystilling is so much
the more perfect and excellent, because the matter seems to be sublymed often
and many times, as nygh a thousand thousand times wrought and driven up and
down, a high and below, during the time of the Dystillation: yet may it not
cause that such an agitacion and moving, to render and yield a perfect
Sublimation of the Quintessence of the matter, that is to say, the Elementarie
converted into the name Elementall, and of a corruptible matter rendered an
incorruptible. After this manner of Dystilling by Discention, may a man attain
Oils out of Woods, and half Mynerals: If so be the mouth of the Bozia strong
luted, be close stopped with a Plate of iron tynned, and stricken full of small
holes: That you may the readyer conceive the manner and Instruments of this
Dystillation, behold the Figure here before descrybed, borrowed out of the
work entitled Pyrotechnia.

That singular man Rogerius* has set forth a like manner of Dystilling on this
wise: Let a Bottell of Earth (well glased within) be filled up to the mouth
with Flowers or Herbs, having in the bottom a reasonable small hole, and the
mouth of it diligently stopped, to be set into the mouth of a larger vessel
like glased, standing under: which done, to close and stop with diligence,
the bottom of the Bottell (within the mouth of the other vessel) with good
Lute or mortar of Potters earth, and to bury both the Pottes wholly within the
Earth, leaving these so covered for a year. The year being ended, to draw
them forth of the Earth, and in the nether vessel shall be found a very
clear Oil, which is dystilled by virtue of the heat and fumes of the Earth.

The form of a Furnace for Balneo Mariae, very rare, and highly commended.
The.xxiij. Chapter.


Behold here a manner or fashion of Balneo Mariae, very excellent, of which
the vessel large and great is of tynne, much like to a bygge Vrinall Body,
in length of three spannes, or three great feet long, very bygge below, and
narrower extending upward: the bottom or bellye of the same standing wette,
well two long feet within the boiling water, and the part above retching
quyte without ye Balneo, in height of a long foot, through a round hole cut
out, in the mids of the cover of the Kettell or Pan, being the Balneo. On
this great vessel is a Lymbeck of Tynne set stedily and fast, covered and
compassed of another vessel like of Tynne far larger, after the form of a
Bucket, that receives the cold water which is caused to run by the Pype or
Cock of Copper out of the upper vessel somewhat long, situated and standing in
the highest part of the Column, and the same for cooling, continually the
Tin Lymbeck standing in the mids, to the end that the vapors which are
ascended, may thicken much better, and be sooner converted into water: so that
this causes, that the Artificers may receive the more yield of water: and
where the same cold water contained in the Vessel or Bucket that compasses
the Lymbecke, may be hot within short time by the heat of the Lymbecke, this
in like manner by a Pype, out of which the water ^^^meth, may incontinent be let
forth in the nether part, through a Cock turned, and the Bucket again filled
with other cold water, drawn out of the vessel on high: But to the end a man
may not have so great a labor and pain to empty so often the hot water, and
to pour in of cold, he may dispose the same on such wise: that from the
vessel which is standing at the top of the Column, he may continually draw
out so often of the cold water into the Vessel which compasses the Lymbecke,
as he lets forth of the hot to run out of the same, in opening and
shutting of the Cocks of the Pypes, when need requires: And to the end,
that the Kettell or Pan of Copper, in which the Balneum Mariae is, may
always be full with a like quantity of water, which otherwise is wasted by
the vehement and continual heat of the fire in the Furnace: it is devised
therefore by Art, that another vessel below, or in the nether part of the
Column placed full of very hot water, which may be caused to run
continually into the Balneum Mariae by a Pype governed of his Cock. And this
water is heated within his vessel* with the same fire that the Balneum is
heated: for so much as the wall of the Column is hollow and empty unto the
bottom of that nether vessel. This sort or fashion of Balneum Mariae, is
commended for the dystilling and yield of waters in great quantity, by reason
of the cold water which thyckeneth and conuerteth incontinent the vapors
into water. For a readyer conceyuing of the former taught, behold the Figure
before lively set forth to the eye: Borrowed out of the learned Treatise of
Mathiolus.

The form of another Furnace for Balneo Mariae, to be wrought by sundry
Instruments of Glass at one instant time. The.xxiiij. Chapter.
THere is another fashion of Balneo Mariae, which contains four Limbecks, of
which, ye vessels being large, that are set into Balneum Mariae, may be of
Glass, or of tynne, but their heads only of Glass, for the persiter seeing
of the spirits ascending: Besides these four Bodies with their heads, there
is placed another comely instrument, which stands far higher than the
others, that is heated only by the vapor of the water boiling (arysing from
the Balneo Mariae) which ascends on high by the means of a great Brazen
Pype: and this renders or dystilleth by the Herbs or Flowers contained in it,
the best water of all the other four: All these vessels well joined and closed
diligently, are to be set into round hoales cut out of the Cover, that they
may so be stayed upright, on the mouth of the Kettell or Pan of Copper
sufficient large and capable: the same also covered with Tynne, and closed on
such wise round about, that no vapor of the water of Balneo Mariae boiling,
may breath forth: Moreover, all the Instruments require so to be placed and set
round about, that these seem not but as one Body together: excepting the
heads, which may be separated and taken of, and those set on again, when
need requires for the dystilling of waters: That this description may playner
appear, behold the figure lively set forth to the eye: Borrowed out of the
Treatise of Mathiolus, at the end of his Commentaries upon Dioscorides.

Of the Dystillation by a Fylter. The.xxv. Chapter.
FIll a wide mouthed Glass, or earthen Pot, with thycke water or any juice,
and take a List or piece of Woollen cloth, being two palms or a spanne long,
and fashioned sharp at the one end, like to a tongue which wholly wette in
water: After lay the same into the Glass or Pot, in such order, that the
one half in a manner, may seem to lie wette within the water or juice, and the
other to hang over the edge of the Glass, or mouth of the Pot without: which
on such wise ordered, you shall then see all the lycour to drop forth of the
Glass, within short time: when you see that the cloth begins to furre, and
waxes fowler or blacker, or the drops dystill slower, by reason of the
grounds or grosser substance drunk in, then the Fylter or List shall you
(at such times) wring hard out, and washing it clean, lay again into the
Glass or Pot until the work be finished. Further learn, that the repeating
of iuyces, waters, and lycours, three or four times over by a Fylter, are
caused both the purer and clearer: if so be you (...) out the ^ee^es or
dregs, as often as need shall require the same.

Some Chymistes there are, which ex^rcysing this manner of Dystilling by a
Fylter, do sometimes use (in stead of it) two crooked Glass Bodies, named
Retortes: the one of these filled with the matter, and put into the neck of
the other being empty (and luted close about): place them so, that the same
being filled, A standing higher, with the body, bending up whereby* it might
the easier and speedyer distill into that marcked with the letter B. standing
lower* For by this manner of distilling, is the lycour (dygested before in
Balneo Mariae) caused the purer, neater, and pleasanter of smelling: But this
Dystilling by a Fylter, is oftener exercysed of the Chymistes, than of the
Physicians: and devised by them to separate the subtiller, lyghter, and purer
matter, from the heavy, gross, and full of dregs, as often as need shall
require the sa^^*

Of the same named vulgarly the Lute of ^ysedome, with which the Chymistes use
to parge^ and fence the Dy^^illatorie vessels, and for to stop or c^ose their
Ioy^^^, that no ma^ter breath forth. The.xxvi. Chapter.
FOrasmuch as we have hitherto entreated su^^^cientl^^, of the Instrument^
necessary, for Dystilling of the most matters and subst^nc^^ (...) therefore
(...) this present, that we likewise set forth and t^^ch the manner of the same,
which defends the vessels from the violence and ^^ghtie heat of fire: and
that closes and fast joins them ^^gither in the ioynt^^, to the end, that
the Dystillation may be the (...) performed* And this is the Morte^* of which
the Chymistes have need for the perfourming of their works, (...) Lute. Now
(...) diverse, sorts of Mortar* as the one named (...) only for the buylding
o^ ^urnaces and Towers for dystilling* The other is named the Lute or Mortar of
wisdom, with which the vessels of Glass are p^rgetted and fenced, to the
end that those may the better sustain and abide the violent force of fire*
The other is profitable for the conioyning and (...) the (...) of the vessels
gaping or ^hapt: although the Mortar of wisdom may sometimes serve for
stopping and fencing the crackes an^ cleftes of Glasses.

The Lute or Mortar common, fit and the best for Furnaces* may on such wise be
prepared: Take Chalk or Potters claye, or earth which appears very fat and
cleau^ng* to the same add a little quantity of Sand or gravel, myxing or
wor^ing with these Woollen floxe, and Horse dung, After incorporate and labor
the whole together with great diligence, unto the time that it be of a
consistence more ^ft, than hard or dry. This borrowed out of Leonarde
Fiarauant.

A Lute or Mortar for the buylding of Furna^es, and the P^ilosophers Tower:
Take a quantity of Hearts hears (with which Sad^^^rs are act (...) to stuff
Saddles) being before well shaken and beaten, or else take floxe of Wo^llen
^loth, dr^sse or beatings of Iron (flying from the Anuill) Lyme, the blood of
a Bull, or Wether: of these well myxed and wrought together, couch and erect
your Furnaces with Tyles and Bryckes.

A Lute or Mortar, for to parget, cover, and arm or fence the vessels, to
the end that those crack not by violence of the fire: Take the fine powder and
well searsed of Tyles, the powder searsed of the beatings of Iron about the
Anuyll, the powder searsed and very fine of Sand, of each one pound, of fat
Lute or Cley well cleaving three pounds: all these diligently temper with
Lie, after myxe them carefully, by stirring the whole strongly together with a
staff: to which (in the working) add always a third part of shoren floxe,
brought very small and myxed as it were in powder: which done, let the whole be
well stirred and myxed together. The vessels pargetted and covered with this
Lute or Mortar, may well abide the violence of fire, without breaking or
cracking at all, if it be somewhat thycke laid, and even spread about the
Bodies.

The Glass Bodies for to be pargetted or covered with Lute, require to be
wrought clear, smooth and without knots or bladders: in that otherwise they be
in danger of breaking, for the weakness of composition, and may lesser or
weakelyer endure the heat of fire. These on such wise strongly made by the
Glassemakers, ought to be fenced with the best Lute (named the Lute of
wisdom) up to the narrower part of the Glass body, or three fingers breadth
higher for Aqua fortis, and such like, and spredde round about of a reasonable
thickness: to the end the Coats made strong; and the choppes filled with the
best Mortar all about (after the well drying of them diverse times) may the
aptlyer abide the forte of fire: The commended Lute or Mortar for the vessels
of glass, is to be made of Potters earth, with a fourth part to the same added
of shoren floxe, and an eight part of white Ashes, with a fourth part of dry
Horse dung, all these well incorporated together, ought to be well beaten with
an Iron rod. For this on such wise ordered, is the composition that the
Chymistes name the Lute of wisdom, with which they cover and fence the
bottomes of those bodies, that they mind to occupy unto Dystillation. There
be some that add to this composition, the powder of Brycke finely beaten and
searsed, and the scales or beatings of Iron searsed: and for the apt drying of
the vessels thus fenced, do make a long Wooden form, bored full of holes
all along, into which they thrust or put the necks of the Glass Bodies, with
the mouths turned downewarde: and on such wise they set all the vessels
together to dry in the Sun, or in the wind, or by the fire, or in some hot
place* which on such wise thoroughly dry, they apply to diverse uses, or as
pleases them for the dystilling of matters: That the form of drying the
vessels may readyer be conceived, behold the Figure before demonstrated to the
eye.

Another fashion of Lute or Mortar, often used of a certain skylfull man: Take
of the fine powder of Sand searsed, one pound: of the scales or beatings of
iron (about the Anuill) brought into fine powder, so much: of Glass beaten
into fine powder, as much: of fat Potters Earth and cleaving, three pounds: to
which add a third part of a pound of the shoren flox of cloth, with old water
of Tartar, or Salt water: which done, myxe the whole together, and work it
strongly with an iron rod, as before taught.

Another. Take of Venice Glass, and of Tartar, of each a like quantity: of
Salt Armonjacke a little, these beat and labor well together. Of this shall
you use, when that you will diligently Lute any thing, or seal glass with
glass, by smearing it round about the vessels when they are hot.

Another for to defend that the Glasses break not by the force of fire: Take
what quantity you will of Alum, putting the same into an earthen Pot, on
which pour clear water to putrify, after boil the whole with diligence, and
skimme it: which done, let this thoroughly cool, then smeare or dawbe with the*
said mixture the Glasses without, until that you may well and safely bestow
them in the fire, or on Sand: these let to dry by themselves, and do the
like unto a third time.

Another Lute or Mortar for to defend the vessels, that they crack or
break not in pieces, by force of the fire, or by violence of the spirits, and
that p^rpetually they may contain and keep Aqua fortis, or the strong water.
The vessels smeared or dawbed with the said Mortar, ought to be well dried in
the Sun: It is also profitable for the conglutinating or fastening together
of Glasses or vessels broken: Take of Glass and V^rmilon, of each a like
quantity, these labor into most fine powder, after sift it through a fine
searse, then incorporate the same with Vernishe: adding to it a little of the
Oil of Lynseede, and making of the whole like to a soft Pultise: which done,
spread the same on a fine Lynnen cloth, and apply or wrappe it about the
Orifices of the vessels, or their joints, letting them so to dry in the Sun
by themselves: which although it be very slowly done, yet does it retain and
keep the fire, the strong water (named Aqua fortis) and the kinds of the
strong water. This is very true, and experienced by the Author of the work
named Pyrotechnia.

For the fast closing and stopping of Glasses, the grounds and thicker
substance of that Mortar of other Glasses made, is very commodious: the self
same does the Meal, Lyme, and Bole Armoniacke myxed together, in the form of
Paste like avail.

Another Lute or Mortar to be applied about the joints, which so lets or
stops, that the vapors in no manner breath forth: Take the fine pouders of
Glass, and Litarge of Gold sifted through a searse, of each a pound: the
Meal of Wheat, two pounds, myxe these diligently, and work or labor
them very well with the whytes of Eggs in the form of Paste, extended and
spredde on the one side of a wette Lynnen cloth, for to apply about the
joints: after that it shall be through dry, bestow or lay yet another
Lynnen cloth upon, and on such wise the spirits shall be retained.

If the Glass that any has to set on the fire, happens to be cracked, it
may be stopped by this means, that the spirits breath not forth: wette or
steep diverse Lynnen clothes in the whytes of Eggs well beaten, those apply
on the crack of the Glass hot, the one after the other, of such sort, that
as soon as the one shall be dry and hard as any crust, to bestow an other,
and in like manner another consequently: Such a kind and form of Mortar is
commended for the Luting and fencing all about of vessels, when as any will
dystill Aqua fortis, or strong water, or the Oil of Vitrioll.

A Lute or Mortar of wisdom on this wise: Take fat Cley, and Horsedung, these
strongly myxe and work together with Wine, Ale, or Beer: and in the second
laboring together, add shoren floxe of Clothe: and in the third working
together, myxe pure Wheaten Meal and Flower, with the whytes of Eggs
diligently tempered: and on such wise shall you make the Lute of wisdom.

Or thus, take two parts of Clay, so much of Horse dung, and one part of the
scales or dross of Iron about the Anuyll: all these diligently bring to fine
powder, dissoluing after a part of Salt in water: with that water work the
whole together, spreading the same after on a Lynnen cloth, which apply round
about the vessel.

Another Lute: Take a fast and tough earth, which after the through drying,
bring into fine powder, the same sprynckle with a little quantity of water, to
which add Horse dung, brought to powder: after the well myxing of all these
with the whytes of Eggs, diligently labor them together, then of both joined,
make one myxture, with which you shall Lute round about your vessels.

Another Lute: take of the excrement or upper dross of the Iron, one pound
and a half: of the Meal dust, half a pound: of Glass brought to fine
powder, one pound: of the whytes of Eggs as much as shall suffyce to myxe the
whole throughlye, unto the form of Paste.

A Lute of wisdom is made on this wise, according to Fyerauant the Italian,
in his book of secret inventions, with which a man may lute vessels of
Glass to resist a mighty heat of fire. Take of the best and finest Chalk,
to which add the dross of Iron brought to fine powder, and the common white
Ashes, the shoren floxe, and Horse dung, these Artely myxe together: For this
is the true composition of the Lute of wisdom, which resists the fire
marvelously.

Another Lute or Mortar of wisdom, that is much commended by an Empericke,
which prepares of the Antimonie: Take of the best Cley, beaten and wrought
with the powder of Tyles or Brycke, the dross of iron in powder, and the
Hearts or Ox hears, all which diligently myxe and labor with the whytes of
Eggs, unto the form of Paste,

The correction of Waters and Oils dystilled. The.xxvi. Chapter.
IN every kind of Dystillation, it oftentimes comes to pass, for the
vehemency of the cause agent, that is, the heat, or the default of
Instruments, or the ignorance of the workman, that the waters or Oils
dystilled, attain some fiery heat, or some incommoditie excrementuous or
superfluous, or other such strange quality; as taste, and evil savor: For
which cause it is very requisite and necessary (for the keeping of them a long
time) to know how it behooves to correct all their defaults. For in that
fashion of dystilling, which is wrought and done by force of the fire agent
(says Ioannes Languis) although that the matters which are naturally cold, as
the Nightshade, Succorie, Endyue, Lettuce, and such others are dystilled, yet
those purchase or conceive an Empyreuma, that is, a heat and dryth
accidental, like to things burned: Of which ( Galen affirms) that no one of
burned things, is perfitely cold because in them is left a fiery quality,
which Aristotle reports to be Empyreuma: After this manner the black Choler
or Melancholy, although the same be Earthly and naturally cold, for so much as
it is engendered of blood adust or burnt, yet is it not altogether without
heat, no otherwise than the Ashes and Vyneger. For this reason, the Chymistes
more expert, to the end that the same heat may be lessened and caused (as it
were) mylder, and that the virtues of matters cold, do not euaporate away,
dystill such things, in vessels hanging over water boiling, that they name
Balneum Mariae, which fashion of Dystilling, they learned of the ancient
Apothecaries of the Greeks: which for the same causes procured to boil softly
or gently the Oils, the Ointments of Spykenarde, of Lauander, of Benjamin, and
other medicines of sweet savor in a double vessel: Also the same in a clear
air, on the fire without smoke, and of Coals well kyndled. After which
manner, they more boiled in time past the medicines Arteriacall and
Stomaticall, that the Arabians named Loch: These hitherto borrowed out of
Ioannes Langius. Now not only the Dystillation brings with it this adustion
to waters or Oils, but they also attain by the same means a watery and
excrementuous moisture, which by the Sunning, ought to be corrected in this
manner.

The waters set in the Sun for certain days, in Glasses well stopped with
Lynnen cloth, or Parchment having sundry holes, to the end that all the same
which is excrementuous in them, may so be consumed: and by the said means,
that what the dystilled waters have of strange heat, may in like manner be
breathed away. In cold Countries for correcting the moisture excrementuous of
waters, which can not be rectified nor sufficiently euaporated by the gentle
heat of the sun and the air: set the Glass or vessel which contains the
things dystilled into a vessel full of water, causing it gently to boil for
two or three days together, unto the consumption of a third part of the Oil
(if the same shall be Oil) but if it be water dystilled, then by the like
means the moisture excrementuous (if any such remain) shall easily be
consumed, and the Oil, or the Water rectified. This Rogerius. Or rather that
the Chemists do and observe in the water of Life, by Balneum Mariae: the
moisture watrie (that they name Fleume) is received a part, and separated from
the subtle lycour. But of the other manners of rectifying lycours, we shall
more at large hereafter entreat in the proper place.

Nor there is no less danger in the Dystillation, which is wrought or done by
the heat of dung stynking and rotten: least that there may* remain some
smatch of rottenness or foystynes in the lycour dystilled. Hereof it comes
also (that Langius in his Epistles makes mention) that many worthy Physicians
(in learning and skill of matters) do abhor utterly this ^aner of
Dystilling, by reason of the rottenness of heat, and euaporation of the dung
stynking, which may easily or lightly infe^t the medicines: for which cause
the matters stynking, are always dangerous to the body. To these the same
Author answers on such wise, that when the things be emptyed out of the
vessels of putrefaction, and at the last dystilled by a Lymbecke, are then
purified wholly from the contagion and annoyance of this rottenness: for so much
as the heat of fire resists the poison, and corrects the same: For Hera
also (a worthy Physician of Cappadocia) reports, that when he purposed to
correct the styptickenesse and astriction of his proper medicine, did before
bestow and bury under the earth, the same for three whole Months, and there
left it in a manner to putrify: hoping by the said industry, that the
substance of the medicine might be restored of the more subtle parts.
Wherefore a man may persuade and believe, that if the matters by happ^ shall
gather and attain any infection by the putrefaction, all the same may be
taken away, and corrected by the Dystillation following.

The end of the first Book of secret Remedies* for Dystillations.

The second Book of Dystillations, containing sundry excellent secret
Remedies of Dystilled waters.

Of the Waters simple dystilled of Herbs especially, and of diverse other
Bodies simple.
Of Vinegar dystilled. The first Chapter.
Bestow or put the best Vinegar that you can choose, into a Lymbecke, set
after into Balneum Mariae, or on fine sifted Ashes, having the lyppes or edges
(round about) well stopped with Paste or Meal tempered in water, or with
Paper pasted: which done, make under it a soft fire for the space of three or
four hours, in which time the flewme, that is; the moisture excrementuous is
separated from the Vinegar, which you ought to cast away as a matter
unprofitable. And a man may know that the Flewme is taken away and gone, when
the Vinegar shall be consumed unto a third or fourth part: After, let all the
joints of the Lymbecke be well stopped, to the end that it makes no
euaporation, then increase the fire by little and little: By the same means
shall you dystill forth (for the second draught) a Vinegar very good, and
most white unto the Lies, of which you shall have a sign or note certain, if
you see the Fecies black, and that there comes forth any Lycour which has
the consistence of Honey or Pytch: you may draw the like of Vinegar, Rosate,
of the Elder, of the Cloue Gellyflowers, and others: If any shall infuse all a
night in Vinegar (which is drawn the second time) the Pellitorie, Staphisagre
(or Iuye bruised) in Balneo Mariae, after the expression made, and the grosser
substance thrown away, dystill with diligence the Lycour poured into a
Lymbecke: This third extraction or draught (besides a number of experiences
that a man may work with it) does greatly prevail against the myghtie ache
and dolor of the teeth: This borrowed out of the Book of an Alchymister of
Paris. In the Dystillation of Vinegar only I suppose (says the worthy
Practicioner Leonarde Fiarauante) that the part wateryshe first runs forth,
after the better sort, in ordering the Dystillation, as above uttered: This
second draught of Vinegar, is a matter incorruptible, which Artely separated
from the Fecies, becomes of such force, that it cannot after corrupt. It also
dissolueth precious Stones, and Mynerals, that are laid to steep in it, as
Iron, Tynne, Lattone, Copper, and other like things. It serves for the
clensing and clearing of women's faces, washyng sometimes with it, in that this
corrodeth and wears away all spots: It serves effectuously, for making the
Sirupe of Vinegar: It preserves all matters corruptible put into it, as are
Flesh, Eggs, Gourdes, Melons, Cucumbers, Orenges, Lemmons, Fennel, and to be
brief, whatsoever thing a man will put into it. This in like manner dissolueth
the Rheum, makes a good and clear voice by drincking a little at a time: It
mittigateth the pain in all sores, and in effect is helping in every matter,
and never harmeth in none. If the Vinegar shall be dystilled by a Lymbecke,
unto the time that the Fecies remain dry, and they after burned so long in
the fire, unto the time that they become white Ashes, which after bestowed in a
moist Celler, or other moist place, dissolueth (as the Tartare prepared does)
into an Oil, which is of so excellent virtue, for the health of man's body,
that a man would hardly believe. For gyuing a little quantity of this by the
mouth, it dissolueth the Stone of the Kidneys, and wastes the Stone in the
Bladder: The Vinegar dystilled with a little quantity of the Oil of Tartare,
and pure Aqua vitae together, preserves the faces of women, and makes them to
appear most comely. Sundry other great matters may be wrought with the
dystilled Vinegar, which here for brevity are omitted: and referred to the
wisdom of skillful practicioners to find out.

The Sea or Salt water may a man make sweet, by this means: If he fills a
vessel or Pot with Salt water, and causing it to boil a time by the fire,
does after dystill the same by a Lymbecke, as the Rose water, and the Salt
shall remain a^ the bottom. But to make a great quantity in short time, it
behooves to dystill the same by a Lymbecke having a Bucket on the head, which
fill with cold water, and as the water waxes hot in the dystilling, draw it
forth by the Tap or Cock, and pour cold water immediately into the Bucket:
For by this often cooling of the head, shall you purchase the more yield. And
this is the secret to dystill much at once with a small cost: and the
Instrument being not of this manner fashioned, a man can not dystill but a small
quantity at a time.

The manner of Dystilling water simple, and the waters of Minurall Bathes, to
the end that a man may know the things myxed in them, and of their property:
Borrowed out of the learned work of Medicinal waters of Gabriel Fallopius. The
second Chapter.
A Man may dissolve after two fashions, the waters of Mynurall Bathes by
Dystillation: the one in Balneo Mariae, but such a resolution is hard to bring
to pass: the other by a Distillation dry, which is done in vessels of Glass,
whether they be Vrinall Bodies, or those named (of the Arabians) Bozia, it much
forces not, as I have said: It is sufficient that by this Dissolution of the
water, which is wrought by the Dystillation of dry heat, that all those
things are known, myxed in such waters, without excluding or excepting the
vapors or spirits, which are known by this reason. Have a Furnace wholly in a
readynesse, the fire represented by the letter A. let be kyndled beneath, a
high on the Furnace, as in the hollownesse, set a vessel of strong Earth very
large, (in fashion of a Carnation pot) full of sifted Sand expressed by B.
fill the Bozia or, Vrinall vessel declared by C. (it forces not much whether
of them) with the Mynerall or Bathe water, and that the vessel be set unto the
myddle in the sand, which is within the Earthen pot: let the Bozia be covered
with his head, having a nose sufficient long, signified by the note D. Both
these Lute well together, to the end that there be no cleftes, nor any space
between the two vessels: After purchase a Pype of Glass about the bygnesse of
a finger, hollow and open at both ends, descrybed by E. into the one end of
this Pype thrust the nose of the head, and wrap a Lynnen cloth many times
about that joint, to the end that the passages and pores may on such wise be
stopped, that no vapor at all breath forth: then have in a readynesse a baled
Payle, or other like vessel of wood, expressed by the letter F. full of cold
water* and bored of either side directlye, that the Pype descending from the
nose of the Head, may pass ouerthwhart this Paile along, within the cold
water: By this means and way shall you know what manner of Spirits have been
commixed with the Mynerall water. For the Sand contained in the Earthen pot,
heated by the fire, does make hot by his heat the Bozia or Vrinall body and
the water contained in the same, from which many vapors continually are sent,
which ascending and flying to the head, are there thickened and converted into
water, which running down by the Pype, retayneth as yet the vapors, because
that the water descending by this Pype, is somewhat cooled, by the cold as
well of the Pype, as of the (...) water which is in the wooden vessel
(overthwart the which, the Pype extends and passes along) that touches the
water: so that the cooling of the one and the other, does not permit that the
vapors being in the water which descend, to breath forth: Thus proceed with
that fire under the Furnace, until all the water shall be dystilled forth, and
consumed in the Glass body. This done, draw the Bozia out of the Earthen
pot, in which you shall find and see yet remaining some moisture, the same let
to dry and consume away in the sun, after set in the Sun the Fecies or
grounds which shall be at the bottom of the vessel, and let them throughlye
dry. When the Fecies shall be thus dried in the Sun, then it behooves to
consider and mark what in them is contained. Certain will that the sedunents
or grounds be laid abroad on a fair smooth Table, and behold them in the
Sun, to the end that what bright and shyning Body shall be there, the same
may appear more easily in the Beams of the Sun. As touching my mind in
this, I rather wyshe that another matter be before done: First, so soon as the
Bozia shall be drawn forth of the Furnace, the sediments or grounds being yet
hot, it behooves to approach and put down the Nose to the mouth of the Bozia,
for a man shall easily know and perceive by the smell, whether the same be of
Cleye, or of Earth, which is impossible to know by any other means: In like
manner the savor of the grounds yet being hot, brings or yields a
knowledge of the red Chalk (that we name Ruddell) which renders a savor
sweet, and by the same note is the presence of the Oker perceived. After that,
the sedimentes shall be somewhat more cooled, take a portion of the same,
rubbing it between the fingers: By the same means shall you discern and
know the Sandaraca, Brymstone, Orpyment, and others like: In the end let the
grounds being dry, be spredde on a Table in the Sun, for if there shall be
any small Bodies of Alumne, those will be made manifest by the Sun, so that
on such wise shall they apparently show and be seen: By this manner and
fashion shall you perceive the Salt, if it be gathered in bygge graynes, the
Nytre likewise if it be in great quantity, for that in small quantity the same
is very hardly discerned. The Brymstone, if it be pure, is known by his
color, in that it is somewhat yelow, or palyshe: even so may a man have
judgment or perceyueraunce of Ashes and Stones, clotted and hardened together.
As touching other Metals, as the Gold, Silver Tin, Iron, and such like, are
not known: for that those are sometimes so much myxed with Marble, Ashes, and
such like things, that they cannot be judged or perceived by any sense: yea,
although that you taste the sediment, yet may you know nothing by the same.
For which cause it behooves to proceed and try by another means and way: as
to spread that sediment on a Lamyne of Iron polyshed and burning, or read
hot: for on such wise shall it be ^asie to dyscerne the Ashes, Marble, Gypsum,
Lyme, Brymstone, Salt, Nytre, and Ceruse: For So Much that if it has of the
Lyme, or Marble, they will not be burned at all, but after that some one of the
others shall be burned, they will remain, and possess a color more white
than they had before. And if you discern or see that it has any matter, which
cannot be burned, but rather incontinent becomes very white, know for troth
that ye same is Gypsu^: for which cause, the Lyme, Marble, and Gypsum agree and
partake in this, that they be not burned at all, but remain, and be caused
more white: yet this difference there is, that the Lyme and Marble are slowly
caused white, and their whytenesse is not much more increased than it was
before: But contrariwise the Gypsum attayneth incontinent a whytenesse, which
is much greater tha^ the same was before. The Brymstone is also easily known
by this experience, for so much as that it m^lteth and represents his proper
savor: The Salt likewise and the Nytre are known, for that their sediments (if
they be there) are burned, and will cast forth sparckles: But this difference
there is, for if there be Salt, it will sparckle and crack likewise, if only
Nytre, it will sparkle without cracking: If the matter be myxed of Salt and
Nytre, whiles the sediment is in burning, part of it will sparckle and crack,
and part of it will sparckle without cracking: I never yet found the Lead by
this experience, but I suppose that if it were found in the s^diment, it
would be molten on a Lamy^e of Iron burning. If there be in it of the Ceruse,
the grounds then will render or be caused read, which is also a note of the
Lead, for so much as these two are very little dyffering: For the Ceruse is
made of Lead, and of Ceruse the Vermillon, that is, a like quantity of Ceruse
and Ruddell or red earth burned together: If you see that the sediment is
molten, and become so white as Milk, you may not persuade and gather
incontinent, that there is in it of the Alum, for although that there be
sometimes a note that there is of the Alum with his stone, yet may it be
caused there to be without m^lting, for the Alum is molten one whiles by
heat, an other whiles by moisture: The other Metals cannot be known by any
of these experiences.

I nevertheless have found an Art, which I have experienced at the
Aponitaine Bathes, Lucensis, and the water of Villensis, which is on such wise:
When you will examine and try, if any water has of the Vitrioll, or of Alum,
or other like Mynurall, cause the water first to boil, not in a vessel of
Glass, but of Tynne, or Iron: after that the water shall be boiled a certain
time, let it settle, then after the boiling yet a little more, incontinent
throw or pour into it the juice or decoction of Gall nuttes, in small
quantity: If the water has of Vitrioll, or of Alum, it will incontinent
become black: Or else take some composition black, as is the medicine (named
Verzinum) known in Italy, causing it to boil in water, unto the time that
the water takes a color in manner black: after strain the same, and
sprinckle a quantity of this water on the grounds, and if there be of the
Alum, that color black, will incontinent be restored or caused more clear.
And what I have said of the color left of the medicine Verzinum, as much it
behooves to understand of any other matter, in such sort that the water for
to work or do such an experience, may be made of every matter, which may dye
the water into a black color: and the water so that it be black, it forces
not of what matter the same be caused black. As touching the astriction, which
consists in the Alum, I report nothing of it, in that the Alum being in the
sediment, cannot be known by the taste: For it comes often to pass, that
when you taste the sediment, and that you feel an astriction, yet the same
proceeds or comes not of the Alum, but perhaps of Salt or some other
thing: The Iron, the Copper, and such like Metals, cannot by other means be
known^, but by the corruption and resolution of the grounds, in such sort that
every Metal (that there shall be) may be turned into his proper excrement,
and so of his proper excrement, shall you after know this or that Metal to
be in it. By the self same fashion and manner is known the Iron, the Silver,
the Gold, the Chrysocolla, that is, the Saulder of Gold, the Copper, and such
like. For these reasons it behooves to join and myxe the grounds with some
medicine, or sharp lycour, to the end that every Metal which shall be
contained in the sediment, may be turned into his proper excrement. Now the
sharp and corrosiue medicine that a man may find, apt and fit to do the
same, shall be the strong Vinegar, the Aqua fortis, and such like. Take
therefore the sediment, and bestow the same into Aqua fortis, or other such
medicine corrosiue, and when you shall see the water to be dried up and
consumed, regard and mark diligently, if the excrement of any Metal, be not
on the sediment: as if you see on the Grounds, the excrement of Iron to be
coagulated and heaped together, you shall easily judge the Iron to be in the
sediment or grounds. If you there see of the excrement of Copper, or a matter
green cankered, the same is a note that there is of the Copper, and even so of
the others. Therefore the Mettalles are known by the corruption, and mutation,
or changing of them into their proper excrements: And this shall you know to
be a sure experience and a troth of the matter (as you may easily try in the
doing) if you take a portion of any Metal, as the Fylings of Iron, and shall
myxe the same with the grounds of any matter, and bestow a pain about it,
that the fylinges may be corrupted, then shall you see that the same will be
corrupted into his proper excrement, which is named (of the Latynes Ferrugo)
that is, the rust of Iron. After this manner are known how much and what are
the things which are myxed with the Mynurall waters, that serve to Bathes,
which is especially tried by the industry and work of Dystillation: But
consider and take heed that the green color does not deceive you, which
appears sometimes in the sediment, although that it has nothing of the
Copper myxed: for oftentimes this color is there engendered of some Bole, which
is myxed amongst the grounds: for that cause thoroughly examine and make the
proof, if this color proceeds of the Copper myxed, or Iron, or the
excrement of Iron, or of some Bole, in this sort: Take the sediment of that
water, and pour the same into Vinegar dystilled, and consider or mark what
color the Vinegar represents or draws unto, the like consider what the
color is of the sediment, after that it shall be through dried. For if it has
there the excrement of Iron, the color shall be black: If Bole, the color
shall be read, that is, less black, and tending or drawing to a redness: I
here utter nothing of the savor and taste, for that so diverse is the savor
and taste of Mynurall waters, that a man cannot know of them, what those are
myxed wythall. All these hitherto have I borrowed out of the learned work of
Mynurall Bathes of Fallopius, which I have endeavored to pen or write word
for word, as things appertayning to the matter, of which we have entreated, in
respect that we so oftentimes entreat of Metals in this Book, which are
things worthy to be examined diligently, for the utility and profit of most
men.

A collection of certain waters dystilled of Herbs, Juices, Lycours, and
Fruits.
The water of Hemp. The.iij. Chapter.
THe congruent time of dystilling the Hemp, is, that the tops as yet tender
and green, shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae. This water greatly
helps the pains of the head proceeding of a hot cause, if the head, the
foreheade, and Temples, be often labored with the same. This also profits
against any heat, in what part or member of the Body it shall be, especially
the Gout, if a Lynnen clothe dypped in the water, be applied on the place: and
this in the Winter use twyse in the day, but in the Summer three times of the
day. Take of the water of the green Walnuts one ounce, of the water of
Egrimonie an ounce and a half, of the water of Rewe, half an ounce, of the
water of Hysope three ounces, of the water of Hemp four ounces, these myxe
together, of which take half an ounce, adding to it half a dram of Mumia,
half an ounce of Sugar Candy, and a dram of the Conserve of Roses, this
after the drinking warm to bed, and lying down well covered with clothes to
sweet, expels those wicked humors of which the plague proceeds: the same
potion helps the Dropsy, taken in the same manner, and preserves a man from
such sickenesses: A water dystilled of the Hemp seed with the juice of
Garlic, of the same fashion that the Rose water is dystilled, which is
Cosemeticall, that is, profitable for garnishing, for it causes hears to
grow in the bare and balde places, being often applied.

The water of Walwort. The fourth Chapter.
THe best time of dystilling the Walwort, is, when it begins to bear
flowers, that then the whole Herb and root finely shredde and bestowed in a
Cucurbite or Glass Body, may be distilled by Balneo Mariae, this water
drunk with a little Sugar, or the juice of Reysons, unto the quantity of
four or five ounces at a time fasting, does loose the Belly: In the same
manner drunk morning and evening, avails against the swellings of the
Body, but especially the Dropsy: even so this drunk, helps the Quotidian
Ague, and stytches or other pains in the sides: it profits against the
outward swellings of the Body, by applying Lynnen clothes wette in the same:
This water also remooueth stytches or other griefs in the sides, by applying
Lynnen clothes wette in it: This gargelled with a little of the powder of
Pellitorie, helps the falling of the Vuula down: This drunk warm (after
the manner above taught) helps a dry cough: This gargelled in the throat,
helps that swelling there, named Angina: The dystilled water of the roots
finely shredde, does much mitigate the grievous dolor of the Gout, by daily
dryncking and applying Lynnen clothes wette in it, on the grieved places: This
also helps marvelously joint aches, by applying on the grieved places,
Lynnen clothes wette in it: and eating a few of the tender green tops
(whether two or three) in a Sallate, causes a man soluble, and to have sundry
stools: The water drunk with Sirupe of Vinegar, helps a burning Ague: The
powder of the leaves marueylouslye works in all sorts of Ulcers, in that the
same asswageth pains, cleanses them, and does incarnate.

The water of Imperatoria. The fifth Chapter.
THe time aptest for dystilling the Herb Imperatoria, is, when it yields the
flowers, then the whole Herb with the roots well shredde (although some
rather will the roots only) require to be infused in wine for twelve hours,
after the bestowing into a Cucurbite, dystill the whole (after Art) in Balneo
Mariae: This water drunk, does marvelous expel the wind of the stomach,
Bowels, and Belly: for which cause, auayleable in the Cholicke p^ssions, and
t^^sion^ of the stomach: This also procures the Terms in women, and moves
vryne: If asswageth toothach, by washing the mouth therewith: The same myxed
with Rosed Honey, and drink warm, helps marvelously the griefs and
stranglings of the womb or Matrice in women, and Conception greatly
furthereth, where the impediment proceeds of coldenesse. This water in like
manner drunk warm, strengthens the stomach, and causes digestion. This
water sundry times gargelled in the mouth, comfort a cold Brain, and
purges it effectuously of Flewme: A dram of the powder drunk with a
quantity of the water, preuayleth in cold sicknesses: so that this
marvelously helps the loose parts of the Body, convulsions, and the falling
sickness. This water myxed with Rosed Honey, and drunk with half a
spoonefull of the fine powder of the root, an hour before the coming of the
fit, helps myraculously the Quartane ague: The water gargelled in the
