mouth, amendeth the breath, and strengthens all the senses: This drunk with
half a spoonefull of the powder of the root, helps the plague, all manner of
poisons, the biting and stinging of venymous beasts and worms. This water
drunk with Rosed Honey, and half a spoonefull of pure Cynnamone water,
amendeth such hardly fetching breath, opens obstructions, helps the water
between the skin and flesh, the Dropsy, and diseases in the Mylt: To be
brief, it heateth all those parts of the Body, where cold occupyeth and
offends.

The water of the blessed Thystell. The sixth Chapter.
THe commended time for the dystillation of the blessed Thystell, is, that the
Herb alone finely shredde and stamped, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in a
Cucurbite of Glass about the end of May. This water drunk Morning and
Evening, unto the quantity of two or three ounces at a time, with Rosed
Honye, purifyeth the blood, remooueth headache, comfort and causes a
ready memory, breaks the stone, puts away gyddynesse of the head,
amendeth the consumption of the Body, and preserves the person long in
health: This like ministered, avails against the Plague, and deadly poisons,
received as well within the Body, as outwardly by the stinging or biting of
venymous Beasts applied upon. This water drunk with a dram of the powder,
before the coming of the fit, helps not only the Quartayne, but other
Fevers, whose beginning are with cold. This like drunk, helps the falling
sickness in children. The water drunk with a quant^tie of Rosed honye,
asswageth the griefs of the bowels and kydneys, cease the other torsions of
the Belly, and keeps the Body soluble: It also causes sweating, sleyeth the
worms in the Bellye, amendeth the defaultes of the stomach and womb. The
abouesayde quantity of the powder drunk with pure Aqua vitae, not only
kylleth worms in the Body of Children, but delivers in short time the
grievous pains of the Body. A Pass made with the powder of the blessed
Thystle, white Bread, and Honye, and dystilled with white wine, yields a
water right singular, for the decayed sight of the eyes.

The water of Pellitorie of the wall. The.vij. Chapter.
THe time of the dystillation is, that the whole Herb shredde and infused in
wine, be dystilled about the end of May in Balneo Mariae, the water drunk
with Rosed honey for eight or nine days together, to the quantity of three
ounces at a time, Morning and Evening, opens the stopping of the Liver and
Mylt, purges the kydneyes and Bladder, cease the griefs of the Matrice, and
sends down the Terms in women: The same drunk Morning and Evening unto the
quantity of three ounces at a time, helps an old and continual cough: The
water simplye of the Herb gargelled, and applied without, amendeth the
inflammation of the throat. The above said water drunk with a quantity of
Rosed honye, avails against the Strangulion, and grypings of the Bellye,
proceeding of wind and cold humors. The water applied with Linen clothes wet
in it, asswageth swellings, and pain of the Gout, also the Shingles, burning,
or scalding, and hot ulcers.

The water of Yarrowe. The.viij. Chapter.
THe congruent time of the dystillation of Yarrowe, is, that the whole Herb
shredde and infused in wine, be dystilled about the end of May in Balneo
Mariae. This water drunk every morning (for a time together) to the quantity
of four ounces at a time, and applying of it on the region of the heart,
heateth a cold stomach: This also avails against the worms of the Belly,
and difficulties of Urine: The water drunk with a dram weight of the fine
powder of Cynamone, stays the over great flux of the Terms: The rather if
the green Herb bruised, be applied at that time by a skillful Midwyfe. This
water drunk sundry days, profits that person which has lost his color by
much bleeding, and purges the blood: Also fresh wounds washed with the
same, and Lynnen clothes after the wetting in it, applied upon, morning and
evening, does speedilye cure them. A handful of the herb bruised between two
stones, and applied on fresh and bloody wounds, after the stitching of the
lyppes, if they be great, cures them thoroughly within the space of.xxiiij.
hours, as of experience known by sundry persons. This water drunk, with
Coowe milk, unto the quantity of three ounces at a time, both Morning and
Evening, helps the vehement heat of the Kidneyes miraculously, and in short
time: and it like avails in them, which have the Liver and Lungs vlcered, and
this often experienced in many persons.

The water of Angelica. The.ix. Chapter.
THe aptest time for the distillation of the most singular herb Angelica, is,
when this begins to yield the flowers: then the whole Herb with the roots
(broken and shredde) infused a time in the best wine, to be dystilled by Balneo
Mariae, in a Cucurbite of Glass with his head, and large Receyuer set to the
Nose of it, well closed about with Wax and Rosin myxed together. This water
(thus Artely dystilled) by dryncking a quantity sundry Mornings, does not
only open, attenuate, and expel evil humors, but marvelously preu^yleth
against the Plague, and deadly poisons: The same drunk with a quantity of
Rosed honey, and a scruple weight of the powder of Cynamon, or more, digesteth
Fleugmaticke and clammie humors. Yea, this amendeth the Cough in short time
proceeding of cold, in that it causes the person more easily to spit up,
gross and clammie fleugme. The water drunk diverse Morninges, sweetened with a
little Sugar or Rosed honey, does recover and heal the inner Ulcers of the
Bowelles, and dissolueth the clotted blo^de within the Body, and strengthens
the stomach. This water ministered with a little of Cynamone water, and a
scruple of the powder of the root at a time, for sundry Mornings, does
mirac^lously help swouning, and other passions or griefs of the heart. This
water avails against the biting of mad and venymous Beasts, applied
outwardly with Rewe, and received within the body, with a scruple weight of
fine Tryacle. Hereof it comes to pass, that certain of the later Physicians
have a great opinion in the bestowing of the root (of the Herb) in their
Medicines, for the expelling of poison.

The water of the Nettle. The.x. Chapter.
THe leaves and flowers plucked of, require to be dystilled about the.xiij.
day of July in Balneo Mariae: This water drunk at Morning, Noone, and at
Evening, unto the quantity of three ounces at a time, profits against the
Cholicke passion, and grypings of the Bowels, it puts away the stone, and
griefs of the Kidneyes proceeding of cold. The like quantity drunk, helps
an old Cough, the hard fetching of breath, and swouning, of an intemperate
coldenesse proceeding, and like recouereth the Lungs cold. The same druncke a
time together, preuayleth against worms of the belly, and all manner of wyndie
passions in the same: It profits filthy and mattrie wounds, and sores
running, if they be often washed with the same, or Lynnen clothes wet in it be
applied upon. If linen clothes wet in the water of the red Nettle, be diverse
times applied, does marvelously recover and help in short t^^^, the byte of a
mad Dog. The water of the roots purely washed and shred, before the dystilling
in the Canicular days, drunk Morning and Evening, unto the quantity of two
or three ounces at a time, preuayleth against a long continuing and cold
Cholicke, cease an old Cough, and breaks the Impostumes of the Lungs: The
water drunk and applied on the members, puts away the deprivation of
feeling, speech, and moving, and the Palsy: It also profits the prime
place, loses the Belly, heals the griefs of the Lunges, and is to be
applied to the breast. The same drunk Morning and Evening to the quantity of
two or three ounces at a time, puts away the pain of the stomach, draws
down women's Terms, and expels the yoongling dead: A dram weight of the
powder of the Seeds drunk with a quantity of the water, and a little of the
sweet Cuite of Reysius, provoke a desire to the Venerall act.

The water of Alkakengi, or Winter Cheries. The.xi. Chapter.
OF the kirnels gathered in the Month of August and bruised, let a water be
dystilled in Balneo Mariae, according to Art: This water daily drunk at
Morning, Noone, and at Evening, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a
time (but to Children and Infants only one ounce given) helps the Liver, the
stone of the Kidneyes, and Bladder: The water drunk in the same manner, stays
the dropping of the Urine, speedily purges the Liver, Kidneys, and Bladder.
This also drunk in the manner abouesayde, recouereth the grievous blystering
and soreness of the Kidneys and Bladder, and right profitable for the pyssing
of Blood.

The water of Alchimilla, or Lions foot. The.xij. Chapter.
Unto the congruent Dystillation, the root and Herb with the whole substance
requires to be shredde, and to be dystilled about the end of May, or the
mids of June in Balneo Mariae: This water drunk unto the quantity of three
or four ounces at a time, both Morning and Evening, is not only auayleable
for inward wounds, but heals wynding ulcers, and ruptures: The water
applied with Lynnen clothes wette in it, on outward wounds, does not only
assuage the evil heat, but also closes them in short time: and this
experienced in wound drynckes, ministered by diverse skillful Germans: A
dram of the powder of it, taken with three ounces of the water, helps the
falling of the Bowels into the Codde, or other rupture in short time, without
any cutting. The like weight of the powder, given with the water (sweetened
with a little Sugar) for fifteen or twenty days together, procures the
woman (not apt to conceive, through a coldenesse of the overmuch moisture of
the womb, which lets the retayning of the seed iniected) to conceive in
short time after: The dystilled water drunk, and conceived into the womb,
does myraculously stay the whytes (or white flux from the back) in women:
yea, by the daily iniection, is the privy place made so straight, that hardly
she can be known from the chaste Maiden, the rather by sitting in the
decoction, which then is sooner performed. This also draws up hanging Pappes
or Breasts of women, and causes them to be fast and hard, if Lynnen clothes
wette in it, with the water of Horsetayles, and the dried pears of Roses, with
other ^ipticke things, be often applied.

The water of Barberies. The.xiij. Chapter.
THe fruit of Barberies when they be ripe (as in October) require to be
dystilled in Balneo Mariae: This water given with the sirrupe of Violets, to
the quantity of three ounces at a time, Morning and Evening, does not only
cease thyrst in vehement and pestilent Agues, but suppresseth Choleric and
pernicions exhalations causing an evil heat in man: The same like drunk,
profits against the heat of the Liver, in the Cholicke passion, in the
casting or vomiting up of meat, in fluxes and painful grypings of the
belly, and restores the appetite weak: The water myxed with read Coral,
and drunk, stays the overmuch shedding of the Terms: The water drunk with
the water of Grass, or Purcelane, or Southernwoode, sweetened well with Sugar*
kills the woormes in the Belly: the water drunk sundry times, helps the
spitting of blood: It fasteneth loose teeth, if they be often washed with it:
It strengthens the gummes and Jaws, by often gargelling, and represseth the
hot styllinges from the head: The water closes the fresh wounds in the
upper face of the flesh, and dries up old Ulcers, being orderly applied:
Nevertheless, this water harmeth them, which be grieved with pains of the
stomach, proceeding of wind and coldenesse, and that hardly fetch breath.

The water of Bryonie. The.xiiij. Chapter.
THe root of Bryonie shredde small, requires to be dystilled about the end
of May: This water drunk to the quantity of four ounces at a time, with the
conserve of Quinces, and a little Ma^ticke, helps digestion, cleanses the
breast, mundifieth the brain, opens the stoppings of the bowels, causes
Urine, expels the stone in the Kidney^, and delivers the falling
sickness. The water g^^en with the ^rrup of Roses and Figs wrought together,
does marvelously help the Cough, and resolves hard swellings, especially of
the Mylt. The water drunk with a little Cynamone, draws down the Terms,
purges the whole womb, and expels the dead yongling, the rather if she
sits in the decoction of the roots: The feet washed and labored with the
feign, preuayleth against the gout. Four ounces of the water drunk, with a
dram weight of some Cordial powder, amendeth an evil stomach: but eight
ounces received at a time, loses the Belly. The water asswageth the burning
heat of the Shingles, puts away unseemly spots, moles, and pimples, yea,
clears a red and L^pr^^^ face, and amendeth the scarres of wounds, if it
be often applied after the form of a Liniment: The water applied with Linen
clothes wet in it, does recover a running Palsy, and puts away a swelling,
and the ^ing^ evil. The water sundry days drunk, does marvelously help
the suffocation or strangling of the Matrice, insomuch that it thoroughly
delivers and heals such of the same grief: And a (...) daily de^e^ (in a
(...)) with this grief for certain years, was in the end thoroughly cured of
the same, by drinking of the water boiled with an ounce of the root sweetened
with Sugar (at the going to Bed) once in the week, for one whole year.

The water of Shepeheardes Purse. The.xv. Chapter.
THe Herb with the whole substance gathered and shredde small, requires to be
dystilled in Balneo Mariae, about the end of May, or beginning of June: This
water drunk morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time,
with a little fine Bole and Plantaine water, is profitable for all manner of
fluxes and grypings of the Belly, and helps the spitting up of Blood: in
the same manner druncke, stays the abundance of the Terms in women, if they
sit in the decoction of the Herb and Persicaria or Arssmart: The water orderly
applied, closes fresh wounds, and mitigateth the dolor of all wounds, by
washing them oftentimes with it: This also dropped warm into the ears*
amendeth the matterie running of them: The water applied with Lynnen clothes
wette in it, on Inflammations, and the Shingles, mightily preuayleth: Yea, it
stays all fluxes of Blood, by applying Lynnen clothes wette in it round
about, or on the place. This also commended for the washing of wounds on the
head, in that it mightilye stays bleeding: and the same druncke to the
quantity of vj. or.vij. ounces sweetened with a little Sugar, stays the
bleeding of wounds: The water restrayneth the bleeding at the Nose, if a
Pessarie made with raw silk and dipped or wette in the same, be put up into
the Nosethrils: The like it perfourmeth, if with a Lynnen cloth wette in the
water, it be applied on the foreheade.

The water of Camomill. The.xvi. Chapter.
THe Herb Camomill with the whole substance shredde, requires to be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in a Cucurbite of Glass, about the end of May, or
beginning of June: This water drunk morning and evening, to the quantity of
two or three ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar, does mittigate the pain of
the Belly, and grypings in the Bowels: It strengthens the sinews, takes
away the Palsy, and softeneth styffe members: The same quantity drunck with
Rosed honnie, loses the Belly, purges downewarde Melancholy and Fleugme,
with other clammie humors, and asswageth heat in the Bowels: The water in like
quantity druncke, amendeth the yelowe Iaundyse, opens the Vrinall ways,
procures urine, and breaks the stone of the bladder and Kidneys, by mixing
the Saxifrag^ water with it: It moves the Terms in women, and expels the
dead yongling (if any such be) in the womb of the woman, and all clammie
humors besides of the Matrice: This water druncke, in the like manner
abouesayde, does put away Agues (without burning in the bowels) proceeding of
Choleric humors, or by thickness of the skin: It also opens the Mylt
stopped, puts away swelling of the stomach, by comforting and heating, it
stays besides the flux of the Belly, named Lienteria: In the abouesayde
manner druncke, recouereth the impostume of the Lunges, and amendeth the Leprie:
The water applied with Lynnen clothes on the vlcered priuities, asswageth
heat, and diminishes the pain: The water druncke, and applied with Lynnen
clothes wette in it, does speedily heal the bytte and stinging of venomous
worms and beasts: The water profits the Marrowe or Bones, if they shall be
felt cold, by often washing and rubbing of them with the same: It also
comfort the Brain, cease headache proceeding of a cold cause, stays the
cold running of the ears, and draws down evil humors from the Brain,
gathered of cold, if the head by a Lie made with the flowers boiled in it, be
well washed.

The water of Honysuckles. The.xvij. Chapter.
THe time congruent to the Dystillation, is, that the flowers bestowed in a
Cucurbite of Glass, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the beginning of
June: This water druncke four or five days morning and evening, recouereth
the Cardiacke passion, and hard fetching of breath: The water druncke in the
same manner, helps the Dropsy, the shortness of wind, causing a long
breath, and purges the stomach: This in like manner, preuayleth against the
stone of the Loins, purges the reins, and dissolueth the swelling of the
Mylt: yet by drincking a long time together of this, procures barraynesse all
the life time: This water is profitable for them to drink, which fear the
coming of the Leaprie, and purges the blood: it also amendeth the red
pushes in the Face, puts away Moles, and causes a clear face, if it be
diverse times in the day washed with the same: the water is effectuous, for
Palsy me^bres, which be dried and consumed, if with the same they be daily
rubbed: it profits old and new wounds, washed morning and evening with the
same: it also heals speedily old ulcers on the legs, as the worthy
Chyrurgian Johannes de Vigo affirms, if they be often washed with the same:
this anointed on any swellings heals them, or druncke morning and evening,
to the quantity of three ounces at a time. The water does like recover
astonished or benumbed parts of the body, by diverse days drincking, or
rubbing them with it: it heals the burning or scalding, if the places shall
be washed with the same, or linen clothes wet in it, applied upon them: it
heals the Canker in the mouth, if it be often washed with the same, and the
gummes vlcered within the mouth. A Canker washed with the same, morning and
evening, or if linen clothes wette in it be often applied, does in short time
cure the sore. The water dropped into the eyes, does amend a thick and dim
sight. The water heals a Fistula, puts away whelkes, the ytche, and foul
scabbes, by often washing with the same.

The water of Centorie the lesser. The.xviij. Chapter.
THe time of Distilling this Centorie, is about the end of June: then the
stalks, leaves, and flowers shred together, require to be distilled by Balneo
Mariae in a cucurbite of glass: this water druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of three or four ounces at a time, is right profitable for them,
which have a raw and cold stomach, for all that which is evil and hurtful
in the same, it co^sumeth: this druncke in the like quantity abouesayde,
draws and sends forth Choler, Flewme, and other gross Humors by sieges.
This water druncke of a Child, to the quantity of two ounces, but of a man
(of full age) four ounces, in the morning fasting, expels the worms in the
bellye: the same druncke at the beginning of the fit, puts away the Ague:
but druncke for three morninges fasting (sweetened with sugar) avails against
all Agues. The water druncke in the manner abouesayde, helps the hard
fetching of breath, and puts away an old cowgh. The water druncke of a
woman, expels out of the womb the dead younglyng. This is right profitable
for staying the desire to vomit, and belching of the stomach: it procures an
appetyte to meat, purges and expels gross Humors, of which are wont to
proceed Ache and pain in the hyppes, feet and hands, the Iaundyse, and
others like. The water sweetened with sugare and druncke in the morning fasting,
recouereth the stopping of the Liver, Loins, Milte, and Bladder: and amendeth
the hardness of the Liver and Milte; it preuayleth against the Chollicke
passion, and gripinges of the bowels. The water closes and cures new wounds
big, if they be washed with the same, or by Lynnen clothes wette in it
applied upon: and old ulcers that may hardly be brought to a scarre, are
doing in the same manner covered with a scarre. The water druncke much
avails, in the spitting of Blood. The water mixed with a little Honny, and
dropped into the eyes, greatly clears them: the same druncke, sends down
the Terms. This druncke, helps the sinews affected, by emptying and drying
up the matter offending. The water sweetened with Sugar and druncke fasting, is
much auayleable, for the obstructions of the liver: and applied as well without
the body, as received inward, is a singular remedy in the hardness of the
Milte.

The water of Cherryes. The.xix. Chapter.
THe great, read, and sower Cherries with short stalks, when they shall be
ripe, are to be gathered: And for two days spread abr^de on a shete, after
distilled by Balneo Mariae, in a Cucurbite of glass: This water druncke twice
or thrice a day, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, sweetened with a
little sugar, does restrain the terms, the flux Dysenteria, and all other
Fluxes of the Belly. In the same manner druncke and applied without, amendeth
the heat of the Liver, stomach, and other parts of the Body, and comfort
the heart. The distilled water of the flowers, dropped into the eyes at
evening, when the pacient goes to bed, puts away the pin and web, and
other spots of the eyes: and the water like puts away the redness, and
watering of the eyes, if it shall be dropped into them, twice or thrice a day.
The water of the black Cherries (distilled in the same manner) druncke twice a
day, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, helps the Dropsy: but it
behooves that the pacient in the mean time refrain, from taking any other
drinck. The water druncke in the same manner, remooueth the depryuation and
Palsy of members: so that they be washed and rubbed with the same, and let to
dry in by it self: in like manner washing and gargelling the mouth with it,
restores the use of the tongue lost. Also such annoyed with those griefs,
ought daily to drink the water fasting, to the quantity of two ounces at a
time. The water druncke helps swellings, and is auayliable in burning, and
pestilent Agues, in that it cools seasseth, thirst, and yields strength.
The water (of the ripe black Cherries, newlye distilled in a Cucurbite of
Glass by Balneo Mariae) druncke to the quantity of half an ounce at a time,
or powered into the mouth at the time of the fytte of the falling sickness,
does forthwith reuyue the person to knowledge of himself, and causes him to
be free from convulsions and Crampes, until the next fit take him. Which
as soon as it shall happen to come again, let the same quantity of the water
be powered into the pacients mouth: for this not only shall let, but take
away, and heal altogether the fit: as the like, of experience known. A
certain woman afflicted with the falling sickness, recovered health, and was
delivered thoroughly of it, by the daily receiving (and at the fittes) of the
water distilled of the black Cherries, the lesser Nettill, and the flowers of
the tree named Tilia. The water distilled of the meat and kernelles bruised
together, does send forth the sand, procuring the stone in the Kidneyes and
Bladder. The Gum of the tree infused a time in this water, and druncke twice
a day, is not only auayleable against an old cough, but helps such as are
vexed with the stone.

The water of Cheruell. The.xx. Chapter.
THe chosen time for the distilling of Cheruell is, that the herb the root,
with the whole substance finely shred, be distilled by Balneo Mariae, about
the middle of May: This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of
four ounces at a time: helps persons bursten, and harmed by a grievous fall,
and resolves the Blood clotted into lumpes. The same drunk, helps the
stone of the Kidneyes, and a great quantity druncke at a time, loses the
Belly: it causes a good stomach, strengthens and comfort the heart,
puts away the cold shiuering or shaking of the Ague, amendeth the head,
and comfort the senses. The water druncke in the manner abouesayde, puts
away most great pains, and prickinges or stitches, it helps the Lunges, and
his affectes or griefs.

The water of Germander. The.xxi. Chapter.
THe time of the distillation is about the middle of May, then the herb with
the whole substance shredde small requires to be distilled by Balneo Mariae:
The water druncke fasting, to the quantity of four ounces at a time,
dissolueth the swollen and hard Milt, provoke Vryne, and sends down the
terms. This druncke in like quantity, cutteth asundre the gross and clammie
Humors, cleanses the stoppinges of the bowelles, and expels the youngling
dead. This water for an inward rupture is right profitable, if to the
quantity of four ounces at a time, it be often times (in the day) druncke.
The water daily druncke, morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces
at a time, sweetened with a little sugare, purges, and causes good Blood,
gladneth the heart, refreshes and cools the Liver, especially if it shall be
distilled with the flowers. The water also recouereth the exulceration of the
mouth, if it be often washed with the same.

The water of the stock Gelyflowere. The.xxij. Chapter.
THe congruente time for the dystillation is, about the end of April or
mids of May, when the flowers shall be full blown: then the herb with the
whole substance finely shredde, ought to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in a
Cucurbyte of Glass. This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity
of two ounces at a time, recouereth the Frenticke person, and comfort the
Brain. The water in ye same manner druncke, strengthens the Liver, and
Kidneyes, procures the Terms, causes women to be fruitful, cleanses them
after the birth of Child, and sends forth the younglyng dead. In the same
manner the water druncke, heateth and comfort the heart cold, sharpneth the
senses and reason, ioyeth the mind, cleanses and strengthens the Blood
corrupt, heateth the marrow of the bones, and recouereth cold Fluxes. The
depriuatio^ or Palsy of the tongue, does the water help: or if the sides
shall be molested with this evil, the water thoroughly recouereth, by drincking
twice a day of it, or rubbing the members therewyth. The water delivers the
trembling of the hands, if they be rubbed with the same: the like does the
water perform, druncke Morning and Evening. The water druncke morning and
evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a time, temperateth the heat of the
heart, comfort and opens the same. The water droped twice in the day,
does put away spots in the eyes, wheather those shall proceed of heat, or
of cold, and procures a clear and fair face. The water seaseth all pains
of the head, by applying and binding about the head, Lynnen clothes wette in
it: and in the same manner applied, procures sleep to weak persons.

The water of Dragons. The.xxiij. Chapter.
THe congruent time of dystilling is, that the root shredde and bruised be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, between the months of July and September. This
water druncke with a little Rosed honnie, preuayleth against the plague. The
water druncke morning and evening, helps the Cough, opens obstructions,
attenuateth gross Flewme, purges the breast of evil humors, cleanses the
Bowels, and helps the dropping of Urine. The water is greatly auayleable, if
any shall happen to have a grievous fall, or be stricken, or pricked with
weapon, or bruised by staff, that the Blood within the body or skin shall
be congeled: then take a wine pint of this water, and four ounces of Muster
seed bruised, these after the tempering with four ounces of Cheruell water,
and strayned through a cloth, and wringed out to the manner of Milk, give to
drink (sweetened before with half an ounce of Sugar pennuttes) morning and
evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, for this thoroughly helps
in short time. If Cotton wette in the water, be laid on fresh wounds,
stays the bleeding of them. It also heals wounds, by Lynnen clothes (wette
in it) applied upon: or by drincking morning and evening, to the quantity of
two ounces at a time. The feet astonished and without feeling by cold, wash
morning and evening with the same water: For it expels the cold, and
mitigateth the grief. The person bytte or stinged of a Snake or Adder, let him
wash the grieved place with Lynnen clothes wet in it, and apply those upon the
sore, for it speedily helps. The like does heal a Canker, if Lynnen clothes
wette be applied.

The water of the greater Comferie. The.xxiiij. Chapter.
THe roots with the whole Herb shredde and bruised, require to be dystilled
by Balneo Mariae about ye middle of the Spring. This water druncke, helps
such as are bursten, and that have broken the bone of the leg: by taking of
the same to the quantity of three ounces at a time, both Morning, noone, and
at Evening: It heals the choppes of the lips, if they shall be washed with
the same. The water druncke, and Lynnen clothes (after the wetting in it)
applied upon, does speedily heal wounds, and extinguisheth inflammations, and
seaseth pains. The water in the same manner applied, asswageth the burning of
the Shingles, and expels outward swellings. Applied with Cotton wette in
it, stays the bleeding of wounds: the like it performs, if myxed with any
other drink, it be druncke twice or thryse a day. The water druncke twyse a
day, dissolueth and sends forth the clottes of blood congealed in the
stomach, or in any other part of the Body. And this applied with Lynnen
clothes wette in it, does marvelously cleanse and sease the running of Matterie
ulcers eaten in, happening about the pryuie place of man or woman.

The water of Quinces. The.xxv. Chapter.
THe chosen time for dystilling of Quinces is, when they be ripe: then they
shredde and bruised, require to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in a Cucurbyte of
Glass. This water to the quantity of four ounces, myxed with three ounces of
thick red wine, and druncke morning, noone, and at evening, yields fresh
blood, amendeth an evil stomach, in that it comfort and strengthens the
same, retayneth the meat in it, and puts away the will to vomit: It also
seaseth belching of the stomach and vomiting, and restrayneth all manner of
Fluxes of the belly, and comfort all the members of the body, by daily and
often drincking of it: the water amendeth the exulceratio^ of the throat, if it
be often gargelled within the mouth. The water retained in the mouth, seaseth
thirst, heals tongue vlcered, and cools the heat of the stomach. The
water taken with a dram wayght of some Cordial powder at evening, procures an
appetyte and desire to eat, yields a great strength to the heart, and
comfort it, and puts away drunckennesse. In the griefs of the bowelles
this is not to be used, in that it restrayneth: and in Fevers this neither is
to be ministered, when as any coueteth to have the belly soluble. The water of
Quince flowers (dystilled by Balneo Mariae in a Cucurbyte of Glass) druncke of
women, to the quantity of two ounces at a time, stays the great Flux of
the Terms. In the same manner druncke, comfort the heart: and stays the
will to vomit and vomiting, by drincking to the quantity of three ounces at a
time, morning, noone, and at evening.

The water of Doder. The.xxvi. Chapter.
THe congruent time of Dystilling the Doder is, when the stringes, eyes, or
seeds begin to appear, for it has no leaves as other herbs: then to
shredde the whole substance, and dystill it by Balneo Mariae: this water
druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time,
recouereth all griefs of the Liver and Lunges, by purging and comforting: for
it cleanses, ^ by a certain astriction strengthens: it opens the stoppinges
of the Liver, and dyssolueth the hardness of the Mylt and Liver, by drincking
of the water of hearts tongue myxed with the same. The water druncke twyse a
day, expels Flewmaticke and Chollericke humors out of the Body, and
causes Vryne. In the same manner druncke, puts away Iaundise, and sends
forth the stone of the Bladder. It helps the grypings of the Belly, druncke
morning and evening: the water dropped into the eyes, causes them clear
within short time. The water recouereth women's places cold, if it be drunk in
the foresaid manner. The water helps women, whose terms be stayed, and that
have a swelling about the Navel. The water druncke with a little powder of
Annis seeds* profits such which abound in corrupt Blood, and be infected
with foul or Leaprowse scabbes. The water myxed with common drink, and
druncke daily for a time, comfort the stomach. The water helps Fevers in
Children, given in Ale with a little of the powder of Annis seeds, in that it
purges the hot humor.

The water of Elecampane. The.xxvij. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystillation is, that the roots with the Herb
shredde together, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May: This
water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of an Egg shell full at a
time, for five or six days together, delyuereth the grief of the stone:
washing the teeth therewyth, strengthens them, and i^ amendeth the cough, by
drinking two ounces at a time with the powder of Lycorise and Annis seeds
myxed. It also expels worms in the Body, helps conuulsions and
swellings, and pain in the Loins. In the foresaid manner druncke, or taken
with drink, helps such bursten. The water druncke with a little Rosed honey,
and the head well labored with the same, that it may dry in by it self,
comfort the head. The water druncke many days together, not only
comfort and strengthens the stomach, but cleanses the breast and Lunges,
of gross and clammie humors: Yea, this causes a fair skin to women, both
in face and Body, through the often using of it. It also procures a glansome
mind, and the person often using the same, to have a cheerful and amyable
countenance. The water druncke and anointed, strengthens loose members. It
profits such fetching the breath hardly, by drincking sundry morninges with
Rosed honey. The water druncke morning and evening, for a certain time
together, expels the stone of the Kydneyes and Bladder, cleanses them, and
causes Vryne. The water of the roots alone (dystilled about the end of May,
or from the month of Iulye unto September) druncke Morning and Evening, to the
quantity of two or three ounces at a time, for certain days, heals an
inner rupture. In the same manner druncke, helps the stone, provoke the
Terms in women, delyuereth the grief of the stone, and causes Vryne. This
druncke in the abouesayd manner, sends forth the dead yongling out of the
mothers womb. It like druncke, or applied with linne^ clothes, dissolueth and
puts away the swelling of women's places. This on such wise druncke, or
applied, remooueth the swelling of the testicles. The water often druncke,
sweetened with Rosed honnie, seasseth the Coughe, and consumes the gross and
clammie humors, detayned within the Breast.

The water of Eiebright. The.xxviij. Chapter.
THe congruent time for the dystillatio^ of it is, that the leaves, stalks,
flowers, with the whole substance be dystilled in a Cucurbyte of glass by
Balneo Mariae, when it yields or bears the flowers. This water dropped and
stryked about the eyes, causes clear eyes, and sharpeneth the sight: the
water used in the same manner seasseth the pain of the eyes: the water dropped
into the eyes an hour before night, and striked about, and druncke to the
quantity of three ounces at a time, comfort, strengthens, and preserves
the sight, especially in the aged persons, and flewmaticke of complexion. The
herb dried and brought to powder, and eaten every day in a rear potched
Egg, for a certain time together, restores sight lost: the water myxed with
half a dram of the powder, and druncke every evening for a month or
forty days together, recouereth a weak sight.

The water of our Beans. The.xxix. Chapter.
THe best time of dystilling them, that the green bestowed in a Cucurbyte of
Gloss, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae: with the water of Beans, wash vlcered
and matterie legs, and that remaining after the water dystilled quite forth,
bring by heat of fire into powder: Which then sprinckle on the sore, for it
dries up, and is the best remedy for foul and matterie legs. The water of
the Bean coddes (distilled when the Sun shall be in Leo, and the Moon in
Aries) druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of two or three ounces at
a time, does marvelously remove and help the grief of the stone, of the
Kydneyes and Bladder. The water of the green herb with the stalks
(dystilled about the end of May) druncke for certain days, morning and
evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a time sweetened with sugar, puts
away the stone in Children, the same every day druncke, to the quantity of
four or five ounces at a time, preuayleth against a strong Poison. The water
druncke in the like manner for a month, engenders good and pure blood. The
face and skin of the Body washed with the same water, procures a soft
skin and clear, and a fair face. The water of the flowers (gathered at the
full rypenesse and before the rotting, dystilled in a Cucurbyte of Glass by
Balneo Mariae) dropped into the eyes at evening, dries up the watering and
dropping of the eyes. It amendeth the exulceration and redness of the eyes
dropped into them, after the manner abouesayd. The like it avails in pushes of
the eyes. The face also washed with this water or labored on the Body,
causes a clear and soft skin, and cleanses or takes away spots on the
skin. The same druncke to the quantity of six ounces at a time, avails
against poison. If Lynnen clothes wette in it be applied upon, does draw forth
Dart or Arrow heads, and thorns run into the Body. The water druncke of
women morning and evening, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a time,
for six or seven days together, sends down their Terms in due season.
The water extinguisheth the burning of the Shingles, and expels evil
pushes, if it be applied morning and evening, with a Lynnen cloth or soft towe
wette in the same.

The water of Filipendula. The.xxx. Chapter.
THe chosen time for dystillyng the same is, that the whole herb with the
roots shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae about the end of May.
This water druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantitye of three ounces at a
time, with a dram weight of the powder of the Gentiane root, sweetened with
sugar, healpeth the stayinge back of the vryne, and dropping of the same: it
also amendeth the coldenesse of stomach, and helps digestion. This in like
manner druncke, helps such fetching the breath short and painefully, and all
sicknesses proceeding of a cold cause. The water druncke in the like quantity
abouesayd, mixed with a dram weight of the powder of the blessed Thistell,
sweetened with sugar, helps the plague, and preuayleth against poison, eaten
or druncke by hap: The water druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantitye of
four or six ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar, eases the griefs, and
expels the stone of the Kydneyes and Bladder.

The Water of Fumitarie. The.xxxi. Chapter.
THe best time of dystillation is, that the herb with the whole substance
shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo, about the end of May or the mids of
June: this water druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantity of three or
four ounces at a time, recouereth the Iaundyse, and clears away the foul
scabbe on the face, after the kind of a Leaprie, and preserves the person by
the dailye vsinge of it, from the Leaprie. In the same manner druncke, helps
every kind of scabbes, the morfew, and ytche. Let the pacient entered into Bath
drink this with a little Triacle, for it then provoke sweat, by which the
blood is pourged, and helps the sickness, which is proceeded of corrupt
blood. In the time of the plague may the water be used, in that it preserves
such by drincking of it. The water myxed with fine Tryacle and pure bole
Armoniake, and given to that pacient afflicted with the plague, yealdeth a
help, and delivers him in short time. The water druncke attenuateth,
pierces, opens obstructions, and loses the bellye: it also purges the
blood, Choler, and all discommodities proceeding of chollor, and adust
humors. The water drunck twice a day, strengthens the stomach, the Liver,
and the Bowels: it also puts away the chollericke and burning Agues, and
those sickness which are caused by the obstruction of the vessels. The water
in the foresaid manner druncke, provoke much chollericke vryne, and helps
the stoppings of the Liver. It also puts away clotted blood, and dissolueth
the swelling, both within and without the body, and provoke the terms in
women. The water druncke with a dram weight of the powder of Synamon,
comfort the stomach, provoke urine, puts away scabbes and ytche, and
mundifyeth the blood. A potion of the same water recouereth ulcers of the
mouth and dolours.

The water of the garden Clar^e. The.xxxij. Chapter.
THe aptest time for the Dystillation of it, is, that the whole herb shredde
small, be distilled by Balneo Mariae, about the myddle of May: this water
druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time
sweetened with Sugare, ceasseth the gripings of the belly, and pains of the
stomach and sides, the rather by applyng upon the places, lynnen clothes wet
often in it. The water drunck twice a day, to the quantity of three ounces at
a time, remooueth the pain of women's places, and prepares them apt to
conceive with child: it also comfort and recouereth the members harmed by
cold, by applying lynnen clothes wette in it on the places.

The water of Caryophyllata. The.xxxiij. Chapter.
THe Herb with the roots finely shredde, and bestowed in a Cucurbite of
glass, require to be distilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of March or
mids of April, this water druncke Morning and evening, to the quantity of
three or four ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar, for four of five days
together, ceasseth gripinges of the belly, stays the blouddie flux, women's
Terms, the spitting of blood, and strengthens a cold brain. This in like
manner druncke, purges all evil and clammye humors, and sends them forth of
the body. The water drunck in the foresaid manner digesteth meat hard of
digestion, and amendeth a cold stomach. This druncke twice a day, profyteth
the Liver. The water druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantitye of three or
four ounces at a time, heals the inner wounds of the breast, the like does
this recover wounds, deep and desperate ulcers, if they be often washed, and
that linen clothes wette in it be applied on the fores. The water helps
impostumes, by applying lynnen clothes wet in it on the swellings. The water
druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantitye of three ounces at a time
sweetened with Sugar, heals fistulaes: it also profits much, if they be
washed with the same, or that linen clothes wette in it, be applied on the
places. The water remooueth and puts away spots, and moles, or other like
marks, which Infantes have taken of the Moothers: if they be often washed in
their Infancy, with that water.

The Water of Broom flowers. The.xxxiiij. Chapter.
THe dystillation of the flowers, is to be done by Balneo Mariae, in a
Cucurbite of glass, when the flowers are full ripe, and begin in a manner to
fall of: this water druncke with a little Rosed honye, morning and evening, to
the quantity of two or three ounces at a time, for twelve of fourteen days
together, draws humors from the joints, purges flewme, and avails against
the shedding of the Gaul. The water druncke twice a day, to the quantitye of
five or six ounces at a time, sweetened with Rosed honye, and a dram weight of
the powder of Fe^ell seeds myxed expels the excrementes of the kidneyes,
causes urine effectuously, and breaks the stone as well in the bladder, as
in the kidneyes and suffers not matter after to gather in th^^^, to harden
into a stone. The water druncke with Oximell or (...) honey for a certain time,
dissolueth the hardness of the Mylte, and puts away the swellings in the
throat. The water profits the head, if applied, it be suffered to dry in by
it self: this in like manner ordered, recouereth the weariness of members.

The Water of Gentiane. The.xxxv. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystilling only the root (as more commendid) is, that
the green or fresh root shredde small, and bestowed in a Cucurbyte of
glass, be distilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of the Caniculare days:
where otherwise the dried roots infused a time in wine, may be dystilled at
any time. The water simple of the fresh roots druncke often fasting, to the
quantity of three ounc^s at a time, expels fevers caused by the obstruction
of the Bowels, and other parts of the body, kylleth the worms in the
belly, cleanses all manner of spots in the face, if they be often washed with
the same and prolongeth man's life, in that it consumes all the clammye humors
in the stomach. The water like druncke provoke the terms in women, and
causes vryne, and against the plague and stinging or bit of venomous worms
and Beasts, this druncke and applied with lynnen clothes, does myraculously
avail. The water druncke of him which has taken by hap the venomous and
monstrous blood of a nim 455. expels the same, nor suffers any hurtful
disease to ensue to the parson. The water druncke fasting for certain days,
procures an appetite to meat, and purges the stomach of clammye humors. If
with it (before the taking) be half a drame of pure Calamus Aromaticus brought
to fine powder and a dram of Sugar myxed, the same potion taken three or
four times, does mightily restore the taste and desire to rate. The ^ater
druncke with a dram of Ginger, and an ounce of Sugar ^asting, does speedily
deliver the grypings of the Bellye caused by wind, and the obstruction in the
flanks. This of experience foun^e, that the fresh root bruised and applied in
plaster form on the belly, does undoubtedly kill the worms consisting in
the Bowels.

The Water of ioynted Grass. The.xxxvi. Chapter.
THe congruent Distillation of it, is done of the Herb with the roots, and
the whole substance shredde small: And the same after the bestowing in a
Cucurbite of Glass, distilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May. This
water drunk morning and Evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time,
with a dram of the fine powder of Synamone, and a little Sugar, stays the
great flux of the Belly. The same quantity of the water drunk at one time,
purges the Reins, provoke vryne, and opens the stopping of parts in the
body. The like quantity taken with a little Rosed Honey fasting, expels
the worms in the Belly: to Infantes and children, only give but two ounces:
to youth of more years minister three ounces: to men and elder persons, four
ounces, as above taught. The water cease the grievous pain of the Shyngles,
by applying lynnen clothes wette in it* It puts away the Fever arysing by
heat, either by drinking or applying the same without the body. The water
preuayleth against all pains, and burning beat of wounds, yea, and closes
them, if they be gently washed and soupled with a lynnen clothe wette in it,
or lynnen clothes wette in the same be applied. The water in the foresaid
quantity, drunk fasting, cease and helps the grypinges of the Bowels,
amendeth the stopping of Vryne, recouereth the ulcers of the Bladder, and
breaks the stone: but a dram of the powder of the seeds mixed with the
water, more avails in sending forth the vryne. The water dropped warm in the
matterie ears, heals them in short time: It profyteth the rottenness of the
Gummes, if they be often washed with the same. This helps black pushes ^ if
a ly^^nen clothe or soft Towe wette in it, be applied twyse or th^yce a day,
and that at each time be three or four ounces drunck. The water cease all
manner of heates, by applying without, lynnen clothes wette in it. In yongmen,
and of xxx. years, does this water m^^e work, than in the elder persons.

The water of Ground Yuie or Tunhoue. The.xxxvij. Chapter.
THe congruent time of Dystillation is, that the whole herb shredde small, be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the beginning of June. This water drink
morning and evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a time, sweetened with
Sugar, preuayleth against the trembling of the heart, the Kings ^uill, and a
weak stomach. The water druncke in a bathe, throughlye cleanses clammie
h^mours, which are contained in the stomach, the Lungs, the Liver, and
Bladder, and procures the ^erson healthful. The water druncke in like manner,
preuayleth ^^ainst the infection and poison of the Plague, in that it expel^eth
the same. The water druncke twyse a day, to the quantity abouesayde, does
recover the ulcers of the Heads, opens the stopping of the Liver and Mylt,
draws down the T^rmes of women, and provoke urine. The water drunck
morning, noone, and at evening, preuayleth against the weariness of members in
women, if the parts also be rubbed, with it four times in a day. This water
stilled into dropping and running eyes, stays and dries up the water. The
like perfourmeth the ^^^ce of the leaves, or myxed with this water, and applied
to them.

The water of Cowslippes. The.xxxviij. Chapter.
THe aptest time for Dystillation of it, is, that the leaves and flowers, with
the whole substance shredde together, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae (in a
Cucurbite of Glass) about the beginning of May, or sooner. This water druncke
twyce a day, to the quantity of two ounces at a time, heateth the stomach,
the Liver, and Matrice. For which cause it is much auayleable for women
painfully traueyling, and provoke the terms in them. The water in the
foresaid manner druncke, asswageth swellings of the hoade, if lynnen clothes
wette in it, be often applied: The water twyse a day drunck, resolves humors
gathered, causing ache in the Hyppes and Joints, and sends them forth by
urine. This water preuayleth against all manner of headache proceeding of cold,
by applying lynnen clothes wette in it, to the aching head. It heals also the
bytte and stinging of venomous worms and beasts, and all poysonings. The
water cleanses the foul staynings, the wrinckling and spots of the face, and
the rest of the b^die: in that it causes a smoothe and fair skin, by often
washing with the same. The water druncke twyse a day, helps the Palsy,
puts away the stone in the Kidneyes and Bladder: It also recouereth loose
and broken bones, by drinking and often applying lynnen clothes wette in it.
The flowers made into a Con^e^^e with Sugar, profit such as are feeble and
often swounding, and that be decay^d of strength, in that they recover and
restore strength lost.

The water of Stoikes bill, or herb Robert. The.xxxix. Chapter.
THe ^^st congruent time for Distillation of it, is, that the stalks, leaves,
and whole substance shredde small, be distilled in a Cucurbite of Glass by
Balneo Mariae, about the end of May, or beginning of June. This water druncke
Morning and Evening to the quantity of two ounces at a time, mixed with a
little Pepper and Myrrh in fine powder, profits such as are dacayed in
strength: and the like quantity druncke twyce a day for three days together
(or longer time) mixed with Rosed Honey, preuayleth against Inflations, and
recouereth the Phthisick or sore in the Lunges with a Consumption of all the
body. The water dr^nck with half an ounce of the seeds, and a quantity of
Myrrh and Pepper in fine powder myxed together, does put away the ^rycke and
s^yffenesse of turning the neck. The water profits the exulceration of
women's places, if they be washed twice a day with the same, and that lynnen
clothes wette in it, be applied. This water puts away the black and blewe
of the skin, caused by a fall or st^ype, if it be applied with linen clothes
three or four times a day: in that it dissolueth and wears away the
congeale^ ^loude under the skin. Th^s also heals the Fistula, if it be
washed with the water morning and evening, or that lyn^^n clothes wette in it
be applied. The water avails against ioyntaches of the shoulders and feet,
if it be labored on the grieved place* or that it be* applied with lynnen
clothes wette in it. The water applied with linen clothes wet in it, puts
away swellings of the Pappes, and cease the pain of them. The water applied
on bruised and shaken members to pieces, recouereth them, and puts away the
clotted blouder.

The water of Horsetayle. The.xl. Chapter.
THe congruent time for the distillation of it, is, that the herb^ and roots
shred small, be d^sti^^ed by Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May. This water
drunk morning and evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a time* mixed
with a dram of the powder of Cynamone and a little Sugar, recouereth the
spitting of blood, heals the bowels exulcerated and hurt, stays the terms
of Women, the flux Dysenteria, and all other fluxes of the Belly, cures the
Bladder, vlcered, comfort the stomach harmed, and the Liver, by applying
also of lynnen clothes wette in it without. The water druncke morning, noone,
and evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, sweetened with a
little Sugar, and that lynnen clothes wette in it, be applied in a plaster
form, asswageth inflammations, and burning of the Shingles. The water druncke
twyse a day, helps the grief of the stone, and the Strangurie. The water
recouereth the perilous flux Dysenteria, if a linen clothe wet in it, be
often applied to the fundament. The water applied hot with lynnen clothes, to
the man's privy member swollen, does put away the swelling, and cease the
pain. The water heals wounds of the feet, and the holes open, if they be
washed with the same. The water applied with lynnen clothes on the swelling of
the Dropsy, morning and evening, does assuage and put away the same. The water
applied with linen clothes wet in it to the foreheade and nose, and put within
the nosthrils, restrayneth and stays the bleeding of the nose, and puts
away the running of the nose, by drawing it up by the nosthrils.

The water of Hoppes. The *xli. Chapter.
THe congruent time for Dystillation of it, is, that the upper tops, and
first branches cut up (in heygth or length of two handbredthes) and shredde
small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of April. This water
druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, and
that mixed with Rosed honey, it be used for three or four weeks together,
puts away Melancholy, of which commonly is caused scabs, ytche, and the
Leprie, and such like griefs that are wont to happen of corrupt blood. The
water druncke in the abouesayde manner, opens the stopping of the Milt,
puts away the pricking, and all griefs, which are wont to be caused by the
stopping of the Mylt. The water druncke, and of it dropped at Evening into the
ears, cleanses and wears away the mattering of them. The water myxed with a
like quantity of Hearts tongue water, and druncke with a little Rosed Honey,
or Sugar, before the beginning of the cold, delivers the Quartaine ague in
short time. The water on such wise prepared, and druncke twice a day, amendeth
the hard fetching of breath, and the stopping of the Breast. The waters like
prepared and drunck, puts away the Iaundise, and Dropsy, and loses the
belly. The water druncke, corrects Choler, purges the blood of the same,
and extinguisheth his inflammations. It also puts away headache, gathered of
heat. The water druncke, mittigateth the heat of the Liver, and stomach, and
avails in Fevers, caused of Choler and blood.

The water of Henbane. The.xlij. Chapter.
THe chosen time for Dystillation of it, is, that the whole Herb with the
roots and flowers shred and bruised, be dystilled about S. John's day. This
water cease all manner of pain of the head, proceeding of heat, if the head
be rubbed and labored with the same. The water anointed on the forhead and
Temples, and washing the feet with it, procures sleep in a sharp
sickness, the rather, if the seeds brought to powder, and myxed with woman's
milk, and the white of an Egg, and a little Vinegar, be applied on the
Temples: It represseth and asswageth all manner of heat, if linen clothes
wette in it be applied on the places: On such wise it remooueth all dolor of
the members, and palifyeth, or rather hydeth the form of the Leprie on the
face, if it be often washed and sowpled with the same, in that it draws forth
all manner of heat not natural. The water profits them, which have no
natural rest, by applying it (by discretion) as well within, as without the
body: and if it be labored oftentimes on the head, and applied with linen
clothes wette in it, then it causes a man the rather to rest naturally.

The water of Hearts ease. The.xliij. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystillation of it, is, that the Herb with the Flowers
shredde and bruised, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in a Cucurbite of Glass,
about the end of June, or mids of Iulie. This water ministered to children
twyse a day, to the quantity of two ounces at a time, sweetened with a little
Sugar, recouereth without doubt the burning heat that commonly takes them.
The water drunk morning and evening, to the quantity of two or three ounces
at a time, helps such hardly breathing, and drawing the wind short* the
inflammation and impostume of the Lunges, and those which have a straytenesse
about the heart and breast, and that have there some sore or a swelling. The
water druncke fasting for a certain time, heals scabbednesse, and all other
corruptions of the skin.

The water of Juniper Beries. The.xliiij. Chapter.
THe congruent dystillation of the Beries, is, when they be ripe, and waxing
black, then they ought to be bruised and dystilled by Balneo Mariae. This
water drunk morning, noone, and at evening, to the quantity of two ounces at
a time, sweetened with a little Sugar, delivers and helps the stone of the
kidneyes and Bladder, also cleanses the kidneyes and Bladder, causes vryne,
and draws down the terms of Women, by drincking three ounces at a time,
with a dram of the powder of Cassia lignea. The water druncke with a little
Cinamone and Sugar, expels the dead yoongling, and poison, and profits
against the byte and stinging of venomous beasts, and worms. The water
avails against all ioyntaches, proceeding of cold, if the joints be rubbed
and applied with the same, morning, noone, and at evening, and let after to
dry in by it self. The water attenuateth, opens, and cleanses filthy
ulcers, if they be washed with the same.

The water of the wood Lilly. The.xlv. Chapter.
THe flowers only are distilled in a Cucurbite of Glass by Balneo Mariae,
about the mids of the Spring: yet the roots distilled, more excel. The
water of the flowers druncke, to the quantity of six ounces at a time,
sweetened with Sugar, recouereth them which have eaten poison in their meat.
The water ministered orderly, preuayleth against the byte of a mad Dog, it
helps the hard traueyle of Child, comfort the Brain, the Heart, the
Liver, and other spiritual members, and riddeth away the falling sickness,
by drincking of the same for forty days together. The water druncke fasting,
sweetened with a little Sugar, helps swounding, recouereth the lack of
speech lost, and sundry diseases of the body, and restores plenty of milk
in women's breasts. The water druncke in the foresaid manner, helps the
Strangurie, avails against the pricking about the heart, and amendeth the
inflammation of the Liver. The water druncke twyse a day, stays the
immoderate course of the terms in women. The water heal^th the byte and
stinging of venomous beasts, and woormes, if a lynnen clothe wette in it, be
applied on the place. The water dropped into the eyes, puts away the
inflammation and darckenesse of them. It cools also hot inflammations, by
applying Lynnen clothes wette in the same. Whose members or head do tremble,
it behooves him before to wash purely, and dry them, after to rub and labor
this water on the places, and to let it dry in by it self, recouereth them, if
this be done morning and evening. The water applied with Lynnen clothes wette
in it, puts away the pain of the priusties. To conclude, this water
orderly ministered, recouereth loose and palsy members, the falling sickness,
convulsions, dazeling and swimming of the head, and swounding. In Germany,
certain do make of the Flowers dried in the summer time, a wine (in the time
of pressing forth ye Grapes) which after the myxing and standing together a
certain time, they minister of it for the foresaid griefs. But there are
other, which steep a pound of the fresh flowers in a gallon or two of old
wine, and set the Glass in the Sun for six weeks or two Months, putting
to it of Lauander, and of Rosemarie flowers, with sundry pleasant spyces: this
after the strayning, they distill in a Cucurbite of Glass by Balneo Mariae,
which water purchased, they bestowed (for the preciousnesse of it) in Silver or
Golden vessels close stopped, and they name this the Golden water, which they
use to all the foresaid griefs of the body: The rather if it be dystilled
three times over, and rectified by a Pellicane, which then ministered with six
graynes of Pepper, and a little of Lauander water, works miraculously: for it
comforts the Brain, restores such swouning, and left for dead in a manner,
yea causes them to live after a long time. It also recouereth the deprivation
of Senses, puts away the Cholicke passion, and profits that person which
shall have an impostume in the hinder part of the Brain and Head, by drinking
a spoonefull at a time, of this precious water. This water in like manner, by
applying it often on the foreheade, and hinder part of the head, procures a
good memory and ready wit. As touching the recovery of swounding, and great
hazard of death by it, the learned Mathiolus reports that he has of proof,
found many times the contrary: yet such is the fame of it (says he) in
Germany, that many cannot refrain the ministering of the same, yea, in most
hot sickenesses.

The water of the Wyldinges or Crabbes. The.xlvi. Chapter.
THe congruent time for Dystillation of them, is, that they bruised, be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of October. This water druncke
Morning, Noone, and at Evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time,
sweetened with Sugar, is a most precious water, and miraculously avails
against the grypings of the Bowels. The water in like manner taken, helps the
flux Dysenteria, delivers the griefs of the stone, cleanses the Reins and
Bladder: The water of the vnrypened Crabbes or Wyldinges (dystilled by Balneo
Mariae, about S. John's day) not only helps the face swollen, by washing it
with the same, and letting it to dry in by it self, but puts away the high
red color, and peeling of the skin on the face, and the red pymples, or
other deformity of the same.

The water of putrified and rotten Apples. The.xlvij. Chapter.
OF the graffed or sweet Apples which shall be rotten, shall you dystill a
water by Balneo Mariae. This water helps that inflammation, which cooled and
putrified larger spreads, insomuch that the flesh falls out, if the place
be morning and evening washed with the same, or Lynnen clothes often applied.
The water recouereth hot and red swellings, and sores, or Cankers eating, and
pestilent Botches, by applying Lynnen clothes wette in it, thryse in the day.
The water of the Apples through ripe (and before their rotting) dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, very much avails for comforting, in that it cools the body
and heart, by drinking morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at
a time, sweetened with a little Sugar. The flowers of the graffed Apples
require to be gathered, when as they be through blown, and by a Lynnen sheet
spredde under the tree, the blossoms ought to be beaten down with a staff,
and to be dystilled in a Cucurbite of Glass by Balneo Mariae. This water
recouereth (and thoroughly helps) the redness and deformity of the face, if
for three or four weeks together, it be washed morning and evening with the
same.

The water of the Peache tree flowers. The.xlviij. Chapter.
A Certain Chemist (of fame in Germany) dystilled a Rose water out of the
Peache Roses or Flowers, which loses the Belly, and procures to vomit: and
he took for loosing of the Belly, the water which dystilled forth first
(before the Roses were burned) and dystilled them in a Cucurbite of Glass by
Balneo Mariae, where he also dystilled the dry herbs, and others in Sand^.
The water of the leaves (dystilled by Balneo Mariae at the increasing of the
Moon in May, druncke in the morning fasting, puts away the grief of the
stone in the loins, the rather by taking it thryce a day, to the quantity of
two or three ounces at a time, which in like manner used, procures urine, and
purges the Bladder. The water druncke of children fasting, to the quantity of
an ounce at a time sweetened with Sugar, kills the long worms in the body.
The water druncke Morning and Evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a
time, preuayleth against the stone. The water dropped into the ears, kills
the worms in them: Rubbing the head with it, cease headache.

The water of the smaller Mallows. The.xlix. Chapter.
WHen the Mallows shall bear flowers, then the roots with the whole Herb
gathered and shredde small, dystill by Balneo Mariae, about the beginning of
May. This water (between day and night) druncke four times to the quantity
of four ounces at a time sweetened with a little Sugar, recouereth the pricking
or stitches in the sides, and Pleurisy, and purges wounds. The water
druncke, to the quantity of six or eight ounces at a time fasting, softeneth
and loses the belly, remooueth the pain of the Matrice, breaks and
heals inward swellings. The water in like manner druncke, stays the
perilous flux Dysenteria, puts away the grief of the stone, asswageth the
pain of the Bladder, and cleanses the Reins and Bladder. The water applied on
the Temples, procures sleep. If the feet of a sick person of a hot Ague be
rubbed or labored with the same, procures rest, and cease thirst. The water
puts away the Impostume behind the ears, by dropping it warm into them,
and by applying it without, and by drincking a quantity each day. The water
druncke, helps the often desire to the stool, and by applying lynnen clothes
wette in it on the Belly. The water heals the bytte of venomous things, if
it be washed with the same, and lynnen clothes wette in it applied upon. This
also puts away scabbednesse and ytche, and spots of the body, by doing the
like. The water drunk, resists the infection of the Plague, and preserves
the person that he be not taken with the same sickness. The water applied on
wounds, or washed with the same, fills them with flesh. The water of the
flowers (dystilled in a Cucurbite of Glass by Balneo Mariae) drunk morning,
noone, and at evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, puts away
the grypings of the Bowels, heateth and softeneth the Belly. The water dropped
into the eyes, diverse times in the day, does marvelously recover and restore a
decayed sight, as the same of experience found.

The water of Horehounde. The.L. Chapter.
THe time for Dystillation of it, is, that the whole substance, with the
roots shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May.
This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of two or three ounces
at a time, sweetened with Sugar, preuayleth against the Cough, the hardness of
fetching breath, the spitting of blood, and the Dropsy, comfort the
stomach, cleanses the breast, and lungs, opens the liver and Mylt, and
strengthens the Kidneys and bladder. It comfort the yongling in the mothers
womb, druncke of women with child, to the quantity of two ounces at a time,
sweetened with Sugar. This comfort and quickens the wit and memory, by
chasing or rubbing it on the head. The water dropped into the ears, takes
away the pain of them, purges and cleanses fresh wounds, by washing them
morning and evening with it: yea, it heals open ulcers. The water puts
away visions, and evil dreams, by drincking sundry times of it. It also
helps the Dropsy if such refrain from moist things, and to much drincking:
and all swellings this heals, by applying it on the places.

The water of the herb Baulme. The.Li. Chapter.
THe herb with the whole substance shredde small, and well stamped, lay to
steep for a whole night in good white wine, that it may well drink in of the
wine. Which done, dystill the whole on the morrow, in a Cucurbite of Glass by
Balneo Mariae, about the end of May. This water druncke twyse a day, to the
quantity of two ounces at a time, recouereth in short time any kind of
scabbednesse of the body, and causes a sweet savor of the same, if with a
grain of Musk myxed, it be washed. The water remooueth Pymples, Letters, and
all other spots happening on the face or breast, by myxing a quantity of the
natural or artificial Baulme, and washing or rubbing the places with the
same: and it causes the face to come to a fair read color. The water
druncke every morning fasting, to the quantity of a small Nutte shell full at
a time, puts away the ill ^auour or stinking of the breath. The water also
remooueth toothache, by holding it a time in the mouth. The water preserves a
long time flesh or fish, by lying in it: and poured into turned wine,
restores the same to be druncke. The water druncke, procures urine: and
applied with a Lynnen clothe on the bottom of the Belly, breaks the stone
of the Bladder, causes urine, and moves the Terms of women. The water
druncke, recouereth the pain of the Body and Kidneyes. The water druncke
twyse a day, and the herb applied in plaster form on that swelling under
the Chynne, named Scrophula, helps it greatly. The water druncke fasting,
breaks an impostume grown within the body. It heals also all prickinges
or stitches of the heart, and sides. This water taken in the manner abouesayde,
is a mortal enemy, or kills all manner of worms within the body. The water
druncke fasting, comfort the afflicted spirits, strengthens all the
members, and recouereth those parts endammaged or grieved with the Gout
through cold: For this comfort the sinews far better, than any other
remedy. The water druncke fasting with a little Triacle, delivers and
helps the falling sickness. And the person, which by occasion of any
sickness cannot speak, by putting a fine lynnen clothe wette in the water,
and put under the tongue oftentimes, recouereth the speech hyndered and
lacking. The water druncke fasting, comfort the breast, and helps
digestion. The water drunck twice a day, procures a sweet breath, cease all
inward swellings, puts away the Cholick and grypings of the Bowels, purges
the matrice, and helps the Dropsy. The water applied on wounds twyse a day,
heals them in short time. The water dropped into the eyes, stays the
watering of them, and procures a sharp sight* The water druncke fasting,
cheareth the heart, makes a man merry, helps a cold stomach, strengthens
the vital parts, helps digestion, recouereth the stoppings of the brain,
amendeth a feeble courage, strengthens the weakness of the heart, and the
same especially, by which sleep is often broken in the night, and the beating
of his pulse repressed. It also puts away the cares of the mind, and
troublesome imaginations, which either are of Melancholy, or of adust flewme
engendered. The water druncke fasting, sharpeneth the understanding, and wit,
and procures a good or ready memory.

The water of the herb Mercury. The.Lij. Chapter.
THe congruent time for the dystillation of it, is, that the whole herb
shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the beginning of June. This
water drawn up into the Nosethrilles oftentimes, profits unto the purging of
the head, helps the running of the eyes, nose, and ears. The water applied
with lynnen clothes wette in it, on burnings, heals them, and mitigateth the
griefs. The water tempered with wine, and applied with lynnen clothes wette in
it on Ulcers, cures them. The water druncke in the morning fasting, to the
quantity of two ounces at a time, expel^eth superfluous heates, and gross
humors, as Flewme, and the gross black Choler. The water druncke, and the
herb eaten for three days together of women, as a day before, and two days
after the Terms begun, and at the fourth day (coming out of Bathe) to
coeate, works a marvelous matter in conception: The rather (as Hippocrates
affirms) if before it, the powder of the roots of Iroos and it, formed into
a Pessarie with Honey, be conueyghed up into the body, the readier to cause
the Terms to come down. The water druncke in time of traueyle of child, and
a Bathe made with the Herb and Malloes, sends forth the afterburthen. The
water dropped into deaf ears, and anointed with old wine, recouereth the
hearing. The water of Grummell (dystilled about the end of May, or beginning
of June) druncke morning and evening for xxx. or xl. days together, to the
quantity of three ounces at a time, with a little of this water, helps the
stone, the dropping of the urine, the Strangurie, and grief of the stone, of
the Kidneys and Bladder: It also cleanses the reins and Bladder.

The water of the Bramble berries. The.Liij. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystillation of the Berries, is, when they are full
ripe, but not tarying till they be soft, and it behooves to wash them before,
and to dry them again, after to dystill them in a Cucurbite of Glass, by
Balneo Mariae. Thy^ water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of two
ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar, helps the stone in children. The
water druncke fasting, recouereth the grief of the stone of the Kidneyes and
Bladder. The water gargelled in the throat, profits the griefs of the Vuula:
and heals ulcers of the throat, by gargelling it hot, four times in the day.

The water of Mulberies. The.Liiij. Chapter.
THe Mulberies are to be dystilled, when they are sufficiently ripe by Balneo
Mariae. This water gargelled to the quantity of two or three ounces at a
time, for three or four times a day, recouereth vlc^rs of the throat. The
water handled after the same manner, and druncke down, puts away impostumes
of the Breast, expels flewme out of the body. The water in like manner
druncke, expels and dissolueth the congealed blood in the body, helps
the Cough, and loses the binding in the breast. The water of the vnrypened
Mulberies (dystilled by Balneo Mariae, dropped and applied about the eyes,
greatly helps them. This water often gargelled in the mouth, helps the
weakness of the Vuula, takes away all manner of roughness, exulceration,
and heat of the throat. The water druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of three or four ounces at a time, with Rosed honey, recouereth the
impostumes of the Liver.

The water of Nenupl^are, or the water Lilly. The.Lv. Chapter.
THe white flowers of the water Lyllie, when they are full ripe, require in the
due season to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae. This water druncke with Rosed honey
morning and evening, for ten or thirteen days together, to the quantity of
two ounces at a time, helps the shedding of the gall, and a hot and dry
Cough. The water also profits them which have an impostume of the Breast,
with pain in the side. The water druncke with Sugar, preuayleth against the
ulcers of the Bowels, softeneth a hot bel^^e, and recouereth an old and
watrie rupture. The water druncke in like quantiti^, preuayleth against the
heat of the Plague, puts away headache, cease the Cough, and helps the
impostumes of the Mylt, if they proceed of heat. The water applied with
Lynnen clothes wette in it, morning and evening, does mightily extinguish all
inflammations in man's body. It also procures sleep, cease the inflammation
of the head, the Liver, stomach, and heart. The water especially profits
unto the cooling of the h^ade, if it be often applied round about: and
recouereth the heat of the heart, by applying lynnen clothes without. The
water drunk fasting, or outwardly applied, greatly avails against the
consumption of the Body. It also delivers the night forms of Venus in
sleep, and takes away the Uenereall delight for ever, by drincking it
fasting, and washing the Genitals with it for forty days together. The water
applied without, with lynnen clothes wette in it, does in short time cool the
burning heat of the Liver.

The Water of Hasill Nuttes. The.Lvi. Chapter.
THe green Hasill nuttes gathered and bruised, require to be dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, about the mids of July. This water well labored on the hands
and arms, morning and evening, and let to dry in by it self, puts away
scabbednesse, and trembling or shaking of the hands. The water dystilled of
the fresh Hasill Nuttes, druncke fasting, to the quantity of tw^ drammes at a
time, miraculously helps the Cholicke, and grypings of the Bowels: a thing
sure, and experimented often, as writes the learne^ Alexander Benedictus.

The water of Walnuttes. The.Lvij. Chapter.
THe green Walnuts gathered and bruised, ought to be dystilled by Balneo
Mariae, about the beginning of July. This water ministered to drink to a
wounded person, twyse or thryse a day, puts away the inflammation of the
wound: the rather, if a lynnen clothe wette in it, be applied sundry times of
the day. The water druncke twyse a day, to the quantity of two or three
ounces at a time, puts away any manner of heat, and profits black Pushes,
as the Carbuncle, and hard swellings in the grynde, and other pestilent
Blysters and swellings, by applying (diverse times) lynnen clothes wette i^ it.
It also helps the Plague, by drinking the like quantity twyse a day, with a
scruple weight of fine Triacle. Certain persons there are, which dystill a
water out of the Walnuts not ripe, and whole with their shelles, which is
sovereign and auayleable against the plague, and for to foment the places
afflicted with Gout, right profitable, as the learned Graterolus writes. The
water applied with lynnen clothes wette in it, puts away Tetters, in that it
extinguisheth and cease pain. The water of the green ryndes of the
Walnuttes (dystilled by Balneo Mariae, in September) taken in drink, with a
third part of Vinegar, when the heat of the Plague takes any, and that a
vein before be opened, and that he shall drink it within.xxiiij. hours, is a
sure and approved remedy against the Plague. This water dropped into the
ears, helps the rynging and sound or noise of them. The water of the ripe
ryndes applied, does like help those griefs. The water of the Walnut leaves
shredde and dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May, dries up the
open ulcers, cease heat, and causes a smooth skin to grow again on
ulcers, by applying lynnen clothes wette in it, morning and evening for a
certain time together.

The water of Palma Christi. The.Lviij. Chapter.
THe roots only gathered, and finely shredde, require to be dystilled in a
Cucurbite of Glass, by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May. This water
druncke twyse a day, recouereth the perilous flux Dysenteria, as the same of
experience known. The water like drunck, expels the gross humors of the
body, and by oftentimes washing with it, greatly cleanses and cleereth the
face. The water is profitable, ministered to mad persons and frantic, and in
the griefs of the sinews. A dram weight of the fine powder of the seeds,
given with three ounces of the water sweetened with a little Sugar, preuayleth
