against the falling sickness. The water myxed with pure wine, and druncke at
dinner and supper for.xxx. or.xl. days together, does like recover the falling
sickness. The water druncke at the beginning of the cold fit, riddeth away
the Quartaine fever in short time, as a certain man of proof affirms. The
water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time,
strengthens the stomach, heateth and comfort nature. The water in like
manner druncke, puts away the yelowe Iaundise, and provoke urine. The
water taken in the morning fasting, for a certain time together, to the
quantity of four ounces at a time, and that Lynnen clothes wette in it, be
often applied: does prevail against all swellings, being as well without, as
within the body. The water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of
three ounces at a time, and that Lynnen clothes wette in it, be often applied,
does heal old and new wounds, as well within happening, as without the body.

The water of Cinkfoyle, or five leaued grass. The.Lix. Chapter.
THe best time for dystillation of it, is, that the herb, stalk, and root,
with the whole substance shred small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the
mids of May. This water druncke morning and evening, for certain days, to
the quantity of four ounces at a time, helps the stone, the grief of the
Stone in the Loins, and cleanses the Reins. The water druncke fasting, to the
quantity of eygth or nine ounces at a time, does mightily loose the belly, and
like resolves the hardness of belly, by applying it without. The water
applied with lynnen clothes wette in it, cease all manner of heates and
swellings: applied with lynnen clothes wette to the foreheade, stays the
bleeding at the nose: It recouereth the trembling of members, and the hands,
if they be often labored with the same, and let to dry in by it self. The
water heals new and old wounds, if they be washed with the same, or
applied with lynnen clothes. It also puts away all swellings, and
Impostumes. The water druncke fasting, for certain days, profits against
all manner of Fevers, and expels them utterly. The water of Thowrowaxe
(dystilled in Balneo) druncke to the quantity of two ounces at a time,
sweetened with Sugar, helps the inner rupture of Children, heals
inflammations with a readnesse, and the Shingles, and cease the grief of a
burning stomach.

The water of S. John's Worte. The.Lx. Chapter.
THe best time for Dystillation of it, is, that the herb, the leaves, and
flowers drawn from the stalks, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end
of June. This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of two ounces
at a time, preuayleth against the Apoplexy or depriving of senses. This water
myxed with the powder of the roots, or seeds, or water of Pionie, and druncke
twyse or thryse a day, to the quantity of two or three ounces at a time,
recouereth and helps the falling sickness. The water preuayleth against the
trembling of members, if they be labored with the same twyse a day. The water
drunck with red wine, helps all manner of superfluous fluxes of the Belly,
the rather being applied, with a lynnen clothe wette in it. The water druncke
morning and evening, heals all manner of wounds, being as well without as
within the Body, foynes, or cuttes, the rather if they shall be washed, or
applied often, with a lynnen cloth wette in it.

The water of Pympernell. The.Lxi. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystillation of the lesser Pympernell (which has a
sharp root) is, that the roots, the herb, with the whole substance shredde
and bruised, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May. This water
druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a
time, sweetened with Sugar, helps the stone, and grief of the stone in the
Loins and Bladder, and cleanses the Reins. This water helps the Plague,
druncke once within six days. It profits women, whose matrice is become
cold, and draws down the Terms. The water druncke in like quantity, with
a little of Castoreum brought to fine powder fasting, puts away the palsy
of members. The water druncke fasting, to the quantity of four ounces at a
time, defends the person from sickness that day, in that it puts away
all manner of grief from the heart, delivers evil humors, and procures
urine: this druncke with a little fine Triacle, preuayleth against poison. The
water causes a clear and fair skin of the face and hands, if any often
washes these outward parts with it.

The water of Plantayne. The.Lxij. Chapter.
THe roots and herb with the whole substance shredde small, dystill by Balneo
Mariae, about the end of May. The water druncke for forty days morning and
evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, sweetened with a little
Sugar, recouereth the Dropsy, a hot Cough, and that swelling proceeding of a
heat, and heals Blysters and pushes rising of heat. It profits any flux
of the Belly, but especially helps that flux Dysenteria, if you mix in
the drinking, the powders of the stone Hematites and Bole Armoniacke, to the
quantity or weight of a dram of each, with two ounces of the water. This
like mixed and druncke, stays the humorall flux, and the over great flux of
the Terms. The water heals the ulcers and impostume of the Lunges: it
preuayleth against poison. The water recouereth the falling sickness, by
drincking it for forty days. The water druncke for four days, helps the
love medicine, if a purgation be afterward taken, and this druncke a time,
delivers the grief of the Mylt. It kills worms, by drincking fasting the
quantity abouesayde: taken fasting for three days together, to the quantity
of four ounces at a time, helps the Ague. It also recouereth the Matrice,
and sends forth the after burden. The water helps the Plague, and
profits inflammations, by applying Lynnen clothes wette in it. The water
heals all ulcers which are happened by a bruise, stripe, fall, or by any
other cause. The water retained a long time in the mouth; heals all wounds
and ulcers of the mouth, and the gummes rotten by blood. The water dropped
every day into a Fistula, heals it, the rather if it be often washed with the
same. The water dropped into the ears, remooueth the pain of them. It helps
the Shingles, and dropped or applied to the eyes, puts away the swelling of
them. The water gargelled in the mouth, recouereth the exulceration of the
throat. The water applied with lynnen clothes on fresh wounds, stays the
issue of blood: It heals the bytte and stinging of venomous beasts and
woormes, recouereth inflammations, and those with a readnesse, by applying
lynnen clothes wette in it. The water applied with lynnen clothes, preserves
wounds, that no inflammation or other incommoditie happens to them. It
heals those Ulcers, which by feeding creep abroad. The water cures that
fore feeding, which most men name the Wolf, if in it be boiled the flowers of
Pomegranates, Psidia, the Cypress nuttes, Xylobalsamum, Carpobalsamum, Sugar
Alum, of each an ounce, of Mumia, an ounce and a half, and of Camphora one
dram, of Plantaine water one pynte: with the which decoction thus prepared,
let the sore be daily washed. The water often applied, causes flesh to grow
again: it heals the Fistula in the Fundament, and recouereth Canker sores,
by often washing the mouth therewith: it heals the exulcered bowels, given up
in glyster wise by the fundament. The water applied on running Pyles with
Cotton, cures them: it cures also evil Pushes, and grievous ulcers.

The water of Rybworte. The.Lxij. Chapter.
THe time of Dystillation of it, is, that the roots and herb, with the whole
substance shredde small, by dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the mids of
May. This water druncke with Rosed Honey, to the quantity of four ounces;
two hours before the coming of the fit, delivers the Quartaine fever, so
that it be used before the beginning of sundry fittes. The water in like
quantity druncke, sends forth the afterburthen, cleanses the Reins and
Bladder, and preuayleth against the ulcers of the Nosethrils or eyes, if they
be washed twyse a day with the same. The water druncke warm, with a little
Rosed Honey, expels the worms of the belly. This water has in a manner
the same virtues, which the greater Plantaine possesses, saving that these are
not so mighty in working.

The water of the Polipodie. The.Lxiij. Chapter.
THe seasonable time for Dystillation of the Polipodie of the Oak, is, that the
roots only gathered (without the herb) and shredde small, be dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, from Iulye to September. This water druncke morning and evening,
to the quantity of four ounces at a time, with Rosed honey, helps the
Cough, and frensinesse: It also puts away Melancholy, heaviness, and
grief of the mind: and druncke for certain days, delivers the quartaine
Ague. The like quantity drunck with the broth of a Cock or Pullet, expels
by siege, Melancholy and flewme, and helps them greatly which by nature are
costiue. The water druncke, loses the streyghtnesse of the breast, softeneth
the belly, puts away fearful dreams, provoke urine, purges the
blood, comfort the heart, and amendeth an evil color.

The water of the Daysie. The.Lxiiij. Chapter.
THe herb and roots, with the whole substance shredde small, require to be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May. This water druncke
Morning, Noone, and at Evening, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a
time, procures an appetite to meat. The water druncke, profits that person,
which shall have a rybbe or leg broken, and heals wounds, by drincking or
washing them with it. The water taken, to the quantity of six ounces at a
time, loses the Belly, heals the vlcered bowels, and strengthens the
Palsy members, if they be often rubbed or labored with the same. It cools
the Liver, extinguisheth an inward heat, represseth Choler, helps the
blysters of the mouth and tongue, proceeding of heat.

The water of Knotgrasse. The.Lxv. Chapter.
THe whole Herb with the roots shredde small, require to be dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May. This water druncke morning, noone, and
at evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, stays the over great
flux of the belly. The water profits against the Ague, which inuadeth with
a heat. It also heals the Shingles, by applying lynnen clothes wette in the
same. The water helps all manner of pain of wounds, where an inflammation
with redne^se consists, if they be washed with the same, or that a lynnen
clothe wette in it, be often applied. The water druncke in like manner
abouesayde, cleanses the Reins, expels the stone of the loins, procures
urine, and opens the obstruction of such members. The water druncke with
Rosed honey, profits children and men against worms. It recouereth rotten
gummes, if they be often washed with the same, and heals black pushes or
bladders, by applying lynnen clothes wette in it. The water extinguisheth all
manner of heates, happening as well within, as without the body.

The water of wild Tansey. The.Lxvi. Chapter.
THe whole Herb with the roots shredde small, require to be dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, from July unto September. This water druncke morning and
evening, for six or eight days together, to the quantity of two or three
ounces at a time, stays the white terms, or whytes in women. The water
dropped into the eyes, recouereth the much running of them, and heals the eye
lyddes folding outward, by annoynting them often with it. The water applied to
the eyes, profits against dymnesse of sight, the pin and web, and other
spots happening in them. The water heals wounds, if they be washed with
the same, and applied often with lynnen clothes wette in it. If the back bone
be labored with the same, it takes away the grief thereof. The water of the
flowers (when they shall be full ripe, dystilled in a Cucurbite of glass by
Balneo Mariae) druncke in the morning fasting, to the quantity of two or
three ounces at a time, for certain days together, comfort all the members
of man. The water druncke, and applied with a lynnen clothe on the forehead,
profits against the gyddynesse and swimming of the head. The water
delivers the Rheum, and running of bleared eyes. It also recouereth moist
ulcers, by applying lynnen clothes wette in the same, in that it draws forth
the moisture by the poores.

The water of self heal. The.Lxvij. Chapter.
THe time for dystillation of it, is, that the herb, stalks, and flowers
shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the end of May. This
water recouereth the putrefaction of the mouth: tempered with the oil of Roses
and vinegar, and applied to the Temples, puts away the burning of the head:
mixed with Rose water, does like help the head. The water druncke morning and
evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time, profits against the
stitches which are felt in the sides, and against the inner impostumes of the
body: It also extinguisheth inflammations, and recouereth a weakness of the
heart: In the like manner druncke, heals the Shingles, and the inflammations
with a redness, as well in men of ripe age, as in children. The water every
day druncke fasting, preserves from the plague, cleanses the breast, and
puts away the strangurie: It also preuayleth against the Tertian, and
Quartaine Ague. The water druncke in the abouesayde manner, helps such women,
whose matrice within begins to putrify and matter, for by the same are they
healed. The water recouereth wounds, if they be often washed with the same,
and that lynnen clothes wette in it, be applied. The water heals swellings
and exulceration of the mouth, by washing and gargelling the mouth with it: for
this delivers the putrefaction and heat, and the pushes or sores of the
mouth.

The water of the leaves of the Oak. The.Lxviij. Chapter.
THe leaves gathered and bruised, require to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae,
about the mids of May. This water drunck to the quantity of six ounces at a
time, recouereth the flux of the belly, whether the same be white or
matterie: It also expels congealed blood into clottes by a strype. The
water druncke, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a time, profits a
foul and corrupt liver, and diseased lunges (or at the least) begins to
putrify. This in like manner druncke, preuayleth against stitches in the sides.
The water druncke twyse a day, stays the over great flux of the terms, and
stops the bleeding of wounds, and like helps the pyssing of blood, by
taking it in the foresaid quantity. The water daily druncke, does especially
prevail against the stone of the loins and bladder. It also heals the
bowels exulcerated, by the dangerous flux of the belly. The water applied
with lynnen clothes on the inflamed member, exceedingly cools. It heals
old ulcers of the legs, if they be often washed with the same, and let to
dry in by it self. The water avails against redness, and burning of the
legs by black pushes, in applying on the places twyse or thryce a day, towe,
or lynnen clothes wette in it, until the heat be extinguished. The water
druncke with a dram weight of the fine powder of Mestiltowe of the Oak, for
certain days together, adding to it a scruple weight of Aqua vitae rectified,
recouereth not only Fevers, and the Apoplexy, or deprivation of senses, but
helps without doubt the falling sickness. The water in like manner prepared
and druncke, puts away gyddynesse, swellings of the body, preserves from
the Leprie, and delivers most diseases: in that it purges and sends forth
the gross, and evil humors offending.

The water of the leaves of the Willowe. The.Lxix. Chapter.
THe leaves of the white Wyllowes strypped from the twigs, being tender in
the Spring time, require to be dystilled about the beginning of May, by Balneo
Mariae. This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of four
ounces at a time sweetened with Sugar, helps the stone, procures vryne, and
preuayleth against the worms of the belly. The water profits against the
redness of eyes, being often washed with the same: It helps the Shyngles,
and recouereth the Fistula, by applying lynnen clothes wette in it. The water
druncke in like quantity, expels the yoongling dead. The water of the
flowers (dystilled after the manner of the flowers of the Apples and Peaches)
recouereth the sight, heals scabbednesse of the head, procures fair hear:
if wetting the hears well with a Sponge dypped in it, and kembed, be after
suffered to dry by themself.

The water of the Elder. The.Lxx. Chapter.
THe outward rynde scraped and pylled from the slyppes of the Elde^ tree, and
the inner ryndes taken and shredde, require to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae,
about the beginning of May. This water druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of four ounces at a time, recouereth the Dropsy. The water druncke
fasting, to the quantity of six ounces at a time, sweetened with a little
Rosed honey, mightily loses the belly without harm. The water (of the
tender leaves of the tops and sides budding forth, shredde small, and
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May) helps hot legs and
putrified ulcers, if they be often washed with the same, and let to dry by
themself. The water of the flowers (through blown and stamped together,
dystilled in a Cucurbite of Glass by Balneo Mariae) druncke morning and
evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, sweetened with Rosed
honey, loses the straitness of the breast. The water in like quantity
druncke, profits against the swelling and water between the skin, and
opens the stopping of the liver, mylt, and kidneyes. The water druncke,
puts away the Tertian ague, cleanses and helps all courses proceeding of
Melancholy, and strengthens the stomach. The water druncke to the quantity
of six ounces at a time, purges all humors by siege, and cleanses the body.
The water dropped into the eyes, extinguisheth the heat of them: It also
druncke twyse a day, and dropped into the eyes, consumes white spots in
them. The water helps the trembling of the hands, if they be wette and
labored with the same, and let to dry by themself. The water profits
against ulcers, and that be cold, if they shall be often washed with the same,
or that lynnen clothes wette in it be applied.

The Water of Scabious. The.Lxxi. Chapter.
THe leaves and roots shredde together, require to be dystilled by Balneo
Mariae, about the end of May. This water druncke three or four times a day,
to the quantity of three ounces at a time, recouereth the straytenesse of
breast, and helps the impostumes of the same. The water druncke morning,
noone, and at evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, preuayleth
against stitches of the sides. The water profits against swellings in the
body, against the Plague, poisoning, the Cough, and all inward corruption of
the body. The water in the abouesayde manner druncke, helps scabbednesse, and
cleanses the blood corrupt: It also puts away swellings arysing in the
body, and heals wounds as well without, as within the body, by applying
lynnen clothes wette in it. The water in like manner druncke, purges the
lunges, and puts away the Cough. The water helps the Pyles, white scurfe,
Letters, and Ringwormes: It also recouereth pestilent pushes, as the Carbuncle
sore, and amendeth the sight of the eyes. The water of the Saxifrage (with the
whole substance shredde small, and dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the mids
of May) drunck every day fasting, to the quantity of three or four ounces at
a time, sweetened with Sugar, breaks the stone of the kidneys and bladder,
helps ache in the hyppes, delivers the stopping of vryne, and cleanses the
reins and bladder.

The Water of Nightshade of the Garden. The.Lxxij. Chapter.
THe leaves with the stalks gathered and shredde small, require to be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, when that the berries be green. This water druncke
morning, noone, and at evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time,
helps a swelling proceeding of an intemperate hotenesse. It perfourmeth the
like, by applying lynnen clothes wette on the swelling. The water in the
foresaid manner taken, helps the stone, and puts away sweat, myxed with
the water of wormewoode, and druncke to the quantity of three ounces at a
time. The water preuayleth against the griefs and aching of the hinder part and
whole head, procured of heat. The water applied with Lynnen clothes wet in
it, on a hot Gowte, and the Shingles, does in short time help them, the
rather by the often applying of the clothes wette in the water. The water
dropped into the ears, puts away grief in them, asswageth inflamed
impostumes of the breasts or pappes of women, and represseth hot swellings
in the throat, that they do not hastily strangle nor stop the wind: and the
water gargelled in the throat, cools the liver, and extinguisheth heat. The
water helps men bursten, by often applying lynnen clothes wette in it, on the
rupture. The water druncke greatly avails, if by any night terror certain
pushes shall arise: and the like does the water prevail, applied with lynnen
clothes. The water of the Mustarde seeds (when the herb bearing flowers, is
to be dystilled by Balneo Mariae, about the beginning of June) puts away
ulcers of the gummes, by often washyng the mouth with the same. The water
profits the consumption of members, if they be often rubbed and labored with
the same, in that (by it) they recover strength and flesh. The water heateth
the marrowe of the bones, if they be often washed and labored with the same,
and let to dry by themself. The water profits against a cold disease of
the joints, if they be rubbed and labored with the same, and let to dry by
themself.

The water of Mullaine or Hygges Taper. The.Lxxiij. Chapter.
THe leaves with the flowers full ripe, gathered from the stalks, (after the
shredding small) dystill by Balneo Mariae. This water is most precious against
all swellings, as well inward as outward, by drincking of it morning and
evening, to the quantity of three or four ounces at a time: or that a lynnen
cloth doubled, and wette in the same, be often applied. The water in such manner
taken, helps the lunges ascending unto the throat, and increasing. This in
like manner profits against a hot gowte, by drincking of it morning and
evening, and applying lynnen clothes wette in the same, for on such wise
handled, a better remedy is not to be found. The water profits against all
manner of griefs, proceeding of a flux, by drincking thereof morning, noone,
and at night, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar,
and a little of the fine powder of Cinamone: in the same manner druncke, puts
away the grypings of the bowels. The water recouere^h the face, which appears
infe^^ed after the kind of a Leprie, if a soft lynnen cloth dypped in the
same, be often applied upon. The water helps burnings or scalding* if a
double lynnen clothe (as soon as the harm done) wette in the same, be applied,
the rather by doing on such wise oftentimes: for it draws forth, and
extinguisheth the heat without harm leaving. The water amendeth an ytching
scabbednesse, whether the same shall be moist or dry, by applying lynnen
cloth^s wette in the same, morning, noone, and at evening. The water profits,
if an inflammation with redness happens on the skin, by wetting a lynnen
clothe in the some, and applying it to the place. The water profits, if an^e
shall have a long time dymme eyes and weak of sight, by letting one or two
drops fall at a time into each eye, for two or three weeks together.

The water of the Lynde or rope Timber tree. The.Lxxiiij. Chapter.
THe flowers orderly gathered, and put into a Cucurbite of glass, dystill by
Balneo Mariae. This water cleanses any spots of the face, if the face be
often washed with the same: as Hieronimus the Herbarian reports. The water
druncke with a little Cynawone water, recouereth the trembling of the heart.
The water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of two ounces at a
time, helps the falling sickness. The water drunck in like manner, profits
against the fretting of the gu^t^s: and dropped at evening into the eyes,
procures a cleerenesse of them. The water druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of three ounces at a time, helps the stone: In the same manner
druncke, recouereth swellings, and sends all manner of evil hum^rs out of the
body.

The water of Tormentill. The.Lxxv. Chapter.
THe herb with the whole substance shredde and bruised, requires to be
dystilled by Balneo Mariae, from the xv. day of August, unto the viij. of
September. This water druncke in the morning fasting, to the quantity of three
ounces at a time, preuayleth against all manner of poisons. The water is a good
preservative against the plague, and an unhealthful air. For the plague when
it inuadeth any, incontinent open a vein, as it behooves, after give this
potion, on such wise prepared: take of the water of Tormentill three ounces, of
Uenice Triacle a dram weight, of wine vinegar an ounce and a half, which
diligently myxed together, minister warm to the pacient, lying in his bed, and
well covered with clothes to sweat: whiles he thus lies in a sweat, rub
and labor his hands and feet, with Vinegar, Rue, Wormewoode, and Salt myxed.
The next day following, minister again the same potion, and he shall then
recover health. The water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of three
ounces at a time, recouereth the desperate and all ulcers in manner, and staye^h
any manner flux of the belly, especially the flux Dysenteria. The water
taken in the same manner, strengthens the body, comfort the brain, the
heart, stomach, lyu^r, mylt, and the whole breast, if wine sometimes be myxed
with the same. The water druncke in the same manner, helps all Agues, it
strengthens and comfort such recovering out of a long sickness. The water
druncke profits wounds, as well within the body, as without, and cures
outward wounds the speedier, if they be often washed with the same: It also
helps all manner of griefs of the eyes, by dropping of the same every night
into the eyes, for it clears the sight. The water heals the Fistula and
Canker, if they be often washed with the same, and that lynnen clothes wette in
it, be applied. To be brief, in what manner, and what sickenesses the water
shall be applied and ministered, shall (of experience found) be profitable.

The water of Valeriane. The.Lxxvi. Chapter.
THe congruent time for dystillation of it, is, that the herb, roots, and
stalks, with the whole substance shredde small, be dystilled by Balneo Mariae,
about the end of May. This water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity
of three or four ounces at a time, and applied with lynnen clothes, recouereth
ulcers, and swellings causing pain, and great pyles in the fundament: It also
profits against other pyles, by applying lynnen clothes wette in the same.
The water helps such bursten, and the bone somewhat broken, by applying and
drincking of the same: It also dropped into the eyes, clears them. The water
druncke in the morning fasting of Children, to the quantity of of a spoon^full
at a time, delivers the worms in the belly. The water druncke, profits
against poison, and a pestilent air: It heal^th new and old wounds,
recouereth ulcers and impostumes within the body, and puts away ache of
the hyppes. The water drunck, procures clear eyes, takes away the pai^^ of
them, and provoke sweat: powered into troubled wine, causes the same cleerer
and purer. The water remooueth grief of the members, proceeding of a cold
cause, by laboring the members with the same. The water of the roots only
(dystilled by Balneo Mariae, from the mids of August unto the viij. day of
September) drunck; helps poison, and profits against venomous beasts and
worms. The water helps the quotidian fever, drunck to the quantity of six
ounces before the coming of the fit. The water drunck, and applied with lynnen
clothes, preuayleth against pain and stitches of the sides. The water
procures unity and love, where two shall drink together a cup full of this
water.

The water of Verueyne. The.Lxxvij. Chapter.
THe male Uerueyne with the whole substance gathered, shredde small, dystill
by Balneo Mariae, about S. John's day in June. This water druncke morning an^
evening, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, for six or eight days
together, recouereth the yelow Iaundise, preuayleth against poison, helps the
Tertian and Quartaine fever: and expels worms of the belly, by taking the
like quantity, every morning fasting. The water in such manner drunck, helps
the straitness of the breast; the hardness of fetching breath, the ulcers and
consumption of lunges. It comfort the liver, and causes a good color. The
water druncke, recouereth griefs of the stomach, the stoppings of the liver
and mylt, and grievous pains of the loins, and bladder. The water drunk,
amendeth the stopping of the bowels, stomach, and belly. The water cleanses
the reins and bladder, and washes the stones in them. The water profits
against inward pushes of the body: it helps the pyssing of blood, and
grypings of the belly. It is a precious water, for grievous pains and strypes
of the head, by often annoynting and applying lynnen clothes wette in it to
the head: It also helps long sickenesses, whose cause is not known. The
water preuayleth against all manner of dymnesse of the eyes, and ulcers in
them: comfort a weak sight* and procures a clearenesse to it, by ^ropping
and annoynting it diverse times in the eyes. The water helps sores or scabbes
arysing amongst the hears of the head, or other places of the body, and
griefs of the stomach, liver, and mylte, by annoynting and applying lynnen
clothes wette in the same. The water profits against the exulceration of
women's places, if they be washed morning and evening with the same, and that a
lynnen clothe wette in it, be often applied.

The water of Fluelling. The.Lxxviij. Chapter.
THe herb with the whole substance shredde small, and infused for a day and a
night in good Sack or white wine, dystill by Balneo Mariae, about the
beginning of June, which after rectified, will endure for ten years. This
water druncke in the morning fasting, to the quantity of two ounces or less
at a time: or that a Sponge wette in the water (myxed with other savors) be
borne in an Orange pyll, to smell oftentimes to it, preserves the person from
the plague. The hands, head, forheade, and temples, anointed with the same,
profits against any evil and noisome smell. The person which is taken with
the plague, if he lets a vein before it be opened, and takes an ounce and
a half of the fine powder of this herb, with three ounces of the water myxed
with a scruple weight of Venice triacle, and after the drincking be well
covered with clothes to sweat: the poison and evil humors be then expelled
from the heart, and by sweating avoided, so that it is a present and proved
remedy against venomous and pestilent fevers. The water druncke twyse a day,
to the quantity of three or four ounces at a time, heals new wounds, in
that the same issues forth of the wounds, by sweating like to an Oil. The
wounds are also to be washed with this water morning and evening, and applied
with lynnen clothes wette in it, for this on such wise cures wounds and evil
ulcers, in a marvelous manner. An ounce of Vitrioll, or rather of the stone
Chalcites brought to powder dissolved in a pynte of this water, heals all
putrified ulcers, the Ringworme, spots of sundry colors, or any evil
scabbe, whelkes, and fowlenesse of the skin, proceeding of corrupt humors.
The elder that this water shall be, so much the worthyer in diverse causes. The
water anointed or applied with lynnen clothes, on the sting of Spyders, or
byte of venomous beasts, heals and puts away the swelling. The water
druncke and gargelled morning and evening, to the quantity of three ounces at
a time, puts away incontinent the swelling of the throat: If half a pound
of Alum be dissolved in a pynte of this water, and heated, dryueth away
Mothes out of clothe; by wetting and washing it with the same. The water
druncke morning and evening to the quantity of an ounce and a half, or two
ounces for certain days together, puts away gyddynesse of the head,
helps memory, cleanses tough and clammie humors, wastes and purifieth
corrupt blood, the matrice and bladder purges, expels poisons, the stone
of the kidneyes, and all inward poisons of the body. The water delivers the
wandering heat, and opens the passages of the body. This also druncke every
morning fasting for six weeks together, to the quantity of three or four
ounces at a time, makes a man lean of body, strengthens the liver, and
consumes superfluous evil humors. The water druncke in the morning fasting,
an^ laboring it especially on the head, does greatly profit to the
comforting of memory, and to the strengthening of the head and brain: it
also causes a readynesse of speech, and purifyeth the blood. The water
druncke to the quantity of two ounces, or two ounces and a half, with a
dram weight of the fine powder of the leaves of Fluelling* and a dram of the
myddle rynde in powder of Amara dulcis, (that is, bitter sweet) myxte and
druncke fasting, for certain days together, delivers the clammynesse of the
lunges, purges the breast by spittings forth, helps the Cough, difficulties
of fetching breath, and corruption of the lungs, for which cause the
shepeheards in our time, use to give ye herb with salt to sheep vexed with
the cough. The water taken morning and evening, does especially help the
lunges and liver, if they inwardlye putrify, and do ascend unto the throat:
yea, though they shall putrified unto the gretnesse of a hasill nutte, yet will
they again be restored to health by this. The water druncke with a dram of
the powder of the herb, delivers the shedding of the gall; g^ntly procures
urine, and causes very fat and barren women, lean and fruitful. The water
druncke to the quantity of four ounces at a time, procures sweat according
to necessity.

The water of the Birche tree. The.Lxxix. Chapter.
THe leaves newly sprunge out* shredde and beaten, dystill by Balneo Mariae,
about the mids o^ May. This water drunck morning and evening, to the
quantity of four ounces at a time* sweetened with Sugar, delivers the
grief of the stone in the loins. The water profits unto the cooling of hot
ulcers, especially those which shall happen on man's priuities, if it be applied
with lynnen clothes. The water dy^tilled out of the tappe of the tree, after
this manner purchased (as that (...) a hole bored in the body of the tree,
near to the root, and under the same a glass set to gather the lycour
dystilling forth, which after dystilled by Balneo Mariae) profits unto all
wounds washed with the same, yea, heals and dries up open ulcers, if it be
often applied with lynnen clothes. The water druncke morning and evening, to
the quantity of two o^nces and a half, sweetened with Sugar, for xl. days
together, wastes the stone of the kidneyes and bladder. The water cleanses
away spots on the skin, and procures a fayrenesse of the same: It also
heals ulcers of the mouth, by often washing with the same. The water (of the
herb Peryuincle, dystilled about the end of May) drunck morning and evening,
to the quantity of three ounces at a time, recouereth women's places cold, the
rather by applying lynnen clothes wette in the same, and helps those which
have a cold stomach. The water for certain days druncke, with a dram of
the powder of the herb, sends forth the water between the flesh and skin
by vein. A Pessarie wette in the water, and conveyed up into the privy place,
draws down the Terms. The water druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of three ounces at a time sweetened with Sugar, cease the grypinges
of the bowelles, and stays the flux of the belly* and terms: It also
purges all clammie humors out of the liver and bladder, and cleanses the
reins.

The water of the Vine tree. The.Lxxx. Chapter.
THe water of the Vine tree is gathered in a great glass, about the beginning
of April, when Vynes are cut: and the same (after the dystilling by Balneo
Mariae) requires to be sunned for xl. days. This water myxed with a little
pure wine, and druncke fasting, sharpeneth or quickens the mind and senses.
The water profits against any scabbednesse, if it be washed with the same, it
causes a clean and fair face, and puts away pushes and pymples of the
face. The water often applied, wears away wartes, and the thick knobbes of
hard flesh on the hands. The water recouereth ringwormes, foul spots on
the body, scuruynesse, and inflammations with a redness of the skin, if
they be washed with the same* and applied with lynnen clothes wette in it,
twyse or thryse a day. The leaves of the best vynes* which grow on high and
sunnie places, require to be dystilled in a due season of the year (as about
the end of May) by Balneo Mariae. Thi^ water dropped into running eyes, dries
and stays the running of them, and clears the sight. The water druncke,
helps the spitting of blood, recouereth ulcers of the bowels, and stays a
hot flux of the belly. The water taken thryce a day, to the quantity of
three ounces at a time, expels the stone, helps the abhorring of women
with child, and their foolish longing for sundry things, that no harm may
insewe to the yoongling. Of the roots of the vine, is made a decoction right
profitable, on this wise: Take of the feet of the Vine shredde small, two
pounds, these infuse in the strongest vyneger (covered well over) to which
after add nine pyntes of Conduite water, and a pynte of white honey: after the
boiling and consuming in a third part, that only six pyntes remain, strain
the whole through a carsey cloth, to which then add of the simple Iu^lepe
viij. ounces, and four graynes of Musk dissolved in four or six ounces of
pure Rose water, which after the pouring into a glass, stop close with a
cork and parchement: If any drincketh four ounces of this decoction hot, in
the morning fasting, and refrayneth meat four hours after, procures in
short time a very good stomach, and appetite to meat. This also helps the
Cholicke passion, increases milk in women's breasts, puts away griefs of
the matrice, and is much auayleable for the cough, the rheum, and grief of
the reins.

The water of the greater Celondine. The.Lxxxi. Chapter.
THe congruent time of dystilling the Celondine, is, that when the herb
bearing flowers, the whole substance gathered and shredde small, be dystilled
in a Cucurbite of glass by Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May. This water
druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time,
delivers the yelowe Iaundise, and helps the grypings of the belly. The
water druncke in the same manner, mitigateth the Ague, and puts away
scabbednesse proceeding of cold, if the places be anointed with the same. The
water druncke twyse or thryse a day, to the quantity of two ounces at a
time, sweetened with Sugar, recouereth the stopping of the liver and mylt. The
water (after the infusion of the herb for six days in good Aqua vitae)
druncke for certain days morning and evening, to the quantity of an ounce at
a time, preserves the body long in health, and expels evil humors. The
water dropped into the eyes, recouereth spots, the pynne and web,
delivers the redness of them, preserves and causes a sharp and ready
sight, and restores the same in a manner lost: If the mouth be washed with the
water, it cease the grievous pain of the teeth, and puts away spots, if
the face be often washed with the same. The water dries and heals a Canker,
and likewise the Fistula, and puts away pestilent pushes, if a lynnen cloth
wet in it, be applied twyse or thrice a day. The water of the greater
Celondine, that has the property of helping diseases, as well the hot as
cold; gives strength to the spiritual members, expels poysen from the
heart, delivers the lunges of that which to it is noyous, heals it vlcered,
and by drincking sundry times of it, stays the flux of blood. I am in
doubt (says a certain skillful Physician) whether a man may believe, that all
these properties be in the dystilled water of Celondine; seeing that according
to Dioscorides and Galen, it is of quality mightily clensing, and very hot,
by reason whereof this causes the veins to be the cleerer of all gross
humors, and delivers the obstructions of the liver in the Iaundyse: This also
is the reason, why the learned Mathiolus in his commentary upon Dioscorides,
does so greatly reprehend the Chemists, which take upon them to draw forth a
Quintessence of this herb, that they affirm to be not only commodious for
their extractions, but as woonderfully profitable for the preserving of health,
and expelling of infinite diseases. Seeing that this herb can work no such
matter, it is possible that the Chymistes abuse the same, where they in stead
of rightly naming this herb Chelidonium, do name it Caelidonum, (rather
devising for it such a word Caelidonum) as if this herb were a gift from
heaven, to which are attributed all these great virtues. This water is on such
wise distilled, take the roots, leaves and flowers, which shredde small, and
put into a vessel of glass, well fenced with Lute, bury the vessel covered
with his head in horse dung, for the space of ten days: After the taking
forth, dystill it in ashes according to Art: the lycour that shall first run
forth, will be waterishe, the second as an oil, which you shall dystill yet
once again, and keep for your use.

The water of Strawberies. The.Lxxxij. Chapter.
THe time most agreeable for distilling of the berries, is, when they are ripe,
yet not over soft: and those which grow and are gathered in the hyllie woods,
be accounted the better. These full ripe, shall you putrify in a Cucurbite of
glass, by strawing upon them a good quantity of Sugar brought to powder,
which let so long stand (close covered with the head) until they appear
hoarie, after dystill the whole by Balneo Mariae. This singular water asswageth
burning humors, puts away spots of the eyes new grown, either of a hot
or cold humor, so that they be not ouergreat. It also stays the watring and
running of the eyes, proceeding of heat or cold, and like restores the sight
to a clearenesse, decayed or lost by either of the causes. This water druncke
in the morning fasting, to the quantity of three ounces at a time, with a
little wine, does marvelously prevail against the inward heates of the
lunges and liver, and extinguisheth thirst. It also comfort nature,
expels poisons, and procures the terms in women. The water drunck in like
quantity morning and evening, sweetened with a little Sugar, recouereth an
evil heat of the stomach, and asswageth the great desire to drink. The
water druncke morning and evening, to the quantity of four ounces at a time,
with a dram weight of pure Aqua vitae, recouereth and heals the Leprie, for
that the same druncke in wine, or otherwise eaten with bread, purges the
blood, and remooueth a noisome scabbednesse of the body. The water in the
same manner taken, helps the inflammations of the liver, the yelowe Iaundise,
the stone in the loins, kidneyes and bladder. It also loses the breast,
comfort the heart, and cleanses the blood. The water holden a little while
in the mouth, and gargelled in the throat, strengthens the gummes, fasteneth
the teeth loose, and stays the dystillations from the brain: It also
profits against ulcers, and swellings in the throat, soreness of the mouth,
and a stinking breath. The water marvelously recouereth and heals blysters
and pymples on the face, which proceed of heat, by often washing it with the
same. This also asswageth the swelling of the face, by washing and often
applying lynnen clothes wette in the water. The water recouereth that person
whose leg is broken, by drincking every morning fasting (for a certain
space) to the quantity of four ounces at a time, sweetened with Sugar, and to
apply often lynnen clothes wette in the same. The water heals all foul
legs, if they be washed morning and evening with the same, or that the water
often applied with linen clothes: It also cures filthy wounds, if they shall
be often washed with the same, and that the pacient in the mean season, does
daily drinck twyse a day of this water. The water mixed with pure white salt,
and distilled once again in a Cucurbite of glass by Balneo Mariae, is highly
commended for the eyes, in that it cools, cleereth, and puts away the
dymnesse of them. The water of the Strawberies, is a souereygne and an
effectuous ointment for the eyes, if they especially be grieved by an extreme
heat, or hot dystillings from the head. The water of the herb (dystilled by
Balneo Mariae, about the mids of May) druncke morning and evening, to the
quantity of four ounces at a time, recouereth the yelowe Iaundise, procures
urine, stays the flux Dysenteria, and the terms in women, and helps the
spleen. The water like druncke, loses the breast, purges the lunges, helps
the Cough, and puts away the Leprie. The water dropped into burning eyes
with a redness, morning and evening, does greatly mittigate the heat of them.
The water druncke, asswageth the overmuch sweating of body. For the burning and
obstruction of the liver, there is nothing more profitable, nor holesommer.

Of the Dystilling of waters out of beasts, or out of their parts.
The.Lxxxiij. Chapter.


THe manner of drawing forth a substance from all beasts and Eggs: Take new
laid eggs, the quantity and weight of nine ounces, of common salt prepared,
one ounce, beat and mix these well together, after put the same into a
Cucurbite or glass body, with the cover fast luted, the which set into Balneo
Mariae, or horse dung for ten days at the least. After set on a head with his
receyuer well luted together, which you shall dystill in ashes with a soft
fire, by little and little, and that which comes, keep charily. The like to
this may be drawn out, of Snayles, Partriches, and Capons, for consumptions:
and also the like may be drawn out of Adders, and Snakes for the Leprosy.

The water dystilled of the blood of a healthful young man, avails against
aches, and running pains in the joints, which is prepared on this wise: take
the blood of a young man, of twenty years old, or thereabout, being in
perfect health: this blood let stand to cool in a vessel so long, unto the
separation of the wheyishe moisture from the blood, which waterie moisture
floting above, throw away: the other put into a glass body with a head
close luted about, after set or bury the same in horse dung, for sixteen
days, that it may putrify or rot. Which after the drawing forth, set into
ashes, luting diligently the receyuer to the nose of the head. This dystill
with a soft and easy fire in the beginning: with this dystilled water, souple
(and as it were bathe) the aching and payning places.

The water of man's ordure dystilled by a Lymbecke, preuayling in the Fistula,
and brings or causes a fair scarre, if the grieved places be applied with
the same: If of this water be dropped into the eye, it takes away the redness
and dymnesse of sight, it breaks and dissolueth the web, and puts away
or dries up tears. This druncke, helps speedily the falling sickness,
namely if their heads be anointed therewith. This water also applied on
Impostumes with towe, speedily breaks them. If ministered with a quantity of
Lyme dissolved in it, breaks the stone. This water druncke, helps the
Dropsy. This water speedily heals the byte of any venomous dog being
mad, or other beast venomous, if the harmed person drink thereof: If this
water be druncke by and by after poison received, it delivers the person.
This Bertapalia.

The water of man's ordure or dung, of a sanguine man dystilled, being orderly
applied, does help the hasty changing of the hear of the head to a
whiteness, and the shedding of it, corrosiue ulcers, the canker, and spots
of the eyes. This also druncke, recouereth the falling sickness, amendeth the
stone of the kidneys and bladder, the Dropsy, and the byte of any venomous
beast.

The water of man's ordure dystilled, causing the hear of the head to grow,
is thus prepared: Take of man's ordure, and the same dystill in a glass body,
and that the same may not stink, myxe a little Camphora, or Musk finely
grinded with it: with this water wash the bare place, where you would have the
hear to grow, annoynting after the place with the best honey for xxx. days.
The place or scabbed part washed with the water of man's ordure dystilled, does
thoroughly cure it: for this is a secret in every scabbe, or in all manner of
scabbes.

The water of Dooues dung (steeped for a night before in wine) dystilled, and
druncke, helps the stone, this Theophrastus.

The water of a Capon dystilled, which a German woman used in the traueyle of
child, and in birth of the child: Take a Capon of twelve years of age, this
strangled, pulled, and orderly dressed, boil then in a sufficient quantity of
the best Malmesie, Rosewater, and Borage in a possenet, or rather new earthen
pot glased, unto a tenderness of the flesh: after stamp diligently the
flesh, with the bones and intrayles, which put into a Cucurbite and luted,
dystill according to Art in Balneo Mariae, add in the dystilling both Musk
and Amber greece, but another wills of Diambra, and of Diamoschus (which I
rather allow) of the powder of precious stones, of Diarrhodon abbatis, of
Diamargariton calidum, Aromaticum Rosatum, of each of these Cordial powders
(gotten from the Apothecarie) four scruples, of Coriander prepared half an
ounce, adding hereunto besides of the oil of Cynamone, four grains weight,
of the oil of Cloves six grains, these diligently mix together.

The description of the water of a Capon, out of the dispensatorie of the
Colonians. The.Lxxxiiij. Chapter.
THe Capon ought first to be much chased up and down, until he be wearied,
and then suddenly strangled, the feathers after plucked of, without dipping of
him in water (as the feathers dry pluckte) which on such wise wholye plucked
and bare, and the bowels drawn, choppe small both the flesh and bones, the
mawe or gyserne, the liver, and heart, the bowels remembered to be thrown away.
The Capon thus ordered and chopped very small, lay to soke in an earthen pot
glased, pouring upon a pynt and a half of read Rosewater, a pynte of Buglosse
water, half a pynte of Maioram or Baulme water, of Malmesie a pynte and three
ounces, of Cinnamon two ounces, of Saffron one dram, of Endive seeds three
drammes, of Galingale two drammes, of Gynger, Nutmegs, Mace, and the cytryne
Saunders, of each one dram, of the ryndes of the pleasant Citrone, a dram
and a half, of the Cordial flowers (to be learned of the Apothecarie) of each
one dram, of Couander seeds prepared, and of Melone seeds, of each two
drammes, of the Pyne apple seeds one ounce, of the Orange flowers preserved
and brought to powder half an ounce: All these let stand in the infusion for
twenty and four hours, upon a furnace, or in any other hot place: which in
setting the head close luted upon, (whether the same be in a glass body)
dystill by Balneo Mariae, and in the dystilled lycour quench sundry times a
piece or pieces of red glowing gold, especially at the time of the ministering
or using of this drinck: This borrowed out of the dispensa* of the Colonians.

The dystillation of a Capon Maystriall, of D. Peter Vnormatiensis. he first
boiled the Capon in water unto a sufficiency (on such wise) that two pyntes
remained of the broth, after he powered the broth and flesh into a glass body
close-luted, which he dystilled after Art in ashes, and having distilled about
a pint, or a pint and a half, ceased of, without adding to this water either
spices* either herbs or roots: which water he often ministered and used to
weak bodies, in Agues, and was delectable without abhorrement to the pacients.

Another, let a good Capon be boiled in pure water, with the leaves of Borage
and Buglosse, of each one handful, of the conserve of Violets, Roses, Borage
and Buglosse, of each two ounces (of the Cordial powlders a like quantity
added) let all these be dystilled in Balneo Mariae, the lycour dystilled,
aromatizate with the powder of the three Saunders: and let this be druncke or
ministered often to weak bodies: this borrowed out of And* a Lacuria, in the end
of his book of the pestilence.

The dystillation of a Capon, borrowed of a certain doctor. Take an ancient
Capon, of six, seven, or eight years of age, the same dry pull and bare,
which after the drawing, steep or soke in pure water for a night, the whole
put after into a new earthen pot glased, which contains four measures of
water, this in the seething skym diligently, and the fatness take carefully
of, remembering always to fill up the pot boiling: After the flesh t^^derly
sodden, and fallen from the bones, take or pare of both the fat and thin
skynnes (which so ordered) shredde the flesh very small, putting it with the
boiled water, into four glass bodies Artely luted, under which maintain
fire, until the whole work be ended, which dystilled on this wise, stop
close unto your use: for this mightily recouereth those which be decayed of
strength, and that have no appetite or will to meat.

Another water of a Capon, unto the restoring of decayed strength, out of a
written book of a certain Physician: the tender flesh and pulpe of one
Capon, the skynnes and fat drawn of, and pulled away, shredde finely, and
wash diligently with Buglosse water: after this, add to the conserve of
Violets, Borage, and Buglosse, of each an ounce and a half, of the conserve of
Roses one ounce, of lease gold vj. in number, all these arteficially mixed
together, and put after in a double vessel, dystill according to Art: let a
spoonefull alone of this licour, be often ministered, or with comfortable
brothes mixed.

Another water of a Capon, out of the same author, recovering bodies low
brought by the ague: Take the pulpe or tender flesh of the Capon, being chased
and coursed up and down, and to and fro, before the strangling, from which
draw or pluck both the fat and skins, then wash both in the waters of
the water Lilly (named of the Latins Nenuphar) and the Lettuce, adding
thereto the conserve of Violets new made, and the flowers of the Nenuphar, of
each one ounce, of the conserues of Borage and Buglosse, of each one ounce and
a half, of the white Poppie and Lettuce seeds, of each one ounce, of the
powder of the cold Diamargariton, one dram and a half, of the juice of
pleasant Apples, two ounces, all these diligently mixte together, and put in a
double vessel, dystill according to Art, which dystilled lycour use after the
manner above taught.

Another water of a Capon, of the same authors, for the recovering strength, in
a cold sickness: Take the pulpe of the Capon thoroughly wearied, and after
washed diligently in white wine, or else in Malmesie, if so be the sickness
shall be colder, adding thereunto of the conserve of Sage flowers one ounce, of
the conserve of Staechas, Anthos, and Acorus, of each half an ounce, of the
ryndes of the Cytrons prepared with sugar, and finely shred, six drammes, of
the inner part of the Cinamone, and of Nutmegs, of each one dram, let all
these be put in Balneo Mariae, and dystilled according to Art: let certain
spoonefulles of this lycour, be ministered for a certain time, to the weak and
feeble bodies.

There be some Authors, which in certain sickenesses, especially of the head,
and in cold diseases, with the weakness, and decayed strength: that highly
commend the waters of Capons dystilled on such wise, yea, the Author has
experienced to have auayled sometimes in the Colic passions, especially those
which were wyndie of body: for the distilled water given to such, much
perplexed with wind of the body, it speedily cease and stays the wind
from any more molesting, if so be the water shall rightly be prepared. Thus
diverse and sundry medicines may skilfully be devised by a learned Physician,
in the variety of sickenesses.

For what cause the brothes of Capons, and other fattes, seeing they be
fluxible, and of an ayreall substance, are so slowly elevated. The Lxxxv.
Chapter.
THe reason of this, is, in that the fatness floting or swimming above, does
of the same procure and draw over a thyn skin, which so keeps the moisture
resting under, that the humor can hardly euoporate through: and even the like,
does the oil poured into a vessel with either wine or pleasant waters, by the
floting above, suffer not any of them to breath through: and the Radish root
also eaten with oil, causes then not the like belchings or reastinges of the
stomach to insew, as did otherwise without the oil: and even the like of
juices may be learned, which when any would have kept for a time, they do
cover it with oil, that neither the spirits (through the same) keeping in the
juice, do breath forth, nor may be drawn away of the outward air: this
written of Langius in his Epistles.

A dystilled water restoring weak bodies, and most profitable in consumptions,
out of the secret conclusions of Fierauantus: Let a good young hen be gotten
that never laid egg, this pull alive, whereby her blood may so be stirred
up, and spersed thorowout all the body: thus being plucked bare, and dead,
draw forth the bowels only, beating after both the flesh and bones together
in a mortar, adding so much of the crummes of white bread, as the weight of
the flesh and bones beaten, beat these well together, putting thereunto also
one handful of the green or dry Scabious, and so many leaves of gold as wey
a French or English crown, to these after add so much of the water of the
garden Nightshade or petie Morell, as is the weight of the whole substance,
which after let so stand together for a whole night, putting it then into a
glass body with a head diligently luted, and three pyntes of the best and
mightiest wine also added before the dystilling, which (after the fastening of
the receyuer to the head) dystill in Balneo Mariae, unto the fecies remain
through dry, and then have you the water. Now to every pynte of this water,
add one ounce of our water of the honye (of which shall after be taught in the
proper place of this book) which let be kept in a glass close stopped, that
the air breath not forth. The use of it serves to be druncke both in the
meals, and between meals: which helps the dry cough of the persons
diseased and sick of the Ague, and women traueyling in childebed, and many
other like matters, does this dystillation work, greatly to be woondered at.

The Alchymistes instruct and teach a way of the drawing of waters out of the
whytes and y^lkes of eggs, (by burying the substance before, for five days in
horse dung) and adding also a quantity of Salt in the dystilling. The like do
they describe of the fattes, and rosinie substances* and many descriptions of
the like waters may be understood and read in many practices of Diodorus
Euclayon, already published by the Author.

The water of Swallows helping the falling sickness, borrowed out of the
method of Rondelle^ius* Take of swallows unto the quantity of vj. ounces* of
Gastore^m one ounce, these mix and infuse in wine for a night, and put after
into a glass body, dystill after Art* let the pacient use and take of this
water unto the quantity of two spoonefulles, once a month, in the morning
fasting.

A plaster marvelously helping the scrofuls, and Fistula etc. It has been
experienced, that cutting of the heads and tails of the snakes, and clensing
forth the bowels, and after dystilling them according to Art: This water
applied on scrofulles and the Fistula, does speedily help them: this
Fumanellus writes.

A remedy against the Leprie, prepared and made of frogs: This one singular
remedy and medicine, I will not hyde from the world (says Fumanellus) nor
lightly ouerpasse the confection of frogs, which ought before to be fleaed, and
the bowels drawn forth, then put into a Copper vessel tynned within, and
having sundry small holes in the bottom, like to the form of a watering pot,
under which must another pot be set, in such sort, that the upper standing
within the mouth of the nether pot; and diligently luted round about, that no
air at all breath forth, these so ordered, set into the earth unto the mouth of
the nether pot, and covering the earth close and hard, make a fire of coals
round about the upper pot, the mouth of it, like close luted: which so long
continue with fire, until the whole substance and moisture of the frogs shall
be dystilled: The licour may be ministered or druncke every morning fasting, for
a certain time, unto the quantity of the third part of an ounce: And if
oppurtunitie and just occasion shall so move me, I intend to make an attempt
of the dystilling also of Snakes, in like order (as above taught) of the
frogs. Now the form of the vessels, which Nicholaus Florenti teaches to be
made in his large commentary ( in fermo. 7.) fifth treatise, and xxxix.
Chapter, is on this wise: He first writes the vessel or pot (in which the
frogs prepared be) to be filled unto the mouth with them: and the mouth all
over filled and covered with butter: with this dystilled lycour, being a noble
medicine, he instrudeth to annoint the Canker, that heals it in short time.



The water of the honey comb, procures hear to grow: and helps the hard
fetching and drawing of breath, or such short wynded through the straytenesse
of the breast, if this be often druncke: it helps a man's beard to grow the
more, being sundry times anointed or wette therewith: but far better and
sooner does the oil and honey perform the same, which has a most great
force in the like.

The dystilled honey anointed on a bald pluee, causes the hear to grow, and
come very soon again, after the shedding of hear: this Theophrastus.

Ioannes Montanus writes, that of honey may a strong water be made: and that in
the third dystillation of it, to become a poysonable lycour: ^^t of Mercury
which is resolved by the strong water, is to be brought into a water the which
will make a helthfull lycour and strengthening.

The water of honey to make the face white and fair: take of reddishe honey
two pounds, of gum Arabecke two ounces, these two myxe together, and
dystill by a Lymbecke with a soft fire* The first (...) tha^ comes, serves
unto the clensing of the face, and unto the clearing and whytening of it: the
second with the third lycour, does cause the hears to grow and become
whytishe or flaxen of color.

Gesnerus distilled a water out of honey, whose first water sauoured somewhat of
wax, where besides it was sufficient delectable and clear, and whytish, which
perhaps may seem auayleable in the Cholicke passions. The second water which
dystilled forth, had a certain sowrenesse. The third water which came forth,
tasted as it were vinegar. The fourth water which came forth, tasted in a manner
as sour as vinegar: he began dystillation in the morning at the seventh
hour, and out of half a measure of honey, he purchased two small vials full
in a day, in the evening he began to dystill, and continued unto noone in a
manner, he also prepared and made his fire to last unto the ninth hour of the
night: and from that hour he renewed the fire unto the sixth hour of the next
morrow: and following the fire from the sixth hour of the morning unto two in
the after noone: then began a great fume or smoke to arise and issue forth into
the receyuet, and that somewhat stinking, and a substance also to ascend (as
when nothing remained of the watrie substance, then did the honey ascend)
then drew I forth the Cucurbite (says the author) which I should not have
done (but rather have set or lyfted him higher in the ashes) and then came the
drops forth read, and burnt in the Limbeck, yea sour, and in savor or
smell like to the oil of the Juniper wood in a manner: and of it fast cleaving
to the sides and bottom of the Cucurbite: The remnant in the Cucurbite, was
the honey of a blackish read color, burnt, somewhat sour, and coloring
yelowe.

Master Gesnerus dystilled the oldest Hydromell in ashes, and left in the
Cucurbite a substance tending or declyning unto a blackenesse, and sweet in
taste, yet sour or loathsome in smell. The first water which dystilled forth,
was odoriferous, and had the hot and quick taste of Aqua vitae, yet the same
conceived nor took no flame. The second water which came forth, seemed
wateryer, with a certain sowrenesse: so that a small quantity of water, he
dystilled of the same.

A water gotten of the hinder legs of frogs, by the sublymed vapor,
helps consumptions, and wasting of the lunges, yea, most effectuous for the
dry distemperance of the liver, being taken fasting, and twyse a day warm,
for this proved Alexander Benedictus, most excellent, and ministered of it to
his great praise.

The water dystilled out of the sperme of frogs, in the month of May: and
applied on the gowte, does marvelously assuage or mittigate the pain, and
takes the pain away utterly within a short time.

Of the compounde waters, especially of leaves, flowers, roots, seeds,
fruit, herbs, and trees, lycours, gummes, and wood. A water for the
eyesight. The.Lxxxvi. Chapter.
A Water defending and preserving the sight for a long time, and purging the
eyes of all spots: Take of the best and pleasantest white wine, twelve
pyntes, of new bread light wrought and well washed, four pounds, of
Fennel, Celondine, and of the heads of the squill onyon, of each four
ounces, of Cloves four drammes: these mix diligently together in a glass
body, having the head, and receyuer diligently luted about, which after set
into Balneo Mariae, to be dystilled until five pyntes of the water be come,
then ceasing, draw forth the fire, which water keep a part close stopped.
This water preserves the sight, as above uttered, and cleanses the eyes of all
filth, happening in them. This water works marueylouslye, by ministering one
ounce at a time: for taken fasting in the morning, for a month together,
preserves the body from any great and grievous sickness: and in all manner
of causes or griefs where this water shall be ministered, it works a great
and marvelous help: Or it is otherwise a great secret, in many sickenesses:
this borrowed out of Fierauantus.

Another water for the eyes, borrowed out of a written book of secrets: Take of
Turpentine, (of Tormentill I rather suppose) of Fennel, of Rue, or Endyue, or
Betonie, Celondine, of Eyebright, of red Rose leaves, of Syler of the
mountain, and of Maiden hear, of each one handful, let all these be steeped
in white wine for one day and a night, after put the wine and the whole
substance into a glass body, which dystill according to Art: for this is a
marvelous water for the eyes.

Another water, borrowed out of the same book, excellent for the eyes: Take of
Eyebright ( orenegliae) Celondine, the five leaued grass, the Veruaine, and
Rosemarie flowers, of each one handful, all these myxe together in the form
of a sauce, by pouring the best red wine upon, which after the infusion for a
time, and put up into a glass body, being luted after Art, let so stand
(before the dystilling for four or five days: which thus prepared, and the
receyuer fastened to the nose of the head, dystill with a soft fire: to this
water after add these following, as the Rewe seeds, the Fennel seeds, Sugar Candy, Tutia prepared and brought to powder, and Aloes hepaticke, of each
three drammes, all these diligently labor and myxe together with this water,
in a glass body with a head, and dystilled (as before) with a soft fire,
which after keep in a glass close stopped: Of this water pour a drop at a
time into the eye, of what grief soever the eye shall be molested or payned,
so that the same grief be cold, for it will ease and heal the grief within
a short time.

A water of master Peter the Spanyarde, which both sharpeneth the sight, and
clears the eyes, and puts away spots and the web of the eye: take of
Persely seeds, Fennel seeds, Smalledge seeds, Siler of the mountain, of
Annis seeds, of Carowaye seeds, of the seeds of either Claree, of the roots
of Celondine, of Acorus, of Betonie, of the leaves of Egrimonie, of Tormentill,
Rue, Veruaine, of each a like quantity, these together beaten and grynded, put
for the first day in a healthful chyldes urine: the second day in white
wine: the third day in woman's milk or Asses: and in the fourth day let all
these together, be distilled according to Art: which after keep as a Balm, in
stopping the mouth of the glass close, that it breathe not forth: for his
property is to breathe and seek out.

A water of marvelous working, clearing a mystie and dim sight, and
preserving the health of the eyes, borrowed out of Ioannes de Vigo: take of the
juice of Fennel, of the juice of Celondine, of Rue, of Eyebright, of each two
ounces, of Honey ten drammes, of Sarcocolla, of Antimonie, of Tutia, and of
Aloes, of each half an ounce, of the galls of Capons, Cocks, and Hens, of
each two ounces, of Nutmegs, of Saffron, of Cloves, of each one ounce, of Sugar Candy, and of the sirupe of Roses, of each six drammes, of the liver of a
healthful goat, two ounces and a half, of the flowers of Rosemarie, and
Veruayne, of each one handful and a half: these altogether beat diligently,
and very fine, and the liver cut or shredde very small, all these put after
into a glass body with a head, dystill twyse over according to Art: and
drop of this into the eye, for it is marvelous.

Another water of the same man's, unto that purpose: Take of the galls of those
fowls which live by rapine, and of the gall of a Crane, of each two drammes,
of the galls of Partriches, Fesants, and of Cocks, of each three drammes, of
Honey one ounce, of the juice of Fennel, and the juice of Eyebright, of each
one ounce and a half, of the wine of the sweet and sour Pomegranates, of
each ten drammes, of Aloes hepaticke, and of Sarcocolla, of each two drammes,
of Cubebae, of the long and round Pepper, of each one scruple, of Cynamone one
dram and a half, of Nutmegs, and of Cloves, of each one dram, of Sugar Candy, and of the sirupe of Roses, of both six drammes, of Antimonie, and of
Tutia, of each two drammes and a half, of a Goats liver three ounces, of
Rosemarie flowers one handful: all these finely shredde and bette together,
and put after into a glass body, dystill according to Art: for this water
dropped into the eye, preserves the health and sight of the eye, and amendeth
both the mystynesse and darckenesse of sight.

A most precious water that amendeth the mystynesse, the pynne and web, and
all defaults of the eyes: It clears also the sight by a marvelous manner, and
cleanses any manner of spotte of the eyes: Take of white wine one ounce and a
half, of the juice of Fennel purifyed and cleared, five drammes and a half,
of Camphora, one dram, of Tutia Alexandrina one ounce, of Ginger half an
ounce, of Honey four ounces: all these beaten and grynded together, let steep
for nine days in a clean scoured basin, set in a clear air, where neither
dew nor the sun beams may fall upon, which after dystilled by a Fylter,
keep the water in a glass with a narrow mouth: and drop of this water both
morning and evening, one drop or two into the eye: this Arnoldus.

A water of a most noble working, in the cataracts of the eyes, for it
resolves the matter consisting or being in the ways of the eyes, with a
notable comforting of the virtue visiue or seeing, borrowed out of Ioannes de
Vigo: Take of a healthful and fresh Goats liver two pounds, of Calamus
aromaticus, and of honey, of each half an ounce, of the juice of Rue, three
drammes, of the water of Celondine, six ounces, of Fenn^ll water, of Veruaine
water, and Eyebright water, of each three ounces, of long Pepper, of Nutmegs,
and of Cloves, of each two drammes, of Saffron one scruple, of Rosemarie
flowers grynded somewhat, Schiara or Bozomus, of each half a handful, of
Sarcocolla, of Aloes hepa^icke, af each three drammes, of the g^lles of those
fowls which live by rapine if they can be got en^ one ounce, or instead of
the^ let be taken or used the galls of the Cocks, Capons, Henn^s, and
Par^riches, of each three drammes: to all these after the grinding and beating
together, add three ounces of white Sugar, of Rosed honey, six drammes: these
after the diligent laboring and myxing together, dystill in a Cucurbite
according to Art, which diligently stop and keep to your use: for this
water comfort any dymnesse and weakness of sight, mundifyeth the
mystinesse of the eyes, and lets or stays the coming of a Cataracte.

A water to be dropped within the eye, restoring the largeness of the apple of
the eye, with a certain comforting of the virtue visiue: Take of the juice of
the sweet Fennel, one dram, of the blood of a Culuer one ounce, of Tutia,
and Antimonie, of each two drammes, of Rosewater, and of the water of Myrtels,
of each one ounce and a half, of the powder of the Myrobalan^s and Citrines
together half a dram, these after the myxing, and put into a glass body
with a head, dystill according to Art: which water after use, as above taught:
this Joan. de Vigo.

A water experienced, for the recovery of sight in a manner lost, being often
dropped into the eyes: take of Cellondine, Fennel, Sage, Rosemarie, Veruaine,
and Rue, of each one handful, these dystill in a Lymbecke.

A water recovering sight, in a manner lost, and the pynne and web: Take of
the garden Tasill, and of Yarrowe, of each one handful, of Celondine, of
Veruaine, of Rue, of Fenell, of the leaves of Euula Campana, of each one
handful, of Caphura half an ounce: these fresh gathered, stamp together,
and dystill in a Lymbecke.

An ointment or rather medicine for sore eyes, recovering the sight in a manner
lost and experienced: Take of Smalledge, of Fennel, of Rue, of Veruaine, of
herb Benedict or Hares foot, of Cudwoort, or Chasewoort, of Egrimonie, of
Germaunder, of Luminella, of Pympernell, of Strawberie leaves, and of Sage, of
each of these a like quantity, these steep together in a young chyldes urine,
adding to these, seven graynes or corns of Pepper, and a little white honey,
all which dystill in a Lymbecke: this borrowed out of Fumanellus.

A water of Sage, Fennel, read Roseleaues, Cellondine, and Rue, of each a
like, with a little of Veruaine, not so much of this herb, as of the others,
dystill a water, which if the same be dropped into the eyes both morning and
evening, it helps the weakness of an old sight: this Arnoldus.

Another water in the beginning of water descending, for the swelling of the
eye lyddes, and tears: Take of Assa one ounce, of pure white honey half a
pynte, of Fennel water, and Rue water, of each twelve drammes, of Maioram
water half an ounce, dystill in a Lymbecke, according to Art: this Fumanellus.

A water, or dystilled lycour unto the provoking of sleep, and it is a secret
worker of sleep: Take of Opium thebaicum, of Garlic heads pylled, of each
two ounces, the Garlic heads bette with a wooden Pestill in a Marble mortar,
adding thereto the Opium grynded, these well incorporate together, that it may
be like to a sauce: this dystill in a Retort, with a most soft or slow fire in
ashes: with this water when need shall require, annoint the temples, the
foreheade, and pulses of the wrestes: and beware you minister not, nor use
this, but upon a great necessity, as in the frantic persons, as you shall
think good.

A water of Fumanellus unto the provoking of sleep: Take of the juices of the
black and white Poppie, of each half a pynte, of the juices of the black and
white Henbane, of each two ounces, of the juice of Purselane, and of Lettuce,
of each three ounces, of the juice of Faba inuersa, half a pynte, of the
Nenuphar, three ounces, of the seeds of either Poppie, and of the roots of
Faba inuersa, of each two ounces, of the seeds of Darnell half a pound, of
the white and read Henbane three ounces, of Xyloaloes, and Nucis Methel, of
each one ounce and a half: of Purselane seeds, and Lettuce seeds, of each
one dram, of Scariola, one dram and a half, of Endive one ounce, these all
beaten together, put into a glass body for three days, which after dystill:
of this give one dram in either wine or water.

A water of Fumanellus procuring sleep, let the seeds of the Poppie and
Lettuce unto the weight of a pound, be bruised and steeped in wine for twenty
hours, adding to these a little of Opium, and after the dystilling, give one
dram of this water at the going to rest or sleep.

A water or sleeping lycour marvelous, being distilled: Take of
Diatragacanthum, two drammes, of Sumach half a dram, of the flowers Bedegnar,
three drammes, of the red Saunders half an ounce, of Psilium one dram, of
the rynde of the Mandrake root one ounce, of Henbane half an ounce, of the
black Poppie two ounces and a half, of the white Poppie half an ounce, of
the red Poppie so much, of Opium two drammes, of the Basil seeds one
dram and a half, of the roots of Alkakengi two drammes, of Camphora one
dram, of Dragons blood one ounce, of the seeds of the Hemlocke two
drammes, of the Adamant stone half a pound, of the Purselane seeds two
ounces, of Lettuce seeds two ounces, of Endyue seeds three ounces, of the
wine of Pomegranates half a wine pynte, of Plantaine seeds two ounces, of
the wine of Barberies half a pynte, of the garden Solanum one pound weight:
of all these dystill a water, which is marvelous: in that the same procures a
most strong and sound sleep, if at the lying down in bed, half an ounce
weight be ministered in a draught of good wine.

A water procuring sleep, borrowed out of Fumanellus: Take of black Pepper, of
the white Henbane, of the ryndes of the Mandrake root, of the seeds of
Lettuce, of Darnell, of the white and black Poppie, of each a like quantity:
and to these one dram of the juice of Lettuce, which after the stamping, let
so lie in the glass body for a day and a night, and being dystilled, minister
of this as above taught.

Another water: Take of the juice of the white Henbane, of the juice of the
leaves of the white and black Poppie, of the juice of the leaves of Mandrake,
or the juice of the Apples, of the juice of Iuie, and of the juice of the
Hemlocke, of each half a pynte, of the seeds of Lettuce, and seeds of the
Darnell, of each three ounces, these after the well grynding together, dystill
by a Lymbecke three times over, and in every dystilling grynde the fecies or
grounds, myxing them with the water dystilled: and in the third dystillation,
the water which then issues or comes forth, keep close stopped in a glass
with a narrow mouth: of this minister only two or three drops at a time.

A water for the washing of the head, borrowed out of the same Author: a
compounde (as they write) experienced, if so be the hinder part of the head be
bathed therewith, and that a decent diet be used before, which ought to be
applied at the going to bed, for xl. days together, and a grain of pure
Olibanum swallowed down withal, the form of the compounde is on this wise:
Take of the flowers of Rosemarie, of Borage flowers, of Buglosse flowers, of
the Roses, of the Violets, and of the herb Balm, of each one dram, of the
Camomill flowers two drammes, of Baye leaves, of Staechas, of Maioram, and
Sage, of each six drammes, these after the fine shredding, steep in pleasant
white wine for five days together: after dystill the whole according to Art,
which dystilled, keep close stopped with a narrow mouth, adding to it one
pound of Turpentine, of Masticke, Myrrh, and of the honey of Anacardus, of
each one ounce, of Olibanum two ounces: all these grynded and wrought
together, infuse for five days within the dystilled lycour: which again
dystilled, to this lycour add of Nutmegs, of Cloves, of Cubebae, of Cynamone,
of Mace, and Cardamomum, of each six drammes, of Lignum Aloes, eight drammes,
of Amber, and Musk, of each half a dram, all these grynded and myxte
