together, infuse for five days, which then begin to dystill with an easy
fire, and toward the end a stronger fire, the same keep to your use.

A water experienced for the whitening of the face, and making thynne the
skin, and clensing or taking away all spots of the face: Take of chosen
Turpentine dystilled, two pounds, of Olibanum three ounces, of Masticke half
an ounce, of the herb Dragons, so much, all these beaten together, and with
the Turpentine water myxte, dystill again, adding to it after new Barrowes
grease molten, one pound, of Cloves two drams, of Nutmegs three ounces, of
chosen Cynamone half an ounce, of Spica Celtica, as much, of Spikenarde two
drammes, of Caphura three drammes, of gold leaves one dram, of silver two
drammes, all these finely grynded and beaten together, dystill it in a
Lymbecke, after add twyse so much of this water, as of the water following,
and scouring the face before with the decoction of Branne, wash the face all
over with this water: Take of the water of Quickesiluer one ounce, of Borace,
of Aluminis Zucharini, of Ceruse washed, of each one dram, these myxe
together, and use as above taught: This borrowed out of Fumanellus.

A water for memory, safe, and to be marueyled at, if so be the pacient keep
and use a diet: Take of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of Ginger, of the three Peppers,
of each three dammes, of Juniper beries half an ounce, of saint John's worte,
of the ryndes of Cytrones, of Rosemarie flowers, of Basil, of Maioram, of
Mintes, of Pennyroyall, of Baye beries, of Catmyntes, of Spyke, of Xyloaloes,
of Cubebae, of Cardamomum, of Calamus aromatichus, of Staechas, of each one
dram and a half, of Acorus roots, one handful and a half, of Orga^^ie, of
Hysope, of Rue, of the herb Hares foot, both the Aristolochia, and either
Picnie, of Cassia lignea* of Pimpernell, of Dittanie, of Tormentill, of
Scabious, of the Woodebynde or Honey suckle, of the Amryse, of Cummin Seseleos,
and of garden Cresses, of each one scruple, of old Triacle one ounce, of Aqua
vitae rectified according to Art, and dystilled out of the best wine thryse
over, viij. pyntes, all these beaten and ^arced, keep together in a glass
body, which then according to Art four times, continuallye pouring the
lycour upon the fecies that remained: to this fourth dystillation, add of all
the Myrobalanes, and of Anacardus, of each two drammes and a half, these
finely brought to powder, and infused, dystill after the sixth day, beginning to
dystill with an easy fire, and within a while after increasing the fire
somewhat, the first that then comes, is weak as water, the next that
comes, is of a yelowishe color, the third and last through the fire
increased, comes forth yelower of color, to which then add both Musk and
Amber greece, and other fragrant powders: and using it twyce in the week, unto
the quantity of a spoonefull at a time, six hours before meat: that if you
shall annoint the seat or place of memory, and the temples, you shall soon
after call to mind and remember what you will: this borrowed out of Fumanellus.

A water for memory: Take of Bean flowers, of the Elder, and Camomill
flowers, of each two small handfuls, of Rue, of Balm, of Pympern^ll, of
Buglosse, of Lycoris clean scraped and bruised, of each three handfuls: these
dystill in a Lymbecke with a soft fire: of this water use twyse or thryse in a
week, unto the quantity of half, or one ounce at a time.

A water helping the frensynesse or madness, which is a precious secret, and
proved in the cure of madness, and the Melancholy frensinesse, borrowed out
of an ancient written book: Take of the flowers of Rosemarie, of Borage, and
of the roots of Buglosse, of each a like, of Saffron one dram, of the Quince
or Quinces four ounces, of the best white wine well digested, and clear, two
pyntes, these after the myxing, let so stand for a natural day, after bury
the glass body in horse dung for fifteen days, which drawn forth, dystill
according to Art, two or three times over: This water (says the Author)
keep as the apple of your eye, for it is very precious: in that I have (says
the Author) experienced the same in all Melancholy sickenesses, very
effectuously, and in the pain and trembling of the heart: the quantity to be
ministered at one time, is a dram.

Another whytening water, causing or procuring a white color: Take of the red Honey two pounds, of gum Arabeck two ounces, these diligently myxed
together, dystill according to Art in a glass body with a soft fire. The
first water which comes, serves unto the clearing and whytening of the face:
the second and third lycour together, procures yelowe hear.

An odoriferous water, not dystilled, out of Alexander Benedict. Allachalach,
as the Arabians write, and it is a certain compounde, of the juice of the
leaves of the Myrtels, of Rosewater and Saunders, and a little of vinegar, and
the water of Alkalef, or of the juice of the fruits well smelling, and of such
like lycour myxed, and put into a glass with a narrow mouth, and after the
well laboring of these myxed, shall a pleasant smell ascend to the nose,
comforting the head and spirits.

An odoriferous or fragrant water, yet in taste in a manner unsavory, but in
savor and smell excellent, and a drop rubbed on the end of the nose,
seems to be as a procurer of sleep in a manner: out of Georg. Sighart: Take
Assa dulcis, and of Styrax calaminta, of each one ounce, of Lignum aloes, half
an ounce, of Cloves, of the cytrine Saunders, and of the ryndes of the Cytrone,
of each three drammes, these beaten and labored diligently together, infuse in
Rosewater unto the quantity of.xxiiij. ounces for eight days, which after
dystill in Balneo Mariae, the same dystilled, keep close stopped in a narrow
mouth glasie, in which hang of Musk and Amber greece, of each half a dram,
tied up in a fine lynnen cloth: of this use, to procure a sweet smell where
ever you walk.

A most proved water for the falling sickness: Take of the roots of the
flower de Luce, or Ireos, of Smalledge, of Fennel, of Perselie, of Sperage, of
Butchers broom roots, and of Hops, of each two handful, of Maiden hear, of
Hearts tongue, and the flowers of Tamariscus, of each one handful, of Fennel
seeds, Annise seeds, and Carroway seeds, of each three drams, all these well
beaten together, dystill in a glass body after Art: of this water minister
or use every morning, unto the quantity of two ounces at a time.

For the falling sickness, let the pacient drink a certain dystilled water
of the flowers of the Lynde tree, of the lesser Nettle, and Cherie tree leaves
or flowers: A certain woman molested with the falling sickness, by drincking
sundry times this water, recovered health.

A pectorall water, or water for the breast, of great strength and virtue, that
especially avails in the weakness of the stomach, through clammie and
rotten humors, in that this softeneth, and helps digestion, and opens
withal, and is also cordial: Take of Figs, of Reysins, of the Pynaple
kirnels, and Almondes, of each four ounces, of Coliander, and Annis seeds, of
each two ounces, of common Honey one pound, these myxed together, pour into
twenty pintes of common water, letting the whole boil together unto the
consumption of six pynts, and that xiiij. remain, after strain the lycour
through a lynnen clothe, and then have you the water: to this add of our
Quintessence, four ounces, and keep to your use in a glass: and this is the
pectorall water, exceeding by his worthynesse the virtues of all other
pectorall waters hitherto invented of any: this out of the secret conclusions
of Leonar. Fiorauantus.

A dystilled water helping the Dropsy, of which let the pacient take fasting
every morning, unto the quantity of four ounces at a time, and if he will
with wine: Take of the roots of Ireos, or flower de Luce, of Fennel, of
Perselie, of Smalledge, of Sperage, of Butchers broom roots, and of Hoppes,

A water perfitely healing the Dropsy, by washing and rubbing the belly twyse
a day therewith, and applying a plaster both on the Pulses and Arters, made
of Bay beries, so that the body be purged before: The water is made on this
wise, take of Cinamone, of Cloves, of the three Peppers, of Xyloaloes, of
Spikenarde, of Opobalsamum, of Galingale, of Calamus aromaticus, of Cubebae, of
Saffron, of each brought to powder one ounce, of Turpentine four ounces,
dystill according to Art: the first which comes forth, throw away: and the
second lycour that dystilleth forth, keep to your use: for the applying of
this above taught, both deliver and cleanse all the parts and veins from
filling any more.

Of a water, dystilled by a Lymbecke, of the matters herevnder described, and
druncke for a year, unto the quantity of a spoonefull, both morning and
evening* each day with four spoo^^fuls of wine, and the powder (described in
the second place) strawed upon the meats, does dissolve any stone, yea,
hardened, being either in the kidneyes or bladder: It also cease the pain of
the bowels, and cures the diseases of a cold cause: The preparing of it, is
on this wise: Take of Fennel roots, of Persely roots, Butchers broom
roots, and Radishe roots, of each one dram and a half: all these
diligently stamped, and stieped in the mightiest wine, dystill according to
Art, to which dystilled lycour add then of the powder of Cynamone half an
ounce, of Galingale, of Amber, of Ginger, and of Catmynt, of each one dram
and two scruples, of Macropiperis, one dram, of Cloves two drammes and a
half, of Cummin one dram, of Ameos, and of Louage, of each two drammes, of
Spikenarde, of Cassia lignea, and of Masticke, of each two drammes and a
half, which again dystilled, add thereunto of Cynamone, of Cloves, of
Spikenarde, of Ginger, of long* Pepper, of Xyloaloes, of Mace, of Galingale, of
Zedoaria, and Lycoris, of each seven drammes, and ten graynes weight: these
together myxed in the form of a sauce, dystill over again in a cucurbite:
which use as above taught: this borrowed out of Fumanellus.

A water breaking the stone in the bladder and kidneys: Take of the juice of
Saxifrage two pyntes, of Grummell, and of the juice of Perselie, of each one
pynte, of the best vinegar of a pleasant wine, eight ounces, these altogether
dystilled, let the lyc^ur be kept in a glass with a narrow mouth, of which
minister in the morning one ounce at a time, the like quantity at noone, and
at evening before the going to bed: for this is a proved water, as writes
Fumanellus.

A marvelous and rare water, causing the pacient to pysse forth sand, and
clensing the kidneyes of the same: borrowed out of Leonar. Fiorauantus. The
which sand in man procures a much and great heat and drythe of the kidneyes,
and such do pysse with an extreme diff^cultie, and burning in the coming
forth of the urine: in so much that such cannot abide many garments on, but
rather desire to go thinly and coldly, specia^ly on their back. And for that
cause any minding to cure such a gri^fe and disease, ought to minister and use
those matters, which both cool, moysten, and take away or abate heat: like as
this remedy following does, both with great facility, and in a short time.
The making of which is on this wise: Take of the seeds of the lesser Lemmons,
and of Orenges, of each one pound, of Saxifrage six pounds, of Balm, of
Hearts tongue, of the herb Vitriolum growing on old walls, of Sperage, of sea
Holy, of Ysope, of the roots of Fennel, and of Perselie, of each vj. ounces,
of the juice of small Lemmons so much as shall suffice, to labor and
incorporate the whole substance together in the form of a liquide paste or
very soft ointment: let this substance be distilled in a Tin Lymbecke, which is
diligently closed in the edges round about, until all the substance of
moisture be drawn, which after keep in a glass close stopped: But this
learn, that when you mind to minister and use of this water, that the body
before be thoroughly purged of the crude and clammy humors, and like the stomach
purged both of fleume and choler, which thus prepared, let the pacient take of
this water warm, both morning and evening, unto the quantity of six ounces at
a time: and in the mean time, to use a diet, in abstayning or refrayning from
cold and moist meats, and to eat the dry. And this in such a case and
disease, is a most proved remedy, often experienced of the Author.

A Tri^cle water of the same man's description: Take of old Triacle one pound,
of Sorrel three handfulles, of Camomill flowers, of Penny Royal, of the long
or great grass, and of the blessed Thystell, of each two handful, these
steeped in white wine, dystill after Art: this keep in a glass with a
narrow mouth: let the pacient take two ounces of the same water, with three
ounces of Sorrel water and Buglosse, when he goes to bed, or enters into
the bathe or hot house: This water cures the pains of the French disease, if
the same be ministered alone, or with the decoction of Grummell or the great
Burre: I (says the Author) by happy success have cured many children, and
old persons with this potion, or by sometimes adding certain drops to the
common decoction of Guaicum, so that through the thinness of parts, does this
water soon penetrate, and send forth the matter. This water also, with the
water of the extinction of gold myxed, does correct and amend all manner of
defaultes, of the Quicksiluer.

A Triacle water helping the falling sickness, of the same Authors invention:
Take of old Triacle four ounces, of Methridate two ounces, of the

sinews.

A Triacle water of Iacobus Siluius, which he used in the French disease: take
of the rasped wood Guaicum half a pound, of Spring or Conduite water viij.
pyntes, of the white wine not pleasant two pyntes, of the waters of

together for a night on hot ashes or ymbers, to which after add of the
Polipodie of the Oak half a pound, of the flower of Time two ounces, of
Sperage six ounces, of the Conserve of Roses, Succorie, Borage, and Buglosse,
of each four ounces, of the best Triacle two ounces, of the conserve of
Helycampane two ounces: these well closed in a glass body, dystill in a
double vessel: The quantity to be ministered at one time, is from two unto
three ounces: and you may (if you will) add to three ounces of the Triacle
water, one ounce of Sugar, and a dram of Cynamone, and let the same dystill
again through an Ipocras bag, for so the taste of it shall be the pleasanter
in the drincking: let be given in bed in the morning, to procure a strong
sweat.

Eight waters of S. Aegidius, helping the falling sickness new come, the
Palsy, wounds and Agues: Take of Isope, Penny Royal, Hares foot, of Succorie,
of each a like, these stamped in a mortar, and dystilled, keep in a glass
with a narrow mouth: After take of Rue, of Perselie, of Zedoaria, of Aloes, or
the stone Calaminaris, of each a like quantity or dram, these beaten
together, boil in the foresaid water unto a consumption of the third part, the
same after strain through a linen cloth, keeping it the^ close stopped: and
after the standing and setting of it. xl. days, let the pacient drink of
this lycour every morning fasting, for ten days together, being molested with
any of the abouesayde sickenesses or diseases, yea, if he happen to have the
Plague, but then let him refrain meat for six hours after the taking of this
drink: This lycour also druncke with a fasting stomach, does preserve the
person from the falling sickness and Palsy, for this exceedingly comfort
the members: If this besides be druncke fasting with Castorie, these
sickenesses being but new begun, it is a special remedy: It singularly
avails, in the healing of wounds, and the cutting of veins and sinews, if
those be washed with it: It cures besides all manner of Agues, being drunck
with a fasting stomach for nine mornings together.

The second water of the Philosophers: Take of Rue, of Egrimonie, of the
Satyrion, of Celondine, of Sugar, of the stone Calaminaris (otherwise Tutia) of
each a like quantity, these beaten together, dystill in a Lymbecke with a soft
fire: This water is very precious, in that it heals any grief or disease of
the eyes: This used or taken with meats, or otherwise in potions before meat,
and with a fasting stomach avails against all poisons, in casting it up by
vomiting: and druncke fasting, cures the Dropsy, and cleanses the stomach of
all putrified and cold humors, it extinguisheth the creeping influmation
called Saint Anthonies fire in a day, if playsters of Towe be applied upon,
being wette in this water: It cures the Canker, being myxt with Aloes, and
that a plaster of the towe of Hemp wette in it, be applied upon twyse in the
day.

strong vinegar, which let so stand close stopped for certain days, after
dystill the whole in a Cucurbite after Art: the water which then comes
forth, breaks both the red and white stone, being either rough, plain, or
sharp: But if the stone shall be broken, then let the pacient drink of this
water with a fasting stomach, and he shall then piss the sand forth. And
washing any scabbed parts with this water, does speedily heal the scabbes,
and causes hear to grow in the bare places: It cures also all manner of
scabbes of the body, by washing all the places of the body with this water,
for three or four days together: and druncke fasting in the morning,
ingendreth good blood in the body: It delivers the Palsy, by drincking of
it twyse in the day with Castoreum or Castorie, unless the sickness shall
be confirmed: This also heals the Apoplexy and falling sickness.

The fourth water: Take of young Swallows brought to powder, to which add
Castoreum or Castorie, myxing a quantity of vinegar withal, these distill in
a Cucurbite: The water drunck, avails against the falling sickness: If he
be a young person of xiiij. years of age taken with the sickness, if he shall
drink of this water fasting for forty days, shall throughlye be cured: It
also helps the Cough, and the straitenesse of the breast, or fetching of
breath, by drincking of it fasting nine mornings together: It comfort and
amendeth the brain, it purges the stomach, it inlargeth the breast, and
takes away the cause procuring the Palsy, it increases sperme, and heateth
the cold persons: and druncke fasting with Isope, heals the Dropsy of a
cold cause, and the Quotidian or daily Ague: But every woman with child must
refrain (that season) from the drincking of this wat^r, in that the same
slays the child. This also druncke with Isope, helps the diseases of the
head, and procures an appetyte, purchas^th sleep, helps digestion, and
sends forth the urine.

The fifth water: Take of Isope, of Gladen, of Sauin, of Sothernwood, of each
alyke, of the^e make a pa^te, letting it so stand impasted together for
certain days, which dystill according to Art: for this is a singular water,
and of a great virtue: It avails against all manner of Agues, as well hot as
cold: It provoke women's terms, and for that cause women with child ought to
refrain the taking of this water, for doubt and fear of loosing the yongling:
The water druncke, stays the bloody flux, or the perilous flux of blood
named Dysenteria, and is a singular remedy also against any manner of flux of
the belly: It purges the stomach of evil humors, and stays the worms in
the body: Druncke with Castoreum, helps the Palsy, ministered or taken warm
every morning.

The sixth water of the Philosophers, is made of a Moule, which serves unto the
dying or coloring of hears white, either of man or beast: Take a Moule, which
artely brought to powder with Brimstone, add to it the juice of Celondine,
which orderly myxed, let so stand for certain days, after dystill the whole
according to Art: The virtue of this water, is on such wise, that if a beast
wholly black of hear, shall be washed all over with this water, the hears
shall in short time become so white as snow: Also if to this water be wax and
Aloes myxed, and annoynting the Palsy member therewith, it cures the same in
short time: It heals besides the disease named Noli me tangere, if this be
applied plaisterwise upon: it amendeth the weakness of the head: Further this
water commixed with the stone named Calaminaris, and Aloes, heals the disease
named the Wolf, if the same be applied plaster wise twyse a day, or only
washed twyse a day with the same water: but beware that this lycour enter not,
and especially that you use it not within the body.

The seventh water, which is named the water of conservation or preserving:
Take Persely, which after the well beating in a mortar, dystill according to
Art: who that drincketh of this water, not having an appetyte to meat, with a
fasting stomach, does not only amend all wyndynesse and rawnesse of the
stomach, but procures digestion: it purges also the breast of superfluous
humors.

The eight water is named the condupliciue or doubled: Take of Smalledge
seeds, of the oil of Poppie, of white Sugar, and of Cloves, of each alyke,
these labored together in a Mortar, add to the whole the above said water of
preserving, and mixed diligently together, dystill these in a glass body after
Art: This water drunck cold in the morning fasting, and warm at the going to
bed, does marvelously help the Cough, and griefs or pains of the breast:
This water also druncke warm with Castorie, avails in all the diseases of
the spleen, and tremblings of the members, yea, and comfort both the head
and brain: These eight waters did the Author translate out of the Germayne
into the Latin tongue, written first by that godly man Aegidius. And a ninth
water, affirms the Author there was, which for that the description of the
same was imperfect, for that cause he left it, as unmentioned in this place.

Of the compounde waters, which are named Elixir, of which some also extend
unto Baulmes: and may like be applied, as shall after appear. The.Lxxxvij.
Chapter.
A Marvelous Elixir once made and experienced, by the singular le^rned John
^^ntiume, in that the same marvelously nourishes and restores, yea,
comfort the sinewie members, and the sinews themselves, as both the
stomach and the heart: besides it purges the stomach, increases memory
resolves windiness, and procures an appetite: The dose or quantity to be
used, at one time is so much as one dram weight. The person which shall have
a hot stomach, let him use this with the water of Endive, especially in the
hot season: But ye person which has a cold stomach, and that in a cold
season, let the pacient then use or take it with Baulme or Wormewoode water, or
such a like lycours: The making of it, is on this wise: take of Rosemarie, and
of Mints, of each half an ounce* of Cinamone one ounce, of the juice of
Licorise, and Lycorise scraped, of each, one ounce and a half, of chosen
Reubarbe one ounce and a half, of Spike three scruples, of Saffron one
scruple, of Cloves, of Mace, of Nutmegs, and of Galingale, of each one dram,
of chosen Manna, and oil of Turpentine, of each two ounces, of Tartare one
ounce and a half, of the pulpe or tender flesh of a Capon, half a pound
weight, of the pulpe of Partriches, one pound, of Diarrhodon abbatis, three
ounces, of the Fisticke nuttes, named otherwise Pistace^, of Iourdane Almondes,
and of the Pyn^ ^pple kirnel^, of each eight ounces, of Oats, of Reysins, and
of Pennites o^ Sugar, of each six ounces, of Musk, and of Amber, of each
half a scruple: all these beaten together, and infused in the best Aqua vitae
for three days, and dystilled after in a glass body: the water of life which
then is dystilled, will be clear and pure: If the dystillation, or rather the
infusion shall be done in Malmesie, i^ shall or will be much better. This
borrowed out of an Italian work written.

A secret water: Take of Malmesey, pure and good, into which put your flowers,
herbs, and spices, and what things besides you please: that let so stand
infused, for three or four days in a glass body close luted, to putryfie:
after dystill the whole with a most slow and easy fire, and make no
separation until the end: then separate or draw away the waters, and cease,
least the waters styncke, and the spyces burn. In that water drawn, dissolve
Sugar, adding after of Musk, Amber, and Cinnamon, and if you will have your
water very delectable or pleasant: the^^ take of Sugar Candy, pouring upon it
the best Aqua vitae, and the same dystill from the Sugar, until the spirits
and fumes ascend: pour the other water in the abouesayde glass body, in
which will three or four Aromaticall read drops fall: and such a dystillation
also shall be repeated with Sugar Candy, as before, and the same so often
repeated over, shall marueylouslye work, being especially mixed with gold, as
you may like co^ceyue: and you shall then have gold dissolved, or potable
gold, that is both marvelous and very effectuous, and sweetest. And if you be
minded to have pure gold, then lay a dead head in a moist place, and you
shall purchase and possess a marvelous Art: And this abouesayde manner, does
excel the others, as reason the like instructs: which the Author here will
not reveal, for causes that he knows.

A golden water, or Elixir vitae: Take of Sage three quarters of a handful, of
Nutmegs, of Mace, of Gynger, of graynes of Paradyse, of Cloves, and of
Cynamone, of each two drammes, of Reubarbe, of Castoree, and of Spikenarde, of
each half an ounce, of oil of Bays Artely drawn, two ounces, these
diligently beaten and mixed together, infuse in six measures of good wine,
close covered in a glass body for a month, at the end of which time, let
the wine be strayned, and the spyces or drugges again beaten very fine, until
the whole be like a thick broth or lycour, upon which, pour then the
abouesayde wine, letting the whole stand for other three days covered, which
after dystill by a Limbecke: The water which comes forth, will be so clear
as Crystal, the same keep in a glass body with a narrow mouth, being
close stopped, which apply to these griefs and sickenesses ensuing: If you
sprynckle Fyshes, Birds, Fowls, Venison, and such like, with this water, they
shall not putrify, so long as you be minded reasonablye to keep them. Wine of
a sower and straung savor, and decayed, is made pleasant and perfect, if you
pour a little of this water ^n it. This water druncke, or applied upon,
heals inward impostumes, it comfort the vowels, and helps the Cholick:
it heals wounds, if a lynnen cloth wette in this water be applied on the
wound: It defends the falling sickness beginning to come or grow on any,
being drunck, or applied on the brain: it cures the grief^s and sores of the
mouth and Jaws, and amendeth the evil savor or styncke of breath, through the
rottenness of the gummes, and the stinck also of the nosthrils and ears: If
this be druncke of men, ^t preserves their strength, and corrects
fearfulness, by drying up the moystures in body: It corrects and cleanses
the spots of the eyes, and amendeth also the defaults of the body: This out
of an unknown Author in the German tongue.

Another named a Golden water, of a most singular virtue: Take of Sage leaves
two ounces, of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of Zedoaria, and of the gra^nes of
Paradise, of each half an ounce, of Cinnamon one ounce, of Lauander four
ounces, of good wine one gallon. Let all these be close covered in a glasen
vessel for xiiij. days, after the wine strayned, let the spyces be well
beaten, and mixed again with the wine, which dystill in a Limbeck in sand, or
in Balneo Mariae: This water does provoke appetite, comfort and
strengthens the stomach, corrects the diseases of the lunges, and amendeth
the griefs of the spleen, and all the inner parts: it is a defender of all
poisons, it clears the blood, it amendeth and takes away the evil savor
of breath, and the stinking air coming out of the nose, caused through a
piece of flesh grown in the ouermost part of the nose within, also Rheu^res,
the cough, straitenesse of the breast, the difficulty of breathing, comfort
the brain* and memory, sharpeneth the sight, heals all manner of griefs of
the eyes, and is a singular medicine to them which are sore whipped, wounded,
or fallen from a high place: it dissolueth and puts away impostumes, it
asswageth and helps both the Gout and falling sickness, it cleanses and
heals the foul sourfe, Ringwormes, and the Leprie* and in the Crampe an
uttermost refuge, and singular help. If this be myxed with corrupt wynes, it
rectifieth the taste and savor of the wine: it preserves old men, such as be
comely or beautiful, and well colored.

The Elixir vitae, of the description of Fiorauantus, that aydeth the virtue
and property of all medicines, if a little quantity be mixed with them. And
this rather to be counted a divine, than a human secret: the making of which
precious and rare lycour is on this wise: Take of Cloves, of Nutmegs, of
Zedoaria, of Ginger, of Galingale, of the white and black Pepper, of Juniper
berries, of the ryndes of the Cytrone, of the ryndes of Orenges, of Sage, of
Ba^ill, of Rosemarie, of Myntes, of Maioram, of Bay beries, of Penny royal,
of Gentian, of Calamint, of the Elder flowers, of the white and red Rose
leaves, of the Spikenarde, of Cubebae, of the Aloes Hepaticke, of Lignum Aloe,
of Cardamomum, of Cynamone, of Calamus Aromaticus, of Stichas, of Germaunder,
of Camepithis, otherwise bitter sweet, Baulme, Mace, Olibanum, the seeds of
Motherwoort, the seeds of Maioram, of each two drammes, of Fygges, of Reysins
of the Sun, of Dates, of Almondes, of Pyne apple kirnels, of each six
ounces, of white Honey one pound, of Le^ant Musk one dram, of fine Sugar
four pounds, all these myxed, beat and labor diligently together, so that
those which may be stamped, beat^ in a gr^sse manner, and the whole then infuse
in xv. pynts of Aqua vitae drawn of good wine, and dystilled before thryse
over, put up, and close c^^^red in a glass body with a head, which le^ so
stand for te^^^ days at the least: after being diligently luted in the
neck, set the body to dystill so long in Balneo Mariae, until the feces
remain dry: then draw away the Receyuer, pouring the water after into a
Peltirane, which set in hot horse dung to circulate for two whole Months:
and being thus circulated, you have obtained your prepared and glorious Elixir,
which contains so great and strange virtues in it: After take the body in
which the feces be contained, and dystill them in ashes with a most strong
fire, for then shall come forth a licour so red as blood, which will
somewhat savor of smoke, and be troubled, the same also circulate in like
order, as above taught: for this is of a fiery substance, which may (through
his virtue) raise as it were the dead: and being thus circulated, stop
diligently the mouth of the glass, keeping it to your use: As touching the
virtues of this Elixir, in standing upon the rehearsal of all, would seem
over long, in that it helps and recouereth all manner of sicknesses and
diseases: notwithstanding shall here be uttered certain particular remedies
and helps with brevity: Now the first water dystilled by Balneo Mariae,
druncke unto the quantity of a dram every third day, preserves the body
in most happy estate, and defends it from many kinds of sickenesses and
diseases: It heals any kind of wound, by applying clothes wette in it,
within twice or thrice dressing, at the most: and both marvelously and
speedily heals all manner of griefs of the eyes, by letting fall o^e drop at a
time, and preserves also the sight a long time, in such sort, that such
persons shall not need a pair of spectacles: and (...) a woman often bath or
wash her face and breast* with this water, it preserves her long in one state,
insomuch that she shall not appear aged of a long time. Taking the Elixi^ by*
the mouth, moves and procures a veuer^ all ^ppetite, (...) disposes b^rr^^
women to conceive lightly with child, as h^th the^e exper^e^ced, and avails
in all matters* as by proof (who that lyfteth to try) shall further
understand, and know of the truth of these. This later water having a red
color as blou^^^ (...) of women by the mouth unto the^ ^^^^titie of two
drammes at a time, helps the pains of the m^tr^ce* and dissolueth the
stitches of the sides and Pleurisies, and cures the Cholicke passions by
anointing upon the grieved places, and the like helps the hardness of the
Mylt, the pain and grief of the teeth, the evil savor and stincke of
breath, and sundry others like: It takes away and heals any kind of Ague,
in that this sends forth and puts away all the evil humors which hinder
nature, so well without as within the body: and through the same apt to heal
any kind of disease or sickness: If any pacient or sick person has so
lost his speech, that he cannot utter his words in the hearing to the
Minister, nor confirm his testament or will, then minister one dram of the
first, with one dram of the second water, which entered and gone down the
throat, causes the pacient miraculouslye to recover speech, and to talk his
mind after until the panges of death, with good remembrance: and this the
Author experienced above a thousand times, in working miraculously by it, to
his great praise and report, and satisfying of the standers and lookers on:
wherefore the Author wills all persons of ability, to be never unprovided,
or without this precious lycour, both for their own healthes, and for their
neighbors, when need shall require.

A marvelous water, which is named the mother of Baulme, whose properties are
infinite and marvelous, and procures a marvelous working in Fistulaes: Take
of Turpentine one ounce, of Olibanum two ounces, of Aloes succotryne, of
Masticke, of Cloves, of Galingale, of Cynamone, of Saffron, of Nutmegges, and
Cubebae, of each one ounce, of Gum Iuie five ounces: all these finely brought
to powder, and close luted with the lute of wisdom in a glass body, distill
with a soft ^^^e: The f^es^ water which comes forth, will be white and
clear: the same continue so long with fire, until the water begins to
appear yelowe and thick, then take away the receyuer, and purchase the
second water, which will be yelow, thick, and swymme above the first water:
when that yelowe color is higher tincted, then remove the second water, in
that the third comes, which in color is as the clear Honey, and named
properly a Balm, and has the like effects and properties to it: If you shall
let fall a drop of it, from a knyues point into a cup glass of water, the
same will keep together, even like a true Baulme, in the bottom of the
glass, which after it has stand for an hour, will flote above the water,
not breaking a sunder: This also burns, further, it courdeth milk, for if
one drop of it warm fall into a pynte of milk, it forthwith thickeneth and
courdeth the same, even like the Baulme: The first water is named a Baulme*
which cures the Fistula, the sound and noise of the ears, if you shall drop
two or three drops of the same into the ear in the morning. The second
water is named the oil of Baulme, which cures the eyes lacking the hears of
the eye lyddes, the Leprosy and the running of the eyes, and that suddenly, if
so be you wash the eyes mourning and evening with it: The third licour is
named the Artificial Baulme oil, which in a manner possesses the like
properties, that the natural has: for this cures and expels all worms,
the scabbe, and superfluousnesse, in what part of man's body the same shall
happen: the like all impostumes, and all ulcers newly happening, and any
swelling of the eyes, if you shall bathe or wash them with the same: It is
also more driving back of cold humors, than any other medicine: it cures,
restrayneth, and slays any pain of the teeth, proceeding either of the
worm, or of humors, if so be you wash them with it. And it singularly
avails in all cold poisons, as of the Tode, the Spyder, the Adder, and
Scorpion, nor it is possible that they may harm a man, if he be either stinged
or poisoned of any of them, so that the pacient apply upon the place one
drop warm of it. All ulcers how deep soever they be, whether in the flesh,
or in the sinews and bone, and matterie impostumes, if you shall wash them
with it, without any tent applied, it cures them within nine days, how
hideous soever, or loathsome, canckred, or Fistulated they shall be, yes Noli me
tangere, and Aegidius disease: It has also marvelous effects, in the
sweeting of metalline bodies. If you wash any cold gowte with it, and shall
apply playsterwyse with a linen cloth wette in it on the grieved place, it
speedily asswageth and cures the same: it puts away, dries up, and
heals the strokes or cuttes happening through a stone, or fall, causing a
wound in the place, by applying a lynnen cloth wette in it, and both stays,
comfort, and strengthens the sinews: and conceive that it is the hottest
above any degree, and no substance can be found hotter then it, and it is
also of such a penetration and hotnesse, that if you let fall one drop warm
on the paulme of the hand, it forthwith pearceth without harm, that you shall
not feel it. It cures and heals the swelling of the feet, the legs, and
also the grief or pain of the joints, applied thereon, it helps any cold
coming of a cold cause, or of corrupt blood. This liquour also is named the
mother of Baulme, which if you will prove the same, take a Pullet plucked
bare, and clean drawn within, or the guts taken out, after heat him so
long, until you can hardly abide the holding of him in your hand, which then
annoint with the said oil, and lay after in the sun for two hours to dry,
which through dry annoint again with the said oil, letting it dry in: after
put or lay the pullet where you will, for he shall never after putrifye, and it
has besides many other properties of the like kind and order: this borrowed
out of Bertapalia.

A water or noble oil, of a diverse and sundry properties unto many grieffes
and disseases, as unto the recouerye of sight, and memory. It also
strengthens any member anointed with it, and digesteth the flewme harming the
stomach, and strengthens it, mynistred unto the quantity of a sponeful at a
time: and in what manner also it be taken every day fasting, the same defends
the person from any byt of venomous beast, and applied on the byt of any
venomous beast, spedily delivers and cures the poisoning: anointed on any
foul scabbes, it spedilye heals them, and slays worms of the body:
dropped into the ears, takes away the hard and flow hearing, helps the
running or watering of the eyes, and all dullness of sight: and drunck it,
delyuereth the swellings of the inner members, and the teeth by washing: and
if both ulcer and canker be anointed with it eueryday, they are spedily cured:
and in the like manner, the resolution of the synewes: it cures besides the
swellings of the legs, or any sickness proceeding of a cold cause. The
Aucthour (to make this:) took of Turpentine, half a pound, of burning water
two pints, of Xyloaloes, of the citryne and read Saunders, of chosen Cinnamon,
of Cubebae, of Galingale, of Nutmegs, of Cardamomu^, of Saffron, of
Frankincense, of Mace, of Mastick, of Ginger, of Spiknard, of cloves, of each
three ounces, of gum Arabicke, one ounce, of Musk one dra^, of Amber greece so
much, all these he did beat apart, and finely searsed them, which after he had
infused the^ together in Aqua vitae or burning water for a day in a glass
body, he then distilled ye whole with a very soft and slow fire, until the
water distylling come forth clear, and when it changed color, he set under
another Receauer, and so kept either by it self: This Fumanellus.

An Elixir, or compound water of Life, which shall be applied unto the Baulmes.
The.lxxxviij. Chapter.
TAke of Cloves, of Nutmegs, of Gynger, of Galingale, of long Pepper, of black

Cynamon, of Calamus aromaticus, of Sage, of Basil, of Gentiane, of Catminte,

yuorie, of Germander, of Chamepithis or bitter sweet, of Nelligetta, of

Ruberbe an ounce and a half, and of oil of Turpentine one pound; all these
above noted, well beaten and brought to powder, and let each be gotten and put
up in his proper time (in beginning from the Spring, and continuing the Summer)

Glass body, and not in a Copper vessel, and in that the flowers and herbs
gathered in their special times infused, and close stopped in a glass body,
with the head dilygently luted on. The Aqua vitae in which the abouesayd spyces
shall be infused, must be unto the quantity of twenty and six pyntes. If you
shall divide the water into three bodies, and like the spyces and other
matters: you shall then distyll safer in those three several times, then in
one body, and at one time alone. And set your body with his head on, in
Balneo Mariae, having a soft fire under. The first which comes, will be the
Elixir or jewel of Life, the same keep alone close stopped in a Glass, that
it breathe not forth. The next water which comes, will be grosser, serving
unto far sympter uses. And the Feces remaining in the glass body, be
compared to Triacle, and serve for the poor, and many sycknesses.

A most laudable water, containing in it the virtues of a baulme, necessary
and helping many sicknesses, borrowed out of Fumanellus. The water which
follows and yields the propertyes of a baulme, procures mirth and
gladness, comforts the brain, and druncke, breaks and cleanses the
rotten and mattery impostumes within the body, puts away the redness and
spots of the eyes, cures the Fistula, and the Cankar applied upon, by

the palsy this cures by applying and anointing the grieved places, which
especially proceeds of a cold cause: the quantity also of a sponefull, drunck
with a cup full of wine fasting, does as it were stay back old age, and
mayntayneth health, and puts away the pymples* waterye whelkes, and other
spots of the face by annoynting upon, yea the high redness of the face
being deformable, and all other foul blemishes happening on the face: it takes
away the pain of the teeth, and the wyndye beating of the ears, being
orderlye applied* the s^incke either of the swelling in the nosethrelles, or
swelling of the gummes, and any manner of swelling of the throat, this breaks
and cleanses: it helps the Melancholicke, the persons molested with ache of
the hyppes, and gout: it cures the dropsy, and pain of the great gutte
proceeding of a cold cause: and anointed about the garland seame, takes away
all manner of pain and ache of the head, coming of a cold cause: and slays
worms in the body, by taking unto the quantytie of half a dram at a time, and
in the same manner does it avail against poison. Many things else he promised,
which are by him thus written: the making of which is on this wise: take of
Masticke, of Cloves, of Nutmegs, of the lesser Cardamomum, of Cubebae, of long
Pepper, of Cynamon, of Galingale, of Ginger, of Lignum aloe, of the great
Cardamomum, of each half an ounce, of Spiknard three drams, of Mace one dram,
of Caphura one dram and a half, of the Iundiane nutte, half a dra^: of a
pleasant and clear white wine, so much as shall suffice to infuse thoroughly
the whole, which after the dilygent, beating and myxing together, distyll with
^ soft and flow fire according to art.

The spyces serving for the distylled Malmesie, in the place to be used of
potable Gold: take of the best Malmesie six measures, which put in a glass
body, distyll with a slow or soft fire in sifted ashes, seven times over, but
after the opinion of the best distyllers, three times over will be sufficient
to be druncke; as affyrmeth Fumanellus. Into the Aqua vitae thus well
rectifyed, infuse these matters following: take of Spermaceti, of chosen Ambre,
and of the best Ruberbe, of each two drams, of very fine and well chosen Musk
one dram, or more: these after the distyllyng and running through a fine
ypocrase bag, made of pure Hob land, and white washed, put up the lycour
into a glass with a narrow mouth, which close stop that no air breathe
forth, for this after the settling, will become and appear of a golden color.
You may put in a little of the inner part of the Cynamon, in the running
through, which will cause the water to taste the pleasaunter. The virtues of
this water are these; it first cures and expels poisons. And to preserve
the body fro^^ having the plague or pestilence, let the person take a drop
of it fasting in the morning, with a little toste of white bread, not to dry
tosted: but purge the body before with some easy purgation, and be let
blood^. And the person infected, give to the quantitye of a great hasyll nutte
shell full of it, with a toste of white bread, which (by the receiving)
delyuereth the pacient. But I (says the Aucthour) always did give of it with
preseruatyue medicynes, and myxed it besides with Cordial medycines and
Electuaries, for the better digesting and comforting of weak persons. And in
this distyllacion (says the Aucthour) I found, and practiced many good helps.
This borrowed out of a written work.

A syngular compound water of spyces, having great virtue, in that the same
helps all cold grieffes of the stomach: borrowed out of the secret
conclusions of Leonar, Fiorauantus, the famous Gretian* This water of Life
(says he) is only aromatizated with the Leuaunt spyces, which is glorious and
woonderful in his working, as ^y reason and practyse shall playner appear,
which is made and distylled on this wise: Take of Nutmegs, of Cloves, of
Galingale, of Cardamomum, of Cubebae, of Mace, of Cynamon, of Gynger, of
Saffron, of Frankensence or rather Olibanum, of each one ounce, these myxed and
grossly beaten together, and having a glass body well luted, put in your
spices, pouring upon six pynts of the best Aqua vitae distylled thryse, or at
the least twyse over, which let so stand for six days: after the closing of
the Receauer, to the nose of the head, distyl the whole in fine sifted ashes,
the water being come forth will be of a red color, which is more precious than
any other water: the same helps all grieffes or sicknesses proceeding of a
cold cause, and cleanses any manner of wound or sore. This also heals all
cuttes and wounds, without causing any pain to the pacient, it procures a
ready memory, it heals the cough of a cold cause, it makes or disposes
the person to mirth, and works many other great matters besides, which were
over long and tedious to utter them one by one: therefore does the Aucthour
here ouerpasse them, wyshing all men to practice and learn further proofs of
the virtues of this precious water.

The making of a myraculous and divine lycour, which causes rare and
wonderful works, in that the same raised in a manner the dead unto life, by
giving a drop or two into the mouth, with either syrup, wine, or broth, or
any other lycour: The making of which is on this wise, take healthful blood of
a young man drawn by vain, the sperme of a whale, and the marow of a Bull, of
each one pound, of Musk one ounce, of the ashes of ye bones of Olives burned
two ounces, of fine Aqua vitae two pynts, these after ye dyligent mixing
together, distyl according to art in a Retorte, until the whole liquide
substance become forth: this the^ come forth distill again in Balneo Mariae
thrice over, leuing ye Feces at the end: this keep in a glass closse stopped*
with the which you may do rare miracles, both within, and without the body
applied.

Of the metalline water, and strong waters. The.lxxxix. Chapter.
A Water of Quicksyluer sublymed, prevailing against ye Canker, in eradycating
or drawing it up by the roots, and soon slays or kylleth ye same, if it be
applied upon, so that you shall need no long cure in the doing of it, but even
the same dylygence and time as is required in an ulcer, to bestow in it: the
making of which water, is on this wise. Let a quantitye of Tynne be molten,
and when the same begins to cool and wax thick, cast then into it so much
of quicksyluer as the wayght of the Tynne, which incorporate or work together,
that the whole may be as a paste, and that the paste must be laid on a smoothe
and even stone, and fynely grynded on the stone: after, it shall be thus
handled, add to it of Mercury, or quicksiluer sublymed, so much as is the
paste, which again grynde and work on the stone, and remaining thus on the
stone, will shortly become liquide as water, the same distyll in a strong
luted body with a head: the water which comes, keep dyligentlie in a strong
glass, to your use.

Against all manner of scabbes, tetters, foul scurfe, ringwoorms, and the foul
Morphew, etc. A distylled lycour out of Theophrastus, on this wise: Take
Helycampane one ounce, of Barrowes grease purifyed half a pound, of
quicksyluer half an ounce, of Brymstone two drams, distyll the whole in a
Retorte, but if you will in a Lymbecke, as the Aucthour wylleth, which drawn,
annoint the places therewith.

An Alome water serving unto all wounds, being a secret, of a certain noble
man: take of Egrimon, of Nightshade, and of plantaine, of each half a pound,
of white wine four ounces, of raw Alome four ounces, of Masticke two drams,
of Orpyment half a scruple, of the whytes of eggs six in number, these after
the well beating and laboring together, distyl in a Retorte according to art:
with this water, let the wound be washed twyse a day.

Another, named an Alome water, which marueylouslye and soon heals, all
corrosyue ulcers, happening either in the mouth, or in any other parts or
places of the body. Take of Alome, of the juice of Purcelane, of the juice of
Plantayne, of the juice of green Grapes, of the whytes of eggs, of each a
like quantity, which after the well myxing together, distyll according to the
order and manner of the Cynamon water.

Another Alome water, borrowed out of the book of Fulgonus: Take of the whytes
of eggs to the number of fyfteene, of roche Alome, of the iuyces of
Purcelayne, of Plantayne, and of Nightshade, of Rosewater of the juice of sour
docke or sour Grapes, of each two pyntes: these dyligently labored and mixed
together, distyll in a Lymbecke, with which wash the grieved places: for it
speedilye brings old ulcers and sores unto a scarre.

A syngular practyse, which a cunning Surgion uttered to the Aucthour, that he
often used, against the eating Cankers, happening in the over parts of the body.
This Surgeon heated a new tyle stone, which he after quenced in Alome water
sundry times: but he oftener used to hang up the tyle read hot, and to pour
leasurelye after a sprinckling manner Alome water upon it, until the tyle was
cold, which water so stylling down, he gathered or received in a basin, or
dyshe, and dypping lynnen clothes in the water, he applied them on the ulcers
and sores: and thus (as he affyrmed) did he marvelous soon heal those
wicked Cankers, to the admyration of many: This Fumanellus.

A most syngular water, helping the spots of the eyes: Take of white Honey two
pyntes, of Antymonie, of Titia prepared, and of Sugarcandie, of each three
drams, of the best Aloes half a dram, of Celondine, of Rue, and eye bright, of
each half a handful, these gross beaten and myxed together, distyll in a
Lymbecke.

A water of Tutia prepared: take of the eye bright water, of Fennel water, of
the Honey suckle water, of each half a pynt, of Rosewater two pyntes, of Tutia
prepared two drams, of Aloes half an ounce, of white Coperase half a dram, of
Camphora one dram, all these labored and dilygently myxed together, distyll
according to art: For this is a notable water, experienced sundrys times,
against the spots of the eyes: this borrowed out of the learned practices of
Arnoldus.

A water of Marchasite, which consumes and cleanses the web and other spots of
the eyes, and the pyn or web confirmed this softneth. The making of which water
is on this wise: take sundry pieces of Marchasite, which read hot, quench in
a basin or deep dythe filled with old sallet Oil, the pieces through
quenched and cold, break very small, which after distyll in a Lymbecke, the
Feces remaining, grynde fynelie again, distylling that over again.

A water helping the Leprie, and other disseases. This water preuayling against
the Leprie, and al manner foulness and deformyty of the body, cleansing the
eyes, mayntayning or preserving youth, and effectuous in many other causes, as
by practice may further be co^iectured: the making of which distylled lycour is
on this wise: take of the fylinges or small pieces of silver, of copper, of
iron, of lead, of steel, of the owre of gold, of copper, of silver, of
s^or^re, of all a like wayght, these stiepe for a day and a night in the bryne
of a child not polluted, the next day infuse those in hot white wine, the
third day these stiepe in the juice of Fennel, the fowrth day stiepe these in
the milk of a woman, gyuing suck to a man child* which she bore into the
world, the fyft day infused in red wine, and the sixth day these infused in
seven times so much (as the whole is) of the whytes of eggs, which after the
distylling keep to your use.

A water auayling against the Lepry, take of May dewflue measures, of Brimstone
one pound, of Crystal half a pound, of Camphora one ounce, these diligently
beaten and myxed together, let so stand a time, after boil the whole easily or
lightly, which settled again, distyll according to art, to this water add
pearls. This orderlye mynistred purges choler adust, and melancholic.

Lyme not quenched or staked, joined with the whites of eggs, and grinded on a
marble stone, distyl on such wise, that the same which is the grosser may
descend, and for a day and a night keep this in a moist place, which distyll
again: with this whyten the face according to discretion.

Another whytning water, take Lyme unslaked, and incorporate the same with ye
water of the whytes of eggs distylled by a Lymbecke: which work so thick, as
a sauce, after power this into a Glass body, setting it covered in a moist
place, for a day and a night, after distyll the whole according to art, which
dystilled keep in a glass with a narrow mouth.

A water whitning the face, take of ye whytes of eggs, of Boraci^, petrosi, of
salt, of roch Alome, of each one dram: each beaten alone, myxe to the whytes of
eggs, the whole distyll, and use.

A great use there is at this day of the strong water, and often occupied of
the Chymistes, and Goldsmythes, yea in Physic exercised unto sundry
disseases. For that well practiced Physician Amatus Lusitanus* prosperously
exercised and ministered the same, in the great and wicked ulcer of the jaws.
And certain at the beginning of the web, cured it, by dropping of this water
into the eyes. A certain Chyrurgian on a time, applied of this water into the
hollow toothe of a Woman, which caused the Woman to rag^ like almadde body;
^ntyll th^^ a little of Opium was applied to the toothe, by the advice of a
skillful Physician, through which she speedily after amended. But this
marvelously cures ulcers, Fistulaes, Cankers, and knobbes, or knottes, whiles
they yet be not entered within the bones, and hollow: by wetting them only
with a Feather or Lynnen cloth dypped in the water, with which the Gold is
separated from the Syluer^e* The ancient in times paste, that they might part
or separate the Gold from Silver, used the dystylled Lycour of Shoemakers
yncke or bleeche: as they also in Asia do at this day, which with it do
separate Gold from Silver. But our later practysioners, that they might make
the water stronger, and vehementer, added to it Salt peter. Bellonius uttering,
and writing of those medycines or compoundes, preserving dead bodies: affyrmeth
that if iron or any other mettallyne matter, be put into the strong water,
that it forthwith boyleth, and ryseth up to fast, that if it has not vente to
breathe out, it then breaks the vessel or doubble Glass. But if you throw
Gold into it, then does it not like boil up, but dyssolue the same into the
form of Sand, and all the other mettalles in the form of a lycour. When
Silver shall be dyssolued in this water, then put into it Copper plates, and
the Silver will clean to it, which after stryke of with a brushe: and in the
end, this in the melting will join.

A strong water is thus made: take of Vitryoll, and of Salt peter, a like
quantitye, of these draw a water by distyllacion, into which if you put
parsyll or doubble gylt ruppes or pottes, the Silver shortly after will be
dyssolued, but the Gold remains vndyssolued, or as I may say whole, which
after strain, and if you will stryke or wype of the Gold, then add unto the
abouesayd water, of the Salt, etc. * after dry each, and prepare orderlye.

Another strong water: take of strong water, of common salt, and a little of
Salt Ammoniacum, these dystill together, or if the strong water shall be
distylled before, and the others after distylled with it: this then is named
the regal water, or water of a king, which seperateth Gold. But the common
Aqua fortis or strong water, does only separate Silver: so that it does both
leave the Gold, and makes it apparaunt.

A causticke water in the Fistula, without pain: and avails also against
kernelles, swellings, and knobbes, yea, it takes away all manner of excessive
or superfluous increasing of the flesh in man's body without pain. The making
of which is on this wise: take of the best oil of Tyle stands, of chosen
Masticke, of gum Arabicke, and of Turpentyne; of each three ounces, such as
are to be beaten, beat dilygentlye, the whole then myxe together, which
distyll by a Lymbecke: this after myxe and incorporate with half a pound of
the ashes of the tree Cerrus: which distyl again by a Lymbecke, and that
distylled or come forth, keep in a Glass well stopped.

A marvelous water in the Fistula, with which golden letters may be written in
iron: take a Rams horn clean rasped and cleansed without, which cut into
small or fine pieces, puttyng it after into a Lymbecked of glass to be
subtylly distylled: this water then come forth, works so on hot iron, that
it gyldeth it, and marvelously avails in Fistulae^: This Bertapalia.

A water corroding and eating away in the steed of a cauterice, in so much
that it eats into iron: take of ^alt water two ounces, of Roman Vitryoll
one pound, of Vermylion (or * of the red sanguinarie stone) four ounces,
grynde each a part: which after the myxing together dystyll by a Lymbecke, the
water keep in a Glass: this Bertapalia.

A ruptory, which serves to part and cut away any swellyng, or mattery
impostume without iron: take of Roman Vitryoll rubys^ed or made read, six
ounces, or Salt and nyter, of each two ounces, of gauls, of salt Ammoniacu^,
of each eight ounces, of Vitryol not rubifyed two ounces, all these after the
powthering, and distylled in a Lymbecke, keep warely in a glass. The use of
this lycour is, that if an Olyue twygge, or other piece of wood edged like to a
knyfe, be dypped and well wette in this water, that the same cutteth away the
swelling: and wartes may in like manner, be taken away with it. This borrowed
out of Fumanellus.

A water against long continuing ulcers, yea how peryllous or wicked so ever
they be, and the Fistula, a medycine learned of a certain religious person
(of which in another place we have mentioned) taught to me many years ago,
and by sundry practices tried the same, that it cleanses all rottenness, and
brings to healing, yea and heals them in a short time: which is prepared
and made after this manner take of Chalcitis or of the Romain Vitryoll one
pound, of Salt nyter so much, of water so much as shall suffice these boil
together with a little of quicksiluer. Take of this water cleared, two pyntes,
of quicksiluer one pound, the whole myxed together distyll in a Lymbecke, and
the distyllacion ended, break then the Glass body, and the substance within
it (which he as Feces or groun^e) grind fynely on a marble stone, which
distyll together again with the abouesayd water, three or four times over:
For the ulcers being old, does the powder remaining heal; by applying upon
them withal the water: This Fumanellus*

Another water taking away, and healing Fistulaes, and knobbes or k^ottes: Take
of the oil of Tyle stones five pyntes, of unquenched Lyme ^ew made, three
ounces, of pure Arsenicke, two ounces, of Euphorbium one ounce, all these
distyll in a Lymbecke according to art: This Fuma^ellus.

Another mightyer water, inputting away Fistulaes, knobbes and wartes: Take of
the oil of Tyle stones half a pynt, of unslaked Lyme four ounces, of pure
Ammoniacum so much, of Euphorbium half an ounce, all these myxed with the
oil, distyll after art in a Lymbecke: and the distylled lycour* keep to your
use: This Fumanellus.

An Oil for the cleansing of the Morphew: take of white Tartare, and of Salt
nyter, of each a like, these grynde finely on a smothe stone, after make a
hole in the myddle of the powder, in which lay a burning coal, and the oil
which runs from the stone, dilygently keep, with the same annoint the
Morphew places, and they shall speedily be cleansed and healed.

A strong water of an empericke Frenchmans inuencion: take of Salt nyter, and
of Vitryoll; of each two pounds, of burnt Alome eight ounces, all these most
fynelie grynded, put after into a glass body well luted, in this manner, as here
this figure demo^nstrateth: under which maitayn a fire for ten hours space,
always increasing it.

A strong water, take of Orpyme^te, of Floris aeris, of each two ounces, of
Roman vitryoll one pound and a half, of Salt nyter two pounds, of Alome
three pounds, all these dyligently brought to powder, distyll according to art.

A strong water maruaylous, in the curing of an old Fistula, and that deep
entered within the bone: borrowed out of a most ancient written book. Take of
Salt Ammoniaci, of vitrioll, of the red and cytrine Orpymente, of green
copperase, of each two drams, either more, or less, according to the
discrecion of the workman, all these brought to powder, distyll in a glass
body well luted, making a gentle fire at the first, and increasing it so long
until the glass body become read: that distylled, keep in a glass closse
stopped, in that otherwise it would breath out and consume away. This water is
of such a force and virtue, that it pearceth the bones, and for that cause one
small drop let fall in the hollow of the Fistula: does forthwith canterizate
the same, even like to fire. After let the burning be taken or gotten away with
the white of an egg, or fresh butter: and a wary application then used, for
the increasing of flesh.

Another strong water, take of Salt peter, and of the Roman Vitryoll, of
each two pounds, of Alome calcyned half a pound, all these brought to
powder, distyll in a Cucurbite, but I rather think a Retorte the better. This
water whytneth the teeth that be black, if so be you apply a drop of it on
the teeth, with a Goose feather, and wash them after with spring or Conduite
water.

A kind of strong water, auayling against worms, wartes, and knobbes, or
little swellings: take of Salt Ammoniacum, of Romayne vitryoll, and of each two
ounces, of Sugar Alome, and of unslaked Lyme, of each half an ounce, all
these dilygentlye myxed, distyll after art.

Another water maruaylous, in the Fistulaes, and in the dyssoluing of pearls,
and the Gold in leaves. Take of Salt Ammoniacum half a pound, of Salt niter
three ounces, of Tartare two ounces, of common salt half an ounce, all these
finely brought to powder, and distylled by a Lymbecke, keep in a glass close
stopped.

A water which dies or colors Horses, Dogs, clothes, and Feathers, of a
green color: take of Salt nyter one pound, and of Smerilij half a pound,
these fynelie brought to powder, distyll by a Lymbecke: the water keep in a
glass, closse stopped.

For the taking away of a Canker, a secret of Master Frances: take the
distyllacion by a Lymbecke of the quicksyluer, of the silver sublymed, of
Roman vitryoll, of each a like, this orderlye use.

A strong water helping a knob called Morum, (Bertapalia) in the sixtene
Chapter of impostumes: take of Roman vitryoll, of roche Alome, of salt
Ammoniacu^, of Salt gemme, of each four, three, two, and one, these are the
wayghtes according to order, which dilygently brought to powder, distyll in a
glass body fensed with the lute of wisdom, and Ore doong, and straw myxed,
This water is maruaylous, for by touching the round knobbe Morum with it, both
shortly destroy it, yea any other knobbe of flesh grown on the skin: and
this is named the strong water, with which the Golosmythes do separate, the
silver from the Gold.

A strong water auayling in Fistulaes, and is besides of great virtue and power
in ulcers. Take of Salt nyter, of Roman vitryoll, of roche Alome, of each
one pound, each fynely grinded alone, and incorporated together, put into a
Lymbecke, making at the first a soft fire: the first water that comes, keep by
it self, dystylling forewarde with the increasing of heat, until the glass
body wareth read, then take away that second water, and receive the other by
it self, for the first water is nothing worth: and increase then the fire
myghtyer, until the Glass body and headde become redder, forsing then the
Ashes which are in the vessel to ascend unto the neck of the Glass, and
increase your heat of fire, stronger and stronger, until the headde be read,
and that the red fume ascending shall cease, which shall well or euidentlye
appear in the Glass, the same thus come, seal dilygentlye with wax, and
keep the abouesayde water. The Furnace through cold, and the body opened,
you shall find in the bottom of it a red mass or lump, which keep. The
said water, is stronger then the water of the world, and has maruaylous
workinges in it. For this water dyssolueth, corrodeth the flesh, and reduces
or changes all things of the world, into a powder and water: as the stones,
and mettalles. If this be heated, it then gives up a very read, and myghtie
fume. This water, if it touches by it self, either the flesh, or a garment,
it dies or colors the same yellowe to Saffron, which spotte will never be
gotten out: for the color or stayne on the flesh contynueth many days, and
if you wash the stayne with Lie, it becomes very read of color. Further
if you shall put a little piece of good Luna, that is of silver, into this
water, it dies then the same of a black color, which after cannot be gotten
out or cleansed away. And if you shall put a little of Mercury, which is
quicksyluer, into it* that it be molten, it is then caused mightyer then the
fire. For if it then touches the flesh, it does cauterizate or burn, even
lyk^ to an iron fire hot, and is not fealt: and is right notable for
canterises, or to make cauterizations: it also mortifyeth all Fistulaes,
Cankers, Carbuneles, wicked, and venomous humors. If iron also be put into
the said water, it forthwith heateth and boyleth without fire* and if you put
into it iron, it causes a red water, by the intermedling and dissoluing of
the iron. And if you shall draw or distyll the water by a body of glass
fensed, the iron then will remain in the bottom of the vessel, and will be a
very read powder, which properly is named, Marses, Saffron. If also in the
above said water you shall put Venus, that is to say Copper, it like boyleth,
and of the same is made a green water. And if you will draw that water forth
by a Lymbecke, then will a most black powder of Venus, remain in the bottom
of the vessel, which properlye is named Venus Lyme. Note that if you shall put
Saturn that is Lead, in the said water, it causes the water clear, and if
you shall draw that water forth by Limbeck, there will remain a white Salt in
the bottom, and that bitter. Also if you shall put Jupiter, that is tynne into
it, it will then cause of it a paste like to butter: and if you shall dry the
same (as above taught) the powder then will be white in the bottom. And if you
shall put Mercury, that is quicksyluer, into it, it makes then a clear water
of the same: and if you shall let the water of Mercury to settle, it will then
fall to the bottom like to yse: and if you will dry the same, then remains a
white salt in the bottom, and strong as the styffest wax. And if you will
recover your Silver, when it is in the water, put then in the same water crude
Mercury, and the good Silver will incontinent enter within the Mercury, after
emptye the water, and take the myxion, which put into a Goats skin, wring
the substance very hard, and the Mercury or quicksyluer will then issue
forth: the substance which shall remain in the skin, put into a Crucible to
be molten, and you shall then find the good silver. Also if you shall put
Gold in the same water, it causes the water yelowe of it, and if you shall
dry the same, then is a golden salt caused bitter as the earth, that avails
in the drying of Fistulaes. If also you shall dyssolue one part of good Luna or
silver in the said water, and so much of Mercury or quicksyluer, and so much
of the white sublymed Silver, and a fowrth part of one of these, of Tutia
Alexandrina, and shall draw this water by a Lymbecke, all these then shall
remain in the bottom of the glass, unto the form of a stone: of which
stone put one part, upon four parts of Copper molten, and it shall soon after
become so white, as the silver (...) if you shall io^ne good Silver, then may
fair ornaments be made of the same. The author ma^es it i^ their kind of

A water and oil of salt Ammoniaci: take of six or ten hard Eggs sodden,
which opened in the heads, and the yolks taken forth, fill those empty places
of the Eggs, with the salt Ammoniaci in fine powder: after let th^se be set
into a vessel filled with sand, that is moystned or wette with water, and the
next morrow you shall find a water within the shell, which power forth the
next morrow after, empty again the water in like manner, and so often do,
until the whole be resolved. But if you mind to draw and have an oil of the
same, then separate the water by a Lymbecke, and the oil will remain, which
keep in a glass. The special use of it is and serves unto the fyxing, and
unto many other Alchymicall works, Marcell.

A water named Royal, for the syngular properties which it has unto many
grie^^e^punc; the making of which is on this wise, take of yellowe Brimstone,
of roche Alonie, and of Salt gemu^e, of each two pounds, of Borrace, and of
^a^^icke, of each two ounces, these dilygentlye beaten in a mortar, and myxe^

continuing the same until all the moy^ture be drawn and come: the water which
distylleth and is gathered in the Receauer, is white and troubled, which
strain through a fine cloth, the same keep in a glass with a narrow mouth,
putting to it four grains of Musk^ dyssolued in half an ounce of Rose water:
and after the setlyng, will this water be clear, and very sweet. The
approved virtues of this water are many, as the Aucthour affyrmeth: of which,
some he does here utter that he has many times experienced. And the first is,
that this royal water takes away the pain of any wound, if the wound all
about be bathed with it. The second propertye and virtue of this water is,
that all manner of ulcers, fores, and grief^es that may happen within the
mouth, and the gummes much putryfied, and to the ache, by holding a little of
this water in the mouth, by the space of a Crade and spytting it after forth,
does marueylouslye and sp^dily heal any of the above said. The third
propertye and virtue of this water is, that rubbing the teeth with a ^yne
lynnen cloth wette in this water, does make them very white, a matter
delectable to many men and women. The fowrth, by giving half a scruple of this
water by the mouth with broth, to the person in the fyt of an Agu^, does
marvelously deliver it, and that for certain. This borrowed out of the
singular practices, of the Greek Fiorauant.

A precious water for the eyes, of Vitryoll: take a quantitye of Vitryoll,
drawing a water of it in a Cucurbite by distyllacion, in Sand: but this
Vitryoll needs not, nor ought to be calcyned. Another, serving to the same
purpose. Take a new laid egg, which after the seething hard, pluck of the
shell, and cut the same into just halues in the myddle. The yolke taken out,
put in the place the quantitye of a Pease, of white Vitryoll in powder, and it
will be turned into a water, after let the* whole be wrynged through a linen
cloth into a glass, and the water kept, for it is singular for the eyes.

A marvelous water, taking away the spots vndoubtedly^ of the eyes, and
clearyng the sight: above all, it preserves and maintayneth youth, and takes
away any spotte of the face: but in the high read c^lour, and Leprie, it
does not so much avail, or not throughlye cure them. The making of which is on
this wise, take of the sylinges of Silver, of Tynne, of Copper, of St^ele, of
Lead, of the Gold and Silver ower, of each so much as the abillitie of the
person may extend: Infuse these for the first day and night, in the vryne of
a sound^ child: the next day, in warm white wine: the thyrd^ day, in the
juice of Fennel, Veruayne, or Celondyne: the fowrth day, in the whytes of
Eggs: the fyfte day, in the milk of a woman gyuing suck to a man child:
the syxt day in red wine: the seventh day, in the whytes of seven eggs:
and the whole together put into a tynne Lymbecke or Rose still, to be
distylled with a soft fire, and that which comes, keep dilygently^ in a
Glass with a narrow mouth, close stopped.

Of this water let fall two or three drops at a time into the eyes, both
morning and evening, washing the eyes before with Spring water, etc. This
borrowed out of the learned work of Arnolde De villa noua.

A powder made by subl^mation most strong, serving with the corr^^ing and

throughlye cool, which being cold uncover the head, and that which then
remains allow in the bottom, throw away. But that which cleaves or
sticks to the cover, take away, and keep in the pieces. And when you shall
need of the same, then use and work with the same by good cyrcumspection, and
in a wary manner, in that this burns like to fire, and both putrifyeth and
corrupts the place, to which this is applied.

Certain instructions, of Mercury precypitate, to be prepared and made, with
Aqua fortis, are here under uttered.

Th^^ Mercury precypitate, is made on this wise: take of Aqua fortis or strong
w^^er, one pound, of crude Mercury four ounces, dyssolued into water, after
the water euaporate in Sand, or by distyllacion, separate it stronglye, that
it waxes read and through dried, the same after grind in a marble mortar,
pouring upon Aqua vitae, distylled five or seven times over, which also
kyndle* and let it burn until the same be consumed. After let it be rectifyed
with Rosewater very well myxed, and then by fyltring or by a fylter, separate
the Rosewater, and leave or suffer it to dry. Then power again of the Aqua
vitae upon, which kyndle and burn until the same be through dry, and the
same repeted a third time, you shall have that you desire and seek. And so
much of Aqua vitae must be powered upon, as may only suffice to cover it, but
not to much in any wise.

A Mercury precypitate, invented of an Empericke French man: take of
quicksyluer one pound, of strong water fifteen pyntes, these put into a
Cucurbyte strongly luted, distyll after the manner of strong water, as is before
taught, increasing always the fire unto the end.

A common precypitate, which serves for the drawing out and eating away of
rotten flesh in ulcers, and much exercised in our time, for sundry grieffes:
the making of which is on this wise, take of strong water, which serves to
separate, and for every three ounces of it, put or add two ounces of
quicksyluer, that is not falsified with any other mynerall, the whole power
into a long necked body, which is strongly luted, applying fire so long under,
until the water be throughlye drawn away and dry, and that no fumes ascend
to the head: after make a strong or great fire for an hours space, and then
let the body cool, which through cold, break the Glass body, for in the
bottom shall you find a red mass or substance, like to Vermyllion, the
same bring to fine powder in a brass mortar (as in a manner vnpalpable which
then may rightly be named the common precypitate. And be which myndeth to
prepare the precypitate in such sort, that it may not work so rygorous and
painful, as it does and is fealt, where the same is applied, let him do it on
this wise, wash the same with clear water, after draw away and dry
thoroughly the precypitate by heat of fire, which through heat burned, quench
in strong vinegar, and this do three times together, for then will his force of
payning be qualyfied, and on this wise is the common precypitate prepared, with
which you may do miracles, applied in sundaye medycines. This borrowed out of
the secret practices, of Leonard Fiorauant, the Greek.

Of Mercury precipitate, which serves and is a remedy against all sicknesses
and disseases, caused of the rottenness of humors. The.lxxxx. Chap.
TAke equal parts of Roman vitryoll, and Salt nyter, and of them gather a
water by distyllacion, with a body, head, and Receauer, into which body you
shall put a sixth part of the wayght of crude Mercury or quicksyluer, that is,
if of the Vitryoll and Salt nyter, there be three pounds, then add to these
of Mercury, six ounces: after this so do, that a water with his spirits may
ascend, and fall into the Receauer. All which come in the receauer, empty
then into another Glass body pure within, and stronglye luted and fensed
without: to the headde of which set a Receauer fastened with lute, and standing
under: the same cause to distyll again, and the water when it shall be
gathered in the Receauer, power the same again into the body in which
Mercury yet remained, and you shall often repeat and go over with this,
until a Mercury come to redness, and being thus come read, take the Cake
forth, and wash it with Cordial waters, as the water of Rosemarye, Buglosse,
Baulme, and such like. But wash the Mercury before (and that often times) in
spring, Cunduite, or well water being before distylled: which Mercury thus
corrected and prepared, you shall mynister to the sick and grieved persons,
after this order and manner.

If the person shall be sufficientlye strong of body, then mynister (after the
mind of Gabriell Fallopius) of Aloes cicotri half a scruple, of Myrre and
Masticke four grains, of precypitate five graynes: myxe these with rosed
Honey, or rather with the conserve of Roses, framing of the whole, either three
or four pylles, which give fasting in the morning, and dryncking a draft of
white wine warmed after them. If the body shall be mean of strength, then
mynister but four graynes with a little sweet^ butter, Sugar, and three graynes
of Masticke. If the body shall be feeble and through crased, then only three
graynes, with half a scruple of Aloes ^ycotrine powthered, and myxed with
Rhodosaccharu^, which made into three pylles, minister as above taught. But if
you mind to minister this to a Child, then use but four graynes, or rather
apply of it, according to the strength and weakness of the Chyldes body,
Further learn and note, that you ought to myxe the precypitate before with
Triacle, and to mynister the same then to the pacient poisoned, to the dropsy
person* and pacient taken with the Pestilence, or any other sickness. And that
more to be understood, if a healthful and sound man shall yearly, or every
third year use this precypitate, as need and occasion shall require the same,
with a prudent digestion of humors, that is, the preparation of the purgation,
the pacient then shall avoid disseases, and from being sick.

Here conceive, that in the place of precypitate, you may use the myxture named
Amalgama, which (after the mind of the Chymistes) is made of sire parts of
quicksyluer, and of one part of Gold: with which thus prepared, you may do
the greater marueyles. And note, that with the first, and second precypitate,
you may cure wounds, by using the same after this manner, as to put of it about
the wounds, and within. Besides the water remaining after the precypitate
