made, takes away the pain of all filthye wounds, if they be bathed with the
same, and a drop of this water put with coten into a hollow tooth, which
greuouslye aketh and payneth, it does sodaynlie astonishe and mortifye the
marow of the tooth, and delyuereth the pain for ever. Also this water mixed
with white wine, and wetting the heirs of the head or beard with it being
hoarie white, causes them to come yelow. And sundry other matters besides this
works, which for breuitye here omytted.

The manner of making the Philosophers stone, which heals all disseases in
man, or woman, is on this wise: take of Salt nyter prepared, of roche Alome,
and of Roman vitryoll* of each two pounds, dry the vitryoll before in an
earthen pan, and being dried, beat altogyther into powder, unto which add
four ounces of Salt gemme, after put the whole into a body luted or fensed
about with the lute of wisdom, and the head close joined and clayed about,
which set in an open Furnace, making a fire under with cleft wood if you will,
unless you had rather use coals, then to the nose of the headde artlye fasten
the Receauer that no air breath forth: which done, kyndle the fire, and when
it begins to distyl, wet then lynnen clothes easilye wringed out, which
shall apply both upon the head and Receauer, unto this end, that the spy^^^es
of the water do not euaporate and waste, for by the spirits euaporating, the
water is so caused vnper^ite to such a purpose: and in the beginning of this
distyllacion, do the vessels appear so read, as blood, and within a whiles
after they become white, when as you distyll with a strong fire: after that
they return so red as at the first: and these ^e the good spirytes of the
strong water, after that they return once again white, and as soon as they
appear no more read, the water is then ended and perfect: after which draw
forth the fire, and let the vessels cool, the^ power forth the water into a
strong glass, close stopping the same, which diligently keep, for the making
of the Philosophers stone. After take of quicksyluer one pound, of vnflaked
Lyme six ounces, of black Soap four ounces, of strong Ashes three ounces:
all these labor together in a mortar, which dilygentlye incorporated, put
after into a Retorte stronglye luted, which fastened to his Receauer, set in a
Furnace to distyll, making about and under it a strong or great fire,
continuing this fire so long, until all the quicksyluer ^ee come forth, and
gathered in the Receauer, which draw away, and keep in a strong Glass
body, close luted. After labor the composition of the stone, which is made
after this manner: Take the said water, which you made first, pouring the same
into a body of such a bygnesse, that two third parts of the same may rest
empty, which stronglye fence and lute about: after power into it the
quicksyluer, which you kept, adding two ounces of thynne iron plates, and one
ounce of steel plates beaten very thynne, to the ^^ put so many gold leaves
or sheets, as wayghe two English crowns, or font what less of wayght:
after these so put into the body, set on the head forth with, and the Receauer
luted to with speed, for immediately after the myxing of these together, does
the substance in the body boil, and cause so read Funles that yse as blood,
which then gather to the head, so that spedilye ^ou must set the body in the
Furnace, applying fire so long under, until the whole water be distylled and
come, and the Fume ended. Then let the vessels cool, and keep the water a
part close stopped, after break the body, in the bottom of which you shall
find the Philosophers stone, the same reduce and bring into very fine powder,
and dilygently sear^e it, keeping it after in a ^alley pot or broad mouthed
glass, ^^ry close covered, and setting it up, as you would a precio^s
treasure. The water gathered, and that you keep, will ser^e anoth^r time to
perform (...) ly^^ effect and purpose: but it for ^^th not, although you can
work ^uer but half the quantitye of the substance, the same half you must
necessarilye labor once ^uer again, in the fayde water, which second work
ended of the stone, bring the same into very fine powder, and myxing ^^ with
the first substance: the water keep then close covered unto infinite uses* as
shall after be uttered in the proper place. But as touching the powder this one
special matter is written by the Aucthour of the singular properties contained
in it, being prepared and compo^^ned after the manner here under taught, which
so framed* and mynistred, does then work myraculously, in that the same (...)
position named of him Aromaticum leonardi, does help all grieffes and
sicknesses of the body, of what qualitye and condi^ion so ever they be, for
settled in the stomach, does forthwith draw to it, round about, and from the
headde, all the evil humors thereabout among the body, which drawn
together, it speedilye sends them forth of the body, as well by vomit, as
downwarde by stool or siege, disburd^ning by that means, nature before
charged, after which the body, may the sooner (without impediment) recover to
health: and in this respect; the same is a helper to the amendment of body, and
preuayling against all sicknesses, as may appear in the glorious and singular
workings of it: the making of which composition is on this wise: take of white
Sugar four ounces, of Pearls grynded, of Musk, of Saffron, of Lignu^ aloe,
and of Cynamon, of each one scruple, of this Philosophers stone, four drams,
which after art make into Tables with Rosewater, as you do Manus Christi:
these after put up in a close wooden box, that no air breath forth, and kept
in a dry place. The quantity to be mynistred at a time, is from one dram*
unto two: and you may either gyu^ it in broth, wine, or Ale, or in any
conserve: But gyuing it in a potion, have regard that the same which setleth
to the bottom of the cup be druncke also: in that the same being heavy,
evermore, setleth to the bottom, and the same not druncke, the effect then is
not, nor will be performed at that time. This also learn, that what ^ays the
pacient takes it, he may then eat but little unto night, and drink only
thynne drink, for the better discharging of the stomach. The Aucthour also
writes of an angelike electuarie to be made with this stone, that is
marvelous in many disseases and sicknesses. For this ministered, avails in all
Agues, by abating the force of them, for grief of the flanks eight
marvelous, and eases straungely the gowte, by taking adosed; quantitye of it,
every third day, and that three times together in ten days, for by that time
(does the Aucthour write) that he shall thoroughly he cured of his gowte, and he
reports that many times he has woonderfullye cured it, to his great fame.
This also avails in the cough, the rewme, and dissease of the Milt: and
helps besides the French dissease, joint aches, and such like.

The making of which precious lycour, is on this wise: take of Saffron, of
Lignum aloe, of Cynamon, of read Coral, of each a dram, of black De^^abore
without preparation two ounces, of the electuarie of the juice of Roses (of
Mesue) not to much or to high boiled, six ounces, of Sugar Roset or of the
conserve of Roses, eight ounces, of the East Musk one dram, of the
Philosophers stone three ounces, of the best quintessence, two ounces, of stone
Honey boiled and skimmed, so much as shall suffice to make a good form of an
electuarie, these after the powthering, myxe and incorporate dilygently
together over a soft and easy fire, in an earthen glased vessel, in that a
vessel of any metal, is not fyt for this composition, and being made, keep
dilygently in a glass, rather than in any other vessel. And this electuarie
may be matched or myxed with any other solutiue medicine, and taken with a
fasting stomach in the morning: the quantity at one time to be mynistred, is
from two drams unto four. This conceive, that the same rayseth in a manner the
doad, through the singular virtue contained in it: as the Aucthour in Rome, and
in sundry other places, has both seen, and done many experiences worthy
memory. For which cause, he wysheth the skylfull practysioners, not to be
without this Angelike electuarie, that myndeth to purchase, fame on earth. This
borrowed out of the singular practices, of the skylfull Greek Leonard
Fiorauant.

The making of the vegelant stone, after a rare and strange order, that
changes bodies from one quality into another, and defends or preserves the
body a long time in health: and that has also infinite virtues in a manner, and
without comparison. Is borrowed out of the practices, of the above said
Aucthour, in this manner.

Take of the Tartare of white wine, which is both thick and clear, or bright,
of Turpe^tine very pure and clear, of the herb Aloes which has long leaves,
thick and indented on the sides (and hanged in men's houses, being
continuallye green, and brought of Marryners many times out of Barbary into
England) of each of these three one pound, which after stamp together in a
mortar, making and incorporating the whole to a paste, the same put then into
an vrynall body of Glass with a head luted to, and a Receauer artlie fastened,
under which apply fire so (...) until all the lyquide substance and moisture
be come: and after draw forth the Feces out of the vrynall, and if you
otherwise can not choose, break then the vrynall, and grynde those Feces,
which incorporate with the whole water come, after distyll the whole as above
taught, and in the end always of your work, make a greater fire, and so
mighty, that your Feces may appear burned well, those Feces again draw
forth, grynde and impaste with the said water, as before taught, and distylling
it the like over again, which repeat and do fifteen times over* or twenty
times together without ceassing, until all the water be wholye consumed after
this manner, and that no moisture rests in the Feces, but are so white and
bright, as Salt. Those Feces then lay upon a smoothe marble stone, hanging it,
or laying it in a moist place, and the stone will after dyssolue and turn into
a most clear water: and being thus wholye dissolved, keep the same in a
narrow mouthed glass, close stopped: for this water is the vegetable stone*
Which water is of such a virtue, that one scruple of the same myxed with two
ounces of the Iulepe or syrup of Violets, and mynistred or taken by the mouth,
of any sick person or evil complexioned, for the space of fortye days, shall
be delivered and quyted of any grievous and hard sickness, and this must be
taken with a fasting and empty stomach in the morning, and that the meat be
well dygisted before: for being ^n such wise, this then works the greater
effect: and is also a syngular remedy against worms, in mynistring of it as
above taught, and cleanses the Liver, dries up the moisture of the Mylt,
delyuereth the cough, the rewme, and causes the pacient to pysse, which has
impediment of vryne, and sundry other virtues this myraculous water has,
which the Aucthour ouerpasseth, for doubting that he should seem to any, that
he uttered impossible matters. Wherefore he wysheth the skylfull to examine
these, and to make further tryalles of this water: whereby they may find out
other secrets, both strange and myraculous, to the benefit and recouerye of
health. This also serves for the fixation of Myneralles, without flying away
in the fume, in that this stone resists the force of any great fire, without
the consuming away: and it also so fyxeth the Brimstone and Orpymente, that
they after may abide the fire, and causes them also most white, through which,
in making proiection with them on Copper, or brass (...) it changes either
into a most pure Silver for whytenesse, or as I (may aptlye term the same)
silver like to the eye, which the Aucthour saw wrought and done by a Chymiste,
before his face.

The manner of making of a red powder, that is, of precypitate, or of
quicksyluer calcyned, borrowed out of Marianus: take of the water, with which
the Goldsmythes do separate the gold from the silver, six ounces, of
quicksyluer four ounces, these after the myxing, distyll in a Lymbeck after
art, which strongly lute before. For the helmette or head has a body, which
must be fensed and luted about (in which the matter or substaunces to be
distylled are put) and the Receauer must be fastened to the Nose of the head,
as this figure here formed dot^ pla^ner demonstrate* Where the letter A.
rep^^^enteth the vrynall body, having yt head set on, with a long b^ke or
nos^ retch^^g out, to which the Receauer, represented by the letter B. must
artlye be luted or fastened. In the Furnace set the body, fenced with the lute
of wisdom round about, as here by the letter A. is demonstrated, and distyll
at the first with a fire of a temperate heat, which increase by little and
little until all the water be come, and that no sum aryseth, which ended, and
the body through cold, break then the Glass body, etc. But the strong
water, which seperateth gold from silver, is made after this manner* take of
Salt nyter, of roche Alome, and of Romayne vitryoll, of each two pounds,
these grind and myxe dilygently together in a mortar, which done, and the
powder thus gross made, put into a vrynall body, of such a bygnesse as may
well and sufficiently receive the whole, and strongly luted about. After this
lute artlie the head and Receauer, that no air of the water breath forth, and
in the distylling draw thus the water, which you may rightly use. And the note
of his goodness, is thus understood that when you let a little of it fall on
the earth, you shall see the same presently boil up. And on this wise have
you the manner of making of the powder and water, which is of such a virtue that
no man will credit the same. This powder to be received within the body, must
be prepared and corrected (after the mind of Matthiolus) on this wise, as that
four pynts of strong water be taken, and a pound and a half of Mercury or
quicksyluer, which put not into an vrynall body with a head, but into a
Retorte or crooked necked Glass, being strongly fenced with the lute of
wisdom etc.

A Mercury sublymed, borrowed of an Emperick Frenchman, made on this wise:
take of quicksyluer one pound, which extinguishe in the strongest vinyger, of
vitryoll dried and pure, two pounds, of common salt very white, three
pounds, after power the whole into an vrinall body strongly luted, with the
head and Receauer close luted in the joints: under which keep fire for six
hours, as by little and little increasing: the work ended, break then the
Cucurbite, and you shall have persite Sublimatum.

Quicksyluer out of Lea^e, was on this w^se drawn and g^tten (...) the same
Empi^^cke: take of (...) mo^^ ^nely chopped, ten pounds, of Salt ^yter, and
of (...) calcyned, of each twelve ounces, let all these be put into an earthen
vessel glased: after they are dissolved in strong Aqua vitae, let them be set
in the hotter place of all the hot house, for four or six days together,
and you shall then purchase and have seven pounds of quicksyluer.

Mercury or quicksyluer crude, powered into strong water, the whole is so
reduced and brought in a manner, unto the form of an oil: with this are
rotten flesh, and the piece of flesh within the nose causing a stincke taken
away, etc. But if an evil or sore shall be within the mouth, then is Vnguetum
aegiptiacum better, or to be preferred.

Of the precypitate with Gold: this is the manner of the taking of it, and this
is the dose or quantity to be mynistred at a time, borrowed out of the letters
written unto Gesnerus. I have given four Barlie corns wayght, sometimes of
this powder, with conserve of Roses, tymelie in the morning, but the pacient
after refrained meat unto dynner time, and made then a small meal or dynner,
but a better supper. Through the benefit of which, for the space of two years
after, yea three years and more, the pacient had perfect health of body, as
he reported. Yet the mind of the best practysioners is, that the precypitate,
how so ever the same be corrected, does always painefully torment the head and
stomach, especially of tender bodies. Wherefore although this may seem to
help sundry disseases, to purge the belly mightily, and to procure strong
vomytes: yet does it many times procure the blooddy flixe to ensue, and a vein
to break in the breast, through the painful inforsing, and strayning to
vomyte, Which nevertheless thought meet for husband men, that have strong
stomachs to abide the drawing of it: so that to them it is porfitable, and may
help sundry grieffes and disseases.

FINIS.
The third Book of Distyllations, containing very strange secrets.

Of certain oils in general.
The.j. Chapter.
MAny needs as much of oils as waters, unto the benefit and preservation of
health, as for other necessary commodityes of body, besides. For seeing of
these which we now possess, that certain especially avail to healthful
persons, for the preservation and maynteynaunce of the health of body, as
those on which we feed, by which a help to be clothed, and defended by
shoes, and that strengthen our bodies, as well as certain helping the sick:
and others also there be of such sort, which both avail to the healthful,
and sick persons, as the oil Olyue does: which as Galen witnesses, is of
such condition, that the same so necassarilye serves the healthful, as the
sick persons, in applying of it as well within, as without the body: For
among those medycines, which are applied on the outward parts, the Oils
bear not the least swaye, as well this simple, as the compounde oils. And the
use of them is very often, insomuch that we are occasioned and procured
sometimes to use them alone, but we often are moved to use them in the making
of ointments, Ceroltes, and playsters. And there be oils and oyntmentes, that
not only for their consistencie or styfuesse, but for their near agreeing in
virtue, that the oils are often named of Dioscorides oyntinentes, as is the
ointment Nardinum Mastichinum, and such like, which many rather name oils than
oyntmentes, Yet many kinds of oils there be. But that (of Galen) is named
symplye and properlye an oil, which is pressed out of r^pe Olyues, and is free
in a manner of any quality exceeding. And for that cause, the ^^me i^ not only
most profitable, and (...) unto the composition of many medy ^i^es^* that of
them with which it is my^ed, it ^as^ly^ (...) but for that it ma^e also be^^
(...) by it self, and alone within the body, unto the ^uryng of sundry
disseases. Yea an oil is, many times pressed out of green O^yu^s, which they
^auie oyl^ ^in^^acine that has the property of rooling and binding^ which
now as a matter of other medycines* like the sweet* can not be. So that these
two* be properly and truly named oils. And as touching the o^ders, of which
we fullye and at large entreat in this book (for that an oil is here named
to be the same, whatsoever juice is fattie and oily) are named oils through a
certain symilitude, as be the oy^^e and running ^^^ees, pressed out,
distylled, or wrought and done by any other order and manner, out of fruits,
se^des beaten, and kernelles, as of ^a^ill nuttes, the Indiane nutte, Almonds,
Balano merepfica, mustard seeds, Line seeds, Ricini, and such like.

And such oils are made, after many orders and manners: for certain are made
by pressing out, and others only by impression (as Mesue names and terms
it) as when ^^mple medycines, boiled, stieped, in common oil, do leave their
virtues in it. But certain are done by a Chymisticall resolution, as when that
which is oily in all parts, is then by the force of fire resolved by
distyllation. And these manner of oils be most vehement in working, and very
thynne. A man may also by the bene^ite of fire, draw a kind of oil, in a
manner out of all things, yet out of some a plentifuller yield, and out of
other some a lesser yield: in which this is a peculiar among the rest, that by
a marvelous thynnesse of the essence, which they received through the fire,
that do most spedilye penetrate or pierce into the deep parts, and do most
spedily offer and show their virtues: like as those oils, which the
Alchymistes draw out of Brymstone, vitryoll, Tyles, and such like. For all
these have greater virtues, then those, from which they are drawn.

And these oils that are drawn by distyllacion, are chieflye done in sand,
in such sort that the spyces or ^eedes, grossly beaten, be put into an vrynall
body strongly sensed and luted about: and at one time are put in unto the
q^^ntitye of three (...) of spices, or according to the g^ea^nesse of the
Cuc^^bit^ or gla^^e body, upon which are ^ixe pyntes of most ^sea^^ water
powr^^ upon, and myxed dyligently. After that a head set on the glass body
answering or ^yt to the Furnace, which body so set in sand, that a good
quantitye be under it, that it may nothing stand nygh ye bottom. To the nose
of the glasen head ^ixe or artlie faste^ a Tynne or iron pype, but ye same
(tynned) both within and without. Let the same pype pass bowingly or after a
leaning manner (a slope) through the vessel, which has in it cold water, that
in the distylling the vapor issuing or going forth with the oil, may so be
cooled: before the distylling, remember to close dilygently the wyntes, with
thick paper or a lynnen cloth wette, and set under a Receauer or Glass at
the end of the pype. After make an easy fire, and take heed in the time of
your distylling, that the substance in the glass body, rises not up through a
rash heat, nor boyleth. Yet certain seeds as the Annise, through the
thynnesse of his substance, and clamminesse together which they have, do
largely boil, and for that cause may not the head be set on by and by or soon
after: but rather when you see bubles arise, and that a vapor to ascend
withal, then prepare and take of your head, and stir the stuff about with a
small stick, that the bubles and some may so be resolved into vapor, which
may after by a mean fire be moderated, aswaged, and dried up* Which done, set
on the head again, and dilygently luted about, distyl orderlye so long, until
you think no more oil to be contained within: which both by sight and taste
you shall by and by perceive, for when by taste the drops distylling, carrye
or have no more savor nor taste of the spyce, then leave of or cease, least
the spice burn then to the bottom of the glass. After separate dilygently
the oil contained in the distylled water, as after shall be taught. But this
note and learn, that certain of these oils, do swym on the water, and
othersome do syncke and fall to the bottom. Of which ye oils of the black
pepper, of the new Cardamomu^, and the Annyse swymme above. But those which
sincke and fall to the bottom, be the oils of Cynamon, of Mace, and of
Cloves, etc. The water of Cynamon and Annyse, when they are distylled, have a
mylkie color, and this mylkie substance is by little and little changed into
an oil: this hitherto borrowed out of Valerius Cordus.

Further understand, that two matters or points especially are required in
the drawing out of oils first, that the substance have plenty or sufficient
water powered upon, that the same may so be lyfted and carried upward, through
which it may the less be burned, or consumed. The other is, that either the
head, yt pype, or long nose, be continually cooled, with most cold water,
standing in some apt vessel fast by. Which two necessary helps yield and give
this use, that the spyrites of the oil, which be very subtle and most hot,
that as soon as they inflame and mightilye heat in a burning manner the
headde, they forthwith by the cooling are repressed, and converted into an oil.



Of the distyllacion of Oils by an instrument named a bladder. The.ij. Chapter.
FIrst let a vessel be made of potters earth, of a finger thyckenesse, that it
may be the stronger and surer, which frame after the form of an Egg, with yt
head (as it were) cut away, as this figure here plainer demonstrateth. And
make the same of what largeness, and bygnesse you will: yet seeing for two
pounds of spyces, there ought twenty pyntes of water be powered upon (and that
the Copper vessel must so be filled, that a third part or a little less be
left empty) even as by this quantity which seenieth a mean, you will
distyll in it oyther more or less, make the bygnesse accordinglye of the
earthen vessel: in whose bottom let fine Sand be powered, unto the thickness
of a finger, or rather two fingers, and round about the body, for the drawing
of oils, out of spyces and seeds: but for herbs, this manner needs not.

2. The vessel thus prepared of chosen earth, purged, well and fast wrought
together, and through dried, etc. as all other potte^^ are wont (yet scarcely
prepared at the three weeks en^^) and mak^ your Furnace in largeness,
according to the compass of the pot, of Tyles only, (for the pot whiles it
is thus baked, is drawn and shruncke together much, and for that cause the
same ought before to be thus handled) having a deep foundation: and a^rou^d
hole framed to the bottom, having a grate made within, above which, fyxe
higher by half a foot, two bars lying cross, on which set or let the
bottom of the pot stand, and let the Furnace rise and be above the bottom
of the pot, that is, above the iron bars, one foot and a half, or little
les^e.

3. Within the pot, set a large Copper vessell^ according to the quantity of
the water (as for two pounds of spyces, let twenty pyntes of water be powered
upon) in such s^r^, that the empty^nesse round about, be filled with Sand a
finger and a half high. This vessel with the head shall stand and be above
the Sand, half a foot almost.

4. Let the helmet or head above be round, and not sharp poynted, that the
vapor fall not again downwarde, nor that the head be cooled with water, nor
has any edge or gutter. For being on such wys^, all the vapor will issue and
pass speedily and forth with into the pype. If the head now should be cooled,
the vapors there gathered, would ^uer soon be thyckened, and fall also
backward: or else this also otherwise hyndered, by this manner in the distylling
of oils. For that cause must be c^nsydered and known, how the crookedness
of the nose ought to be, according to the standing and space of the place, that
the pype fastened to the nose of the head, may aptlye pass and retche through
the Fyrkin or other vessel of water, etc.

5. Let the pype be long, in a manner six foot, and let it pass or retche
through the tubbe or vessel filled with cold water.

6. Let the fire first or at the beginning, be made somewhat great: after that
by little and little abated or lessened, but let it be kept in an equal force of
heat. The oil will come forth together, with the water, and flewme, etc. Some
part of it setleth under the water, and another part swymmeth above, and the
oil also may be separated. The water then may be distylled again, and that
which shall first come, will be the sweetest water, for the other is only
flewme. This distyllacion, may be performed in eight hours: these hitherto
of the practices of the learned Gesnerus.

A most apt instrument for the drawing of Oils, out of Roots, Herbs,
Seeds, Spyces, and others like. The.iij. Chapter.
A. Represents the vessel, which the Aucthour names a bladder, in which the
matter or substance is contained.



B. Does here represent the bellye that is fastened to the neck, that the
neck may the commodiousser, be applied to the large mouth of the vessel,
which the neck could not so commodiously be fastened, but through this mean
and help.

C. Does here show the long neck, that lets the head, that ^t heat not to
fast.

D. Signifies the head.

E. The vessel or bucket compassing the head, into which cold water is
continually powered, after the heating.

F. Represents the long Receauer.

G. Here signifies the Tappe or Cock, letting out the water hot.

This form and manner of Furnace, purchased the Aucthour, of a skylfull
practisioner, and learned Physician of Basyll.

Of the drawing of Oils by distyllacion of water boiling. The.iiij. Chapter.
TAke a Copper body or pot, of such a greatness, that will well receive
fifteen pynts, the same fill so with wine or water, or with both myxed
together, that a third part only may remain empty. To the water power your
substance, apt to yield an oil, and that grosely beaten, which let stand to
infuse for three hours, yea the better four, or six hours. After set on the
head, very close luted about, and cause the water most strongly to boil, for
with the vapor then of the water, do the oily spyrites ascend, which by the
pipe, passing through the cold water, do descend and distyl into the
Receauer of Glass standing under, and are so changed into oil, which after
in the Furnace of dygestion, you shall separate from the water, with a Silver
spone. And on this manner, may you draw an oil out of Nutmegges, Mace, Annise
seeds, Fennel seeds, Cynamon, Cloves, Juniper berries, and others. This
Furnace of digestion, is a vessel, into which the water and oil is powered
together, in a place temperately hot standing, that they may the aptlyer be
separated, one from the other. And how this seperacion ought artlie be done,
shall after be taught.

The manner of purchasing Oils by an iron, or wood press. The.v. Chapter.
TAke a press made with strong cheeks, between which two sides, put too iron
plates sufficiently heated, but not burning hot: after wring hard together
the substance, out of which you mind to purchase an oil (remembering before
to put up your matter into a new Canuas bag) and then in this hard
drawing, will an oil come forth. That if your substance shall wax dryer and
dryer, before the end of the work, then moysten the same, by sprinckling a
little of the best Aqua vitae upon. But this conceive* that all substaunces
ought before to be gross beaten, and being well heated in an earthen pan,
put then up hot into a new thynne bag, and wrynging the same hard, a more
quantity of oil will come. But for a playner understanding, conceive these
examples following: and first the purchasing of the oil of Almondes, which is
gotten ^n this wise. Take of iourdaine Almondes or of other Almondes, four
pounds, these after the paring and cleansing of them dry with a knyfe (for
that they may not be blaunched in water) stamp grosely in a marble mortar,
which sprinckle with a little of the best Aqua vitae mixed with Rosewater, to
the quantitye of two ounces of both, these after the dilygent incorporating
together, put into a new earthen pan glased over the fire, which after the
heating so hot, that it begins to fume, or at the least that you can not
suffer your hand in it, then put up of the same, a quantitye being so hot,
into a thynne square bag of new cloth, and wring this very hard in a
press between two smooth iron plates, or two square boardes smoothed of Sugar
cheast, into a porrenger or clean pewter dyshe: this wholye gathered, wash
after if you will, in an earthen pan filled with rain water, which so long
labor with a stycke in the water, until the same be come white, with this
may women (if they will) annoint their faces, both in the morning first, and
at night last, for this both clears, and makes be wtyfull the skin, in any
place, wheresoever the same be applied.

Another example, ayding the above taught, made of Almondes compowned after
this manner: take of Almondes ten pounds, of read Saunders, in powder six
ounces, of Cloves one ounce, of white wine four ounces, of Rosewater three
ounces: these after the gross beating, let so lie in the marble mortar close
covered for eight or nine days, beating the same over once a day, after the
heating of the whole in an earthen vessel, until it begins to fume, and
be through hot, put then of the substance into a new square bag of lynnen
cloth* which stronglye wring in the press; as above taught, for out will come
a red oil, with which women may onnoynt their fa^^, for it causes a
comely^ read; and bewtifull skin, a secreth not before uttered ^n any book,
and known to few otherwise.

The making of anoth^r oil* which causes the face white and be wtyfull* ^of
no^ ^esse importance than the others, on this wysel^ take of common Abu^nde^
s^^^ped, six pounds, of Sond a ^acha* of Masticke white, a^^eac^e three
ounces, of the whytes of new laid Eggs four ounces, of gum dragant two
ounces, all these beats dilygentlye in a mortar, which after closed cover for
six days, beating and s^^rring it about once every daye^ which heating in a
pan (as before taught) and put up into square lynnen ^agges hot, wring hard
in the press, for out wy^^ come an oil which clears the skin, and makes
it white and comelye, in such sort that it will appear myraculous and rare:
for this is one of the greatest secrets taught of bewtifying, in that the same
mayntayneth the skin smoothe, clear, and white, and never harmeth the
person, nor the place where it is anointed.

The making of a synguler Oil, very rare, which causes a comelye face, and
makes the person merrye, which uses it, yea strong and hardye to fight, being
gotten after this manner: take one pound or two of Hemp seed, which after
the fynely beating, sprinckle and wette with a little wine, then put the whole
into an new earthen pan glased, and set over the fire, heat so long until
you can not suffer your hand in it, after put of the substance hot into
square bags, which wring hard out in a press, and an oil will come forth
very profitable: of which if any drincketh, vnt^ the quantitye of an ounce at
a time, it makes him pleasant and merrye, and being a Soldier which
drincketh it, this makes him both flexce and hardy to fight, having the^ no
doubt nor fear of his enimye: and also profitable to women, in that the same
makes them merry, and comely to see to. And in this manner, may you draw an
oil, out of all seeds.

The making of the pleasant Oil of Cloves, by only pressing out, after this
manner: which for that an oil alone, cannot be purchased through their
dryness, therefore do on this wise: Take of Cloves one pound, which bring to
powder in a brass mortar, to it add three pounds of Almondes scraped and
beaten in a mortar, which after the well myxing together, sprinckle an du^e of
the best white wine on each pound of the wh^^e, letting it ^^lye in (...),
for the spare of eight days at the lea^^* after (...) the whole over again,
putting it into an (...) earthen (...)* which heat so long until you can not
suffer your hand in it, then put up into s^^^re bags ^wordand ^^de in a
press, until all the whole substa^^^e of oil be co^^.

The making of an ^do^ifer querade of (...) with another substance right
profitable ^^ and to be ^desyred, prepared on this wise* take of Spy^^ ^arde
one pound, this beat fine in powder, after beat six pounds of sweet
Almondes sera^ed, which my^e together (...) letting the whole solye* for ten
days, at the least after beat the same over again, sprinckling upon each
pound of the substance, one ounce of Aqua vitae* the whole after heat in an
earthen pan so hot, as you can not suffer your hand in it, then putting it
into square bags hot, wring hard in a press so long, until all the oil be
come which is very sweet, and serving to the use of Phis^icke, and for other
needful purposes.

The making of an odo^iferous oil of our garden* Spyke, with an other
substance, in that this of it self yields no lycour, and yet of a strong
sauoure: yet to purchase his savor or smell, do on this wise: take what
quantitye of Spyke you will, the same after the fine beating, wette with the
fynest Aqua vitae, until the substance be sufficientlye wette: to each pound
of this, add four pounds of ^^urdaine Almendes scraped, which beat and
labor together, letting the whole so lie for ten days, the same after the
well beating* wring hard in a press, for out comes a most clear, and
pleasant sweet oil: which serves so well in Physic matters, as in the
art of per^^ming.

The making of the Oil of Nutmegges, in an easy manner, gott^n by pressing
out, on this wise: take of Nutmegges, and of the best Almondes scraped, of
each a like quantity or wayght, these beaten together* let so lie ^or fow^^
or five days, and after the sufficient heating, wring hard in a press, for
an oil will some, of (...), savor, and taste of the Nutmegge^. And this by
good reason, in that the oil of Almondes enters to the making of it, which
neither abateth his savor nor taste, nor hyndereth any thing hi^ virtue: for
being myted with any other substance, neither hyndereth, nor takes away any
part of hi^ quality* So that this is the aptest manner that any can use, in the
drawing out of the oil of Nutmegs, and works a greater effect* where the
same ^^ applied: for it is more? p^ar^^ng, and has then a pleasaunter savor,
and more delectable in ^aste* and worthyer in all his other workinges.

The drawing out of the oil of Cynamon, after an easy manner by presse^ a
secret veris rare and marueylous^ borrowed out of the syngular practy^^o^^r ^
which serves to the use of P^^^cke, in that the same preserves the stomach
from corruption, by taking of it by the mouth^ and applying of it on the
stomach: the manner of purchasing this oil, is on this wise. Take one pound
of Canell or Cynamon, which finely bea^e, after myxe and impaste it is with
the oil of sweet Almondes, ^nt^ the form of an ^yntment, the same he^^fe in
an earthen glased pan^e soft what, which after ^et stand ((...) close) for
fowreteene days, or twelve at the least, at the end of which time, heat the
whose again sufficientlye, the same wring hard in a press (as before taught)
until the whole Cynamon rest through dry in the bags which come forth, will
then be of the color, savor, and taste of the Cynamon (a secret) and an own
to few, to be wrought in th^^ ^rder.

The making of a pro^^^able Oil, named the oil of the yolks of Eggs,
borrowed out of the before said Aucthour ^ which serves to diverse and sundry
matters, and is an oil, which never consumes: the same besides serves in
many working^ of Ale^ymie, as in gyuing fyxation to the medy^^^, when the
spyrites are fleeting a way: the drawing of it, is on this wise. Take a
quantitye of the yolks of Eggs, when they are hard, those beat and work
together in a mortar, which after put into a copper pan setting the same over
the fire, and making under a great fire of coals, which in the mean time
stir dyligentlye about with a splatter, until the same begins of it
self, to turn into an oil, which thus turned, speedily put up into thynne
canuase bags and wringe the oil hard out: and on this mane^ have you
purchased the oil of the yolks of eggs, which is both precious, and
marvelous. And in the drawing of it on this manner is a secret, and known to
few persons: and has also such properties in his workinges, that a man will
scarcelye believe them: for this healet a wound with marvelous expedicion, it
causes the heirs of the head and ^eard bl^ck, and takes away the sign and
blemishe of a wound, by annoynting often upon, it aswageth the grievous pain of
the Pyles, dyssolueth and helps the pain of the sides, and does many other
matters besides, which for breuitye are here omytted.

The Aucthour here shows of a certain Practysioner, that otherwise prepared
and drew such manner of oils: For he took the flowers of Camomyll, and the
like of all other fresh and green herbs, and after the chopping or
shredding of them, he artlye boiled them in oil: and when the oil was cold;
h^ strongly pressed the whole forth, putting into yt oil again fresh
flowers, which he after set in the Sun for a time.

A Greek; and synguler practisioner, instructs the manner of making all
sorts of oils, out of flowers, herbs, and other dry things: as out of the
Saunders, the woodde Aloes, the Tancariske woodde, and such like, that have no
oil in them: which is on this wise. Take that simple, of which you mind to
draw an oil, the same orderlye beat, letting it after lie to soke in the
oil of sweet Almondes, for the space of eight or ten days, which after the
heating in an earthen pan (as before taught) and put up into square bags,
wring hard in a press, and out will come a pleasant oil serving to sundry
uses. And after this manner may you draw an oil out of any, of the others,
above mentioned, and the same very perfyte: in that this oil of Almondes (as
before uttered) (...) apt to receive the virtue and property^ of all things
infused in it, and nothing hyndereth the virtue, nor working of any.

By what devise and means an oil which distylleth forth with the water, may
be artlie separated. The.vj. Chapter.
THe separation of an oil, may aptly be done from the water, either with a
silver spone, especially if the oil shall swym on the face of the water: or
otherwise which is by a more dilyge^ce and skill, in preparing a peculyar
instrument or funnel of glass, serving to the same purpose, as is this
instrument or funnel, here placed, right against, which has in the bottom a
hole stopped with wax* or a vessel having three small pypes contained in it,
as the one retching to the bottom of the vessel, another to yt middle of it,
and the third to the highest of it. But further does Bessonius utter, in his
little treatise of the drawing of oils, after this manner. First, he wills
the practisioner, to consider and learn that the receauer ought to be made
somewhat sharp toward the bottom, and to be like the point of a thing bored or
stricken through, with many strokes of a small punchin or small nail. This hole
then in the time of the distyllacion, stop dilygentlye with wrought wax. The
water and oil after distylled, and set a time to cool in the air, mark then
in the clear receauer of glass, what place the oil occupyeth in the water.
Which you shall well perceive, by the dyuersitie of the color. That if the
same occupyeth the bottom, in taking or plucking away of the wax from the
hole of the receauer, forthwith does the oil issue or run into the vial or
glass set under, and the water will rest behynd: if so be you mind to keep,
or to stay the water, by stopping the hole speedily with wax. But if the oil
occupyeth above the water, then in opening the hole again, the whole water
shall be drawn forth softlye* and by little and little, into the glass standing
under* that the^ (...) in the bottom of the receauer may so be reserved (...)
it (...) wise happens through the hastiness, and imprudencie of ye worker,
that it shedd^th so away into the receauer being under, then into the glass
prepared for the only purpose. But if the oil through the water carrying it,
be troubled and turned into clouds, the whole water then shall be strayned
through a lynnen cloth in the air, I mean, in the cold air, and the
distyllacion before cooled. Through which all the oil in the end thus stayed,
will rest on the linen cloth, that you may after gather easily of with a
knife, and shyft thence unto a vyall or small glass, by which in the end if
need shall be, you may resolve into a thynne lycour, ^uen with the least heat
that may be, etc.

Of the rectifying of oils, out of ^^ares or gummes, wooddes, Seeds, yea and
of Baulme. The.vij. Chapter.
THe oil that presently is by yt force of fire drawn, needs also to be
rectified, which to do, shall then be powered into another Retorte or glass
with a bended neck, and with a most soft fire, in ashes distylled: which
distyllacion performed, you shall then purchase a most pure oil, piercing,
and falling to the bottom.

Note, that out of two pounds of Cynamon, scarcelye half (...) ounce of pure
oil is attained or gathered: but out of two (...) of Cloves, is gathered two
ounces, or at the least an ounce and a half: and out of two pounds of Annise
or Fennel s^edes, is purchased two ounces: and out of two pounds of Nutmegs
the practysioners attain in a manner, three ounces most commonly.

Of the many sold use of oils. The.viij. Chapter.
MAny and sundry wise, is the use of the distylled oils, as shall after
appear. But on such wise or on such manner, are they commodiouslye applied and
used, if so be a quantitye of Sugar be dyssolued in the water of Vyolettes or
Rosewater, or in the water of Cynamon or other spyces: and the some being thus
dyssolued in either of these, power into after, a drop or two of some oil,
whose use you seek to try, and fra^e or make s^^are tables (or round if you
will) of the whole: of these minister according to art.

Of the Baulme, and Baulme oils distylled, and of a few not distylled, and of
other oils compouned, being in ^se like the Artyficiall Baulme. The.ix.
Chapter.


WHat a true Baulme is, and whether the same also be known to be at this day,
is thoroughly uttered and opened by the Aucthour in a proper chapter of the
first part of his work. Therefore our mind in this place is, to utter and
entreat of the artificial Baulme, which by a certain imytacion and nere
agreeing in the use of the true Baulme, was of the same (at the first)
inue^^te^, and put in ure, of the ancient practissoners. For when they wayed
and understoode, that both the one and the other were falsyfied by the
counterfayters, and that those compound lycours which were sold and mynistred
to men, neither agreed in substance nor properties by any manner to the true
Baulme, were upon the occasion the earnest lier moved, for the avoiding of such
an end ^nyt^^e and great harm, and that such a treasure especially should no
longer lie hyd and unknown to men, upon this good and so reasonable
consideration, they applied their wits and industrye, to the attayning and
trying out of a lycour, nearest aunswering in properties of the precious
Baulme. And for that they might the commodiousser perform and bring it to
pass, invented to us a certain general kind* of the qualityes and
properties of the true and natural Baulme. And s^ing by nature the Baulme is
most hot, and piersing, and endued with a mighty property and drying, or
that mightylie ^ryeth of property, for that cause especially this may
preserve bodies very long from putrefying, being anointed with it, and put of
old^ age or mayntaine youth a long time: for the perfourming of which, they
chose simple (...) of like property, so nyghe as they could purchase, which
myrte might yield the like faculties, so aptlye as art could match them. Of
which kind, that be principallest, are the Myrre, the Olybanum, Frankensence,
and Aloes. The next to these, be the Turpentyne, and Aqua vitae. The third
sort are these, the gum yuie, Galbanum, ^yquide stor^^, the Woodde Aloes or
Lignum aloes, etc. But from the purpose these disagree not, as the Galingale,
the Nutmegges, the Cloves, and many others of like kind. For all these being
gathered into one, by an artificial conjecture matching, was so made, that of
all these myxed together, by a iu^^ proportion, in the Chymisticall art, they
drew an oil, which in faculties and consistence, was most like and nearest
agreeing to the true Baulme. These hitherto agreeing in a manner, to the words
and mind of Leonarde Fiorauant, in the making of the artificial Baulme. So
that to the making of the artificial baulme, is necessarily required* that the
Turpentine of it self, with the essence (of wine) be only (...) in Balneo: the
other spyces after dyssolued in the essence, and with the abouesayd oil of
Turpentyne, by Balneum again distylled For wrought in ashes or sand. does a
gross oil ascend, even with a most soft and easy fire, so that the same in
the receauer come is then nothing worth.

If so be you defyre or would perfitelie know, a good and true Baulme, from an
evil and falsyfied, then after the mind of Fallopius (in his secrets) cast
or instyll certain drops of the Baulme into clear water, and with a stycke
labor well the water* that if the water then be troubled, the Baulme is not
perfect: but contrariwyse, the water if it shall abide clear, then is the same
true and good, and does gather it self alwaye^ into one place.

It is to be considered and noted, that out of three pounds of Turpentyne,
myxed with one handful of Salt, and a little of the essence of wine, are four
ounces and a half of the oil of Turpentyne, distylled and gotten in Balneo
Mariae. Yet they ought to stand, for certain days before, to putrifye.
Further that Turpentyne gives or yields more oil of it self, if the same
be distylled by a small pype, than by boiling water, is to be doubted.

A marvelous Baulme made or drawn by art, most laudable, and often tried,
which serves unto diverse and sundry disseases and grieffes: invented by a
synguler Greek of great same in our time, named Leonarde Fiorauante: the
making of which is on this wise, take of most fine Turpentyne one pound, of the
oil of Bays four ounces, of Galbanum three ounces, of gum Arabic four
ounces, of pury Frankencense, of Myrre* of gum yuie, and of Lignum aloes, of
each three ounces, of Galingale, of Cloves, of Consolida minor, of Nutmegges,
of Cynamon, of Zedoaria* of Gynger, of the white Dyttanye, of each one ounce,
of Musk, and Amber greese, of each one dram, all these beat and labor
together; putting the whole after into a Retort, to which add or power upon
^i^e pynts of the best o^ ^ine^^ Aqua vitae: the trial of which is on this
wise, that a lynnen cloth wet in it (and set on fire) burns clear, which
cloth so burning put into the Retorte, that it may so cause the ^^ter to
burn, and the cloth in it together, which thus burning, ^turr^ dilygentlye*
the water with the stuff about, letting the whole stand to infuse for nine
days, which after the setting in Ashes, distyll according to art, the same
which distylleth and comes forth, is a white, water with an oil together,
and on such wise proceed, forward with a soft fire, until you see the oil
begin to come forth black^she: incontinent upon that sight, change your
Receauer, setting under another, and increase the fire stronger, until all the
spyrites of the substance he come forth of the body, all which throughlye
come, separate then the oil from that black water, and each keep a part by
it self; and the like do with the first water, in seperating the oil, and
keeping each a part. The first water, which is white, is named the baulme
water, the oil separated from that water, is named the baulme oil. The
second water blackishe, is named the mother of baulme, the lycour separated
from that water, is named the artificial baulme* which ought to be kept, as a
most precious Jewel. And this composition have I gathered, and dygested into
such a perfection, as in (my opinion) seems not no defull of any further
addicion: besides I have made many practices and trials, of all these matters,
here under uttered. The first water come, and dropped into the eyes, does
marvelously clear, and preserve the sight of the eyes: and washing the face
with this water, makes after a most comely and bewtyfull face, it preserves
youth, and puts of old age, it breaks and dyssolueth the stone of the
kydneys, and causes the pacient to pysse, which otherwise is let by a
certain fleshie stopping in the way: this also cures all manner of wounds
happening in any part of the body, and of what condition so ever they be, by
the washing with this water, and the applying upon of Lynnen clothes wette in
this water, which sundry times exercised, will show so marvelous a working,
(as though the same were done by the blessed hand of God only.) This besides
mightily helps the persons in a consumption, and all manner of rewmes, and
the coughe. This water also bathed or rather fomentedon the Sciatica or ache in
the hyppe, causes the pain forthwith to cease. That other water named the
mother of baulme, fomented on scabbes, does speedily and with marvelous
easiness heal them: and works the like on the foul scurfe, the Leprie: and
all manner of ulcers, which are not corrosyue, this water marvelously cures,
and that without tediousness: and unto infinite other grieffes also this
serves, that the Aucthour here ouerpasseth. The baulme oil serves unto
infinite matters and purposes, and especially for wounds of the headde, where
bones be perished or harmed, and the pannickles: by pouring into, and applying
on it on the wounds. This preserves the fa^e, by annoynting (after
dyscretion) with it.

This also does marueylouslie help the Plewrisse, by giving one dram with
water at a time* and many other matters this works besides. The Baulme is a
marvelous lycour, for who that has pain of the flanks or bowelles, by
taking two drammes of this Baulme in the mouth, shall spedilie be eased and
delivered: this does like help the cough, the rewme, the coldness of the
head, and the stomach: and for all wounds of the headde, this is a most
synguler remedy, by annoynting all the headde about once a day, for this
pierces into the brain, and even to the stomach allow. This also dissolueth
any swelling happening in any part of the body, and in short time. This
besides cures the quartaine Ague, by annoynting all the body with it, in
omytting no part untouched, and the same in a short time: to be brief, the
Aucthour knew at no time, any sickness or dissease, which he did not cure
with this Baulme: in that this avails as well in the hot sicknesses, as in
the cold: for the cold this heateth, and the hot sicknesses this (of a
certain hid property) cools. To conclude I have (says the Aucthour)
found and tried such synguler virtues in this p^ceious lycour, that I can not
utter all (or at the least) to write of them all, were over long. Wherefore I
wyshe all men and women (being of abilytic) to be always provided, and to
carry of this treasure with them, whether so ever they traueyle or journey,
for the health of body: in that the use of this, defends them a long time,
from any sickness or dissease, and this is a most certain truth, as the
Aucthour of trial knows.

The manner of distylling an artificial Baulm^, of D. Ioh. Mag. In the
beginning ought thyrteene pounds of Turpentine myxed with Aqua vitae rectyfied
be distylled, and gather that oil by a Receauer, which by Balneo Mariae
ascends, that is most clear, very thynne, and light. Of this oil take one
pound and a quarter, of Borrag^ flowers, of Roseleaues, of Buglosse flowers, of
Staechas arabica, of the garden Spyke, of Rosemarie flowers, of Lauender, and
of Chamomyll flowers, of each one pugyll or little handful, of Annnise
seeds, of Basyll seed, and of Pyonie seeds, of each half a dram, of the
roots of Angelica, of Helycampane, of Valerian, of the flower Deluce or Ireos,
of the true Acorus, of Dyttanie, of Lycorps, of Pyonie, of Spica, of each one
dram, of the ryndes of the Cytrone and Orrenges, of each two scruples, of
herbs, as of Sauge, of Maioram, of Lauender, of Rosemarie, of Hysope, of
Myntes, of Bytonie, and of Baye leaves, of each one little handful: let all
these be finelye shredde and stamped according to art, and put into the glass
body strongly luted, or Copper body, together with the oil of Turpentine
distylled, and to all these power the water of Annyse, or Cloves, or that last
in the dis^yllacion of Cynamon, in so much that the body be in a manner fylle^.
On this after set the headde, and the joint about close stop, with lute. Then
fire put under, let the distyllation be like done, as of the Annise, or water
of Cyanmon, that is, let this be distylled, by a pype running through a vessel
of water. Which done, that is, when the water shall be ascended and come, then
let the refuse or Feces of the herbs, flowers, and roots be taken forth, and
put again^ into the body cleansed, into which power one quarter of a pynte of
Lyquide stora^, and to the same power, what so ever you shall draw forth in
the next distyllacion, and let them be distylled again, as the first. That if
the water of the first distyllacion, shall be diminished in quantity, then shall
you power more lycour upon. Now as soon as the second distyllation shall be
ended, cleanse again the body, pouring into it of Storaxe calamyte, and of
Myrre, of each two ounces, of Masticke, Frankensence, and of Asa dulcis, of
each one ounce and a half, which finely brought to powder and put in, power
upon the water and oil already distylled. If those suffice not, then add to
it of the like water, above taught, until you shall think it sufficient, and
let a like distyllation be done, as above taught of the herbs. Which
performed, take then forth all those which remain in the bottom of the
Glass, and power in these following in their steed. Yet this must be noted by
the way, that many mix the Lyquide storaxe together with the foresaid gummes,
so that there ne^deth no peculyar distyllacion of these following. The spyces to
be added are these, take of Gynger, of Zedoaria, and, of Galingale, of each two
drams, of Rubarbe half a dram, of Gentiane, and of Cubebae, of each one dram
and a half, of Saffron half a dram, of Cynamon one ounce, of Nutmegges, of
Mace, and of Cloves, of each six drams, of Calamus odoratus half an ounce,
let al these be finely brought to powder, and powered together with the water
and oil of the last separation, and distilled like the first time by a pype in
water, which thus fynished, separate the oil from the water, and keep the
oyl^ of the artificial Baulme in a glass, which use, as here under
instructs. There may also in this last distillatio^ be a ball or great button
made of the spyces tied round up in a fine lynnen clothe, and distilled
together, and that the savor, may be purchased and caused the sweeter, take of
Mus^^ dissolved in Rosewater five graynes, of Camphora two grains, of Cynamon
and Cloves, of each one scruple, these orderly mix as above taught. And this
Baulme is four times distilled over, as first with the herbs only, in the
second with the Liquid storaxe, in the third with the gummes, in the fourth
with the spyces. This has the property of comforting all the synewie parts,
and those lacking blood, which be, the stomach, the womb, the bowels, and
bladder. But it especially helps the stranguri^, and those passioned with the
stone, if eight or ten drops of the same be druncke, in either Fern water,
or wine. This also opens all inner stoppings: it defends and preserves a
person long in health, by taking certain drops mixed in broth, and that in
the morning fasting twice in the week, etc.

A brief rehersall of this distillation, he took one pound of the oil of
Turpentine, and added besides sundry seeds, of herbs, of flowers, and of the
above mentioned roots, and mixed all in a glass body luted, and added after
to it, five pintes (of rectified Aqua vitae) and of Cloves, and distilled them
together by a pype. The next day, he took Lyquid styrax, and the other gummes,
and distilled it again, and this distillation (note) is hard, in that the same
so lightly boyleth up, and for that cause shall the coals be drawn forth, when
it begins to boil up. The third day following, he distilled the spyces and
others, with the Baulme by a pype in water, etc. And on such wise, he purchased
the prepared Baulme.

A Baulme of G. a Klee, take of good and clear Turpentyne, one pound, of the
oil of Bays two ounces, these two mix together, after of pure Olibanum, and
of Lignum aloes pure, of each two ounces, of Masticke half an ounce, of Myrre,
of Ladanum, and of Castorie, of each two drams, all these diligently brought to
powder, and mixed with the abouesaid, let so stand for thirty days in the
abouesaid oil. To these after add, of Galingale, of Cloves, of Cynamon, of
Nutmegs, of Zedoaria, and of Cubebae, of each half an ounce, of Dittanie, and
of Campherie, of each two ounces, all these prepare and put into four ounces
of Aqua vitae rectifyed, which mix artely together, and let the whole thus
stand for four days, at the end of which time, mix together all the whole,
and put into a Lymbecke diligently luted and closed in the joint, distill then
with a soft or slow fire. First comes a water, which is named the Baulme
water: next insueth a cytryne lycour, in color like to oil, which as soon as
you shall see distylling, draw away the receauer with the water of Baulme,
setting speedy under an other receauer, to gather the most precious lycour
then coming after the manner of oil, which is named the mother of Baulme.
After these shall the great lycour distill and come, and remove then the
receauer, setting under an other, to gather that blackishe lycour a part, which
then sends forth drops or droppeth, a long space and time between drop and
drop, and this lycour (slowest distilling) is more precious than the other two.
These three lycours thoroughly distilled, keep diligently in several glasses
close stopped, with wax, which wax notwithstanding through the fortitude of
ye Baulme water, is within a short time softened like paste. The second lycour
is cytryne or yelowe, which is the mother of Baulme. The third is black,
which is named Xylobalsamum, eue^ as the first, named Opobalsamum. The first is
good, the second is better then it, but same excellenter is the third. I saw
says the Author, a person tro^bled with the palsy, which by applying one
drop on the forehead, and another on the nauill of the belly, was forth with
delivered and cured of it. Another taken with the palsy, lest the sense and
feeling of the right Arm and foot, who with the annoynting of the joints,
the shoulder blades or p^yntes, the arms from the Elbowes to the hands, the
knob and joint of the hand, the knee, the neck, and breast, by spending on
each place thr^^ drops; arose within a few days after from his bed, and was
thoroughly healed by it.

A Muncke carrying a Beam in Paui^ a City of Lumbardie, wrung and
grieuouslie bruised his hand betw^^ne a pyller and the Beam, in such sort that
his hand (...) after waxed so black as a coal, with an intolerable pain,
and ^rampe that hap^ed after in that hand, which being anointed with this oil
of the mother of Baulme, the pain in short time after ceased: but being after
anointed with it, morning and evening, the hand became white again, and
thoroughly restored and healed. The Aucthour (by a chance) cutting his finger
deep, healed it only with this baulme, in a short time.

Another Baulme distylled in a Retorte, which not much varyeth, both in the
properties and composition, from the other above. Take of Turpentyne one pound,
of the oil of Bays two ounces, to these mixed* add of Galbanu^, of gum
Elenum, of gum yuie, of Frankensence, of Lignum aloes, also diverse spyces, of
each two drams, these after the artlie distylling, put up in a glass. The use
of this baulme is, that a certain noble man, having the hand drawn and
shrunk together, in such sort, that he could not (...) the same: by annoynting
the joints and hand with it (and covering or wrapping yt hand with a hot
cloth) was within fifteen dai^^, thoroughly cured. Another person having a
hardness in his throat, on such wise, that he could not retche nor cast up
spy^tle out of his throat and mouth, but by annoynting the throat with this
oil* the whole throat after was greatly inlarge^ (...) ^y annoynting again
the throat ye next day following with it, the pacient was wholly cured. Another
having a pestilent Ca^^o^cle or swelling in the grynde, by annoynting the sa^^
with this lycour, was wholly cured. This also helps the belching and pain of
the stomachs the crampe* the chollick, and stitches: the (...) of the ears,
^y ius^ylling one drop at a time, both morning and evening into them. The
synewes shrunck, and at wounds: the canker, the Fistulaes, bruses or the
strypes of black and blue; the pe^^il^ce; and every hard impostume does this
resolve. This besides helps memory, if you apply or anoint one drop on the
forepart of the head, and anointed on the back bone, and joints, helps the
palsy*

A maystrial Baulme, of unknown Aucthour to Gesnerus: take of Xyloaloes, of
Masticke, of mace, of Galingale, of Nutmegs, of Spykenard, of Gynger, of
Cinnamon, of Cardamo^^, of Cubebae, of Cloves, of Zedoaria, of gum Arabicke, of
Santali muscellini, of frankensence, of saffron, and of Olibanu^, of each two
dram^^ al the^^ finely labor and bring to p^wder, and myxe with the waters of
Turpenti^^ and honey, prepared on this wise: take of Turpentine and honey, of
each half a pound, these distyll together, and a part from others, without any
myxing of spyces to them. After take of Aqua vitae once rectifyed, one pynte,
this myxe with the abouesayd confection, letting the whole then putrify in the
sun, in a Glass close stopped with wax, for eight days, or longer time if
you will. After make a separation by Lymbecke, according to art, and the first
water which then comes, is named the mother of Baulme. The second which
yssueth, named the oil of Baulme: the third, named the artificial Baulme,
and in the end aromatizated or made pleasant of savor, with Musk and Amber
greese, and that addicion very much comfort and delights, and used or
added in every confection of Baulme.

The mother of Baulme simple: take of the best Turpentine, three pounds, of
fine Frankensence, of Lignum aloes, of each three ounces, of Cloves, of
Galingale, of Cynamon, of Nutmegges, of Cubebae, and of gum Elemi, of each
two ounces, all these beaten and incorporated together, and put in a luted
body, and standing in fermentacion for five or six days, distyll after in
syfted ashes, beginning with a soft fire, and increasing stronger and
stronger, unto the end of the work: and this which first comes, named the
mother o^ Baulme. Of this mother of Baulme then, and of the Elixir vitae, alyke
myxed in the Lymbecke, and fermented again (as above taught) and a
distyllacion after wrought in Balneo Mariae: there will a most clear water
distyll and come forth, which is named the mother of Baulme coniunct, or
compouned.

A Baulme invented, and first made in Rome: take of Turpentine, half an ounce,
of Olibanum six ounces, of Aloes succotryne, of Masticke, of Galingale, of
Cynamon, of Saffron, of Nutmegges, of Cloves, and of Cubebae, of each one
ounce, of gum yuie two ounces, all these brought to powder, and myxed with
the Turpentyne, and put into a Glass body, and to these adding of Camphora,
and Amber greese, of each two drams, distyll after with a soft fire. The first
water which comes, is white and clear, and the wine of the Baulme: the
second is yellow, and named the oil: the third more yellowe, and is the true
Baulme.

The description of a certain Baulme or water, invented of a famous Physician,
of which he reported and affyrmed very rare and wonderful matters, and gave
to it a royal name, which is, the reuyuer, and defendour or mainteyner of
youth. Take of Turpentyne one pound, of pure honey half a pynte, of good Aqua
vitae two pyntes, of Lignum aloes dilygently beaten, and of all the Saunders, of
each three drams and a half, of Olibanum, of gum yuie, of the bones of the
Hearts heart, of Zedoaria, of long Pepper, of each three drams, of gum
Arabicke, one ounce, of Nutmegges, of Galingale, of Cubebae, of Cynamon, of
Carrowayes, of Masticke, of Cloves, of Spykenarde, of Saffron, and of Gynger,
of each three drams and a scruple, of ^ine musk, the wayght of two pence:
these artelie prepared, distyll according to art, beginning with a soft fire,
and increasing after a stronger and stronger heat unto the end, the first
water that comes forth, is as clear, as the Cunduite water: the second will
be fyrie, as a coal: and then increase the fire, and the third lycour will
come forth blackishe.

A Baulme lycour of Johan Mesue, very excellent, and most profitable unto many
grieffes and disseases: he took of thosen Myrre, of Aloes hepaticke, of
Spykenarde, of Dragons blood, of pure Frankencense, of Munia, of Opobalsamum,
of Bolellium, of Carpobalsamum, of Ammoniacum, of Sarcocolla, of Saffron, of
Masticke, of gum Arabicke, of Lyquide storax, of each two drammes (otherwise
two drammes and a half) of chosen Ladanum, of Succi castorei of each two
drammes and a half, of Musk half a dram, of the best Turpentyne, unto the
wayght of all: these artlie brought to powder, and myxed with the Turpentyne,
and powered into a Glass body with a headde, and the same strongly fensed with
the lute of wisdom: distyll in the beginning with a soft fire, and
increasing the heat after, according to skyll and discretion: the lycour which
aryseth by distyllacion, and artlye gathered, preserve in a strong Glass,
close stopped. This lycour draws nighe, unto the true juice of Baulme. Guido
a cauliaco, did sometimes to this precious lycour, add the herbs appointed
and used to the Palsy, and then the worthyer, and much more effectuous (as he
witnesses) practyses, he wrought and did: And with this lycour alone, in the
palsy, Mesue many times dealed, without the addition of any others, and had
good success, by annoynting the pacientes nape of the neck, and all the rydge
bone of the back downwarde, and that part affected or taken. For in this manner
doing, it marvelously helps the great debilitie of the back, and decayed
strength of all the parts, and the deprivation of the synewes and bones. So
that it much profits the Palsy, all the griefs of the synewes, the beating
and trembling of the heart, and a manifest looseness of parts, through the
secret property incredible. And this conceive, that there can no medycine be
invented, nor found worthier then it. For at any time, when the heart needs
any speedy comforting and strengthening, use this as a singular and divine
remedy, if we may credit the learned practisioner Mesue.

An oil of the Philosophers, drawn out of Turpentine and Wax, which is a
certain secret Baulme having infinite virtues, exceeding all other lycours,
that can be invented and made, in that the same is made of two symples, which
be but little subject to corruption, or in a manner incorruptible, the one is
Turpentine, which is a lycour dystilled and gotten of the Fyrre tree, and the
other is the wax, which is a celestial matter, that discendeth or falls
from heaven, and that this is true, we thoroughly know, that nature neither
produces the honny nor wax, but rather prepared and sent from heaven. And we
after see that the Bees by their wonderful skill and Art (far above man's
towardness) gather the one, and the other, and carry them to their home,
which man by no industry can gather one drop the like, but to abreuiate
this, the preparyng and making of this precious lycour, is on this wise, take
of clear Turpentyne eyghtene ounces, of sweet yealow wax, twelve ounces, of
the Ashes of the Wine tree six ounces, these put together into a Retorte or
crooked neckte glass, artely luted and fensed, which after the setting into
Ashes, distill according to Art, mayntayning a stranger and stronger heat,
unto the end of the work. And when no more will dystyll forth, you shall
then see about the neck of the Retorte within wax courded, which is a
manifest sign, of the distyllation performed. This now distylled and
gathered, stop dilygentlye with wax, and keep to your use, for you have
then a lycour like to Baulme in properties, which is of a syngular virtue, and
much piersing. If any with this lycour, shall be anointed all the body over,
it then by the sundry times using, preserves and mayntayneth youth a long
time, and keeps all things put in it from corrupcion, and putrefying: and
does also keep the body a long time in health, and preserves dead bodies
imbaulmed with it a long time. And a person wounded in any member or part of
the body, by only annoynting on the wound three or four times, with this
oil, shall thoroughly be cured. And that person which can not pysse, by
taking only two drammes of this lycour by the mouth, shall forthwith pysse
plentifullye: and this the like mynistred, helps the grievous pain of the
flanks, stitches in the sides, the worms in the body, the cough, the rewme,
and pestilent Ague, and other like grieffes and disseases, by mynistring the
abouesayd quantytie by the mouth, shall speedilye be delivered. This borrowed
out of the skylfull practyses, of the Greek Leonarde Fierouant.

A water or Baulme of Hermes, borrowed out of that book, named Trotula, in the
end of the woemens passions: where he wylleth to take of Turpentyne three
times distylled over, and at last all together one pound, of Lignum aloes
likewise three times distylled over one pound, of crude Amber one pound, of
Nutmegs beaten and grynded on a marble, unto the manner of an ointment, with the
oil of the same added, unto the full incorporating of these to a mass: the
whole distyll nine times over. This Baulme dilygentlie keep to use, for it is
then perfect and susteyneth all trial of fire and water: it soketh through the
hand, and by annoynting the face with it, the same preserves youth, closes
and cures any cut or wound, clears marueylouslie the sight: and by
annoynting all the body with it, does defend the same from putrefying, and
from worms feeding on it: these hitherto has the Aucthour sundry times done
and experienced, and found a most certainty in them.

An oil of Baulme maystriall, borrowed out of the dispensatorie of the
college of Physicians of Florence: which wylleth to take of Turpentyne one
pound, of old Oil six ounces, of the oil of Bays four ounces, of
Spykenarde, and of Cynamon, of each two ounces, of new Tyles well baked eight
ounces, these after the well beating and laboring together, distyll in a
Lymbecke after art. This sends forth vryne, breaks the stone, kylleth
worms in the body, the rynging and noise of the ears proceeding of a gross
wyndinesse, the palsy, the fierce crampe, the ache of the hyppes, the pain in
the knees, and grieffes of the other joints: this speedily delivers and
helps by drincking and annoynting with it, but a small quantitye at a time,
and mynister of it, myxed with that water apt to the dissease, in the taking
by the mouth.

A marvelous oil of Baulme, that cures all manner of wounds, borrowed out
of the practices of that synguler man Gabriell Fallopio Modouese: take of
Turpentyne one pound, of pure Frankensence, of Masticke, of Myrre, and of
Sarcocolla, of each one ounce, of good Aqua vitae eight ounces, all these
dilygentlye beaten and myxed together, put into a Retorte strongly luted, with
the lute of wisdom, the same after the setting in Ashes, distyll according to
art, beginning with a soft fire, and increasing the fire after by little and
little, unto the end of the work: the same substance gathered, will be an
oil and water, which orderlye separate, and keep the one from the other a
part: this seperacion may you make and do on this wise, take a Glass funnell
fylling it up in a manner to the brymme with the distylled substance, holding
one finger in the mean time under, and that stopping the nether hole: by this
means, the water will fall to the sharper end, and the oil flote or swymme
above: which by warylye shyfting your finger (stopping the hole) now and then,
the water will slide or shed forth, leaving the oil fully behind, if you
be careful in the doing. These thus separated, keep in several glasses
dilygentlye stopped. The Oil is of such a virtue, that it heals all manner of
wounds, in a very short time, and without payning at all. And of this has
Fallopio made the proof many times, and especially on wounds of the head, in
closing or stitching first the wound, and applying after on the cut, with
lynt dypped in the Oil: for this synguler Oil dries the wound, defends it
from putryfiyng, and corrupting: and to be briffe, this Oil works miracles.
This secret did he attain of one M. George Catelyne a Genua, in France.

A synguler Baulme oil, drawn out of wax and Turpentyne, which dries, and
mightylie pierces, where the same is applied, borrowed out of the secrets of
Fallopio: take of the purest and clearest Turpentyne that can be gotten, one
pound and two ounces, of new yellowe wax, that is odoriferous, one Venetian
pound (which with us is twelve ounces) of Nutmegs, and of Cloves, of each one
ounce, of common ashes six ounces, all these after the beatyng, put into a
Retorte, fenced with the lute of wisdom, and set in ashes, distyll with a
slow fire at the first, after increasing it, until all be come: which
gathered, dystyll the second time in a glass body with a head, and Receauer,
putting into it before the distylling, four ounces of the powder of brick or
Tyles, which dilygentlye luted in the joints, maintain fire under, until no
more will come: then have you purchased an oil of a rubyne color, which
works miracles in wounds, especially where synewes be harmed: this also
helps any manner rewme, proceeded of a cold cause: it helps besides the
cough, by annoynting the region of the breast with it: and is also of great
importance, unto many other grieffes: invented and proved, by the abouesayd
Aucthour, infinite times.

An oil of Baulme, borrowed out of the practices of Petrus de Abano: take of
Mire, of Aloes, of Spykenarde, of Dragons blood, of fine Frankensence, of
Munia, of Panax, of Carpobalsamum, of Bolellium, of Amoniacum, of Sarcocolla,
of Saffron, of Masticke, of gum Arabicke, and of Lyquide storax, of each two
drams, of Ladanum, of Castorie, of each two drams and a half, of Musk half a
dram, of Turpentyne unto the wayght of all: these after the dilygent beating,
mix together, and distyll in a Lymbeck according to art. This may perform
and do all these matters, that are uttered before of the baulme oil in the
dispensatorie of the Florentines, yea and effectuousser.

A Baulme oil synguler, that forthwith eases and helps the Gowte, as well
cold, as hot, or of other accident. Take of Venice Turpentine two parts, of
new Masticke one part, of Opopanax, and of the ryndes of Pomegranates, of each
a small quantity and a like, these prepared, distyll according to art.

A perfect Baulme, helping the cold gowte, by annoynting the grieved places
with it: understood and learned of an Ancient Chymiste. Take of Turpentine
three pounds, of Frankensence, of Masticke, of Myrre, and of Ladanum, of each
one ounce, distyll the whole by a Retorte, and keep the oil.

A baulme of a certain Empericke, of great same and aucthority take of
Turpentyne four ounces, of Frankensence half an ounce, of Lignum aloes, two
drams, of Mastick, of Cloves, of Galingale, of Cynamon, of Zedoaria, of
Nutmegs, and of Cubebae, of each two drams, of gum Elemi, one ounce and a
half. This baulme marvelously works, in that it puts away the Leprie*
both ways, in applying of it both within and without the body: and many other
incurable diseases, as the Canker, and Fistulaes, and of the like kind.

Another baulme of a certain English man, with which he cured wounds, by
laying lynt upon wette in it, the Ague, the impostume or gathering under the
short rybbes, such short winded, the consumption of the Lunges, all swellings
except the dropsy. It eases bruses, the crampe and palsy of a cold cause,
and a drop mynistred to a person lying (or at the point of death) reuyueth
him. He took of Turpentyne two pounds, of chosen Myrre, of Castorie, of
Mastick, of each three ounces, of Olibanum, of Aloes succotryne, of each four
ounces, of the roots of C^nsolida minor one ounce* of Turmentyll roots, of
gum yuie, of the Indian nut, (and if you will of Nutmegs for it) of Zedoaria,
of each half an ounce, of Cubebae one dram* let al these be stieped two
days) then distylled with a slow fire.

A compounde water distylled, called the lycour of youth, which is a great
secret in nature, and is named the medycine of medicynes, and curer of all
infirmyties and disseases: take of Lignum aloes, of Cloves, of Galingale, of
Cardamomum, of Cubebae, of graynes of Paradize, of chosen Ruberbe, of Cynamon,
of the smaller Nutmegges, of Calomus aromaticus, of Mace, of each two drammes,
let all these be finelye beaten and searsed, to these then add of the juice of
Celondyne one pynte, of the iuyces of Sage, of Bryonie, of Rue, of Bytonie, of
Myntes, of Borrage flowers, and Buglosse, and of the juice of Fennel, of each
half a pynt, these after the well myxing and incorporating together, dystyll
