in a glass body with a head, according to art. Of this water take one
sponefull fasting every morning all the summer, and in the winter use two
sponefulles. For this water is right profitable to all sorts of persons, both
young and old, for this preserves the stomach in great strength, and
yields great strength of body, if that a great heat be not in the brain
and liver: and this delyuereth or recouereth that person in a consumption, the
iaundise, and the dropsy: this greatly preserves and helps the sight, and
comfort the hearing. This helps poisoning, and comfort all the members,
and preserves the blood in good color, and from any manner putrefying, and
helps a stinking breath.

A Baulme of a marvelous virtue, in tremblings, and the Palsy, which a most
synguler Physician kept pryuie to him self a time, as a most precious secret,
which in the end revealed to the Aucthour: the making of which is on this
wise, he took of Galbanum one pound, of gum yuie three ounces, these finely
beaten a part, myxe together, which after put into a glass body with a
headde, and distyll the substance in Balneo Mariae: this after distylled myxe
with one ounce of the oil of Bays, and of good Turpentyne one pound, then let
the whole be distylled, and separate the water from the oil, as before taught.
The use of this is, that the pacient vexed with the Palsy, convulsions, the
crampe, and trembling of members, be laid vpryght, and of this oil
temperatelye hot powered upon the bellye into the hollow and bottom of his
navel: and you shall see after a marvelous working that may rather be
accoumpted a dyuine, then natural, and very much helps the palsy, after a
collicke.

An oil or Baulme, that the like is not to be found, against tremblyng, the
crampe, drawings, convulsions, and the astonying of parts or members: take of
chosen Myrre, of Aloes hepaticke, of Spykenarde, of Dragons blood, of
Frankensence, of Numia* of Opopanax, of Carbobalsamum, of Saffron, of Masticke,
of gum Arabic, of Lyquide storax, of Storacis rubrae, of each two drams and a
half, of fine Musk half a dram, of Herba paralysis, two handfuls, of good
Turpentyne unto the wayght of all, these after the dyligent bringing to powder,
and incorporating the whole together, put into a Lymbecke, which distyll
according to art: for this according to the declaration above opened, is one of
the most syngular medycines: with which therefore, let the Nucha, and rydge
bone downward be anointed, of the person troubled with the crampe, the
trembling of members, the Palsy, the astonying of parts, and the drawings or
convulsions.

A most precious Baulme, helping the palsy, and many other grieffes, borrowed
out of Leonellus, a syngular Physician: take of Lignum aloes two ounces, of
Opopanax, of the Rosen of the Pynaple tree, of Bolellium, of Galbanum, of

A precious water and marvelous, which avails in wounds, ulcers, and
Fystulaes, and prevail against the plague or Pestilence, and the virtue of it
besides is marvelous, but the whole must be distylled by a glass body with a
head: For in such a manner of distyllation, do then three lycours appear,
having diverse colors, and each ought properlye to be gathered a part, and
powered into sundry glasses. And note, that the first water which comes,
avails against the plague, and ought daily to be druncke in the plague time
with a fasting stomach: this also comfort the brain, by drawing up of the
water by the nosethrelles: this besides destroys the piece of flesh grown
within the nosethrell causing a stynking air to issue, and all other defaultes
or euylles, growing within the Nosethrelles, in daily touching this piece of
flesh within the Nosethrell with the said water. If daily the temples, and
the pulses, be fomented with this water, and the rydge or back bone the like,
in a warm place (as a hot house) shall speedilye be cured. If any were fallen
from any place, let him then be anointed with the said water. If any has a
weak brain or memory, let the headde then be anointed all about, but the
forepart especially (being shaven) many times fomented warm with it, and he
shall thoroughly be cured. The said water drunck, maystreth and expels
poisons forthwith. The said water avails, against ulcers and wounds.
Against the Palsy of the tongue or other members, if they be impostumated or
cankered, and against any manner of sycknesse of the body. The second water
which comes, is like to oil, and is an oil, with which we may apply on
places of the body, in steed of the Baulme: for if you still one drop into
water, this drop then goes or falls to the bottom, and may be had or
gotten again. If you also throw a needle into the said lycour, it shall
swymme above. This also cowrdeth milk, and has all the virtues, which seem
to be and are in a Baulme. The third water, may be named a Baulme, whose
virtues be infinite. This borrowed of the learned Bertapalia: Take of the
finest Turpentyne (in the steed of Oleum vici or Lachryma, of which two
seems a contrauersie, whether to use, and yet in the end concludes, that
for the lack of either, to use Turpentyne, as not much dygressing from the
purpose) of this therefore two pounds, of pure Honey skymmed two pounds, of
good Aqua vitae one pynte, of Lignum aloes pure, of Santali muscati, of Mace,
of Cubebae, of Galingale, of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of Spykenard, of Masticke,
of Gynger, of Cynamon, of Saffron, of graynes of Paradize, of each three
drammes, of gum Arabicke three ounces, of fine Musk half a dram.

An oil serving unto sundry disseases, having the virtue of a Baulme, thus
discrybed of D. Gesnerus (as I think:) take of the best white wine two
measures and a half, of new Cow mylk (new milked) three ounces, of good Honey
eight ounces, of the roots of the Gentiane eight ounces, of Astrantia three
ounces, of Angelica two ounces, of chosen Baye berries one ounce and a half,
of Rue, of Juniper berryes, of dry read Roseleaues, of each one handful, of
Helycampane roots one ounce, of Cloves, of the sweet ryndes of the Cytrone,
of Calamus aromaticus, of Cynamon, of Annyse, of Fennel seeds, of Masticke,
of Beniamyne, of each half an ounce, these after the finely shredding and
beating together, stiepe in a large glass, or glasses (if you will) close
luted, and set in a hot place for seven or eight days. After dystyll the
whole with a head, and Receauer, close luted in the joints, so great and large,
that a third part or more of the body remain empty. This body set in fine
sifted ashes, and distyll in the beginning with a soft fire, after increase
the fire by little and little, unto the end of the work. But the Aucthour
supposes the first distyllacion ought to be done a part in another vessel,
and that the wine and milk to be first distylled together. Out of this
distyllation, are also three lycours gotten and gathered. This water will
avail against poisons, the Pestilence, the stone, the quartayne, the cotydiane
Ague, unto sweating, moving, etc. This also helps the hard fetching of
breath, and the obstructions or stoppings of the bowelles, unto all flewmaticke
matters, and unto the Falling sycknesse, and to defend or preserve also the
pacient from the Falling sycknesse. A man may like conjecture, that this
Baulme, for the making of a perfect Tryacle, to be aptlye and to good purpose
appointed.

The Aucthor of Nouia viatici, in the Chapter of the palsy, discribeth a like
licour to the baulme: take of the whitest Fra^kensence, and of Mastick, of each
two ounces, of Lignum aloes one ounce, of Cloves, of Galingale, of Cynamon, of
Zedoaria, of Nutmegges, and of Cubebae, of each six drams, of Myrre, of
Aloes, of Ladanum, of Sarcocolla, of Castorie, of each half an ounce, of Bay
berries, of the kernels of the Pyne aple, of each one ounce, of gum Elemi, of
Opopanax, and of Beniamen, of each two ounces, of the iuyces of Iua, and the
herb Paralycis or Cowselyp, of each three ounces, of good Turpentyne unto the
wayght of all, the whole dystyll in a glass body, after art. The first which
comes, is a water: the second, like to oil: the third like to Honey.

A compounde oil borrowed out of Aristotle, against the hot and cold gowte,
and against the incuruacions of the synewes, so that the synewes be not cut a
sunder, borrowed out of an Italian book written: take of Aqua vitae thryse
distylled, and of the juice of Byttonie, of each three ounces, of Saffron, of
the juice of Mugwoort, of the juice of walwoort, of the juice of Capreni or
Caprellae, of each four ounces, of the juice of march mallows eight ounces,
of Cloves, of Carpobalsamum, of Xylobalsamum, of each two ounces, of Ceruse, of
Frankensence, of the Tartare of the white wine, of each three ounces, of
chyldes urine, and of good Honey* of each eight ounces, of the oil of
Turpentine three ounces, of the oil of Eggs four ounces, of the oil of
Brymstone two ounces, of the oil of worms six ounces, of the oil of
Rosemary half an ounce, of the oil of Bays three drams: let al these be
distylled by a Lymbeck: the first which comes, delyuereth the person from the
hot gowte: the second* from the cold gowte, and heals any manner pain, in
what part of the body so ever the same shall happen, and be.

An oil or water, which is named of virtue, and a drinck of youth: borrowed
out of a high Dutche or Germayne book written, of one Michaell Schricke. Take
of Sage leaves three quarters of a pound, of Cynamon, of Cubebae, of
Galingale, of long pepper, of Annise, of Mace, of Nutmegs, of Gynger, and of
graynes of Paradize, of each half an ounce* these brought to powder, myxe
artlye, which power into six times so much wayght of good wine as the whole,
being in a tynne vessel, the same cover close, that nothing vapor or breath
forth, and let so stand in a hot place for fowreteen days. At the end of
that time, separate the wine from the spyces, by a strayner, and beat the
spyces then finer, that of the whole may be made like to a thick broth or
gruell, and with the aforesaid wine join the whole again, which then distyll
according to art. This water distilled and come, powered either on flesh or
fish, and lying covered in it, does defend and keep either from putryfying:
and wine commyxed with it, does not suffer it to corrupt, but rather clears
it, and if the wine presently be corrupt, this speedily restores it unto
perfection. This druncke fasting in the morning, consumes impostumes, and all
inner disseases, and heals also the outward grieffes, by fomenting on the
places: it amendeth besides any manner grieffes of the eyes: and wounds, by
applying of it upon, within eight days this closes. This druncke, causes
mirth, and mayntaineth youth. This besides avails in the disseases of the
head, and apoplexy. This water (to be brief) may be compared to baulme, for
it swymmeth above any other lycour myxt with it, except oil: dropped on the
fire, this burns. It cures the spots of the face, and druncke, defends
or keeps back the Leprie.

A certain sublymacio^ like to a baulme, in procuring of memory, borrowed out
of ( Michael angelus Blondus) of memory. In remembering to orderly purge the
stomach and head before, which done, prepare of Frankensence, of Cubebae, of
Cloves, of Nutmegs, of Galingale, and of Juniper berries, of each half a
dram, of Cynamon three drams, of Castorie fat, three drams, of Costus, and of
long Pepper, of each a dram: all these brought to powder, myxe a due
proporcion of Aqua vitae answerable to the whole: these put up together in a
glass body covered, set into horse doong to digest, for the space of a. xi.
days or more, and longer time if you will: after this time ended, sublyme then
this in Balneo Mariae, and to the sublymation add, of Mellis anacardini two or
three small ounces, and this then sublymed with the Honey, let be buried again
in a glass body under doong for ye space of two or three months, but let
this doong be changed every eight days, least too much or to strong a heat
may break or crack the glass: by such a space of time, thi^ sublymacion
shall be then perfect, unto the sharpning and quickening of memory. The use of it
is on this wise, before you would apply for memory by a days space, annoint
the temples and hinder part of the head, and instyll one drop into the
nosethrelles, after that, eat down fasting in the morning certain drops,
before you would rehearse or utter your Oration, or in any other manner
(exercise of memory) for this is the worthyest medicine of procuring memory.

An holly oil, which is very singular unto diverse diseases, for it especially
avails against any Canker and Fistula, and all old griefs or diseases,
borrowed out of a book of secrets in written hand. Take of old oil Olyue
two pyntes, of old white wine and the best, four pintes, of clear and the
best Turpentine one pound, of the seeds of Hypericon or Saint John's worte two
pounds and one dram, of the white Dittanie, of the Tormentill roots, and of
the Gentian, of each one ounce: all these brought to powder, and mixed together,
putting the whole into a glass body well stopped with paste, that no matter
breath forth, procure that they may boil in this manner. Let the said vessel
be set into a c^uldron filled with water and straw and boil there a time
softly, after raise it from the fire, and when it shall be cold, put that vessel
into a pot filled with sand, in such sort, that the whole vessel be
compassed and covered unto the neck with the said sand, which set in a place
where the sun all the day shines, and there let it stand, for forty days.
After draw it out of the said sand, and set it in the vessel of sand, in
such order and manner, that the sun for eight days fully, may with his beams
wholly compass about it, which time ended, strain ye whole through a new
lynnen cloth, and press out strongly the remnant in a press, the oil after
separate from the wine, and the same keep a part, put up into a glass close
stopped. This distillation ought rather be done in the month of July or
August, then in any other time. This oil gotten, avails against the Fistula
and Canker, if either be washed before with the abouesayd wine, and anointed
after with the said oil, shall speedily and soon be cured. This ^yle also,
helps all griefs, and pains of the synowes. This ^elpeth the ache of the
hippes, the pains of the joints, and a cold gowte. And if a plaster be made
of it, and Ammoniacum, does then dissolve the impostumes of the spleen, and
the hardness of it, in a short time, it does the like help, all other hard
impostumes. This avails in all passions of the ears proceedyng of a cold
cause, it kylleth the worms of the ears, and helps speedily the hyssing,
noise, and deafness of them. This also helps the Palsy and drawyng awrye
of the mouth, if the same be often anointed with it. It provoke the
terms, if of the same be aptly applied into the Matrice, and draws forth
the Embryo quick or dead. If a little of it be druncke, it dissolueth the
curded blood in the body. If a small quantity of this oil be commixed with
the Syrope of Roses, does then purge the Lunges of gross and clammie humors,
and such short winded. This marvelously helps all infirmities, and diseases
of the eyes, but especially, the Cataractes. This druncke avails against
poisons: for if the pacient shall drink a little of it, it extinguisheth any
person. It speedily cures the quartane and tertian Ague, if the back and
rydge bone be anointed with it against the fire, in the beginning of the
fit. This does immediately take away and deliver the crampe or co^vulsion of
wounds, if the same be applied warm on the place. This to conclude, heals
all wounds as well old as new, yea better and perfecter in one day, then any
other medicyne in a month.

A Lyniment or thynne ointment, as M. Michael Angelus Blondus writes in his
book of memory, which in virtue may be compared to a Baulme choose (says
he) of the best Turpentyne thyrtie ounces, of the oil of Bays, six ounces,
after that bring to powder, of gum Elemi, of the Rosen of the Pyne apple
tree, six drammes, of Sarcocolla two drammes, of gum yuie, of Ammoniacum, of
Bolellium, and of Frankencense, of each two drammes, of Masticke, of Aloes
Hepaticke, of Castorie, and of Ladanum of each one dram, of Galbanum six
drammes, of Xyloaloes an ounce and a half, of Cynamon, of Cloves, of
Nutmegges, of Mace, of Gynger, of Pepper, of Galingale, of graynes of Paradize,
of Cubebae, and of Zedoaria, of each one ounce, Xylobalsamum, Carpobalsamum,
of tormentill roots, of the white Dyttanye* of Liuerwort, of Celondine, of
both the greater and lesser Cons^lida, of each one ounce and a half, these
after the dilygent beating, myxe together, addyng to so much of Aqua vitae, as
to make and bring the whole into a form and body, which leave so for three
days, the fourth day following, add to it the Turpentyne, the oil, and
Rosen, and other of the gums which can not be powdered, these then sublime in a
glass body according to Art, making in the beginning a soft fire, but
continuing the fire unto the end, and for that three kind of lycours are
sublimed and gotten of the whole, as in the same, that the first which shall
come, will then appear yelowishe, the second and next oily, but the third of
a swartyshe color, and as the changing of colors, even so put under other
receauers, keeping each several and a part, and those close stop with wax,
that no air breath forth. But this one thing does the Author admonish and
give us to understand, that the fire be studiously cared for and looked unto,
until the sublimation of the whole shall be performed, for in the stopping or
slaking of fire in that time, the lycours could then not be thoroughly drawn
and gathered. These three lycours to be brief, or rather this sublimation
tryple wise, be indewed with properties, agreeable or answerable to their
degrees, yet the first of these lycours, is of lesser power in properties, then
the other, and ye second weaker in virtue then the third, so that the third
is mightier and worthier then both, or the other two. The report is, that
besides the quickening and helping of memory, they repress the hollow ulcers,
master the canker that it cleaves not to the bone, they also sease
convulsions, help cold rewmes, vanquishe the langours and griefs of the
stomach, and the cold tormentings of the body, especially of the Bowels,
they cure also the noise of the ears, the grievous pains of the teeth, help
the synew drawn together or shrunk, and they dissolve hard gatherings and
swellings they master and help many cold langours, and recover memory lost,
by annoynting the hinder part of the head with it, it draws down and
purges the head of all humors offending, through the help of the root
Cyclaminus, put up with it into the nosethrells, as the Author reports and
instructs. After this, let the pacient swallowe down, of the pills of Hiera
Mag* with Agaricke, one dram, and the day after draw up certain drops of this
oil into the nosethrells, in that this procures ye virtues of the brain,
quickneth understanding, and recouereth memory. If so be the temples and hinder
part of the head, be anointed for certain bays with it.

This also is a certain composition of a baulme: take of clear Turpentine
seven ounces, which wash well in wine, after take of Honey white, three pyntes,
clean skymmed over a soft fire with a little wine, to the same well clarifyed
myxe very well the Turpentyne, pouring upon four pyntes of good Aqua vitae, to
these then add of Borrage, of Buglosse, of Baulme, of Sage, and of Lauender,
of each one handful, of Hysope, of Camomyll, of Yarrow, of read Roseleaues,
of each half a handful, of wormewoodde one dram, of Rosemary two handfuls: to
these after add of Lignum aloes, of Xylobalsamum, and of the three Saunders,
of each one dram, of Mace, of Nutmegs, of Cynamon, of Galingale, of Cloves, of
Cubebae, of white Ginger, of long Pepper, of Saffron, of Spykenard, of graynes
of Paradize, of Cardamomum, of each one dram, of Zedoaria half an ounce, of
Squinanthum half a dram, of the ryndes of the cytrone, the seeds of the
cytrone, of Stoechas, of each one dram, of Calamus aromaticus, half a dram,
of Carlina that is cardopacia two ounces, of Bistorta two drams, of Ireos or
the flower De luce, half an ounce, of Baye berryes, of Valerian, and of
Polypodie, of each half an ounce, of Lycoryse, and of Annise, of each half a
dram, of Fennel seeds two ounces, of Colyander seeds prepared half an ounce,
of that wythie on the mountain, and of Cummine, of each one dram, of blaunched
Almondes, half a pound, of Reysons of the Sun washed with wine, half a
pound, all these orderly stamped and beaten together, put into the abouesayd
body or Cucurbyte with the Honey and others. And if there be not sufficient of
Aqua vitae, power then more upon the whole, letting these stand to digest for
seven days close stopped, after distyll the substance in syfted ashes, set
within three fingers breadth of the bottom of the pot, and the ashes artly
put about the body, the head and Receauer being artly luted in the joints,
that no air breathe forth, which after sublyme for four hours, with a very
soft and easy fire (least the Honey boyleth up) and a clear water then yssueth
and is gathered in the Receauer: after which, increase the fire, and you shall
see come a yellowe water, then draw away the Receauer, putting under another
glass, which you shall like lute as the first, to the nose of the head, the
first water then come, keep several and a part, and strengthen or increase
your fire. And when the yelow color in the water shall cease, make your fire
again stronger then before, and a water blackishe will issue, and when you
shall see a fume arise, then cease, for you have drawn sufficient, which
water also keep a part, letting the Cucurbite then stand to cool in the
Furnace, before the drawing forth. Into the first water put of fol^^ Iudi, one
dram, of Amber one dram, of Musk so much, and fifteen leaves or sheets
of Gold, which after the mixing diligently, keep. If you will apply of this
white water to the head, then add to it of Bytonie or of Buglosse water one
ounce, which mix and drink in the morning fasting. For this fortifyeth all ye
members. To an ounce of Malmesie or good wine, add a sponefull of this water,
which myxed together will be white as milk, the same drink with a fasting
stomach two hours before meat, and it preserves all the members. For the
liver, use of it with one ounce of the Succorie, Sage, Mulberie, or Endive
water. For the breast, and cough proceeding of a cold rewme, use of it with
Hysope water, or ye water of Louage. Unto the heart, minister of it with
Borrage or Buglosse water, or of Yarrow, with Wormwood or Baulme water, unto
ye stomach. For the Lunges, with the water of Lung wort* maiden hear, or
Polipodie. For the Spleen, with ye water of Hearts tunge. For ye gyddinesse of
the head, and Apoplexy, with the water of the Pyonie roots, or Hypericone.
For the Stone with ye Radish root water, or the water of Alkekengi. In the
retention or staying back of urine, with water^resse water, or the parcely, or
sa^i^rage water. For the eyes, with Fennel, Celondine, or eye bright water. In
the retention or staying back of the Terms, with the water of Mugworte, or
with the water of the roots and herbs of Mader. In the over great flux of
the terms, with the water of playntayne, or Solanum. In ye harming or hurt of
the matrice, through the ygnoraunce of the Mydwyfe, or of a cold cause,
whereof she can not after conceive wi^h child, let her use of this with the
water of Valerian, or Bytonie, or Lyuerwoort In the spots of the face, take
of Pympernell water four drams or ounces, of this water one dram or ounce,
which after the myxing, annoint the face with it, morning and evening, drink
also of this water, with the water of Endive, twyse or thryse in the week. It
cures the Canker by annoynting with it, and dropped into the Fistula speedily
heals it: this helps a cold ache in any of the joints, by applying of it
upon. In Agues, add to it of Folefoote half a handful, which put into a
glass with a quarter of a pynte of Alome water, letting these stand to dygest
for three days, which after shyfte into another glass, then of these an hour
before the coming of the fytte of the Ague, drink one sponefull, and annoint
the Temples, the Nose, the pulses, the back, and the Mylte. The Cytryne oil
has many virtues, if the same shall be anointed on grieffes. The black oil
is of great virtue in the joint sickness, even like to a baulme: and the
white, is named the golden water.

Take of Lauender eight ounces, of Sage so much, of Cynanamon, and of Mace, of
each one ounce, of Gynger, of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of each one ounce and a
dram, of Rubarbe, and of Galingale, of each one dram, of small Reysons two
ounces, of the graynes of Paradize, and of the red Saunders, of each half an
ounce, of Cubebae two drams, let the Reysons be beaten a part, and the spyces
put and labored a part, which after put al together into a Cucurbyte, addyng
to these one measure and a half of Malmesie or of other good wine, the same
then dilygentlye stop, setting it in new earth toward the Sun for
fifteen days, which after distyll by a Lymbecke, with a Receauer luted to it,
and beginning with a soft fire. Take of Turpentyne six drammes, of Diagridij
five drammes, of Ginger two drams, of Mastick, and of white Saunders* of each
one dram, of Sugar half a pound* of fine wheaten flower one pynte, make of the
whole a thynne paste* which bake after the manner of hosts or waver bread, of
which take one or two in ye morning fasting, with flesh broth, or Pease broth,
with Buglosse water. etc.

A most excellent oil for the recovery of the weak memory, for the coldness
and moisture of the brain: which very often proved on the Aucthour, and on
many others, to his great ^umendation. Take of Rosemarie flowers, as many, as
you think good, of these distyll a water: of this water then take one pynt,
the same put into an vrynall body of Glass, well fensed about with strong
lute, into which after put of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of the graynes of Paradyze,
of Cynamon, of Cubebae, of Mace, of Gynger, of each one ounce, of Musk four
carates (or sixteen graynes wayght) of long Pepper one dram, of Saffron
three drams, of Galingale two drams, all these brought to powder and myxed
together, incorporate with the Rosemarye water, which let stand to putrifye
for three whole days* after the setting in syfted ashes, distyll according to
art, and continue the fire unto the burning of the Feces, or that the Feces
rest burned. After get a pynt of the water of Rosemarye leaves distylled,
which myxe together with the said water, already distylled, these then powered
into a strong glass, and set into Balneo over the fire, boil unto the
consumption of the half: which done, take of the oldest oil Olyue that you
can find one pynt, of oil de Been one ounce, of Euphorbium, and of Castorie,
of each four ounces, of Mustarde seeds six ounces, of Oleum sesaminum, of
oil D^tiri, of the oil of Hypericon or Saint John's woort, of Olei citri, of
the oil of Spyke, of Olei ex cibeto, of each four drams: all these above
uttered, put into the glass body, which then stop close that no air breath
forth, setting ye same after in horse doong, sufficiently hot, for fortye
days, at the end of which time, draw the glass forth, letting it after stand
in the Sun for three whole months, and then have you purchased the oil
thus prepared, unto the abouesayde purpose. This is a lycour of such power and
virtue, that ye same puts away any impediment that may hinder memory, by
annoynting at night, before the going to bed, all the head about, and the
stomach. But this especially is to be remembered and noted, that you may not
use this anointing, all the three Summer months, but in any time else
throughout the year, you may use it safely, and without any scruple or doubt.
And for truth it is marvelous, and his working very great, and this I (says
the Aucthour) have often experienced, both on my self, and on many others, and
have always seen and understood a myraculous working of it, in a manner
incredible to be reported. Wherefore I wyshe all those, that would purchase a
good and ready memory* to use only this singular oil: setting a part all
others invented for the same purpose, as most vain and fryuolous. This
borrowed out of the most worthy practices, of the Greek Leonarde Fiorauant.

A marvelous and dyuine oil, borrowed out of the practyses, of the abouesayde
Aucthour, Leonarde Fiorauant. Which reuyueth the sick, and in a manner dead, by
receiving a drop or two of it by the mouth, in either broth, wine, or any
other lycour: take of the blood of a healthful young man, of Spermaceti, and
of the marrow of a Bull, of each one pound, of good Musk one ounce, of the
ashes of the Olyue tree (or for lack of it) of the young Oak tree two ounces,
these after the dilygent working and incorporating together, put up into a
Retorte artlye luted and set into fine sand, which after distyll with an easy
fire at the first, in artlie seperating the Elements. For the first water
which comes will be white: the second, a cytrine or yellowe oil: the third
lycour which comes, will be of a reddishe color, and of the greatest
property, which is most profitable unto diverse matters. But more of this
understand, in a place uttered before.

The making of a Baulme, borrowed out of the secrets of Gabriell Fallop. Take
of good Turpentyne, half an ounce, of Xylobalsami as much, of cloves two
ounces: these after the beating and laboring together, distyll according to
art: and the first which distylleth and comes forth, is a water, the second
an oil, and the third a Baulme.

Another Baulme borrowed out of the same Aucthour: tak^ of pure Turpentyne one
pound, of Aloes hepatick one ounce, of Myrre half an ounce, all these artlye
grynded and myxed together, distyll thryse over, and you shall then purchase a
Baulme, serving unto all matters. But unto the preservation of dead bodies, the
excellentest.

An oil, preserving the body in safety a long time, and sharpning or
quickening the wit, which is to be used after the exact^ purging of the body,
and a reasonable diet used the whiles or in the mean time. Take of the
Philosophers oil three pyntes, of the oldest oil Olyue* or at the least
sublymed by a Lymbeck, and Olei de alcana, of ea^^^ two pyntes* of the fat of
a Moele, of a Wesell, and of a Bear, of each two ounces, of Castorie three
ounces, of the juice of Acorus four pyntes, of the juice of Rosemarie flowers,
of the juice of Bytonie, of each half a wine pynt, of the juice of Clare, of
the juice of the English Galingale, of each four ounces, of the wine of Candie
two pynts, of burning water half a pynt, all these boil with a very soft
fire, unto a certain consumption, adding to these after of Ladanum, stieped
before i^ a sharp or eager wine, and well beaten, one dram and a half, of
Nutmegges half an ounce, of Mace, of Cloves, of Euphorbium, of the three
Peppers, of each two drams, all these dilygently beaten, put into a vessel,
close stopping it, which after let stand for thyrtie days, the whole then
distyll according to art. The use of it is in the winter, and once in the
week: but in the Summer time only once in a month: the head before washed,
and to the hinder part of the head, of this applied, but the temples before
being anointed: Fumanellus.

A description of Christ's baulme borrowed out of the learned practices of
Theophrastus Paracelsus: take of oil Olive one pint, of good wine three
pyntes, these myxt together in a strong glass* set after into Balneo Mariae
for a month, and of the oil will a lycour then be caused: but beware you fill
not the glass to full, for sufficient will it be, if to a fowrth part it be
filled. The alteration and amendment of Theophrastus: take of oil Olyue one
pynte, of the oldest red wine three pyntes, these after the myxing and
distylled: add to of the lycour of Hyperycone six ounces, of the lycour of
Mumia four ounces, distyll the whole for a month in Balneo, and keep to your
use: This avails in the wounds of the joints.

The making of a blessed oil for wounds, happening on the head, which this oil
heals dyuinely, whether there be a fracture of bones, or the perishing of the
pannicles: and that further, in any other part of the body, where either the
synewes, the muscles, or veins be harmed, or any member besides, this blessed
oil heals most easily, and in a very short time, without any danger, or
incombrance to the person wounded, and this many times experienced of the
Aucthour. The making of the blessed oil, is on this wise. Take of the oil of
the Fyr^^ tree, (...) ^ynd of Turpentyne most clear and fair, one pound, of
the whiles of new laid Eggs sodden hard in water, and the yolks taken
forth, fowreteene ounces, of Rosen of the pyne aple tree* six ounces, of
chosen Myrre three ounces, of gum yuie two ounces: all these artlye ^rought to
powder, and mixed together, put into a Retort, stro^glie fensed with the lute
of wisdom, the same after set in ashes, distyl with a most slow fire in the
beginning, increasing after the fire by little and little unto the end of the
work, until that all the substance be come, which will wholly be finished
in.xxxvi. hours: this distyllation then gathered will be a water and oil
blackishe of color, these separate, keeping either a part in a gl^sse: which
oil after the settling for a time, will become read, yet darck. And here note,
that if you draw these with a very soft fire, you shall the^ purchase a better
and sweter oil, as Fallopio affirms of experience* in his book of secreet^.
This oil miraculously heals al manner of wounds, and bruses, that especially
happen on the head: for that singular Surgiane Gabriell Fallopio, did
woonderful cures with it, among which, he healed a plowman of two such long,
and deep cuttes on the head, that were fearful to behold, besides a wound
that passed through both sides of his thyghe, that he healed only with this
oil, and with such expedicion, that it were in a manner incredible to be
reported: so yt where need is of drying, there cannot be found anything of
greater virtue then this blessed oil, so often and many times proved of
Fallopio. Besides the greek Fiorauant reports, that it causes hear to
grow on the head, and the hears of the beard shedding, this stays, and
causes them to grow again with expedicio^, by annoynting the weak place, and
the bare pla^e after a wound this also helps the pain of the flanks, and
retention or staying back of the ^ry^^, by applying a glyffer prepared with a
little of this oil with^^ the body, and this it does forthwith. For it
mightylie dries up that alteracion caused in the secret places within, where
no lo^all matter can be applied on the kydneys, nor otherwise de^^^ withal.
This oil first invented by the famous Greek Leonarde Fiorauant, and increased
by that worthy man Gabriell Fallopio* (...) ^^most precious oil for wor^^^*
whi^^ ^uer they be* borrowed out of the first chapter (...), written by
Bertapa^^a. Take of the kernelles of Peaches, of bitter Almondes, of Gentiane,
of wormwood, of Horehounde, or of Lupynes, of Colewort seeds, of the Peache
tree leaves, of the river or water Catmintes, of Oleandri, of Pellytorie, of
white Elleborie, of the roots of the long grass, of each half a handful:
all these dilygentlye brought to powder, and labored with the gaul of a

oil one ounce, of wormwood oil two wine pynts: all these after the dilygent

well stopped, which after distyll with a headde close luted, and you shall then
purchase a water and an oil, reuyuing and strengthening the disseased and sick
of the worms, by taking two scruples of the water by the mouth, with Malm^sie:
and by annoynting of the oil on the temples, and pulses of the hands and
feet, and all about the body, and the mouth of the stomach, and about the
shoulder points: By which doing, the Aucthour saw many children, in a manner
deadde of the worms, recover health in a short time after: and healed wounds
with this oil, and ulcers with expedicion.

Of Baulmes which are applied and used without the body: of which some are
prepared and done by distyllacion, and some without distyllation. The.x.
Chapter.
AN artificial Baulme, curing all old wounds, and helping the dryness of
members, and the members shrunck: take of Galbanum, of Ammoniacu^, of Mastick,
of pure Myrre, of gum Elemi, of Bolellium, of each half an ounce, of
Turpentine one ounce and a half, or two ounces, which is the better, of oil
Olive two pyntes, of Viridis aeris two ounces and a half, all these brought to
powder, infuse for six or eight days in the strongest vinegar* after
distylled by a Lymbecke, as in the first day by Balneo Mariae, and the next
day in sand: but if you will have it stronger, and of better taste, then add
these under taught, and let it be brought and done as before uttered: take of
Storax calam^^a; of gum yuie, of Spykenard, of Car^^e, of ^olophonia, of g^m
Traga^^^ite, of gum Serapine, of Opopanax, of each half an ounce, (...)
ph^^^bium, half a dram, of Viridis aeris three drams, of Turpentine one
pound. This baulme cures all old wounds, in a cold and hot cause. It
helps also the dryness and shrincking of members, if those shall be
anointed with that baulme.

A distylled oil, helping the trembling or shaking of the hands: let equal
portions of the oil of Bays, of Rue, and of Sage be distylled together, which
after ten days power into a strong wine, and distyll the whole in a
Lymbecke: with this water gathered, annoint the hands, and feet, and the
trembling members.

Another oil helping the tre^bling of the head: take all the abouesayde, which
put into Aqua vitae for fowreteene days, the whole distyll by a Lymbeck: and
with this water annoint the temples, both morning and evening. Here it is to be
understood, that where he speaks by the matters above taught, he means
not the oiles in this, but the Bay berries, the Rue, and Sage especially.

A distylled baulme helping and curing wounds, and deep ulcers: take of
Turpentyne six pounds, of Olibanum half an ounce, of Lignum aloes, of
Masticke, of each one dram, of Cloves, of Cynamon, of Zedoaria, of Nutmegges,
of Cubebae, and of Galingale, of each three drammes, of oil Olyue six drams,
these brought to powder and myxed, distyll with a slow fire: this helps the
cold poisons of Toades, Fistulaes, Noli me tangere, the Palsy, and venymous
wounds with or by a Tente. Here in this place besides is to be noted, after
the mind of Theophrastus Paracelsus, that baulmes prepared and gotten by
distyllation, are not to be applied at all on wounds, of which let others
judge.

An oil effectuous and proved, for softning of the synewes, or palsy, and the
shrincking of them, or the crampe, the falling sickness, or Epileptia, the
trembling of parts, and any cold disease: it increases also memory, and the
understanding. Take of Galbanum half an ounce, of gum yuie five ounces, these
after the bringing to powder, distyl in a Lymbeck, and mixed after with one
pound of Sebesten, distyll the whole again: with this anoint the hinder part
of the head, and the nape of the neck at night, before the entering into
bed: this borrowed out of Fumanellus.

The best oil, serving unto all the synewes, and unto the joints, and helping
marvelously all the aches, happening in the hyppes, the knees, the hands, and
feet, the body before purged* after the beginning of the sycknesse: and let
the grieved place be anointed at the fire, or in the Sun, twyse a day. Take
of chyldrens vryne twentye pyntes, of Brymstone one pound, of vnflaked, Lyme
two pounds, let the Brymstone and Lyme be brought to powder, and the Vryne
^^^tyng a hand breadth above them, which boil together, until it shall come
unto a green color, after the strayning, boil again the grosser parts and
Feces remaining, with the other part of the Vryne restyng, and this do three
or four times, (and so often) until the vryne has lest his color: and
sees that which remains, unto the thycknesse of Honny, being cold, distyll
in a Glass body: the same which first comes forth in the color of water,
throw away: and the next which comes, being of a yellowe color, through
the fire increase, dylygentlye keep.

Another of the same man's.
An oyntmente helping Synewes cut a sunder, in what part of the body they
shall so happen, puttyng away swellyngs, and all manner of hardness in the
flesh, the Canker, the hollye fire, and any pain of wounds, and bruses, and
works more in one week, then any other medycine in a month.

A certain Physician (of small understanding) promysing and under taking
much, confessed that he healed many disseases, with this medycine alone, as
any manner ulcers of the Synewes, the grieffes of the wyntes, convulsions, and
swellings, and to be brieffe, to do more matters, than may decentlye be
written: the making of which, is on this wise: let three pounds of new
puryfied wax be taken, and stieped in twelve wine pyntes of the strongest
white wine: the wax soked through, let it be wrynged hard with the hand, and
put after into another vessel of the like bygnesse, having so many pyntes of
wine, and through wrong the wax hard prepared, and the wax put into a body,
which distyll after art, three times over, this keep to your use.

Another of the same man's.
The best oil for the Canker, and Fistula: take of the oldest oil Olyue two
pyntes or three, distylled with a sufficient small fire, continuing for twelve
days, the same which shall come, and be gotten, helps the pains of the
joints, and grieffes of the Synewes* the same which remains ^ee grounds in
the bottom of the vessel, helps Cankers, and Fistulaes, and by myxing
Caphura with it, works the perfyter.

Another of the same man's.
A water or oil of great efficacye in healyng wounds: Take of washed
Turpentyne, of the flowers of Saint John's woort, so much as you will, of
Olibanum in powder, of oil Olyue, and of fresh butter, of each a like
wayght, but little in quantitye, these distyll in a Lymbecke, that which first
comes keep to your use, and by increasing the fire, that which next comes
serves for wounds.

This likewise of the same man's.
A blessed oil for wounds, out of the secrets of Fallopio: read in the end
of the other Baulmes, more at large uttered their in this place; wherefore (for
repiticion sake) here wyllinglye omytted.

An artificial Baulme, for the healing of wounds, borrowed out of the Italian
secrets, of the famous Chyrurgian Gabriell Fallopio: Take of the clear
Turpentyne, one pound and a half, of the oil of Bays, of Galbanum, of gum
Arabicke, of gum yuie, of each one ounce, of Frankensence, of Lignum aloes,
of Galingale, of Cloves, of Nutmegges, of Consolida minor, of Cynamon, of
Zedoaria, and of Gynger, of each six drammes, of the white Dyttanie, and of
Lyquide storax, of each two ounces, of Leuaunte Musk, and Amber greece, of
each one dram, all these brought to powder, and myxed together, power into
eight pyntes of Aqua vitae, four times distylled over, which let stand
together for eight days, in a glass Retorte. At the eight days end* dystyll
the whole in an open Furnace, beginning with a soft fire, and a white water
^^^eweth as Milk: which diligently followed, you shall after see, a clearer
water come, then changing your receauer put under an other, gathering the
clear water apart. In this water is a whytishe oil contained, which must also
be separated and kept. This water, is named the water of Baulme, and the oil,
the oil of Baulme. After this, will an other water come, whytishe as common
water, which when it begins to wax and come forth black, change then the
receauer, putting under another, and this is named the second water of the
Baulme. After increase the fire, and a Baulme black in color* will then
follow and come, whose fume stincketh: The work or distillation ended,
separate the black water, from the black Baulme, that which remains in the
bottom of the vessel, keep in a glass, the same standing open for a good
space that the fumes may pass, becomes sweet of smell. The first water
anointed on the head, helps the rewme, deafness, the Leprie, the weakness
of sight, and marvelously heals wounds. The oil of Baulme does speedily
dissolve, bruses, bewtifieth the face, preserves youth, and is a divine
medicine in the piercing and searching of wounds, if the same be anointed, and
drunk in wine The second water, gives a comeliness of face, if once in the
day it be washed with it. The Baulme also, does excel the natural Baulme in
properties. The black water separated from the Baulme avails in all wounds,
proceeding of a cold matter etc. It is (to be brief) the most precious and
surest remedy unto many diseases.

An oil of great efficacy and power, in the closing of wounds, singular and
experienced. Take of Turpentine two pounds, of the flowers of Saint John's
woortten drams, of Frankencense in powder two ounces, of common oil four
ounces, of fresh, butter without any salt three ounces, all these mixed
together distill in a Limbeck, and the same which first comes, gather unto
your use, but that which remains in the bottom of the vessel, distill with a
fire encreas^d, the same gathered is mightier in the healing of wounds. This
out of Fumanellus.

A singular oil, helping the grief and pain of the synewes and joints. Take
of the oil of Turpentine one pint, of new gum Iuie six ounces, of pure
lyquid ve^uishe, of Frankensence, of each two ounces, these mixed together,
distill in a Limbecke, which keep to your use. This out of the same Author.

An oil, or ointment sharpning the wit, and increasing memory, out of
Fumanellus. Take of Stoechias, of Rosemary flowers, of Buglosse flowers, of
Borrage flowers, of Camomyll flowers, of Maioram, of Sage, of Baulme, of Violet
flowers, of red Rose leaves and of Bay leaves, of each, one ounce and a half, al
these put up into a glass body strongly luted with four pints either of
Malmesie, Rennishe wine, or Aqua vitae, let these so stand to infuse for five
days, and distilled, add to it of the best Turpentine, one pound and a half,
of Olibanu^, of chosen Myrre, of Masticke, Bolelliu^, and of gum Iuie, of each
two ounces, of Vernicis integrae, one ounce, of Mellis anacardi, three ounces,
all these brought to powder and infused for five days with the foresaid
distillation, in a boddy with a head close luted, distill again, adding to it
of Cinnamon, of Cloves of Mace, of Nutmegs, of Cardamomum, of grains of
Paradize, of the long and round Pepper, of Ginger, Xyloaloes, and of Cubebae of
each one ounce, all these finely brought to powder. To these add of Musk and
Amber greece, of each two drams, al these mixed together distill (after that
these added and put into the former distillation have remained five days) the
fire in the beginning soft, increase after by little and little, unto thend of
the work. The use of it, is, yt the same may be applied in the winter time
once in the week, but in the so^mer time once in a month* ye head before
being washed, ye temples and hinder part of the head anoint with it.

An oil helping the gowte, borrowed out of a written book, tak^ of
Carpobalsamum, of Xylobalsamum, of red corral, of long Pepper, of Nutmegs, of
each two ounces, of Saffro^ one ounce, of the fat of a Beuer, of the fat of a
Grype, or of the kydneys of a Weather, of the marrow of the bones of an Ass,
or of an horse, of each four ounces, of Turpentine six ounces, of old oil
Olyue, one pint, of virgin wax four ounces, of old Malmesie two pintes, of
live water frogs xxx. in number, of the juice of the tops of Canes or
reeds, of the juice of the wall yuie, which yeldeth yelow seeds* of the juice
of ye roots of Veruaine, of each four ounces, all these beaten a part, and
put after into a Limbecke, distill with a soft fire. The first water which
comes, will be clear, and helps the moist gowte: the third water
gathered, will be read, which avails in the cold gowte: and this remember,
that the frogs ought to be put alive into the Lymbecke, for this is an
approved m^dicine, and always found true.

A marvelous oil in the palsy, and shrincking of synewes, the falling
sickness, and the crampe, and helps any cold sickness, engendered of a cold
cause. Take of Galbanum half a pound, of gum yuie three ounces, these brought
to powder and myxed together, dystyll in a Lymbeck after art, the water and
oil distylling forth, gather in a receauer, into which put one ounce of the
oil of Bays, and one pound of good Turpentine, the whole thoroughly myxed,
dystyl again, the oil and water then gathered, separate the one from the
other, and the oil keep as a Baulme: for it matcheth and is like to the
baulme in all his virtues. A certain practyser, applied one drop of the
oil, on the pacientes forehead of the palsy, and another on his navel, and
he ^ncontinent arose, as amassed of him self, and was after an hour, delivered
of the grievous pain of a wound, in a certain place of the body: and the
shrincking of synewes he anointed with this oil, and the pacient was speedily
healed. And in other sicknesses and grieffes, was this oil diversely proved,
and found to be of great efficacye. The hinder part of the head anointed with
it, at the going to bed, and that in the morning he eats one dram wayght of
the Reysons of the Sun, it quickens (in a short time) the memory: This
oil helps the defenesse, and any sickness proceeding of a cold cause, and
helps besides the loss of smelling: this borrowed out of the Breuiarie of
Arnoldus de villa noua^^^ the Chapter of the palsy.

An oil of many virtues, but auayling especially in wounds, borrowed out of
the secrets of Fallopio: take of clear Turpentine two pounds, of the oil of
Line seed one wine pynt, of the Rosen of the Pyne tree six ounces, of
Frankensence, of Myrre, of Aloes, of Mastick, and of Sarcocolla, of each two
ounces (of Mace, of Saffron, and of Lignum aloes, of each two ounces) but these
three last, add to if you will. All these wrought together, put into a Retorte
of glass strongly fenced, which artly distyll in sand^, with a very soft fire
in the beginning, and a clear water shall come: but a red oil within a
whiles after will distyl forth, which seen, begin then to increase your fire,
and stronger and stronger unto the end of the distillation or that all be come,
after take away the receauer, and separate the water from the oil, which keep
apart in several glasses. The water within a time, waxes read, and the oil
will become of a Rubine color. This oil is precious, especially to be applied
on wounds, where the synewes, the bones, and veins be cut, for by closing
or stitching the parts and lips of the wound, and applying of this lycour
upon, it heals the same speedily, without any grief and pain to the
pacient. And Falloppio on a time, cured a scholar (being a young man) with
this lycour, which had fourteen wounds, and of these eight were deadly, by
sowing or stitching all the wounds, and applying only of this lycour upon, was
in the space of thyrtie days thoroughly cured, without annoyance to the
pacient. And of the wounds, of small importance, he healed a great number,
within four or five days, with the said oil, and used none other, so that he
concludes and proves this oil to be singular in his properties, and that a
man with it may do miracles, in applying of it on wounds, and ruptures.

An artificial Faulme helping and putting away the scarres of wounds, if
after a stripe, a great scarre shall remain on the face, or in any other
parts of the body: then with this Baulme following may you remove a scarre,
not wholly or altogyther, but in such sort, that it shall be little seen of
any. Take of Mastick one ounce, of the ryndes of the sweet Pomegranates, and
of gum Arabicke, of each half an ounce, of Saffron two drams, of English
Galingale, one ounce, of Carpobalsamu^, half an ounce, of Aloes ten drams, of
Frankensence one ounce, of Myrre one ounce, of Turpentine of the Fyrre tree
half a pound, of old oil Olive one ounce, those to be beaten, bring to powder,
and after the mixing together, put the whole into a Retort of glass strongly
fensed with the lute of wisdom, which order distill with a soft fire in the
beginning, and increasing after the fire by little and little unto yt end. The
receauer after the close sealing or stopping (after art) set into Balneo
Mariae, or bury in horse dung for ten days, which then draw forth, and use.
This perfourmeth the same, which the Baulme does, in all proofs.

The confection of a baulme, which is named a greeks baulme, borrowed out of
Tarquinius Schnellen bergius: take of Turbith two ounces and a half, of
Rhapontick four ounces, of Rubarb one ounce and a half, of long Pepper, and
of Cloves, of each two drams, of Gynger one ounce two drams, of Zedoaria one
ounce, a half, and two drams, of Nutmegges seven drams, of Cardamomum one
ounce, a half, and two drams, of Cubebae, eight drams, of Cynamon three ounces,
of the roots of Pympernell one ounce, of Annise six ounces, of Sugarcandie
three ounces and two drams, al these beaten a part or severally, take after of
oil Olive four pyntes, of the oil of Line seed one pynt, of the juice of
wormwood half a pynt: Let the oils be first heated, after put in the
powders, but beware that you heat not the oils over hot. After the putting
up of the whole unto a Retorte (or if you had rather in a Cucurbite) distyll
thrice over.

A secret water of good accoumpt, which puts away spots, whitneth the
skin, takes away spots, wrinckles, and pimples, causes besides, a clear
and most comely face, borrowed out of Bertapalia: take of Turpentyne sufficient
clear two pounds, and of the same draw a water by a Lymbecke, to the same
distylled and come of the Turpentine, add these powthered, of chosen Masticke
half an ounce, of the white and pure Frankensence three drams, of Tragacanthi
half an ounce, all these dilygently mixed together with the abouesayd water,
put after into a Lymbecke, and distyll the substance with a very easy fire,
that which then comes keep in a glass, close stopped. After take of
Barrowes grease strayned through a thyck cloth, one pound, of chosen Ginger
one ounce, of Cloves two drams, of Nutmegs three in number, of chosen Cynamon,
and of Euphorbium, of each half a dram, of Spykenard two drams, of Cubebae
half a dram, of Camphora three drams, all these after the finelye brynging to
powder, myxe artlie with the said Barrowes grease.

Also take of crude Mercury three pounds, of fine silver one dram, ye silver
finely file to powder, chopping ye powder over again, which after myxe with the
said Mercury, and of these two make an argenture, incorporate then al these
dilyge^tly with the abouesaid mixture of barrows grease putting altogether into
a glass body, and setting the headde artlye upon, distyll with a soft fire in
the beginning, but after increase the fire stronger unto the end of the work,
and the same which comes forth and is gathered in the Receauer, power into a
glass, dilygentlye keeping the same to your use. After take of the first
Turpentyne water half a pynt, and of this other myxte with the Barrowes grease
one pound, and these two artlie myxed keep in a glass close stopped. And
when any woman will use this water, let her w^ she her face well before, with
the water of the decoction of branne, after wyping very dry her face, let her
pause an hour after, and by applying of this water on all the face with a fine
lynnen cloth wette in it, will then cause such a comely whiteness to appear,
that will endure or continue many days after.

An oil having the properties of a Baulme borrowed out of a written book:

Of the Baulmes not distylled. The.xi. Chapter.
AN oil supplying the properties of a baulme, in the curyng of wounds,
borrowed out of a written book: take of the flowers and herbs of Saint John's
woort as much as you will, those put into glass with a narrow neck and mouth,
fylling the same full with old oil Olyue, or common oil, setting the same
after in the sun, for fifteen days, at the end of which time, power into
it, half a cup full of white wine, and laboring altogyther, set the glass
close stopped, into hot horse doong for fifteen or twentye days, which after
the drawing forth bind about with a small hand of hay, into which put then of
Myrre, of Mastick, of Venice Turpentine, and of Rosen, of each two ounces, or
according unto the quantity of the oil prepared, and let all these be finely
brough to powder, before the putting in, and the glass then close stopped,
that no air breath forth, set after into a kettle of water over the fire,
letting the substance in the glass boil for a certain time: and after the
same shall be sufficientlye boiled, strain the whole, through a common
strayner, and the refuse throw away: the oil preserve in a glass close
stopped, which the older it shall be before the occupying, the greater will be
his effects: and when you will use of it, heat the oil a little before.

orderly put into a glass, boil in Balneo Mariae, as above taught.

A good baulme of many virtues, but it does peculiarly close and heal ^^lde
wounds, without leaving manifest signs of scars, this also cleanses the
eyes, preserves the flesh from putrefying, and does marvelously help the
swelling of the joints, and pain of the hot gowte, this borrowed out of a
written book of secrets, in the Italian tongue: take of the lycour of the

into a glass, which set in sand to digest for fifteen days (the same lycour
strayning every third day) after set this in the Sun, for two whole
months. And note, that this ought to be prepared and made, from the middle of
the month of March, unto the mydle of June.

Another, take of oil Olyue two ounces, of white pytche one ounce, of Galbanum

Another, which receaueth all those, which are required unto the true baulme,
it easilye pierces all wounds, and on what wounds soever this is applied, it
spedily heals them: take of ye white Rosen two drams, let this be dissolved
in good wine, after strain it through a linen cloth, this lycour boil with a
soft fire, unto the consumption of the wine, after take one pynt of oil Olyue,
in which dissolve the Rosen with a soft fire, this done take of gum Ammoniacum,
of Galbanum, of Opopanax, of each one ounce, of gum Elemi two ounces, which
myxe together or stir so long about, until the same shall be thoroughly
prepared to use.

Another, of the same man's, take of Galbanum, of Ammoniacu^, and of Bolellium,
of each half an ounce, of Myrre, of Masticke, and of Olibanum, of each two
drams, of Turpentine two ounces, of Verdigresse half an ounce, of oil Olyue
one pynt and a half, let the gums be stieped for three days in wine vinegar,
in such manner, that they may wholly be covered of the vyneger, then let them be
boiled with the oil, in an earthen pot glased, unto the consumption of the
vyneger, after strain the whole through a lynnen cloth, wringing out the
substance thoroughly, then finely make the green Verdigresse into powder, which
diligently work and dissolve with the oil Olyue, and added to the lycour
pressed out, boil the whole, until it come unto ye perfy^ color of
grenenesse, which diligently keep in a glass.

Another, serving unto all new and old wounds, especially to those happening on
the head, take of Turpentine twelve ounces, of gum Elemi five ounces, of Rosen
four ounces, all these melt together, and when they shall be molte^, add the
pouders following, of Aristolochia long a two ounces, of Drago^s blood three
drams, with which let a mass be made after art.

A Baulme not distilled serving unto all ulcers and wounds, and through the
applying with tents, this then mundifyeth and heals. Take of the oils of
Turpentine, of line seed, of sweet Almondes, and of Roses, of each one ounce,
let the oil of Roses boil in a glass, with the grene Verdigresse, as much as
you can take up on a knyues point, and when it has boiled a little, strain the
same through a cloth, myxing it after with the other oils.

Another, take of Turpentine one ounce, of the Juice of ripe Lemmons, two
ounces, these after the putting into a possenet or skellet, set in such manner
over the fire, that it touches not the possenet, which let boil unto the
consumption of an ounce, after take up a little with an Iron spattle, and
^^still sundry drops on a cold stone, which so often do, until it shall be of
a red color: this then use, as the right and perfect baulme. This borrowed
out of the secrets of Fallopio.

An oil curing the prickings of the synewes, and wounds: of a practisioner
unknown to the Aucthour. Take of the Rosen of the pyne tree, two ounces, of
common oil one ounce and a half, of Turpentine one ounce, all these molten
together, strain dilygently, to which after add of Frankensence, of Masticke,
of each one dram, of gum Elemi two drams, of this apply hot on sylke to the
place.

The discriptio^ of a baulme in wounds of the bones, borrowed out of the
practices, of Theophrastus paracelsus: Take of the grease of Mumia, of the
juice of S. John's woort, of Centory, and of Sophia, of each seven ounces, of
the lycour of Myrre, of Masticke, and of Frankensence half an ounce, of
Litharge prepared, of the lycours of Centorie, Trebanae, Spicariae, Pastonicae,
of each one dram, of ye oil of Baies unto the weight of al, these bring into a
baulme after art.

A compound oil, proved many times, helping spedily such that be poisoned:
the making of which is on this wise. Take of the oldest oil Olyue one pynt, of
Aloes hepatick, of Ruberbe, of Spyknarde, and of Myrre, of each four drams, of
Turpentine, of white Dittany, of Ge^tiane, of Bistorta, of Camphery, and of
Madder, of each four drams, of Triacle, and Methridate, of each three drams, of
live Scorpions three score in number, but let the Scorpio^s before be boiled in
Balneo for four hours, after add to them all the others, letting the whole
the^ boil for other four hours, which after the strayning, keep dilygently
in a glass, close stopped. For this undoubtedly is, a divine lycour in such an
accident, in which as you perceive the Scorpions be, that are venomous beasts,
and their venom avails against venom, and such as are poisoned, even as one
poison (of property) drives out another, and as we daily see that a person
through druncke, by drincking after the juice of the Cabbedge with wine, does
sone after become sober, which the wine alone does not. A like to this, that if
a man happen to be burned in any place with fire, that the presentest remedy
is, to burn the same place again, as a sovereign help experienced. And a
like also to this, that if a man happen to be deep wounded, that he sheddeth
of the same much blood, the next remedy then is, as has been many times
tried, to let the pacient bleed of a vein. By these and many other like
reasons, the Aucthour here proves, that to drive forth poisons, a man ought to
do those, with the kinds aunswerable to them. But in such manner prepared,
that the matter alter not, and be by that means, a more harm to the poisoned.
For that cause, the manner of applying the oil against poison, ought on this
wise be done: when any needs ye use of this remedy, let the pacie^t then be
outwardly anointed with it, and take immediately two drams of it by the mouth,
with white vinegar, as well in the morning, as at night before the going to
bed, and he shall thoroughly be cured of any great poison. Unless it be
either Sublimatum, or dyamonde, which this remedy helps not, in that they be
no poyso^s, yet deadly myneralles, that in no manner can dygest, nor their evil
effect but little mytigated. Notwithstanding if any shall be intoxicated with
Sublimatum, he needs then no other, but to bath him self in Vinegar, to
drink plenty of milk, to eat often butter, and to drinck the whaye of
milk, at a sure and true remedy experienced. It shall also be good and
necessary, that the pacient vomitte once a day for a time, for the readier
purging and emptying of the stomach of that matter. This borrowed out of the
Greek Fiorauant.

The best oil, for the helping of Scroffles, fresh and new begun, especially
on children, which ^y it are soon healed, borrowed out the breuiary of
Arnoldus de villa noua: take of the roots of Tapsia, and of the Radishe, of
each one dram, of the old oil Olyue two ounces, let this oil with the roots
well beaten be put together into a glass, or into any other vessel, which
after put into a kettle of water, set over the fire, letting it there stand
unto a consumpcion of half the water in the kettle: of this oil warm, instyl
two or three drops into the ear of the pacient, on that side where Scroffles
be, and let this be done many times. And if through the oil, the care shall be
heated, or swell, in so much that some rottenness or matter begins to
yssewe forth: conceive then that only a little of this oil hot, put thus
every night in the ear, may so cure such Scroffles, and the matter of them by
the same shall so be emptied and wholly purged. And use or persevere with this
oil, after the abouesayd manner, until the pacient be thoroughly cured. But if
the ear shall neither swell, nor run any thing, then may you use other apt
remeedies to the purpose.

An oil, or certain great lycour of the famous greek Leonarde Fiorauant,
being a composition of most excellent virtue, in sundry workings: the making of
which, is on this wise. Take of oil Olyue twenty pyntes, of white wine two
pynts, these boil gently together unto the consumpcion of the wine, or unto all the wine be gone away in smoke. Which after power into an earthen pot
glased, stopping the mouth very close with clay, the same then bury two cubits
deep or more in the earth, and let it there so stand covered with earth for
six months. But the time when to bury or set this pot into the earth,
ought to be about the first or second day of August, and to be drawn or taken
forth of the earth again, must be in the month of February: which opened,
the oil will then appear, as if it were fyftie years old. But when you
mind to bury the pot, then put in these insewing: of Rosemary flowers, three
pounds, of Lignum aloes six ounces, of Frankensence, and Bolellium, of each
ten ounces. And after the drawing forth of the pot, and setting it in the
Sun, add these following: of Sage, of Rosemary, of Rue, of Byttonie, of
yarrow, of the root of Campherie, of Tamarisci, and of Bryonie, of each one
handful, of Galingale, of Cloves, of Nutmegs, of Spykenard, and of Saffron, of
each one ounce, of Sarcocolla, of Dragons blood, and of Masticke, of each two
ounces, of Aloes hepaticke, and of Rosen of the Pyne tree, of each eight
ounces, of Greek pytche one pound, of yellow wax, and of Barrowes grease, of
each eyghteene ounces, of S. John's woort with the seeds two pounds, of Musk
one dram, these after the dilygent myxing together, boil in Balneo, until the
herbs appear dry in it, and that no more substance seem to be gotten out
of them, which after the being on such wise, draw them forth, and strain them
through a cloth: to the lycour add for each pound wayght, six drams of the
natural baulme (of Fiorauants invention.) And when September is come, to it
add (in that month) two pounds of the fresh fruits, of that herb named
Balsami which be read: this done, you have then the greater lycour prepared
and in a readiness, which dilygently stop that no air breath forth: and this
lycour also, the older it shall be before the occupying, the better it works.
For this is of such a virtue, that it heals consumpcions, and dropsies, in
the ministering four drams weight of it, with one ounce of the syrup of Roses
hot by the mouth, every morning fasting: which for forty days thus given,
does thoroughly cure them. This also is a true and perfect oyntme^t, with which
Petechiae are thoroughly cured, by annoynting the places sundry times with it.
And any wounded, and having the veins, the sinews, and bones cut, by
closing or stitching the wounds, and applying of this oil upon hot, shall in
short time be cured, without any alteracion or great pain to the pacient. This
also cures the scurfe, by annoynting those places of the head with it. For the
coldness of the head, and rewmes, by applying of it to the nosethrelles
morning and evening, shall speedily be cured, without the use of any other
thing: and this it does through his sharp savor and piersing, which enters
and flies to the head and stomach, and does so dissolve those corrupt
humors, both in the head and stomach: in that this is a lycour, which
preserves from any corruption. And if the stomach be anointed round about
with the oil, it procures a good digestion of meat: it also moves vryne
retained, or that cannot pysse, through a fleshinesse stopping it, or the
Gonorrhaea, or of any other cause. This causes besides the heirs to grow,
and preserves the beard black a long time, and avails against worms, artly
applied. And all these practices are most true, and proved many times in the
abouesayd diseases and grieffes, and in many others, and never harmed nor
pained any pacient with it, except such infected with ye French disease: for
annoynting any such with this, it mightily paineth him: by which at any time
you shall thoroughly be persuaded, whether the pacient be vexed with the same, or
any other disease.

A secret oil, and experienced, that heals the Legs vlcered, and all other

An artificial baulme prepared and made without distyllation, that avails in
wounds, and cures them without the ingendrin^ or procuring of matter: it
helps also the palsy members, and stay^th the blood, and water, which
yssueth out of the wounded joints, this borrowed out of a certain Emperickes
book, written in the Germayne tongue: take of Rubarbe two drams, cut and
pared into round balls, to which add of Camphora one dram and a half, these
after put into a tynne porrenger, pouring upon one ounce and a half of common
oil Olyue, the same let stand in the Sun for fowreteene days.

Another approved baulme, out of the same book: take a glass which is about a

good Sallet oil, letting it after stand for a month in the Sun, which
always stir about. To it after add of the oil of Violettes two ounces, of
the oil of Spike so much, of the oil of Camomyl, and of the oil of Roses, of
each two ounces: all these myxed together, let stand for a whole month.

Another of the same man's not to be contempned: take of Galbanum, of

half an ounce, the same taken from the fire, and become through cold, strain
through a lynnen cloth, putting the lycour dyligently up into a glass, to
your use: for this avails in all wounds, by applying lynt, and tents wette
in it.

Another ^el^^ng members, shruncke, borrowed out of the practyses of

Another of the same man's, auayling in wounds: Take of oil Olyue one pynt*

Of the oils gotten out of Flowers. The xij. Chapter.
THe oil of Spyke is thus prepared, if so be the Spyke be infused in wine, and
distylled, an oil first follow, where a water otherwise by distyllacion (I
guess in Sand) should be separated. This oil anointed on the region of the
kydneys, helps the Gonorrhaea. A certain friend (of the Aucthours) having
his wife now and then sick, procured to be ministered to her in a draft of
wine, but two drops of the distylled oil of Spyke, which after she had
druncke down, was brought by it in great hazard of life, but through it, she
voyded soon many worms, and recovered within short space.

The oil of the common Spykenarde, which is brought out of France, does
Brassanolus commend: but he affyrmeth that little worth, or of lesser accoumpt
to be made of, which certain prepare and make of the Lauender in Italy: the
same (writes he) that many name a Balsamyne, and use it in the steed of a
natural baulme. Of the oil of Spyke, which many used in the steed of baulme,
and of his properties: was fully and at large uttered in the other book, or
first part of the treasure of Euonimus.

The oil of the flowers of Verbascum, is thus made: stamp the flowers in a
mortar, which after the putting into a glass, set in the Sun close stopped,
for five or six weeks: this oil much avails and is right profitable for
the gowte in the feet and other members. It cures also fresh wounds, and if
the same be infused in the oil Olyue, it will then serve unto many grieffes.
The flowers ought to be gathered, when they be dry, for the virtues sake.

The oil made or drawn of the flowers of Tapsus Barbatus, infused in oil or
wine, and set in the Sun for five or six weeks, or boiled in a double
vessel, like the oil of Hypericon or S. John's woort, and artly strayned:
avails in the ache of the hyppes.

The oil of S. John's woort, is hot and dry, and stipticke, through which it
closes and heals the wounds of synewes cut, and the burning of fire: it
ceasseth also the pains, about the privy place, and bladder, and procures
urine. The preparing and making of the oil, is on this wise, borrowed out of
the natural history, of Adamus Leonicerus. Take of the tops being presently
full ripe, of S. John's woort three ounces, let these be stieped in pleasant
wine for three days, after let those boil in a double vessel, stopping
dilygentlie the mouth of the vessel, which in a redynesse wring hard out,
putting in a like wayght of the Hypericon fresh gathered, and infusing it in
like order, as above taught, which after boil, and strain, and do this a
third time: and if the wine be dyminished before the end, then add a little
more, according to discretion. Take after of clear Turpentine three drams, of
old clear oil six ounces, let these be boiled in a double vessel unto the
consumption of the wine, after the strayning and clear purging of it, from the
sedyment, power the oil into a glass.

The oil of Hypericon, learned of John Tanwyler the younger, a singular
Chyrurgian in the City of Auguste: take of the flowers of Hypericon or S.
John's woort, four ounces, these infuse in red wine for fowreteene days,
after boil these a little, which after the strayning forth, put in other
fresh flowers, unto the quantity of four ounces, of the oil Olyue half a
pynt, let these stand to infuse other eight days, which after strain, adding
to it of the juice of yarrow two ounces, of the earth worms washed in white
wine, two ounces, of Turpentyne one ounce and a half, of Saffron half a dram,
of Masticke six drams, of Myrre, and Olibanum, of each two drams, of
Opopanax, and of Sarcocolla, of each two drams and a half, of madder three
drams, let all these boil together, unto the consumpcion of the wine and
juice: which after the strayning, keep close stopped in a glass.

A compounde oil of Hypericon, borrowed out of the wonderful practices of
the Greek Leonarde Fiorauant, which avails and cures by a marvelous manner
wounds, especially of the sinewie parts: in that it closes them, and
brings those to a scarre, without sign to be plainlye seen. This also
dissolueth bruses, avails against poison, and helps any crude kind of
venymous Ague, by annoynting all the pacientes body, without omytting any
part: and many other virtues has this oil, which for breuitye are here
omytted: the making of which, is on this wise. Take of the Flowers, Leaves,
Stalks, and roots of Saint John's woort, as much as you will, which stamp
together in a mortar, stieping it after in the best white wine, as much as will
well cover the substance, the same let stand in the Sun for ten whole
days, pouring into it after of oil Olyue, as much as the wayght of the whole
with the wine, these then let stand in the Sun for other ten days: herein
considering, that the oil before be wayed, whereby a just wayght of it may be
known. This done, add for every pound of the oil, two ounces of good
Turpentyne, of Saffron one dram to every pound, of the Nutmegs and Cloves, of
each half an ounce to every pound, of Myrre, and Rosen of the Pyne tree, of
each fifteen ounces for every pound, of Vitecella two ounces for every
pound: let all these be put into a body of glass, well incorporated together,
which after set into Balneo Mariae, letting it there boil, with the head close
set on, and the Receauer artly luted to the nose of the head. The note when
this is sufficiently boiled, when the head distylleth no more forth, and this
will be within twenty hours or there about: this seen, draw forth the body,
and whiles the substance yet boyleth, strain the whole through a cloth,
keeping this lycour close stopped in a glass, as a precious iuel: for with
this (as we have above vttred) may many matters be done, so that you lay of
this hot on the upper face of wounds, with out the applying of tents within:
and in such manner doing, you shall win great praise, and have prosperous
success at al times. For the Aucthour (many and sundry wise) proved this oil,
to his estimation.

The oil of Hypericon (although the same may many ways be prepared and made)
yet this way and manner is the perfitest, invented by a singular Chirurgian of
Dadna, named Gabriell Fallopio: take of Bolellium, of Opopanax, of Galbanum, of
gum Serapinum, of gum Elemi, of each one dram, of Turpentine, of Rosen of the
Pyne tree, and of Masticke, of each one ounce, of the earth worms washed with
white wine two ounces, of Antimoniu^, of the flowers and leaves of Hypericon,
of playntaine, of the greater and lesser Consolida, of the greater and lesser
Centorie, of the yarrow, and of Canda aequina or horse tail, of each three
ounces: al these yt are to be beaten, somewhat broken before, which then myxe
together in a glass body, with so much oil (but better the same shall be, if
it be with the oil of Roses) as will well cover the whole substance, and
infused thus in the oil, let the glass stand in the Sun, for fifteen
days. This oil with the whole substance put into a Retort, which dystyll
with a soft fire, for the first that comes is a water, the next yt follows
(by a stronger fire increased) will be an oil, at the coming of which change
the receauer, and maintain the fire unto the end of the work: the
distyllacion ended, add the water and oil together in a glased pan, which
boil for an hour: to which after add one ounce of Madder, of Graua sina
half an ounce, of Saffron two drams, and a handful of the flowers of S. John's
woort, putting it again into the glass, where the whole substance standing in
ye Sun was. But if you will make a most precious oil of it, burye the glass
with the lycour in the earth or horse doong, for six months: of which after
apply on any wound, and you shall then see a miraculous working of this oil,
for it seaseth the pain of wounds, it dries up, cleanses, and comfort,
and does the same which may be wrought by any, and is especially profitable to
wounds of the synewes. The use of this oil is, that it ought to be applied
hot on the grieved places.

Another mastryall composition, of the oil of Hypericon, right profitable for
wounds, borrowed out of the Italian secrets, of the abouesayd Aucthor: take
of common oil Olive, that is sweet, and pleasant of taste, as much as you
think needeful, into which put so much of the Hypericon, the flowers, and
seeds, as yt oil will well receive, this let so stand in a glass, until the
oil appears read, into which after put these: of Turpentine one ounce for
every pound of the oil, of Nutmegs, of Saffron, and of Beniamine, of each one
dra^, for every pound of the oil, of claryfied Barrowes grease, two ounces for
every pound of the oil, of yarrow, of read Roseleaues, of Campherie, and of
Cummine, of each one ounce and a half, for every pound of the oil, of the best
wine two ounces, for every pound: let these infuse together, for the space of a
month, after shyft all the substance into a glass body, with a cover which
set into Balneo, letting the substance there boil, unto the co^sumption of the
wine, and dryness of the herbs: after the taking forth, strain the whole
through a lynnen cloth, which preserve in a glass close stopped. This oil is
