marvelous, used on wounds: if so it be applied hot with lint, or a fine
lynne^ cloth upon yt wou^d. This oil also avails against poison, and helps
Petechiae, and swellings or knobs, by anointing of it on the places, and that
with expedicion. And with this oil has ye Author done many singular
practices, to his high co^me^datio^.

An oil of the Orrenge flowers, take Melone seeds well broken, so many as you
will, of these straw a part in yt bottom of a broad or gallie glass, on which
straw a bed of the flowers of yt Orrenges, upon that straw another course of
the seeds: which done, let them so stand for a day, after the throwing away of
the flowers, put in fresh flowers to ye seeds, in like order as above taught:
this do for sundry days together, in shyfting the flowers, until the seeds
have purchased the virtue and savor of the Orrendge flowers, which sprincled
and wette somewhat with good Rosewater, put up into swear lynnen bags, these
wring hard in a press, pressing the oil.

The oil of the Iasemyne flowers may in a like manner be purchased, by
ordering the flowers as above uttered: and if you think the yield not
sufficient at a time, then may you increase the same (in my opinion) with the
iourdaine Almondes clean scraped, and broken after discrecion.

An oil of the Damask Roses, may in a like manner be obtained: if so be you
break Almondes into small parts, being clean scraped before (and not
blaunched) and ordered as above taught, of the oil of Orrendge flowers: which
after put into bags, press forth an oil.

An oil of Roses by sunning, is prepared and made on this wise, as Rogerius in
his fowrth treatise and eight Chapter instructs. Take the Flowers of green
Roses, and fill the glass with the flowers and oil, in such manner: that to
one pound of Roseleaues, be two pounds of oil added, which dilygently
stopped, set the glass in the Sun, for forty days, sturring about the
flowers once a day. After such a decoction, strain it through a Lynnen
cloth, into a Basin of fair cold water, and labor or stir the oil about
with a Hasill stick white scraped, after shift the oil into another Basin of
cold water and sturring it, and this do ten times together. For through this
often washing, it purchases a coldness in working, and a lesser dryness. By
which it does after more cool, and moysten. Also the substance put into a
glass and set in the Sun, until the moisture which enters the powers, may
through the same be consumed. In a cold country, where through a weak heat
of the air this can not be decocted, let the glass be set into a pan of
water, that it may there softlye boil for two or three days, unto a third
part of the oil away: and if that country has not oil Olyue, then draw an
oil of fresh Nuttes scraped, with which make your oil of Roses: or otherwise
use old Nuttes scraped clean, and stieped for two days in cold water, after
let an oil be pressed forth. Whereof the Aucthour alleges, that the milk
drawn or made of fresh Nuttes, may so safely be given to the sick of the
Ague at all times, in a cold country: as the Almonde milk, in a hot
country. This oil also above taught, has sundry properties, for if a
pacient vexed with the Ague, be daily or often anointed about the forehead,
and temples, and paulmes of the hands, the soles of the feet, and on the
beating veins of the wrestes, this note only represseth the pain of the
head, and other parts, but alters the heat and procures sleep, yet this
in no case, may be done in the sick day, where you hope of the universal or
particular action. A singular remedy commended, that the yolks of Eggs be
labored with the oil of Roses, and laid plaster wise on the region of the
Liver, or upon a fyrie impostume: which being once, or twyse applied, does
marueylouslie mitigate pain, and does dissolve the fumositie, and sharpness
of matter. And the same cleanses the place or swelling to fall, and remooueth
the redness from the place. This oil also mixed, with a like wayght of the
juice of plaintayne, for a glyster in the blooddy flux, or perylous scouring
with blood is greatly commended, this does speedily bring wounds to a scarre,
and mytigateth the pain, by repressing the matter.

These oils before placed, although they be prepared and gotten without
distyllation, or but by pressing out, or otherwise made by the Sun: yet would
I not omytte them, in that these forms and ways, seem easy, comely, and to
skyll invented: and oils being thus prepared, may aptly be applied to men's
use, and vtilytie.

The oil of Violettes, is prepared and made of Violettes, in the like manner,
as the oil of Roses (out of Rogerius) and serves to like purposes, as the
oil of Roses, saving that the one ofter the new making is laxatiue, and the
other bynding. If with a like wayght of ye juice of Mercury, this oil be
applied in glyster wise, in the sharp daily, and renewing Agues, and
Tertians, the same gently does louse the belly, and easilye expels the
superfluities, by the excrements sent forth. This out of Rogerius.

An oil helping the spots of the face, which commonly we name Lyntelles:
take a sufficient quantity of the flowers of Rosemarie (which put into a
glass) burye it in hot horse doong, in a place free or safe from rain, for
thyrtie days, or unto the time, the flowers be dyssolued, after set the glass
in the Sun for o^^er nine days: putting into it then of the powder of
Pollypodie, so much as you may take up with three fyngers: of which let the
pacient every day take, for one whole month.

An oil of the Rosemary flowers not distylled, may be drawn and made after
the manner ensewing, borrowed out of a certain written book in the Italian
tongue: take of Rosemarie flowers, a good quantity, putting them into a pot,
and thrusting them hard down with a staff. After power upon of oil Olyue,
so much as shall be sufficent, that a part of the pot remain empty: which
done, close and stop dilygently the mouth of the pot with paste, that no
air breath forth. The pot ordered on this wise, set or bury in horse doong,
not made of hay: in such wise letting the pot stand, that the doong be more
then three fingers above the mouth of the pot: the same so standing for
forty days, draw after forth, and keep the oil carefully. When you will
use of the oil, strain it through a cloth. This mightily helps in the
grieffes and pains of the Loins, the ache in the hyppes, the Arms, and other
parts. It is in the like manner appointed, and prepared of the Earl De alta
villa.



Of the oils out of Seeds. The.xiij. Chapter.
SEeing that sundry Spyces, and the seeds of all herbs in a manner, be rather
of a hot, thin and ayreall substance: for that cause, it must needs
insewe, that these possess a certain oily substance. In that every oil in a
manner, has a like myxture. Now oils distylled or gotten out of seeds, as
well hot, as cold, are purchased in this manner.

These oils by distyllacion drawn in Sand, ought on such wise be prepared,
that the seeds before the putting into the Cucurbite be bruised, and the glass
very well fensed about with the lute of wisdom. And there may, six, or
seven, or eight ounces of any seeds bruised, be put into the glass at a time,
or more if you will, but this according to the greatness of the Cucurbite.
After power five, or six, or seven pyntes of the clearest water at a time on
the seeds, myxing the whole dilygently together. Which thus myxed dilygently
in the infusion, let stand to infuse, or dygest, or putryfye, in some hot
place, for certain days, as either eight, or ten days, after set the
Cucurbyte into a pot apt to the Furnace, which fill so with Sand, that the
Cucurbyte standing in it, touches not the bottom, by two fyngers breadth, and
that a good thycknesse of Sand be round about the body. And let the oil be
distylled in the same manner, and with the same vessels, as shall after be
uttered: whereas we teach the order of drawing of oils, out of Spyces and
wooddes. This by the way does the Aucthour warn you of, that at the first you
make a soft fire: and take heed, that the substance contained in the
Cucurbyte, boyleth not up unto the Lymbecke or headde. For certain seeds, as
the Annise seeds, through the thynnesse of their substance, and clammynesse
together which they possess, do myghtilye boil up: for which cause, you
may not by and by fyxe on the headde: but after you see bubbles arise, and the
vapor carried upward, take of the Lymbecke, and puttyng in a fair stycke,
stir the substance well about. And on such wise may the foam or bubbles be
resolved into vapor, and breath up, which may after with a mean fire, be
qualyfied, and increased, at the will of the Practysioner. Which thus mytygated
or alayde, set on your Lymbecke close luted about, and distyll or draw so long
until you suppose that no more oil be contained within, which by sight and
taste, you shall easilye and soon perceive. For when the drops distylling,
in taste, carry with them no more virtue of the manifest qualitye of the
seeds and Spyces put in, then must you cease gathering any more, least the
matter stick, or burn in the bottom of the Cucurbyte: this borrowed out of
Cordus.

A preparation of oils out of seeds, as of the Fennel, Annise, etc. Is
wrought after this manner, as the Aucthour gathered and learned, by the sundry
letters written unto the singular Gesnerus in the German tongue. First, I
took (says he) such a quantity of seeds, as I thought necessary, but a
five or six pounds alwaeys: those I so stamped or beat in a gross manner,
that I left no one seed unbroken, which I then powered into the Cucurbyte.
After I powered upon so much scalding or very hot water, that well covered the
seeds, and then set on the Lymbecke or head, close luted in the joint about,
and stopped the nose, that no air breathed forth: which standing to putrify
for three or four days, I after distylled with a soft fire, and a fair oil
followed (so that the water by which the oil passes, be very cold) as you
were before taught. This one matter is worthy to be considered, that the oil of
Annise seeds can not in the Summer time be distylled at all, for that their
spyrites then are over subtle, and the Fennel seeds at that time much
subtyller then them: which they euaporate through the heat in that season,
how easy so ever you make your fire under, or labor you^ distyllacion. So
that the aptest and meetest time for the dystyllacion of these, is in the
winter: in that the colder the air shall then be, so much the sooner, when the
oil shall fall into the Receauer, will it be cowrded together, like to
Camphora. Which when after you shall strain through a fair cloth, all the
water then runs through, but the oil remains on the cloth: which I after
(says the Aucthour) dyssolued in a gallie or broad mouth glass set in a
stewe or hot house, and the flewme so separated.

In the distylling of such manner of oils, must first be considered and noted,
that a man may not prepare and distyll more then half a pound at a time.
After remembering, that the matter to be dystylled, be brayed or broken in a
mortar, after a gross manner, and not in a subtle or fine powder. To this
matter then let a due quantity of pure water be powered, that it may cover the
seeds, which after power into a copper Cucurbite, and well myxed together, set
on a copper head, close luted to the body in the joint, that no air breath
forth. This distyllacion then ought to be done through a vessel filled with
cold water, the tynne or leaden pype retching to the nose of the head, whereby
the oil (in the distylling) may not burn. All which thus prepared, make a
very soft or slow fire in the beginning, until the Furnace waxes hot, then
increase your heat or fire, more and more, as the matter begins to distyll:
the water and oil all come, separate the one from the other, after art. When
this begins to distyll, you may withdraw some of the fire, and mark whether
the fire being at that stay, the distyllacion nevertheless proceeds, then
must the stronger heat or fire be left, and the other followed and mayntained:
but if otherwise, then let the heat be increased. Thyrdly must be considered
and learned, that the oil first distilleth, so that at the coming of the
second, or third oil, the receauer may be changed. And within an hours space
in a manner, will half an ounce be distilled and gathered in the receauer. So
that when no more lyquidnesse appears on high, in the Cucurbite, then will no
more matter distyll forth: and the work upon this sight, is fully ended.

The oil of Annise seeds, is thus prepared and drawn: take of Annise seeds
(for this is a common form and way, unto the distylling also of oils, out of
other seeds) one pound, these after ye gross beating, r^t into a horned or
croke necked body, to which let the receauer be artly closed and fastened,
setting the body the^ into a pot of ashes, the same distyl with a most soft
fire, and you shall gather a water and an oil in the receauer. The water you
shall draw forth by a reuoluing or repeting again of the whole substance: yt
oil remaining or tarrying behind in the body, whose use serves unto the
collicke passion, and pain of the bowels. But of the water is an electuary
made with Sugar, in the form of losings or Manus christi, of which one table
at a time, either after dynner, or after supper may be given or taken. For this
strengthens ye stomach and digestion, and puts away or expels wynd. This
at any time taken or used profits, but in ye morning especially: and helps
the lungs, the cough, and the obstructions or stoppings of choler, and helps
the inward parts. The use of it properly, is in drops.

The oil of Annise is much more in property, then the Annise it self, and in
working myghtier. Yet the natural heat, of the whole Annise seed, can never
be so exactly purchased, as to draw forth and separate a perfect substance:
although an artificial preparation may be wrought, and the same by man's
industry. For like as any meat, that the same may be taken and eaten, without
danger or harm, it needs before an outward preparation: even so must a like
preparation be wrought in medicines, that the subtyller parts be separated from
the grosser, before those be applied or taken within the body: for on such wise
prepared and ordered, may any medicine work the easier, and perform the
proper action in the body, without harm to the pacient. The use of this oil
much avails in the gyddinesse of the head, the hard fetching of breath,
proceeding through a dangerous Rewme in a manner suffocating or choking the
person, in the weakness of stom^ck and wyndinesse, in the dropsy, in other
cold diseases, and those procured of wynd. This also much profits the
members lacking blood; and the synew parts, as the stomach, the veins, the
bladder, the bellye, and the white flux of the womb this mightilye stays.
This oil may be taken or ministered by droppos, in gyuin certain drops of it
either in wine, or in breath in the morning, or in time of necessity.

The oil of Fennel seeds helps the head, but the eyes especially, the
kydneys and bladder: Tables may be made of the same, of like propertyes, and
unto the same uses: or certain drops may be mynistred alone, at any time: or
else taken morning, and evening. And an oil is drawn, out of the dry seeds,
without any other addicion, it is very pleasant and sweet of taste, as the
Aucthour proved and felt of the same: the same also in color is white, that
first distylleth.

The oil of Cummyne drawn, is profitable to wounds, joining near unto the
Mylt, the swellings of the body proceeding of a cold cause, which sometimes
happens and is the cause, why the vryne is stayed back: unto this use may a
drop, or two, be mynistred in Fern water, or in Tables, if they be made with
it.

The oil out of Henbane seeds, prepared in the same manner, as the oil of
Roses, by the description of Rogerius, avails the like, that the oil of the
apples of Mandrake does. It avails also in the hot joint aches, in
repressing mightily the pain, and causing an astonishment to those places
applied: in burning and in excoriations, it may procure and make a little
scarre, and mytigate the burnings, out of the same Aucthour.

The self same Aucthour, does otherwise prepare the oil, which works
stronger and to greater purpose in the abouesayd burning. Take on Mydsomer eve,
the tops, flowers and leaves, with which let a new pot be filled, having in
the bottom a little hole, and let the mouth of the upper pot be dyligently
stopped, which set into ye mouth of another pot standing under, the mouth of
which lute round about with the other, that no air breath forth: this done,
set the pots so deep into the earth that they may wholly be covered and buried
in the earth, after let them stand for a whole year in the ground: at the
end of which time, draw the pottes forth, and you shall find in the nether
pot a clear oil, which by the heat of the fumosities of the earth, is
drawn forth from the Henbane. This manner of instruction is found perfiter, in
the description of the oil of yuie berries (where is otherwise left in the
earth for six months) with this are members laboring and sore payned with
daily fluxes falling to them, anointed.

A compounde oil out of Seeds, procuring sleep: Take of the Seeds of
Lollij, of Henbane, of the white and black Poppie, of the Lettuce and
Purcelane seeds, of each four small handfulles, of the seeds of Faba
inuersa, which is Telephium, two small handfulles: let all these be distylled
together: of this distylled, mynister two scruples wayght at a time, with a
little or small quantity of Opium.

Of the oils out of Fruytes. The.xiiij. Chapter.
THe oil of Juniper berryes, is distylled in the same manner, as the Aqua
vitae, by pouring water upon, and it then speedilye and easilye distylleth. As
an oil first comes, and a water next inseweth: even in the like manner, as
when the Spike is distylled. But it behooves to break the berries before.
Some also distyll them in a body: this avails unto many grieffes, unto the
gripings of the belly, unto the mattering of the yard, which is as the same
were the Gonorrhaea, unto the pains or grieffes of the neck, proceeding of
Rewme. Agyrtae or Iuglers publishe marvelous matters of the same oil, which
who that list may read their tables imprinted with them. But the manner how
this oil ought to be distylled, is on this wise: I took (says the Aucthour)
a pynt full of Iunyper berryes, which I brake somewhat small, upon which I
powered pure water, such a quantity as very well covered them, after I powered
the whole into such a copper vessel, as the same is, in which the Aqua vitae
most commonly is distylled, and with a copper pype also passing through cold
water, did I distyll, having under a bygge Receauer, fastened to the pype,
which might well receive or hold four measures of lycour: and on this wise,
did the oil distyll and come, with the water. But another instrument I used
standing on the head, which I filled with cold water, for ye better cooling of
the spyrites, that they burned not in the coming. Out of the abouesayde
quantity of berryes, I never drew above three ounces of perfect oil. There is
a further instruction, for the drawing of this oil, in the first part of
distyllations.

By pressing out also in this manner or on this wise, we draw and get an oil
not evil sauouring: take of Juniper berryes broken, first myxt with burning
water, and after with oil Olyue: let them boil a little, or at the least let
these be infused together, often sturring them with a spattle, for eight days,
then pouring them into a body, distyll in a Furnace after art, the oil after
swimming above, gather into another glass: you may then put into it a little of
Angelica, or some other thing a little bruised before.

The Mandrake apples are cut into quarters, and boiled in oil, in a double
vessel, in a cold country as before of the oil of Roses, out of Rogerius was
taught, or you may otherwise prepare the Oil, by the heat of the Sun. This
Oil avails the like in contynuall and burning Agues, which the Oil of Roses
does: but in that this oil stupyfieth and mightier alters, more then the
oil of Roses does, it ought (for that cause) that the malice or hurt be
repressed, with woman's milk myxed, the same oil also avails, in the hot
aches, and gowte. This borrowed out of Rogerius.

An oil out of Bay berries, does Rogerius instruct to make many ways: take
the green berries, those break small, which after the sufficient boiling,
strain through a cloth, and keep the lycour in a glass. Otherwise, take a
quantity of ripe bay berries, and those after the finely breaking, boil with
bay leaves after art, and the same strayned, keep dilygently in a glass. Or
after the baye berries be finely broken, and infused for six or eight days in
wine, and then put up into bags, and an oil drawn by a press. Or the ripe
and fresh berryes broken, which after the putting into bags, an oil pressed
forth. This oil (as witnesses Rogerius) avails against the Colic, the
Ilyacke, and Sciaticke passion, or pain in the hyppe bone.

An oil out of yuie berryes, is gotten and made many ways, especially by
those ways taught above, in the drawing an oil out of bay berryes: this oil
purchased, avails against cold causes, especially against the cold joint
aches. Wherefore I affirm (says Rogerius) that whatsoever consists in the
yuie, avails against ache of the joints: whereof the oil, that myghtier
works, is on this wise prepared and made: take of the dry wood, the berries,
and gum of the yuie, if you can purchase altogyther, and the wood small cut,
put into an earthen pot, being full of hooles in the bottom, or at the least
having three holes passing through in the bottom, which set into the mouth of
another pot glased, the mouths of which stop close, with potters clay or
past: these two so ordered, set to deep into the earth, that the upper pot
stand wholly above the earth, and the mouth of the nether pot covered over
with the earth: which done, make a fire about the upper pot, and a black oil
will after distyll into the nether pot.

A Rape oil gotten, by pressing out: take a Rape, which after the making of a
hollow deep hole in the root, fill that hollownesse up with oil Olyue, on
which set the cappe or cover of the root, before cut of, and being thus close
stopped on the head, wrap the whole root dilygently about with towe wette,
which after bury in the hot ymbers with a few coals upon: this done, let it
there lie for half an hour: after which time draw it forth, and taking of
the cappe, preserve the oil strayned, and the root also strayned together
through a lynnen cloth. This oil avails against cleftes and choppes of the
hands, caused of cold. This borrowed out of a written book.

Out of the Pyne aple kernelles (I saw) an oil drawn or gotten by
discencion, which serves for the wrincles of women's faces: this out of
Manaraus.

An oil out of the Onyon and Triacle, provoking sweat in the pestilence, take
a big white Onyon, in the myddle of which make a deep hole, filling the same
with good Triacle, after the cappe set on and a wet lynnen cloth wrapped round
about* put it under the hot ymbers to roast for half an hour, which after ye
distilling in a Limbecke, give of this lycour, unto the quantity of two ounces,
to the pacie^t. The same effect works; six ounces of the distylled lycour*
of the green Nuts. This out of Fumanellus.



Of the oils out of Spyces: but the oil or water, to be gotten out of
Cynamon, see and read hereafter among the Barks. The.xv. Chapter.
THis general precept, ought to be observed, in ye distillacion of all spyces
in a manner: yt what spices soever you chose, bray the^ first into fine powder,
pouring upon a quantity of cunduite or spryng water, which after the same shall
be colored with the spyce, shyft into another glass, into which power other
fresh spyces broken: and so often do the same, until ye water purchase no
further color, then distyl it in Balneo Mariae, and separate after the water
from the oil: this G. Rast. But the waters and oils, which are preapared and
gotten out of spyces, ought to be done by the infusion in simple water, and not
in wine, or Aqua vitae in that those do hastily ascend, and not carry the
force of the spyces with them: but the water contrarywyse ascends not,
without the spyce. And to be brief, those are here to be applied, which are
before taught, of the oils out of seeds, in the beginning uttered to be done.

The oil out of Cloves, Nutmegs, Pepper, Mace, and Cinamo^, are made and
wrought through the spyces before broken, and put into a Cucurbite well luted,
or into a copper body, with a head set close on: which you shall distyll by a
pype retching through a vessel of cold water: for on such wise cooled, will a
water and oil come, which after separate, as the one from the other. For the
oil evermore swymmeth above the water, except the oil of Cloves, which
falls to the bottom.

An oil out of Nutmegs, unto the imitacio^ of this general rule, which a
certain Empericke teaches to be in a manner like prepared. Take a third, or
fowrth part of good Aqua vitae distylled, and the Nutmegs finely broken, put
altogether into a glass body, filled with the Aqua vitae, three fingers above
the Nutmegs, which let stand covered to infuse for.xxiiii. hours, and that the
Aqua vitae has attained a yellow color, the same then shyft into another
glass: into which pour after fresh Aqua vitae, so much as before, and the
same so often repeat with fresh Aqua vitae, until it will color the Aqua vitae
no more. Which done, power all ye Aqua vitae thus colored into a glass body,
which after the setting into Balneo Mariae, distyll according to art, that the
Aqua vitae may ascend, and the oil of Nutmegs remain in the bottom of the
body: and on such wise, shall you attain the oil prepared. In the like manner,
may an oil be altogyther distylled, out of all other spyces.

I saw, says one of Gesnerus friends, a distyllation of the oil of Nutmegs,
which was an oil drawn most pleasant and sweet, and of a great yield, by an
Alchymist, after this manner. He took the Nutmegs and brought the^ to fine
powder, on which he powered two measures of simple pure water, after he shyfted
the whole into a glass Cucurbite fensed about with yt lute of wisdom (this
lute was made with simple clay, to which he mixed the shorn floxe of cloth
tempred with salt water) eue^ as the Alchymists are wont to lute their bodies,
for the purchasing of strong water: after the head set on, he like luted the
joint of the head round about, and the joint of the receauer in the same manner,
that no spirits should breath forth. The body thus fenced he set into the
Furnace, making under a soft fire in the beginning, but next a bygger, and last
a strong fire: even as they do, which distyl the strong water: and drawn, it
was for truth an oil most excellent of savor, swymming above the water come
in the Receauer, which he dilygentlie gathered: for he affirmed the same to be
of great virtue in sundry matters.

The oil of Mace, is of a hot quality, and for that cause the use of it is
right profitable in the collicke passion, proceeding of a cold cause, and of
the rewme distylling or descending from the head: it comfort also the heart,
the stomach, and matrice. But a most singular help in especial, is felt of
this oil, in the tremblings of the heart proceeding of fear, or through the
stopping of the bladder, or matrice, it avails besides in the strangurie, and
helps all diseases proceeding of a cold matter. A three or four drops may
be ministered or taken by the mouth at a time, prepared with some other dayntye
matter, or in an iron Ladle or great spoone over the fire: or in a fresh draft
of good wine: this borrowed out of an unknown Aucthor, in the Germain tongue.

An oil out of Mace may be gotten, by pressing forth, in the same manner, as
shall after be taught, in the form and way of preparing the oil of Cloves.

An oil distylled out of Pepper, having all those propertyes, which the Pepper
it self, saving that the same burning which the Pepper procurrth on the tongue,
is not the like fealt (by taste) in yt oil. This oil of the pepper is none
other matter, then an ayriall element separated from the other elements: even
as the like we prove in the distylled oil of the vitryoll, and brymstone. In
the same manner, is the oil of pepper thoroughly separated from his burning, and
consists or has greater properties then the Pepper it self, and has the
singular property of piersing. In the Collicke passion, and parts stuffed
with much soft and clammy flewme, let two or three drops of it be ministered
or taken with broth, unto the cutting a sunder, and breaking away of it. I gave
(says a certain Practisioner) in the Tertiane ague, after a purgation, and
the bleeding by vain done, three drops of this oil, with one scruple of
Mina, two hours before the sytte began: and it let within once or twyse
taking* yea and maystred the cold, the shaking, and the Ague it self, to the
wonder of the pacient. And he further affyrmeth of it, that if this avails
not in the first giving, it wholly cures in the second time.

An oil of Cloves is like prepared and gotten as the oil of Juniper berries,
and not as the oil of Cinnamon. This oil is far sooner and easier purchased,
if the same distyllatinn be done with waters, as oyther ^ayne, or ponde waters,
or other more dayntie waters. The Cloves besides have a far more moisture
contained in them, then has the Cinnamon. There be some (yea many) which do
like prepare and get an oil of Cloves, by only pressing forth.

Take of Cloves what quantity you will, those beat in a gross manner, which
after stiepe in Rosewater so long, until you think it has thoroughly purchased
the qualities and effects of the Cloves. Then take a quantity of good
Almondes, clean and white scraped with a knyfe, those lightly cut into
pieces, which after infuse in the said water, that they may thoroughly drinck
in of the savor and taste of the Cloves, those then lay a sunder to dry:
which dried, infuse again in the said water, and those dry again, and this
do for four times together. After put into bags, press an oil forth,
which set in the Sun to purify for a time. And in this manner also may many
profitable oils be prepared and gotten, as an oil out of Musk, Amber, and
Beniamine, Storax, Cynamon and Mace. This borrowed out of a written book, of
the Aucthours.

An oil of Cloves, that is as the Cloves it self, being hot and dry, in the
third degree, which helps the stomach, the Liver, the heart, the humorall
flux of a cold cause, and all cold diseases of the stomach. The Cloves put
away Melancholy spirits, and clear the gross: but the oil does these far
excellenter, and as I may soothly affirm (says the Aucthour) it has all the
virtues of a Baulme. For this does heal outwardly fresh and green wounds. It
stateth, the yssewing of blood and water, out of wounds. It comfort within
the natural parts, it purges Melancholy blood, it comfort the heart and
head, and does especially help, the gyddynesse of the head, and weakness of
sight: if in the morning three or four drops of it be taken fasting in a
spoone, with some pleasant syrup, or other daynty thing, or in wine.

Of the oil of Cloves, writes another: who thus says, this I dare affirm,
that it has the virtues of baulme: I saw (says he) a wound closed and healed
by it, without stitching, by one Ioachimus Rhoeticus. And as touching the other
worthy effects of this oil, I (by silence over pass) which this does in
strengthening, and in restoring especially decayed strength. The oil of Cloves
druncke, to the quantity of two or three drops, in the broth, or ^ulleys of
a Capon, does then avail in the Colic, and suffocations of the womb. Tables
or losings prepared and made of the oil of Cloves, and eating of them morning,
and evening, do strengththen the head, and stay rewmes.

Of the oils out of gummes, tears, or lycours thyckned, or coniealed, and
Rosens. The.xvj. Chapter.
THE ^ COVER


THe oils of Gums, or Tears, may thus be distylled: take of G^ins, what
quantity you will, those put into a Retort set in ashes, which in the beginning
distyl with a soft fire, but after increase, by little and little, until no
more will come, and the oil power forth, which must thus be rec^tifyed: take
an other fair Retorte, into which shyft the oil, the same set into ashes,
distyll again with a very gentle fire, and you shall obtain a most pure oil,
piercing, and entering much better the powers of the body. And in the same
manner rectyfy oils drawn out of wooddes, the seeds, and Baulme. Lullius
distylleth an oil out of a gum, or gummie matter, being before well brayed,
and infused for a day, in sour verguice, or sharp vinegar.



An oil out of Masticke, is gotten by descentio^, in a Retorte: in such manner
ordered, that ye fire be made both above, and under it, and you shall so
purchase an oil of Mastick, which after may be rectifyed, as above taught. A
certain Practisioner in ye worthy City of Auguste, distylleth it on this
wise: in taking whole Masticke, and it alone puts into a Retorte luted, unto
that part showing and lying without the Furnace, which has four vente holes,
and covered above: this with a soft fire distyll: for that which comes, is a
marvelous Baulme unto wounds. Note, I have distylled (says a certain
person, forgotten of the Aucthour) Masticke by a pype, but the same would
yield no more, then a savor or taste. Yet was that Masticke, nevertheless
light and ^orous in the bottom.

The water also which remained in the bottom of the Cucurbite, was of a
yelowishe color, and bitterishe. And to conclude, the Masticke in the boiling
(then by a Limbecke) loses a virtue, powered into the same matter, in which it
is boiled. Seeing ye essence of it, yields a greater virtue by a Lymbecke.

A confection of the oil out of Frankensence, and Carabe, peradventure also
out of Assa dulcis, Caphora, styrax calaminta, etc. Take first a body very well
luted, but of small length, and the neck somewhat broken of or cut away with a
big wire read hot, that the mouth of the glass may be the wyder (for into
the mouth of it must another glass be thrust) into which power your fine
powder of Frankensence, or of Carabe, unto the weight of half a pound. After
this, prepare another white glass of Crystal, having a broad mouth like to
our pewter quarte pot, into which you may power the hot water, and into
this set the first Cucurbyte, in such order, that the same may stand upright in
the myddle of it. Then close the Cucurbite about his end, being bored in the
top, into which hole set an apt Tunnel, that may have a tappe somewhat
higher than the hole whose narrower part, and end, may regard or lean toward
the glass with ye hot water, which thus prepared and done, power the whote
water into the Tunnel, and by opening or plucking forth the tappe, the hot
water may not then distyll down* by drops softly, into the vessel standing
under: and on such wise govern your water, that ye glass be not drowned, for
through this with the help together of the vapor of the hot water, a most
sweet and pleasant oil ascends into the Lymbeck, bearing with it, or having
the very savor of the Frankensence, which without ye working with this vapor,
does most filthily smell.

Johannes Manardus in his Epistle of the woormes.xxxi. writes that he observed
two simple oils preuayling against the woormes: as the oil of Frankensence,
and oil of vitryol, prepared by the Chymis^^^ (...) art. With the first
(says h^^) let the dully be anointed: but in ministering the second, the same
must cyrcumspectly be done* least the place may be uttered with it, if inwardly
it be given or taken. But there be which dare give, a little drop of it to
drink, with Mellarate.

An oil of Myrre, that mayntaineth the person long youthful, even as the
natural baulme does: for this oil by his natural virtue defends and
preserves all things from putrefying, which are laid into it: and this also
anointed on the face, mayntaineth a fresh and comely face, and that long
youthful appearing. This besides heals wounds marvelous soon, and cures
all inward grieffes, or at the least, a marvelous number of diseases, in
giving unto the quantity of two drams at a time by the mouth. This helps the
defnesse of the ears, by pouring certain drops into them: and mightily
avails against all manner of aches, proceeding of a cold cause: it preserves
the sight, by being distylled into the eyes, and especially one drop at a time:
and marvelous singular for women payned with the grief and disease of the
matrice: and it stays the sheding of heir, by anointing the places with it:
and annoynting all the parts of the body of him which has a grievous Ague, and
procuring him to sweat, shall speedily be cured of his ague: and many other
sicknesses, does this precious oil cure, if those be wrought after knowledge.
The making of which singular oil is on this wise: take of chosen Myrre, that
in no manner is falsyfied, six ounces, of pure Aqua vitae which has no flewme
in it twelve ounces, these after the myxing together in a glass body, set into
hot horse doong to digest, for six days. After the taking forth, distyl the
substance in Balneo with an easy fire at the first, until all the Aqua vitae
be distylled and come forth: for then will the oil carry behind in the
bottom of the body, which strain through a fine lynnen cloth, the same
dilygently keep in a glass to your use. And when any person will annoint of
it on the face, to make it seem at one stay, and comeliness, a long time:
let him or her make a decoction of Nettles in common water, and whiles the same
boyleth, let the party hold over his face, that it may by the same means
strongly sweat, after in drying the face very well, annoint forthwith the
face all about with the oil: and the like manner may be observed and used, in
annoynting the breast, the hands, and other parts of the creature, in
preserving that those appear not wrincled, and ill favored: as commonly they
do in old age. This borrowed out of the worthy Greek, Leonarde Fiorauant.

This precious oil of Myrre, is otherwise prepared and made by a certain
practisioner, helping the aches and pains of the Gowte, and serving unto many
other matters before uttered. Take of new laid eggs ten in number, which after
the hard seething, cut into just halfes: the yolks taken forth, fill those
hollow places with so much fine powder of Myrre in each, as will well
contain the half of the yolke. Which done, close the two halfes of the whites
of the eggs together, and putting or laying them in a glasen vessel, set after
into a deep seller, which let there remain for fifteen days, or longer, and
a lycour will then yssew forth, which keep dilygently to your use. And if the
making of this oil on this wise, seems not agreeable to reason and art, let
them read Mattholus last increase upon Diascories, where he utters the same
words above taught, etc.

Beniamine is the gum of a certain tree, which (in the Italian tongue) is
named Lasero Cirenaico, yt grows in India, and brought to Venice, and other
parts of the world, in very great pieces, being in savor most pleasant, of
which by art, may a most pleasant and marvelous oil be drawn, serving unto
diverse diseases, and very pleasant of smell: but who that myndeth to purchase
an oil, that for smell to be woondered at, let him prepare and draw the same,
after this manner. Take one pound of Beniamine, of Leuanute, or the East Musk
one dram, of most pure and fine Aqua vitae ten ounces, of the River sand well
washed and dried before, four ounces, all these after the myxing together, put
into a Retort of glass, of such a bygnesse, that the same may remain three
fowrth parts empty, after the substance put in, which then distyl in Balneo,
until all the substance be come: and when no more will distyll forth, draw
away your Receauer, and separate the water from the oil, keeping each a part
by it self: for you shall then inioye a water right pleasant, and oil of
Beniamine myraculous. The like for sweetness and savor not seen, nor
invented of any. This borrowed out of the rational secrets, of Leonarde
Fiorauant.

An oil of Beniamine is thus m^de^take so much of the Aqua vitae, as of the
Beniamine in wayght, which after the fine beating into powder, power together
into a short body and wide, the same after set into a pan or earthen pot with
ashes, the head close luted about in the joint, and receauer the like with
past: this done, distyl in the beginning with a soft fire, until all the water
be distilled and come. Which dilygently keep, in yt the same serves unto
sundry uses: after increase the fire by little and little, and when you see the
oil distyll forth, increase the fire bygger and bygger, until you shall have
obtained all the oil. And in the end will follow a certain gum, like to
Manna, which avails unto the making of pleasant sweet water, with spryng
water, but better and sweeter will it be, being made with Rosewater. This
borrowed out of the Italian secrets, of Gabriell Fallopio.

Another oil of Beniamine well commended, take of Beniamine one pound, which
after the fine beating into powder, power into a body with a head (or rather
into a Retort) on which pour then of Rosewater two pynts: the joints after
dilygently stopped, begin to distyll with a soft fire, until all the water be
come, then increase the fire until you see the oil distyll, which appearing,
increase the fire stronger and stronger, until all the oil be gotten, which
rectify in the Sun. And in the same manner altogyther, is an oil distylled of
the Storax, both Calamita, and Liquida.

An oil by distyllacio^, of the Lyquide storax, is thus made: take of the
Storax what quantity you will, the same put into a retort, upon which power so
much of good Aqua vitae as the wayght of ye Storax, and to every pound of the
Storax, put in three ounces of river sand well washed and dried, which after
the diligent luting set into ashes, beginning first with a soft fire, and after
the appearance of ye oil, increase ye fire stronger and stronger, until al ye
oil be distilled and come. And in the end of ye distyllatio^, when certain
fumes come into the retort which savor, draw away the receauer, putting under
another, for the odoriferous oil otherwise would be spylt and lost: after
separate the oil from the Aqua vitae, which keep in a glass. This out of the
rational secrets, of Leonarde Fiorauant.

An oil of Ladanum, is drawn and gotten on this wise: take of Ladanum what
quantity you will, which brought to powder, put into a copper body tynned
within, on which power a pynt or half a pynt of Rosewater, according to the
quantity of the Ladanum, and about half the wayght, power in of the oil of
sweet Almondes: after this set on the head like tynned within, and close the
joint about, as you do in the other oils: after let the substance boil in
your Furnace, for a reasonble time. In this, it behooves to use your own
discretion in permitting it to boil, either a longer or shorter time,
according to the quantity of the substance, put into the body. And before you
draw the oil forth, let it thoroughly cool in the body, which after keep in a
glass to your use. And that the same may the longer and better be preserved,
put into it a little of roch Alome burnt, or of Ambra cana.

Of the oil of Turpentine. The xvj. Chapter.
THe ancient in times paste used alone the Turpentyne, and not the oil, yet
the oil is the thynnest part of the Turpentyne, helping the cold grieffes of
the synewes, and all cold and wyndie diseases: in the hard fetching of
breath, and shortness of wynd much auailing, if two drams of it be taken in
the morning fasting for a time together. This also is profitable in the
gathering of matter in the bulk of the stomach, and in all manner of paynfull
grief in the breast, proceeding of flewme: the Collicke passions also, and all
grieffes that comes of wind: it corrects besides, and brings to fair
pass, the scarres of wounds. Very fair is the oil of Turpentyne, and has
few Feces or grounds in the bottom of the body, after the distyllacion, for it
is in a manner all oil of it self, and the greatest part of it, is by
distillacion gotten or drawn into oil. For an oil is purchased out of it,
either by force of an extreme cold labored, or of an extreme hotenesse
done: even as out of all matters in a manner, this may be drawn.

Also this distylled oil of Turpentyne, heals scabbes, and the choppes of
them: the brain it heateth and comfort, by putting up a feather into the
nosethrelles dypped in it, and draws forth flewme without snysings: this
heals besides, the chops of women's breasts. For the recovering of memory,
defnesse, and the crampe, this obtayneth principality. That wounds may
speedily be healed, take the oil of Turpentyne, and heated by the fire, myxe
with it an equal part of Viridis aeris, which after keep to use. This learned
out of the written book, of a notable Empericke.

The proper manner of distylling oil out of Turpentine, read among the
Balsams: and in the first part, of the treasure of Euonymus.

A simple oil of Turpentyne, which has many virtues, in sundry grieffes: take
of clear Turpentyne, what quantity you will, and for every pound put three
ounces of the ashes of a hard or strong wood, which after the myxing together,
and put into a Retort, set on a Furnace: and in the beginning distyll with a
soft fire, until all the moisture be drawn: after increase the heat with a
stronger fire, until all the oil be distylled and come. Which keep diligently
in a glass, for this is the simple oil of Turpentyne, which serves unto many
grieffes: and heals simple wounds in.xxiiii* hours; by applying the oil
upon. It is right profitable and auaylyable in sinews ^hrunck, proceeding of a
cold cause: in taking one dram of it by the mouth with white wine or other
wine, procures the pacient to pysse speedily, and dissolueth all the
windynesse of the body. This also helps stitches in the sides: and
marueilously* cures pestilent Agues, by mynistring the same quantity (above
taught) by the mouth: and by annoynting the mouth of the stomach with it,
causes a good digestion. This borrowed out of the Italian secrets, of
Gabriell Fallopio.

Another of the same man's, I have distylled (says Fallopio) in Padna, an oil
out of Turpentyne in the same manner, with washed in sand myxed, which so let
that the Turpentine did not hastily ascend: this I tried, to be a marvelous
oil in wounds.

A compounde oil of Turpentine, against the crampe, and other open pains,
take of clear Turpentyne one pound, of oil Olyue ten ounces, of
Frankensen^s, of Sarcocolla, of Mastick, and of Saffron, of each one ounce, of
Panis porcini, of Cauda equina or horse tails, and of Madder, of each one
ounce, of earth worms washed three ounces, all these incorporate well together
in a pan, over a very soft fire: which then pouring into a Retort of glass;
distyll in the beginning with a soft fire: after increase the fire unto the
end of the work. Which ended, separate the oil from the water, and the oil
keep dilygently in a glass. For this is a myraculous lycour, against the
crampe: and marvelous sone heals wounds, bruses, and other grieffes of the
body. This out of the secrets, of Gabriell Fallopio.

An oil out of Turpentyne ( Larigna) marvelous against the shryncking of
members, if members be anointed with it, borrowed out of an unknown writer,
to the Aucthour. He took of Turpentyne one part, of Vitryoll calcyned one
part, of Apples dried and brought to powder without skin or paring one part,
of oil Olyueene part, of burnte Tyles one part, all these synelie brought to
powder, and myxed together, he let stand in a pot glased, in a hot place,
for fowreteene days, sturring it about each day. After the whole he distylled
by descention, in a vessel (which most diligently be luted, of three fyngers
thycknesse) and through dried it, before the occupying.

An oil to be drawn out of Turpentnie with Sage, is on this wise prepared and
done, which preuayleth against the palsy of the members, left after an
Apoplexy, or Hemiplexie. Let be put into a glass Cucurbite, named a Retorte,
of the green Sage leaves finely shred, about one pound, to which add the same
quantity^ of Turpentine, which may suffice to the forming of a certain paste
with the Sage, that the same may be handled with the hands, that is, that of
the one there may be as much, as of the other, and so much in the end, that
after both myxed there be no more, than may fill two third parts of the
glass Retort. This before remembered, that the Retort be dilygently and
strongly luted about, after use and art. Then set the belly of the Retorte
within the Furnace, fastened and luted dilygentlie in the joint after art, that
no air breath forth. And let your Receauer be of a sufficient bygnesse, and
strong, for if it shall otherwise be over small, then through the vehemency
of the spyrites, it will lyghtlie break. In the beginning proceed with a
soft fire, and with the same fire persevere or continue so long, until all
the moisture of the Sage shall be distilled and come, for after the same, there
is no danger in the force of the fire. But whiles the dystyllacion is in
doing, the neck of the Retort will be vehemently hot: when as in it shall no
other be contained or remain, then the excrementes of the Sage, and the
remnaunt or Feces of the Turpe^tine, which are none other, than that named
Colophonia* the neck shall then be cooled, although it may appear very hot,
in that no more does after ascend, which may heat the neck. Yet that the
whole distyllacion may be performed and done by a easier way, and with lesser
danger, and that the fire also may by a better means be governed according to
the necessity and will of the workman. For that cause are here two furnaces
placed, standing one by the other, of which the one serves for the fire, and
the other is for the Retort* this (for the Retort) receives the fyrie heat,
by an apt hole framed unto it, placed in the myddle between both, which may
one whiles shut, and another whiles open, according to the necessity of the
work, through the help of a certain plate or wyndowe of iron, hid between
both the Furnaces.

And when any matter is in the distylling, both the Furnaces in the mean time
ought to be closed and shut in all places, except certain vent holes in both
the Furnaces, that the fume may so pass by them. And that these Furnaces, may
appear playner to understanding, conceive this figure, here above discrybed.
With this oil (purchased by the means above taught) the payned members ought
moderately to be anointed.

An oil by distillacion of the ship pytch, anointed on places, does avail
unto the extenuation of resolved and weak members, yet does it not like
resolve, as the pytche lying a long time together. An oil out of the white
pytche, by distyllacion may be gotten, right precious: this borrowed out of an
Empericke, unknown to the Aucthour.

Of the oils gotten out of Barks. The.xviij. Chapter.
A Water or oil of Cynamon, is to be required and coueted before other waters,
and Oils: as the Cynamon it self in respect to other spyces. And the Cynamon
is of a subtle heat, through which it especially avails in the winter, in
that it strengthens then more the stomach, and marvelously puts away all
evil and corrupt moystures of the stomach, and defends it from corrupting
at all: it also sharpeneth the sight, and opens any manner stopping of the
veins and marvelously comfort the heart. But an oil distylled of it, does
answer in general to a natural baulme, which within helps all
putrefaction, and without the body cures all fresh wounds or ulcers. And the
distylled water mightily avails in all cold diseases, as well of men, as
women, especially which have a stomach so affected, that they have no
appetyte. When the spirits also be weakened, or the pacient weak, a draft of
this water, with a little of good Malmesie, o^ of the juice of the Pomegranate,
taken by the mouth, woonderfully avails and helps. Men in a manner dead, by
dropping or pouring a drop or two into the mouth, does recover the person in
a swoone or trance: especially which to old men many times happens, this is
the presentest remedy. Mydwiues and other motherlye women with us, carry of
this water with them, and use of the same with prosperous success, to young
women in the dangerous traueyle of child. For does in the hastening, and
helping forward of the birth, it is the worthyest remedy. The sundry manners,
that a water and oil may be distylled and gotten out of the Cynamon, shall by a
few examples here be uttered. Some there be which stiepe the Cinnamon before in
Rosewater, others in white wine* many draw it in a Cucurbyte luted about, but
then is the substance lightly burned. If the same be distylled in a bladder
(which the Apotetaryes use) it can not then be done without the great quantity
of Cynamon. The best manner and way of drawing these, is in the vapor of
boiling water: but as touching the rehersall of these, is here sufficient.

The Poticaries (certain years past) were wont, to stiepe the Cynamon for
certain days, in Rosewater, as that which regarded the heart, and was always
applied for the recovery of strength: and for that a little quantity of the
water, has not his smell, the water is esteemed of the lesser value with many.
And for that cause better it is, that the Cynamo^ be stieped before the
distyllation, in old pleasant white wine, for a certain time: For on such
wise prepared, the distylled water is caused the excellenter, and in piercing
more effectuous.

The manner of preparing a water out of Cynamon, which Gesnerus received of a
certain friend of his, that made great trials, and often distylled the same.
Let one pound of chosen Cynamon be gotten, which beat so fine, that the powder
may pass through a fine sieue, yet the whole you may not work to powder:
after put al into a Cucurbite, on which power of the water of Borrage of
Buglosse, of Endive, and of baulme, of each half a pynt, these let stand to
infuse in a glass close stopped, for four or five days. After out of this
Cucurbite or glass body, let the whole be shyfted into a copper body, which
you shall place in a Furnace with his head set upon, and cooling beak fastened
to after art: and beware that the body stand not over nigh the fire, but that
an iron plate full of holes, be fyxed in the myddle between, that the fire may
so vent through, and the vapor be sent upward* First kyndle or begin with a
soft fire, until the distyllacion be somewhat come, but increase after the
fire bygger and bygger, that it may the speedilyer distyll forth. When a
measure is come or dystilled forth, separate yt a part, as principal, setting
under another Receauer, for ye same which next distylleth and is gathered, is
much inferior to the first, and may serve for new Cinnamon, to be styeped in
the same. And in the same manner, may a water be distilled out of Cloves. Where
to be noted, that a manner and way of cooling be used: as when the water
begins to wax hot; to draw forth the same, and power in colder water.

A water of Cinamo^, if any will distyl by a bladder made of copper, together
with a pype fyxed to it, passing through a vessel of cold water: a great
quantity then shall be distylled together, for it would not easily be drawn in
a small quantity. But in a Cucurbite dilygently luted, this special care is to
be had, that your stuff burn not to the bottom, whereby your water then
distylling forth may savor of the burning. That if the fire shall be hoter
increased, an oil also distylleth, and so much the more, if the Cynamon shall
be stieped in good white wine. A water distylled in a Cucurbite, is gathered
white in the receauer.

I do take (says the Aucthour) ^ (...) quantity of Cynamon, even so much as I
thinck good, and put the same into a Cucurbite or glass body not luted,
together with water, to stiepe for certain days, after I distyll the
substance by the vapor of boiling water, in such sort that the Cucurbite in
which the Cynamon is contained, does not touch the water, as the like Manardus
teaches: and on such wise I distylled and gathered a clear water, not
troubled, nor the spirits also of the Cynamon heated to much. Sometimes when I
would have the water myghtyer, I then add to it a little of Gynger. And in this
manner, a certain Poticarie (with the Aucthour) distylleth the water of Cynamon.

Certain others there be, which follow and use this manner: take of water
sixteen parts, of Cynamon one part, which grosely was powdered together, the
same after put into a Cucurbite to stiepe close stopped, for a certain time,
as either four, or five days: after this set on the head close to the body,
and distyll the substance with a most temperate heat in Balneo Mariae, which
exceeds not the heat of man's vryne in the first coming forth, for so may a
most pleasant water be drawn and purchased. In the time of this boiling, may
hot water be powered in, that a like quantity continue still, for doubt of
wasting away, and you shall gather into a Receauer the distinct waters: as the
first a mighty water, the second of lesser strength, and the third feeble. And
in the like manner may all other spyces be ordered and dystilled: and many
distyllers there be, which purchase by the same doing, an oil and water.

Another manner briefly, in purchasing the water of Cynamon: take of chosen
Cynamon two ounces, of water, a fowrth part of a measure, of wine so much,
these after the myxing, distyll, as before taught.

Others prepare a water of Cynamon, after this mamer: they take of Cynamon, one
pound grosely beaten, on which they power a Sextarie and a half, that is
(about a wine quarte) of pure water, which close covered, they let stand to
infuse, for.xviii. hours, after they set the body on a soft fire, and
distylled the water, even as we do Aqua vitae, by a pype passing through a
wooden vessel or tubbe filled with cold water, which crooketh or wryeth in
an out (after the figure here playner dyscribeth) least the spyrites should
burn. This form also may serve all those distyllacions, which ought to be
done, by cooling means, through a vessel of cold water.

A certain woman well practiced, and skylfull in distyllation, prepared and
drew Cynamon water, on this wise: but it little dyffereth, from the ways
before uttered: take of the best Cynamon fynelye brought to powder in a mortar,
but not searsed, half a pound, this so charilye power into the distyllatorye
body, that none cleave on the sides falling in, on which power one measure and
a half of clear Cundui^te water, then set the headde close to the body:
after distyll in the beginning with a very soft fire, and increase the fire
by little and little, as you see the drops come, either quick, or slowly: to
the Nose of the Lymbecke or headde, let a Pype be fastened (as before taught,
and demonstrated) passing or retching through cold water, at the end of which
a Receauer fastened.

When the water thus comes, you shall need three persons to stand by, the
one and first to consider and tend the head, and pype, that he or she always
cools them, with lynnen clothes wette in cold water and applied after
discretion on the head and pype, the other standing by the Receauer, let him
observe and mark the color of the water distylling into the receauer: the
third, that he mark and tend the glass in such manner, as when need shall
be, to retche or put under speedily another Receauer, and to take the other
again, and stop dilygently. The water distilling has four differences, for
which cause it shall need four sundry receivers. The first water that comes,
is somewhat fattie and strong, and of this, is the best: and as this proceeds
in distylling, and a mylkie color begins to come, then gather the second
water, which in his fortitude lacks of the first, or is of a weaker virtue:
and when this color is vanished, and that the water coming forth, as a water
distylled out of other matters, remember and consider the third water, which
must like be gathered a part or several by it self. When this water shall be
turned into a yellowe color, or changed yellowishe, gather then the fowrth
water, which distylleth or comes forth in a small quantity: and the work is
at an end, when certain drops begin to appear of a red color, at
which sight cease, for the rest behynd is of no force, nor serves to any use
or purpose. Besides take heed, least through the force of the fire your
substance over high boyleth up, and through the same may the distyllacion
proceed amysse, and in danger of losing the whole stuff. Of which to be out
of doubt, you shall avoid and end that care (by good government) in the space
of one hour.

Three drops of this water, myxed to other waters of like property
aunswering, do help the falling sickness. If with this, the veins under the
tongue be aptly rubbed, does help the palsy persons in a short time.

Out of the Cynamon may by distyllacion, but a little oil be gotten, for which
cause in the steed of it, we may often use the water of Cynamon, especially
the same which is first gathered, for this has singular properties contained
in it.

An oil of Cynamon, is prepared and gotten on this wise, borrowed out of a
certain written coppie, of an unknown Aucthor: take of the best Malmesie
three measures, and the same distylled twyse over. After let it be a third
time, that one measure only rests in the Cucurbite. Let it be distylled
once again, that a lesser quantity may remain in the Cucurbite. Then let it
be yet once again distylled, that one measure only remains: by so often
repiticion shall you have the wine very well rectifyed, which keep to your use.
The same done, take of Cynamon what quantity you think necessary, the same
break smally, after power the Cynamon with the rectifyed wine into a
Cucurbite, that it may be two fingers above the Cinnamon. Let the Cucurbite then
be dilygently closed with a blind Lymbecke, and setting it into Balneo Mariae,
make a soft fire under for three days. Which time ended, power yt wine warely
forth, in regarding that none of the Feces or grosser substance be powered
forth withal, and the wine keep a part. Then power other rectifyed wine upon,
and work as you did with the other before. These done, mix either Aqua vitae
or both together, in a Cucurbite, which dilygently cover with a head, and begin
to distyll with a very soft fire, and so slow, that nynes stroks or knockes
with the finger, may be made between drop and drop falling: and on this wise
you shall continue, unto the time that all the wine be ascended: for in the
bottom then of the glass, you shall have an oil, which dilygently keep.

The manner of preparing and drawing a water of Cynamon, and an oil of the
same: which a most singular Physician named Master John Crato a Krafftheim,
gently opened and taught to the Aucthour. The.xjx. Chapter.
TAke of the best and finest Cynamon, which beat very small, after the tying
up in a fine lynnen cloth, and this little bag hanged within the vessel, in
which water is contained in yt bottom, but in such sort that the water
touches not the bag, and the vessel in the mean time dilygently closed,
which vessel set into a great pot, full of hot and scalding water, in such
manner, that the water, which is contained in the same vessel: in which the
Cynamon hangs, may boil: and let the Cynamon hang in this manner for a
certain space, in that or over that hot vapor, until the Cynamon has
sufficiently drawn and gathered to it of moisture. After the Cynamon thus
prepared and moystned with the vapor of the boiling water, let it be again
beaten over, and as it were, a certain paste made thereof, and the same
together with the impressed lycour, which it before gathered and received, let
be put into a Lymbecke: if need shall require, you may yet power in some more
hot water, but ye lesser water you power in or occupye, so much the worthier
water of Cinnamon you shall possess, and somewhat also of the Oil. But if you
covet to have a more store of water, and less precious, then power in the more
water, as certain (at this day) do, to purchase them rather a more gain,
then men's commoditye and health: but ordering it thus, you shall then
obtain, either none, or very little of the Oil.



A. Represents the cover of that pot, in which the Cynamon is hanged: this
cover, if it have within a head pynne, made of purpose, in the myddle as it
were, of the hollownesse, like to that pynne set in the top of a Helmette, or
rather as this figure more playnlie demonstrateth, to which the bag may
aptlyer be fastened, and hang by that means the iustlyer in the myddle. That if
the same like can not be gotten or wrought, in putting a stycke overthwart the
head of the pot, it may to the stycke be tied and hang. And the cover stop
dilygently about* that no air breath forth.

B. B. Does here represent the empty hollownesse of the vessel.

C. Does here show the bag filled with the Cynamon.

E. Expresses the tunnell pype, by which the water, if that any fails or
needs, may be powered in, but the hole after dilygently stopped.

F. F Is here the great pot full of water, which conteyneth and receives the
vessel* into which the Cynamon is put.

If the vessel receiving the lycour distylled* be large, there needs not to
draw the water by the pype of the Helmette, ex^ept the Receauer wax hot* and
then let a lynnen cloth wette in cold water be applied upon, which by that
means, shall perform and yield the same use. In the same manner, as the
water of Cynamon is prepared and drawn; may also the Annise, the Fennel, the
Cummyne, etc. be distylled and gotten.

The distylled oils of Gums, and Rosens, have another manner and way, and
require an inspection in the putrefying: for a man must dilygently beware and
foresee, that the fire be made very soft under, and the same still or
continually a like, for if the spirit once begins to breath forth, the oil
and whole work is lost. And unto use, must not the ponde, but river water be
taken.

Again the oil of Cynamon, certain do affirm, that the same to be prepared
and made of some, with Aqua vitae: and that it ought to be applied to them that
are encombred with the falling sickness, by gyuing of the oil for three
months, as daily a drop with Maiorome water, or some other like.

An oil out of the ryndes of the Orrendges dried, is made most singular: but
whether the same ought only be done in the Sun, or by distyllacion properly, as
yet is not known to the Aucthour. But this the Aucthour learned and knew, that
the Oil is whytishe and sweet smelling, and has very little sowrenesse, or in
a manner nothing at all, that the Aucthour could taste or feel.

An oil out of the ryndes of Nuttes: take the dry rynders of Nuttes, which
after the beating in a mortar, put into a Retorte very well luted about, the
same set over a fire not over bygge, and you shall then draw forth an Oil and
water out of the ryndes. After shall you separate the oil, from the water, by
Balneo Mariae. And last, you shall purge the oil, by distylling of it in a small
glass in Sand, three or four times over. This is in a manner better, then the
oil of Vitryoll, especially in the pestilence, and in poison, G. Ras.

Of the oil of Tartare, which is the dry Lies of wine prepared. The *.xx.
Chapter.
AN oil of Tartare is on this wise drawn and made: take of the Tartare of the
white wine, or Malmesse, if you can get the same (for it shall be ye better) as
much as you think good, the same calcyne in a glass Furnaces: until it be so
white as Meal: which done, prepare and get a marble stone into moist place,
this so order, that it may seem to hang, on which lay your Tartare calcyned,
that will of it self dyssolue and convert into oil, within six or eight
days, which gather and let run through a strayner or ypocrasse bag, into a
vessel or pan set right under, and this will be white of color, which keep
in a glass close stopped. This is the true oil of Tartare, but the same is
most strong and corrosiue: when any woman will use of this to bewtifye the
face, let her then myxe a little of it with some other water proper to the face,
with which wash morning and evening the face, for it corrodeth and cleanses all
manner spots of yt face, clears and whyteneth the face, and takes away the
redness of the same. This oil clears the hands, of any foul spots: it
mundifieth matrie and foul ulcers, by washing them sundry times with it. This
also helps the evil dispositions of the stomak* by taking one scruple of it,
with two ounces of rosed Honey, and three ounces of Rosewater by the mouth, in
the morning fasting. This besides serves for fixation, in Alchimye matters.
This borrowod out of the Italian secrets, of that singular Gabriell Fallopio.

Another oil of Tartare, borrowed out of the same Aucthour: take of Tartare,
cleaving to the sides of the vessels, especially of the white wine, which
beaten before, calcyne in an earthen pan, after the calcynation, beat again,
which being put into an ypocrasse bag, hang in a cold and moist seller,
setting under a deep glased pan: the same let there hang for six, or eight
days, until you see the oil come. This oil thus purchased, helps all
manner of spots of the face, makes a clear, and smooth skin: it heals
the foul scruffe, scabbes, and ryngwoormes, the redness of the face, through
a saltmatter, and such like.

An oil of Tartare* that avails against the pushes, or little wheales of the
eyes, proceeding of the Leprie. Take of Tartare beaten, three pounds, this put
into a glased pot with twentye ounces of vinegar, boil for half an hours
space, which in the mean time dilygently skym, after take the pot from the
fire, in stopping it dilygently, that no vapor breath forth. Then set the
pot again an whote ymbers or hot coals, which let there so long boil, or
calcyne, until the Tartare may be brought into powder again. The same after
the cooling, or being cold, bring to powder, which the power into a Sugar
strayner, or ypocrasse bag, and hang it in a cold and moist place, or wine
seller, some glased pan set under. The use of this oil, is on this wise: let
the pacient before enter into bathe, and at night when he goes to bed,
annoint the places under the eyes, where the wheales or bladders appear, and
cover them dilygently with a lynnen cloth, that they may not be touched of the
air before the drying up of it. This continue in like order, morning and
evening, for eight days together.

For to calcine the Tartare on a sudden, that with nyter it may be white,
which avails aygainst wartes: out of a written German book. Take of salt
peter and Tartare brought to powder, of each a like quantity. After heat an
oarthen pan not glased, into which power the nyter and Tartare, and when they
make a ^o^se^ and shal^e through burnt they become speedily white. This Tartare
thus calcyned, after the lying in a bag, you shall hang in a moist Seller,
and an Oil will dystyll forth into the pan standing under. This oil thus
gathered, does remove and put away the wartes on the hands, and other parts,
if with it they be anointed. Here is to be noted, that when you shall myxe
lesser together of nyter, then of the Tartare, the substance after the
calcynation, will not be so white: although four ounces of salt peter, with
one pound of Tartare, myxed together, may calcyne the Tartare, but not reduce
it into a whytenesse, but that the same will after remain black, out of which
an oil notwithstanding is wont also to be distylled.

Of the oils that are drawn out of woods. The.xxj. Chapter.


THat an oil may be drawn or gotten out of any woodde: take the small chyppes
of either the Guaicum, the Pyne tree, the Ash, or Juniper tree, which ordered
by two pottes, distyll after by discention (as before was taught) or happily as
you know, and you shall purchase without doubt oil abundantly. But if you
will, that it should be mightyer wrought, and that the same may be worthier,
distyl then the substance by a Retort, and your oil shall after be very fair,
and piercing, and sone entering, where so ever it is applied.

An oil out of the wood Guaicum, or (that better succeeded) out of the Polly
wood (says Manardus) I used in the French grieffes or ulcers, or in Aches:
unto which use, does the oil also out of the Juniper woodde, not a little
avail.

An oil out of the wood of the Ash tree, is prepared and made in the same
manner, as out of the Guaicum: the use of it serves, in a cold ache of the
joints, and brings to a scarre the excoriatio^s: it does properly dissolve
and put away the white morphew, and makes it appear black. And in the like
manner, may an oil be gotten, out of all wooddes: this Rogerius. Such an oil
besides, cures the palsy persons. Manardus also reports, that the oil of
the Ash wood, not only anointed, but druncke also, to help the persons
diseased with the Spleen or Mylt.

An oil out of the yuie woodde, how the same may be prepared and gotten, was
before taught in the place, where we instructed the manner of drawing an oil,
out of the Iunyper berryes, borrowed out of Rogerius.

An oil out of the Iunyper woodde, is obtained in the same manner, as the oil
out of the yuie woodde, that remooueth or represseth the causes of coldness,
and the type or figure of the quartayne: but more singular and especial it is,
by annoynting from the navel, unto the pryuie place: for it avails and has
the property, to comfort the kydneys, and matrice, and to dry up the moisture
of it, and to prepare also the party meet unto conception: this Rogerius.

The Oil of Juniper, does avail in Fistulaes, in cuttes of the skyn, in that
named, Malum mortuum: the Serpigo and Canker of the Legs, in wounds and evil
ulcers. Take of the small chyppes of the Juniper wood, a sufficient quantity,
which put into a bigg^ glased pot or great pytcher glased within, and fylling
the pot full, whose mouth ought to be narrow: after make a deep hole in the
earth, and prepare the walls of it with potters earth, after set the other
pot glased within to the bottom of the hole, and vpryght standing, having a
large mouth, and covered with a plate stricken full of small holes, after sense
and stop the mouths of these two pottes, set one within the other, with
potters earth, that no air breath forth of neither pot, which covered close
about with earth, kyndle, and maintain the fire clear for three hours,
until ye shall have yielded the best oil of the Iunyper woodde, into the
lesser and shorter vessel standing under.

An oil of the Iunyper woodde rectified, is wrought in the first distyllation
by discention: after the whole powered into a glass body, distylled over
again, and that upward, in Balneo Mariae, which although it be the slower
way, yet is it the comelyer manner, and causes a bewtyfuller oil, then either
in Sand or ashes, in that it causes the oil readyer in them.

An oil out of the small chyppes or pieces of the woodde which the Germans
name Hobelspon, prepared and drawn on this wise, helps sundry grieffes of
the eyes: take of the good mother of Pearls, which lay for a night, either in
a wine Seller, or into cold water, after let it be thoroughly dried: which
done, to this mother of pearls, put in so many chyppes of the wood as the
pot will well receive, the same draw with a fire by descention, or by (a
shorter way) kyndle the chyppes, and an oil will come, of a yellow color for
the eyes.

Of the oils gotten out of Paper, and the pieces of lynnen cloth. The.xxij.
Chapter.
AN oil out of Paper is thus purchased, take a pewter dyshe, in which put so
much paper as you mind to burn: after the paper burnt, you shall find a
yelowishe some running out of the dyshe, the same gather, and annoint the
wryncled or folded eye lyddes: or otherwise use for the spots, the whitneses,
and other grieffes of the eyes.

An oil otherwise purchased out of paper, make a long hoode rolled together of
white paper, the very top of which cut of: and the sharp end folded many
times about, hold with a pair of sheeres or long nyppers, on such wise that
the brother edge and end hang or be within the dyshe, until the half, or
greater part be burnte, yet suffer not the flame to fall into the dyshe, unto
the end of the work.

An oil out of lynnen pieces, take a fine lynnen cloth clean washed, the
same kindle or burn over a pewter dysh, and a canstick oil will come, with
which annoint ulcers: after dissolve chalk in vyneger, into the manner of a
white ointment, with which annoint round about, as a defensive to the place.



Of the oils out of Beasts, or their parts, together with an Epistle of
Arnoldus de villa noua, of man's blood distylled. The.xxiij. Chapter.
MY dearelye beloved friend Master lacobus, of late you required of me, that
I would open to you my secret of man's blood, which the dyuine power
favoring and helping me, and by my own industry (although not wholly) and by
many experiences, with the manifold labors bestowed, I have found some worthy
practices, of which I have tried, and those by my letters, I mind to utter to
you. And although I have been a long time occupied about the same, yet for that
I now wax aged, and set rancour or envy aside, for that cause, will I fully
open to you, what I many times, have experienced, by this worthy secret.
Therefore give ear, and hear the chosen secrets, and words of my mouth in
that the holy Ghost, where (it him best likes) breaths his divine gift* and
of this, let it be recluded in the pit of a penitent breast, if any will make
common, or reueile this secret, to either a foolish, or negligent person,
which the ancient in times past, so carefully and busily sought, and yet could
not attain the same yea they many ways practiced, and yet could not retche
to, nor purchase the same high secret. For it is celestial gift, revealed to
us unworthy of God, which neither ye Physicians before knew, nor the
Philosophers also which labored in the deep secrets of Alchymie, found. But
I take God to witness, that by sundry traueiles, which a I long time have
bestowed (as you know) in the secret Art of Alchymie, have now brought to
pass, that I have known by experience, such an efficacy to be of this
matter, that ye full to utter of the singular virtues of it, my wits will not
extend, and for that cause I reclude the^, in the pit of a penitent breast.

To come to the matter, conceive this secret, yt is, man's blood, and let the
blood be of healthful men, about xxx. years of age, out of which draw
according to Art, the four Elements, as you well have learned and know by the
rules of Alchymie, and diligently stop each Element a part, that no air
breath forth.

For the water of it avails in all sicknesses, as well hot as cold, in yt
the same is of a hid nature and property, and reduces unto a temperament the
quality decayed, and does especially avail in pacients corrupted in the
spiritual members, and expels poison from the heart. It has also the
virtue to enlarge, and moysten the Arters, and this I say, through the manifest
working, that it dissolueth the gross flewme contained in ye Lungs, without
harm, and the same vlcered (no mighty matter hindering) it thoroughly heals.
And briefly, all matters found in the Lungs, and spiritual members, this
singularly purges, and preserves those purged. It cleanses the blood, without
any other medicine ministered. It cures also, any flux of the belly, and
speedily delyuereth and heals any impostume of the side.

The Air also distylled of it, much avails unto the aforesaid matters, and
perhaps more, then the water, and does especially avail in young persons, that
they may persevere and continue in the same state of strength and youthful
comeliness, if they use now and than of it, and in a little quantity at a
time. And it is in a manner of such a virtue, that it suffers the blood by no
