means to putrify, nor flewme to superabound or have the ouerhand, nor that
choler to burn. Further it does increase blood above measure, and for that
cause, it behooves such using it, to blede often by vain. The same Element
besides does open the vain and synewes, and if any virtue shall be deminished
in them, this reduces it unto a dew temperament. I have besides these proved
(says the Aucthour) that if a young person, before the state and rypnesse of
his age, as in the growing time, shall have the sight perished* let him every
day put one drop of this Element into the eye, and keep him quiet for a
month together, shall recover his sight without doubt. If in any member also,
any superfluous matter consists, or comes apt to putrefying, this forth
with dissolueth and takes it away, and if it finds any thing, that is
diminished, it strengthens the same by restoring. And this Element avails in
the Ap^plexie, the falling sickness, the dymnesse of sight, the mygrynie, the
gyddinesse of the head, and in all these it ought to be ministered with some apt
electuarie, auailing unto the purpose.

But the fire purchased of it, is more precious and marueylousser, and avails
unto all those, which the air helps, yea and unto that which more is, of the
man dead, that it restored to life; this is here so meant and understood. That
if in the hour of death (yet resting or ye^ing) be given of this fire, unto
the weight or quantity of a wheat grain, distempered or myxed with wine, in
such manner entered down, that it be past ye throat, it shall forthwith cause
the person to reuyue again, and shall at the instant enter to the heart it
self, in expelling the superfluous humors, and with this reuyueth the
natural heat of his Liver, and quickneth so all the parts, that it moves
the pacient and very weak person, as it were within an hour to speak, and to
dispose and utter his will, etc. And on this manner, I saw (says the Aucthour)
a miracle wrought on the noble Earl and deputy of Paris, which before lay in
a manner as dead, and immediately after he had received this down, became
again to himself somewhat, and within an hour after dyed. And this I
ministered, and tried in many the like. If old men also use of this fire every
day, in a little quantity, it makes old age lusty, and to continue in like
estate a long time, in that this cheareth their hearts, in such manner: that
they will think themselves to possess In ^enyle hearts and courages. And
for that cause this fire, is named the Elixir vitae: yet is not this the
Alchimisters Elixir* in that this is prepared and drawn of putrifyed blood. If
the same also were made of putrifyed blood, then man's nature would overmuch
abhor such a medicine. This conceive, that if the Elements shall be distilled
a second time over, they shall then be most excellent, and through them may a
man live, unto ye uttermost peryode of his life, without disease or sickness,
if of these be used, every other day. And such a skill and knowledge consists
in these last distillations, even as is in the distillations of Alchymie.

Here note of this man's blood, that I do myxe the same fresh drawn, with the
strongest and best Aqua vitae, and do distill (...), and the same shall serve,
for the first Elemente. And upon the Feces, I power another most strong water
of life, and distyll in like manner, and the same shall be, for the second
Elemente. Here somewhat (seems to lack) and this I proone, says the
Aucthour; in that he writes, let a latten cup be made, and set on a Table,
and if poison be laid or set near to it, the cup will, then change into
sundry colors, like to ma^i^lyne^* etc: and on such wise in poison known to
be there present, and a like matter of the Ague.

A most holy Oil prepared and made of dead men's bones, seruyng unto all
griefs, and often proved of the Aucthour, after a dew Purgation, take of the
great benes of dead men, breakyng them into small pieces, which after suffer
to be glowing hot in the fire, and being so fyerie hot, quence them
speedily in a pan or pot, filled with auncientoyle Olyue, and as soon as
you have put them into the Oil, forthwyth stop close the mouth of your
pot, with a proper cover, as the like we taught, in the making of the
Philosophers Oil. Which bones leave thus to stiepe and soke in the Oil for
certain hours (whether six, or eight hours, or more) these bones thus
ordered, (without any part of the oil, yet resting behind in the pot* beat
fyner to a powder, which alone put into a Retort, and distyll it like to the
Oil of the Philosophers, before taught, which keep in a glass, and use after
knowledge. For this works a mighty matter, unto all pains of the joints,
experienced.

An Oil of bones, helping the falling sickness: Take the hinder sea^^e bones
of dead men (named Sut^^^ lab^orides) ^^ose put unto calcyning, until they be
glowing hot, after let them be quenched in oil Olyue, and then brought to
powder, as before taught of the other bones above* and like used in the
distyllacion: this is a most singular medicine and remedy, by annoynting the
apt place.

An Oil of men's bones, by discention, that mightily avails against the
gowte: of experience.

An oil drawn out of the excrements of children, that avails in the foul
matterie scabbes of the head: distyll twyse over in a glass Lymbecke the
excrem^^^^s or or^ur^ of ^^yldren, and with the Oyl^ (that you shall draw of
the same) apply hot on the grieved place or (...) part: but before you ^^all
^^^ppe nee^^ away, or shave away the heir, a^^ shall wash the affected place
with sharp lie* prepared and made after this manner: take of the ashes made of
the Oak branches a reasonable quantity, on which power a like quantitye
aunswering of water, this cover with a cloth close, letting it so stand to
infuse for a day and a half, into this water then put in one handful of the
white whea^^ ears: which done, wash the affected part, once a day, with the
said water or lie, letting it dry in, after annoint the place, as above
taught.

An Oil out of man's ordure, does cure the Canker, and mortifyeth the
Fistula. Of the properties of the water, drawn out of mane ordure, read among
the waters out of Beasts.

An Oil or fatness, gotten out of a fat Goose, avails against the cold
joint ache, and gowte: and I believe also (says the Aucthor) that this
mightily helps the extenuation of members. An old Goose stuffed or filled
with swynes blood, sheep sewet, pytche, larde or common fat of the hog,
of each two ounces, of Frankensence three ounces, and a little wax: this Goose
so ordered, roste according to discretion, under which set a pan glased, to
gather the fatness distilling, the same dilygently keep, and with it often
annoint the grieved place. In the like manner, they do distyll a fatness out
of a fat whelpe, stuffed with Iunyper berryes, Bears grease, etc.

An oil or distylled licour, gotten by discention, out of the Badgare or
Graye, helping members shruncke, through synewes shrunck, borrowed out of a
written book in the German tongue. Take a Graye or Brocke, whose skin
flaye of, and cutting of the head and feet, and throwing away the bowels: this
then so ordered, put into a glased earthen pot full of holes in the bottom,
which set into another wyder mouth pot glased within, the same after bury in
the earth, when they be close luted in the seame or edge, and the mouth of the
upper pot close stopped, that no air out of either post may pass. Which
done, let a fire of clear coals, be made round about the upper pot, that
all the fat by such a means and way may from the upper, distyll through the
holes into the nether pot: and when all (by conjecture) shall be thought
distylled and come: then after with that fatness kept, annoint the shruncke
members.

An oil marvelous, gotten out of the Beuer, that helps any palsy, and
extenuacion of parts: take a Beuer, the same let be put into the strongest
Aqua vitae, that it may putrifye, which after distyll with a soft fire, with
which let the parts be anointed.

For the extenuation of a member (resolved) distyll the feet or fatness, and
the Liver of a Calfe new killed, with fine handfulles of Sage, and one ounce of
Pepper: with this anoint the member.

A marvelous oil distylled of Eggs, and experienced on many matters, the
Aucthor not known: take of the yolks of Eggs sodden hard, fifteen in
number, those break between the fingers, with one dram of Pelytorie brought
to powder, these distyl together in a glass, but first begin with a soft fire,
after by little and little increase the fire, so that in the end, let the fire
be strong, until all the lycour be drawn^ and come. Which done, take of white
Frankensence, of Castorie, and of Ladanum, of each half a ounce, althese
brought to powder, mixed with ye oil new drawn, and let these together be
distilled four times again, ever pouring the oil upon the pouders. The fire
of the first and second distillation, let it be but weak, this oil in the end
kept stopped diligently in a glass, keep to your use. For this is a great
secret, and a proved matter or practice, unto these which ensue. First this
heals the defaults and griefs of the eyes, if a drop at a time shall be
instylled into them. This mortifyeth and cures by annoynting the Fistulaes. It
heals the Canker, and ulcers hard to close, and does besides that which other
remedies cannot overcome. It destroys and maistereth the grief named the
fig or sort, like to a skabbe, which grows in the places of a man's body
where heir is* It takes away the prickings of any part of the body, and
cures the^. It heals the mattery skabbe on the head, if ye heirs before be
shaven away, and that the skin be rubbed with a lynnen cloth wette in lie,
and that dried in, annoint the places after with the oil. This also profits
the Apoplexy and especially the gowte if the places be anointed with it twice
a day, for four days together. This also speedily heals the burning of
fire, by annoynting the places with it, and cures the disease called the
woulfe.

An oil out of eggs: take six eggs, which boil unto a hardness, after the
shelles pylled of, cut away the whites, the yolks after with your fingers,
break into small pieces, those put into a frying pan, which whilst they
heat and fry stir to and fro, by little and little, with a spone, until
they begin so to melt, and run in the pan, yet does the substance remain,
of a yelow color, when the whole shall be in this readiness, power the
substance into lynnen bags, which wring hard in a press, and you shall
possess a lycour or yelow oil, with which annoint the burnings.

Others, after the yolks be so heated and molten in a pan, unto the time the
substance run about the pan, yet do they further heat, and as it were fry
the^, until they appear dry and black in the pan, which they as soon after
as these shall thus be dried, and become black, do melt them again, and by
that means cause a plentiful moisture, and black, to run forth, yet ill
savoring. The^ with a spone those which be in the frying pan, they stur
grossoly together, yt the oil and all the humor fallen to the one side of the
frying pan, may like fall into the other side, and be so gathered to use.

A red oil out of the yolks of eggs, that avails against a cold gowte,
borrowed out of a written book, in the Italian tongue. Take the hard yolks of
seventy eggs sodden, out of which let an oil be drawn after this manner: let
them be put into a frying pan on the fire, which stur to and fro with a spone
diligently, and let the same so long frye, until it be well molten, the whole
after put into lynnen bags, wette before in water, which wring hard out in a
press, and an oil will distyll forth. With this oil myxe of Pelytorie, of
Castorie, of Mas^icke, and of Ladanum of each one ounce, all these together
put into a glass Limbecke, distill after the accustomed manner with a soft
fire, the joints of the head and receauer before close luted that no air
breath forth, and the same which shall come of this distillation, repeat upon
the Feces thrice over, and with this oil, annoint the grieved place, and it
shall speedily cure it, for this is a most excellent oil proved.

A Juice or lycour, pressed out of the hard yolks of Eggs sodden, and
instilled or dropped into the ears, does much help the ringing and sounding
of the Ears. The oil of the yolks of eggs druncke, before meat, puts
away drunckennesse, how mightily any drincketh. If pain vexes a person, by
the cutting of any member, if is cured by the oil of the yolks of eggs, and
Goose grease incorporated together, unto the form of an ointment, and of it
applied upon, which does marvelously assuage the pain, and causes sleep.
This also mytigateth the pain of the privy member, anointed with it. The use
of it also serves in Alchymical works, in that the same fixes certain
medicines.

The shelles of eggs cleansed or pylled from the inner skin, out of which
Chickins have lately been hatched, beat to fine powder, of this a dram weight
druncke, wi^h Saxifrage water, does provoke urine speedily, this borrowed out
of Leonellus.

Out of the honey, is a Quintisence drawn, by Art of distillatio^ which
yields marvelous and wonderful effects, prepared and drawn on this wise:
Take of honey two pounds, that is very clear, of a good savor, and gathered
of Bees in a good region or country, which put into a large glass body, that
remains four or five parts empty, this body lute about very well, setting a
head close upon, with the Receauer luted to the Nose: after make a fire, which
maintain greater and greater, until certain whyt^ fumes or vapors come or
appear, which after be converted into water by applying linen clothes wet in
cold water and those laid on the head of the glass, and the like on the neck
of the receauer. The water distilling, will then come red as blood: which at
the end of the distyllacion, power into a glass, dilygently stopping it, and
letting it there stand, until the water come most clear, and be of a Rubine
color. The same then distyl again by Balneo Mariae, above six or seven
times, through which it loses the red color, and receives a golden color,
and it then obtayneth a most sweet and fragrant savor. This quyntisence, does
dyssolue gold, and makes it potable or to be drunck, and the like, it
dyssolueth all precious stones infused or put in it. For this is a blessed
water, which given to the quantity of two or three drams, unto a person lying at
the point of death, makes him speedily recover and come to him self again.
If with it wounds or other fores be washed, or applied wet upon, are speedily
cured. This the like heals the cough, the rewme, and sicknesses of the
spleen. If it shall be twenty times distylled over, it would render or restore
sight to the blind. I have (says the Aucthour) given it to a person of ye
palsy, xlvi. days, through which he was thoroughly cured. This besides heals
the falling sickness, and preserves the body from putrefying. To whom I gave
this by the mouth, I ministered it so closely (in that I would not be seen of
any standing about) through my which doing, and the success that followed, they
supposed me to use some manner of incantacions. This borrowed out of the greek
Leonarde Fiorauant.

An oil of Honey, serving unto the coloring of the heirs of the head yellow:
take of Honey one pound, to which add one handful of wheaten meal, these after
the myxing, distyl according to art, and draw the oil from the water, after
myxe the oil and water together in a glass, with which kembe the heirs.

The distylling of two waters, of which the one serves to the clearing and
bewtifying of the face, and the other, to the coloring and dying of the heirs
of the head yellow. Take of the best Honey one pound, this put into a great
Retort, set into sand on a Furnace, under which make a soft fire, until a
white water be dystylled and come: and when a yellow begins to distyll, draw
away the Receauer, setting under another, and increase the fire by little and
little, until certain white fumes y^^ew forth, and so long maintain your
fire, until no more lycour will distyll forth. And this last distyllacion,
will be of a Rubyne color: with which if you wet the heirs, it dies them of
the color of gold, and makes the heirs grow very fair and long. But
washing the face with the first water, makes it comely and fair, and
preserves the skin a long time, from appearing old. These two, have many
noble women used, and found great vtility by them: as well for the face, as
coloring the heir, to their great admiration, as writes the Aucthour,
Leonarde Fiorauant.

A water or lycour, prohybiting or letting the ingendring of the stone: Take of
new Honey two pounds, of Venice Turpentyne one pound, these after the myxing
together, distyll with a soft fire: let the pacient take ounces, but (I rather
judge two drams) to be taken, in the morning fasting.

A lycour or water out of Honey, drawn by distyllacion, which serves unto the
making of the heir yellowe, cytrine, and golden. Take of Salt peter, and Honey,
of each a like quantity, these after the myxing, distyll in a tynne Lymbecke:
with this water, kembe the heirs of the head. But after the w^tting of the
heir, beware that it touches not the skin, or flesh.

An Oil out of fat wax, drawn by Chymicke or Chymisticke art, most
excellent unto the softning of hard swellings: in that it mightily pierces,
softneth, and dyssolueth, and this is no common medycine in brynging wounds to
fair scarres, so that within a few days, after the closing of the wound, you
use to apply of it, least a new inflammation be caused. The oil is on this
wise prepared: take new wax (and Gesnerus judges virgin wax to be taken) and
the same especially fat, which you shall leasurely melt in some vessel* with a
soft fire, and the same you shall often wash, and thryst hard together in
wine, which you shall melt again, and into the same molten, shall you put many
small pieces broken, of Tyles made glowing hot, which may so drinck up much of
the wax, and this do a second, and third time, if need shall require, until
all the wax be thus druncke up: which done, put al your small and fine pieces
of Tyles, into that crooked body named a Retorte, the same dilygently fence with
the lute of wisdom, to which fasten a receauer, to receive the drops
distylling: the first which comes, will be a water, but in the end will a most
pure oil distyl forth, which you may use unto the mollifying and softning of
members: this Bartholomeus Maggius, in the cure of hard swellings. I learned
(says the Aucthour) of a certain Alchymister in Padua (in Italy) that Sand
very well washed, after syfted and myxed with the wax molten, would let the
rising and boiling up of the wax. There be some, which to wax, and all other
Rosen substances to be distylled, put to glass fine brought to powder* by
which means it lets the rising of the wax, but this then causes in the
distyllacion, that the oils after distylled with it, purchase a certain
strange and an ungrateful savor, through the salt Alkali, for which cause,
this ought utterly to be refused. Some say that in the distylling it makes a
noise, as it would break the glass. The oil of wax works miracles, in
the ceasing of pains, as of the gowte, and joint aches. This to conclude, is a
singular remedy to many grieffes, and a most temperate oil: for which cause,
it is highly commended in wounds, and ulcers.

An oil of wax, that heals the clofts and choppes of the hippes, and
choppes or other soreness that happen on the Tettes of women's breasts,
borrowed out of a written book in the Italian tongue: take of the oil of new
wax distylled, by a glass, in the same manner altogether, as the oil of
Frankensence is distylled: with this oil annoint the chops of the hyps, and
Tettes of women's breasts, and they are spedily healed: and it nothing hyndreth,
yt the child suck in the night time, for this takes away the pain.

An Oil of wax myraculous and dy^ine, that helps most diseases, and heals
a great wound in ten or twelve days at the most, but a little wound in three
days, by applying of the oil on the wound, and clothes wet in it on the
place, it stays also ye shedding of the heir of the head, and heard: and
given to the quantity of one dram by the mouth, mightily delivers the
Colic, and wyndy gripings of the body. The making of the foresaid oil, is on
this wise: take a glass Retort, which dilygently lute, into which put such
quantity of wax as you thinck necessary, so ^ it excedeth not ye half of the
glass, and to each pound of the wax, add four ounces of Brick in powder,
or rather more aptlye (make the wax into many small balls, with the powder of
the Brick) which after put into a Retort, setting it into a pan of ashes, or
sand, under which make a soft fire, until all the oil be come, which although
it conieale or thicken in the glass, it forces not (says the Aucthour) as
touching to his perfection: for if you should distill the oil so often over,
until it will no more conieale, it would be ^uer hot, and sharp to take by
the mouth: so that once distylled suffices, to be given inward, and to annoint
on the outward parts of the body: that always helps, and never harmeth. This
borrowed out of the greek practisioner, Leonarde Fiorauant.

An oil of Rosen simple, serving unto sundry uses, distylled on this wise:
take a glass Retort, being well fensed with lute, into this put of Rosen, unto
ye quantity of half the glass full, and to every pound add of fi^e sifted
ashes three ounces, which after set into a pan filled with sand or ashes,
standing in a Furnace, under which make a soft fire: and the first which
comes will be a water, the same setting a time, will be most clear: after it
follows an oil (by making the fire stronger) ye ysseweth forth of a Rubine
color, the same (after the settling) certain days, keep in a glass close
stopped: the water first come, serves unto sundry purposes, among which, it
myraculously cures the swellings, and choppings of the hands, proceeding of
cold in the winter time, by holding the^ first over the fume of hot water
boiling in the evening: and anointing the^ after with the distilled water, and
then drawing o^ glooues on ye hands: by which doing, this heals the^ in a
very short time. This also does spedily cure, the foul scurse of the head, the
scab and other like matters. The oil serves in many grieffes, especially in
all manner of cold grieffes, if yt they be inward, by taking one scruple at a
time, by the mouth fasting: and if any grieffes be outward, the^ annoint of it
on the places* and on great wounds* annoint only of this oil, without either
applying plaster, or tent, and it cures in a short time: and a bruise in like
manner anointed with it, does spedilie dyssolue the same: and sundry other
matters this does, not here mentioned: this out of the greek Fiorauant.

An Oil of Frogs, right profitable to such payned with the Gowte, to joint
aches, and members over febled, whose description Gesnerus received, of yt
learned Georgius Pictorius* take of oil Olyue one pynt, of river Frogs four
in number, these put a live into the oil, letting them so remain until they
be dead, after the whole powered into a new earthen pot sensed with clay, and
the mouth close stopped, boil with a soft fire, unto the parting and
dyssoluing of the flesh, from the bones. Let the frogs after be taken forth
of the Oil, and beaten in a mortar, which put again into the Oil, boiling it
after with a very soft fire, one boiling more: this done, take it from the
fire, and strain the same, that the oil may so be clear from his Fe^es, to
which then add, of clear and washed Turpentine four ounces, these by the
fire, without any more boiling, myxe dyligently together. This oil is
precious, above measure. Of the water of the Frogs legs, read among the
water of Beasts.

An Oil prepared and made of the red Serpent, that avails against
Scroffles: take a red Serpent, or Adder (as I judge) cutting of the head and
tail, the rest of the body put into an earthen pot full of small holes in
the bottom: this set into another pot, but that second set into a vessel of
boiling water, where let the water boil so long, until you suppose, that the
oil of the Serpent be distylled, into the nether pot, and that the Serpent
it self be consumed in the upper pot. With this fat* and powder of the root of
Caphars myxed together, the Scroffles anointed for eight days together, are
thoroughly healed.

An Oil of Scorpions distylled, against poisons, borrowed out of a written
book: take of the oldest oil Olyue, as much as you will, into it put of
Scorpions, so many as you can purchase and gather, in the month of Iulie, to
which after add, of white Dyttanie, of the leaves of wormwood, of Byttonie,
of Veruayne, and of Rosemary, let all these stand to iufuse together for many
days: after distyll the whole by a Lymbecke, and that gathered, keep in a
glass close stopped.

An Oil of Antes eggs, and the Nettle distylled together, with which the
kydneys and bladder anointed, provoke speedily vryne: this borrowed out of
Leonellus.

Of the Oil of Antymonie, and those which are prepared of the same, named the
glass, or precious stone, and powder. The xxiiij. Chapter.
STimini, or Stibium, of the later Practisers named: which with the Chymistes,
and makers of Oils, and sweet ointments, Antimonium, is now by great
experience, well accoumpted of and used very common among men, and with great
praises extolled. For there are three kynds of remedies, prepared of the
Antymonie: which either given within ye body, or applied without, do cause
miracles. Of which the one and first, named the oil and Quintessence: the
other and second, the Powder: and the third the glass and precious stone.

Of the oil of Antymonie. The.xxv. Chapter.
THe preparing and making of an Oil of Antymonie, which I received and learned
of a certain friend, is on this wise: take of crude Antymonie, and of crude
Tartare, of each half a pound, these after the beating together in a mortar,
or laboring on a stone, put into a pot well glased before, the mouth of which
let be close covered, with a cover and lute, that no air after breath forth,
and the pot so prepared, give to the potter, to set among other pottes to bake
in his Furnace. For by this burning it is made a paste, and blackishe or
swartishe read of color, round formed, and easily brought to powder: which
after the pot is through cold, and the pot opened, let the substance be
taken forth, beaten, and brought again into fine powder, after powered again
into another pot well glased, on which power distylled vinegar so much, that it
may lie two fingers breadth above the substance: this pot then set on a Furnace
to be heated, that the vyneger may approach and draw to a redness, and with
the same colored. And it ought to stand on the Furnace, for three or four
hours, the vyneger after shyfted into a distyllatory of glass, and other
vinegar powered upon: and the same so often do (I suppose six, or eight times)
until the vyneger be no more colored. All that colored vinegar powered forth,
distyll by a Lymbecke, that the vyneger may so be separated by distyllacion,
and the red substance abide or remain in the bottom. Which done, break
the glass, taking the whole forth, which cleaves or sticks to the glass,
and put into an ypocrase bag made of white cloth, the same hang in a cold
and moist Seller, where the oil will distyll forth drop by drop, into a glass
standing under. And in this manner, was a certain Practisioner, wont often to
prepare and make the same.

An oil of Antimonie also is gotten after this manner, communicated to
Gesnerus, by a most skillful practisioner, in the making of this matter. Let ye
Antimonie be brought into most fine powder, and powered into a glass body, on
which a most sharp wine vyneger powered, and the same distylled, stiepe on a
soft heat of fire, (least the glass break) so long time, until the vinegar
be changed read. The same thus colored, power into another glass, and on
the Feces power new distylled vinegar, until the same in like manner has
purchased a red color. These powrings upon, and addicions of new vinegar on
the Feces, ought so often to be repeated, until the powders send out of them no
more redness. The vinegar all gathered ought to be distylled with a soft fire,
until the redness beginning a little and little to thicken, seame to arise and
appear in the head. Then are the vessels to be cooled, and the red lycour,
set to dygest under hot horse doong for xl. days, until it attayneth ye
perfect form of an oil. The same some affirm, to be so sweet as sugar: to
cease al paints of wounds, and to heal them perfitly as certain write:
besides it does marvelously cure throublesome and tedious ulcers* and such
Cankred.

Another secret of Antimonie, which also unto the white work, not meanly
avails: take af Antimonie brought to powder, *xi. ounces, of Tartare
calcyned.ix. ounces, these after the myxing together, put into a goldsmythes
melting pot, which closely luted and stopped, set into a Furnace for two
hours, and it will well be calcyned, the same after it be cooled, and the mouth
of the pot opened, you shall find the substance in the pot, to be of a darcke
ashie color, myxed with certain yellow spots. This then beaten in a mortar,
put into hot water, and boiled in an iron pan, let the whole be after
distylled by fyltering, which distylleth like to lie. The first water yssewing
is read and troubled, which poured after on the Feces, will distyll and be
gathered clear. This water then euaporate in a glass Cucurbite in sand,
until the substance be left dry, or the moisture resolved. But this matter
left in the sand distyll, as first with a soft fire, after with a stronger,
until the spirits of the Antimonie begin to ascend, and begin as it were to
color the neck of the Lymbeck like gold. Then set the matter in it self, be
cyrculated. Some report, that if thynne silver plates be laid in this that they
are wholye gylded, and appear like gold, in such manner, that rubbed with the
touch stone, they yet appear as gold. But I suppose (says the Aucthour) that
it will be far better, if the first troubled water colored be kept a part,
and new powered on the Feces: for peradventure the second and third water,
would draw and carry with them more of the redness of the Antimonie, which
after gathered into one, may then be drawn with a soft fire, until the oily
redness appearing.

Another manner, which a certain practisioner often exercised and used: let
first the redness of the Antimonie, drawn many times by the distylled
vinegar, as is above taught, and let the exhaltacion of the vinegar be after
done on a soft fire, and the red powder preserved in the bottom. Let the
Quintessence then of wine be powered to it, and stand to cyrculate together for
forty days: this after may safely be ministered by the mouth, into the body.

Another manner, of the same Aucthor: take the Tartare calcyned unto a
whytnesse, let it run with the Antimonie in a gold^smit^es Crucible, this
after brought into powder, dissolve in hot water: and you shall so find a
certain redness to swym above ye water, all which gathered, and put into a
retort, a water first ysseweth, and a most bewtiful read oil after follows,
let ye same be cyrculated for *xl. days, and the best oil of Antimonie will
the^ be purchased, less corros^ue. And this manner, who that can be understand
and compass, shall attain a rytch oil, singular in many causes.

Another oil of Antimonie, learned of a French Empericke: take of Antimonie
two pou^ds, of Tartare, and of salt nyter, of each three ounces, of copper
Incisi one pound, al these grinded together, put after into a glass body, and
not vnglased body, which set into a furnace, make a great fire for three
hours. After ye cooling of the vessel by the own accord, break the vessel,
and you shall find in the bottom ye Mercury of the Antimonie separated from ye
brimstone, which you shall separate from the upper: this done, burn after the
upper face so long, until it be come impalpable, and of a red color, ye same
the^ put into a glass Lymbeck well luted, if it before be dissolved in most
strong vinegar. Which distyll after the manner and order of strong water, and
you shall possess a most precious oil like to blood. Note, that the Mercury
drawn out of the Antimonie, is a most pure gold, with which if you will
color, take then of the oil of Antimonie one ounce, of Aeris v^^i, and of
Viridis aeris, of each three ounces, of Vermilon or Cinnabaris fifteen ounces,
of salt nyter five ounces, of the abouesayd white gold four pou^ds, these put
into an earthen vessel well luted, and set in an open furnace, with fire for
six hours, and you shall then find a cytrin^ mass^: which put unto the
royal cemente, after unto Capella, and you shall obtain most pure gold. But
these royal cements, and the Capellas also, do goldsmythes prepare and make.

Another description of the Oil of Antymonie, not to be contempned,
communicated to Gesnerus by a skylfull practisioner, and very studious in these
matters. Take of Antymonie three pou^ds or four, which dyssolue in a
goldsmythes pot, that it may ru^ne. After power a measure of vinegar, into an
earthen glased vessel: which done, and the Antymonie molten, let him then
instyll by great care and dyligence, a little of this molten Antymonie into the
vinegar (taking diligent care, that you instyll not to much at one time, in
that the vessel then breaking, you should lose both oil and your labor) and
a red fume will breath forth, and the vinegar also will become so red as blood.
So that by times, and a little and little, and even by drops as it were, must the
whole Antimonie be thus instilled. For ye same is in a glass body, that the
vinegar floting above it, must always be separated, and so often, as it is
molten in the goldsmythes vessel. The Antimonie then must be again molten in
the Crucible, as before, and as the same shall be molten, it must then by little
and lytl^ ^e instylled into the vinegar* as above taught, and the same ought to
be repeated seven times, that it may so draw and gather both the property and
redness. The vinegar is consumed by the same order, and for that cause must
other vinegar be powered upon (for if the pot or vessel shall remain either
empty, or be over filled, the vessel breaks: for which cause, you must
especially take heed of the excess) least the vessel by such means
breaks. That if it shall be repeated seven times, let the red vinegar in a
glass body dilygently luted, be distilled in ashes: and a white vinegar will
yssew, but the oil remains behynd in the bottom. Which on this wise done,
and the spring or Cunduicte water left so with the oil for a time, that softly
powered forth, and distylled again, the savor af the vinegar may so be taken
from the oil. The same after it shall be thus twyse together ordered, that is,
the second time Cunduite water shall be powered upon, and by distyllacion shall
after separate the same, you shall then obtain a sweet oil of Antimonie, in
the bottom of the Cucurbite or glass body. But this form and manner of
dystylling, can not so well be uttered and discrybed in words, as by
demonstracion to the eye, and sight of the same done.

This way and manner also of making the Oil of Antimonie, is not to be
contempned: which as it should seame, Theophrastus Paracelsus, accoumpted for a
rare secret. He took of Antimonie half a pound, of Sugarcandie six ounces,
these brought to fine powder, distyl in sand, or in Balneo, according to art.
Of this oil take one ounce, of Aloes succotryne half an ounce, of Amber two
drams, of Saffron three drams, these after reduce into a mass, of which make
small pylles, according to discretion: let three of these be mynistred or given
by the mouth, with the conserve of Borrage, before the fytte of the Ague, and
the pacient procured to sweat, if it be possible.

I hear of an oil of Antimonie, to be distylled in the worthy City of Vlmes
in Germany, by a notable Physician, in the like order and manner, as the strong
water (or water of separation) is wont to be made. Which before wrought into
most fine powder, and myxt with a small quantity of good Aqua vitae: for thus
prepared, it may aptly be applied and given by the mouth, for the healing of
ulcers within the body. Such an oil also is exercysed and used of the
Chyrurgians, in the City of Norimberge, which applied, does forth with eat
or take away superfluous, or rotten flesh. This oil of the Antimonie is
prepared, with the salt G^mme, and Ammoniacum.

Another manner of oil there is, which a certain practisioner druncke before
me (but certain affirm the same not to be an oil, but rather a certain
washing or Lie) yet I suppose the same (says the Aucthour) to be distylled.
Others affirm it to be prepared, like the oil of Vitryoll: of which matter,
read more in that book named Coelum Philosophorum, where the manner of such a
preparing, and this oil is fully taught. And I hear (^sayth the Aucthour)
that the Chyrurgians of Norimberge do much and often use this oil.

There is besides a certain oil prepared and made, which by reason of the
redness, is named the blood of Stibium, which oil is most singular unto
creeping ulcers, and malign to cure, for this dries and takes away all the
malignity of them: and this oil is made after this manner, out of the learned
Fallopio of Metals or mines. They take (says he the Regulum of Antimonie,
which is here meant the Antimonie, five or six times molten and cooled. For
they take the Stibium, melting if, and letting it cool, which they again
melt, and cool the same, and proceed after this manner, unto the fyft, or syxt
time: so yt the Stibium which the last time remains cooled and compact, they
name Regulu^. Now they take this Regulum, and soften it on a marble, on which
they power the distilled vinegar, and when the same shall be very well softened:
they put into an ypocrasse bag to fylter, and power distilled vinegar upon,
until the Antimonie shall be wholly dyssolued and molten through, and that
nothing remains behynd in the fylter or bag, but all fyltred into the
vessel set under. They after take the strayning, or that lycour, and put it
into a Lymbeck, and dra^re forth a lycor: which drawn, there remains a
certain substa^c^ in the bottom of the Lymbeck, like to a red feces, which
they take, and put into a fyltring cloth, hanging it in a moist place, that
the feces may so melt (through the moisture of the place) into a vessel
standing under: and the same which melts and runs through, is the oil,
which otherwise is named the blood of the Antimonie, a medycine (as above
uttered) the notablest unto creeping, and wicked ulcers.

An oil of Antimonie, which is the flower of all mettalles, read in color,
as the Rubyne (for so does some, comm^nd it) it may safelye be taken by the
mouth, unto the wayght of three grains: for in taste it is sweet, pertaking
most lightly of a sharpness: he valewed four drams wayght of it, at two
Crowns. He knew little use or none of it, yet invented he (at the first) to
sell the same of a great price. I my self tasted (says the Aucthour) and
found a certain sweetness of it, and saw the redness tending unto a sanguine
color: and a drop or two let fall into water, went to the bottom. This out
of a letter sent unto Gesnerus.

Another read oil of Antimonie, the ab^^esayd person has, which I (says the
Aucthour) never saw, unlike to the first color, and of a burning qualitye,
whose smallest portion prouooked the bladder, and burned, that unto this day,
the least portion of it, dare not safely be given, through the wicked quality
not sufficiently corrected (whether of the crude quality, I can not justly
report.) This oil powered to Aqua fortis (through the vitriol, the Alome, and
salt peter) it stayneth Mercury of a yellow color. These I understood of
him, in that I could not come to the sight of it: he esteemed or valued half an
ounce of this oil: at a Floreyne. This I learned by the letters of a certain
Physician unto Gesnerus.

The oil or Quintessence of Antimonie, when the same is prepared and made
after a dew form and manner, is a most precious medycine, to be used as well
within the body, as without, and the quantity of one drop given at a time by
the mouth, either with wine or broth, or any other distylled water, does as
well empty the body by vomytting, as downewarde by syege: and this given to a
sick person, does thoroughly cure him of any crude, and malign kind of
sickness: as by trial, a further truth may be known. And this locally
applied on wicked ulcers, does marvelously cleanse them. The making of which
oil or quintesse^ce, is on this wise: take a quantity of the strongest
vinegar, the same distyl thrice over, to which ad of Antimonie so much as you
will, brought to fine powder, these put together in a body of glass, but let
the vyneger flote three fingers above the Antimonie, then stir them very well
together, and setting the body on hot imbers, let the substance boil a little
space, until the vinegar become read, which after the being read, let then
setle, until it appear clear, the same empty into another body, and on the
feces power the like quantity of distylled vinegar, as before taught: the same a
whiles boil, and empty after into another body: and do on this manner so
often, until the vinegar will no more be changed, and become read: this done,
the feces throw away, and all the red vinegar gathered, power into a crook
necked body or Retort, that is very well luted, and distyll the vyneger, which
will yssew forth clear and white: but take dilygent heed, when the red
drops begin to distyll: at the sight of which, draw away the receauer with
the vyneger, putting under another glass, and the fire increase stronger and
stronger, unto the end of the work, or that all the substance be yssewed
forth: for this come, is the quintessence of the Antimonie, which diligently
keep in a glass close stopped, that no air breath forth. And this is the
myraculous oil, that mortifyeth all kynds of rotten and wicked ulcers: for by
bathing on them with the said oil, are mortifyed, for which cause this
heals them in a short time, and with easiness: and given besides with any
lycour by the mouth, does heal any wicked sickness, as above vttred. So that
this Quintessence of Antimonie, may be accoumpted and named a holy lycour, and
precious for the health of man's body. This borrowed out of the singular
practyses of the greek, Leonard Fiorauant.

Of the same, does a certain Physician thus write: I find the oil of
Antimonie to be prepared and made, by Stibium most finely brought to powder,
and so often washed and infused in dystyll vinegar, until it will no more
color nor stayne the fingers, which after sublyme: for this they say, to
avail against the vlcered Canker, that it creeps no further: and so to let
or stay, that the Canker eats nor payneth any more.

An oil of Antimonie of the Alchymistes, unto the coloring of Luna or Silver,
is on this wise prepared, as I found the same written (says the Aucthour) in
an old Alchymy book. Take a a quantity of vinegar three times distylled over,
in this dyssolue of salt artyficiall one part, of salt Alkali two parts, after
the dyssoluing, distyll a strong water. Then take of Antimonie, so much as you
shall thinck needeful, pouring of the said water upon, and distilled with a soft
fire, power upon the water again, and this do for four times together. In
the end, when ye moisture shall asce^d, and that whytishe fumes appear, then by
increasing the fire stronger and stronger, you shall purchase the true oil of
Antimonie. Of this oil take three parts, of ye oil of the Sun one part, of
the oil of Mercury one part, these put unto fixing, does color and change
the Moon, Mercury, and Jupiter prepared, into ye Sun most perfect.

Of the preparation of Antimonie, that is like seen through as the glass, and
the sundry effects of the same powder. The *.xxvj. Chapter.
A Certain practisioner in the City of Vlma in Germany, chose the Stibium,
that had long strakes within, which the longer they were, so much the better he
accoumpted it: and he took away the upper part, or his spume, he after ten
or fowreteene days, grynded the Stibium on a marble with vinegar, for one day
still or continually: but in the night he lets it always dry, and the next
day he always gryndeth it again.



The precious stone of Antimonie, clear through as the Iacynt, they prepare
and make after this manner: the fine powder of the Stibium they put into a
goldsmithes Crucible, covering the same with another Crucible, which two they
close and fast lute together with strong lute, letting ye lute dry. After they
set the Crucibles on the fire and cover them wholly, until the powders melt
and run within: this mass then taken out, and brought to fine powder, they
thus commit to the fire, for two or three times together, and at the third
time, they power the lyquide mass, on a smooth Marble stone, which sone
coniealeth and is hard, and is transparent or to be seen through, even as a
precious stone or glass. It is sufficiently burned or calcyned, by twyse doing
over, and at the third time molten, and powered forth.

Another preparation of Antimonie, not much dyffering from the same, which
Matthiolus in his second edicio^ of Dioscorides discribeth, saving that he
adds also certain other things, where here nothing at al is mixed. Take of
crude Antimonie, the same grind very fine on a stone, which put into a small
Crucible, not glased, setting it unto a soft fire, that the same may putrify
and be cleansed: and stur it continually with an Iron spattle, until the
substance begin to gather up round, which then remove or take away, and grind
the like on a stone, as before, and put into the Crucible, setting the same to
the fire again, and let this so often times be done, until the powder be
changed and come unto an Ashie white color, and this will be, about the x. or
twelf, or more times. After let this be put into a like Crucible, yt the
goldsmythes commonly use, and the same Artly covered, set into coals, that
they may lie burning three fingers above the Crucible, for on such wise, shall
the substance melt and be decocted sufficiently, within the space of half an
hour, the same after take forth, and power into thin plates in a latton basen,
and cooled, keep diligently in a dry bore. For you shall have, yt you desire.

A certain preparation of Antimonie, which many hyde for a most great secret,
and this description did a notable Physician send unto Gesnerus, who was a
singular friend of Gesnerus. After that the Stibiu^ is calcyned, it must so
often be powered forth, as the same may be molten, in a Crucible. And ye same
ought so often be molten, as any impure matter remains in it, and for that
cause, the spume always gathered away. And at the last melting, but little of
the spume must be taken away, and the same part to which the spume cleaves,
(as a cloud) must be thrown away. The same is rightly prepared, yt is clear
and to be seen through, in a manner without any spot, after the form of a
Iacint, which nearer draws or approaches to a yelow, the^ unto a red and
blackish color. And the same the paler it appears, so much the better it is,
so that it be pure, without any cloud, or black spotte.

An Antimonie like to glass, yt may be seen through, and draws to a
redness, communicated to Gesnerus as a secret, by a singular Physician. First
take of Antimonie finely brought to powder (on a stone, or Marble) so much as
you think needeful, the same put into a new earthen pot not glased, which set
on a mean fire, in such order, that it may seem to lean on the one side, as
the pots that burn the lead, and to stur after the substance about with a
spatle. But when ye matter begins first to fume (of the fume shall you
beware, as you would of poison, if you be wise) which after power on a Marble,
and grind about, until the same be cold. This the^ put again into the pot,
sturring the same (as above taught) and when it begins to fume, power it
forth and grind ye same, as before rehearsed. This so often repeat, until it
approaches to a brown color, or otherwise is as black as glass, which is
performed in a manner by the tenth time repeated. The^ take of crude Antimonie
half an ounce, which melt at a strong fire, and of the brown Antimonie burnt
and brought to powder, as above uttered, four ounces, these by little and little
put into a Crucible, unto ye time the half ounce of of the Antimonie molte^,
and the whole be powered in, which so melt together, and when it shall be a
whiles thus molte^, power ye substance on a smooth and cold stone. The same
cooled melt again, and repeat the like, until it shows as glass of a fiery
color, or like to a Rubine. That if you shall diligently mark, and follow this
order, you can not err (believe me) says the Author.

Of the Antimonie thus prepared, they mix a few grains (either five, or six)
with one scruple of the juice of black Ellebere artificially drawn, or more,
and they form pills of ye same, which they name the pills of life yt do
marvelous matters, as they report. And yt the reader should not be frustrate
of any matter, nor of the preparation of this juice, for ye cause I will not
here discame to write the same, yt al me^ may conceive, that there consists
nothing in me worthy memory, yt I refrain to utter, and make known to the
world, so well of mine own practices, as those learned and purchased of ye
singular Gesnerus, to the benefit of all young students, and favorers of good
knowledge. Therefore understand, that the juice of the Ellebore is thus drawn,
let one pound of ye black Ellebore be stieped in hot water for certain hours,
the same the^ shifted forth, power upon other fresh water, and the same
repeat ii^. or v. times, and in the end that water, which is no more bitter,
boil unto a thickness of honey. About the middle of this boiling, add of the
juice of Alkakengi or winter cherries purified, two ounces and a half, but
about the end, of Annise seeds, and of Cinamo^ of each one ounce, of fennel
seeds half an ounce, of the flowers of Nymphaee or the water lilly two ounces
(where must be considered, whether these ought not to enter in the substance
but rather to be put in the last infusion of the Ellebore, and to be strayned
together, that the water alone may after be boiled unto a consumption) in the
end must a little Masticke be added, or at least in the forming of the Pylles.
This procures three or four stools without grief, and causes the belly to
remain sufficient solluble many days after. A certain person required a
great value to be given him, for a dose of these.

Another manner of preparing the Antimonie, that a certain practisioner, which
prepared the same for his Lady, had learned: and this by hap he left briefly
noted in writing: he bought (says the Aucthour) of Stimmeos four ounces and a
half, that is, one quarter of a pound and better of our wayght, the same
brought to powder and searsed: he melted ^n a white earthen pot (the mouth of
it covered with a great burning coal, so laid upon, that the same could not
fall of) upon the coals into the fire: and when this was through cold, he
dilygently considered whether any other myxture of matter consisted in it, that
approached to Tynne, or rather somewhat like Tin (being altogether of the same
kind) which many times the like happens in the Antimonie separated, and is
easily discerned and known: which unless the same be removed and cleared
away, it permysteth not the Antimonie, or rather so hyndereth, when the same is
molten, that it can not be transparent or seen clear through: but we found no
such matter in this Stimmi or Stibium: that if he had seen or known before
the like, he would then not have molten it. But now this black substance
brought again to powder, he powered into a Crucible made of the best earth,
new, and never wetted, and set on a mean fire to calcyne, unto the performance
of which matter, he used almost a day and a half, and sturred the same all the
whiles with a large spattle of iron, still and continually about (but some, as
I remember, do calcyne the same in an earthen skellet or pan) but he rather
supposed the color to come the darcker through the iron vessel (and the
whiles did a most wicked savor of Brimstone continually breath forth) through
which (he reported) ye whiles he was thus bus^ed, the same did often molest and
grieve his head, in such manner as if a fyt of sickness should incontinent
follow. Now this is perceived and known to be sufficiently calcyned, when it no
more sends forth the savor of Brimstome, and that the same appears of an
ashie color, nor can after in the calcyning be burned. The pot in the end
shows burned, and although it be cract and has a cleft in it (as the like he
reports, his pot had) yet may the same last and serve unto the end of the
work, unless the cleft shall wax and be greater. After these, let it be
taken forth, and brought again to fine powder in a mortar, and powered in a
Crucible for an hour space almost, and fire made to it for half an hours
time, this fire after dyminishe by little and little: that if there yet
consists or remains any strange matter behynd, the same may either be taken
away, or purged in the flying away. The Crucible must be covered with another
pot, that it may the sooner be molten. When this shall be through cold, add to
it one dram of Chrysocolla, which brought to powder, shall be mixed in a mortar,
and the whole powered into a crucible, that it may be molten, then occupy a long
iron spattle, or rod, in that a certain peril inseweth by touching the
substance, howsoever it were, if we may believe him. An the melting or running,
which is hardly done at the first (in that for an hour or more standing in the
fire, with great coals laid round about, and blown after with a byggs pair
of bellows, the Crucible, all the whiles appearing read hot, the substance
scarcely melted in that space (yet after the same was molte^, he powered it on a
marble or smoth stone, according to length, or rather in thick and round
plates. The color of the stone, in the first melting, is whytish. The second
melting, and all the others, succeed and come much sooner. After the first
melting, it begins next to appear and show of a darck yellow color: which
little or nothing alters, but abides in the same color in a manner, after the
sixth time molten. When the matter powered forth, is through cold, it must again
be brought to fine powder in a mortar, and molten.

Another manner of preparing the Stibium, take what quantity you will, the same
bring to powder: but first wash it well in cold cunduite water, until in the
same washing this appears pure, after wash this again in the water of Roses,
and the blessed thistle, which let the substance drink in. This powder then
set in the Sun, until it cleaves together in gobbettes or bygge pieces:
which again bringing into fine powder, power into a Crucible. The same melt,
with a soft fire: which as soon as a yellow vapor, and in the color of
Arsenicke, begins to breath forth, and that purple spumes or fomes swell or
rise up to the brymme, increase the fire, adding a certain quantity of each,
answering to the substance, of salt nyter, of the urine of a sanguine or read
man, dyssolued together with that named Hydrargyru^, and spitle of the same
man, so nygh as you can, that these may so be fyxed: which thus ordered, and
mixed in equal portions agreeable, stir about with an iron, or steel rod,
until all the green, and yellow vapors in a manner, be breathed forth. The
cla^mynesse and gl^wish cleaving to of it, you shall thus correct, in that the
same which otherwise was not persitely lyquide, but stycketh, or cleaves to
only, like glue, shall you cause to melt and run. By the side of the Crucible,
you shall set a marble stone, and in the sturring softly about with the rod,
power the liquide matter forth with a broad spattle on a smooth marble stone,
when the time requires. For the uppermost and most frothie by a great deal
power forth, the myddle (being the purer) next, and the lowest more drossie or
fuller of Feces, power last forth with the spattle, the same which runs
whole in the pouring forth, myxe not with the upper spumes, or the middle parts
mix not with the lowest (in that the myddle parts be judged the better) for
which cause, you must dyligently separate them, in pouring forth until the
whole be emptied. But after what manner and how this may be learned and known
these will sufficiently instruct and show, both in the ringing or sound, and
Silver bryghtnesse of the mydle parts. But in the sturring about and pouring
forth, least the wicked and venomous fume, and that dry spirit enters into
the mouth and nosethrelles, a man must carefully beware, for yt the same savor
is in a manner deadlye: so that many there be, which draw a bladder on the
face, to eschew this evil. Now so much as shall be of the purest, and of that
note (as in the ringing and clearenesse) put into a glass, which cover with
burning water six times rectifyed, the same distyll (whether by a Retorte) and
a red water will first yssewe, this draw away, and put under another
Receauer, gathering the same which shall distyll forth. At last, in the winter
or colder time that this may so much the better gather and thicken together)
dygge in the ground of a stable, a f^rrow of two foot in deepenesse, ye same
cast and make into a square room of three foot every way, this ground purge
with burning coals and Bay ^erryes cast among, after the cleansing of the
place, straw then horse doong meanly moist, a foot high: in which set the
glass (that the lycour is contained, which yssewed in the former distillacion)
and cover it (the pype of the same, which shall be put into the Receauer,
stop dylygently with the Philosophers lute) and at the fowrth day you shall
uncover the glass, putting about and covering it with fresh doong. And when
all is come, that will yssew forth, you have purchased the thycke lycour,
resembling or drawing nere to the lycour of Amber. Which power into christaline
and syluerlyke plates, these set abroad, in a cold and clear sky, the North
wind then blowing, that they may thycken and fryse (for these will then be like
as we have seen) in the end we have melted them with so little a heat, as the
Gum is molten: they annoint with this, desperate Cankers left as incurable, the
palsy members* the Apoplexy, and joint aches: and they inwardly mynister two
or three graynes at the most, finely brought to powder. And I hear that he
gave to the person infected with ye plague, not bleeding by vain before, which
shortly after dyed: but to another I heard, he gave the same dose, but letting
him blood before, and he escaped with life.

How the red spirits, is drawn or gotten out of Antimonie, is the most rare
secret, of a certain notable Chyrurgian. Take of pure Antimonie two or three
pou^ds, this dried and brought into fine powder, put into an earthen Cucurbite,
under which make a soft fire in the beginning, for twenty hours space, after
increase your fire somewhat hoter, the next stronger and stronger, unto the
end of.xxxvi. hours. In the belly of the earthen Receauer or Cucurbite, on
the side a high, fasten in a wooden pynne, which now and then drawn out of
the hole, does utter and express the color of the spirit breathing further
and cleaving too, as first white, next yellowishe and yellowe, and last
manifestly read. This sublymation being thus performed, and the vessels
through cold (the powder sublymed by force of the fire) let it be purged from
the Receauer either with a feather, or soft Pares foot, and put into a
Retorte, which set into Balneo Mariae, where let a second exhaltacion be
wrought, which also receive and gather in a glass or earthen receauer. For in
the same manner shall you purchase a powder wholly sanguine in color. And the
receauers into which the spirits or fume of the Antimonie breaths, ought
always o be cooled, with Lynnen clothes wet in cold water and applied upon.
For the Receauers cooled often, do by that means, draw to the^ so much ye
sooner, the fume of the Antimony. Then the bellyes of the receauers ought to be
set vpwardes, and the mouths into which the Cucurbites are fixed, placed
downewardes, as the figure hereafter playner demonstrateth. The Cucurbyte into
which the sublymed Antimonie must be put, ought to be fensed with the lute of
wisdom. But the Cucurbytes receiving, ought to be fourmed through the lute,
to endure the fire. Let their necks be long, in a manner of an arm length: and
the belly by that reason large, least stuffed or filled with the spirits it
breaks. But let the neck be so large, that the hand to the elbow may easily
be put in, and drawn out again, even as this figure here to the eye, does
more perfitly express.



A. Does here represe^t the furnace, and place of the fire, for the preparation
of ye Antimonie unto remedies, in a better manner, then Matthiolus instruc^eth.

B.B Express the Cucurbytes, containing the Antimonie in fine powder, formed
of strong potters clay.

C. The neck of the Cucurbites, te^ding upward, and carrying forth the ^ume
or spirit of the Antimonie, into the receiving vessels. And they ought to be
raised upward, and stayed on some proper shealfe, or on the like that the figure
does here show, or else on a form. The vessels in which the pegges of wood
appear, by which a judgment is bad and learned in the drawing forth of them,
how the fire ought and must be moderated, as either increased or lessened. And
these pegs serve in the steed of tappes of wood: that they may the readyer be
opened or drawn forth, whereby the color of the Antimone isublymed may be
seen, etc.

This powder ought to be ministered, but a little in quantie, at a time, yet how
much (and a perfect dose, does the Aucthour not know) to be given in the
ple^resie, the stoppings of the breast, in the purging of flewme, and in the
french disease, with ye waters answering to each, etc. There be some which
affirm, that they can cure the persons infected with ye french disease, within
three or ii^^. days, after this manner. They include or set the pacient within
a Pype or Butte (that his head may be quite without) and sitting on a stool
boored with many holes, under which they lay a thick plate of Iron meanly or
but lightly heated, and on the same straw of ye powder, that the fume of it may
ascend and compass about all the body, and enter into the body by the lower
parts, and they will the pacient thus to sweat there for three hours, if he
can bear or suffer it, but if (in no wise) he cannot, the^ let the pacient the
oftener repeat this kind or manner of sweating. For in so many days space shall
the foul disease be wholly cleared, as the pacient will exercise and use this
manner of sweating. And this, did a notable Captain report to the Aucthour,
that he saw and knew tried on sundry, to great admyration, etc.

Stimmi or Stib^um is molten in a white earthen Crucible, and set on a fire,
for certain hours (perhaps ten, yet does not Gesnerus express the same)
which after the through cooling, melt again, as before taught, and through
cold, repeat a third and fourth time, so that you shall not need to labor
it (as the Aucthour supposes) on a Marble stone, and on such wise, is his
vapor by little and little consumed, and the color in the end changed into
a yelow, and after thi^ manner, is the powder yelow, wholly subtle, and light,
which is stronger in virtue, then the glass, or the stone of Stibium. For two
or three grains of this in fine powder, shall be sufficient to be ministered at
one time by the mouth The stone of Stibium is brought to powder, yet the same
is grosser, and not so light and yelow, as the other, of which may seven
grains, and more, be given at a time.

Of the Antimonie prepared, the judgment of the learned, and of the use of it.
The.xxvij. Chapter.
OF the Antimonie prepared, which shines like to glass, does a certain
learned man thus judge, as seems by the letters unto Gesnerus: I have (says
he) thoroughly reuolued and called unto judgment the essence of the red
Antimonie prepared, and I find that this glass, not to be the same of ye old
Philosophers, of which they write so many matters, although of ye like it may
be made, in that it is more earthly and of the grosser parts, for which cause,
although we try and find out sundry properties of it or that this has, yet
does it but little possess of the self same virtues, which the ancient
ascribe to their proper glass. And this is named the glass of the
Philosophers, although (in very deed) it be no glass but rather a certain
natural Sugar, and that sweet, and clear or to be seen through like
Crystal, and cold, as the yse, coniealed. The preparation of this Antimonie,
is not the self same, or a like framed with all persons, by which reason it
does not cause nor work a like effect. That if we could attain, and purchase
a true and sure preparation of this Antimonie, it were a singular treasure
won.

Of the use of the Antimonie, as he has experienced, for on such wise Gesnerus
writes The Antimonie prepared (as Matthiolus instructs) I gave in the year
1563. and in the.xxij. day of January, to a Melancholy person, sore vexed,
which had often assayd to destroy himself, and a fleshie young man, five
graynes almost in powder, mixed with a little conserve of Roses and wine, framed
in a bale or dose (yt lay before on bed for three or four days, without
eating in a manner any meat, and could scarcely lift up his head, but with a
certain turning about, and imagined that he saw devils, through which he
came sorrowful and fearful, and with sighs calling on God) within an hour
after, yt a fat brothe was given him, he strongly vomited and within a whiles
after, he made sundry sieges or stools together, yet felt he after a mighty
^ormenting and vexing about the heart and belly, with a grievous headache sore
molesting, yt he never endured ye like in all his life time, as he reported,
(yet increased nevertheless the sickness, Melancholy lur^king in him, and he
became after marvelous thirsty and dry, to the qualifying of which, he had
drunk over much water with wine) he refrained besides supper, and slept
nothing, but lay groaning and sighing all the night, and vomited again the
morrow following, to the staying of which I gave him Rob de Ribes with the
syrup of Quinces, and the syrup of Roses, with wine and water warmed
together, and cordial matters I applied on the breast. The next day following
was given to him brothe, whether he would or no, after which he slept almost an
hour, and he began then to wax better. Nevertheless I applied to the
foreheade, a linen clothe wet in the water of Roses, Lettuce, the oil of
Roses, and vinegar, which I commanded a good whiles before to be done, but they
had neglected it. And I minded to have ministered to him of the oil of vitriol,
if he had not amended or recovered somewhat, and perhaps ye conserve or syrup
of Nymphea, I had given. The same night, I willed to be given him a little
quantity of new Triacle after myd night, if the vomiting ceased not, or yt he
slept not, but they gave him to little a quantity of it. Here note, yt I only
licking my fingers, whiles I mixed ye medicine, within two hours after, felt
an aching; and swimming or giddiness of the head, and cast much water and
spittell of my stomach, with a little gryping and pain in ye bottom of my
belly, especially of the right side, and provoking my self to vomit, I dranck
after of the syrup of wormwood warmed, and amended. The same Antimonie was
clear, and of a yelow color, and to be seen through as a precious stone, or
Glass, and lightly broken between the teeth. In the Hospital of Tygurie in
Germany, to a certain other person mad, Gesnerus gave of ye Stibium
prepared, and clear as glass, and nothing of the fumyng matter in it, six
grains in fine powder, and when he was about to vomit, he (upon the eating of
bread) sent the matter down ward so that he felt but a little pain in the
belly, yet this after wrought and caused, four sieges or stools. But the
next day after he said and complained, that his head marvelously grieved
him. Gesnerus also gave to a dropsye person, six graynes of the Stibium
prepared, darcke and fumyng a little, which after was grievously vexed about
the heart, the pain contynewing unto the next morrow, and he purged upward,
and downward, but little in quantity.

A certain notable, and singular preparer of the Antimonie wrote unto
Gesnerus, yt he had give, more the^ to four hundredth persons of every kind and
age, this his Antimonie, not only without any harm, but with prosperous
success. He gave of this to five taken with the pestilent Ague, who after
recovered to health. He also affyrmeth it to be a present remedy* in the
Plague, but who that minds to receive of ye Antimonie, may neither before,
nor after the taking of it, blede by vain. Of this his Antimonie he sent
certain parts, being of three sundry colors, differing one from the other,
of which the same, that was of a red color, be preferred before the others, in
yt the same tarried a longer time in the fire, that it might attain the
color, and so the virtue breathed forth. But for that it is a deeper red to
fire, for yt cause must a greater dose or quantity be ministered. The same
person gave of the red Antimonie, to a certain man strong of body, five
grains, but to such which were mean of strength, and to women, he ministered
only four grains. And to the persons weak of body, only three grains. But
if any shall be of a mighty strong complexion, the^ to him may six grains be
safely applied, but he thinks not good to minister above this dose, where
necessity requires, it may be ministered at any time of the day, yea at
midnight if need shall be, so that it be received five or six hours after
meat, and before or rather after the taking, to fast two or three hours. But
where necessity does not so urge or require, the aptest time in giving of it,
shall be in the morning, an hour before the sun rising. I minister (says he)
this Antimonie against al Agues, the dropsy, the Iaundise, the bloody
scouring, the Melancholy of women, rewmes the pains of the head, ye french
disease singularly, a costiue belly, the flewme and fullness of the breast and
stomach, a stinking breath proceeding of the corruption of the stomach,
poisons, fransynesse and many other diseases, these hitherto be his. Against
the falling sickness, take of the powder of Antimonie, of Dragons blood, of
Castorie, of each two drams, these brought to powder and mixed, minister after
Art, this also put under the tongue of a child, if need requires.

Gesnerus also has thus noted, by the judgment and opinion of others, of the
manner of using of the same. The dose of Stimmeos or Stibium to be prepared and
given to the strong persons, must be in weight either five or six grains, but
to persons weak of strenght, only three or four grains, mixed with Sugar
Roset, or Violets. To children being four, five, or six years old, give but
one grain weight and a half, in the Rob or syrup of Walwooort or elder
flowers. To slender old women, one grain, with milk. For this works within
an hour, or half an hour, after the taking. This also may be ministered (as
some report) to women with Child, without peril or harm (which I marvelously
doubt.)

They which mind to receive the Antimonie prepared, let them take it with a
fasting stomach, not eating any meat after, for seven or eight hours: but
within a whiles after the taking, let the person drink a little quantity
warm, of the broth of C^cerum. And keep within the house, for two days
space, and moderately drinck yt time. Some use of the Stibium being only most
finely brought to powder and calcyned, with ashes or Lyme in the same manner,
but it rather seems safer, that it be sundry times molten before.

This helps sicknesses, and first the pestilence, and those also which be
infected with it, soon after the same is ministered: it is given besides to
purge, for the preseruatiun of health. It is also a singular medicine, against
poisons drunck. It secondarily helps the^, which be continually vexed with
headache. It thirdly staieth rewms, falling to the Lungs. It fowrthly, helps
the grieffes, and pains of the stomach, and weakness of the same. It does
fifthly remedy, the dropsy. This sixthly, helps the hard fetching of breath,
and ha^dnesse to breath. This seventhly, does cure, the particular palsy. And
eyghtly, this helps ye falling sickness. Nynthly, this cures quartaine
Agues. The tenth is, that the same remedieth yt Melancholy, the frantic, and
mad persons. The eleventh, whose bodies do inclyne to a kind of Leprie, and
be affected with a foul scabbe. Many prepare and make pylles of Stibium, after
this manner. Take of Aloes half an ounce, of Cynamon half a dram, of Cloves
half a scruple, of Masticke half a dram, these artly myxed, make a mass of
the whole with Rosewater. Take of this mass, unto the quantity of three
Tares, to which myxe three graynes of the Stibium prepared, and with Rosewater
or wine, frame to the form of a pyll, which minister in two or three pylles.

A certain secret of a skylfull practisioner, in the cure of that piece of
flesh above in the nose causing a stincke, with Antimonie prepared. Take of
the powder of the Antimonie prepared, after make a tent, which annoint with an
ointment serving to the purpose, the same then roll in the said powder, and
put up to the flesh in the nose: for this speedily cures, and it is
experienced many times. After the use or taking of Antimonie, unto the
comforting of the stomach, certain are wont to give, these medicines
following. Take of the pleasant spiced wine, named Hypacras, two parts, of the
Inlep following, one part: in these mixed together, dyp a toast of white bread,
on which after straw of the powder of the electuary of the three Sa^ders, and
so much of ye pouders of the mynt and worm wood. The Inlep, is on this wise:
take three parts of ye Aqua vitae drawn through a parchment skyn wet with the
oil of Annise seeds, or with some other sweet smelling oil, and the same
distylled by the vapor only of Balneo Mariae, and of Rosewater two parts. In
the Aqua vitae let a few cloves be infused for a night, which mixed together,
add to sugar, so much as shall suffice. The French men are wont to give some
Cawdell, or broth, after the taking of the Antimony, when the person feels
him self provoked to vomit, that he may the easilyer vomit. This gathered out
of the letters, of a certain notable physician, unto the singular Gesnerus.

A certain Empericke affyrmeth, that it may at all times or always be safely
given to the sick of the quartaine: and he also vttreth certain proper
experiments of the same. For he gave of the same, to a certain dropsy person,
and had good success. Yet he affyrmeth, that this pacient at the first, was in
great danger. Of whom when we required to know the cause of this, he answered,
that he could not purchase the Antimony, sufficiently prepared.

To conclude, a certain practisioner affyrmeth, that the Antimonie is and may
safely be taken: for this kind of medicine (as he alleges) has the same
property of nature, that it rayseth or sends away no benign and profitable
humor in the body, but expels only the noyouse: and the same either by
sweat, which where it appears, occasion is then moved, either by vomit, or
by stool.

Certain do marvelously extol the use of Antimony, and suppose it to pass or
excel al other remedies, in the^ which be infected with the pestilence: but I
(says a most singular man) in his letters unto ye learned Gesnerus, which have
the Antimony as well prepared, as they have, know much harm done to many in ye
giving of it. For in ye taking of it, it grievously afflicts or torme^teth the
heart, which is especially caused and wrought in pestilent Agues, this is
certain.

Of the use of Antimony, a certain other learned man thus writes unto D.
Gesnerus: it answers in all, as gold to life, both in the preparation and
use. The Antimony in the use, but not in the preparation, that it expresses or
resembles not the Iacint, it manifesseth. I now have first prepared it, and
in the preparation of the same, certain, have tried it, as a perfect matter.
So that in their report of practice, and proper preparation trusting, gave
three graynes of it to a certain person, who within two hours and a half
after, vomyted six times, and went three times to the stool, procuring nor
leaving after it any harm.

Of the Antimony prepared, and his use, another certain learned thus writes
unto D. Gesnerus. I here send to you but a small piece of Stibium prepared, as
the learned Matthiolus upon Dioscorides instructs, of which he utters a
number of notable virtues, that if those were certain and true, who I beseech
you were happyer than I: which may by this medicine rydde or deliver my self,
from that my continual, and cruel sickness, as he reports there a story of a
certain person incombred with much windiness of body, like cured. But I have
used the powder of this (unto this day) and given it more then to twenty
persons, having sundry diseases: in all which, this first procured vomyting,
and after sundry great sieges or stools, and those without grief in the body
after remaining, as Matthiolus in the same place affyrmeth. And although
certain, of the^ became after better, yet were none wholly cleared of their
sickness. For which cause, whether the same perhaps may often be ministered, I
now doubt. But our noble persons much allow and commend it, seeing it taken in so
small a quantity, does so singularly and thoroughly purge corrupt humors. I am
wont (says he) to myxe this poison, with most pleasant conserues, and iuyces:
in such manner, that without any procurement to vomit, they may the wyllinger
and lightlyer swallow down the same. I my self (says he) have since used or
taken of it, to the quantity of two graynes, where I otherwise gave three
graynes, and for truth, without any grief in a manner: and I first vomyted
above half a pynt of green choler, with most tough flewme: after I made nine
sufficient stools, but the sickness nothing abated of these, but I rather
after a few days became worser (so yt I customably affected with the
Mela^choly disease in my fla^k) was constrained, to cease from taking any
purging medicine, whether they shall be vehementer or gentler, etc. That if any
be apter or easier to vomit upward, and harder to purge downward, or at ye
least indifferent, to this person may you safely minister two or three grayns
weight of this Stibiu^. But to the^ which hardly and painfully vomit, and have
a loose belly, or be of a slender and weak nature, this ministered, is not
without peril. The same which hitherto I have studiously observed: have I in
my letters, faithful written to you.

Again another certain Physician, writes unto D. Gesnerus, of ye use of
Antimony prepared. I send here to you Antimony, as you required the same of
me, prepared by the fire, and brought to powder, and in that I would not
purchase now the whole to send you. I for that cause send you two sorts: the
one which declineth unto a blackness, is the self same, that here with us was
often ministered to many. Of the use of this, I can report yt the same never
harmed: but I suppose there is another, far better and worthyer. They which use
the same, do give of it in the form of pyls, making an incorporatio^ with an
apt syrup. They give these pyls a little before meat, yt the meat may so insew
sone after the taking of the medicine, for by such means they affirm them to
be retained, and the working of this to be then strong. But they be many times
cast up again, before their proper working, if a longer space or time be
