deferred, between the taking of the medicine, and the meat orderly dressed.

Of the oil of Brymstone. The.xxviij. Chapter.
ALthough brimstone appears dry and hard in sight, and for that may seem to
be quite without moisture, insomuch as no oily substance ca^ be drawn out of
it: yet the same for truth, is not so dry, and hot, but yt by the mixtion of
elements, a certain moisture, and the same fatty, by which truly it consists
in this form, it does and may contain to it adjoined: for an oil is
distylled out of it, as sometimes absolutely and by it self, without the
myxing together of any other simples: but sometimes other simples, are mixed
also to it.

An oil out of brimstone alone, as B^assanolus affirms, distilled and
gathered marueilously by force of fire, and yse. But ye best should be, if any
(says he) would purchase ye sweating of the brimstone, which in brymstony
places, out of hyls, as a flower sends it forth: yet it may and ought to be
named the flower of the brimstone: for as ye dew, even so does the sweat issue
forth of the stones. When I (says he) accompanied our most noble Duke to
Naples, unto the mighty Charles Emperor, in the year. 1535. and being there,
labored to see those hot bathes named Baiae, and other deep pyts of boiling
water, where among the mountains lies or is a goodly valley, in the myddle of
which does a water boil most hot, and in another Angle of it, is there a
pytte boiling, the ground or soil of this vall^e appears blew, and
compassed with mountains round about: certain Ch^^dren were there, which I
saw wype the hills with theye fingers, who after thrusting the fingers into
the mouth, lyeked them sweetly: which (when I saw) I demanded what the
children then did, and answer was made me, that they did eat Brymstone, and
that it was most sweet: then began I to taste that flower, which did sweat
out of the stones like dew: and I found this to be most sweet, insomuch that
the same morning I would eat none other thing at my dinner, saving bread, and
that most sweet flower of Brimstone: and this is the very same, out of which
the most perfect oil should be made. And in another place he writes again,
where he uses the like word* an oil of Brymstone may be distylled as well
out of the mine stone, that is, ^he Brymstone not tried by the fire, as out of
the (...) molte^ of the fire. But the best oil to be co^iectured, is drawn
out of the flower of brymstone: but out of the Brymstone tried by fire, that is
puryfied and fine^* or purged from the stones and earth, by force of the fire
is better, and out of the s^^e, which has not (...) molten or ^ried of the
fire, i^ a good oil distilled and gathered. The oil a part and simple i^
(...) any other thing, a great hea^ of (...), after the fou^ me of the head of
a Tin (...), with a Nose, being la^ge bene^^h and narrow above, ^ having a
kn^bbe to hang by which so tie up, that the same may (...) from the touching of
any other thing in that place (...) another vessel, narrower then the compass
of the (...) of white earth (...) which power your (...). And let you^ ^ell
hang so high from the vessel under it, that the smoke going out, choketh or
puts not out the fire, but that the smoke may wholly go up and be received
within the Bell, which if you hang the same two or three fingers distant, from
the vessel set under, it will well come to pass, and to the nose set a
receauer, having a little Musk in it dissolved in Rosewater, these done,
kindle the Brimstone in such manner, that the fume or smoke whiles it burns,
may ascend and rise all within the head, and the Brimstone ought to be sturred
sometimes, that it may burn the fre^^er. And this conceive, that neither any
water or oil will distill, until the time, it makes a certain thick cote
or crust within the Bell, round about, this Crust will be sometimes a whole day,
or it be thoroughly made, and the oil then begins to distill which
diligently gather. And this note, that never nothing distilleth forth, until
a thick cote or crust be gathered and made round about the Bell, and when the
Brimstone fails in the dishe, or vessel set under, then by little and little
power in of the Brimstone, that it may orderly burn, which spent, pour in
more after the same manner, and this do so long, until you see* that you have
gathered a dark red oil, which diligently keep in a glass. And this
conceive, that of five pounde^ of Brimstone, you shall hardly gather one ounce
of oil. And your Brimstone beaten must not be powered in all at once, but by
little and little, as it wa^^eth. And this is one of the rare medicynes, that so
long time has been hyd, and is also of such efficacy, and virtue, that
scarcely any man will bel^eue the marvelous effects, unless he had or
should see the wounderfull matters, that this does. For I (says the ^^mous
Leonard Fiorauant) never used this lycour, but that it singularly wrought,
especially mynistred by the mouth. And this oil thus sweetened, being very
sour or eager in taste, may be made potable or to be druncke, if it be mixed
with waters agreeable, and proper to the matter, or rather with any pleasant
Sy^ope, and the quantity at one time to be ministered, is sour graynes, unto
six, ^n^ not above. It may be incorporated or accompanied with all manner of
Electuaries, and kind of Pylles, and work a further benefit and help so
mixed, then ministered alone. This helps all sickenesses, as well the hot, as
the cold, etc. And is a most effectuo^s oil in easing of the tooth ach, and
whytning of the teeth. For thi^ ^^th vehemently dry up the moisture of them. A
certain person of great report, used the same in the french ulcers, and of the
yard, for although this in the beginning byteh somewhat, yet does it after take
away the pain and ulcer. The heat of it is qualified, with the white of an
egg beaten, and squirted in and upon, or with the ointment of Ceruse applied
upon or butter often washed. This cures also the wicked ulcers of the Gumes or
Jaws, and mouth in Children, unto Canckers, and wartes (which I in my self
prosperously have tried) and other desperate diseases. This oil of Brymstone
is applied into the Fistulaes of the fundament and Buttocke, and other members
of the body, with a syring or squyrte and the heat, if any such be, is after
qualifyed, as above taught, and it fylleth Fistulaes by the help of the white
Ellebore, and this experienced. This besides orderly ministered by the mouth
with any apt Syrup, does help the sheuering cold of the Ague, in that after
the taking, this provoke the body to sweat, and purges much matter by
vryne, it also dries up all the evil humors of the stomach, and heals all
Agues, which come by accident of cold, it dissolueth the stone in the kydneys,
and applying of it an ulcers, speedily cures the^, in that this heateth and
dries. And this oil does, all the abouesayd matters myraculously, as ye
Aucthor reports, who many times proved them, and had singular success.

Matthiolus has also a description of the oil of Brimstone, in a manner like
to this, saving that there is a certain difference of the vessels. Let a large
mouthed glass having a long tail retching out (like to yt lamp hanging in a
Church) be set into sand or Ashes in a bo^le or other vessel of wood, that the
same may stand steddie and upright. Then about the edge of the glass, let an
iron vessel be hanged (in height three fingers from the glass) being oyther
round or square, and bo^^d through in four places, where let iron wiars be
thrust down to the brim or edge of the glass, in such manner, done that ye
vessel in no manner touches the glass, but the wyars only, and above the
glass let a long and deep pot be hanged, that at the least, a foot, which
may receive the fume ascending, that it may distill again by the nether edges
of yt pot into ye glass standing under. A man must in the mean time whiles ye
Brimstone burns pour on new powder by little and little with a spone, and the
plate (whose nether part draws unto the bigness and form of the joint of
the thomb) lay in burning hot, and pour always new brimstone in until one or
two pound be consumed. That if the oil thus succeeds or comes not, in that
the Brimstone perhaps shall be over dry, the pot which inward received the
fume, set into a cold and moist place, and the oil within two days will so be
gathered.



Isabella Cortesa utters an apt manner, of the making of the oil of
Brimstone: take of cytryne Brymstone a certain quantity, which bring into fine
powder, ye same then power into an earthen pot neyled, like to that which the
Pottecarie puts his ointment into, this set vpryght, fylling it in a manner
full, or near to* After hang over a Bell of glass, like to the form of a
Lamp, as you see here figured. This done, set the vessel on an earthen
platter glased, into which then put an iron plate read hot, on the said
brimstone, and forthwith hang over the said Bell: in such manner, that it
touches not the mouth of the vessel standing under, whereby the oil may so
distyll round about, and fall into the platter* For the said brymstone does
then make a sufficient smoke al about the Bell, through which is caused, that
the oil distylleth down, and into the platte^. If so be you hang the Bell in
such order, that it (...) covers the mouth of the vessel, and be the breadth
of a knyfe haft distaunt from it, and the vessel standing in a large platter
very fair within, that the oil may fall into it, which ordered on such wise,
let so remain, until all the Brymstone be burned in the vessel. After shyft
the oil into a glass, which keep to your use.

The Brimstone (as a certain practisioner reports) does not dystyll by a
glass, hanged on high, but cleaves and sticks to the ^^^es of the glass.
For that cause, let a little Aqua vitae be powered into the glass, so much, as
will only wet all the sides of the glass round about, in rolling the Aqua vitae
to all the sides and parts of the glass round about. After let the whole
glass be ^euer^^ with a wooden boole, a sheet of paper put between, that no
air breath forth, and set into a cold and moist place for certain days,
until all the matter so settled in the bottom, and distylled by a glass
Lymbecke. Or if the whole matter be clear, power it then into another long
necked clear glass, and let it be separated, that the oils may so be
separated.

Another manner out of Sulphur vyue, which a certain Physician uttered to the
Aucthour: first the brymstone ought to be a little calcyned, but warely that it
be not burned, or set on fire, in such manner that it may almost be brought into
powder. After distyl the same by ascension, for it then easily ascends. But
he affyrmed, that hard it is, to prepare this oil: nor that he could well
discribe the manner of the same, but that a present sight in the doing is
rerequyred. Unto D. Gesnerus from a certain place, was a small piece of
brimstone sublimed sent, out of which an oil was drawn: which is the like
astringent, as the oil of vitryoll, and is rather of a watery substance, than
oily, which I marueyle at. This borrowed out of a certain Epistle, unto
Doctor Gesnerus.

Again unto D. Gesnerus, wrote an old friend, and learned man, thus of the
oil of brymstone. Let the brymstone not yet tried on the fire, be kyndled in
an earthen pan, and on the pan standing on a Treuet, hang a head, as some name
it, or a Bell (being of glass) and pargeted with lute: that it may receive the
fume of the brimstone, which within it is thyckned into an oil, and by the
pype or Nose of the Bell stylleth forth into a Receauer standing under, which
so gathers the oil distylling.

Another way: certain do make it, after another manner: unto one part of the
powder of Brymstone, they add another part of flynt stones like brought to
powder: this myxture power into a Retort, and set over a very soft fire, they
so draw a singular oil. Which oil in what manner diseases it may be used, and
with what it may be given in each, and in what quantity and how, shall
brief^y be here under uttered.

This oil is used in cold diseases, whose cause proceed and are the humors
either cold or putryfyed, or in whom much wind consists, as in rotten
Agues, Tertians* Quoti^ians, and Quartaynes: in the Pestilence, in wounds, in
ulcers, espetially hollow and wynding, in many grieffes of the brain, the
mouth, the teeth, the stomach, the Liver, the Mylt, the Matrice, the bladder,
the Bowelles, and joints: to those also which proceed, of the abundance of
humor, or of putrefying.

And a little of this oil is ministered, with a distilled lycour, or decoction
of a congruent herb, according to the qualitye of every part and disease.
This is the manner of the measure, a Hens quyl must be dypped into the oil,
and quicklyer drawn out again, and what that ha^geth on the quyl, of the
fatness or oil, the same temper in either syrup, or distylled lycour, and
give to drinck to the sick.

And with what, this may be conjoined in each disease: in the quoti^^a^ Ague,
in the wine of the decoction of Rosemary, or mint, a little before the fyt. In
the Tertian, with the decoction of Centorie in wine. In the quartaine, with the
water of Buglosse. In the Pestilence, with the wine of the decoction of
Radishe, to which a little Triacle and Methridate is mixed. In the ulcers and
sores of the mouth, a feather or fine bombasie wette in the oil, and the same
softlye apply on the vlcered place, for in the repeating sundry times, this
oil does so thoroughly heal the evil. And druncke of such as are molested
with falling sickness, in the decoction of Byttonie and Pyonie, speedily
helps. To such vered with the cough, with Nettle seed and Ysope boiled in
wine. In the abundaunce of flewme, with the water of wormwood. In the pain of
the stomach, and great gutte of wind, with the water of Camomyll. In the
coldness of the Liver and dropsy, with the water of Ireos, Celondyne, and
Honey. In the stoppings and grief of the Mylt, with Aquatamaricis. In yt French
disease, with ^umiterre water, and broom flowers. Against worms, in the long
grass or wormwood water. In the grief of the Matrice, with wine of the
decoction of byttonie and Mugwoort. In the staying back of vryne, with wine of
the decoction of garlike. Unto the cold gowte, with the water of Chamaepytyos.
And in all these, the like manner must be used, as before was uttered, of the
quyll or feather dypped in the oil, and forth with tempered in an apt lycour.
But in wounds and ulcers, the affected place must be anointed with the oil,
and that gentlye with a feather. The tooth that aketh, must be dressed with the
same softly. But if all the teeth pain and ache, then let the pacient hold a
space and wash the mouth, with the hot decoction of mynts, myxed with a
drop or two of the oil.

An oil of brimstone, invented of a certain Physician of Rome, and borrowed
out of a written book in the Italian tongue. An oil of brymstone, is easily
and soon prepared, and gotten with a Bell of glass: but the better, and
perfiter manner, is this. Let the brymstone be finely brought to powder, and so
much of the Pumeyse stone in fine powder, which two myxed together and put into
a Retort, fasten to it a sufficient large and bygge Receauer, and within two
days space, by a most soft fire, (...) shall distyll and gather the oil of
brymstone: which of the Italians is named oil De grata or De regestro. And the
powder of yt Pumeise is added, that the brimstone may not ascend, and that it
may also send the vapors sooner upward. The self same properties in a manner
are assigned to it, which a little before we recyted, saving that in a few, we
noted this diversity. That it cures wounds, by taking of the powder of the
leaves of the Oak, of Pympernel, of E^r^^onie, of Campherie, and of S. John's
wort, al which well beaten together, seath in wine, and to the straining mix a
little of this oil, or at least so much, as may be for the malice, and
greatness of the wound. And with this decoction, let yt fresh wou^d, or old
ulcer ^e washed, and they are speedily cured. In the French disease, after a
sufficient purgation, avayleth the oil ordered in the same manner, as above
taught. These truly, and all the others before written, which are to be applied
here: are reported, to be all experie^ced, by a singular phisitio^ of the
Emperors at Bononie, and of another notable phision at Rome.



An Odoriferouse or sweet smelling oil of brimstone, and potable or to be
dru^cke, which heals and cures in a manner all diseases and griefts how
wicked and desperate so ever they be: borrowed out of the Italia^ book of
secrets, of the singular Fallopio. Let the Brymstone be grosely brought to
powder, which put into an earthen vessel, over which hang a head or Bell with
a Nose, being two or three fingers distant from the vessel, and to the Nose
set a Receauer, in which let a little of pure Musk dyssolued in Rosewater be
put. Which done, kyndle the Brymstone, and the fume shall so ascend and be
received within the head. But before the Brymstone distylleth will a certain
C^ate or thynne skin as it were be gathered within the head (which nothing
will distyl, before this Coat shall be thus gathered round about the head)
remembering always to add or power in of the Brimstone, by little and little, as
the other before shall be consumed. This oil thus dystylled, is caused sweet
smelling, yet very sour in taste. But the same that it may be potable or to be
drunck, and well delyghted to be taken by the mouth, let a inlyppe be made of
Honey, in the same manner as commonly is made of Sugar, into which instyll so
much of the oil of Brymstone now made, as shall be needful to the purpose,
and that the same be not over sour to take. This drunck provoke sweat and
vryne, it cutteth a sunder and ^^ (...) the wicked humors of the stomach, all
Agues, which in ^ade with a cold, it helps, it dyssolueth the stones of the
kydneys* ^^ ^^^eth all kind of ulcers, if they be applied with this oil: in
that of the proper nature, this heateth and dries. And all these, the oil of
brymstone, prepared in the abouesayd manner, I have found to perform by a sure
and infallyble experience.

Another manner* but the same by distyllacion, uttered by the same Aucthour* the
joints before dilygently luted and sealed, and followed with a sof^ fire, ever
increasing the fire by little and little in a mean^ manner. In this manner is and
oil distylled, of singular virtues. First the same expels all manner of
inward impostumes of the body, unto the upper face of it: if of the same be
taken for three or four days* every morning fasting one dram (consider that
the same quantity, it be over much for one time) with broth, or wine, or any
such lycour. This avails in the hard fetching of breath, helps the cough,
the rewme, the evil dispositions of the Liver, any manner of scabbe, and cures
especially the pestilence. It is a treasure also, to ulcers and wounds.

Another manner: let some iron vessel be taken which may be sealed with a
Lymbecke, six fingers or a little more (...), and the same in the nether part
downward by two fyngers, let it have a large hole of three fyngers broad, by
which let the Brimstone be powered in, on this vessel set a Limbeck pergeted
about with lute, after by the hole a low let the Brimstone be kindled, and
burn so long as you think needful, and a lycour will after distill and
yssew forth drop by drop. And this manner although it be tedious, yet is it
not to be contemned.

An oil of Brimstone also is made by descention unto the Chymistick works, in
this manner. Let one part of the Cytrine Brimstone brought to powder, and put
into an earthen vessel, be molten with a soft fire, to which mix so much of
Roche Alome melted the like at the fire. After grind both together, putting
the whole into a discentorie standing under the earth set into an apt pit
made for the only purpose, on which ceales burning laid, and the same which
shall the^ be gathered, keep to your use, this out of Diod Euchyont.

An oil of Brimstone, is thus comp^wned, take of Brimstone, calcyned two
pounds, which infuse in vinegar, that the vyneger may flote four or six
fingers above, the same after bury in horse dung for four weeks, at the end,
distill it with a strong fire, for the spyrit of the Brimstone does then ascend
with the vinegar, which bury again in horse dung for two or three days, after
let the vyneger be euaporated in a large vessel having a wide mouth, and the
spirit and oil of the Brimstone will then abide in the bottem. The same oil
bury again in horse dung for eight days, which after distill by a Limbecke*
and in the end let it be buried for a month, for on such wise shall the oil
of Brimstone be purifyed. And it is of great virtue, yet but three drops
given at a time. This dung also of the horse, must always be renewed.

An oil of Naphtae, that is, of Brimstone vncombystible or never burned, which
is of the spirits vnseperated, and clarifyed, is prepared and made after this
manner, take of the Naphtae, that is, of any cytrine Brimstone, one part, of
salt Armoniacke five parts, these two beat, and mix together. After add to
them of the common oil a little, which then temper together after the form of
paste, or of a thick sauce. These then put into a Cucurbite, and a humor
after will distill with a soft fire, of great virtue unto many matters. But to
the first distillation ended, add of common salt five parts, of vnsleaked
lyme five parts, then a paste made of these distill again, and thus do for
four times, and at every time prove with a candell or otherwise, until it
burns not. For with such an oil of Naphtae, is Mercury sublimed, and
Arsenicke sublimed purifyed, and made clear, auailing vehemently unto the
white work.

An oil of Brimstone without distillatio^, against the pain of the gout,
prepared and made after this manner, borrowed out of a written book. Take of
sulphur viue, two pou^ds, of the yolks of eggs.xxv. in number, these beaten
and labored together, put into an iron possenet, boiling these with a soft
fire, and when the substance begins to burn, lean the iron pan on the one
side, and the same which is lyquid, will then yssew forth, and you shall so
purchase, that you desire.

An Oil of Sulphur or Brimstone, without distillation, does Brassanolus thus
prepare, take of Cytrine Brimstone, and of Turpe^tine, of each three ounces, of
good wine three ounces, of oil of Roses one pynt, boil these together with a
soft fire unto the consumption of the wine, what that after remains, is the
oil of Brimstone.

Otherwise and that sooner, is on this wise prepared, take a strong lie, or the
lycour made of unquenched lime stieped in it, that will well bear an egg
above. In this strong lie, let the Brymstone boil so long, until a fatness
shall appear on the upper face of the lie, and that the Feces shall fall to
the bottom, then as it were by a skymming of, is this fatness gathered.

Or let the Brymstone brought to fine powder, and powered into hot water, boil
so long, until the earthly part be settled, and that the Oily swymmeth above
on the face of the water, which practice was reported to me to be done, whiles
I was in Venice.

Or take of the oil of Line seed two parts, into which put one part of
Sulphur viue, these after the diligent mixing together, bury in dung for two
days, in a vessel close stopped, and it will be clear and fair.

Of the oil of Vitrioll, and of the making of the Oil of Vitrioll, out of
Valerius Cordus in a manner. The xxix. Chapter.
THe Oil of Vitrioll, which of some is named the Oil of life, or Artificial
Melancholy, and that many affirm to make of it a kind of Au^^m potabile or
potable Gold, in that the mine of Vystrioll, is a kind of the mine of Gold,
desired both of the Physicians and Chymistes. And it is also at this day much
exercysed and used of many Physicians in sundry purposes, for which cause, as a
most rare and singular secret, kept with them covered and unknown. And this
is none other, than an Alome quality and substance, drawn out of the
Vytrioll by Art, and a little myxed with Brymstone. For the same Vytrioll of
what manner it is made, does appear to consiste of a triple myxture, as of
much Alome, some ruste, and a little Brymstone. For the Alome water in
Mettalles, distylling by the Copper veins and Marchasite, attayneth a rus^ie
or cankred qualitye, and a Brimstonye, which rests myxed to the Marchasite,
that by little and little gathers, or by industry is boiled unto a
thickness. But in the distylling, the Alommie and Sulphurie vapor only do
ascend, and the rustie quality (by that means) left behind in the bottom
of the Retorte, through which is caused, that this oil has of Alome, and not
the taste of Ruste in it. And there are two diversities of this oil, as a
sharp and sweet. The eager or sharp Oil consists of a double myxture,
that is, of much Alome, and a little Brymstone. But the sweet, does simply
consiste of Brymstone. In that it is none other, then a lyquid Brimstone,
drawn out of the eager Oil. For which cause not the Alome in taste at all,
but the Brymstone is perceived. And both is to be prepared and made with great
care and diligence, in formyng an apt Furnace, and applying of a Retorte, and
receauer agreeable, for the aptness of the Instruments (as certayn^ Chymistes
affirm) procures a maistrie. These hitherto Cordus. But in this place, what
the ancient Philosophers understood by the name of the oil of Vitrioll,
whose discriptions we mind here to utter, whether the same any otherwise, then
that in the manner of preparing, may at the least differ, and not in the matter
out of which, those of any skyll and practyse in this Art, nothing doubt.
Seeing this, besides the other properties of it, in a manner innumerable, may
also conteyne in it the virtue of corrodyng (which matter also that it may be
made apparent of the same, in that this can not be wrought and keepte* but in
the best V^nice glass, that the cankred lyppe^ an^oynted of the same oil
may be consumed) of this, the use of it at anytime, ca^n^t be dangerous. For
that cause I suppose (says he) that this oil of the auncientes was prepared
in another manner, and was much subtiller * without corroding, and distilled in
Balneo Mariae. But for so much as this manner in unknown, therefore the later
practisioners from time to time invented, diverse and sundry preparations. Nor
am I ignorant (says he) how near unto the perfection of these, the
preparations agree, as that the pure and hurtful, may be separated from the
vnpure and vnhurtful, the subtle and penetrable, from the gross and
immouable. For in what manner soever any matter, may be made subtiller, clearer
and more penetrating, of these, does it declare the greater virtues in action.
In that the Feces of the simple elements, hinder the actions. And for that
cause do the ancient Philosophers, make mention of the reduction unto the
first matter, unto which when it shall come, the matter attaineth an extreme
subtilnesse, and the greatest also it yields in the practiue work. So that
you need not to deubt, but such an oil of Vitrioll, which shall attain the
extreme subtilnesse in preparation, may in his actions to come, be not only
most perfect, but also nothing at all hurtful, by which reason, if the
practysioners in the preparations, shall be either negligenter or slacker,
through this may it be caused the more venomous, to the taking within the body.
For how much the lesser the practysioner may err or does err in the
preparation, and distillation of the same, or how the oil may be made
perfitter, these three hereafter are diligently to be considered before all
others. First, what manner of Vitrioll must or ought to be chosen, then how the
same may be boiled, and what manner of calcination used. For it seems, that
the same rule or order, which was before vttred and taught in the preparation of
Antimonie, may like be applied in the oil of vitrioll. And the Antimonie (as
they say) except it be diligently chosen, and very well calcyned after art,
they in no wise grant, that the same rightly and without danger may be
ministered, for which cause they will it carefully to be prepared, that the
venomous quality may so be avoided.

THe true choosing of Vitrioll out of Valerius Cordus. The.xxx* Chapter.
Seeing there be many kinds of Vitrioll, for this reason, must it fully and
perfitely be uttered, what manner and kind of Vitriol, best answers and
agrees to this work. And although out of every manner and kind of Vitrioll, an
oil by distillation may be drawn, yet a more yield of oil, and the same
worthier or more excellent then the others, is distilled out of the blew or
green Vitriol, in that this contains much of the fugitive Brimstone, through
which it is much helped, that the oil may the easier and lightlyer ascend. It
is also to be noted, that the growe^ Vitrioll, and especially the Hungarian, to
be better and rather chosen, then the made or counterfaited. The same besides
is rather to be chose^, which cleaves in great clusters, and is coniealed in
greater lumpes. For that the small broken Vitrioll, and in a manner to powder,
must be rejected as unprofitable in this case, even as that also, which
gathered through the injury of the sun, or air, a witness, and dustie
hoorinesse. But the learned Fallopio, and singular practisioner Leonard
Fiorauant, do rather commend and prefer the Roman, then the German
Vitriol, to this use, seeing the same contains somewhat of the iron in it.

The manner of seething of the Vitrioll out of Cordus. The xxxi. Chapter.
FOr as much as the Vitrioll contains much of the waterie and excrementall
moisture in it, which weak^^eth or hinders the oil, and can not without a
long time, and great pains, be separated by distillation from the Oil, the
same compendiousser way must (of this) be invented by which in a short space
of time, that moisture may be consumed, least the long tarryaunce may cause
a weariness to the practisioner* Therefore take of the aforesaid Vitryoll,
twelve pounds, which powered into a great new pot, and well nealed, set into
the Furnace deep, upon burning coals, where, when the same shall begin to
melte and sees, stir with a spattle, that the whole may be myxed with the
molten, and until that be like molten, which suffer so long to seethe, until
no bubble or small bladder at all appears, and that the whole be thickened,
after the pot with the Vitryoll taken forth of the Furnace, suffer to cool,
neither in a moist, nor wyndie place, but in a dry and warm The Vytrioll
being through cold, take out of the pot, and consider whether the upper face
of it be throughout reddyshe. For the redness of it* is a sure note of the
perfect seething, that it may the easier he calcyned.

The manner of calcining of the Vitrioll, out of the same Aucthour. The xxxij.
Chapter.
THe Vitryoll taken out of the pot, break into small parts, and in a mortar
most fynely bring to powder, after power a third, or fourth part of it, into a
new and strong nealed pot, which set again into a deep Furnace, as above
uttered, and burn a whiles, until it be come redder, after take the pot
from the fire, and sturring it, see whether the Vitrioll be sufficiently
calcyned. For if in the pot appears after the manner of quicksyluer, or
molten lead, and that it casts or sends forth leapyng bubbles, you may
then conceive that the Vitrioll is sufficiently burned. Then power it into the
great and new pot before heated, and it will run forth as it were lyquid, or
unto the manner of quicksyluer. And what that remains of the Vitrioll, burn
in like manner orderly, that it may wholly be calcyned, when it shall thus be
burned and cold, let it be mixed again very well in a mortar, in such manner
laboring and sturring of it, that you raise not up the powder or dust, which
might offend the mouth, and nosethrelles. After you have performed all these,
and pouring the Vitrioll into a Balance, consider and know justly the weight.
For if it be six pounds, which is the half of the same* that you first began
to sees, yet remaining, then have you well handled, and rightly done all
things, that ought to be performed.

Of the making* and form of the Furnace. The xxxiij. Chapter.
FIrst an apt Furnace, must be framed and made, of Tyles laid flat, for how
thicker the walls be made, so much the stronger is the fire caused within, and
the heat longer kept. The walls also of this Furnace, ought to stand four
square, and of a like thickness round about, and the hollow sp^ce within,
must be of two spanne lengthes, lacking the third part of a spanne, which
done, it must then be builte up within, and in the top, after this manner,
that the first and lowest part or hollownesse, be builte half a foot high,
with strong iron bars thycke laid, which the wayght of the burning coals
can not bend. The second space or hollownesse made, above the iron grate (for
a resting) ought to be two foot high, and through the foresyde a square hole
artly made, just by the grate, to put the coals in with a little shouell.
After by the myddle space, regardyng the Furnace in the self same myddle, let
a four square iron bar be laid ouerthwarte, in bygnesse or thycknesse of a
thombe, which may well bear the Retorte laid upon. Then on the left side of
the Furnace, must a hole be left open, through which the neck of the Retorte
may be drawn.

The distillation of the Vitrioll. The.xxxiiij. Chapter.
AFter you have thus built and prepared the Furnace, choose then a big
Retort, and that apt to the purpose, being of the Venice glass made, if it be
possible to be gotten, which diligently and strongly lute about, into the same
pour all the Vitrioll (as by example the six pounds before prepared and
calcyned) yet that a fourth part of the^ Retort remain empty, whereby the
spirits may the easyer ascend from the Vitrioll, after upon the iron bar
laid ouerthwarte, Lute spredde, and a sharde of a pot or tyle laid just
upon the myddle of the bar, being like luted, on which set the Retorte thus
fastened, that the belly of it may be placed, just lying in the myddle of the
Furnace. And let the beak or neck of the Retorte retche without, and stoop
down ward, and the hoole also through which the neck passes, diligently
stop with Lute. After take five Tyles, with which make a ^yuer on the
Furnace, that the Retort may so lie hyd under that cover. This cover then
spredde over with lute every where, saving four holes left open, and that in
each corner one, for the fume or smoke to pass, being so large, that a thombe
may well pass in and out, in each hole. After make four couers sufficient
broad (for the holes) of strong Lute, with which stop or cover the holes,
as need requires. These being done, thrust the mouth within the neck of a
great receauer set under, being like of Venice glass, which how greater the
same shall be, so much the freelyer it will receive the spyrites entered, but if
the receauer be small, then is it dangerous, least the plenty of spyrites
stretched abroad, may break the glass. Also power into the receauer of very
clear water sixteen ounces, in that the water soon receives the spirits
unto it, and prohibiteth or defends that the receauer be not broken, and let
these be diligently luted together in ye joint taking careful heed besides,
that nothing fall after into the receauer, seeing the oil staineth it into a
red color. When you have performed all these, let the lute dry for a night,
and if any chops or cliftes do appear, let those be pargeted over with lute,
and the same morning after make a gentle fire in the beginning, of pure and
great coals, setting open one of the holes above, by which the fume may pass,
and let the fire within a whiles, be increased by little and little unto evening,
at which time the second hole must be opened. And mark then diligently,
whether any spirits appear, which yssew forth of the Retort, after ye form
of a white smoke, breathed into ye receiver. In ye night following be marvelous
careful, that the fire slack or abate not, but rather sharper, yet but a
little more increased, so that the fire after increased keep in that force: and
in the next day open the third hole, increasing still the fire, until the
neck of the Retort glowe like a burning coal, in the second night following
increase the fire, and after mydde night open the fourth hoole, when the fire
shall be grown and come unto the greatest heat, you shall then see the
spyrites yssew forth, even like to clouds heaped together, which when they be
at the point to cease, open all the passages and ventes of the Furnace, and
without ceasing power in coals with a small shouell, until the receauer also
appear glowing hot, in the mean time, and presently be very careful, that
no cold nor moist matter, fall by negligence, or by hap on the receiver. These
be^^de ^ ought to be wrought, in a close rome where neither went, nor wind
may enter. And the fire must so long be maintained, ^^tyll no spirits at all
be left in the Vitrioll, which by ^ight may easily be discerned, when no more
spyrites yssew forth, let the fire die and go out by it self, and suffer the
whole work to rest and cool, for a whole night and a day. After draw away
the receyuer with the whole lycour in it, and set aside close stopped, until
you ^^all separate the oil from the water, behold then the Retort broken, and
see whether the dead head be black, for this is a note of the work
performed.

A separation of the water infused. The xxxv. Chapter.
FOr as much as in the receyuer, is water contained, together with the oil of
Vitryoll: the same must be separated, that the lycour of the Vitrioll may be
set up, and reserved pure. And this is separated by distillation in Balneo
Mariae, or in fine syfted Ashes, but saffer is the doing, in Balneo Mariae. For
which cause power all the lycour which is in the receauer, into a Cucurbite of
Venice glass, setting on the head made of the like glass, which diligently
lute in the joint round about. After make a soft fire by little and little under
Balneo, and suffer the water to yssew, until the eyghteen ounces be come forth,
that you powered in. If so be the Vitrioll shall not be well calcyned then a more
quantity of water will yssew. For which cause see that these eighteen ounces,
be large or down wayght: when you have done this, suffer the Balne^^ to cool
and the water distilled forth thr^w away, but that which in Balneo shall
remain in the bottom of the Cucurbite, is the pure oil of Vitrioll, yet has
it for the more part a red color, for which cause must it be rectified, after
the form and manner following.

A rectifying of the oil of Vitrioll. The *xxxvj. Chapter.
TAke a Retort of Venice glass* which diligently fence with lute after power
into it, ye oil which is contained in the Cucurbite. That Retort set into a
lesser furnace, and into a deep pan, filled with pure and washed Sand, which
like distill in the Sand, as you did in Balneo, in sharpning and increasing the
fire by little and little, that the drops may leasurely fall. Thrust the mouth
of the Retort into the neck of the receauer made of the same glass, and the
joint diligently close with the best lute, ^^ no matter breath forth, when the
whole shall be distilled forth of the Retort, suffer it to cool and after the
taking away, power it again into a pure Venice glass which has a narrow
mouth, and set the same ^h^rely v^ ^l^se stoppe^ as a present remedy in many
diseases* that is* the shar^e oil of v^trioll, whose virtues and property
shall he^e under be vtt^^ed.

The virtues of the oil of Vitrioll. The *xxxvij. Chapter.
THe pure and not mixed, ought not, nor may be ministered or taken within the
body, for through the mighty sharpness thereof, after the m^^er of ^^e* this
(...) all places within the body, w^^re ye same touche^^* It ^oth also (...)
all things, except (...) the fa^tie substances* as the wax ^ pitch* (...) the
color of (...) oils this cha^ngeth, except the color of the oil of Mace* to
which ^^ it be (...) procures a sanguine color. If the Oil als^ (...)
conti^^^d within two vessels* and that the one has a cold (...) in it, and
(...) to the same* (...) after ^oyle so fe^^^ntly (...) scarcely ^e (...) hold
the glass in yo^^ hand. The oil shed down, boy^^ ^^^he ground, even as a
kind of Melancholy, whereof this is ^a^^ed the artificial Melancholie^* For
like as the Mola^^holy* even so does this oil comfort the stomach, and both
moves and pro^^^eth an app^tyte to meat, heateth ^ colde^ s^^acke* ^onsumeth
all manner (...), ^utteth a sunder the gross and cla^^^y humors, ^elpeth the
(...) and perrillous ^yxe Dysente^^* extinguisheth or qualifyeth the thyr^^,
and burning heat of the inner members in Agues, it stays belching speedily,
and puts away the desire to vomit, and the abhorring of meat, but this
must be orderly myxed with some other apt matters. For the better and readyer
conceauing of this artely myxture, learn an example or two here under uttered.

Take of the oil of Mace, and of clear Turpentine, of each twelve drops,
of the water of Annyse seeds, and of Fennel, of each two ounces, of the
syrup of Lycorise one ounce, of the oil of Vitrioll three of four drops,
these after the diligent myxing together, taste, if the whole has a sharpness
with it, which ast^nieth not the teethe then is it well, but if the potion be
not sour or sharp, instill one or two drops more, proouing the same by
taste how it is, after drink the same safely, against the stone. Or thus.

Of the sour oil of Vitrioll, how the same may be made sweet to taste. The
xxxviij. Chapter.
AT the beginning of this Chapter of the oil of Vytrioll, we sufficiently
uttered, the oil of Vitry^ll to be sour, and to consiste of a double myxture,
as of much Alome, and a little Brimstone. For which cause, when you will have
out the eager or sour, draw a sweet oil, the same is none otherwise wrought
and caused, then that the brimstone be separated from the Alome, E y which
appears, that the sweet oil of Vitryoll, is none other, than the oil of
Brimstone, or the Brymstone it self reduced into a lyquide substance, and
this properly may be named a^ oil. For it is both fattie and unctuous, even
as the Brimstone it self, which into an oil, and not into water dissolueth or
melts. The manner now of separation, after inseweth.

An oil of Vitryoll* prepared after this manner, according to the learned
F^llopio, in his Italia ^ooke of the ^ecrete remedies. Take of Romayne
vitryoll, in that the Germayne is not to be used, nor ^ood* for this contains
copper in it, and the Romayne has iron: and this is the cause, why the one is
good, and the other evil; so that when any will mynister of the oil to the
sick, regard must he had: seeing the copper is an enemy to the stomach, and
the iron a friend, and much healthful. Of this Romayne vitryoll take a
quantity, which put or set in a Furnace of reuerbaration, letting it there so
long remain, until it be calcined unto a redness or become r^dd^* After it
shall thus ^e ^aloyned to a redness or be read, put the whole into a body of
Venice glass, strongly fensed with the lute of wisdom, and the glass body
ought to be made, after the form of a lute, with a part of the belly ^la^, and
set into a Furnace of reuerberation, after such manner, that a part of the neck
hangs without the Furnace and tends downward somewhat, to which annexe the
Receauer, dilygently stopped or closed in the joint with lute: then contynew a
fire for four whole days, and so many nyghtes, until all the substa^^ce be
yssewed forth, or that no more remains which may be distylled by force of the
fire. Which ended, the oil will appear very black, in a manner as Incke, this
diligently keep in a strong glass close stopped, that no air breath forth.
This manner of way is easy to be done, and the best. That synguler Fallopio,
applied and used of it after this manner, he first took one pound of the

and hot Ague, is by and by after refreshed and cooled* And for the spytting of
blood, the flux of the body, the breaking of veins in the breast, an^ a

An oil of vitryoll, learned of that singular Georgius Haymberserus: take of
common vitryoll so much as you will, out of which distyll a water by a
Lymbecke, as you know: after take the Feces, or earth of the vitryoll out of
the glass, and calcyne the same so much as is possible: then power the water,
which you distylled from it before, upon the earth of the vitryoll calcyned,
which after set into a dry wine Seller, and you shall attain the true oil of
vitryoll. But the earth of the vitriol calcined, ought a fore to be well brought
to powder, and the water then powered upon it. With this oil, and vermylon,
make as you know, unto the coniealing of Mercury. This first borrowed out of
an old Alchymy book written.

Another manner: that you may make the oil of vitryoll, take of Romayne
vitryoll finely brought to powder, twentye pounds, which dissolve by little and
little on coals in a pot or pan not glased, and after the vitryoll shall be
molten, suffer it after so long to boil, until it be well dried. Which done,
let it be diligently brought to powder, and powered into an other vessel not
glased, but well and close covered, that no fylth nor dust fall into it. After
this a clear and vehement fire of coals made, above and beneath it, that the
vitryoll may become so red as Vermylon: of this vitryoll brought and made so
read, take twelve pounds, which power into a Retorte very well luted: with
his Receauer, like luted in the joint: and the first day begin with a soft
fire, but the second day with a stronger fire of coals only, and the third
day, with a most strong fire made of wood, shall you distyl the oil of
vitryol. It is here to be noted, that you must power in a little Aqua vitae into
the Receauer, that the spyrites of the vitryoll may be retained in it. And
after the distyllacion ended, the same ought to be euaporated forth, the
Receauer being set on coals, for on such wise is the styncking vapor
elevated, and when no more vapor shall appear, or grievously stincketh, then
shall the oil be left and remain pure. The propertyes of this oil, be in a
manner innumerable. With the water of Tamaricis, it avails against the
passions of the Spleen. With the water of Radishe, or powder of the Tables of
marble stone, it avails against the st^ne, and all passions of the kydneys,
and the stopping of them. With the waters of the Marygold and Veruayne, it
avails against the pestilence. With the waters of Sage and Buglosse, against
the byt of Serpents. With Aqua vitae, it is a singular remedy, for the
superfluous course of women's terms. In the same manner given, it cures the
Tertian Ague. With the waters of cinquefoyle and Horehound, it helps the
Quartayne. With the Fern water given, it kylleth the worms within the body.
With good Malmesie, or with Pympernell water, unto the quantity of eight
drops druncke with a fasting stomach, does cheer the heart, mundi^yeth the
blood, represseth the Lepry, and both preserves and increases natural heat.
Taken with Fumyterre water, and the water of Mirobalanoru^ Citrinorum, cures
ye Leprie. With the Maioram water, does ease the headache, and kylleth the Lyce
of the head. With the waters of Buglosse and Baulme, it takes away the pain
of the head, the mygrime, gyddinesse, and dymnesse of sight. Taken after a
purgation with the water of the white Lyllyes* purges the Letharge or sleeping
downryght. With the water of Rue, it like cures the Letharge. With the water
of Fennel, or smallache, or Acorus, it helps memory, and profits unto the
dyminishing or loss of understanding. With the water of Lettyce, or the white
Poppie, it provoke sleep. With the water of Borrage or Buglosse, it
profits the Melancholicke persons. With the water of Nenuphar or the water
Lyllies, and with the water of the Myrtylles, delyuereth frenfynesse, and a
hot impostume, and profits in the pellycle of the brain. With Aqua vitae,
after a purgation, takes away the Apoplexy. With the water of Pyonie,
delyuereth ye falling sickness. With the water of wild myntes, it preuayleth
against the palsy. With Sage water, helps the crampe. With the waters of
Basil and Maioram, delivers the trembling of the heart. With the water of
Trifoyle, takes away the pain of the body. With Fennel water, and water of
the wythie of the mountain, takes away all manner of weakness of sight. With
the water of Sigillum salomonis, it avails against defenesse, and rynging of
the ears. With the water of Ireos, helps the rewme of the head. With the
water of the Acorne cups, and cups of the Roses, it stays the bleeding of
the Nose. With the water of Sage and Hysope, avails against the Palsy. With
the waters of Maiden heir, and Hysop, it helps the cough. With the water of
Playntayne, preuayleth against the plewresie, and such which spytte blood,
speedily helps. With the waters of Doder, and Maiden heir, avails against
the plewresie. With the water of Roses, or wine of Pomegranates, avails
against sounding. With the water of the rinds of the Cytrone, recouereth the
weakness of appetyte. With mynt water, avails against the weakness, and
coldness of stomach. With the water of Myrtylles, quallyfieth against the
pain of a hot stomach. With the water of Purcelane, avails and
extynguisheth thyrst. With the water of Byttonie, takes away belching, and
pain of the stomach: and if the pain be of a hot cause, it ought then to be
given with Rosewater, or with the powder of Diarrhodon abbatis. With the water
of Quinces, it del^uereth vomyting, and if the same be with blood, let it then
be given with Plantaine water, or with the water of s^epperds purse, and powder
of Diarrhodon abbatis. And if it be of a vain broken in the breast, then
apply with the Lyme of Egg shelles, and be shall be whole, in giving it every
day fasting, for one whole month. With the water of Penny royal, and powder
of Diarrhodon abbatis, after a purgation, avails against the inflammation of
the stomach. With the water of Scabious, takes away the gryping of the body,
which comes of the cause of venom, and if the same be of another cause, then
let it be given with the water of Rue, and syrup of Nenuphar. With the water
of Rue, it helps the chellicke passion. With the water of Molyne or yarrow,
preuayleth against the Pyles, and other passions beneath. With worme^ wood
water, it avails against the hytte of venymous heastes. With Endyue or
Egrymonie water, it delyuereth all the impostumes of the Liver, and helps the
dropsy. With the water of Cyn^quefoyle, it heals the Iaundise. With the
water of Mugwoort, it avails against the passion of the Matrice, and the
hard fetching of breath. With the water of Garlyke, it delyuereth the
toothacke. With the water of the wild myntes, or Aqua vitae, it takes away
the Sciaticke passion. With the water of the Colewortes, it delyuereth cold
gowtes. With the waterr of the Pellytorie or Plantayne, it cures hot Gowtes.
With the water of Egrymonie, helps the palsy. With the water of Eupatorium,
takes away the passions of the mylt. With the water of Rosemarie, comfort
the stomach. With the water of Catmynt, stays the rewme, falling to the
breast. And to conclude, it avails in all passions, if it be given with the
water agreeable to the passion: and is also named potable Gold, and is
precious in every medycine, even as Gold gives and works in all the
Myneralles. With the water of Bytonie it avails against the Ilyacke, and
chollyeke passion. With the water of Cresses and yarrowe, provoke vryne. This
borrowed out of the Italian practices, of Iero. Ruscell.

Another manner of preparing the oil of Vitryol, not much differing from the
former, and good, that he purchased of a certain friend, which affyrmed, that
he knew a Chyrurgian, which with this only got his living: translated out of a
written Copy, in the Germayne tongue. There be some (says he) which by force
of the fire draw an oil of vitryol, out of ten or twelve pounds of the Roman
or Vngarian vitryoll, in a body well fensed with lute, or earthen pot vnglased,
which they say to one side stouping, in that Furnace: with the receauer annexed
to it, and dyligently luted in the joint. Others when they have distylled it by
ascension, do separate the flewme from the oil, and power again the same
flewme on ye dead head, and distyll it in the like manner above uttered, and the
same they so often repeat, until the vitryol shall be wholly brought and made
unprofitable, and that no oil at all remains or is contained in it. And
although the oiles drawn by these means, be profitable unto many and sundry
diseases: yet I (says he) yt the oil may be applied within the body, or used
in any other manner, do, in ye preparation of it, proceed after this manner. I
take also two new pottes vnglased, into one of yt which I power the vitryol,
and set to the fire, that the vitrioll may melte. And the water may also be
powered to ye same; although it be not so requisite and necessary, and to be
sturred together with a wooden spatle, and on such wise to be through dried by
the fire. In this first calcynation* is the vitryoll purged from his
venemousnesse. Then I bring the vitryoll again into powder, and sy^^e it
through a fine sieue or salt, that it may so be labored into very fine powder,
and if any piece shall yet remain vnbroke^, I beat it again, etc. After do I
heat water, and the same very hot, do I power on the powder contained or
being in a vessel sufficient large and deep, and stir sometimes about with
the wooden sp^ttle, and let it so rest, that it may settle all the night
following. In the morning after the settling, I take away, so nygh as I can, all
the clearer and purer water resting above, but the troubled I distyll by
fylter. On those Feces or grounds remaining after the distyllacion, I power
the scalding water again, and both stir, and separate, as above uttered: and
I the same so often repeat, until the vitryoll has no bytternesse contained
or remaining in it, or is agreeable to the water. This clear Lie or water of
the vitryoll, let it be boiled so long by the fire, until in the vessel the
vitryoll be hard gathered together as a stone, and the water consumed.

Of the properties of the oil of Vitrioll, does one of D. Gesnerus friends
thus write: The principal virtue of this oil, is ( Montane also affirming the
same) that it causes men not to appear aged a long time, and most foul and
corrupt teeth, this causes fair and strong, and the gummes also it procures
strong: if the teeth daily are lightly rubbed with one or two drops of it: by
which manner doing, a famous curtisan in Venice, preserved her teeth from all
filth and corruption, and maintained them steddie and fast many years: but
Montane would not the oil to be used unto the remoouing of fittes, and curing
of sicknesses, without the addition of other simples or myxtures to it: for he
had always a regard unto those matters which were temperater, and surer in
the giving: these hitherto he: Ad morbum scorbunticum, a certain person not
without great reward used it prosperously.

Arnoldus of the use of the oil of Vitrioll: Take of the best Triacle, to
which add a few drops of the oil of Vitrioll, and let stand myxed
together until you will use it: If any lies grievously sick, and not unto
death, give a French crown weight of this myxture, but if the man be not over
weak, then a little more: and drinck the whole meanly hot, with a little wine
fasting in the morning four hours before meat: and if a little shall happen
to remain in the bottom, the same rynsed with wine, drink in like manner:
After this, the sick well covered in be^, and wrapped about the head, in such
manner, that nothing of the whole body may appear, saving the mouth free and
uncovered: which done, let the pacient lie sweating, so much as is possible for
the space of four hours, and sleep in no wise that time: The sheets then
changed, let the pacient yet abide in bed for other three hours, not
sweating, before he eats any thing, then let him eat somewhat, and drink
good old wine after his meat.

After this medicine given, the Physician may use other medicines, as the
purging and comforting: The nature of this medicine is to diminishe all
sickenesses, and to prepare the way unto health, and the same with expedition,
and in a short time: do in that manner, that the pacient may obey and keep a
good diet: The cure consists, that the pacient sweat rightly and plentifully
for the foresaid four hours: for this drinck rightly ministered, never
fails nor beguyleth the Physician: If the pacient after the taking, be not
cured, yet does he cast up (by vomiting) much evil matter offending.

In the Cholicke, Benedictus Victorius, thus used the oil of Vitrioll: he
took of Malmesie two drammes, of the oil of Vitriol half a dram: This is a
marvelous experiment, if of the same, or the said quantity be ministered at
the instant time of the grief, without an Ague: It also profits if the
payned or grieved place be anointed with the oil of Vitrioll, an apt plaster
or fomentation used before: An expert medicine of Alexis Pedemontanus, curing
the swelling of the throat or Squince: Take of the oil of the Roman Vitrioll,
three drops, which well myxed in wine, gargill in the throat sundry times:
Two drops of the oil mixed with Saxifrage water, and druncke, provoke vryne:
Against the evil ulcers of the legs, does the water of Alum, myxed with a
little of the oil of Vitrioll avail.

Against Agues, take the Vitrioll calcined and brought to powder, on which
pour Aqua vitae, that it may exceed two fingers above, the same let so rest
for three or four days, after pour in other Aqua vitae, and do the like,
then draw forth the Aqua vitae, of which give two or three drops in a
sufficient or congruent quantity of water: A certain person reported, that a
lynnen cloth wet in the oil of Vitrioll, and applied for six or seven days
on the forheade, does help the grievous pain of the head: A potion made of
the oil of Vitrioll, with two drammes of Malmesie, does deliver the pain of
the belly, and stomach: So much of the oil of Vitrioll dropped into fair
water, as will make the water sower, does purge. A certain practisioner cured
with the same, the Collicke despayred or out of hope: and he gave it in the
fleumaticke Asthma, or straitness of breath, and in the peril of suffocation,
for it has profited with the vomiting: This gave sometimes one dram with
good success to all fleumaticke affectes, especially of the stomach: For the
taking away of wartes, this is a singular remedy: A certain learned man
supposed the oil to help corns in the feet, although the same not
experienced.

Our Oil of Vitrioll is thus made: Take of the better Vitrioll such a
quantity as you shall think needful, the same dissolve in hot water, after
let that water clear again, and dystill it by a filter, the same which is
dystilled, pour into a Copper vessel, or vessel not glased: after pour it
again into another vessel of glass, set between coals, that the glass may
be through read: after dissolve it again as before, the same dystill by a
filter, and fully dry, until it be through read: then let it be brought to
very fine powder, and of the Vitrioll in powder, pour one pound or two pounds
into a Cucurbite or glass body, and before you pour the same in, pour into
the glass hafe a cup full of good Aqua vitae, without any fleume, after
pour upon the powder of the Vitrioll, and set the mouth of one body against
another, diligently luted in an apt furnace: beginning first with a soft fire,
until white fumes shall appear, after increase the fire, making a strong
flame under it, and continuing the same unto the end of the work: After take
all that which shall be dystilled, and dystill the same in a Retort by sand:
which gathered again by dystillation, pour into the Retorte, and distill
again, and the same so often repeat, until no feces shall remain in the
Retort, then dystill it in Balneo strong boiling, and the Quintessence and
fleume shall after be separated, and a pure oil shall abide in the bottom of
the glass: that if you shall not find it sufficient pure, pour it again by
it self into a Retort, and distill it once again by sand, and you shall then
purchase the oil rectified, which diligently stop and keep, for it is
precious.

An ingenious preparation of the oil of Vitrioll, proved, and that perfect
and sure, uttered by a singular practisioner, after this manner, translated out
of the German tongue. Unto the dystillation of the oil, before any other
matter, you must first build a furnace four square, of the same largeness,
that in it may a great body luted, be easily placed or set, being of glass,
which will hold eight or ten measures, and having a bygge and large belly: In
the beginning build the Furnace a foot, or thereabout, high from ground,
after place a grate at that heygth, being about a foot and a half distant:
then by the middle of the furnace fix a long and strong iron bar, luted over
with the best lute, and that it retcheth from one side to the other of ye
furnace: between the grate and iron bar, place or join the slow harrie to
the furnace, unto one side, even as this figure here ensuing, does playner
demonstrate: and let the slow harrie be of such a bygnesse, that the head
may in a manner lie all without: which prepared and done, let the building o^
the furnace be raised or made a foot and a half above the iron bar, and
left so open, unto the time the glass in which the Vitrioll shall be
contained, be set in the furnace. And note, that the same side from the slow
harrie, ought from the grate unto the top to be open, until the glass be
set into the furnace: the furnace being prepared, take of Vitrioll thirty or
forty pounds, according to the greatness and capacity of the glass, and
the Vitrioll pour into an vnglased pot, which set on the fire, that it may be
exactly calcined, and that no moisture, remains in it, and that also it be
brought to a red color, or hardened as a stone: the earthen vessel then
broken, and the Vitrioll through cooled, let it be most finely brought to
powder in a mortar, and that powder pour into this great glass, of which is
above mentioned: This glass thus filled with the Vitrioll, in the same part of
the furnace which is open, let be laid along on the iron bar, the neck
lying without, and turned downewarde so much as is possible, but in such man^r,
that you shed not out the Vitrioll, and let the neck also retch without the
furnace, unto the length of half a foot, whereby the receyuer may after be
annexed to it, and the commodiouser fenced about the joint with lute: which
done, close the open part of the furnace, from the grate unto the very top,
and the glass diligently join together to the furnace with lute: when you
shall thus come unto the top, make in each of the four corners, a hole so
large as the compass of an egg, with an apt cover to each, which may be set
on, and taken away at pleasure: let vent holes also be framed, and those
lesser, yet no wyder than that the thumb may easily pass in and out: after
work the furnace up narrower and narrower, into pinnacle form, that in the
top a hole may be left so wide, a^ you may well occupy the hand in and out,
for which hole also srame a cover that may cover it close, and be taken of at
pleasure: after the furnace thus wholly framed and buylt, together with the
glass body joined to it, and thoroughly performed, you shall then annexe
another great receyuer of glass, that will well conteyne eight or ten measures
of licour, into the neck of this receyuer, let the other enter a good depth,
and both by a diligent care, with the best lute, artly close in the joint,
after the common manner and custom: The figure hereafter following, does
manifestly utter to the eye, this whole description of the furnace and vessels:
where to be noted that the slow harrie ought not so exactlye to touch the
grate: but to be sufficient, if it ca^ieth the coals to it.

1 Represents the door, by which the air entering in, does maintain the
fire.

2 Signifies the grate, on which the coals settle and lie.

3 Does express the slow harrie, carrying in the coals.



4 Does show the place, in which the iron bar is fixed, that bears up the
glass body.

5 Represents the neck of the glass body retching without, and turned
downward.

6 Does represent that great receyuer annexed t^^.

7 Does plainly teach the four vent holes of the furnace made in the Angles.

8 Does manifestlye show the large hole being in the top of the furnace.

When all these are prepared, let the furnace be heated with a fire of coals,
and the slow harrie filled with great coals: and with a cover let it be close
covered, and all the other vent holes, except the three small above mentioned.
The door also which is under the grate, and noted with the number one, must be
half shut, for the air sake, and to preserve the fire: In the beginning
make a mean^ fire, and after shall a clear oil dystill: when the clear
color of the oil shall begin to appear darker, and the oil after a manner
troubled, then shall the fire be fortified, and a red matter will ensue,
which must be forced forward, in fortifying the fire a little more, and the
same in such manner, as by a hole which consists in the top, that you may
pour in the coals, and fill the furnace up with them unto the vent holes,
which ought to be opened, and none of them left covered: and this dystillation
m^st be continued so long as any matter distilleth, which indureth unto.xxiiij.
hours, yea, sometimes to thirty hours: so that this must be followed without
any staying, until all be gathered, for in this manner shall you obtain the
most perfect oil of Vitrioll: and this manner, as a most certain practice,
sundry times proved by a certain notable practisioner: Where to be noted,
that the receyuer ought to be cooled, by another vessel filled with cold
water, and having a tappe, that the cold water may continually dystill upon the
receauer, or set this into a filtring vessel, that the cold water may like
dystill upon it, and cool so the receyuer, which otherwise by force of the
exceeding heat would soon burst. After the dystillation fullye ended, and
cooling both of the furnace and glass, let the oil be poured into a Retort,
and rectified in Balneo Mariae, from the fiery or read matter, of which each
must be kept several in glasses. Another practisioner supposes it to be more
skilfully handled, that after the red matter shall appear in the
dystillation, the receiver be changed, least the true oil by any means may
be affected with a certain strange quality. The use of this oil is against
all Agues: against the cholicke, and strangurie: against the stone, or sand of
the bladder: It does marvelously help the suffocation of the womb, the
Cough, the Apostume of the breast and lungs, the matter ascending, and as it
were, suffocating the lungs. It cures the dropsy of any cause, and prevails
against the Gout, the Palsy* etc. And they ought to give or take at a time,
two, three, or four drops in some dystilled water or wine, morning and evening.

Leonard Fiorauant; that singular practisioner, in his second book of secret
practices, published in the Italian tongue* does there utter the manner of
dystilling the oil of Vitriol* which from the common manner does differ nothing
at all, saving that the dystillation of the oil at the eight or tenth day was
performed: and from the beginning, as it seemed, wrought with flame of fire,
and the oil dystilled, was black.

A compounde oil of Vitrioll, of the said Leonard Fiorauant prepared and made
after this manner: Take of pure and white Sugar four pounds, of Rhaponticke one
pound, of Ruberbe one ounce, of Mercury flowers, one pound, these after the
well beating together, frame into a paste: on which pour four pyntes of the
best Aqua vitae, then pour all into a Retort, which diligently stop, and
bury in hot horse dung for six days, after the drawing forth, dystill the
whole in Balneo Mariae, until no more will issue forth. The feces then gotten
forth of the Retort* put into a lynnen bag, which wring strongly and
thoroughly in a press: After take of Buglosse water, of Fumiterrie, and of
Scabio^s, of each six ounces, and with these waters, wash very well the feces
pressed out, and wring them hard again in the press, which done, throw the
feces away. And these two waters together, which you gathered by pressing
forth, dystill so often over by ^ filter^, until it appears sufficient
clear* after mix it with the first water, and dystill all together in Balneo
Mariae. And when of those three you shall have performed one water, then to each
pound or pynte of the water, add half a scruple, or one whole dram (if need
be) of the finest oil of Vitrioll, which diligently keep in a glass, unto
use. Th^s excellent composition I prepared in the summer, and used it to many
with singular success: for it restores a weak or decayed stomach* it
helps the disease of the mylt, and mittigateth the pain of the head and
teeth, and many other matters, which for breuitte are ^urpassed: But this
composition is of so maruailous a working, that it may be put in the book of
the maruailous things of Physic. For thy^ keeps or maintayneth old men in
their proper strength: a matter greatly to be abashed and woondred at. And I
can this avouch, that I have seen many men and women, which by using it after
my appointment and counsel, are renu^d, and become lustyer of age to see too:
A matter in deed greatly to be maruailed at, and scarcely to be believed: and
this compositi^n also preserves them long in health which use to take of it.
The manner of taking this excellent lycour is on this wise: that is, in the
morning let half an ounce of it be taken fasting, and so cold as it is: and
let the person after refrain to eat for the space of four hours, and the
same day, use to eat the best meats of s^^^nance: and this used for a time
together, preserves the person, as above uttered.

A corrosiue oil of Vitrioll: take of Roman Vitrioll six pounds, of common
salt one pound and a half, let these be calcyned so long together, until
they wax read, which then take from the fire, and bring to powder together,
the whole divide into three parts: after g^t three glass bodies, fashioned to
a Lu^e, very well fenced with the lute of wisdom, and into each of these,
pour a third part of the said Vitrioll rubified, and set all the three
bodies into one furnace of reuerberation: and make a fire under by little and
little, until all the substance by force of the fire be drawn, which will be
so black a substance as yncke, and many times flows, or is long in the
issuing forth: and when the same is come forth, keep it in a glass sufficient
large and thick, that it burst not: with this lycour you may open all manner of
impostumes, and cleanse all kind of putrified ulcers, by wetting only on the
upper face with the said lycour, which does cause speedily a marvelous
working: and mortifieth cankers, and ulcers cankred, and does many other
matters besides: all which I have many times tried, and found evermore true and
perfect: This borrowed out of the Italian secrets of the singular Fallopius.

Another of the same man's, otherwise prepared and drawn, named a compounde
oil of Vitrioll, and that most strong, on this wise: Take of Roman Vitrioll
six pounds, of salt Armoniack, of Brimstone, of Vermilion, of Orpiment, and
of Roche Alum, of each six ounces, let all be calcined (as we have above
uttered) until all the whole be come unto a redness, and being thus rubified,
let all be brought into fine powder, and poured into a body (as above uttered)
and let fire be continued under it for six whole days, remembering before that
the joints be diligently luted: With this licour may you depopulate or cut of
any member, if you wette a large knyfe made of the wood of the Olive tree in
it, and mark the place about with tha said wood where you will cut it of:
this then is of such a force and efficacy, that it opens the flesh, even as
the same were done or cut with a rasour, and works the proper effect, without
the shedding of any drop of blood: And this causticke is one of the worthyest
secrets of all Chirurgerie, and proved very often of the singular Fallopius,
and sundry other Chirurgions, which have wrought the self same effect, which
I have seen many times.

A natural and most subtle oil of Vitrioll, pleasant or sweet in taste,
which is accounted for a miracle: Take of the Hungarian vitrioll four pounds,
which brought into very fine powder, and dried in a body, pour after into
another body well fenced with lute, being well beaten together, and thrust
down: Then pour upon of sublymed wine rectified, unto the top of the four
pounds, which set to digest for forty days, after dystill according to Art:
and you shall then see the Oil of Vitrioll swim above the upper part of the
sublimed wine: But the common oil of Vitriol shall be mixed with his water,
and for that cause needs rectifying: this borrowed out a written book.

An oil of Vitrioll which mortifieth the Canker and Fistulaes, and old
corrosiue ulcers especially, is made after this manner: Take of Roman
Vitrioll, burnt in a pan unto a redness, one pound, which bring to fine
powder, to it after add, of oil Olyue half a pynte, these pour together
into a glass body, and sublime after the common manner: then let it be
distilled with one body set against another, or by a Limbecke, in adding to it
a little of Aqua vitae well rectified, that the Oil may ascend. etc.

Fumanellus of the oil of Vitrioll, against the Canker, thus writes: In
extreme diseases, the extreme remedies are best: and seeing the Canker is a
disease of the same kind, for that cause a man must apply extreme remedies to
it, as is the oil of Vitrioll which is made after this manner: Take of Vitrioll
a sufficient quantity, which after the through drying, and coming unto a
redness, and the same rubified, and brought to fine powder, pour into a
Limbecke, and dystill according to Art: of this let be given in the first day
fasting, one drop, with three ounces of Buglosse water, and in the second
day, two drops, with a greater quantity of the water, and in such manner adding
a drop of the water, unto five days end: These ended, let the extreme parts
or edges of ye Canker be anointed with the foresaid Oil, until the matter of
the canker be gotten out by the root: and this medicine has not been tried of
the Author, but obtained of an Impericke. A sirrupe digesting cankerous humors,
is made of the juice of Fumiterrie, of Borage, and of Scabious, of each three
ounces, of Endive, and of Succorie, of each two ounces, of Epithimi, of Senae,
and of the wine of Pomegranates, of each three ounces, of Sugar so much as
shall suffice, to form the sirrupe: and the solutiues belonging to the same,
are, the Electuarie of Hamecke, Pills de lapide Lazuli, pillu Iudae, Senee,
epithimum, and whaye wherein Senee is steeped.

Of the Oils out of other Mettalles. The.xxxix. Chapter.
AN oil of Copper learned of a French Empericke: Take of burnt Copper two
pounds, which finely brought to powder, and poured into a glass Cucurbite
very well luted, and imbybed with the strong vinegar, the whole dystill in
xxiij. hours space, and you shall obtain a most strong oil, of a red and
green color.

An oil of Saturn or Lead, is thus prepared and made, which is after an
easy manner: Take of Ceruse which is Lead calcined, and boil it with the
strongest vinegar, after let the same settle or rest a time, and the vinegar
shall become yelow of color: the same then pour into a body, and euaporate
the vinegar forth, and in the bottom will the oil remain: This oil of
Saturn is commended in old ulcers, especially those (which Theophrastus
names the ulcers of the face) of which kind are, the Canker, and Fistulaes
about the nose. I knew (says the Author) a woman who had her nose almost
eaten away with a wicked ulcer, and was thoroughly cured with this oil alone:
This oil molten, ought to be applied with a warmenesse, or by the furnace in
the Winter time, and striked over with a fether. A certain person sold half
an ounce of this for a crown of gold. The dose of it at a time, to be given
inward with any lycour, is three graynes: and used both in the cholicke, and in
fistulaes.

An oil of Iron, understood of a French Empericke: Take of the filings or
beatings of the Iron about the Anuill finely labored to powder, so much as you
will, the same imbibe with childs vryne, after calcine so often in the Furnace
of reuerberation, until it be brought impalpable, and of a sanguine color,
then pour it into a glass body well fenced with lute, and imbybe the
substance again, with the strongest dystilled vynegar, which dystill after the
manner of Aqua fortis, by the space of. xxiiij. hours, ever increasing the
fire, and you shall obtain a thick and very read oil. The experience of the
oil is, that the lamines of any metal rubified, if they be quenched in this
oil, forthwith receive the color of gold: so marvelous is the tincture, and
peercing, and does also congeale Mercury divinely, and does many other
affectes in the Art of Alchimie. Besides, in Physic, this works
marvelously, in that the same resolves and heals many infirmities, and
especially the flux of the body, if so be a small quantity be given by the
mouth with any sirrupe, or other like composition, which works a marvelous
help to the pacient that takes it: so the^ I affirm the sand oil to be as
a true* Quintessence to our bodies, seeing it is so miraculous in his working.

An oil out of Steel^, and the Ad^man^ stone, is drawn after the same manner,
as above taught of the Iron.

An oil of Litarge, is holden and accounted for a great secret, in that the
same is marvelous in the clearing of spots, and Morphewe, or other blemishes
of the face, it makes a small scarre, and puts away the redness of them,
borrowed out of a most ancient written book: Take of Litarge finely brought
to powder, so much as shall suffice, the same dissolve by decoction in the
strongest vinegar, many times together, after euaporate the vinegar on the
fire, and a black oil shall remain in the bottom: which then dissolve with
hot water, by the stirring about with a stick clean scraped, and after
dystill it by a woollen tongue, or by Fylter, and the oil shall abide in the
bottom, which separated from the water, is singular in the working.

An oil which is drawn out of Lyme, is marvelous: Take of vn^eaked lyme one
whole piece, which infuse in common oil until it be di^solued, and let the
Lyme be brought to powder, the whole after poured into a gla^se Limbecke, and
dystilled, an oil will then issue, which shall be named the calcine oil. etc.

An oil drawn out of Bole Armoniacke, is taught in a certain place of the
w^^ks of the singular learned Theophrastus Paracelsus.

Of the preparing and making of the oil of Amber, by the description of a
singular physician of Germany, which freely described the history also of the
whole Amber, as shall appear in the proper places. The.xl. Chapter.
THe oil of Amber is none other than a most subtle, fat, and ayreal substance
which consists in the Amber, drawn out by Art: and although it be not hard
to purchase such an oil, yet a special care and aptness of instruments is
required unto ye same art: for which cause must diligent heed be given that ye
precepts following be observed.

What manner of Amber must be chosen. The.xli. Chapter.
Although it be agreeable to Art, and right necessary to choose the purest
Amber, unto the dystilling and drawing forth of the oil, and that it be the
greater part of the Amber, for in taking the purer matter, a purer lycour also
issues forth, and the receyuer shall be filled with the lesser quantity of
the excrementall humor and refuse, and it besides shall not so easily be
resolved with fire, and at one instant fall together into the receyuer, if it
