shall be of the grosser parts, but shall dissolve and melt by little and
little, and slowly, that the subtle substance which consists or is in it,
may the beter be separated from the feces: yet in the slaking of it, may the
powder and pieces be taken and used, in that those also yield an Oil, if they
be rightly prepared and poured into the vessel. A man must besides observe and
know, that on the Amber poured into the Cucurbite, be very small flynt stones
laid, and on them again an other course of the Amber, and like an other bed
of the flynt stones, and thus orderly to the end.

Of the Furnace and Instruments necessary unto the dystillation of the Amber.
The.xlij. Chapter.
IT much avails to have apt and fit instruments: And first, as touching
the Furnace, let it be round, and two foot and a half high, but in breadth
over, about two spannes: And let it be buylt either of Tyles, or Iron plates
covered over with strong lute, and having two round holes in it, by which (as
shall after be demonstrated) the Pypes of the Instrument set in the second
place, may retch forth.

But let other two instruments of copper be prepared and made, and those
covered or glased within, with tynne, especially the nether part, and let it
have the figure of a Cucurbite above, in heygth of one spanne and a half,
compouned of one whole lamine or plate, and let the neck of it be thrust
within the nether instrument, and enter a sufficient way within the same.

Let also a round cover be prepared of Copper, and full of hole^ stricken,
that the Amber covered with it, may issue and dystill liquide forth: but the
nether instrument receiving the Amber (for that it is a Dystillation by
descention) let the same be framed round, having a neck which may receive,
and may contain in it the neck of the Cucurbyte, and will well receive three
or four measures of lycour, having two Pypes, of which let the one ascend and
look upward, and the other descend and retch downward, as these figures
herevnder, does playner express to the eye.

The Furnace.
The upper hole retching unto the other Pype.

The nether hole by which the nether Pype issues.



The upper instrument or Cucurbite, into which the Amber with the flint stones
is poured.

The upper Pype by which the hot water is poured in.

The nether Pype by which the oil together with the water issues.

The nether instrument here receiving the refuse and oil.



A. The cover boared full of little hoales with which the Cucurbite is covered.



A Cucurbite with the nether instrument conjoined, as if both presently were to
be set in the furnace.



The Furnace with all the necessaries unto the dystillation.


In this figure, are all the necessary instruments propouned, serving unto the
dystillation of this Oil: The buylding of the furnace appears at the right
side, in the middle of whose top, does the Cucurbite appear and show: The
same Furnace has on the right side, a pype retching upward (which properlye
is named ye upper pype) stopped with a wooden stopple: In the same on the left
side, is an apparent nether pype, reatching downewarde, to which is another
pype annexed passing through a cooling vessel: In the myddle of the figure,
does a cooling vessel appear, with his pype retching unto the left side, with
which immediately is the Receiver committed and fastened.

Of the Dystillation of the Amber. The.xliij. Chapter.
AFter you have prepared the Furnace, and all the Instruments necessary to it:
Take the nether instrument, which set into the Furnace, does draw forth the
pypes of it (that you saw made in the former figure) and the same very well
fence in the furnace with Tyles and Lute, and let there be a cover within made
sufficient strong, that cannot be seen without, and that the fire lying on it
cannot harm, and then pour so much water into it, until the water runs
forth of the Pype: After the Cucurbite filled by turn with the Amber and
flynt stones (laid by courses as before taught) and fenced with lute, let not
the Amber but rather the course of flynt stones touch and be next the cover,
and cover the Cucurbite, then nail or fasten stronglye the lydde round about
the edge or sides with Iron nails, that the cover through the force and
mighty power of the heat may not fall of: but rather be able well to bear
the weight of the substance: Which done, set the Cucurbite on the nether
instrument, and the place where they be joined together, fence diligently about
with lute, that no vapor at all may issue forth: and stop the Pype ascending
with a wooden stoppell, that you may draw the same forth, if the hot water
must be taken forth, which shall then be done, if a little shall so hinder in
it, that the Oil cannot issue forth: To the nether Pype fasten another Tynne
pype, or Copper Pype, passing through a vessel filled with cold water, which
when it shall be hot, pour in other cold water. And to the end of that Pype
set a Receyuer, having in it one wine pynte of pure cold water, sufficient
great and able to contain both the Oil and water: And let the Receyuer be of
Glass, or earth, glased within, and not of Copper, in that it lightly draws
the oil to a greenness through the Canker which consists in the Copper, and
let all be marvelous well stopped: When all these shall be thus handled and
done, about the Cucurbite, kyndle a gentle and soft fire of coals in the
beginning, yielding an equal heat leysurely out of all the parts, and
increase the fire by little and little, unto evening (for in one day is the
same Dystillation ended) until the whole Cucurbite be covered and hid with
burning coals. And this conceive, that when the Cucurbyte is in a manner read
hot, then the Dystillation to be ended: so that then you may withdraw the
fire, and let them stand all a night without fire, that they may cool by
themselves. After draw forth the Cucurbite, and you shall find it empty of
Amber, but the stones which yet remain within black, covered as they were
with soote: And in the bottom of the nether Instrument you shall discern the
Feces, or the refuse appearing like to Pitche, and the Oil carried through the
Pype unto the receyuer, swymming on the water, which both are to be reserved,
until the oil be rectified. And these hitherto may suffice for the first
dystillation.

Of the Rectification. The.xliiij. Chapter.
LEt us now come unto the second and last dystillation, which is wrought by
ascension: and is the Rectifying of the oil, that is, the separation of the
pure from the vnpure, and performed after this manner: Take a glass Cucurbite,
and pour into it the water with the oil, that the belly of the same may be
filled unto the neck, and set on in like manner a head of glass, which commit
into Balneo, and you ought to govern all very well, least the heat breaks
it, and pour into Balneo hot water. For the glass through hot, cannot
endure the sudden cooling, but cracketh or breaks incontinent, which
prepared to distill, set then to the nose of the Lymbecke a glass receyuer,
and an oil will issue forth most pure, myxed with a little water: which also
must be separated from the Oil, by an instrument of glass, after the
instruction of Valerius Cordus, which manner he always used: or for lack of the
same, you may use the other instrument of glass, much like to the Funnell:
for this oil evermore swimmeth above the water.

And this dystillation may also be done by sand in the same manner, if so be
you fence the body before with lute, that the heat break not the glass, but
the purer and best commended, is that done by Balneo.

The Instrument of Valerius Cordus.


Another instrument of separating after the form of a Funnell.


4. Is ye empty space.

B. the pipe, by which ye air enters into ye empty space. 2. the space of
the oil and water.

5. the pype by which the water issues.

Of the virtues and utility of the rectified oil. The.xlv. Chapter.
THis Oil in ancient time was named holy, for the marvelous and secret
virtues of it: for it has the same properties, which the Amber it self, but
far effectuouser. For what efficacy and virtue consists in five, six, or
seven pounds of the Amber, the same may be reduced eas^ly into one pound: By
which reason it much avails in the falling sickness, in the Palsy, and
Crampe, and mightily helps women molested with the suffocation of the
Matrice, it comfort also the yongling in the mothers womb.

Of the Oil of Amber, and the virtues of it, does a certain learned man thus
write: it exceeds by his property (says he) all waters of life, as they
name them, and any manner of Aurum potabile, or potable gold, especially in the
curing of the Apoplexy, and falling sickness.

Of the Oil of Tylestones. The xlvi. Chapter.
THe Oil Benedick, or Oil of Tyle stones, having in it many virtues unto
cold griefs and diseases, and profitabler than a Baulme, by his virtue and
subtilnesse, is prepared and drawn after this manner: Take of new baked Tyles,
that never water came upon, such a quantity as you think needful, those
beat so small as Fetches, Hemp, Milium, or else the ponder most finely
fifted: After let it be poured into a glass body, or other body, and
mightily maintained with fire, or strongly burned: which thus burned, pour
into old and clear oil Olyue, if it may be gotten, being in an earthen
vessel glased: and let it so rest to infuse for vij. or x. days, and if any
pieces be gross, beat those small, and pour the whole into a great
Cucurbite, on which set a head artely luted in the joint, and dystill with a
soft fire: and this conceive, that of one pound of the Oil, you shall gather
but one ounce, whose natural virtue exceeds, and is greater in effect than
the natural Baulme, in the curing of all cold sicknesses and griefs, and is
hoter than it: and for that cause it is named oil Benedick, or blessed oil,
especially unto ye curing of cold sicknesses, and the older the oil shall be
before the occupying, ye better will it work.

The true and certain notes to know this Oil assuredly, are these: that the
oil Olive holds or bears up (as it were) this oil in the myddle of it: or
stays it hanging about the bottom, and not touching the bottom, whereof
this shows it self to be hoter and lighter than the oil Olyue: and the same
also which is not Artely drawn of Tyles, i^ heavy, so that if a drop be let
fall into this purer oil, it falls to the bottom: and in this is the
coldness and he auynesse of it known. Also this Oil causes or yields a
strong savor, and is read in color: and a drop of it besides poured in the
hand, does incontinent vanish away, and spreads all the hand: and if an iron
rod be anointed with the same Oil, and touched of any fl^me, does forthwith
burn: and kindled or flaming, does not easily go out, nor is lightly quenched.
When the distillation of this Oil shall be fully performed, open then the
vessel wittily after it shall be through cold, and draw forth the powder of
the Tyles resting in the bottom of the glass, into which oil after pour a
quantity of other powder burned, if you mind to purchase more of the Oil,
and dystill after the manner above taught: and the Oil dystilled, keep well in
a glass close stopped with wax.

There are here uttered xliiij. virtues of the same, auayling in a cold cause,
so well inward as outward. 1. First the Oil restores all those members cold
by any accident, if the harmed members be anointed with it. 2. It heals a
wound, if the proper herb agreeable, be a little boiled in it. 3. This
helps all ye clefts and chops happening on the hands and feet in the winter
time. 4. The oil helps sinews weak through the Gout, or some other cause,
and the trembling or shaking of the head and hands. 5. The Gout and ache of
the joints proceeding of a cold cause, the neck payning, and so stiff, that
it cannot turn hither and thither, is helpen with this oil. 6. It breaks
into small pieces the stone of the bladder and kidneys, by annoynting on the
places, and drinking often of the oil with white wine. 7. It cures also the
excoriation of the bladder, so well within as without (which is known by the
biting or fretting of the yard) by anointing on the proper place. 8. This
helps the staying back of the vryne, and hardness in the making of water. 9.
The oil helps the passions of ye ears proceeding of a cold cause, as the
deafness, the noise or hissing, and the flux of evil humors to the ears,
by applying a fine lynnen cloth wet in it within the ear. 10. This avails
against the worms either bred within, or crept in by hap. 11. This helps ye
drawing of the mouth by a crampe: and the drawing or tormenting of the belly,
and the griefs of the matrice in every age: to the help of the Sciaticke
pain, or ache of the hip, and pain of the kidneys and ridge bone, may be
added those herbs, flowers and roots of a hot nature, appropriated to them,
as the Sage, the Penyroyall, the Wormwood, ye running Time, Organy, Betony,
Hisop, and Dittany. 12. To every push, and raw impostume not through ripe, in
that the raw it soon rypeneth, and the ripe soon or speedily dissolueth: to
which if the Da^nell root, the yolk of an egg, and white Onyon roasted under
hot ymbers, be artly applied, does greatly profit. 13. The oil helps the
hardness of the milt through over much coldness, in that it speedily moystneth
and gently heateth it. 14. This oil helps such molested with the falling
sickness, is the nosthrill of the pacient be anointed with it. 15. This
helps the ^^slation or stopping of the brain and nose, through a cold cause
howsoever it shall happen, whether the eyes run or water, or the nosthrils be
full of phlegm, if the proper places be anointed with it, or that it be taken
by the mouth. 16. It helps all manner of coldness of ye head and brain: for
anointed with the oil, it does heat, and marvelously comforts. 17. This
also anointed on the hinder part of the head, does help forgetfulness, and
^ weak memory. 18. It cures the toothach, by rubbing or annoynting the gums
with it. 19. The oil drunk, helps the coldness of ye matrice, being also
anointed both within and without, and the staying back of the monthly terms.
20. It brings forth the dead yongling by opening the mouths of the veins.
21. It avails or cures the clotted blood of a stripe, and dries up the
evil humors of barren women. 22. The oil helps a cold cough, and stopping
of the lungs, by drinking and anointing the breast with it, and it cures a dry
and weak cough, which is named the straytnesse of the breast, and dissolueth
there the congealed humors, and opens the pypes of the lunges: anointed also
on the watery eyes, cures them, if the annoynting be done on the lids of the
eyes. 23. The oil cures the swelling of the lids, the pain and redness
through the swelling, or the abundance of bleude caused in them. 24. It also
cures ye bit of any venomous beast, as the Scorpion, the Spyder, the Waspe, ye
Be, the Snake, and Adder, if the stinged or poisoned place be anointed with
it. 25. The oil helps swounding and weakness of the heart and stomach, if
of it be drunk with good wine. 26. The oil profits fishermen, if their nets
be anointed with it before they go to fishing, for it allureth and draws
fishes in with the only savor. 27. It avails against the drinking of Opium,
or Henban. 28. This helps the grief and pain of the fundament, and worms:
drunk and anointed, especially if wormwood shall be admired with it. 29. It
helps the spitting of blood, and pissing of blood. 30. And whose blood is
congealed or clotted in the head, and the cause is of an impostume engendered,
or of a strype, if the place be anointed with it, this helps in short time,
31. The oil also avails and helps the person broken, by anointing, and
applying of it in plaster form, with the juice of wormwood. 32. This avails
against a hard and dry scab of ye head, by annoynting the places with it. 33.
This helps any Fistula. 34. The oil helps the stone of the bladder and
kidneyes, if the herbs agreeable unto this, as the Saxifrage, Grummell seeds,
Parsely seeds, Fennel seeds, and Gotes blood be mixed with it, and given to
drink. And blessed be the Lord God who of his exceeding liberality has
provided so many sundry helps, and varieties of things to man's frailty. 35. If
in the oil Benedick, you shall boil long pepper, and the grains of paradise,
and Pelitorie, of each one dram, and half a dram of Castorie, and with this
shall anoint (the Edray) avails unto coeating. 36. That a candell may not go
out, neither with rain nor the wind: take a quantity of silk or towe, and
wet the same in the oil Benedick, and with talow or wax make a candle, which
may burn in the water. 37. The dung also of the Dove myxed with the oil
Benedick, and a dry stick anointed with that mixture, and laid for a space
in the hot Sun, will kindle and burn of it self. 38. Take also of vnstaked
Lyme and Brimstone, of each a like quantity, these temper or myxe with the oil
Benedick, and form pylles of the whole, which throw into a pot of water, and
fire will issue forth of the water. That a thread may put out a candell
burning, wind it then about the candell: but annoint it before with good
Triacle, and it will put the light forth.

The fourth Book of Dystillations, containing many singular secret Remedies.

Of the dystilling of Aqua vitae, or as some name it, burning water, and of the
properties of the same.
The first Chapter.
THe water which is dystilled out of wine, or the lies of the same, is named of
some the water of life, in that it recouereth and maintayneth life, yea, and
stays old age. But this may righter be named the water of death, if it shall
not be rightly and Artly prepared: insomuch that such a water causes more
harm than commodity, as the Author of Pyrotechnia utters. But of some
named burning water, in that this poured on the hear of the head, or on a
cloth, and putting a candell to it, forthwith burns, in such manner, that the
hears of the head seem, or the clothe to burn, although neither of them be
consumed. The Quintessence also is said to be reduced of the Chemists, unto an
extreme subtilnesse. The burning water or water of life, is sometimes
dystilled out of pleasant and good wine, as the white or read, but oftener
drawn out of the wine lies, of a certain eager savor, or corrupt wine, by a
Tin or Copper Lymbecke, having the head sharp in ye top (like to a spyre
steeple) and a bucket for cold water framed artely upon, and the Furnace also
heated moderately with coals, as writes Lemnius. Further when out of pure
wine, a water of life is distilled, I hear (says D. Gesnerus) that out of a
great quantity of good wine, a little yield or quantity of burning water to
be distilled: but out of the lies of wine, a much yield and quantity
gathered: and out of the wine Alsatico, is not so commendable an Aqua vitae
dystilled: Besides, the burning wine in lightness, does in a manner exceed or
pass all other moystures, forasmuch as there be four (as the same Lemnius
reports in his second book, and. 34. cap.) of the secret miracles of
nature, which by reason of the lyghtnesse and heaviness, do contend in
themselves, as the wine, the water, the oil, and honny, of which the lightest,
and smallest of weight, is the burning wine, which mixed with the oil, floteth
above, and the oil setleth under: In that it is all the earthlye gathering, to
the uttermost boiled to it, and is the whole fiery and ayreall substance
wrought of the same, and next to this in lightness is the oil. etc.

That if you will try, whether the Quintessence be pure, or cou^terfaited,
wette a napkin or lynnen cloth in the said lyquour, and putting a candell to
it, set on fire, if incontinent it flameth, and the cloth never the worse, then
is it most effectuous and perfect. And handkerchiefes wette in this water,
being kyndled, flame, and not consume them, for the flame so lightly burns on
the linen cloth, that it pierces or enters not through, but as it were, by a
licking manner, suppeth up the lycour agreeable to it, and of a fiery nature:
That if you pour a little of it in the palm of the hand, and set it on fire
with the flame of paper, it then burns in the palm, and not heateth nor
burns the hand.

I have tried the marvelous virtue of it (says Lemnius) in many matters, for
at what time the air is very cold, and that it strongly freeseth, this lycour
for all that is not frosen, nor congealed to yse, insomuch the ynke at that
season, and many others besides, myxed with certain drops of it, are
defended from being frosen, and the same proceeds through the extreme
hotenesse and thynnesse, which consist in it: this burning wine myxed with
salt, and set on fire, causes the standers about, whiles it flameth, to
appear like dead persons. Hitherto Ringelbergius. This seetheth an egg, and
preserves boiled or raw flesh from putrefying, being dipped in the same: and
troubled wine myxed with it, cleereth, and is restored: and dropped into new
wine, does like clear it: Wine decaying and sower, it also restores: It
draws forth the virtue of all herbs, if they be infused in it, except the
savor of the Violet, which it retayneth not: The savor of it slays all
venymous worms, and auoydeth poison. This Vitalis. And this one thing is
marvelous, which I learned (says the Author) of a credible person: that if
certain drops of the water be poured into a gunne, and myxed with the powder
at the shooting of, this htetsarb: In the same manner are also great rocks of
stone broken: and I hear (says the Author) a beaten way so made by the
valley Tellina, (as I guess) toward Millaine: By the dropping of the water on
the rocks, made of wine thrice dystilled over, which by that means are
woonderfullye cracked and broken a sunder. Further a lynnen clothe dypped in it
(as we have above uttered) does wholye flame, without harm of the threades:
and dystilled a fourth time over, if you then throw of it up into the air,
nothing of it will discende or fall to the earth: And if you will a fish to
have a better savor with it, kill the fish then in this dystilled licour, and
suffer the same to lie in it a time, and it will continue in the like savor for
many days: if you season the fish killed in this manner, with Salt and Pepper,
there will nothing eat pleasanter, especially if it shall be a fish of the
best kind. The burning water often distilled, if with it you shall wash the
hands, and set on flame, they will burn without harm. This Gaudentius Merula,
in libro. 4. memorabilium, that if in the dystilling, the powder of Sulphur
viue be myxed, then the Aqua vitae kindled, will burn the stronger. This
cease the pain of the head, if it proceed of a cold matter. And druncke
with a fasting stomach for two days together, with a little quantity of
Triacle, purges the head, and dries up by the moystures of the same: If any
drincketh a quantity of this, with some manner of wine, in the morning fasting,
does like comfort the brain: This puts away the dymnesse of sight, and
consumes the web and spots of the eyes, and dries up the running of them:
and dropped into the ears, restores hearing: A lynnen cloth wette in it, and
laid on the tongue, restores the speech of the palsy person, if it shall be
often repeated for certain hours. Some commend the sublimation of wine
against worms which breed in the teeth, by washing the mouth with it: and the
best wine for this purpose (as affirms Alexander Benedictus) is the Candie,
or Rennishe wine, which the oftener repeated by distillation, will be the
stronger. This water drawn by a glass Limbecke, anointed on the neck, and
drunck in the morning fasting, helps hoarsnesse. The use of it in the
dropsy, is on this manner exercised: take half a measure of the Aqua vitae,
which gently heat, that it may be in a manner warm, after wash the feet with
it, and let the feet stand in the same for one quarter of an hour, then the
soles of the feet rub with the juice of the Nettle, and about the ancle
bones, and the pacient shall in short time be cured, as Virus of Rochberg
reported to the Author. The water sublymed of pure wine, avails against
refting or belching, proceeded of cold and wind: This Alexander Benedictus.
The Germans in a certain place, do drink or taste of the water thryse
distilled over, supposing it auayleable against flewme: the same Author. To be
auayleable against the pains of the loins, and phlegmatic swellings, did the
author understand and learn this of a certain farmer or franklin of the
country, on this wise: that a platter or basen should be taken, and so fenced,
that it could not be harmed with the fire, through a cloth laid on it: the same
so prepared, set into a hot house, close on every side, and the cloth then wet
with the best Aqua vitae, set on a flame (for if the Aqua vitae be good, the
cloth will not be burned) and let the pacient incontinent enter into that close
room, and he shall forthwith sweat, in that it procures there a mighty
heat: and let this be done five times, or more, according to the strength of
the pacient, and the places payning, bath well with the Aqua vitae, in which
the flowers of Spykenarde, shall be steeped, and the pacient shall be shortly
helped: And unto the stone of the bladder, they will to drink the water of
life, for the space of seven months, every day morning and evening, myxing
together two parts of pure wine, and one of the water of life: and in this
manner is the stone broken, and the pieces sent forth with the urine: Wounds
bathed with the water, and the Canker, and Fistula, are healed with it.

Vitalis de Furno (out of many) attributed these properties to it, that it
breaks impostumes as well within as without the body, if it be drunck, or
applied sometimes without: It takes away the spots of the eyes, and both the
redness and heat of them, and stays the shed^ing of tears: It helps such
diseased in the spleen and liver, being discretely drunck: It congealeth
Mercury, whiteneth Copper, and dissolueth the spirits and bodies calcyned: It
cures wounds, any manner Gout, the Canker, and Fistula, if drunck, or the
place of the wound washed with it: It sharpeneth understanding, discretely
taken, and matters past, it brings to memory, and makes the person
exceeding merry, and preserves youth: It cures the salt phlegm, and read
spots of the face: It takes away the stink of the nosthrils, gummes, and
armeholes: Gargelled, breaks impostumes in the throat: It very much helps
the Melancholic: and much profits the ache in the hippes, the gout, and
ioyntaches: It cures the Dropsy of a cold cause: It much avails against
the cholicke passion: with his lyme dissolved in wine, it breaks the stone of
the bladder: but dissolved with his salt, does break the stone of the kidneys,
and sends the pieces forth: And taken moderatly, does put away the quartaine
Ague: If the leprous person shall measurably drinck of the water sometimes, the
lepri^ shall not further extend: It profits women to conceive, and
conception it strengthens, if the woman conceived, drinck of it: If a little
of it be druncke sometimes, or holden a whiles in the mouth, cures the Rheum
^ The water anointed on the decayed eyes, and liddes, cures them: It gives
boldn^sse, if any faint hearted or weak couraged person, shall sometimes drink
of it. These hitherto Vitalis. Further of the properties of the same water in
general, does Leuius Lemnius: utter these in his book of the secret miracles
of nature: where he writes, that no lycour, which is ministered unto any use to
man's body, is either lighter, or more peercing, than the Aqua vitae, or that
more preserves and defends all things from putrefying, or corruption: whose
use has grown so common with the nether Germany, and Flaunders, that
freelyer than is profitable to health, they take and drinck of it: for not to
all persons, or at all times, the drinking of it is so agreeable and
healthful, insomuch that to lean persons, and of a dry nature, and in the
summer time, the use of it is very dangerous, for it burns their bodies, and
consumes natural moisture in them: but in the fat and moist bodies, and
such which do abound in the flegmaticke humors, this nothing harmeth, in that
the water digesteth the excrementall humors, and both defends and preserves
such bodies from the lithargie, or sleeping down right, the Apoplexy, and all
cold sicknesses. For which cause in ye winter time, I allow a moderate use of
it, as the quantity of half a dram (which fills a spoone) at one time,
thoroughly sweetened with sugar, and a slyce of fine white bread eaten with it,
whereby the burning force of it may the less strike or give unto the nosthrils
and brain, or hastily carry any harm to the liver, through the penetrable and
fervent heat: but applied without, does greatly help the sinews and muscles,
and the members oppressed with cold, all other painful diseases, which come
of cold humors, it asswageth and puts away, through the heating force, and
swiftness of piercing: and it recouereth also speech deprived and lost, if at
that instant time be mixed to it, of the seeds of Roket, and the squillitick
vinegar: That if the Aqua vitae be distylled twyse or thryse over, it
purchases an incredible force of peerchig. These hitherto Lemnius.

Of the instruments which the best practitioners use, unto the dystilling of
Aqua vitae. The second Chapter.
Seeing in the dystillation of the water of life, many gross spirits are
elevated or sent up by force of the heat, for that cause, the practisioner
must endeavor to temper them, and to cause those subtiller through the benefit
and help of the long, narrow and winding instruments, and the distillation to
be performed, needs not only cooling, but also to be in a cold place, where
water may remain for the continual cooling of them, that no viscositie or
grossness come unto the Limbecke, whereof is come to pass, that diverse and
sundry instruments are invented by skillful practisioners, unto the better
performing of the abouesaide.

Many do dystill the burning water by a bladder (as they name it) as Louicer9
reports, and teaches in his book, which the learned may there read, and
practice if they will: but this manner of dystillation, for that they shed the
water, is not allowed of the best dystillers: and for that reason they use this
manner and way, for a more speedynesse, and shorter form invented in a manner
for the Poticarie, only with us of Germany.

An instrument for the dystilling of the water of life, out of the lies of
Wine. The third Chapter.


A. represents the Furnace being round in form, or square, if it be,
forces not much.

B. does here express the place or hole, by which the fire is made under the
pot, or other copper vessel.

C. does here represent the Brass pot or Copper vessel, sufficient able or
great enough, containing the lies.

D. does signify the cover of the vessel, which if the same be made hollow
imbossing toward the myddle, and that in the myddle where the pype issues
forth, this be framed to a sharpness, it will send by the vapors much
better, than if the cover were plain or flat.

E. does signify the hole of the cover, into which the pype is set, and artely
fastened.

F. does aptlye show the Copper pype, carrying forth the vapors, which ought to
be made wrything and wynding after this manner: for on such wise (as they say)
the water will seem the oftener to be dystilled: or the same perhaps so framed,
that the vapors the longer kept back, may the lightlyer and easier be
thickened. Some there be, which make sundry windings in the pype, before it
enters within the Bucket or firkin, which perhaps less allowed and commended
of the skylfuller practisioners.

G. represents the wooden payle, bucket, or firkin containing in it the cold
water. H. Does signify the benche or great stool with four feet, bearing
the bucket or firkin full of cold water.

K. the place lower on the bench or stool, where the receyuer ought artely to
be set and fastened.

Two furnaces may be buylt near to this firkin or bucket (for on such wise
with us, a certain practisioner was wont to dystill the burning water) of
which, the one may be erected nearer to the bucket, and the other placed
further of: in the nearer pot to the Bucket, let the Lies be first dystilled:
in the other vessel placed further of, let it be dystilled a second time,
that the water may be the subtiller and purer. And the same water, may perhaps
be drawn with lesser business, if in the second dystillation, it be dystilled
with a longer Pype: in that by a longer Pype and way retching, the spirits
sent forth, may the thinner be gathered.

An other Instrument. The fourth Chapter.
1. The vessel or pot, containing the matter or liquide substance: A
certain dystiller (with the Author) had a pot that held xvj. measures: out of
which he drew, after a second, or third dystillation repeated, about three
measures.



2 Represents the cover of the vessel.

3 Does here set forth the pype, which ought to be made broad beneath (as the
Pynapple) and sharp vppewarde: and the same pype may be made double, that
the one filled with cold water, and heated, may be again drawn out.

4 Expresses the paile or bucket, containing the cold water.

5 Signifies the trancheon or small block of wood, set on a high stool, ye
apter to bear the Bucket, equal to the head, and nose of the instrument
placed.

6 Does here represent the place where the receyuer ought to be set and
fastened. 7 Plainly shows the fire, to be made round about of any small cloue
wood. By such an instrument, is a far greater yield of burning water
purchased, than by the common Limbecks: for so much as the pype retching from
the cover of the vessel, does ascend right up, and not as in the others
windingly: and in this perhaps is a greater speed made, than in the other
instruments.

Another Instrument for the dystilling of the water of life, borrowed out of
Pyrotechnia. The.v. Chapter.
ALthough sundry and diverse instruments be daily invented: yet I saw this
always most commodious, and profitablest, whose form shall hereafer be
described: and first let a Copper vessel tynned within be prepared, out of
which in that part, by which the wine is poured in, let a long pype formed with
many empty parts retch upward: and at the end above of three or four
yardes, let a small bucket either of Copper or wood be set, in the same manner
placed, that the pype in part of the bole, or in the upper part of the bucket,
retch wynding up, from the middle of it: but at the top or straight end of
this wynding Pype, let a head of glass be aptlye framed and set on, to the
nose of which artely set and fasten a receyuer, for the Aqua vitae dystilling
forth: This vessel on such wise prepared, set aptly into the furnace, and
the wine pour into it, by the pype retching up on the other side, right
against the cock, by which also the grounds or superfluous substance after
the dystillation ended, are purged clean forth: But in the upper part, the
bole or bucket placed under the pype, which for his wynding is named the
Serpent, shall be filled with cold water, and a soft fire in the beginning
made under the vessel of wine: whose furnace ought to be buylt after this
form above demonstrated.

A fourth Instrument for the dystilling of the Aqua vitae, so workemanly and
cunningly drawn, that the water but once dystilled, may be purchased most
mighty or strong: And I hear such a practice at Florence to be in use.
The.vi. Chapter.


A. Signi^^eth the place, where the ashes rest.

B. Does here represent the grate bearing the fire.

C. Does here manifestly show the place, where the fire is made.

D. Does express the high and narow furnace, worckmanly made.

E. Shows the long and byg vessel, receiving the great quantity of wine.

F. Represents the most narrow joint.

G. the pype, by which the wine is poured in.

H. does instruct the way, by which the vapors ascend.

I. The nose of the head, to which the mouth of ye receyuer is set and
fastened. K. Does here represent the bucket or other vessel, filled with cold
water, and cooling the head. L. Does show the cane or pype, by which the cold
water ascends or ryseth up into the bucket, M. Represents the nose or pype
of the bucket, by which the hot water is drawn forth. N. Signifies the
barrel or hoggesheade made long, and filled with cold water.

An instrument which is so formed, that the water by sucking, is forced to rise
up and run forth: as the like practice is often ^sed, in pittes of water, or
wells. And by this instrument with a little fire, may a great quantity of
the water of life be dystilled and gathered.

Of the diverse manners of distylling the Aqua vitae, so well simple, as
compounde. The.vij. Chapter.
A Water sublymed out of pure wine, affyrmeth an unknown practysioner, and the
same is of late days invented, to sublime the water by a glass or Copper
Body, in the which doing, the gross substance and refuse remains, or
stays behind, and the lighter matter, in the vapors ascending, dystilleth
and is gathered in the Receauer. Vitalis de Furno wylleth thus to dystill, the
simple burning water: Take pure Claret wine, and strong, which power into a
Lymbecke, and dystill with a soft fire, as you do the Rosewater, and a burning
water will issue forth by sublimation, which look how oftener it shall be
dystilled over, and so much the subtyller and profitabler it will be.

That the water of life once dystilled over, may be so perfyte and good, and
possess the same properties: which an other thrice, four times, or oftener
dystilled does. The.viij. Chapter.
IF so be you will dystill, a simple Aqua vitae, or burning wine at one
dystillation, that in property and virtue it may be, as if the same were
twenty times dystilled over, then cover a Sponge over the mouth of the
Cucurbite, and the Lymbecke close with the seal or lute of Hermes, and a
receauer set to the nose of the Lymbecke, and luted in the ioynte, dystill
according to Art in Balneo Mariae: For on such wise is caused, that the spyrit
of the wine ascends unto the highest, and from thence by the Nose falls
into the Receauer: but all the waterynesse, remains by the way in the
Sponge. And a certain Alchymister used this manner, for a most great and deep
secret. We compared or assayed it (says D. Gesnerus) with the Aqua vitae,
once dystilled over without a Sponge, and we found ours of greater effect and
virtue: and we again assayed it, with an other water dystilled ten times over
without a Sponge, and ours did more pearce, then that. A certain dystiller
with us (says the Aucthour) affyrmeth that the Aqua vitae only once
dystilled, to be very unwholesome to them, which drink it: and to have a great
force of putrefying, as the same experience proves. If the burning water be
set on fire (says he) and quenched again after a whiles, that which
remains, very much sauoureth or stincketh. But the water which shall be twice
or thrice distylled over, neither stincketh nor putrifieth.

Of the distyllation of Quintessence out of wine, by Balneum Mariae: Take of
white wine, the best, four measures, or five according to the greatness of
the Glass body, so that a third part of the Cucurbyte be empty, on which,
set a head of Glass, luted in the ioynte, with the whytes of Eggs, meal, and
water myxed together, and spread on a Lynnen clothe before the laying on: which
on this wise prepared, set into Balneum Mariae, and distyll after with a very
soft fire, both day and night: For out of five measures, you shall purchase
but a half measure pure, which after the rectifying in a Pellicane for
certain days, keep to your use.

A water of Life out of wine, distylled thrice over: Take twenty pyntes of good
and gross wine, and draw out of the whole four pintes, in such a vessel as
you know: after out of those four, draw two pyntes and out of those two
again, draw only one pynte. This water avails against any redness, and
spotte of the eyes, and is profitable unto all wounds, and avails also
against the Rewme and Fistula, and unto many other grieffes besides it is right
profitable. That if you myxe with this the gaul of a Partriche, it takes
away the heat, and myste of the eyes: also dropped in the eyes, stays and
takes away the tears, if it shall be mixed with the juice of the wild Time.

A burning water, take a pottell of the auncientest Red wine, and poured into a
great pytchard or Tankard, having a large bottom, and narrow mouth, to which
add three ounces of either Brunstone, or either O^pyment, of Armoniacke, of
Tartare, and of Salt nytre, and one pynte of very old Oil olyue, or common
Oil, which boil together unto the consumption of two parts, and let the
whole be strayned, to which then let hot or burning water be added, and drawn
after by an Ippocrasse bag or strainer, that the first water may be gotten.
If a Candle be anointed with this water, or the wyke of any other light, and
put under the water, will not go out. If this water also be sprinkled on the
heir of the head, on a clothe, or on a cappe, that it may burn, this after it
shall be consumed, the clothe will remain unharmed, or any other, on which it
is sprinkled. This Rogerius, in his fourth Tract. Chap. 7. where you shall
fullyer learn, this manner of distillation, by the former Chapter.

A burning water you may make on this wise: take thick, mighty, and old red
wine, to which add a quarter of the same, of vnsleaked Lyme, of Brymstone most
finely brought to powder, of the Tartare of good wine like brought to powder,
and of baye Salt: which pour together into a Cucurbite well luted: after the
head set on, and luted in the joint, distyll according to Art, and the burning
water gathered, keep in a Glass close stopped: this Albertus Magnus.

A spyced water, which they name the water of Life, or an Hyppocras, or Baulme:
let the herbs, the sweet smellyng roots, and Spyces, be stieped in six
times so much of good wine, for thyrtie days, the wine after strained, and the
spices broken, add again to the wine, and distyll the whole according to
Art. To the water distylled, add of fresh Sage, half an ounce, of Cynamon,
of Gynger, of Cloves, of Nutmegges, of Sage with the roots, and Grains of
Paradize, which after the infusion, distyll over again.

A water of Life serving unto diverse grieffes, proceeding of cold: as unto the
Gout, and pains of the same, unto the pain of the Bowelles, and distyllation
from the head, druncke twyse in a month: and the grief also of the teeth, the
gummes, and disseases of the Tongue, this marvelously helps, it works much
good to the stomach charged with flewme: and the collicke passion* one dram
given, with so much of good Triacle in wine. Take of burning water one pynt, of
Euphorbium, of Odellium, of Sagapenum, of Spodium, of long Pepper, of Cubebae,
of Opopanax, of Cynamon* of Cloves, of Nutmegs* of Pellytory, of Cyperus, of
Squinantum, of each one ounce, all these artlye brought to powder, stiepe in
burning water for three days, and draw the lycour according to Art in a
dystyllatorie instrument: this Bertapalia.

A water of Life against the Pestilence, borrowed out of a written Book: Take
of the Cloves half a dram, of Cynamon, of Zedoaria, of the roots of Valerian,
of Pympernell, of Turmentyll, and of red Roseleaues, of each one dram, of
the Cytrine and red Saunders, of Spodium, of the ryndes of the Cytrone, of
Doronicum, of Terra Sigillata, of Dittany, of Seseleos, of Baulme, of Maioram,
of the Helycampane, of the seeds of Seseleos, of Carabe, of Ruberbe, of
Nutmegges, and of Mace, of each half a dram, of Scabious, of the flowers of
Borrage, of Buglosse, of Rosemarie, of the Hearts horn burned, of Rue, of
Colyander prepared, Spetierum liberantis, Specierum de gennus, Diacameronis,
Letitiae Almansoris, Diarrhodon abbatis, Diamargaritonis, of the Iacinct, of
the Smaragde, of the pure Pearls, of each one dram, of Methridate, of Triacle
of venice, and of fine Bole armoniacke, of each half a scruple, of the leaves
of Gold and Silver, of each seven in number, of the best burning wine eight
pyntes: let all these be disligentlye beaten and labored together, and myxed
with the sublymed Wine, which after power into a glased vessel, and stop
diligently the mouth, that no air breathe forth, best let so stand to infuse
for three days, and dystill after with a soft fire according to Art, in
Balneo Mariae. Let of the same be given in the Pestilence, with the Electuarie
aunswerable or agreeable to it.

A water of life, helping all cold grieffes and sicknesses, especially an
astonyed dissease, the tenderness of members, and pain of the Gout and
joints: Take of burning water drawn of the best wine, half a pynte, of
Acorus prepared, two ounces, of Rosemary flowers and Sauge flowers, of each
one ounce and a half, of the leaves of the same herb, half a handful, of
Cynamon, of Xyloaloes, of each one dram, of Mace, of Cardomomum, of the ryndes
of the Cytrone, of Cloves, of Saffron, of each half a dram, of Nardus one
scruple, of Gynger one dram, of Stachados two ounces, of Musk, and of Amber,
of each six graynes: all these after the breaking somewhat, stiepe together
for five days, the Spices separated, dystill the liquour, and ad too after the
Spices.

Of a noble water, helping many sicknesses and griefs, of which as well the
first that is dystilled, as the second, laid on a fresh wound twyse in the
day, is affyrmed to heal it in a short time: also the Canker, the Fistula,
eating Cankers, or Wolf, and the dissease which is named Noli metangere, if
they be washed once a day with either, does speedily cure them: and if half a
dram weight be druncke, with a small draft of the best wine, breaks the
stone, and sends it forth: it mittigateth and helps the heat of the vryne
in the coming forth, and any manner grieffes of the Matrice: and anointed
with a like wayght of fat lycour, helps weariness, and strengthens the
Synewes: the Pacientes also molested with the Crampe, and washed thrice in the
day with this water, are speedily helped, and many other infirmyties this does
like help. But the water a third time distylled of these, maintayning the
color of the blood, is very precious, of which, if any shall drink half a
spoonefull, for fifteen days together, shall be cured of the Leprie, the
Palsy, the water between the Skin, the joint Ache, the Gout, and other
like disseases. This druncke besides unto the quantity of half a dram, or at
the least twice in the week, with a spoonefull of Borrage water for a year
together, does stay back old age, and recouereth strength (in such manner)
that if any sick be near drawing an^ ^r nigh head, and shall receive a little
quantity of this water, shall not ha^tity or sodaynlie dye. The manner of making
this water is on this wise: take of Zedoaria, of Galingale, of the long and
round Pepper, of Cloves, of Gynger, of Juniper Berryes, of the ryndes of the
Cytrone, and of the Orrenge, of Sauge leaves, of Basyll, of Rosemarie, of
Maiorame, of Myntes, of Baye berryes, of Penny royal, of Gentiane, of
Catmynte, of Elder flowers, of the red and white Roseleaues, of Nardus, of
Xyloaloes, of Cubebae, of Cardamomum, of Cynamome, of Calamus aromaticus, of
Stoechados, of Germaunder, of Chamaepithis, of Melegeta, of Mace, of Olibanum,
of Aloes Hepaticke, of the seeds and leaves of Mugwoorte, and of the seeds of
Wormewoode, of each one dram, of Fygges, of Reisons, of the meat of Dates, of
sweet Almondes and of Pine Apple kernels, of each one ounce, of chosen Honey
six ounces, of Sugar unto double the weight of the whole: all which brought
well to powder, stiepe in burning water drawn^ of the best wine, unto the
quantitye of three times so much, as the weight of the whole, which distyll
with a glass head according to Art^.

A singular water clearing the face and eyes: take of the field^ Rue, of
Fennel, of the leaves of Veruaine, of Bytony roots, of Roseleaues, and of
Maiden heir, of each a like quantity: these stiepe together for a night in
white Wine, strong and pleasant, and distyll after in a Cucurbyte after Art:
this Fumanellus.

A distylled lycour, for the speedylie healing of wounds, out of Fumanellus:
Take of the water of Life, or burning water, four ounces, of good Triacle
half an ounce, which distyll in a glass body after Art: of this apply on
the wound, on which straw dry, both of Aloes and Myrre (I mean the powder)
and on this again a Lynnen cloth wette in the foresaid water.

Unto the procuring of sleep, so many hours as is thought needful* take of
the white and black Poppie seeds, half an ounce, of good white wine, and of
the gaul of a Hare, of each two drams, of pure Aqua vitae, four ounces: let
these be poured together into the water, and (infused) for three days, which
after distyll by a Lymbecke, in Balneo Mariae. A drop of this procures
sleep for an hour, and two drops taken, for two hours, etc.

A certain composition of Doctor Gesnerus, for the dropsse, or the hardness
of fetching breathe: Take of old White wine two pyntes, of Cynamon one ounce,
of the Ireos of Florence, half an ounce, of our Ireos two drams and a half,
of the red Roseleaues three drams, of Colya^der prepared, one dram and a half,
of Fennel, and of Gynger, of each two drams, of ye roots of Asarum, three
drams, of Master woort half an ounce, of Chamaeleontis albi, and of Brionie,
of each two drams, of the ryndes of Esula three drams, of Arum one dram, of
the Electuarie of ye juice of Roses half an ounce^ all these after the
beating, stiepe in a Glass body well-luted, which distyll in ashes according
to Art, until strakes like to parted lines appear in the head. Of this give
one ounce, at a time, as tried. And for the same, may it be wrought or done
with ye whay of milk alone or with wine, in adding thereto a quantity of
Sugar, or Rosed H^nny, when you shall mynister it.

And he sometimes wylled a wine to be dystilled, in which the Raspinges of the
wood Guaiacum, the Juniper berries, and Cynamo^* and a little of red Roseleaues,
have been stieped before.

A water of Life, of D. Thomas Fincke, for many grieffes: take of Lauender, and
of Sage, of each three quarters, of Rue one ounce and a half, of Gynger, of
Nutmegges, of Cloves of Cynamon, of Grains of Paradize, and of white Sugar, of
each half an ounce, of Mace, of Alkekengi, of each one ounce and a half, of
Oil olyue two drams: al these after the beating, power into three pyntes (or a
pottell) of the strongest wine, which let stiepe together for fourteen days,
after distyll the whole according to Art, with a very soft fire.

A most singular water of Life, distylled for a noble man, helping the
consumption (and perhaps the wasting of the Lunges) take of ye sublymed wine,
of good Malmes^e, four pintes, here white bread a quantity, which let stand
close stopped in a Lymbecke for fourteen days: then distyl the same by
Balneum Mariae: after take of Specierum diamargariton, of Diambrae, of
Diarrhodon abbatis, of Dianthos, of Diap^^riscu^ musco, letitiae Galeni, of
each two drams, of Cassia new drawn, and of Sugarcandy, of each one ounce,
of the juice of Lycorys, two ounces, of Rosemary three drammes, of Musci
Alexandrini, half an ounce: let al these stand close stopped, in a
distyllatory vessel, for a whole month. After let the distyllation be done,
by Balneum Mariae, and the water separated into two parts: for the first water
gathered, is nobler then the second.

Another water of Life, written in the Germane tongue: take of the best Aqua
vitae one pottel, which distyl as you know, in a glass body in water, or by
Balneum Mariae: and of the whole gather a quarte, after take of Cynamon two
ounces, the same finely cut or choppped, and powered into a Glass, let it be
myxed with the Aqua vitae, (in such manner) that it may cover the Cynamon a
finger breadth above, which let stand together close stopped, for twelve or
fifteen hours, that the Aqua vitae may so purchase a red or blooddie
color, which pour after into another Glass, and dylligentlie stop the
same. Again to the same Cynamon, power another part of the Aqua vitae (of
like quantitye) least of the whole, which order as above taught: and the same
you shall do so often, as this half part endures, always pouring in, and
that so powered and colored, mix with the first, until the Aqua vitae powered
in be no more colored read. After take half an ounce of Cloves, finely
brought to powder, and likewise the other half of the Aqua vitae or more
remaining, power to this powder, as above uttered. That if of the Aqua vitae in
this doing, there shall no more remain, then take the red Aqua vitae in the
Glass body, and setting a head on it, dystill so much, as shall be needeful to
stiepe the matter: for no redness at all ascends, but what that is then
gathered by distyllation, is white. After this take half an ounce of Nutmegs
finely cut, and as above taught, pour the water of Life upon. Which done, take
the Aqua vitae of the Cloves, and of the Nutmegs, and mix them together with
the Aqua vitae of ye Cynamon. Then take of pure Malmesie, or of the best Renish
wine, one measure, which pour into a glased pot, to it add of Sugarca^dy
beaten, three ounces, and the mouth of the pot covered with paste, set on the
fire, that the Sugar may by little and little melt, and the Sugar molten* let it
leysurely cool. After the cooling, pour into it the red Aqua vitae, which
myxe together in the pot, or rather in a glass, for that it may aptlyer and
closer be stopped: and then shall you obtain, a singular Aqua vitae.

A most noble Aqua vitae, against a Reume: Take of Hysope, of Sauery, of white
Horehounde, of Euulae, of Ireos, of Louage, of Bytony, of Sage, of the leaves
of that Trifoyle (which sends up or yields many gross flowers so byg as a
Nut, in which flowers sucked, is found a certain sweetness, so pleasant as
Sugar or Honey) of each half a pound. All these, after the gross beating, put
into a Glass body, on which power so much of the strongest or myghtiest wine,
that will cover a finger breadth above. This after the distylling, keep
dilligently in a Glass: for it is more of value then Gold, or precious Stones.

A water of Life helping the Apaplexie, and Falling sickness, for it is, as a
certain water of Baulme: Take of Gingar, of Cloves, of Nutmegs, and of Grains
of Paradize, of each half an ounce, of Sage leaves one pound, of Cardamomum,
of Cubebae, of Masticke, of Galingale, of Rosemary, of Lauender, of Mai^rame,
of Baulme, and of Bytony, of each two drams, all these beaten and brought to
powder, power into a Glass body, on which pour nine pyntes of the strongest
and best wine, or so much dystilled wine as will well cover the whole, this
infused for ten days, distyl after according to Art. The water gathered,
helps the Palsy, the swymming of the head, the Ap^plexie, the Crampe, both
memory, and the head, and a cold stomach: and flesh, or fish sprincled over
with the same, does not after corrupt. And myxed with corrupt wine, rectyfieth
it: of this let be druncke three or four drops at a time, with a small slice
of bread dipped in the same, and after eaten, does so sharpen the wit. And let
the hinder part also of the head, and other places, be rubbed with it. It
helps the dropsy, the Melancholicke, and such disseased of the Spleen: and
for the eyes, it is very precious.

A certain marvelous and delectable distyllation, which a certain person
obtained of a certain occupyer, the experience of which. I both did and saw,
says a certain man unnamed: take of the best Malmesie, six measures, the
same distyll by a Lymbecke with a soft fire nine times over: after add to it
of Amber greese, of Sperma ceti, of chosen Rubarbe, of each half an ounce, of
Musk half a dram, these brought to powder: tie up in a fine Lynnen clothe,
being thin, which hang or put within the Aqua vitae. This water is
marvelous, and of great virtue, and serves for Kings, and Princes.

A water of Life of Frederick the Emperors, serving unto all grieffes: Take
of Aqua vitae half a measure, but of Malmesie a whole measure, of Cynamon
three ounces, of Cloves one ounce, of Gynger one ounce and a half, of Nutmegs
one ounce, of Venice Zedoaria, three ounces and a half, of the Grains of
Paradize, one ounce and a half, of Galingale two drams, of Cubebae half an
ounce, of Rosemary half an ounce, of Hysop so much, of Althea so much, of the
roots of Benedictae one ounce, of Sage one ounce, of Lauender half an ounce,
let al these be broken with the hands, and the others brought to powder, which
after put into a Glass body sufficient large, that may contain or hold three
or four measures of licour. To these the^ add of Sugar Candy three ounces, of
Reysons of the Sun, half a pound, of small Reysons one quarter of a pound, of
Figs one quarter of a pound, of Camphora one dram, of Rosewater, half a
cup full, of the water of Elder flowers so much, and so much of Endyue water,
all these then stop close, and set in the Sun for eight days, before the
Feast of S. John, and so many days after it, which after the strayning,
dyligently keep in a Glass close stopped. Of this use, when need shall
require, that is, in the greatest weakness of body and feblenesse of
strength, give a spoonefull of it, and you shall try and see maruailes: for
with this alone (as the report goes) was Frederick Caesar recovered.

A compound water of Life maruaylous, auayling against the Pestilence sore
vexing, and often proved, discribed of D.D. Mag. Take of the Rue newly

Iunyper berries, and Baye berries, of each one dram, and a half, of Terra

roots of the counterfaite Dittany, of Seminis sancti, Benedictae,
Caryophyllata, Helenij, Gentiane, Rhapontici Dioscoridis, Ciambet (an Zurumbet)
of each three drams and a half, of Coliander prepared, of Sorrel, of Basil,
