hang within the water, then dilligently stopped, keep unto your use.

A distylled wafer for all Fistulaes, borrowed out of Theophrastus paracelsus:
take of the best Aqua vitae four pints, of the Rosemary water, and of Sage, of
each two pintes and a half, of pure white sugar, five pou^ds, these after ye
mixing together, distill by a Limbeck according to Art: for this is most
certain in Fistulaes, and inward ulcers.

An Aqua vitae helping joint Aches, the heuinesse and soreness of the Breast,
and serving unto the fear of falling into the sicknesses of the Brain, like
as the falling sickness, the Apoplexy, the Palsy, gyddinesse and such like,
borrowed out of the Counsels, of the singular Benedic victorius: take of the
roots of Acorus two pou^ds, of Pyonie half a pound, of Galingale, and of
Zedoaria, of each one ounce and a half, of Ina, of the lesser Ce^tory, of
Sage, of Maioram, of Stoechados, of Bitany, of Rosemary, of Penny royal, of
Catmint, of Pol^opodie, of Poley, and of Folium, of each one handful, of red
Roseleaues, and of Baccarum Myrthi, of each half a ha^dfull, al these beat in
a gross manner, and in two hundred pintes of mighty and pleasant white wine,
let the whole be infused for the space of three whole days, after wring the
wine and substance very hard out, and that wine pour into a Glass body with
a head, which distyl after Art, to this then add, of Nutmegges of Mace, of
Cloves, of Cynamon, of Masticke, of Gynger, of each in a gross manner beaten,
one ounce, these after the standing a whole day, distyll again the whole by a
Lymbecke, and this water gathered, repeat nine times over. To the water
remaining of the ninth distyllation, add or mix of leaf Gold, leaves a
hundred in number, and of Silver leaves fifty, Om^^u^ fragmentorum, of each
two drams, of Pearls half an ounce, al these most finely bring to powder,
which again distyl two times over. And in the last distyllation* Aromatizate
the water with Musk and Amber. And you shall then possess, the dyuine Elixir
and treasure of Life. The manner of the taking, and use of it, is on this wise:
that in the morning before the filling of the belly, all the spondyles of the
neck, the Muscles of the breast, and all the parts about it, be wette and
rubbed over with it. And for three hours also before dynner, let this drink
be taken, as of the waters of Sage, and of Endive, of each half an ounce, to
it mix flue drops of the Elixir of Life, and give to drink, as most
profitable for the grieffes, above uttered.

A co^pound burning water distilled, against ye Pestilence, borrowed out of the
treatise of Guayuerus of the Pestilence: Many things (says he) are very
singular and effectuous against the Plague, but far excellenter and mightyer
of virtue, is the water that here is taught. For such is the agreement
between the heart and it, that at any time as it should seem, may this water
be drawn of the heart, and thus drawn, be changed in a short time, and
converted after into a spumouse substance, not only of the co^plexional
virtue, but even the whole form resists, any Pestilentiall poison, and
maistryeth the same out of hand. And for that cause, such is the excellent
virtue of the water, that the taking and use of it, not only preserves a man
from Pestilence, but that taken of it, both speedily deliver him: the making
and drawing of which water is on this wise. Take of Tormentyll roots, (fresh
if they may be gotten) one pound, of the roots of Fluellyng, and of Dittany,
of each half a pound, of the roots of Elecampane, eight ounces, of Sorrel
with the Seeds (if they may be gotten) two pound, or of Sorrel one pound,
and eight ounces, and of the Seeds of it, four ounces, of Borrage and
Buglosse, with their flowers, of the red and wild Roses, of each one pound, of
Pympernel, and of Scabious, of each half a pound, of the juice of Lymons one
pound, of fine Tryacle, half a pound, of burning Water drawn out of the
best Wine, and often repeated two ounces, of Terra sigillata, and Bole
Armoniacke, of each two ounces, of the white and red Saunders, of Spodij, of
the white and red Ben, of clear Pearls, of each one ounce and a half, of the
bone of a Hearts heart one ounce, of the shauings or filings of Iuory half an
ounce, of Saffro^ three drams, of Camphora two drams, of Leaf Gold half an
ounce weight: but first take the Leaves of Gold, and those clippe into so small
pieces as is possible, with a fine pair of sheeres, or those on a Marble stone
grind with Honey a long time into a powder not to be perceived by feeling, shall
you bring the leaves: after put them into the burning water, stopping close ye
mouth of the Glass, yt no air breath forth, and let it so stand for fifteen
days. Then take the pearls most finely brought to powder, and power the^ into
another glass with ye juice of the Lymons, which well stopped let stand so
many days: after with ye best wine wash well the roots, that they may be
cleansed from the earth, and dried of the wind in the shadow, beat them in a
Mortar, and like the herbs, the flowers, and Roses, with the seeds: which
done, pour all these into a certain earthen vessel glased, into which after
put the Triacle with those powders and other things. After with these power
that burning water with the leaves of Gold, and the juice of Lymons with the
Pearls, sealing the mouth of the vessel in such manner, that no air breath
forth. Then make a deep pyt in the earth in a moist place, unto the depth of
three feet, and make a Bed in the bottom of the pyt, half a foot thick of
unsleaked Lyme: That vessel then place in the myddle of it, with Horse doong
laid round about, and covering it, on which then power one or two buckets or
pailes of water: and the vessel thus buried, let stand for twelve natural
days, in remoouing it every third or fowrth day with fresh doong, which
time ended, draw the vessel forth, and the whole substance after power into
a Glass body, setting a head close on it, and stopping the joint round about
that no air breathe forth, after make a soft fire under of small cloven wood,
without smoke (or rather of pure Coals) and to the Nose of the head remember
to lute the receauer, that no air breathe forth. The water drawn according to
Art, power upon the Feces, and dystill again, which a third time power into
the Lymbecke without the Feces, and dystill again in Balneo Mariae, the water
gathered keep to your use in a Glass close stopped: Of this water take one
small sponefull by it self, or with any other confection or powder: For this
water multiplyeth the spyrites, clears them, comfort the principal
members, and dysposeth them, that the body hardlye may receive the impression
of any plague, being never so mighty raygning, and infected or stricken with
the Pestilence, does marvelous speedily help the impression. For whiles those
matters remained hyd, in those is a certain fermentacion caused. To conclude,
by the dystillation is a new form procured in them, that of it self caused,
and not by reason of the four qualyties: but in that it is on such wise, as
Aucthours report, that the Pestilence mightily vering each, is through
corruption caused.

A compounde water of Life, helping all grieffes of the body: take of
Nutmegges, of Floris moschatae, of Cloves, of Cynamon, of Ginger, of Cubebae,
of Grains of Paradize* of Stoechaaes, of the seeds of Pyonie, of each half
an ounce, of Mustard seeds, and of Lauender, of each one ounce, of Vermilon
(or rather Dragons blood) of Colyander, of Anise and of Basil, of each half an
ounce, of Geate (but I rather will, says D. Gesnerus, of Aumber) and of
Rosemary, of each one ounce, of Maioram, of Cardamomum, of Fennel, of Lycoris,
of Hysope, and of Spyknard, of each half an ounce, of the flowers of Borrage,
of the Lyllies of the valley, of Baulme, of the heads of the seeds of Roses,
of each half an ounce, of ye Missill toe of the Oak, of the bones of the
Hearts heart, of Lignum aloes, and of Saffron, of each one ounce, of Sage one
handful. The manner of preparing the water, is on this wise: take forty
measures of good wine, which dystill by a Lymbecke in Balneo Mariae: in the
first dystillatio^ gather twelve measures, which dystill over again, until no
more remains or be in the Glass, then a Nutte shell will hold, the same then
cast forth in that it is al flewme; the wine last dystilled, distyl again,
and the whole leysurely or softly five times over, in Balneo Mariae, and the
water shall then be prepared. Take after all the above said symples, as part of
them small chopped, and part beaten into fine powder, which may be brought to
powder, or which power so much of the dystilled wine, as will well reach four
fingers above the whole, these let stand together to infuse for three or four
days, until the water be coulored. The wine after pour into another Glass,
and stop the mouth close, that no air breathe forth. But on the Feces or
grounds remaining, pour fresh wine, which let so stand to stiepe for seven
or eight days, until the wine has drawn and gotten the substance of all
the infused. That wine then separate from the Feces, pouring after the whole
wine into a Glass body, which distyll with a head close luted, in Balneo
Mariae, until no moisture remains in the Glass: and then shall you possess
the Quintessence of the foresaid matters, which keep dyligently stopped, that
it be not touched of the air. After distyll wine of those simples drawn by a
Lymbecke, and take or gather the half part of the wine: for this shall be,
the true Quintessence of that wine. But the other part of the wine which
remains in the Glass, throw away, for it is only a waterie moisture. Then
the Quintessence of the wine, joined with the Quintessence of the other
matters, will become so yellowe as Gold. To this then add Muscum
Alexandrinum, and Amber greese, of each one dram, of Ruberbe two drams,
which after the tying in a fine lynnen clothe, hang within the water, and
stop dylligently the mouth of the Glass, for it is then wholly performed to
use.

A water of Life, marueylouslie comforting, etc. Dissoluing and coagulating
Irone, and other Mettalles, etc. Take of Nutmegs, of Galingale, of Cardamomum,
of the Graynes of Paradize, of Cubebae, of Mace, of Ginger, and of Cynamon: all
these brought to powder, and myxed with the strongest White wine, let all after
be beaten and labored together, unto the styfnesse and thickness of a
Pultyse, which then distyll with a soft fire, and you shall gather a clear
and pure water. To this water if you myxe a quantytie of Oil, the Oil will
then descend: but if you myxe Camphora with it, then shall the water possess
all the virtues, which the Camphora has. That if this Camphora water, be mixed
with the common water, it then works the same as milk, and if it be strayned
through a Lynnen cloathe, this water will remain courded: of which you may
after make a Candell, and lyghted, will burn like the match or Candle in a
Lamp. Now thi^ water profits in the cold disseases of the body, for it
dygesteth, and preserves flesh from putrefying, the sad person makes
merry, and draws unto it the virtues of all herbs, infused in the same:
druncke certain times, breaks the Impostume: it coagulateth and fyxeth
Mercury: it dries up tears of the eyes, the redness, and heat of them it
helps, and cures such disseased of the spleen. It preserves wounds from
putrefying, it helps the Fistula and Canker, reformeth or amendeth cold
causes, and the Palsy, it sharpneth and increases understanding, and helps
memory, if the temples sundry times be anointed with it. It makes a man
joyous and merry* preserves young age and health, and takes away the styncke
of the mouth and gummes. It makes old wine, of the new: it defends a man
against poison: it takes away the pain, and defenesse of the Ears. Two
drops druncke in a cup of the best White wine, do marvelously preserve
memory: if the same be used at the going to bed. The water anointed on the
Temples four times in the week, in the winter time, preserves memory.

A water of life invented and drawn, for a noble person: take of Spetierum
diambrae, one dram, of Dianthos, half a dram, of Pellitory roots, two drams,
of long Pepper, six drams, of Anacardus, one dram and a half, of Xyloaloes
one dram: these fynely wrought together, infuse in Aqua vitae of good
Maluesie, dystilled seven times over, eight ounces, which let so stand close
stopped, for eight days: after dystill the whole by Balneum Mariae, according
to Art.

An Aqua vitae helping Tertian Agues, borrowed out of Theophrastus paracelsus:
take a penny worth of Aqua vitae, and the white of one egg, these beat very
well together, until they be brought unto the form of a Pultyse, which give
before the coming of the fytte, well an hour or two, and to it also add a
little Saffron. etc.

A Golden water, helping the Apoplexy, the Falling sickness, and infirmities
of the Synewes: take of the leaves and flowers of the Sage, two ounces, of
Nutmegges, of Cloves, of Gynger, of Cynamon, of Graynes of Paradize, of each
one ounce, of Castory one dram, of the rindes of the Citrone, three drams, of
Spykenard one dram, of the pure Oil of Bays, one dram, all these after the
dylligent beating, power into one measure of the best white wine, and the mouth
of the Glass body close sealed, let so stand to putryfie for four days,
after dystill with a soft fire, according to Art.

Another water not unlike to the former, procuring and mayntayning young age:
take of the leaves and flowers of Sage royal, three ounces, of Gynger, of
Cloves, of Nutmegges, and of the Graynes of Paradyze, of each half an ounce,
all these most finely brought to powder, power into two measures of the
strongest wine, close stopped in a Glass body for fourteen days, after set
on the head cloose Luted, and dystill with a soft fire according to Art, the
water gathered, keep close stopped in a Glass. This helps the inward cold
impostumes: for druncke with the agreeable water, incontinent breaks them. It
avails unto the Pin and web of the eyes, in clearing and putting them
aawy: it sharpneth also the sight, and cures the cold Ophthalmia, with a
Feather a little dropped into the eyes, does marueylouslye clear them. It
avails also both without and within, applied and druncke: it preuayleth
besides against bruses and strypes. It cures the Gowte, and pain of the
joints. And annoynting with it, helps the pain of the head, the Apoplexy,
the rewme, and any manner coldness of the brain: and druncke, avails against
the dropsy, helps the stomach, and avails against the cough with the
water agreeable. I believe that it does preserve young age, if a little of it be
druncke every day. It cures also any Scabbe, anointed with it, and the bytte
of a mad Dog, applied on the byt, and given to drink.

A water of Life, according to Aristotle's instruction: Take of Cynamon, of
Gynger, of Cloves, of Nutmegs, and of long Pepper, of each half an ounce, of
Dates half an ounce, of Cubebae, of Grains of Paradize, of Mace, of Almondes,
and of Galingale, of each half an ounce, of Sage twelve ounces: all these
broken and beaten to powder, infuse after in Malmesie, for eight days in a
Glass body, which then distyll with a soft fire according to Art.

Another water of Life: take of the root with the herb of the black
Ellebore prepared (whether in the Quince Apple) sour ounces, of the flowers of
the Orrendges, of the flowers of Stoechados, of the flowers of the Pome
Cytrone, and of the flowers of Horehounde, of each four handfulles, which
serves for the first distillation. For the second distyllation: take of chosen
Ruberbe half an ounce or one ounce, of the flowers of Borrage and Buglosse, of
each six handfulles, of great Reysons half a pound, of Mouse ear, of the
flowers of the Dasie, of the herb of the black Ellebore prepared, of each
two handfulles, of the flowers of the Cytrone or Baulme, six handfulles, of
the flowers or leaves of Angelica two handfulles, of the flowers of Organy,
eight handfuls, of Lycorys scraped half a pound, these after the brusing,
distyll according to Art. Also take of rectifyed wine unto the uttermost,
four measures, which power on the Spices, and let the whole infuse for eight
days, sturring it every day twyse or thryse: after distyll with a soft fire,
and on such wise let it be done, a second and third time. After of chosen
Honny clean skymmed, and of oil Olyue, of each half a measure, let these be
mixed with the wine distylled, and distilled together with a most soft fire,
for then takes it away the stincke in the wine, and sweetneth the wine, and
takes away the stincke and burning of the herbs. But if you will have it
better, let the wine be filled with the flowers of the Cytrone Stoechados, and
distylled again with a most soft fire. After take of this Aqua vitae two
measures, of white Sugar one pound, and thus corrected let it be most finelye
brought to powder, and set on the coals, ever sturring it about, until the
whole Sugar be dyssolued in it, and it shall be performed and done in.xxix.
days. After take of the best Cynamon, one pound, which bring to fine powder,
the same infuse for eight or ten days, sturring it once or twice every day,
after strain and wring the same hard in a press. If you be minded to have it
smell and taste pleasaunter, then add to it of Musk and Amber greese,
according to your discretion. For this lycour is of a maruaylous efficacy in
the decay and faynting of the heart: in myxing it with Electuaries, and
Cordial Medicines, as you know that understand practice.



An Aqua vitae, aromatyzated, of great virtue, serving unto all cold grieffes
of the stomach: the making of which is glorious and rare water, is on this
wise. Take of Nutmegges, of Cloves, of Galingale, of Cardamomum, of Cubebae, of
Mace, of Cynamon, of Gynger, of Saffron, and of Frankincense, of each one
ounce: these beaten in a gross manner, myxe dillygentlye together: after power
all these into a Glass body, very well fensed with lute, on which power six
pyntes of the finest Aqua vitae, the whole let stand together for six or
eight days, then dystyll the lycour, with his head and Receauer in Ashes, and
a red water will be gathered, which is very singular and precious: For this
(as above uttered) helps all grieffes of the body, proceeding of a cold
cause, and both cleanses and heals all wounds, without any grief, it
procures a good memory, helps the coughe, and puts away heaviness of
mind, and many other matters it works, as by trial may be known: this
borrowed out of the synguler practices, of the famous Greek Leonard Tiorauant.

A maruaylous water of Life, that avails in the Apoplexy and falling
sickness, druncke morning and Evening, but better if taken every morning. In
the Evening three or four drops taken with a slyce of bread, comfort
both the heart and Brain, and all the powers and virtues of the Brain and
body. It dries up all the humors above nature or not natural, and all other
superfluityes also, whether these proceed of a hot or cold cause, and
preserves natural heat in his temperament. Yet persons under thyrtye years
of age, may not often use or drink of the water, unless they be much
charged with many cold humors: but very apt and agreeable, to old and
cold persons.

The virtue of this water, can not sufficientlye be expressed, in that the same
avails both within, and without the body. Against the plague, let it be
taken the same day, with good Venice Triacle. Anointed within the
Nosethrelles, very much comfort. And is a singular Medycine against the
Apoplexy, and falling sickness: it is also the mother of all Medycines, for
it comfort the Matrice, and Womb at any time, if it runs to much, this
stays it, and like provoke it, if need be.

Take of Sage half a pound, of Wormwood two drams, of the flowers of Organy
six drams, of Bytony half an ounce, of Rosemary half an ounce, of Maioram
one ounce, of Penny royal two drams, of Roses one ounce and a half, of Hysope
two drams, of Sauorye two drams, of Parcelye one ounce and a half, of the
roots of Parcelie one ounce, of Polypodie, and of Pympernell, of each two
drams, of Lauender one ounce, of Tormentyll half an ounce, of Bistorta six
drams, of Valerian two drams, of Maisterwoort one dram, or a half, of Radicis
benedictae one ounce, of Ruta six drammes, of Juniper berries one ounce, of
Gynger one ounce and a half, of Nutmegges, and of Mace, of each half an
ounce, of Cloves six drams, of Cynamon six drams, of Cubebae, and of
Cardamomum, of each two drams, of Galingale half an ounce, of the Graynes of
Paradize one dram, of the long and black Pepper, of each two drams, of Saffron
one dram, of Calamus aromaticus half an ounce, of Zedoaria, of Corticis
baccarum lau^i, of each two drams, of Fay berryes half an ounce, of Coliander
half an ounce, of Annise and Lycorys, of each one ounce and a half, of
Triacle two drams, of manus Christi, and of Sugarcandy, of each half an
ounce, of Cummine, of Carrowayes, and of Dyttany, of each two drams, of
Ruberbe one dram, of Nigella, and rindes of the Orrendge, of each half an
ounce, of the conserve of Roses, one ounce, of Psydia two drams or three, of
Honny half a pound, lastly add of Musk the sixteen part of a dram, of
Amber greese so much, of Camphora half a dram, of white Sugar one ounce, of
the sublymed wine, five times of wine, and not of the Feces three measures. The
herbs and roots beaten in a gross manner, power into an earthen Judge well
stopped for three days, and in the fourth day, let the whole be sublymed.
After let the Spyces be beaten and not searced, which power in: and let stand
to infuse for ten days, in the Judge close stopped, and once or twyse a day
stir the whole about. Then let the whole be sublymed in a Glass body with a
narrow neck, and Receauer artlye fastoned to it, and when it shall distyll
white forth, or styncke, then is it sufficient. And then pour into it these
four, as the Musk, the Amber, the Camphora, and Sugar broken: but the other
three not broken, which let stand together for three or four days, sturring
it every day once or twyse, from the bottom, with a wooden spattell: let
these then stand for other three or four days, until the whole be settled,
and that it appear clear, which being clear, power forth, in strayning the
same through a fine Lynnen cloth into a Glass. But in the end when the lycour
wareth troubled, myxe together again* and let it setle again, then strain
again, as before, and continue the like doing, until you have purchased all
that which is clear, which myxe altogyther, in keeping it in a tynne Bottell,
for that the Glass destroys it, and let it be kept in no hot place, and the
virtue of it endures for two or three years, or a longer time. When you will
use or give of it, pour forth a little of it apart, in stopping again the
^est. The remnaunt or that resting, you may dry on a cloth in the shadow, and
on the whole then power two measures of clear and good wine, close stopped in
an earthen Judge for ten days, after distyll according to Art, and the
sublymed wine keep in a vessel close stopped, and it shall be a noble water,
although not so mighty, as the first water: for this avails anointed
without, or applied on places with a Lynnen cloth wette on it, in many
infirmityes and grieffes. At the first a strong fire ought to be made of
coals, until it become so hot, that you cannot suffer your finger upon it,
then draw away and abate the fire, and so proceed with a soft fire, that if
you touch it, you may be able to suffer the finger upon: and yet let not the
fire be over soft, nor over strong in heat, least the substance may be dried
in the pot. Many times also a drop falling prove with the finger, for on
such wise shall you redilye perceive, when his faculty and strength is feebled
or lessened, or that his savor be changed odious or stinking: for if it be
felt on such wise, then change the Receauer, as is before taught.

A sublymed wine of D. Ambrosius lung, described for a Noble person: Take of
the inner part of the Cynamon three ounces, of Gynger, of Cloves, of each one
ounce, of the red Saunders, two ounces, of Mace, of Nutmegges, of black
Pepper, of Galingale, of Cubebae, of Cardamomum, of Annise, of Fennel, of
Coriander prepared, of Speticrum aromatici Rosati, of Drambrae, of Dianthos, of
Maioram, of Basil, of Laue^der flowers, of Rosemary flowers, and of Spyknarde,
of each half an ounce: all these beat in a gross manner, to which then add
of red Roses two handfuls and a half, of good Malmesie four pyntes or two, of
sublimed wine. xi. or. vj. pyntes of Rosewater Musked, one pynt and a half, of
the water of Cloves and of Cinnamon (that is of the water) of each two ounces,
of Sugarcandye brought to powder, three pounds: let all these stand to infuse,
for four days. After let a decoction be made according to Art, and claryfied

A water of Life, being a great secret of Master Edwardes: Take of Cynamon,

A water of Life, helping joint aches, and synewes drawn together, and the

of Paradize two drams, of long pepper two drams, of Nutmegs, of Ginger, of
