days, which after distyl in Balneo Mariae according to Art.

A water serving unto many hard infirmyties and disseases: For this water
cures the Canker, the Fistula, Sinus, Morbum attonicum, the falling sickness,
the ryng woorme, the Serpigo, the joint sickness, the Gout, and any pain of
the synewes, whether the same shall proceed of hot cause, or cold: the making
of which, is on this wise: Take of burning water, fine and pure, ten or
fifteen pyntes, of Ina one handful, of Sagapeni half an ounce, of Cubebae,
one ounce and a half, of Xyloaloes, two drams, of chosen Myrre half a dram,
of Aloes hepanticke half an ounce, of Aristolochia, of Ammoniaci, of
Opopanacis, of chosen Cadanum, of each half an ounce, of Sarcocollae half a
dram, of Frankincense, three ounces, of Masticke half an ounce, of Gum
Arabicke so much, of the red Saunders two drams, of Spyknard, one ounce, of
Galingale half an ounce, of Saffro^ two drams, of Mumia half an ounce, of Gum
Elemi three ounces, of Galbanum half a dram, of Storax, and of Cloves, of
each one dram, of Nutmegs half an ounce, of chosen Cinnamon half an ounce, of
Grains of Paradize, or of Amomum half an ounce, of Resina liquidae five
pounds, of Turpentyne thee pounds, of Dragons blood, and of Castorie, of
each half an ounce, of these let a lycour be dystylled according to Art.
This borrowed out of Fumanellus.

A syngular water for the preserving of youth, and staying back of old age:
the making of which, is on this wise. Take of Ligni aloes, of Cloves, of
Gynger, of Galingale, of Cynamon, of Mace, of Nutmegs, of long Pepper, of
Calamus aromaticus, of Cubebae, of Rubarbe, of the graynes of Paradize, of
Cardamomum, of each two drams, of Rosemary, of Celondine, of Mercury, of the
blessed Thystle, of Imperatoria, and of the white Dittany, of each one ounce,
all these after the beatyng infuse in six pyntes of the best Aqua vitae (that
serves for the Quintessence) which let so remain for eight days, after
distyll the lycour in Balneo Mariae according to Art. Of that water gathered,
add to each pynte, two ounces of fine Sugar dyssolued in Rosewater, and eight
graynes of Musk, which dillegentlye keep in a Glass close stopped. This
syngular water druncke every morning, unto the quantitye of one or two drammes
at a time, preserves the person a long time in health and perfyte strength:
in that the same heateth the stomach being cold, increases natural heat,
and causes good digestion of meat, through which, nature is preserved long
lustye and young. This also heateth the blood in the Veins, in such manner,
that the same causes it to run, and work his effects without impedyment.
It dries up cold and moist humors, which hinder the working of nature, and
worcketh many other helps. This borrowed out of the singular practices, of the
Greek Leonar. Tiorauant.

A water not to be mysliked, yielding and working many matters: for this
helps the Gout, joint sicknesses, the dystillation of the head, preserves
young age, and strength: gives also wit and memory, reuyueth the spyrites,
and causes them purer. The making of which is on this wise: take of burning
water, three or four times distylled over, four pyntes, of Rosemarye flowers
one pound, of the tops of the branches of the same, half a pound: these
stiepe together for a day, and draw in a double vessel, with a long necked
Receauer, the nether part of it resting in a cold place. For we so name it,
says Galen, when in a Pan or Kettyl, which contains the hot water, another
vessel stands. Of this water thus distylled by a Lymbecke, take half a
pynte, of Nutmegges, of Galingale, of Cloves, of Cardamomum, of Mace, and of
Cubebae, of each three ounces, of white Aumber, one ounce and a half, of Ligm
aloes so much, of Castorye, and of Spyknarde, of each two drams, these beaten
several and apart, and compounded after altogyther, until they be come unto a
certain thycknesse, and then distylled again together, keep to your use. For
an ounce of the above said water, druncke with a slyce of white bread,
avails so much, as a Baulme: This Fumanellus, as the Aucthour supposes.

Of the Iuyces or drawing of Iuyces, out of Symples and compound matters.
The.jx. Chapter.
IVyce, which of the Greeks is properly named (...) and the working of the
same, termed, (...), is that which is pressed or wringed out of simple or
compounde matters bruised, chopped, or stieped. But Iuyces are otherwise pressed
out, as either out of the leaves or branches of the herbs, beaten alone, and
that green and full of juice, or out of fruytes, as out of Grapes, not ripe or
green, Pomegranates, Services, Medlars, wyld Sl^es, Quinces, Lemons, etc. Or
out of herbs having little moisture, and the same clammye, as the Iuie, the
Purselan, Cotylidone, the Houselyke, etc. Out of which not simply a juice, can
be had or gotten, but through water poured upon, or other lycour, like to the
properties of them, that need wringing or pressing out, that pressed out
together with the same humor, the force and virtue of the simple herb may
so be purchased: or if bruised and put into a strayner or Bag, and hanged in a
cold Seller or place, that the juice by little and little, may drop into a
dyshe or Porrendger set under. Of these, and such like drawings forth of
iuyces, which in shoppes, in a vessel with a narrow mouth, oil being poured
upon finger high, or sprinkled with Salt, as appears of the juice of
vnripened fruits, unto Physic use, set up and kept, we mean here to entreat
nothing thereof: nor the like of certain others, which in the Sun, by a daily
moving, are dried and thyckned, and that in the shadow, as the juice of Sloes:
in an Oven or Furnace, or other hot place* included and hanged to dry. But we
will only entreat of those iuyces, which are described out of roots, and the
dryer herbs, or such having but very little moisture, stieped for certain
days in water, or any other lycour, distylled after by Balneum Mariae, that
separated from the watery moisture, that substance of the matter infused, pure
and sincere may be left somewhat grosser: or without distyllation, by boiling
only converted into a vapor having a strange humor, the substance of the
matter infused may thicken, strayned before, or the whole water distylled by
Fyltre, etc. And the use of this drawing forth, or substance purchased* which
of the juice taken in a small quantity, yields great commodities in our
bodies. For where of Medicines in the whole substance, is want to be given one
ounce: of the juice drawn, suffices only one dram: in which undoubtedly
may the sick be much delighted and pleased, especially seeing many are wont
much to abhor the taking of Medicines.

And this is to be noted, in the drawinges* that if the spirit shall not be
sufficient pure, or dilligently separated, insomuch that somewhat of the
earthinesse yet remains, and may contain, that then the virtue or propertye
of the matter drawn is myxed to this earthynesse, and ascends and
euaporateth together. But the sincere and pure spirit, does cause this least,
in that out of the matter drawn, this descends without any savor or taste:
and for that cause is the spyrit easily separated by Balneum Mariae, whose
heat exeedeth not the degree of heat, which consists or is in man's vryne.
Yet it behooves also that the wate, by which the washing is caused, be very
subtle, even like as the spyrit of the wine, least the evil quality of the
water may ascend together. But a sure trial and knowledge of the water is, if
it shall be without taste or savor.

The drawing of herbs, and other remedies, with burning water, perfytelie
distylled in Balneo Mariae, etc. As out of Rubarbe Agaricke, Ellebore, and
Guaicum, according to Theophrastus instruction. The.x. Chapter.
THe artificial drawing of simple matters, are wrought after this manner:
First let purest and best Aqua vitae be chosen, which is sufficient effectuous
unto the drawing forth and purchasing the properties of the herbs. Then take
Sage, or any like simple, out of the which you determine to draw a juice, the
same lay in a dry air, toward the North especially. Where after it shall be
a little dried, shred or choppe finely, and power the whole into a Glass,
whose mouth shall be sufficient wide, that is, two fyngers broad, that when you
will, you may easily get or draw forth whatsoever is put in, on which power
the Aqua vitae, or spirit of the wine, well the little finger breadth above the
herb. After cover the vessel dilligently, in this manner: let paste be made,
with which let the mouth be a finger breadth stopped round about, next to which
bind upon a fair white Paper, and let it be so stopped, that it may only
stick to the sides about the mouth of the Glass. This Paper thus set on, let
paste again be laid on round about the place, above taught, and another new
Paper again bound upon the same. Then a third time lay paste upon, and round
about the sides of the mouth, and let a third Paper be fastened, which
covers fullye over, that the mouth through the paste and Paper may closely
be stopped. After cover the whole with ware, although this be not so
ne^defull. These thus orderly handled and done, let the vessel after be set
for two or three days in a hot place: according as the herb put in, shall
be of a thycker or thinner substance, and shall so need to stiepe a longer or
shorter time. At the end of which time, power the spirit into another vessel,
and cover it again: and the herbs remaining, press or wring through a
Lynnen cloth, so strongly as is possible, (or that you can do by your
strength) and after the wrynging, throw them away. Then power other fresh
herbs again of the same kind, and prepared as above taught, power into the
same spyrit, which stiepe, and press forth, and the same repeat three or
four times over, even as you will purchase the drafte mighty or weak. That
if the matter, out of the which a juice shall be drawn* shall be of great
price, as is the Rubarbe, and Lignum aloes: then not once pouring of Aqua vitae
on it is sufficient, but diverse and often times* that whatsoever of the spirit
or property of the simple shall be, may wholly be left in the water. Now
after the spirit of the wine, shall abound in the faculty of the herbs, in so
much that it shall in a manner have lost the proper taste or savor, then press
or wring forth the herbs, and the same which shall be pressed forth,
dylligentlie and subtyllie distyl by Fylter, and use when need shall require.
Or the spirit of the wine from the property of the herbs, shall be easyer
separated by distyllation in Balneo Mariae, in drawing forth either the half,
or all together, until it shall come unto an extreme waterynesse, or until
it be thyckened as a Sauce, or the juice dried and hardened, which may be
brought to powder, according as you will apply and use the same. For when much
moisture shall be, in the drawing forth, then after the separation of the
wine, is it a noate or token, that the spirit of the wine was not sincere and
pure. But where the spyrit of the wine shall be sufficient mighty, and that in
the end of the distyllation, no waterynesse remains and insueth, then take
the distylled water of the same simple, and pour to that drawn, and myxe
dylligentlye together with a quyll or Feather, that the spirit yet remaining or
left behind in the matter, may be myxed together with the water poured forth:
then draw again by Lymbecke, the water poured forth, and the same may you so
often repeat, until no spirit of the wine be fealt or perceived in the
drawing, the which like may thus be known or proved. When no wine mixture of
the spirit is dystilled together with the water, but a pure water only, then
may you judge and perceive, that the same to be sufficient.

But I do counsel (says the Aucthour) and the same also is of use and
practice, that to the draft or substance of the herbs, let the proper water be
poured* yet before distylled apart, even as I have above uttered in the drawing
of the Sage. And in the same manner may the spirits of the wine be gotten, as
by pouring the water of the Sage distylled in the end, and very well mixed
together, and separated again. And such a drawing forth is excellent, and is
preserved many years.

An order and way by which the juice, of each herb, may be obtained: as in
the distylled water of any herb, power the dry herb powdered, which infuse
in hot water for a time, but boil it nothing at all. After strain the same,
then into the strayning power again the dry herb of the same kind in
powder, and like infused, strain again, which often repeat, and in the end
distyl it in Balneo Mariae, that the thynner part may be dissolved into a
vapor, and that which shall after remain in the bottom, will be so thick as
Honny, and juice of the herb: and in the Receauer is only gathered, the water
of the herb: Or thus.

Of the herb whose lycour you would distyl press out the juice, and the
remnaunt of the expression distilled together with ye juice, the lycor shall be
ye effectuousser and clearer as I hear, says D. Gesnerus.

A very comely manner, and nothing so laborious or painful, by which the true
substance, or Quintessence, and the water also may easilye be drawn, out of
any Simple, or herb, or root: and this manner also shall serve and be ayte,
for diverse fruits, as that the iuyces presed out and putrified.

Take the root or herb gathered in the aptest time, and dried in the shadow
or air, and the same in a clean vessel, poured in upon the proper water
drawn otherwise by distyllatio^, which infuse so long together untyl ye water
has purchased the color of the infused matter, the^ separate the water into
another vessel apart, which keep close stopped. And to the root or herb
pour ye other water distylled, and let them stand again covered, unto the
chau^ging of the color of the water, the^ (...) (above taught) separate the
water* and myxe it with the first, which so often repeat, until no more will
issue forth, and that the root or herb, obtains no more strength at all.
Which done, the waters gathered in a Cucurbite, distyll in Balneo Mariae, with
the head and Receauer set to after Art, that all the water may ascend and be
gathered, and the matter or substance be engrossed as paste, or a Pultyse. Which
when it shall so come unto, draw forth the gross matter left in the bottom
of the Cucurbite, and when you have poured it into Basen or other clean
vessel, stir the whole about with a most easy and gentle heat: as nygh to a
Furnace, or on hot ymbers, that ye superfluous moisture may by little and little
within certain days euaporate forth, and the same matter attain the
styfnesse of an Electuary, or else of Honny: then have you purchased the best
and most precious substance of the matter drawn, or the Quintessence, with
which, even with a most small quantity, you shall do more, then with great
quantityes of the roots or herbs. And let this be kept in a Silver, or
Tynnie vessel close stopped, which the older it shall be before the occupying,
the better will it be to use. And further note, that the water drawn by
distyllation, no less avails, then the other waters distylled of the herbs
or roots.



Another manner, of drawing forth of substaunces: Take any dry root, as the
root of Petasitis, the same brought to fine powder, and put into a Cucurbite,
pour upon a sufficient quantity of wine: the Cucurbite dilligentlie luted,
set into Balneo Mariae, and let the wine be drawn forth. When out of this wine
you shall have drawn a cup mean full, and that the matter which is in the
Cucurbyte, shall be cooled, power then the same water or wine which you have
drawn forth, and distyll it again in Balneo Mariae, and the same repeat or
do three times over, if need shall be, or oftener, until all the property
through the decoction shall consist in the wine. This being done, wring the
substance gently with the hands, and that pressed forth dylligentlye keep.
For this is so precious as Gold: and where you will, the substance in the
glass may be set in the Sun, that the wine may euaporate, and an oylinesse
only remain in the bottom.

Another manner of drawing forth, very singular, of an uncertain Aucthour:
Take your Quintessence, in which infuse your proper simple, or compound for
fourteen hours, grosely brought to powder, and set rather in a cold place,
then hot to infuse: and the proper Quintessence shall draw to it, the fixed
spirit of your matter, and be like in property to it: and when you shall see
the Quintessence colored, of the matter infused, separate then the same
artificially by an instrument, which dylligentlye keep in a Glass, close
stopped with wax.

Take again your proper Quintessence simple, and pour it upon your matter
before infused (which is now separated, by the instrument) and let it remain
again to infuse, for *xxii^* hours, in a cold place: after it be colored
again, separate the Quintessence again by an instrument, from the substance
infused (as you know) and that separated, add to the former Quintessence
colored.

And pour upon the simple essence of al your substance infused* and separate
the same so often* until your substance infused will yield no more color, or
color the Quintessence no more.

Take your Quintessence gathered, which pour into a long necked Cucurbite,
setting upon his Lymbecke or head, and luted accorcording to Art, set into
Balneum Mariae, after distyll the Quintessence with a soft fire, until you
shall see it come unto the styfnesse of Pappe in the bottom of the Cucurbite,
and shall have in the bottom of the substance infused, the spirit remaining
fixed, which gather artificially into a Silver vessel.

A most singular, and the profitablest manner of drawing iuyces out of herbs.
Take green Sage, and draw a water out of the same by distyllation: or let the
dried Sage be taken, on which power the water, that from it the subtyller part
may be separated, but the grosser Sauge infused, stiepe for certain days,
which after distyll according to Art. In this distylled water, stiepe again
the dried Sauge, in such manner, that the water may cover the Sauge, well two
or three fyngers above: and let the whole stand close stopped in a Judge or
pot, that it may breathe very little out, in water temperatelye hot. After
let the Sauge be pressed forth, and the Sauge like dried, as above uttered,
stiepe again in this water, and the same repeat three or four times. Which
done, let the water be separated, which unto another drawing may aptlye serve,
or unto other uses. And the same drawn, euaporate in an earthen vessel, and
that in a Furnace, or some other hot place, until it come unto such a
styfnesse, which best lyketh the practisioner.

When you will purchase the true substannce, out of the Rubarbe, the Ellebore,
the Agaricke, the woodde of the Ash, and other symples of like kind: then
proceed in the like order, as above uttered. As first, power upon the spyrit,
which infuse so long until it be very deep colored, then power the same
forth, strain it, and the spirit by little and little separate in Balneo: and
this power again to the abouesayde Rubarbe, which infuse for a certain space
in a hot place, until it purchases color, or be colored, then strain the
same, and separate again by distyllation in Balneo* which so often repeat,
until the spyrit through the Rubarbe be colored no more. The same then press
or wring out stronglye, and distyll by Fylter, for it has or purchases after
a certain qualytie of the tenacitye or clamminesse of the Rubarbe, which in
the drawing forth is unprofitable, yet many profitable parts of it issue
together, which are not to be neglected: and for that cause ought after this
manner, to dystyll by Fylter.

By the beak or nose of the Lymbecke, with a thread draw the Fyltre of a
finger breadth cut, so high up, that for the strayghtnes of the Nose, the
Fyltre will no further follow: yet taking heed that in the strong drawing,
you break not the Glass: which done, power the spirit to be filtered into the
Lymbecke stopped with wet Paper. The spyrit distylled by Fylter, to the
drawing, which was before separated, power again into the Glass (seeing much
cleaves to the Glass, for that cause into the first Glass, into which the
spyrit was infused, all the spyrites of the Rubarbe are to be strayned, and
unto the separation poured) not caring or regarding, that the one drafte, even
now before may be found in the Glass, for all the draftes are necessary to be
joined, and unto the end of the water distylled mixed together, and separated
again, until the water be clear drawn forth. And the draft may be done,
either in a dry manner, or in a moist form, even as it shall please any
practisioner.

Out of the wood of the Ash, is a draft gotten with easy labor, for the
spyrit once powered upon, and the wood stieped in it for four days, after the
lycour powered forth, and other fresh wood put into it as before, and the same
repeated and done for two or three times, according as you desire a great or
little yield of the draft: after let the lycour be cleared by Fyltre, but
separated by distyllation.

The extraction or drawing forth of Turbith, of Agaricke, or of any other
purging Medicine: take any of the Purgatiues, as the Turbith or Agaricke, or
any other with his correctiue: the same thus brought to powder, put up into a
bag of fine Lynnen cloth, or white Taffatie, and put either bag, into the
same part of the Lymbeck, which sends forth the conieled vapors by the
Nose: but into the bottom of the Cucurbite pour on Aqua vitae rectifyed,
which contains or has no flewme in it, which distyll by the same; which in
the bags included, are placed in the Lymbecke, and on such wise is all the
property of the Purgative drawn forth. Which done, wash dillygentlye and
purelie the body, and the water drawn power again into the body, into whose
mouth put a Sponge, and the head set on, distyll the Aqua vitae through a
Sponge, and in the bottom will a certain thick matter like to Honny remain,
which ^^ the true substance, and drawing of the matter stieped.

Of the Agaricke, the Turbith, the Colocynthis, the Rubarbe, the Berberis, the
Sumach, the flowers of Pomegranates, and others either laxatyue, or
restrictyue, or sweet smelling. Take of Agaricke (or of any Medycine) the same
a^^lye bring to powder: which power into a Glass body set in Balneo, and
power upon burning water, after the sealing, let it stand for a natural day,
to dyssolue, then draw it, by strayning through a Lynnen cloth, without
wrynging hard. After power it again into a vessel with so much water, as
before, and let it be cyrculated for xxiiij. hours in Balneo, and then
strayned. These strayninges gathered, power into a large vessel, which artlie
draw with a head and Receauer annexed, (the water if you will, keep
dylligentlye, which will serve to other uses,) and when it shall come unto a
thycknesse of Honny, or styfnesse, draw the same forth, and make Trochises or
flat balls of it after Art, which use according to skyll.

^ The drawing of Rubarbe: take of chosen Rubarbe four drams, the same brought
to powder, power into the waters agreeable, which let stand to infuse for a
day and a night, and then stronglye pressed or wringed out. Unto the
substance pressed forth add Sugarcandie, so much as you shall think
needful, and lyghtlie in the euaporating in Sand, dry it, unto the
thickness of an electuarye.

Or on such wise: the infusion of Rubarbe, is commodiouslye wrought, in the
iuyces of Borrage and Buglosse. After the infusion for a whole day in a double
vessel, let it be boiled unto the consumption of a third part away, and then
pressed or wringed forth. The juice pressed forth, and myxed with Sugarcandie*
boil unto an even styfnesse. For so may it be preserved and kept, many years.
The Feces or grounds after the pressing forth, are not to be thrown away:
in that there consists a great use of these, in bynding of the bellye,
especially in the perilous scouring Dysenteria. But the proper iuyse does
very gently louse the belly, yea in Infantes without harm.

The extraction or drawing forth of Rubarbe, which the learned D. Gesnerus
purchased of a singular Physician: the Rubarbe may in the same manner be
infused, as the roots of the black Ellebore, which hereafter shall be uttered
and taught: but in the water of Cynamon, and with the syrup of Roses solutiue,
ought the juice of Rubarbe be gotten and made.

Agaricke in the affect^s or grieffes of the head, and the Rewme, wo^^keth
better, if with the infusion and decoction it be prepared, than if drawn, and
the same may also be hardly drawn. But if you will thoroughly draw a juice
out of it, then do the same with the oil of Annise seeds in conduite water,
or with the water of Annise seeds, the oil clean taken of.

The drawing of the black Ellebore, described of a Phisitio^ of Caesaria^* let
the rindes of the root of the black Ellebore, the pythes taken forth, be
infused in ye water of Annise seeds, from which ye oil is newly separated,
and let the same rest to infuse for.xxiiij. hours, or as long as you will,
after boil ye whole together, until the roots remain, and that the water in
a manner be consumed, which after by a mighty strength wring forth. In ye end
boil the same pressed forth, with ye syrup of Roses solutiue, unto a
sufficient thickness, which put up in an earthe^ vessel glased, and use when
need requires. The dose or quantity at a time, is from one scruple, unto a
scruple and a half: and this purges the Melancholy humor, without grief or
harm. This infusio^ also, very much pleased D. Mo^tanus, for he reported ye
Hypocrates always in ye giving or ministering of ye black Ellebore, accustomed
to take and use also Annise, as a special correctour of it.

Another extraction or drawing forth of the black Ellebore, described of
Doctor Hieronymi Heroldy: take of the juice of Borrage and of Buglosse, of
each two pounds, which strain and purifye that they may be clear, to these
after add of Fennel roots, of Succorie, of Sperage, and of Parcelie, of each
four ounces of the fruits of Sebesten, and of Iniubarum, of each two ounces,
of the lesser cold seeds, of each half an ounce, let these be boiled in.xvi.
pints of water, unto a third part consumed, to the strayning add ye abouesayd
iuyces, which boil on a little fire: then join of the roots of the true
black Ellebore* four pounds, which so long boil, until the roots appear
as uncovered, the whole then strongly wring, and boil after with a soft fire,
unto the thickness of Honny.

A solutyue extraction or drawing forth, invented of D.D. Magenbuch: Take of
Colocynthis six drams, and two scruples, of Agaricke half an ounce, of
Rubarbe two drams, of chosen Cynamon four scruples, of Azari, of Spykenard, of
red Roses, of Masticke, and of Ligni aloes, of each one dram, of lyquide
Storax four scruples, of good Mal^^es^e one measure: of the whole, let an
infusion, and an extraction or distyllation be caused, like a Quintessence.

Another solutyue extraction or drawing forth, invented of the same Doctor,
whose dose or qua^titye is from one scruple unto half a dram, to a mane from
half a dram, unto two scruples or a whole dram: take of the Pulpe of
Colocinthis six drams, and two scruples, of white Turbith and gummie ten
drams, of Stoechados arabic, half an ounce, of Diagridium three drams
(otherwise six drams) of white Agaricke half an ounce, of chosen Rubarbe
three drams, of the inner part of the Cynamo^ five scruples, of the root of
Azari, of Spykenard, of red Roses, of Masticke, and of Lignum aloes, of each
four scruples, of Aloes hepatick one ounce and a half, and two drams, of
lyquide Storax two scruples, and three grains: these chopped and beaten,
infuse for a time in sublimed wine, which rectifye, and make an Electuarie of
the same according to art.

The description of another Electuarie, in a manner like to the ^ormer, which at
Norimberge is reported to be drawn, and the same after this manner was
prepared: take of Colocynthis one ounce and five drams, of black Ellebore, and
of the Cast Senee, of each half an ounce, of the whytest Agaricke one ounce,
of ye best Raned half an ounce, otherwise of his top one ounce, with ye Rubarb
not so excellent, and of Diagridij one ounce and.vi. dra^s, of Cynamon two
drams, and two scruples, of Turbith, and of Stoechados arabicke, of each two
ounces, and a half, of red Roses, of Ligni aloes of Mastick of Ligni paradisi,
of Myrre, of Mader, of Azori, of Spyknarde, and of lyquide Storax, of each five
scruples: let an infusio^ or putrifactio^ be made of all these for certain
days, as either.x. xij. or.xiiij. days, with the essence of wine, that is,
the Aqua vitae thrice distylled over, hot, and the juice after pressed forth,
joined or mixed with Aloes prepared, three ounces. But the Aloes, was in this
manner prepared: it was finely shred or cut, and the Aloes unto the quantity of
a pound, either more or less* was put into a Basin, or pan, or pot, to which
added of Rosevineger, and of Rosewater, of each* so much as shall suffice, yet
let there be more of the Rosevyneger, then of the Rosewater. And let these
boil together with a soft fire, for two or three boylinges, after strain it
by stronglye wrynging forth. The substance strayned boil again with soft
fire unto the styfnesse of Aloes, continuallye sturring it about with a spatle.
And when it shall be through cold, let it be kept to use. The Spyces above
named, shred before finelye, then beaten, and Aqua vitae after powered on these
(thryse distylled over) so much as shall suffice, sturring the same often every
day: after wring the whole through a Lynnen cloth, gross or course, and that
stronglye, then let the waterye moisture be drawn in a Lymbecke with an easy,
fire made under, until the same, which remains in the bottom, comes unto
the styfnesse of the confection named Diacyton^tes. That if in the same, shall
yet a certain moisture remain* then let it be set in some apt vessel on
burning coals, so long as shall seem needful: that the same moisture may
through the heat ^e wasted, and euaporate away.

Aiuyre drawn out of the Iunyper berryes, may be preserved and kept for
twelve years, if it be ryghtlie wrought. Which avails unto the preservation
of the stone, and the use of it has been experienced in many persons, which
of late days (before the publyshing of this book) were greeuouslye payned and
vexed, and many sharp and persing Medicines were applied, and yet none of them
so much auayled, nor the like helped, as by this. For this is a hot Medicine,
and for that cause may perhaps heat overmuch the Kydneys, as a certain
learned supposed: yet through the manner of preparing which is supposed to abate
and qualifye the heat somewhat, may in this avail greatly. This also either
dygesteth, or consumes, or casts forth the flewme in the stomach, and both
cleanses and strengthens the stomach. The use of it serves not so well unto
the defending and preserving from sycknesses, as unto the curing of grieffes.
It besides helps any kind of dystyllations and Rewmes, the gyddinesse or
swymming of the head, the blearedness of the eyes, the horseness of voice,
strayghtnesse of the breast, the coughe, the chollicke, the suffocation of the
Matrice, the staying back of the Terms, the sounding, the stone, and the
Pestilence. Yea these sicknesses* also are numbered of others, which this juice
is reported to cure, as the Frepesy or madness, the dropsy, styncke of the
mouth, the fal^lyng falyng sycknesse, the tremblyng of members, and inward
impostumes. The head and heart are marueylouslye relieved, and refreshed with
this juice, and preserves health many years. It must in discreet order be
taken with a fasting stomach three parts of the year, as in the Harvest, the
Winter, and the Spring, but in the Summer through the heat and dryness,
reserved to necessity. That if the air or season yet shall be moist, and the
heat temperate, you may then use it in the Summer. In the curing of disseases,
it may be applied at any time and often, yet by certain distaunces, and other
apt times between aunswering and agreeing with the same. Many there be which
name it the German Triacle, both for that it is effectuous against poisons,
and that friendlyest* yea especially healthful to German bodies.

The simple juice of the Quince Apples, and without any mixion, may be prepared
in a manner in the same form and order: which of it self is most singular, and
may be reserved or kept a very long time, and becomes also better and
sweeter, in a manner every day after the making.

Of Xylobeuo, of Theophrastus, of Hohenheim: First we purchase three kinds of
Medycines, as a Lycour, Gum, and Alkali. The lycour which yssueth, is like to
the juice of Acacia: the Gum, to that which is named Albotim: Alkali, to the
salt Geme. The lycour, is the proper or very drink it self, the Gum, only
the ointment: the Alkali, purging and mundifying. After the lycour by the
included distyllation, is as the Oil drawn forth: an ounce or four ounces of
which, are effectuousser and of greater value then a whole Talent, which
according to the boiling common of the Physicians yssueth forth of the wood. In
the second manner, the Gum succeeds the lycour, as out of the same wood,
which is remaining, after this manner. Put the Xyloebenum into the inclusiue
reuerberation, in the second degree of fire, and you shall at the end
of.xxiiij. hours see by and by after the Gum come, which in the same tenacitye
or clamminesse with the lyquyde Storax, is separated from the body, and unto
the same through the marvelous sweet savor (resembled) yet whiles each in
the mean whiles consist or rest in the heart, the body and Gum may be
molten, of which one pound, and six ounces, be effectuousser, then two
hundred pounds, which in the boiling are drawn. Last* the Alkali is drawn
after this manner: The body is changed or altered into the uttermost
substance, which is as the spring and original of Alkali, and mixing the
water of Fumyniter with it, is very well courded, even like Anation or Entali,
whose value of one pound and five ounces, is accoumpted worthyer then fifty
pounds, which are by the common way prepared.

For the use, in the beginning, purge the sick person after this manner: Take
of Alkali Xyloebeni half a scruple, of the Triacle of Alexandria two drams,
these myxe together, the dose or quantitye is half a scruple. And the self
same not a first and second time, but a third or fowrth time, and this acording
to the manner of the sickness. Further such a virtue of purging, especially
those payned and dysseased with the Gout, the Palsy, and pustulous humors,
has this Alkali: as the like neither in the laxatiues, purgatiues, and
expulsyues is to be found. And the Chyrurgicall way and form of curing, may
always follow and use this purgation, after this manner. In the beginning
whatsoever is open, aptly with the pure Alkali, after annoint the gum twyse
in the day, and the same use so often and so long, until each are restored
to a sound skymme. That if nothing be apparent, that you can evidently see:
there anoint and use the Gum, where ye pain lur^keth or seems to lie hid.
After this manner may you help, the Gowte, the Palsy, yea and the French
dissease. And wheresoever you shall apply and use it otherwise, then here
prescribed and taught you by us: you shall with the Emperickes, not without a
great expense and damage, lose both toil and travail.

The manner of government and diet: I will not that you prescribe (says he) in
this place the proper manner of diet, but that you cherishe the sick, as it
behooves, with good wine, and meats aptlye prepared. For the order of curing
of the foresaid disseases, consists not in the manner of diet, but in the
efficacy of the remedies, as may appear. Wherefore no cause there is, that by
strayte diet, you appoint here spare meals to the pacient. For this exceeds
all, and not the common virtue of this medicine.

Of the drawing forth of a true substance out of the Myrre, the Aloes, or
other like tears fattie, out of which truly can no perfect extraction or
drawing be* caused, but only in the resolution and dystillation which is done
by Fyltre, that may be putrifyed. As for example, take of Aloes what quantitye
you will, which stiepe certain hours, in a hot place, in some distylled
water agreeable, or in dew water, until the same water be colored, then let
this water be separated, and new poured upon, which water after it has
received color of the infusion, power the same forth, and this so often do
and repeat, until the water will no more be colored or receive color. Then
all these waters ought to be distylled by Fyltre, and when the water ^y
distyllation shall be separated, a substance will after remain, which you
seek. Such manner of drawinges are coni^aled through cold, but dissolved by
heat: and they are ministered and even in the same wayght and quantity, as the
substance out of which they be drawn, which like is not caused and done in
other drawinges, in that the draft is much mightyer, then the same substance
out of which it is drawn.

Of the made Saltes, and oil of Saltes. The.xj. Chapter*
OF the Saltes also of which are burned out of the simples, the use of them in
Physic is in a ma^er so great, as is the wine or common Salt, which daily and
in general serves to man's relief. For when from simples a gross flewme is
gotten, which for truth hyndered, how much less would they perform their
working, that they might be converted into a spiritual matter, which in the
long distillation, and Fyltring is caused, that they may change by a certain
manner into a fyrie matter. Nor it is to be doubted, that when the symples be so
converted into a Salt, and the Element of fire has on such wise dominion in
them, but that they also sooner pearce, and may perform the proper action:
that such a heap or company of diverse symples, shall not need besides, in the
composition of remeedyes. But such Saltes have certain properties, by which
the other purgers distylled, are in a manner abated and troubled: For every
Salt, as affyrmeth Theophrastus, purges: but the distylled waters of the
purgers, lack or have not the same propertye, in that the Salt is not joined
or increased in them. So that I suppose, a great tartnes or sharpnes consists
in all, which do change the vryne.

But the way and manner, by which such Saltes are prepared, is diverse and
sundry wise prescribed and taught of Aucthours. For some will on this wise
these to be made, as that the simple be gathered in a due time, from which let
his proper water be drawn by Balneu^ Mariae, and the Feces remaining in the
bottom, calcyne in the Furnace of reuerberation: the proper water Fyltre many
times over: the water Fyltred from the grosser matter, pour into a basin,
which set in the Sun, or on hot ashes, that the waterinesse may so breath
forth, and the Salt remain. This like may be wrought and done, of all the
symples.

Another manner of drawing the Saltes out of herbs, or roots, or any other
matter, written in the German tongue. The herbs or roots prepared unto this
use* ought before to be dried, then burned in a pot unto an ashie whiteness.
When you shall have purchased a sufficient store of these Ashes, then power
them into a vessel, on which power the cold distylled water, or pure and
clear rain water, letting them so stand to infuse for certain days, in
moving and sturring the whole often about, after Fyltre the water, or let it
run through an Ippocrasse bag, and on the former Ashes pour new or fresh
water, and the same so often (in the same order, as in the first time)
repeated, until the Ashes possess or have no more sharpness in them. Which
ended, all the waters gathered, and poured into a Cucurbite, euaporate in Ashes
or Sand, and a Salt in the end remains in the bottom, which dyllygentlie
^eepe, for it is precious.

It is to be enquired whether when this Salt shall be purchased, it were best to
burn the herbs not whollye, nor ^^daynlye, that a Lie may be made of the
Ashes: or unto the half burned, whereby a more virtue of the taste, and smell
may remain, and a lesser quantity of the yield: or at ye end whether any
Masticke may also be added, or any Gum, or any other matter, that being wrought
and made glutynous or glewishe, it may the better be preserved, and may also be
formed into Pylles: this D. Gesnerus.

Whether the Ashes may be boiled, as of the wormwood, with the water of the
same simple distylled, or with the juice of the herb puryfied and Fyltred: or
the same herb dried, which after the infusing boil together a whiles, then
strain the whole, for on such wise shall you purchase a better savor and
taste: dry Roses may in the like manner, be ordered and prepared. The same
Aucthour Ge. Here is to noted, that a certain person wylleth the drawing of
Saltes not to be done with hot water, but rather with colds. After the Ashes
drawn, a man may both burn, and calcyne them again, as above taught, and
draw a Salt out of them: and the same so often repeat over, until no more
taste of Salt be contained or remain in them. That if the Salt drawn, be not
white, then let it be reuerberated unto a whiteness: which three manner ways,
are dylligentlye to be noated.

In the preparing of Salts, this also is worthy to be noated, that the Saltes
be very well purged by Fyltre: which certain do Fyltre, well twente and
four times over.

These Saltes, which Theophrastus names or reports to be the true A^kalia,
ought to be kept in a Glass, that they be not molten with the Air, which
like happens especially to Saltes, that are drawn and made of herbs (and
those substaunces) which possess and have a more quantitye of Oil and the
sub^iller. The Salts (after a time) wax so hard as a stone: or those, which
be very well Fyltred, are so clear, that they may be seen through, even like
Crystal.

The Salt of Hypericon or S. John's woorte, certain affirm to be syngular and
hyghlie commended in the pleuresie. The dry plant of Hypericon, reduce or
bring to Ashes on the fire, the Ashes after pour^ into hot water, which boil
a time, and the earthlye parts will descend to the bottom. After let the
water in a Cucurbyte be euaporated or consumed away, in Balneo Mariae, and in
the bottom of it will the Salt remain, which dry very well: of which give to
the pacient in warm wine, so much as half a Hasyll nutte shell will hold or
receive. A certain singular Physician in the pleures^e, gave one Pugill, or
very little handful of the Salt of Hypericon, and God is the witness, that
the pacient was delivered by it.

A certain person gives the Salt of wormwood in all sycknesses in a manner,
but above the rest, he profitablye mynistred it in wine, in the Pestilence, as
I hear. Theophrastus only mynistred three grains of this Salt in the
^^^psie, but (as I suppose) he gave the same sundry times. The Salt of
Wormwood seems especially to savor the vryne, having no manifest
vytternesse in it: this Gesnerus.

The Salt of Mugwoort does also savor the vryne, but the same is white and
clear: and the same besides, as it were a certain Talow, fattye.

Of the herb called Kali, do certain prepare a Salt: which herb Kali is
of two Cubits of heygth, having no prickles or thorns, and is sometimes very
red, saltye in taste, with a certain ungrateful smell, found and gathered in
saltie places: out of which, the Salt of Alkali may be purchased, it must be
prepared after this manner, as they report, which prepare it. First they dygge a
pytte, in which they lay wood cleft overthwart, on which they lay a heap of
the foresaid herb, and the fire kindled, they so procure, yt the lycor of ye
herb may still into the pyt, which licour in the end contealeth hard, and
becomes or is made the salt Alkali, being partly of a black, and partly of
an ashie color, very sour and saltie, in so much yt it may accord, as
witnesses John Bauhimus physician of Geneua.

The Salt of Camomyll, gave a certain Physician in the best wine, that is, of
this salt, one little handful or Pugill in the hardness of making water: and
the pacient through it, was spedilye delivered.

Gesnerus thus prepared a Salt, of the Berries, and wood of the Iunyper: I
took (says he) the dry branches or sticks of the Juniper, together with
his berries, in a great quantity, which I brought to ashes: (for it behooves
most exactlye to burn them, some in a great new earthen pot, and in which no
lycour before has been, they burn these) with the ashes of these, let a
proper Lie be made, with water meanelye hot: or the ashes with the water may
be powered in a wooden vessel or Bole, that they may setle, and the water
after powr^d forth a part^, and the ashes with the troubled water to be
separated. To these must other water be powered, and the same sundry times,
until no savor of the Lie remains in the water, and the water by decoction
euaporated and consumed, unto the persite or full drying of the matter, and
whiteness of the same. It yields a smell and sauoureth, like Bora^e and
bryne: sour it is also, and pearcing.

The manner of making Salt, out of the waters of the Bathes of Aponensis in the
field near to Padna, which Johannes de Dondis first found, and invented, by
which he made and purchased such a store of Salt, that it sufficiently served
all his famylye, and had a reasonable store besides, to give of it to his
friends. Gabriel Fallopij teaches the like, in his learned book of bathes,
waters and metals. But ye Salt which he made of the same water, was more
sauourly or salty, and sowrer, than the Sea salt, or any salt dug out of the
earth. In the large Lake of water, of Aponitana, he placed certain hollow
vessels of flynt, well four fingers breadth deep, which vessels, besides
that they were made hollow unto such a depth, were also framed square. So that
he placed these vessels in ye lake, in such manner, that the water could not
enter into it, but stood on the water, well two fingers breadth above. After he
got many earthen pots, which he filled with that water: then placed he them
in those square vessels, and left them even there, until it came to pass,
that the water in those pottes contained, were wrought and boiled through the
heat, and by little and little euaporated forth: and so long this Philosopher
did permit or let this water there remain, that it might boil, as how long a
certain brightness appeared in the water: and he then powered forth that water
of the pots, into those hollow stony vessels, in which ye salt coniealed most
white, as in the highest upper face of those vessels: but in the lowest
remained, the matter or substance properly named of him Gypsea.

The urine of a Child, if it be distylled in a Lymbecke after the manner of
venyger, unto the thickness of Pitch, and the flewme then powered forth, let
the vessel after be very well sublimed, and you shall possess the volatyle
Salt. There be many which use this Salt, unto the dyssoluing of Gold and
Silver: and sundry Philosophers also there be, which name it their Menstruum.

Unto the procuring of the Terms, as I my self have experienced: Take the
roots of the Celondyne clean scraped, and not washed, so many as you will,
those dyllygentlye stamp in a Marble mortar: then put them in a vessel of
cyrculation (as you know) for a natural day, on which power the life of wine,
or burning water, as was of the Agaricke, and others taught before: after let it
remain for a night, in Balneo Mariae, and then in the morning draw it forth,
without any pressing or wrynging forth at all. After so work that it may be
separated (as that it may euaporate) the burning water in the dystylling, after
the accustomed manner, and that gathered, as before taught of the Agarick. And
when all the burning water shall be consumed by Balneu^ Mariae, in the bottom
of the vessel will then remain a cetayne powder, (but whether like Salt)
which use* of this minister at a time one scruple, in white wine, in an apt
place, and necessary time.

A powder of Saltes, unto the seperating of any flewme: Take of Hysope, and of
Penny royal, of each half an once, of Organy two drams, of Fennel seeds
half an ounce, of Carr^way seeds two drams, Lycorys one ounce, of burnt Salt,
six ounces* of ye Salt of wormwood two drams, of ye Salt of Juniper so much,
of Cinamo^ one ounce and a half, of long pepper six drams, of Cordamom^, of
grains of Paradise, and of Cloves, of each half an ounce, of Ginger ^ue
ounce, these after the laboring into powder, mix together.

Of the Oils, of the Saltes of the herbs: which to purchase, the Salt must
on this wise be dyssolued. Take the Salt, which calcyne in the strongest fire,
and calcyned, let it be after fynelye wrought to powder on a Marble stone, this
powder then straw abroad on a Glass: the Glass after with the powder, set
into a wine Seller, in a moist place, and the Salt will after be dyssolued into
an oily substance, which of many is properlye named Salsal.

An oil of Salt, or ointment of Salt, which mightilye anayleth and helps as
well the hot, as the cold distyllinges of the head, which is properly named
the rewme: take a good quantitye of Salt, which grind so fine as is possible,
after let it be boiled with out any moisture in a frying Pan, until it shall
attain a swart color, which ended, let it be labored to powder in a Mortar,
unto the finest of ^oulted flower, the same then myxe with the oil Olyue, unto
the styfnesse of an ointment, without heat or fire. With this ointment,
annoint the affected or grieved part, in a warm place.

The Salt Armoniack, invented of a French Empiricke: take of the whitest Gum
Arabicke, three ounces, which dyssolue in common water, to which after ^dde of
common Salt, clear, and brought to powder, two pounds, the whole boil unto a
just thickness, after power the same into a certain vessel, washed before
with common water, and both sproungen round about, and covered with Chimney
soote brought to powder, and dried in an apt place.

Of Borace. The.xij. Chapter.
THE confection of Borace used at Venice, a singular secret: Take of Cowes
milk distylled two pyntes, of clarified Honnye four ounces, of Saffron three
drams, or Salt nyter well purged (that is, pure and somewhat sweet, having no
sharpnes nor tartenes at all) four pounds. Let all these be incorporated with
the milk (that is dyssolued at the fire) with three pyntes of the water of the
strong myxture drayned, through the strongest and best ashes, and myxed
strongly together. After pour the whole into a pot glased, which set in a
cold (and moist) place, for one month. The stone after found in the bottom,
let it be cleansed again, and purifyed after this manner: Take of the said
stone one pound, of simple water dystylled four pyntes, the whole dyssolue
together at the fire, and purge or skymme the froth of very clean, and when
no more some or froth shall arise, euaporate the whole water (that is, cast or
pour the same forth, when it shall be through cold) and you shall possess a
most pure and fine Borace.

A syngular form and way, in making of the Borace, borrowed out of a French
book written: Take new Butter of one months making, or there about, salted,
which dylligentlye wash often times in clear water. Of this Butter washed,
take one pound, of the oil of Tartare three pyntes, these after the myxing in
the Sun, pour into an earthen platter or pan glased: which strongly stir
and labor together with a large spatle. After take one pound of roche Alome,
being very pure and clear, of Salis nitri Alexandrini half a pound, these
also myxe in the hot Sun, and set abroad at night in a clear air: For
otherwise if rain fall on the whole, or be wette with water, all would be in
vain and come to naught. The upper face of it only will be coniealed like to
Crystal, ye coniealed take of or away, for the same is the stone labored and
desired. And this may aptly be prepared and made, in the months of June,
Iulie, and August.

A syngular way of making Borace, that at this day is in use with the
Goldsmythes, which was brought out of Alexandria unto the Aucthour, and out of
an Italian book by him, and into Latin turned. Take of Goats milk distylled,
and poured, into a Glass body, add to it of roche Alome brought to powder,
that it may easily be dissolved without fire in the water of the mylk. The
whole poured into a narrow necked Glass, let the water be well two fingers
breadth above the Alome, which close covered, let so stand for five or six
weeks, or until the Alome appears a part, which from the water must be
separated or taken, and put into another Glass. Which thus ordered, take two
pounds of Oil of sweet Almondes, and four pounds of the marrow of an Ox
or Cow: the marrow with the Oil mix so together, that it may melt and be
dissolved* which after strain through a Linen cloth, and you shall obtain a
thick Oil. To this Oil add the abouesayd Alome, in such manner, that the
Oil covers two fingers breadth above the Alome, the same then set in the
Sun for three months, or a longer time, which is the better: and on such
wise shall you prepare, and make what quantity of Boraxe you will: and this
conceive, to be a most excellent secret. For it is the true Boraxe, which is
made in Alexandria.

Another composition, out of the same D.H.D. Take of Alome purged from the
Feces, which Dyars use, and of the same with water drayned through strong
Ashes, able to bear an egg, make a Lie: after take a quantity of the past of
Boraxe, which you mind to have, the same put into a vessel, to which power
such a quantitye of scaldyng Lie, as will cover the paste, and with Canell let
them be well incorporated together, then let the whole stand, until the ^eces be
settled in the bottom. Which so ordered, ingeniously separate the Lie, as above
taught, that the paste may be well separated and purged of all grounds and
fylthe. After take the whole. Lie (and power upon the paste of the Boraxe)
these in the boiling in a pan or pot, skymme very pure and clean. And the
skimme keep a part in a vessel, for in it is an Oil contained, which kyndled
burns like a Candle. That you may rightlye judge and know of the perfect
boiling of the same: instyll certain drops of it on a marble stone, or on
your nail, and if it remain coniealed, it is then sufficient.

Another perfect way, borrowed out of a Goldsmithes book, of fame with us: Take
of Alome one pound, which break in a gross manner, to it add of pure and
clear Gum Arabicke one quarter of a pound, very fine brought to powder, of
the seeds or corn of Wheat and Barlye, of each one quarter and a half, the
seeds of the Wheat and Barlie power into an earthen vessel glased within,
which cover with warm Cow milk, after set these into whote Horse doong for
five and fiftye days, and at every seven days end, renew it with new whote
doong.

Another well lyked, and to be put in use: Take two parts of ancient oil
Olyue, and one part of new Cow milk, these after the myxing together, power
into a Glass with a narrow mouth, to which add of roche Alome, such a
quantity chopped into pieces, so bygge as a Date, that the licours may well be
two fingers breadth above the Alome, then bury the Glass in hot Horse doong,
for fiftye days, and let the doong be sufficient hot all that season, after
dry the substance in the shadow, etc.

A special paste of Borace: take of white Soap, which finelye raspe or scrape,
the same myxe with Honny, and boil so long together in an earthen pan, until
the whole becomes tender: this proved.

A worthy confectio^ of Boraxe: take of roche Alome, two ounces, and resolve
two ounces of Salt Alkali dissolved, which put into a Tyn vessel, over a soft
fire to boil, for half an hour: after draw forth the water, and myxe with
the same two ounces of Salt Geme brought to powder, and so much of Salt Alkali,
and of Honny two pyntes, and one pynt of Cow milk: these then set in the Sun
for three days, and you shall purchase stones.

Another special manner, and that good, is thus made perfyte, unto all
judgments. Take of Salt Armoniacke, one ounce, of Gum Arabicke two ounces,
of Masticke, and of roche Alome, of each half an ounce, of Salt nitre one
ounce, of common Salt two ounces, of Tartare calcyned one ounce: all these
finelye brought to powder, pour into a Glass with vryne, which boil until
it be thycke.

Of potable Gold, of the oil of Gold, and powder of the Sun, or the Gold
of Life. The.xiij. Chapter.
THE ancient Philosophers in times past, had diverse opinions in the dyssoluing
of Gold, and yet unto this day, the same not of the learned fullye uttered,
whether so pure and perfyte substance, as the Gold is, may be purchased by
man's industrye with any Art, force, and property of fire, to be resolved into
a perfyter and purer lycour. For which cause, we shall here under utter
certain disputacions and arguments of this kind, even as we found them
written in scroules, in the treasure of Euonymus. And all those in a manner are
propouned, of learned men, on either part by their Letters familyarlye written
to D. Gesnerus. And first of all does a certain, most syngular Physician of
great report and fame with us, defend thus the Negatyue part. If so be (says
he) an Oil of Gold may be prepared and made, then the Alchymisters would
obtain and possess all things. For neither an Oil, nor water is purchased,
except it be reduced into a spirit, and the substance of the same perfitly
mixed dissolved. The same whether it may be compassed and done, I beseech you
to reuolue and ponder, according to your learned and Philosophical
understanding. Yet may Gold be dyssolued, and into very small parts, in so
much that with the lycour in the distyllation* as they name it, it may ascend:
Notwithstanding, certain it is, that the substance of Gold does remain. And
many things there be, which so dyssolue the Gold, that they reduce it into
very small parts. But do draw a water or oil, out of Gold, the skylfull
practysioners know: yet believe meacute;e, that none hitherto, which affirmed
this, performed the matter in deed: which if he could or knew the same, he
would be rytcher then Croesus. I do not deny, but that a stone and tinctures
may be wrought and done: yet consider a little I pray you, that these be but
tryfles, and to small purpose, So that how in a Golden vessel, the keuer of
Golden vessel can no^ be (...) a dream (...) as the most instructions in a
mane^ of all the Alchymi^^e^, which like many men of our time, have set forth
and le^t in writing, their own inventions and (...), and have uttered nothing
at all of the (...) pra^^ises and very^ tru^th: For as the others were
delighted to set forth other men's ^^^ties and (...) so the* Th^ophrastians also
with these, ^^^ye and practice to ma^e, of ^oole^ mad men. And very like it
is, that somewhat is aided, no^ by dyuine help, but that the master of them
to have wrought and done: yet that those (...) and remedies* which they
publy^he, to be* vain and false, nothing dou^te. For they utter them with such
an obscurity, least their peruersenes in teaching might be perceived. But of
those hitherto, shall su^fise. But this one thing (to conclude) I may adioyne,
that the same person must needs be very impudent and shameless, and an utter
enemy and defamer of your worthy name, which labored to persuade you to
credyte this. These hitherto be the words, which a singular Physician wrote
unto D. Gesnerus, of the oil of Gold.

The like wrote another learned, unto the same Gesnerus, yet otherwise he wrote
after this sentence: that what shall I write and utter of the dy^^oluing of
Gold, or Gold potable, seeing such practyses are the speculacions of ^ryuolous
persons, which if those helped, or served unto the matter, then loses he both
oil and labor. That Gold may be reduced into very small parts, and be so
caused lyquide, and that the nature of the Gold may be converted in a spyrit
and oil, the Alchymistycall hope, and not the ^eueth it self, allows it to
be performed and done. Yet the Gold brought into very small parts, and
reduced into the first Elements purest, may so be made potable: but the same
(not under the form of water or oil) seeing it may through the myrion,
cause other metals to be the better, and as it were to alter, which I do not
deny, yet grant I not the same to be any thing at all, as they affirm of the
Philosophers stone. But of the water and Oil of Gold, which they so
conninglye utter and teach. I am out of doubt and sure, the same to be wholye
untrue. And of the same mind and judgment seem both the learned Auycen, and
Albertus Magnus to be, yea and that syngular Brassanolus: as that (...), and is
as it were contrary (...) a substance that may seem to have no grounds,
seems (...): the rather, that by force of fire, without any other help may
in substance by any manner be altered. And the like words* used Brassanolus*
That of the purginges, th^se not only to be vain and fryuolous* which are
reported of the potable Gold and Silver* but he also doubted not to affirm
them to be poisons. And many like words and opinions may be alleged and
agreeable unto the same sentence, which at this time for breuitye were here
(...)* But a further instruction and larger discourse (...) shall be uttered,
in the Book intytuled of Stones, precious stones* and Myneralles: which as
infynite Papers in a manner written* our syngular Gesnerus has left them as
yet, vndygested in due order.



But the dyssoluing of Gold, that many affirm, which may be performed and

Of the dy^^olved a^^ ^^table Gold and property (...) of the same* borrowed
out of the seventh Chap^ter of Antonius Fumanellus* in the book of the
composition of Medicines. The.xi^^^. Chapter.

It stays back old (...) natural h^^^rs, and pr^serueth all the parts of
the body without (...) ^^ decay, it cures the Leprye, cleanses the blood,

the decoction of the same taken: which suffices once to bane uttered, that
above declared? This with Bytonie water* helps headache, the ^ynmesse of
^yght, and ^yd^inesse or (...) of the head* with the decoction of Buglosse, and
