with the water of (...) the bleeding of the Nose this helps, with the water
of S^abious: it cures the cough with the water of Maiden hair, and in the
spytting of blood with the water of ^^antane: in the consumption of the Lunges,
with the water of Honny, and milk: in the pain and swelling of the L^ng^,
with the water of river Creauisses: in the trembling of the heart, with the
water of ^^^line, or Buglosse: in the pain of the stomach, with the water of
Myntes, or decoction of the same: in a hot disposition of the body, with
Rosewater, or the water of Myrtylles: in the blooddy scouring, and gryping of
the bellye, or flyxe, with the water of plantaine: in the pain of the
Collycke, with burning water: in the passions of the worms, with the decoction
of Zedoaria, or wormwood: in the swellings of the Liver, or stopping, and
water between the skin, with the water of the wild Endyue, and of
Lyuerwoort in a hot cause, but in a cold cause with the decoction of
Spykenarde, or Cynamon: in the Iaundise with the water of Honysocles, commonly
named Periclymenos, or with Goats whaye: in the passions of the Mylte, with
the water of the Ash, or Tamariske: in the passions of the Kydneys, stoppinges
or fylling, and the stone, with the water of Tribulorum marinorum, or Radyshe,
Alkekengi, and Pympernell, or with the powder of Philantropos, or Apparina: in
the Srangurie, and ulcers of the Kydneys, with Goats milk: in the rupture of
the caul of the guts, and falling down of the guts into the coddes, with the
water of either Consolida: in the staying back of the Terms, with the water
of Sauyne, or Mugwoort: and in the painfulnesse, or straightnes of birth, with
the water of Mugwoort: it helps besides barrenness, with the water of Nepte,
and Lauender: all manner of joint aches, happening in any member and part of the
body, and consumpcions: this cures with burning water, or the Cowslyp, or the
Lauender: this serves to the pestilent Ague, with the water of Sorrel, or
Buglosse, and Scabious: to the Canker fystula, and scabbydnesse, with the water
of Verueyne, or Buglosse or Sorrel. It preserves a man from poison, and
helps persons poisoned, and cures the byt of a mad Dog with the water of
Tormentyll, white Dittany, or Bystorta, or the water of ye root of the Pyonie:
Quotydians, Tertians, and quartaine Agues, in the coming of the cold, or
beginning of the fytte give it with the water of Hearts tung, and it puts
away the unstable and burning Agues with the syrup of Violettes: and that
briefly to write, they affirm the potable Gold with burning water, to procure
a noble effect in man's body, and to put away in a manner all sicknesses. And of
it they appoint in great sicknesses, one scruple or half a dram wayght, to be
ministered at a time, but in easier or gentler sicknesses, unto the quantitye of
half a scruple, in small grieffes unto the wayght of two Barlye grains, and
myxed with a decoction being ten times so much. Seeing that they utter ^ teach
the making of it many ways, for that cause will I here declare sundry of them,
but if any shall desire to know more ways of the same, and that the Chymistes
term and name of fyxion of the Son in our heauine, let him read the
Commentary named the heauine of the Philophers, where you shall find many
forms of the potable Gold, and that sundry wise, and in the same also shall
you read many compositions of Aqua vitae: of which the truth it self
utters, what fydelitye is to be given to them.

A dyscription of the making of potable Gold.
The first, take a quantitye of the leaves of chosen Gold, which shall seem
apter to thy purpose, of the juice of Lemmons very well puryfied so much as
shall suffice, powered into a body, orderly stopped as it behooves, and set
into a Furnace of ashes, under which a fire made of a Candle or other light,
for fowr^ days, or more, to which after add half so much of burning water,
five times distylled over, this use, according to discretion.

The second they uttering and teaching another way of making the po^able gold,
do take of gold leaves beaten very fine and thin, a. C. i^ number, of salt
finely grinded on a smoth marble stone half anounce, these mixed together, and
washed in hot water, they after pour into a glass body, framed or having a
long neck, and in the bottom fenced with ye lute of wisdom, on ye mouth of
which a keuer artly set, under which a fire made of a light having. iij.
matches or wykes, that they may distill, as ye order is, accordi^ to art* yt if
any part of ye gold shall yet remain in ye bottom of ye vessel, they k^epe ye
same unto use.

The third, by another manner preparing and making the potable Gold, they take
one part of the purest Gold, of quicksyluer two parts, which they stiepe
together for a day and a night, until the Gold shall be dyssolued by his
force, after they distyll the whole with a fire, until the quicksyluer be
separated from the Gold: and to the Gold resting in the bottom of the
vessel, then tending unto a blackness, they add of Buglosse water half a
pynt, and the mouth of the vessel being stopped or keuered after art, they
mayntaine fire under for three days, and three nyghtes, unto the meltyng or
through dyssoluing of the Gold.

The fourth, let be taken of the cement of Gold, one ounce, which compound or
myxe with one ounce, of pure Spanishe quicksiluer: the whole put into a Glass
body, common Oil powered upon, and floting well two fingers above, then let it
boil on hot Ashes or ymbers for.xxiiij* hours, and when it shall be through
cold, draw forth the Oil, and that which remains, wash with warm water,
until the moisture, and vnctuousnesse be separated, and dried, the same bring
or work into a fine powder, which then put with the Sulphur into a Crucible
or coals, mayntayning the fire, until the Brimstone be burned or consumed:
after take the gold, and grynde it with Salt for a certain time, and after
with Honey make a long grynding on a Marble stone: then wash it with hot
water, until the Gold be very well cleansed, and pure: after take vryne
dystylled, three times over: as at the first let it be distylled unto the half
^ next unto the third part: the third time unto the fowrth part* and to this in
the last time distylled and powered into a Glass set on hot Ashes, add Salt
grynded, and Salt Armoniacke on a soft fire, until they be dyssolued into
the distylled vryne, and these distylled together in a Lymbecke. But the Gold
by fylter, which to the vryne prepared myxe, and to both the Saltes, the same
set on a soft fire, and that which swymmeth or floteth above, let it be taken
of and washed so often as an Oil, until no saltness rest in it, which then
powered into a Glass body with the water of Life, let them after be dyssolued
into a clear water.

The fyft, take of Vytrioll rubysied, one pound, of salt Nytre, nine ounces,
of Vermilon six ounces, of common Salt three ounces, the whole grinded
together, draw a sharp water, with which let the gold be mixed, prepared as
above taught, and distylled by a Lymbecke, until a water shall issue in the
color of Gold: that Gold remaining in the bottom of the vessel, reduced
unto the form of Honey, myxe with the water here under described. Take of
Vermilon three pounds, of Vitryoll ruby^ed, of Salt nytre, and of roche Alome
calcyned, of each one pound, of common salt one pound and a half, all these
grynde together, and artificiallye distyll: that which is sublymed, and cooled,
and made white, grind with a like wayght of salt Armoniacke, then let it be
sublymed, and grinded five times over: that which is sublimed work on a Marble
stone, the whole set on the ^yre, and molten, myxe with the Gold, prepared as
above taught, which boil with a soft fire, until the Gold be dyssolued, and
when it shall be through cold, let the vessel containing the above said
matters, be buried under hot horse doong, for thyrtie days, and set again on
the fire: that which shall be dystilled, safelye keep.

Another potable Gold against the Pestilence, and all sicknesses happening of
vntemperatnes* of ^uyll compowning of the members, and of the unity dissolved,
and those which be common. The.xv. Chapter.
OF the vryne thryse distylled, which is wrought after this manner: Take of man's
vryne twenty pyntes, the same distyll, by drawing at the first time ten
pyntes: in the second time draw out of these ten, five: and out of the five,
three: and with these five (or rather three) let the Gold prepared, be poured
into a Lymbeck. Take of Gold out of his natural cemente, one ounce, and
Amalgama, it with one pound of Spanishe quicksyluer, these power into a Glass
body, then boil the whole with common oil for four and thyrtie hours,
which after draw forth, and let cool throughlye: the same wash with hot
water, until the oil, and all ventositye be dygested, then press or wring
the substance through a skin, and the Gold shall remain Amalgamated, which
dry, and dried very well, grynd in a Mortar with Brimstone, that the Amalgama
with the Brimstone may be brought into a fine powder: after take the distylled
vryne, above uttered, which power into a glass with a narrow neck, to it add
of common Salt in powder, and of Salt Armoniack, these then distyll again:
after power it on the Gold in a glass body, and let it boil, that the Gold
may be dyssolued, then take the Gold of, swymming above, with a Spone of
glass, the same power into burning water, or into the same, which is distylted
out of the Elyxir vitae in a double vessel, and in this by heating dyssolue
the Gold: for this Gold is profitable, unto all manner grieffes. The seventh:
take the Honey comb with all the wax, and the Honey, which power into a glass
with a narrow neck, pouring upon of the best burning water: the same very
well stopped* let stand to stiepe for two months in a hot place (or in hot
Horse doong) and m^yst, until all be molten, the same distyll. That which
first yssueth* will be as a water: which in the second draft, will be as
vapor: that in the third, will be as a fyrie part: which boil so long,
until the Gold be dissolved. For this is marvelous, and experienced for the
Stomach, the Liver, and the Bowelles, affected of a cold vntemperatnes, and
where fear (of that swelling) named Ascites, is doubted to come.

The manner and way of making a potion like to potable Gold, serving unto
sundry sycknesses. The.xvi. Chapter.
C^rtayne of the Chymistes, supposing the burning water to purchase the
propertyes of Gold, do heat red hot the same Gold, which they name the
Sun, that by nature or by art purified into thinner plates, or pieces, an
hundredth times, and so many times quench them in the burning water, and
commyxed to the Quintessence, as a heauine, they used in sundry sicknesses:
this hitherto Fumanellus.

The manner of making potable Gold, invented of a Physician of Craconiensis,
which he also used in the compositions against the Pestilence: take of leaued
Gold, and myxe it (but I would put the same into a Glass body) with such a
quantitye, which shall seem reasonable and sufficient to your turn, of the
juice of Lemmons purifyed. After stop dilygentlye the mouth of the Glass,
which burye in hot Ashes, and let it so stand for four days or more, even
as need requires the same: then add for the half of this mixture, such a
quantitye of the best Aqua vitae (as of that sweet, of which above taught)
rectifyed, and close well the mouth of the Glass that no air breathe forth,
which keep as a precious pearl and Baulme, and an estimable Treasure, for the
health of man's body, necessary above all others. And of this treasure may a
man receive or take four times in the year, as in the beginning of every
third month, so much as a sponefull at a time, with the best Malmesse, or
with Brothe, in quantytie either more or less, as necessitye shall require. Of
the distyllation he makes no mention: yet what and if the juice of the Lemmons
should be first drawn by distylling, then the water of life added, and should
again be distylled. Or you may otherwise see and perceive, what manner if may
be, if it be so prepared by the order of the prescripcion, and if you will,
distyll besides with a mean fire of coals, for four and twenty hours.

A potable Gold prepared after the manner of the Alchimisters, on this wise,
which the Aucthour borrowed, out of an old Alchymic book written. First let
the Gold be calcyned, after the use and manner of the Goldsmythes, by
Mercury, and permytt^ that the Mercury or quicksyluer euaporate from it, then
let it be fynelie grounded on a Stone, after set in a Furnace of reuerberation
for two days, and most subtle flowers shall appear, which gathered and
calcined, and reuerberated to long, until the whole be changed and come to
flowers. With those flowers of the gold, take vyneger of the best wine
distylled, and put these flowers in a glass, then set it to putrify for
fourteen days, after power forth the vyneger colored, and power upon new
vyneger, sturring it well, after let the same thoroughly settle, then let the
vyneger in the end be changed again, pouring upon other, and the same so
often repeat, until no more remains in the bottom of the Glass, and that
the whole be dyssolued into the vyneger. After power the colored vyneger into
a bygge Glass, that the vyneger may freelye euaporate forth, and in the
bottom will a black Gold remain, like to an oil as pytch, which take, and
power to your wine rectifyed, that it may there be dyssolued, and powered into a
vessel of cyrculation, which let stand in a most gentle heat for twelve
weeks, and all the spyrites of the Wine shall so be gathered and fyxed, and
converted into a powder, together with the Son or Gold, which take forth,
and prepare or put to be dissolved: for it will be dissolved into a most
clear Oil, as Gold, and this is named potable Gold, of which use as you
know. And the rectifying of the wine, is on this wise done, in a vessel of
recteration or rectifying, let the Wine stand for ten days: but in the Wine
before let these be dyssolued, before that it be put into a Glass to be
rectifyed, as of Camphora, two ounces, of crude Sugar well dried before so
much, of Nutmegges one ounce, of Mace, of Zedoaria, and of Gynger, of each one
ounce, with these rectifye the Wine, in the vessels of rectifying, the
vess^lles ver^^ t^ose sto^^e^, that little or nothing may breathe forth, after
let it ^e taken, and with this Wine prepare the Gold.

The potable Gold, says the singular Fiorauante, is a dyuine lycour, to
which none other may be compared, that the ancient, and later Philosophe (...)
have by dillygent study, great search, art, and practice, dyue ^selye sought
and labored to dissolve and make this pocion of Gold, and have also attempted
diverse and sundry ways: of which some of them I will here rehearse, to the end
that the wife may judge, which way (of these) seems best. For some there
were, that before the distyllation, did diuer sly calcyne the Gold, to bring
it to dissoluing: others there were, which labored to dissolve the Gold with
Aqua fortis and others after the calcyning, have endeavored to dissolve the
Gold with Aqua vitae: and thus many have trauayled without light, in the
search of the Art, having neither knowledge, skyll, nor yet experience. And
this co^ceyue, that all those matters which are possible to be done are wrought
with great easiness: and in the like manner, is the dyssolucion of Gold easilye
wrought, Wherefore I will here utter and teach an easy manner, and sure way of
making this most precious lycour, so greatly and highlye esteemed of mortal
creatures, not without desert: in that the same is a substantial essence, and
as it were another Soul, yea our life this potable Gold may be named* for the
sundry effects, right wonderful, that it in desperate cases has wrought.
Take of Gold leaves, or leaf Gold, in wayght one ounce: after get a byg and
well fleshed Hen, or male Pullet, which after the kylling, pull, and take forth
the bowels and other*refuse, the body yet warm, then open or cut holes in many
parts of the body, where most flesh is, as on the breast, the legs, and under
the wings. These parts stuff and fill with the leaf Gold, until all be
full, or that the whole be bestowed. Which done set this Hen or pullet into an
apt place, where for six and thirty hours the body may retain or keep a
natural heat, that the Gold may so be dyssolued into a water: for there is
a certain hid propertye in the Hens or Pullettes flesh, for the
dyssoluing of Gold into a water. Which time ended take the body forth, and wash
all the flesh of the Hen or Pullet so thoroughly round about, and clearly that
nothing at al remains (...) of the Gold, with the water of Honny* distylled
with his spyrites, being re^tifyed twyse or thryse. This washing ended take so
much of the water of life, as is of the water, of the washing of the Hens
flesh, which mix together: and for each pynt of the said water, a^de one
dram of Salt Armoniacke, which is white without any blackness, these power
together into a Glass body, after burye the Glass in hot Horse doong, for
three whole months. But every month look^ to your substance, taking or
pouring forth the clearer above, which keep in a Glass close stopped: the
body again set into the hot Horse doong, and remaining another month, that
which shall be clear likewise separate from the Fece^: and on such wise, in the
space of three months, shall you purchase all the water dyssolued and clear.
In the end, distyll the Feces in ashes or sand, with a strong fire, that all
the substance may the better ascend and issue forth. But in the distyllacion
of the Feces, this remember, that on the Feces must half a pynt of the fynest
Aqua vitae be before powered, and the same which shall be distylled, power and
mix with the other, that was kept in the first draft* these distyll again in
Balneo Mariae, until all be distilled: which set again into hot Horse doong,
for.xxv. days, and then have you purchased potable Gold, easilye prepared,
and with small cost: which by his maruaylous propertye and great virtue,
rayseth in a manner the dead. The use and manner of ministering it, is on this
wise: Take one dram of the potable Gold, with one ounce of the Inleppe of
Violets mixed together. And this composition may be given in Broth, or with any
water, or by it self, without any other mixture or lycour. And if any sick
person be at the point of death, in giving such a lycour, shall live a far
longer time, then perhaps he might do without it: and many by the dryncking
of it, have recovered life and health a long time after, by which may well
appear, of what importance this is for the Aged, to live one, or two, or four
days after the taking, for the better dysposing of their goods and will:
besides this greatly avails, unto the restoring of strength. This also has
caused the speachlesse, in extreme danger, to speak and utter their minds
before death, of which (this Fiorauante) saw sundry in the like case.

The confection of potable Gold, borrowed out of the letters of a certain
shy^full pr^^tisioner, which wrote in the French tongue unto D. Gesnerus. Take
of Tartare what quantitye you will, which Calcyne unto a whiteness, that may
be performed in three days, the calcyned Tartare, dyssolue in common
distylled water: and this conceive, that to one pound of the Tartare calcyned,
are three pyntes of the water (...). After the dissolution, let the water be
distylled by Fylter, and conie^led. Which done, it must be calcyned again for
other eight or nine hours, then dyssolue the same again in the common water
dystylled, and let it be coni^aled as above taught, and the same repeat seven
times over. And after the seventh time calcyned, let the Tartare to be
dissolved be put by it self into a large glass, which set in a moist place,
where neither the air, nor rain may touch. Which on this wise prepared, take
fyftene ounces of this water calcyned of the Tartare, that for each ounce of
the Sun calcyned, add of the manner ensuing. Take of the purest or finest
Gold one ounce, which dissolve with Mercury, even as the practisioners and
Goldsmythes dissolve the same, that gylde vessels, after let the Mercury by
euaporating be separated on the fire. When you shall have purchased the lyme, or
ashes, or the powder of the Gold in a due wayght, put the same then into a
Glass, like to a Receauer, which the longer the neck shall be, so much the
better it is. Then stop dyllygentlie this Receauer, that no other impure or
strange matter fall into it, which after burye in hot Horse doong, or rather
set the same in Balneum Mariae for fiftene days: and beware you stir not the
vessel, least that which is dissolved, and the some which is sublymed cleaves
to the sides, may fall of, and the action so byndered, whereby the lesser may
the rest be dyssolued: And let there remain, as either unto the whole, or let
the greater part at the least be dissolved* When the dyssolued Gold shall be
drawn, the same with great dylligence shall then be attempted and be gu^^e,
least that which is dissolved, may be myxed with the same, which is not
resolved. And that the sharpness of the water, which it received of the water
of the Tartare, may be taken away: take of the water of Life four or five
times distylle^, which myxe with the water of Tartare, and the Son or Gold
dyssolued, and this so often repeat, until the whole water of the Tartare
shall be separated from the Son, and unto that no savor nor taste of the
Salt remains. After add to it a little Rosewater, that the savor of the
burning water may so be abated: and on such wise have you purchased, the Oil
most pure.

Of the way and manner of making, and preparing the potable Gold, wrote a
certain learned person thus unto D. Gesnerus: I here send unto you the
potable Gold, as you (most syngular learned) required* that is, the way of the
making of it, as I saw the same done by two practystoners conuersau^t with
nice, which prepared the same in this manner with (...), even of late years.
And I beseech (...) m^st singular Gesnerus, that if it shall so seem to you,
to continue any truth that you will voutchsafe to allow and retain it with
you. For the Aucthours thereof which were with me, made very much store, and
danger of the same, and condicioned with me to be an ^uer^^er of them (...),
to the end I should not communicate^ the (...) to any: which will of their I
hitherto kept, that I have not to any vt^ered the same, either by word or
writing, saving to you alone, and this with good faith; so largelye as memory
could bear away, and wit utter, I here communicate to you^ the brief sum
of which is on this wise.

Let the wor^hyest Gold be chosen, the same purge with fire ^y semen^e, that it
may be ^^ade (...) pure, and sincere, as is possible: af^^^ let ^t be ^^yuen
(...) the n^^e plates, and cut into ver^e ^^^ll pieces, which on such wise
shredded, dyssolue in a Glass with a long neck, much like to the Receauer,
having a flat bottom. For in this shall the dissolucion be sooner wrought.
After let Aqua f^rtis be taken, which purged four times from the Feces, and
dyst^lled with a fowrth part of common salt prepared let the gold f^n^ly cut,
be p^t into th^^ water thus prepared, and let the Tartare very well calcyned be
by little and little put in, and on a (...) fire so gentle, yt you may always
handle ye neck of the glass: this dissolved into a pour and clea^^ water*
(...) from the fire, yt it (...) through lie ^oole. Then pour the water out of
it, into a Glass with large mouth* and let (...) water be ^esol^ed in hot
Ashes, and the substance ^^odryed; that sea^celye you may f^^lt the savor of
the Aqua fortis, and after the same, the matter again cooled* then Rosewater
powered on it, and the matter resolved, let the substance again be euaporated
and (...) a^oue taught* and the some ^gaine like repeated* as above uttered:
for on (...) shall the force of the Aqua fortis in (...) v^rye well (...) forth.

The substance purifyed and dried after this manner that it come to putrefying,
the same shall on this wise be done and let the matter be put into a Glass
sufficient large, to the same add the common distylled water, ^o much as (...)
^ouer the subst^u^ce, three fyngers in a manner above it, the Glass set into
Horse doong; or let it ^^e wrought in Balneo, which better ^greeth by the space
of ten d^yes. Then distylled so long as the vapor of the water (that is, until
the water be euaporated forth) and the substance dried: on the matter dried
let the d^stylled water be powered, and with a soft, fire, let the water again
he dyssolued into a vapor, after distylled in Ashes, and dried as above
taught. If the wor^ke hitherto shall be decently continued* the substance is
then brought to that purpose, that it will give forth white clouds in the
end, which that it may the spedilyer be done: in the end of the fourmer
dystyllacion the substance dried, let the wine thryse distylled be powered on
the same, and by the vapor of the water on a soft fire, let the substance be
dyssolued. Which if it shall be orderly done, the white clouds will then begin
to appear, and golden drope will by little and little ascend from the bottom of
the Limbacke, unto the upper face of the water, which the whole most pure,
shall compass as a Cause, in which, the Golden drops will hang: and of the
same they interpreted this to be the Golden shower of Dana^^. And for trut^ I
never saw any thing, pleasaunter then the same. For which cause it behooves
studiously to regard, and gather these clouds. And they are taken of with the
back of the imbossed part of the Spone of Glass (the clouds ought to be
taken of with the ^^bossed part, that the wat^^ be ^ot drawn (...) taken up
with them, for to the imbossed part do they easily clean: and shyfted into a
dyshe of Glass, but sound or whole received from the water; (in the same I
mean to be conduite water) and shyfted again into a dyshe of Glass, which is
in a man^er filled (with conduite water) dystylled. In this by and by will the
cloud, fall to the bottom. The first cloud thus gathered, let the
putrefaction, the exicration, and dystyllacion be repeated by order, for on
such wise shall another cloud be gathered, and the same so often repeat
until all shall be gathered. When no cloud more shall appear, you have then
purchased the Gold separated from the Tartare (as it were the Tartare before
conglufynated to the Gold or corporated together) which shall remain white in
the bottom. The Gold thus converted into clouds, taken out of the water in
the dyshe of Glass, shall be dried in the Furnace of calcynation, for (...)
shall it be delivered of the strange humor, which perhapp^^ shall be wrought
or done by the tenth day, ^at the heat ought to be gentle, that it exceeds
not the natural heat of man's body. The substance dried by the tenth day or
after, shall ea^lye be brought to powder with a spone in a Glass dyshe. The
clouds thus gry^^ed to powder, and powered into a long necked Glass, putrifye
at Balneo, and let them be again dyssolued together, which will be compassed
and done sometimes at the thyrtye day. But it shall be dyssolued into an oily
matter, which again dried, shall thus be performed, as unto the present
purpose sufficientlye prepared. For that Sellar or other moist place, shall it
be converted if need v^^ into a cytryne water, which as they report to be of a
marueylou^ propertye, unto to all kinds of sicknesses in a manner. These by
good says and so far forth as I could by memory utter, I have commit^^^
(...) whole to you, etc. Farewell.

Another manner of Theophrastus, for potable Gold: the Gold must be dyssolued
(as into most thin plates driven, and shredded very small) in Aqua fortis
agreeable (as four times purged from the Feces; named Royal) and washed from
the sharpness with sweet water dystylled, after the dyssoluing dried, of
which take three drams of Aqua vitae purchased of Homry three pyntes, these
power together into a Cucurbyte dylligently luted about, and the mouth very
well sealed or stopped, and set on ymbers, or a gentle fire for four and
twenty hours, let the same then most easilye boil. For on such wise is the
Son or Gold dyssolued in this water, whose use is as you learn of the
others.

A most noble manner of potable Gold, very rare and secret. First let an
Orrenge be made hollow, in taking forth the pulpe and seeds, into which put
leaves of Gold, not driven unto the uttermost thynnesse, so much as shall
seem needful. Then the juice of the Orrenge or Lemmon pressed forth, and
powered to the Gold leaves, let the Apple be close covered with his cappe or
keuer, and set in a hot place, or by a Furnace, for five or eight days. In
this manner do they affirm the Gold to be brought into an Oil. Which done,
let the juice be separated from the oil, and the Oil mixed together with the
strongest Aqua vitae, which sometimes must be separated again by dystyllacion
from the oil. And the judgment of the perfection of the oil, is learned
after this manner: let a little of the Oil be anointed on a piece of flesh,
which if it gylde not the same, but pierces unto the deep parts of it, so
that no show of Gold any where appears, then is the distyllacion and
working cunninglye handled. And the singular practisioners affirm this Oil,
to exceed both in virtue and property, any other potable Gold, how so ever
the same shall be prepared.

A potable Gold borrowed out of an Italian Pamphlet: take of the Pomeyse stone
brought to powder two pounds, of the finest Gold in leaves eight ounces,
these very well labor together, after take other four pounds of the said
stone in powder, without gold, then let a Bed be made of the Pomeyse, and
another on this course, of the Pomeyse with the Gold, proceeding by like order
again, in a glased Pot luted, that no air breath forth: which done, set the
Pot in a Furnace, making under a temperate fire for forty days, after draw
forth the water of Life, as you know, that is, power the water of Life on it,
and the gold as an Oil shall ascend.

A potable Gold, which is reported, to have been prepared of Raymunde Lullie.
He took of the purest Gold, so much as he thought needful, which in Aqua
fortis (dyssoluing especially gold) be first dyssolued, but after he drew
forth a water and spyrites by distyllation, unto the through drying of the
matter, wrought wholye after the manner of precypitate, practiced in our time.
The same thus dried, he after in a wine Seller brought into an Oil (which he
performed by the fifth day) and myxing it with other apt matters, gave it to
drink. This is easy to be done, and a speedy way, and well to be regarded.



A potable Gold is thus made, borrowed out of an ancient Alchymie book
written. Potable Gold must be made in the same manner, as before uttered,
where out of the same boo^e, we have taught the way, to make the oil of
Vitryoll. And in the same manner may all precious stones be brought and made
potable, not by adding Mercury, but only Sulphur or Brymstone. Therefore
take what precious Stone you will, and the same grynde very fine on a Marble
stone, to it then add so much wayght of Sulfure vyue most finely grynded,
these powered into a Crucyble, set after on quick coals, until the Crucyble
become so red, as a burning coal, and that the Brymstone be burned and
breathed forth. This powder remaining power again on a Marble stone, to which
add a like wayght of Brimstone, these work the like, as above taught, and do
the same again a third time: which done, thy stone then shall be sufficient
prepared. Of this powder, take half a dram, and of the foresaid water three
ounces, these power together into a little Glass, and cause the water to wax
white, and thy stone after shall remain as paste, to which then add the water
of Life, and you shall possess the precious Stone potable. Such potable Stones
do myghtylye avail against diverse affectes and sycknesses of the Body.

A Medycine revealed of God, for the preserving of man's health, and life, a
long time: yea, resysting the Leprye, and containing in it many marvelous and
bydde virtues. Take of the purest Gold brought into very fine powder three
drams, of chosen Baulme, one dram, of chosen Myrre, of Aloes Hepaticke, of
Frankencense, and of pure Ladamum, of each two drammes, of Camphora, five
drammes, let the whole be wrought and made with the Oil of Mandrake Apples,
and Baulme, myxed together. Of this Medycine let the Pacient receive one
dram, or half a dram once in a month, and drink on it a Glass full of
burning Wine myxed with the water of Buglosse, and Rosemarye flowers, myxed and
dystylled together by a Lymbecke. This is a royal and famous medycine, whose
myghtie praises are innumerable, and not ^ytte to be communicated to the
unworthy. This also is compared, to potable Gold: yet if pure Gold were
resolved into a water without corrosyues, and myxed with the abouesayde
matters, it would be a much preciousser medycine. If any also would preserve
youth a long time, and could not compass or attain the like medycine, let
him use Chebulis preserved with his syrup.

Another potable Gold, most excellent: before any other* take of the oldest
wine so much as shall suffice, the same power into a glass Lymbecke, after
lute the head and body together in the joint, and the Receauer in like manner,
then let the distyllation be done in Balneo Mariae, by seperating the four
Elements from it: as the first water coming forth, shall be sharp tending
unto an unsavory taste, which is nothing worth* The second water shall be
most sharp, felt like fire, which also is unprofitable. The third shall be
sweet in taste, and the same is the best, for that is an Ayereall matter. The
fourth water will be altogyther unsavory, which is nothing worth, and is named
earth. Now take of the abouesayde sweet water, as the Ayereall matter five
ounces, of the purest Gold driven into very thynne plates, and clypped into
little pieces, one ounce and a half, these power together into a small Glass
Lymbecke, very well fenced with Lute in the bottom, which distyll by the
space of five days, with the light of four Candles: as the figure here under
to the eye, playner demonstrateth.



The five days being ended, remove the flame or light, and put under a mean
fire of coals, for the space of four and twentye hours, and the whole water
shall pass or fall into the Receauer, and the Gold shall r^mayne in the
bottom of the Lymbecke, being then a most clear Oil, which is the true and
sincere Gold potable, and most precious for the use of Physic. It is a
certain skylfull man often used, without the commyxion of others, with the
water of Life. And it avails or cures the shedding of tears of the eyes, if
into the outward corner of his eye, the pacient lying vpryght, a drop or
half drop of it be distylled.

Where you see the candelsticke stand, there must the burning flame, with the
four lyghtes be set. into the ear. It thoroughly heals the French scabbe, if
the heads of the pushes be before clypped, and the scarres anointed with the
same, after this manner. If the pushes shall be old, then these ought first to
be low seared away with a burning Iron, or deep clypped with a pair of
sheeres: after the vlcered places, anointed with the only Oil. That if the
pushes shall be new then anoint the oil only on them: and in this manner many,
were restored as by a sure practice, sundry times experienced. This Oil mixed
together with the water of Life appropriated with a proporcion in a manner six
times, or eight times so much of the water unto the oil, does avail against
all distillations of the head, especially the cold, that is, the suffocatyue
or choking Rewmes. But on such wise it must be myxed together, that a drop of
the oil of Gold be instylled, into the water of Life, and mightylie shaken
together, until the water of Life through the gold purchases a red color,
yet very clear, and to be seen through. The same Oil prepared with the
water of life, and then myxed together with Goats milk, so long labored,
until the milk be colored, helps swellynges, and sores of the mouth, and
throat, if it be sundry times gargelled in the throat. For the preseruacion of
health, let six or eight drops be given or taken every week, or fowreteene
days, for a time together. But in the curing of a sickness, let then be
mynistred half, or a whole sponefull at a time to the pacient: as he which
shall be vexed with the Palsy, or falling sickness, or crampe, or with a like
grief, shall through this be cured. To be brief, the propertyes of it are, to
enforce, purge also, and strengthen. He which has this Oil, in a redynesse
prepared, will never sell the pure to any, but rather prepared always with the
water of life: which evermore must be mynistred in the same proportion, as
before uttered. He sold one ounce of the same, never lesser, then two crowns.

A syngular oil of Gold: let the leaves of Gold be stieped in the juice of
Lemmons (but whether in vyneger, especially distylled) and by the waterie
humor in the distyllation drawn forth: yet (what if Pearls, and Corralles be
added) then remains in the bottom, like Butter. The same wine myxed,
purchases to it a Golden color, and makes it sharp, and does maruaylously
resist rottenness. It does also p^^ge many grieffes, and ^^ouoketh sweat. For
better credit of these, make a proof, and you shall well perceive that I have
written and uttered a truth to you (as reports a certain learned man, in his
letter written unto D. Gesnerus) which I nothing doubt you shall well like,
and not dyscommende the use of Gold. This remedy and practice, even as the
Oil of Vitryoll, which may be reduced into Gold, greatly avails in the
Leprosy, and such which are destroyed, by the Mercuriall annoyntings of those
men, which (as Hippocrates writes) purchase money by their blind practyse and
ygnoraunce.

An Oil of Gold, being the secret of a certain syngular practysioner with
us, which D. Gesnerus obtained of a certain friend, of that condition, that he
would not communicate or utter the secret to any other. The Gold must be
dyssolued into a water, but with what sharp remedies I know not: thus
dyssolued, it cannot on the fire be elevated and distylled through the wayght
of the same, but through a little burning water rectifyed, powered into it,
which by and by without fire ascends (so that speedilye must a Receauer be
set under) and separated from that other matter eating or freting it, by which
it had been before dyssolued into a water.

A great secret of the oil of Gold, invented by a man singularlye practiced,
in this kind of distyllation. First of all, for this working, prepare a Glass
cup, or other vessel with the best red wine, filled even unto the top or
brymme, which you shall then set into another vessel filled with the coldest
water, especially if the work be attempted, and begun in the Summer time:
for how much colder the wine then shall be, and so much the more yield of the
Oil: but how much the hoter, so much the lesser yield, or nothing at all can
be purchased. And on this Cup set the greater square, and large, yet a thynne
iron plate, as the figure noted with the letter A. Does plainer demonstrate,
having in the middle of it a round hole, and large. Into this great hole by and
by put and frame a deep dyshe, or vessel of Copper, like to D. expressed, or
of Gold like to the letter F. or of any other matter framed (for made of
Copper, and Oil of Copper is obtained, even as of the Golden, or ^yluer
vessel; is an Oil gotten of the Gold or Silver) in which after the a^^^ture
working an Oil is found, whose foil o^ heavier substance re^^eth drowned in
the wine cooled. That if the same vessel shall be strayghter or smaller, then
that it may era^^^stfyll the myddle hole A. Set on them the thynne cy^^le B.
on the ^^myne or plate A. that the hole (by that means) may be the nar^qwe^e*
^rayghter, whereby it may rightlye fytte, the vessel D. narrow^r^ which that
it may stand the surer, and not be easily moved hy^her and thither, out of
place, must then be fastened and stayed, with those iron hooks, or such like
pynned on the Lamyne or plate A. and with this note * marcked. Now all these
ryghtly prepared and done, then in the bottom of the vessel D. or F. shall a
round cloth be said, being sma^^ nigh worn, thynne, and of Lynnen. Which
done, a fire shall be made of quick coals, and the keuer C. set on it, if the
vessel with wine D. shall be drowned or set into ye water, or the keuer ^. if
that F. shall there be left, until the whose be very hot: then with ^^arpe
nyppers or tongues, take of the ^euer by the ring or knobbe a^ you may learn
and s^e in both, here following and set on spedily the little vessel or deep
Cup, in the same m^^ter as you see here afte^ ^^gured, and a noise by that
means will by and by be caused, and ^he little lynnen cloth lying in the
hollownesse, will then be burne^* When the noise shall cease, (...) those
vessel shall be a little (...), then the keuer taken of again with the ^^all
Longes, and the cloth also burned, and the black ^y^^yhe taken away, in the
(...) of the vessel will appear to you, either on the sides many hanging, or
at the least one small drop of the Oil, either of Gold, or Copper, or
Silver, after the nature of the vessel, which must be gathered with a thynne
and small Spone made of Silver, and kept dy^^gentlye in a Silver vessel. Here
worthilye is to be noted in this place, that such an Oil, by his nature, to
be ^oone coni^aled and thyckened like to pytche. Of which, if you desire the

Life, or the water of Cynamon, and mynister the same to the sick: For then
shall you throughlye know and try, not without admyration, the efficasie and
propertye of this Oil.

That if you seek and get the Oil in a copper, or la^ten vessel, beware that
you mynister or give not of it with^^^ the body, but only apply of it
without, to the Serpigo, and other (...) spots on the skin. An oil by the
same s^yll and practice wrought in a Silver vessel, is a syngular medycine for

THE INSTRVMENTS INSVE.


A. Represents the square plate of iron, to be set on the Cup, or vessel
containing the wine, which has four great holes, that the Cup may so be
fastened, that it lightly or easilye swa^^eth not out of place. This has
besides two small holes, aunswering or agreing to the two little holes in the
Cyrcle of Band B. that if the same needs or must be put on, tha^ it may be
fastened by these. In the same plate are two books or the like fastners seen,
noated with a little Star, that the (...) ^up set into the great hole may so
be stayed by them.



B. Does here represent the Cyrcle, which does express and show a lesser
hole, for the Cup or small vessel to stand in.



C. Does here declare and show the keuer of the vessel, having a ryng in the
myddle.

D. Does here demonstrate the narrow vessel, agreeing to the Cyrcle B. with
the keuer and handle (as above said) standing upright.



E. Does here denote the keuer of the same vessel above, being hollow, with a
handle retching both above and beneath.

F. Does here express a greater vessel, set immediately on the great and
myddle hole.

A dyscripcion of the Gold of Life, or powder of the Son. Take of Mercury
four ounces and a half, or five, which let be thoroughly washed with Vinegar
and Salt, of the Hungariane Gold half an ounce, of these let a Amalgama be
made, like to the same which the Goldsmyths do use to gylde Silver vessels,
after let the same Amalgama be washed so often with Vyneger and Salt, until
the myxture sends forth no more blackness at all. This then put into a
Glass body, to which after power so much of Aqua fortis, that the whole
Mercury may thoroughly be dyssolued whereby in the bottom the Gold may
appear in powder of a red color. Then on this body ^et a head dyligently
luted i^ the joint, and by distyllacion separate the Aqua fortis, as first
beginning with a soft fire, next with a stronger, ever increasing the fire: but
last let it be so strong, that ye sand be fire or burning hot, and that all
the spyrites be drawn forth, then let the vessel cool, and after the cooling
open the body, and you shall find a powder of a purple color, in form like
to a certain * pleasant pastri^ myxed or wrought together. After break the
Glass, and grynde this pastrye in an open place and free air, on a marble
stone to fine powder, and turn your face from the wind then blowing on you,
because the fume and savor, is pestyferous and venymous.

The calcynation: Take the vessel or deep Basin sufficient large, noted with
the letter B. Which set under a hollow keuer in fashion like to a Pot, and
framed withsmall holes in the edge beneath round about, as the figure E.
hereafter playner demonstrateth: these together set in a Goldsmythes Furnace,
and suffer that it may burn darckishe or swartishe in color: which so
prepared, power a quantitye of this powder with an iron Ladle into the nether
vessel, as the portion of an ounce and a half, or two ounces at a time, which
in the heating stir dilygentlye with a^ iron spatle, and there shall appear
to you (in the doing) sundry^ colors, which in the end, come all unto a
black color, yet then work forewarde, and cease not, until the same
purchases again a red color. Which color so appearing, take the
su^staunce from the fire, and let it throughlye cool. These thus orderlye
handled, put under another vessel like to the abouesayde and of the same
largeness as the former was, and the same set into the place of the former,
and power again a like quantitye of the powder as above taught, and let it be
burned in the like manner, as above uttered, always and continuallye sturring
the same about, until all the colors be vanished away, and the same has
obtained a redness: for on such wise, by the benefit of this calcynation, all
the spyrites of the Aqua fortis are dispersed and euaporated away: that by
receiving a portion of the powder within the body, no harm at all can ensue of
the same.

In the preparation of this powder, a man must beware of the common Mercury,
which ye Alchymisters truly dye or change in sundry colors, but without
Gold, nor it cannot so mightily calcyne.

The dose or quantitye of this powder at a time is, that to old persons about
the wayght of an old pennye (waying so much, as I guess, as a pease groate,)
but to Children of twelve or fouretene years of age, so much as an old
halepenny wayght, given in a wafer cake, that the whole powder may well
descend.

The Aqua tortis, is thus prepared and made: take of Vitryoll two pounds, of
Salt peter, not extincted, and the best, one pound, these in the grynding myxe
together, and distyll the whole unto the drawing forth of all the spyrites: and
the like again a second time, distyll without any addicion, that it may so
be separated from the grosser spyrites, which on this wise ordered, the Aqua
fortis is then so mighty, that it may dyssolue the Mercury, and calcyne the
Gold. All these borrowed out of the book of Casparus Xeglerus Physician,
printed at Lipsia.

An explycation of certain of the former, with fygures expressed, uttered by a
certain singular Physician.

The letter A. which signifies the Amalgama, is thus prepared and made, the
most pure Gold must be brought or driven into thynne plates, the Crucyble
after set on the fire, make red or glowing hot, into which (beside the fire)
power the plates of gold and Mercury, that they may be so myxed together, and
this myxture is named Amalgama.

The letter B. represents, the body set on a hot place: for by that means,
is the working of Aqua fortis sooner caused.



D. Does demonstrate a vessel, named properlye a Test (as I may conceive of
the form) which the Germaynes term with them, Ein trybscherb, for it
expresses by a certain manner the same vessel, into which the Barbars
opening a vein, do receive the blood, saving that this is made of Lattyn, and
the same is made of earth, the perfyte form of which, is here before expressed.



E. Does here represent a hollow keuer, of the Aucthour named a Test, which
otherwise in the German tongue Ein miiffel. It is artlie made of Brickes and
mortar, framed like to a little Oven, having proper holes made in the edge
beneath, passing through, and that round about, as this figure here does
playner demonstrate.



F. Does here witness the goldsmythes Furnace, prepared and made of strong
Lute, after the manner here discrybed.

This is a descripcion of the powder of the Son or Gold, by a brieffer
manner, according to the observation of the same Aucthour. And in vain
labors he in many things, where otherwise it may be performed with few
things, and a short traueyle. To come to the matter, take a new and large
earthen vessel, with a wide mouth, as are the Basens of the Barbars, serving
for blood letting, saving that this ought to be wyder: the self same heated
red hot on burning coals, that it may appear glowing, then bring to fine
powder this thy red head gotten by distyllacion, as a little before was taught,
and power the same burned into the vessel, which continually stir about with
an iron spattle, that it may become and proceed from black of a swart color,
and in the end again of a red color: by which means you shall obtain, the
powder of the Son or Gold. But beware in any manner, that you be not
anointed and infected with the venymous vapor of the same.

Or thus, take the same Amalgama, of which above vttere^, the same order, that
it may melt into a water, whereby in the bottom the Gold may appear, after
the manner of a red powder. Then Lute dylligentlye the body, in which the
distyllacion mu^t be wrought, and let the same dry by it self, that it may
the ^eadyer and better abide the fire. After set the head on the body,
dyllygently luting the cleftes or joints with a piece of Lynnen cloth, and the
Lute of wisdom, that the spyrites breathe or issue not forth. And this
conceive, that if the body, in which the Amalgama with the Aqua fortis is
contained, shall be to the bygnesse of one measure, that then the Receauer must
be ten or twelve measures great: For otherwise through the multitude and
strength also of the spyrites, the Receauer would break. Which thus prepared
and done, set the body with his head in the Furnace of reuerberation, in which
a fire of coals must be made, as after ensues. First let the fire be soft,
until the spyrites begin to ascend, after let the fire be increased by
little and little. For in the end the Aqua fortis clears again. And in the
upper part of the Furnace, where the vente holes be, let the Furnace be
stopped, leaving open only the breathing places.

Of the Gold of Life, or powder of the Son (others seem to name the same
precypitate with Gold, of which somewhat has been entreated, and in the place
also before of the Mettalline wat^rs, at the end) thus wrote a certain learned
man unto D. Gesnerus. Of the Gold of Life, or powder of the Son (says he)
you seem to me to require the descripcion unto the same end, that you may
the readyer judge, whether the use of it may be safe and sure. I do commend
the inuencion, in that you apply all things unto use. This is compowned of
^ue ounces of Mercury five, of pure Gold half an ounce, and of Aqua fortis
so m^che as shall suffice. I have used the same even this month, and do
^aylye search and prove the virtues of it. I also do cure a great dissease
with this, which if the same shall so cease, as the working offers and gives
a good hope, I then affirm and pronounce the same to be a gift from God, etc.
And I believe that he which late^ye prepared it, with whom always I have been
conuersaunt, to have sold two drammes of this, for two Duche Dallers: in that
he acco^mpteth the labor great, the savor tedious, and the vessels
chargeable. Of this powder of the Son. I remember that I have given of it
five grains wayght, without any harm, but when I retch^d and took unto eight
grains, then did I mightilye procure and force vomyting, and the going to
stool, where I had before taken or re^cyued for four days together, unto the
wayght of five grains at a time, etc.



The manner to prepare fine Silver, which the Alchymisters name the Moon, and
to convert the same into a clear water, which the Alchymisters name also the
oil of the Moon: must be wrought and done, after this manner. Take the Silver,
which prepare and fine with Lead, as the Gold and Silver fyners cunninglye
do: which wrought on this wise, drive the plates so thynne as paper, those
then cut into very small pieces, and heat^ again on an iron plate: which
done, have in a readynesse your Aqua fortis, made of Salt nyter, Alome, and
Vitryoll, with all their spyrites, into which put your Silver, that forthwith
will be turned into a water, in color so blew as the Sky: and when you (...)
more of the silver undissolved in the water, then powr^ ^he whole water into a
body luted of purpose, with his head artlie set on, and a Receauer fastened to
the nose: the same distyll in ashes, until all the water be drawn and issued
forth* which keep, for it serves in other workings, and distyll so long,
until the silver rest and appear in the bottom of the body, so thick as a
san^^, which take from the fire, and let the substance dry on hot ymber^,
but suffer it not to be through dried: then take salt Sea water, and power such
a quantity on a little of it, that the same may appear wet with it, and no
more, this then heat again on hot ymbers, which speedily turns into a most
clear water, the same boil so long, until all the water be euaporated away,
and then will the Silver remain in a water potable: which has infinite
virtues given by potion. This also avails against the Leprie, helps a
saltie humor, the disseases of the Legs, a swelling of the Liver, and
sundry other grieffes, according to the skyll of the learned Physician. This
also mixed with Aqua vitae, heals all manner of fylthie wounds, happening on
the body by applying of the same on them, when the body shall be well purged.
And this is a new remedy, invented by a singular practisioner, with which
marueyles may be wrought.

Of Silver (an oil I suppose) may be gotten and made, after this manner: Take
of Silver calcyned, so much as you think necessary, the same put into
distylled vinegar, which within a few days will be dissolved, and become
blewishe: the same then euaporate gently in Balneo Mariae, until all the
vyneger be ascended, and in the bottom will a fair oil remain.

The virtues of wynes myxed after art, and those with medycines, and the manner
of using them. The.xvij. Chapter.
THe first wine here uttered, procures the Melancholicke to be merris, ^
puts away Melancholy: it helps also the Cholloricke, and such which have
infected Liver* or grief of ye Kydneys, or that can not pysse: this besides is
singular in the Quartaine, and inward burning of the body. The making of which
wine, is on this wise: take the whole Buglasse, with the leaves and roots, the
pythes of which roots take forth, of these let there be a pound, and so much
wayght of Sense* a pound of read Roseleaues, a pound of Borrage flowers* and a
pound of Buglosse flowers, all these after the beating together, put into a
Bag, and the Bag put into a vessel containing three gallons of go^d white
Must wine, it is a kind of wine so called the half of which Must wine, with
half of the said things, put together into the said vessel, and the other
half after the boiling and clean skymming, put then the whole together, and
let the same settle and clear in the vessel: of which use all the year
through, especially in the Winter, the ^pryng, and Harue^^ and yt helps all
the above said grieffes.

A syngular Cordial wine, is made of Borrage and Baulme: Which also is good
for the Melancholicke, and for the trembling of the heart* this cl^anseth the
evil blood of the body, and increases the good, it puts away from man an
evil thought, and all evil cogitacions coming to mind: This wine also serves
in the foul breaking out* and Leprosy, it makes a man merrye, and mas^tyeth
the worms in the bellye. The making of which wine, is on this wise: take a
pound of Borrage, and so much of the herb Baulme, which put into new Must,
boil together, and when the same is clear use of it, for it serves unto many
other purposes, not here mentioned.

The wine of Buglosse after the instruction of Macrobi^, is prepared and made
after this manner: Take the roots of Buglosse, which after the clean scraping,
s^iepe in good wine, until the wine has purchased the virtue of them: this
wine often used cleanses all the evil humors by vryne, and causes a good
brain, and if a person were become wholye mad, by the drincking of this wine
he should be recovered and helped th^oughlie: as the like proof was made on a
woman, who often was mad, either through ^re, or melancholy, in so much that
they were forced to byn^ (...), until she came again to her perfyte mind
and reason. And by chance a poor man coming to her door, to are his Alms,
understanding hereof, taught this remedy, through which in (...) time, she was
wholye delivered.

A laudable wine, helping the disseases of the Mylte, and heat of the Liver:
take the leaves and roots of Succorye, of Hearts ^ung, of Endyue, and
Horehounde, which boil together in a lytl^ ^uantit^e of wine, the same let
run through an Ipocras bag, and this wine pour on the herbs, letting the
wine run through two or three times; until it be clear. This wine hel^eth all
diseases within the body, as the griefs of the Liver, the Lungs, the Mylt,
and stomach: If the wine be over bitter to drink, myxe the same with other
sweet things, as Reysins, dry figs, Lycorise, and other sweet things.

A comfortable wine for all griefs of the eyes: Take eyebright, the same
infuse in new Must wine for a time: of this wine use daily, as morning and
evening, and you shall obtain a perfect sight, without pin or web, and it
recouereth besides any manner grief of the eyes, that may happen in either
old or young, where the sight is decayed. And sundry persons having not seen
a long time, through the drincking of this wine for a year together, recovered
sight: If any also use to eat every morning of the powder of this herb with a
rear egg, or with good wine every evening, shall recover sight, as above
taught: For many by using any of these, which before did read with
spectacles, could after read the smallest letters, without the occupying of
any spectacles at all, to the wonder of sundry. And there is no remedy
perfiter for the sight.

A commendable wine for memory: take an ounce of Ginger, two ^unces of long
Pepper, two ounces of Galingale, half an ounce of Cloves, and half an ounce
of Cubebae, and half an ounce of Nutmegs: these brought to powder, and tied in
a clothe, hang in a vessel covered with seven pyntes of wine, the same then
boil a little, in such manner, that no air breath forth, after the clearing,
use of this wine, not taking forth the bag: and this also is profitable for a
cold stomach.

The wine of Sage, being of great virtue, and marvelous, is made after two
ways: some put the Sage into a bag, and hang it in the vessel of wine: and
others boil the Sage in the wine, until it be sufficiently boiled, and both
ways be profitable and good: This wine is good for tooth ache, and for pain
of the gummes: it helps also any member that trembles, and any weak member
it strengthens, and puts away any evil humor in the body: this also is
good for the Palsy, and often proved for pain of the body, and drawing or
crampe of members, and sinews: this besides is good for the Lunaticke, which
at the change of the Moon lose their proper wits and reason: and to
conclude, this is profitable for pain of the stomach, and grief of the
Matrice, and all the smewie places.

The wine of Fennel commended with the seeds, for the dimnesse of sight, the
spots of the eyes, and dropsy, and the swellings like to Leprie spots,
happening to children: this also avails against evil meats, against
poisons, the Cough, and griefs of the lunges, and it multiplyeth the milk in
women's breasts: when this wine is made with ye roots, it avails against the
disease of the bladder, and purges al evil humors of the body.

The wine against the Fistula, is made on this wise: take the long and round
Aristolochia, of each two branches green, these after the steeping and
stamping in white wine, boil unto the consumption of two parts of the wine,
which strayned through a lynnen cloth and settled, drink every morning
fasting, and evening going to bed: and it helps or delivers any Fistula,
in xv. or.xx. days, so that the pacient in the mean time eat no gross
meats, nor white meats, nor other contrary, things: and on the sore also
lay plaster wise of the root of the round Aristolochia, or of the powder of
it, blowing the same into the hole, and on such wise shall the Fistula be
cured, so that it be not in the bone entered.

The wine of Rosemarie is made in like manner as the others: of which through
settled, if any takes a good draught morning and evening, it cleanses the
blood, procures a desire and appetite to meat, expels all the inner
humor^, and recouereth a great weakness: this taken with a quantity of the
electuarie of the flowers, helps the weakness of ye heart: this comfort a
moist brain, and strengthens memory: it confirms and heateth the veins
cooled, and comfort the Palsy, rubbed on the members: it cease any cold
swelling applied upon, preserves from the plague, mitigateth the hard
fetching of breath, and helps an ol^e cough: it heateth the marrowe in the
bones, helps digestion, and a cold and clammie stomach: it puts away the
swelling of the stomach, re^^^reth speech lost, makes a man bold and hardy,
and cleereth the face if it be washed with it: this daily drunk, causes a man
to look young a long time, procures a good or sweet b^eath, and cures the
Canker and Fistula, and cleanses evil and matterie ulcers. This wine of
Rosemarie, or the herb it self boiled with the flowers in wine, and a draught
at each time taken warm morning and evening, and not eating nor drinking three
hours after, does marueylouslye help the white flux, which is wont to
happen to women of an ulcer, and cures the exulceration of women's places: In
the same manner taken, it puts away the Kings evil, the hard drawing of
breath, opens the artery, causes easy spitting up, helps digestion,
cease grypings, and cleanses blood.

To make an oil incombustible, which is miraculous. The.xviij. Chapter.
TAke white Soap the best that may be gotten, the same after ye beating fine,
put into a big Retort, on which pour so much weight of Aqua vitae, vij. times
distilled over: the Retort then set into ashes, string a large receiver to it,
and very well luted in ye joint: this done, make under a soft fire in ye
beginning, and increase the fire by little and little, until all the substance
be issued forth that will come: which together shall be an oil and water, the
receiver then draw away, and separate the water from the oil, which oil is
incombustible, and miraculous in sundry matters, in the work of Alchimie, for
this greatly avails in fixing the medicine volatile, and serves well to
incorporate with all metals, and seasoneth such which be crude, and like
sweeteneth when they be eg^r: this also dissolueth al pains and swellings
caused of grosse^ cla^ (...), a manner all sorts of ^^cked vlc^r (...) in thi^
(says the author) and conceived a great delight, as to work such a mays^^r^e,
to see so many strange fumes and varieties: but a more pleasure I took in the
practice, as to see how the same auailed in every matter where it was applied:
by which I prove this to be a divine substance* and an oil worthy of eternal
memory* and this was that great secret, with which that singular Matheus the
Hungarian, did so many great maruailes in Padua: for he healed with it, the
gout, ye quartaine ague, the pain of the French disease, and the dry scab on
the head, with sundry other griefs, for which* whiles he remained in Padua, he
was highly esteemed and woondered at. And at the last, in his departure from
Padua, he revealed to me that the only medicine which he used to all the
griefs, was this oil, and none other: the making of which he fully uttered to
me at his departing (which before he would not teach any man) and the same I
have many times made, and have also seen such strange practices of it, that
here to report them, I should scarcely be believed. etc. This borrowed out of
the rational secrets of the singular Fallopius.

An other singular way in making of ye inco^bustible oil serving for the
Alchimical Art, on this wise: take of that substance drained through, of which
so^^ is made, and common oil, of each a like weight, these after the grinding
together, grind with so much weight of white so^e as the one of them, to each
pound of the said substance add one ounce of salt Alkali brought to powder,
which substance well mixed shall be as past: the same put into a retort, having a
receiver fastened to it after art, under which make a soft fire in ye beginning
and increase after the fire by little and little, until no more will distill
forth, the water the^ ^^p^rate from the oil, and the oil keep, for it is the
incombustible (...) with which they make all the Alchimical medicines to
penetra^e ^^ttalline bodies: and this it does in that the oil is fixed, and
the nature thereof is to suffer any medicine to pass away in the ^ume, and
this fixed oil so burns in the lamp, that it neue^* consumes, and it
serves to many other purposes which the author refuses to utter for sundry
causes* and the philosophers have alwais ^id th^^ oil, to then^ it should not
be known. I having thus travailed to bring this book to an end do render
thanks to ye heavenly Physician, on whom the success of all medicines
depends.

FINIS.
